site_title: Australia's biggest state hikes taxes for foreign property buyers
summary: Australia's New South Wales state has doubled property taxes for foreign buyers to 8% from 4%, aiming to curb housing affordability issues. The move follows similar surcharge hikes by other states and concerns that foreign investment has priced locals out of the market. China is the largest source of foreign investment, but its investors have been accused of contributing to housing shortages. The new tax will apply to home sales and is expected to affect Chinese investors who have dominated the property market in the past.

site_title: UE owners said to have picked Perennial for talks
summary: United Engineers Ltd's largest shareholders have chosen Perennial Real Estate Holdings Ltd for final talks to acquire the century-old Singapore property group, edging out KKR & Co and SingHaiyi Group. Perennial, led by CEO Pua Seck Guan, is seeking clarification from Singapore regulators on procedures for a simultaneous purchase of investors' holdings. The deal, if reached, would add to the US$11.6 billion of acquisitions in Singapore's real estate industry over the past 12 months. United Engineers has a market value of S$1.7 billion and owns properties including shopping centers and condominiums.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start day with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.19% in early trading on Thursday, following a broad advance across Asia. The Hang Seng Index gained 48.99 points to 25,709.64, while the benchmark Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.28% and the Shenzhen Composite Index dropped 0.55%. Investors brushed off losses on Wall Street, despite US President Trump's new threats.

site_title: US: Stocks dip as banking shares hit
summary: US stocks fell 0.1% on Wednesday, with banking shares plummeting as the Federal Reserve's "beige book" reported ebbing optimism in US companies. The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed at 21,008.65, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes fell to 2,411.80 and 6,198.52, respectively. Banking stocks dropped due to lower trading revenues, with Bank of America, JPMorgan Chase, and Goldman Sachs falling over 2%. ExxonMobil fell 0.7% after shareholders voted to adopt stricter climate change policies.

site_title: Japan launches satellite for high-precision positioning system
summary: Japan successfully launched its Michibiki No.2 satellite, a high-precision geolocation system that will complement the US-operated GPS. The satellite, which can provide positioning accuracy down to mere centimeters, is part of a constellation of seven planned satellites by 2023. Japan aims to provide a supplementary system to help overcome GPS signal interference in mountainous terrain and high buildings, supporting civilian applications such as car navigation and internet browsing.

site_title: Hot stock: United Engineers up 5% on news of interest in OCBC, Great Eastern's stakes
summary: United Engineers rose 13 Singapore cents or 4.9% to S$2.76 on Thursday after news that OCBC and Great Eastern received proposals for their combined stakes in the company and are evaluating these proposals. Nearly 1.6 million shares changed hands, making it one of the top 20 gainers on the market.

site_title: Huge bomb blast near German embassy in Kabul kills at least 80
summary: A powerful bomb exploded in Kabul, Afghanistan, near the German embassy, killing at least 80 people, wounding hundreds, and damaging embassy buildings. The blast occurred during morning rush hour and targeted civilians, with Afghan security guards also among the dead. No group claimed responsibility, but the Taliban denied involvement and condemned the attack. The blast comes as the fragile Afghan government faces mounting discontent over its inability to control the insurgency and provide security. India and Pakistan condemned the attack, with Germany announcing it will cease deporting rejected asylum seekers to Afghanistan.

site_title: Seoul orders probe into controversial anti-missile launchers
summary: South Korea's defense ministry has been ordered to investigate after intentionally omitting details about the deployment of US Terminal High Altitude Area Defence (Thaad) anti-missile launchers in a report to President Moon Jae-in's top aides. The omission was made without reporting to the new government or the public, sparking "very shocking" concerns. The Thaad system, initially deployed in March, has infuriated China, and North Korea has conducted three ballistic missile tests since Moon took office. The incident comes amid signs of easing tensions between South Korea and China.

site_title: Japan launches satellite in bid for super accurate GPS system
summary: Japan successfully launched a Michibiki No.2 satellite as part of a domestic geolocation system to boost GPS accuracy. The satellite, intended for civilian use, will cover the Asia-Oceania region and operate in tandem with the US-operated GPS system. Japan aims to launch four satellites by 2018 and seven by 2023, with applications in self-driving cars, agriculture, and construction. The system will provide more accurate navigation and overcome interference from mountainous terrain and high buildings in Japan.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars on the skids after weak China PMI survey
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars fell against the US dollar after a private survey showed a slump in China's manufacturing activity, with China's manufacturing PMI contracting in May for the first time in nearly a year. The Australian dollar dropped around half a US cent, while the New Zealand dollar slipped to US$0.7076. The euro extended its rise, scaling a one-year high of A$1.5225, as a break of A$1.5363 would target the May 2016 high of A$1.5644.

site_title: Fed survey shows modest growth with tight labour and tame prices
summary: The US economy continued to grow modestly in recent weeks, with 12 regional Fed banks reporting expansion in various sectors, including manufacturing and housing. However, consumer spending softened, and optimism waned in some districts. Unemployment hit 4.4% in April, but inflation remained tame, with the Fed's preferred gauge rising just 1.5% in the past year. Labour markets continue to tighten, with shortages across occupations, but wage growth remains modest. The Fed is expected to raise interest rates in June, with officials citing a growing tension between inflation and labour market signals.

site_title: k1 Ventures divests stake in US unit holding childcare centre assets for US$29m
summary: k1 Ventures has divested its 10.2% stake in KUE 3 LP, a US unit holding childcare centre assets, for approximately US$29 million. The deal is part of the company's strategy to monetize its investments and distribute surplus cash to shareholders. The transaction is expected to increase earnings per share and net tangible assets per share by about five cents for the financial year ending June 30, 2017.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise at the end of trading
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% to 5,738.10 at the end of trading, driven by gains in healthcare and utilities stocks, despite declines in commodity-driven and consumer stocks. CSL Ltd and Resmed Inc led healthcare gains, while AGL Energy and APA Group led utilities. Miners Rio Tinto and BHP fell, contributing to the benchmark's losses. New Zealand's benchmark also rose 0.4%.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets edge higher at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets edged higher at the open on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.3% to 7,541.14 points. The eurozone's Frankfurt DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices also gained 0.1% each. The rally was driven by gains in mining and healthcare shares, with US-EU trade talks in focus.

site_title: Trump hails deals worth 'billions' with Vietnam
summary: US President Donald Trump hailed business deals worth billions of dollars with Vietnam, including a $5.58 billion deal with General Electric and a $15 billion deal with various US firms, during his White House meeting with Prime Minister Nguyen Xuan Phuc. The deals are expected to create jobs for the US and provide high-technology products and services to Vietnam. However, trade friction remains a concern, with the US seeking to address a widening deficit of $32 billion, and Vietnam urging the US to remove inspection programs and make fair decisions on anti-dumping measures.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump talked trade with Vietnamese Prime Minister Nguyen Xuan Phuc during a White House visit on Wednesday and welcomed the signing of business deals worth billions of dollars and the jobs they would create.

site_title: Australia home prices fall in May as lending curbs start to bite
summary: Australian house prices fell 1.1% in May, marking the first decline in 17 months, as lending restrictions and interest rate hikes took effect. The decline comes amid concerns of a housing bubble, with regulators tightening curbs on lending and banks raising interest rates, especially for interest-only loans. Despite the decline, prices remain 8.3% higher than a year ago.

site_title: BOJ will not face big long-term losses when it unwinds stimulus: Harada
summary: Bank of Japan board member Yutaka Harada stated that the central bank will not face significant long-term losses when it unwinds stimulus, citing the ability to buy high-yielding government bonds and pay high interest rates on excess reserves. Harada expects inflation to accelerate as the jobless rate nears 2%, leading to higher government bond yields and a potential profit for the BOJ.

site_title: UK 'disappointed' if US pulls out of Paris climate accord
summary: The UK government expressed disappointment if the US pulls out of the Paris climate agreement, with Interior Minister Amber Rudd vowing to influence Washington to take the right step. A US withdrawal would deal a devastating blow to global efforts to combat climate change, made possible by 196 parties signing the pact 18 months ago.

site_title: Australia: Shares buoyed by defensives while Wesfarmers slides; NZ higher
summary: Australian shares rose 0.1% to 5,731.1, driven by gains in defensive and industrial stocks, while Wesfarmers slid after Morgan Stanley downgraded the retailing giant. Healthcare and utility stocks led the gains, outweighing declines in commodity-driven stocks and financials. The S&P/ASX 200 index was also up 0.1% on Wednesday.

site_title: Jerry Garcia guitar raises more than US$3m for rights group Pictures
summary: A custom-made electric guitar of Grateful Dead legend Jerry Garcia, known as Wolf, raised over $3 million at an auction to support the Southern Poverty Law Center, a leading civil rights group. The guitar, which was a constant companion of Garcia until his death in 1995, was bought by HubSpot CEO Brian Halligan for $1.932 million. The auction comes as the group voices alarm at a rise in hate crimes since Donald Trump's presidential campaign began. The guitar was previously owned by Dan Pritzker, a Deadhead philanthropist, who put it up for auction to support the center.

images.alt_text: A guitar of Grateful Dead legend Jerry Garcia on Wednesday raised more than US$3 million at an auction to support a leading civil rights group.

site_title: SoftBank invests in industrial software firm OSIsoft
summary: SoftBank Group Corp has taken a significant minority stake in OSIsoft LLC, a privately held industrial software firm, as part of a deal to buy out venture capital investors. This move aims to capitalize on the trend of industrial companies incorporating more software to cut costs and improve supply chains. Japan's Mitsui & Co will remain an investor, while SoftBank's purchase marks a notable investment in the industrial software sector.

site_title: Pound falls as poll shows Conservatives may fail to win majority
summary: The pound dropped to a five-week low after a poll suggested Theresa May's Conservative Party may fall short of a majority in the upcoming UK election, raising the spectre of a hung parliament. The currency weakened 0.5% to US$1.2791, with traders expressing skepticism over the poll's methodology. Despite the drop, some analysts are taking a cautious approach, citing the unpredictability of polls and the recent tightening of the election race.

site_title: Simon Cheong joins SIA board
summary: Singapore Airlines appoints Simon Cheong as an independent non-executive director, effective June 1, 2017. Cheong, chairman and CEO of SC Global Developments, brings over 30 years of experience in real estate, banking, and international finance. He previously worked at Citibank and Credit Suisse, and has held board positions at several institutions, including Republic Polytechnic and the Singapore Business Federation. Cheong's appointment aims to bring fresh expertise to SIA's board.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei snaps 4-day losing run on upbeat data, weaker yen
summary: Japan's Nikkei share average rose 1.1% to 19,860.03, snapping a four-day losing run, driven by upbeat domestic data and a weaker yen. Domestic companies increased capital expenditures, boosting sentiment. The yen fell 0.1% against the dollar, following a two-week high. The broader Topix and JPX-Nikkei Index 400 also gained 1.1% and 1.2% respectively.

site_title: NY Times offers buyouts in newsroom reorganisation
summary: The New York Times is offering buyouts to its newsroom employees to eliminate multiple layers of editing and focus on reporting. The move aims to shift the balance of editors to reporters, with the goal of hiring up to 100 new journalists. The newspaper is also eliminating the position of public editor and establishing a "Reader Center" to improve response to reader concerns and increase transparency. The Times reported a profit in its latest quarterly report, thanks in part to the addition of over 300,000 digital subscribers.

site_title: Panda stars take to new digs in the Netherlands
summary: Two giant pandas, Wu Wen and Xing Ya, have made their public debut at Ouwehands Dierenpark zoo in Rhenen, Netherlands, marking a 16-year dream for the zoo and Dutch officials. The pair, who arrived from China, are being housed in a specially built, $10.8 million enclosure and will stay for 15 years, with the hope of breeding and contributing to global panda conservation. The pandas' presence is part of "panda diplomacy" and will support conservation efforts in China, with the Dutch paying $1 million a year to house the pandas.

site_title: Trump's trade tirade against Germany has officials in a bind
summary: US President Donald Trump has sparked a trade dispute with Germany, criticizing the country's chronic trade surplus with the US. Trump administration officials claim Berlin's trade surplus is widening due to the weak euro, putting US exports at a disadvantage. This issue has created tension in the bilateral relationship, overshadowing other differences such as Nato and climate change. Trump's approach is seen as a reversal of the Bush administration's 2003 formula, where the US punished France, ignored Germany, and forgave Russia.

site_title: Thai May headline consumer prices dip for first time in 14 months
summary: Thailand's annual headline consumer prices unexpectedly dropped 0.04% in May, marking the first decline in 14 months. The drop was largely due to last year's high comparative figure, which included high food prices due to drought. This unexpected drop gives the central bank room to keep interest rates low to aid economic recovery.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 1.38 points lower at 1,764.490 on June 1, 2017, with 156 losers outpacing 146 gainers. Volume reached 1.755 billion lots worth RM60.7 million.

site_title: Funds under CPF Investment Scheme up average of 5.1% in Q1
summary: Singapore's CPF Investment Scheme (CPFIS) funds saw an average 5.10% increase in Q1 2017, with unit trusts rising 5.20% and ILPs 5.04%. Equities outperformed with a 6.44% gain, while bonds and money market funds lagged. Over the past year, CPFIS-included funds posted a 14.17% average return, with unit trusts and ILPs rising 15.80% and 13.16%, respectively. The three-year period saw CPFIS-included funds grow 17.11% on average, driven by equities' 20.11% gain.

site_title: Mapletree delivers record profit of S$1.41b for FY2017
summary: Mapletree Investments, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust, reported a record net profit of S$1.41 billion for fiscal 2017, a 46.5% increase from the previous year. The group's strategy of expanding globally and venturing into new asset classes has paid off, driven by strong recurring earnings, investment gains, and revaluation gains.

site_title: 50 years after Six-Day War, Israeli-Palestinian divide widens further
summary: Israelis and Palestinians mark 50 years since the Six-Day War, with the Israeli-Palestinian divide widening further. The anniversary comes as hopes for a two-state solution dwindle, and US President Donald Trump's pledge to reach a "ultimate deal" faces skepticism. Years of violence, failed negotiations, and broken promises have left both sides deeply scarred. The anniversary highlights the challenges in resolving the conflict, with the future of a peaceful resolution uncertain.

site_title: Eleventh-hour push drives STI up 6 points
summary: The Straits Times Index closed 6.03 points up at 3,210.82 on May 31, 2017, after an eleventh-hour push driven by positive data on China's factory activity growth. This marked a three-day reversal from the index's flat-to-lower trend. The positive trading sentiment was attributed to the steady pace of China's economy, signaling further stabilization.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: HK property market still at record high
summary: Hong Kong's private home prices reached a record high for the sixth consecutive month in April, with a nano-apartment costing up to $500,000. The Asian financial hub is known for being one of the least affordable places on earth. Authorities are seeking to tame the market fervour.

site_title: Moody's upgrades outlook for S'pore banking system to stable
summary: Moody's has upgraded its outlook for Singapore's banking system to stable from negative, citing improving economic fundamentals and stabilizing commodity prices. The upgrade reflects growing loan growth, strong capital and funding buffers, and a rebound in credit growth. Moody's expects the Singapore economy to grow 2.2% in 2017 and 2.5% in 2018, with asset quality weaknesses largely peaking. The stable outlook is based on five key drivers, including operating environment, asset quality and capital, and systemic support.

images.alt_text: Funding, liquidity will remain key strengths, says Moody's.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Valuetronics Holdings reported a superb FY17 with expected 10-12% growth in CE and ICE segments. However, the share price is downgraded to "neutral" with a revised target price of S$0.81 due to slower growth ahead. Singapore Myanmar Investco's FY17 results exceeded expectations, with a 211.8% revenue growth and a net loss of US$4.3 million. Noble Group's refinancing and coverage suspension are due to uncertainty over its strategic review and recent credit-rating downgrades.

site_title: Moscow and Riyadh will work to decrease oil stockpile: ministers
summary: Moscow and Riyadh agreed to decrease their oil stockpile in a meeting between OPEC and Russia, aiming to bring global inventories down to the industry's five-year average. Saudi Energy Minister Khalid al-Falih expressed confidence in reaching the target in the near future. The cooperation in oil markets is expected to last beyond the current joint output agreement, set to expire in March 2024.

site_title: Oil prices dive 3% to 3-week low; Opec crude output up
summary: Oil prices dropped 3% to a three-week low on Wednesday, with Brent crude futures falling to $50.31 a barrel. OPEC crude output rose for the first time this year, boosted by increased production from Libya and Nigeria. Despite OPEC-led production cuts, oil inventories fell, and analysts expect further declines. Brent's premium over WTI narrowed, marking its lowest in almost five weeks, as the US Energy Information Administration report is delayed due to the Memorial Day holiday.

site_title: Macau casino revenues beat expectations, hit 10-month positive streak
summary: Macau's casino revenues surged 24% in May, beating expectations, and marked a 10-month winning streak. The 23.7% growth in gaming revenue to 22.7 billion patacas ($3.92 billion) was driven by a rebound from five-year lows set in 2014 amid steady economic growth in China. The increase surpassed analysts' expectations of 15-20% growth, as wealthy gamblers returned to the territory despite a corruption crackdown.

images.alt_text: Revenues in the world's biggest casino hub of Macau jumped 24 per cent in May, beating expectations and posting a 10-month winning streak as wealthy gamblers returned to the southern Chinese territory despite a corruption crackdown.

site_title: Trump to announce decision on global climate pact soon
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to announce a decision on the global climate pact, with a source close to the matter indicating a potential US withdrawal. A US exit could deepen a rift with allies and leave the US as the world's only non-participant in the 195-nation accord, agreed upon in Paris in 2015. Trump declined to confirm whether he had made up his mind, saying, "You'll find out very soon."

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump said on Wednesday he was nearing an announcement on whether to pull out of a global pact to fight climate change and was listening to people on both sides, while a source close to the matter said Trump was preparing for a US withdrawal.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 4.87 points to 3,215.69, opening 0.15% higher on Thursday, with 135.8 million shares changing hands worth S$284.3 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 76 to 59. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and amid a global stocks rally.

site_title: M'sia's Sime Darby Q3 profit rises on plantation, car sales gains
summary: Sime Darby Bhd, Malaysia's largest palm oil planter, reported a 5.4% increase in Q3 net profit to RM 699 million, driven by higher crude palm oil prices and gains from car sales. Revenue rose to RM 12.5 billion, up from RM 10.2 billion last year. The company's motors division saw a 28.5% increase in profit, while the industrial division's contribution fell 10.9%. Sime Darby's plans to list its plantation and property units are on track, according to President and group CEO Mohd Bakke Salleh.

site_title: CNN fires comedian over decapitated Trump photo
summary: CNN fired comedian Kathy Griffin from its New Year's Eve coverage after she posted a photo of a severed, bloodied Donald Trump head, sparking outrage from the US president. Griffin's photo, which included a fake severed finger, was widely condemned. Trump called her "sick" and said her children should be ashamed. Griffin's firing came after she provoked a backlash on social media.

site_title: Secretive global group gathers in US to mull Trump era
summary: A secretive global group of 131 elites, including politicians, bankers, and business titans, gathered in Chantilly, Virginia, to discuss Donald Trump's presidency and transatlantic relations. The four-day Bilderberg meeting, which started on June 1, 2017, includes Trump supporters like Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross and billionaire tech entrepreneur Peter Thiel, alongside critics like Eric Schmidt. The agenda includes a "progress report" on the Trump administration and discussions on the future of the European Union and US-EU relations.

site_title: CBS move to own shows like 'MacGyver' pays off in overseas sales
summary: CBS Corp's decision to own more of its broadcast shows has paid off, with international sales rising to $1.5 billion in 2015 and 36% of revenue last year. The network now owns 80% of its shows, a significant increase from 10 years ago. This strategy has allowed CBS to maximize value from deals with streaming services like Netflix and drive more subscribers to its TV app. The approach has also insulated CBS from declining ad revenue, which is expected to drop 1-2% this year.

site_title: Sterling flounders but UK stock market soars
summary: The UK stock market surged despite sterling's 1-cent fall to US$1.277 due to upcoming polls, which caused the pound to reach a five-week low. The FTSE 100 traded up, defying the uncertainty. A hung Parliament prediction by YouGov contributed to the pound's decline, but the stock market ignored the uncertainty, reaching new heights.

site_title: Beijing's hand seen as yuan hits nearly 7-month high
summary: China's yuan surged to a near seven-month high on June 1, trading at 6.7800 per US dollar, amid speculation that the government was propping up the currency following Moody's credit rating downgrade. The currency has been in a slide since mid-2015, but strengthened sharply after the downgrade on May 24. The yuan's gain is seen as a response to Beijing's efforts to stabilize the currency, which has been in an extended slide due to economic growth slowdown and dollar spikes.

site_title: Politicians must do more to heed the concerns of younger voters
summary: A growing discontent among young people is manifesting as widespread protests against societal issues. Their concerns include dwindling job prospects, limited pension security, and crumbling social security systems. This sentiment is fueled by a backlash against globalization, reflected in recent elections in the US, UK, and other countries. As a result, policymakers must prioritize the concerns of younger voters to address these pressing issues and mitigate potential social unrest.

site_title: Asia: Stocks rise as yuan strengthens, oil rebounds
summary: Asian stocks rose as the yuan strengthened and oil rebounded. Japan's Topix advanced after capital spending beat estimates, while China's Shanghai Composite Index fell due to a manufacturing gauge below 50. The yuan is poised for its biggest four-day gain in nearly 12 years amid speculation of policy makers discouraging bets against the currency. Oil rebounded from a decline triggered by doubts over an Opec deal extension.

site_title: BHP board set to select new chairman in June: sources
summary: BHP's board is expected to select a new chairman in June, replacing Jac Nasser, who is retiring. The company has been searching for a replacement since October, amid pressure from US activist investor Elliott Management over its strategy. Potential candidates include internal board members Ken MacKenzie, Lindsay Maxsted, and Carolyn Hewson, as well as external candidate Andrew Liveris, a former Dow Chemical CEO. Some investors, such as the Tribeca Natural Resources Fund, have expressed concerns over the existing board's performance and are pushing for an external candidate with technical experience in the mining industry.

site_title: Trouble brewing for Opec as once costly deep-sea oil turns cheap
summary: Deep-sea oil production is becoming more viable as costs decrease, potentially challenging Opec's efforts to curb output and sustain high prices. According to Wood Mackenzie, oil from deep-sea wells can now break even at around $50 a barrel, down from $62 in the first quarter and $75 in 2014. This shift could lead to increased investment in complex and costly deep-water projects, potentially competing with Opec's oil in the market.

site_title: Clinton slams apparent US-Russia collusion against her
summary: Hillary Clinton blamed the US election loss to Donald Trump on alleged cyber attacks by Russia, stating that Moscow likely influenced the outcome of the campaign through "disinformation" and social media bots. Clinton claimed that Americans, including associates of President Trump, may have been involved in the effort. She based her claims on intelligence and counter-intel information.

site_title: Application for the two certificates needed to run for presidency opens on June 1
summary: Singapore's Presidential Elections Committee announces the application process for the two certificates needed to run in the country's next Presidential elections will open on June 1. The deadline is set for the fifth day after Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong issues the writ of election in August. Candidates must obtain a Certificate of Eligibility and a Community Certificate, and will also be required to sign a statutory declaration and a form pledging to campaign in a dignified manner. The elections are scheduled for September, with a new form of Acting President to be appointed if the President is unable to perform their duties.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: OCBC, Great Eastern evaluating proposals for United Engineers, WBL
summary: OCBC Bank and Great Eastern (GEH) are evaluating proposals to acquire United Engineers and WBL Corporation. Perennial Real Estate Holdings has been picked for final talks to buy United Engineers, according to a Bloomberg report. OCBC and GEH have stated that there is no certainty a transaction will occur and are in discussions with parties.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines plane turns back after 'bomb threat'
summary: A Malaysia Airlines flight was forced to return to Melbourne airport on May 31, 2017, after a Sri Lankan national attempted to enter the cockpit claiming he had a bomb. The passenger, identified as being intoxicated, was overpowered by the crew and later arrested by airport security. The incident was not a hijacking, but a "disruptive" incident. The plane returned safely to Melbourne airport.

site_title: SIAS asks S i2i to allay fears it can't escape watch-list
summary: Singapore investors' lobby, the Securities Investors' Association (Singapore), has asked S i2i to alleviate concerns it can't escape the Singapore Exchange's watch-list by the March 2018 deadline. S i2i's shareholders are worried due to the company's lack of major acquisition plans and growth in market capitalisation. The company has proposed a share buyback, which, if done at a meaningful level, could improve shareholder value, according to S i2i's president and CEO. S i2i needs to demonstrate a six-month average market capitalisation of over S$40 million to avoid suspension and delisting.

site_title: Stocks to watch: United Engineers, CapitaLand, k1 Ventures
summary: OCBC Bank and Great Eastern (GEH) received proposals for their combined stakes in United Engineers and WBL Corporation, with evaluations ongoing. CapitaLand agreed to buy Guozheng Center in Shanghai for 2.64 billion yuan (S$535 million). Meanwhile, Singapore stocks notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, while US stocks reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Shipwreck casts shadow over fleet of Vale iron-ore carriers
summary: A second Vale iron-ore carrier, the Stellar Queen, was delayed for repairs after a similar ship, the Stellar Daisy, mysteriously sank off the coast of Uruguay, killing 22 people. The Stellar Queen was found to have cracking on its main deck and underwent repairs in Brazil before departing on May 26. This incident follows a third vessel, the Stellar Unicorn, which also experienced a crack in April. The ships, owned by Polaris Shipping Co, are over 20-year-old dry-bulk carriers converted from crude-oil tankers, raising concerns about safety and the need for thorough examinations of these vessels.

site_title: Tennis: It's a girl! Venus lets Serena baby secret slip
summary: Serena Williams is expecting a baby girl, according to her sister Venus, who appeared to let the secret slip during an interview at the French Open in Paris. Venus jokingly mentioned that Serena will call her her "favourite aunt" and expressed a desire for the baby to be named after their other sister, Isha. While Venus did not confirm the baby's sex, the comments suggest that Serena is indeed having a baby girl.

site_title: CapitaLand buys Guozheng Centre for S$535m; divests Innov Tower
summary: CapitaLand has agreed to buy Guozheng Center in Shanghai for S$535 million, and will divest Innov Tower for S$316 million. The Guozheng Center deal translates to an investment of S$6,628 per sqm, while the Innov Tower sale yields S$7,800 per sqm. The divestment of Innov Tower is expected to generate S$85 million in net profits. Both transactions are expected to be completed in June 2017, allowing CapitaLand to redeploy capital to another income-generating asset.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Secret diplomacy not an unusual practice
summary: US President Donald Trump's son-in-law Jared Kushner met with Russian Ambassador Sergey Kislyak in December 2016 to discuss setting up a secret communications channel between Trump's foreign policy team and Kremlin officials. Critics claim this is an example of "collusion" to advance the Kremlin's interests, but it's part of a long history of secret diplomatic backchannels used by US presidents to resolve international crises. Presidents Kennedy and Nixon used similar tactics, and Kushner's actions align with US national interests, particularly in defeating ISIS.

site_title: China still treats foreign firms unfairly: EU group
summary: A survey by the European Union Chamber of Commerce in China found that European companies are pessimistic about doing business in China, with 49% saying operating conditions became more difficult in 2016, and 54% believing foreign-invested companies are treated unfairly compared to Chinese competitors. Only 15% expect regulatory obstacles to decrease, while 40% expect the situation to worsen. The survey comes ahead of EU-China talks, where market access and investment will be a focus, highlighting a gap between Beijing's rhetoric and reality.

site_title: The sun may be setting on one-party rule in Cambodia
summary: Cambodia holds local commune elections, a precursor to the July general election, with the ruling Cambodian People's Party (CPP) facing challenges from the opposition Cambodia National Rescue Party (CNRP). Prime Minister Hun Sen has warned of war if the CPP loses, but the CNRP aims to increase its vote share. The opposition party has criticized the electoral system, citing issues with voter registration and campaign finance laws. The CPP has a significant lead in local areas, but the CNRP's ambition and growing popularity suggest a shift in the country's political landscape, potentially paving the way for coalition rule.

site_title: Platts approves Indonesia's Karimun terminal in Singapore pricing
summary: S&P Global Platts has approved Indonesia's Oiltanking Karimun Terminal in Singapore pricing, starting July 3, for gasoil, jet fuel, and gasoline cargoes. This marks the first Indonesian delivery point in Platts' Singapore price assessment process. The terminal, with a 730,000 cubic meter storage capacity, aims to serve growing demand for oil products in Asia. The move is expected to offer more flexibility and improve market liquidity, with traders citing the potential for increased loading options and better price transparency.

site_title: Daughter of South Korea's 'Rasputin' returns to face questioning
summary: South Korea's daughter, Chung Yoo-Ra, returns home to face questioning by prosecutors investigating an influence-peddling scandal. Chung, 20, is accused of receiving bribes from Samsung and violating laws on foreign currency. Her mother, Choi Soon-Sil, dubbed "the female Rasputin," is on trial along with ex-president Park Geun-Hye. Chung was arrested in Denmark and extradited to South Korea, where she will face a handful of journalists and cameras. Prosecutors intend to seek a seven-year jail term for Choi and may also charge Chung with obstructing business at Ewha Womans University.

images.alt_text: Prosecutors say cash for equestrian training for Chung, who was arrested Wednesday, came from Samsung which had handed over the money in a bid to curry favour with her powerful mother.

site_title: Citigroup wins UK lawsuit over firing of currencies trader
summary: Citigroup has won a UK lawsuit against a former currencies trader, David Madaras, who was fired after confirming a client's identity in an electronic chat with a rival. A judge ruled that Madaras intentionally flouted the rules by responding to a "seller/fking a" comment, which revealed the client's name and trade price. This was despite Madaras knowing his response was inappropriate. The ruling marks a rare loss for a Citigroup FX trader, who had a clean record before being fired amid the market-manipulation scandal that cost banks $10 billion in fines.

images.alt_text: Mr Madaras is the fifth Citigroup currencies trader to sue the lender after he was fired following the market-manipulation scandal.

site_title: Hotels compete with Airbnb by banking on local experiences
summary: Hotels are competing with Airbnb by offering local experiences through partnerships with tour and activity-booking startups. Marriott International has invested in PlacePass, while Royal Caribbean Cruises introduced GoBe, an app selling land-based tours and activities. These moves aim to provide travelers with unique, memorable experiences that blend into local communities, rather than feeling like tourists. By leveraging data on frequent guests, hotels are targeting more spending per guest to stay competitive.

site_title: Nissan's rental car strategy carries risk as US sales slow
summary: Nissan's rental car strategy may be at risk as US sales slow. A consumer, Myles Arnett, reported that rental car companies like Hertz predominantly offer Nissan vehicles, with little else available. This trend may be attributed to Nissan's rental car strategy, which can be costly and may not be profitable if sales are slow. As a result, Nissan may face challenges in maintaining its rental car business, potentially impacting its overall financial performance.

site_title: US-China trade: A tale of two reports
summary: China's Ministry of Commerce released a report on economic and trade relations with the US, which agrees with the US Congressional Research Service's report on trade issues between the two countries. Both reports cite economic globalization and the transfer of manufacturing from other countries, such as Taiwan, as factors contributing to China's trade surplus and the US trade deficit. The reports also highlight the complexity of global supply chains, using Apple's iPhones as an example, and challenge the accuracy of trade data. The US and China agreed to a 100-day plan for discussion of trade issues, centered on reducing the US trade deficit with China.

site_title: Macau tycoon favours Osaka over Tokyo for casino
summary: Lawrence Ho, billionaire owner of Melco Resorts & Entertainment, favors building a casino in Osaka, Japan, over Tokyo due to the city's smaller size and potential for entertainment development. Osaka is considered a prime shopping destination and a favorite for tourists from China, offering more opportunities for growth. Melco is competing with Las Vegas Sands Corp and MGM Resorts International for Japanese licenses, with the potential to generate $25 billion annually. Ho believes Tokyo's high costs and existing infrastructure make it less suitable for an integrated casino resort.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rise; electronics, semiconductor sectors lead gains
summary: Taiwan's main stock index rose 0.3% to 10,069.01 as of 0432 GMT on Thursday, driven by gains in the electronics and semiconductor sectors. The electronics subindex climbed 0.9% and the transportation index rose 0.8%, while the financial subindex slipped 0.08%. Shares in Asustek Computer and Realtek Semiconductor Corp also increased, and the Taiwan dollar strengthened against the US dollar.

site_title: Miyoshi to place up to 45m new shares at S$0.068 each
summary: Miyoshi is issuing up to 45 million new shares at S$0.068 each, representing 9.11% of its enlarged capital, for new investments, acquisitions, and working capital. The placement price is a 9.93% discount to the volume weighted average price of S$0.0755 on May 31.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Japan's budget furniture king discounts his way to a fortune
summary: Japan's discount furniture king, Akio Nitori, has made his company, Nitori Holdings Co, the country's biggest by offering affordable prices without compromising quality. The company has expanded rapidly, posting 30 consecutive years of increased profit and expanding its sales. Nitori's unorthodox tactics, such as hiring car industry engineers to test products, have contributed to his success. The company has become the third-most valuable Japanese retailer after Seven & I Holdings and Fast Retailing Co, with Nitori's personal fortune estimated at around $3.5 billion. Nitori plans to expand into cities like Tokyo and China, aiming to reach 3,000 stores by 2032.

site_title: Google co-founder Brin building 'air yacht' to help the poor
summary: Google co-founder Sergey Brin is spending over $100 million to build the world's largest airship, a blimp with a rigid structure designed for humanitarian projects and personal use. The airship, being built at NASA's Ames Research Center, will be 650 feet long and can bypass congestion and costs of traditional transportation. Brin's project has sparked criticism, with some questioning the altruistic motives behind the project, which also allows for luxury travel.

site_title: Amazon shares hit US$1,000, likely to push higher: analysts
summary: Amazon shares briefly reached a record high of $1,001.20, marking the first time they've hit $1,000. The stock has risen 40% from last year, more than doubling the S&P 500's gain. Analysts predict further growth due to Amazon's dominance in e-commerce and cloud computing, with a $1,125 price target. The company's Prime subscription service and AWS cloud division are key drivers of its success, with Prime memberships increasing 38% and AWS expected to receive $246.8 billion in revenue this year.

site_title: Deutsche Telekom CEO claims driver's seat on T-Mobile US M&A
summary: Deutsche Telekom CEO Tim Hoettges asserts the company's position on a potential merger with T-Mobile US, stating that any decision will be made in Germany. T-Mobile US has been a key growth driver for Deutsche Telekom, with its market value more than doubling since 2015. Hoettges considers T-Mobile US his "kingmaker asset," indicating the company prefers to use it as a launchpad for growth. This stance comes as T-Mobile US considers a potential merger with Sprint, and analysts have also speculated about potential coalitions with cable companies or technology players.

site_title: US dollar wobbles on US political tension, eyes jobs data
summary: The US dollar fell to two-week lows against the yen and a one-week trough against the euro due to growing US political tension. The dollar's worst monthly performance against the euro in over a year was seen, amid mounting dysfunction in Washington and a lack of hopes for a fiscal stimulus package. Economic data showed mixed results, including a decline in pending home sales and a rise in US Midwest manufacturing activity. The Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates next month, with 86% probability, but data in the run-up to the meeting could impact this.

site_title: Why experience is at the centre of the Future of Work
summary: Singapore is investing S$2.4 billion over four years to implement strategies for the "Future of Work", focusing on training and giving employees more resources to strengthen their skills. A recent analysis by Adobe Digital Insights found that while automation and big data are key trends, employees are increasingly excited about how these technologies can make them more productive and free up time for creative work. The experience of work is at the heart of the Future of Work, with flexible work schedules, better work environments, and faster transportation also becoming increasingly important to employees.

site_title: Qatar talks tough on project stakes in Japan LNG contract negotiations
summary: Qatar Petroleum is warning Japanese companies that pushing for better terms in long-term LNG supply contracts may lead to them being squeezed out of Qatar's LNG projects. Qatar faces increasing competition from other LNG sources, and Japanese buyers are demanding lower prices and more control via shorter contracts. If Japan pushes too hard, Qatar may force Japanese companies out of their stakes in Qatar's LNG projects, potentially forcing them to sell to less creditworthy buyers in Africa and the Middle East.

site_title: Australia probes bank levy leak after shares fall
summary: Australia's corporate regulator, ASIC, is investigating a leak of details about a planned A$6.2 billion banking levy, which triggered a 2.5% sell-down in the stocks of the country's five biggest banks. The leak occurred before the official announcement on May 9, and ASIC is seeking information from Treasurer Scott Morrison's office about what individuals were aware of the plan. Police are assisting with the investigation, which ASIC chairman Greg Medcraft says is important to market integrity. The affected banks have strongly opposed the levy.

site_title: AIB in the spotlight as Ireland plans biggest London IPO of 2017
summary: The Irish government plans to sell 25% of Allied Irish Banks plc (AIB) in a share offering in London and Dublin, with terms to be set in mid-June. The sale, valued at approximately €3 billion (S$4.64 billion), aims to raise funds for the nationalized lender. The initial public offering (IPO) is seen as the country's biggest London IPO of 2017, and the government hopes it will help stabilize the bank's finances.

site_title: Government looks at piloting collaborative contracting model
summary: Singapore's National Development Minister Lawrence Wong announced plans to pilot a collaborative contracting model for public sector projects, similar to those in the US and Hong Kong. The goal is to reduce inefficiencies and duplication of effort. Currently, risks are passed down the chain from developer to consultants and then to contractors. A more collaborative approach is needed to coordinate effectively. The government is also exploring the use of digital building tools like Building Information Modelling (BIM) to facilitate collaboration and place greater emphasis on quality assessments and productivity over price.

site_title: Ascott Reit pays US$106m for NYC's DoubleTree
summary: Ascott Reit acquired the 224-unit DoubleTree by Hilton Hotel New York - Times Square South for US$106 million, increasing its Manhattan portfolio to 1,004 units. The property, located in Midtown Manhattan, is expected to boost pro forma distribution income by S$1.2 million and raise distribution per unit by 0.06 cents. The acquisition, funded by bank loans and/or perpetual securities, is expected to benefit from growing demand in the area, driven by the nearby Hudson Yards development.

site_title: British PM boycotts TV debate as election looms
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May boycotted a live TV debate just days before the June 8 general election, prompting accusations of a floundering campaign. Polls show the opposition Labour party gaining ground, with the Conservative party's lead now in single figures. A shock projection forecast that the Conservatives could lose their majority in the House of Commons, adding to concerns about May's ability to deliver on Brexit.

site_title: Process automation could be the key to productivity
summary: Singapore's economic productivity is declining, with overall productivity since 2007 (except 2010), prompting the government to explore solutions. Robotics Process Automation (RPA) is seen as a key solution, automating repetitive, rules-based tasks currently carried out by white-collar staff. RPA can free employees from mundane tasks, allowing them to focus on value-added activities, resulting in higher job satisfaction and productivity. Implementing RPA can bring significant benefits, including cost savings, improved efficiency, and enhanced financial services, particularly for smaller banks and startups.

site_title: Uber fires exec over driverless car legal battle with Waymo
summary: Uber has fired executive Anthony Levandowski, who was at the center of a legal battle with Waymo over self-driving car technology. Levandowski, who joined Uber in 2016 after working at Waymo, was accused of stealing trade secrets and patents. A US District Judge had ordered Uber to turn over materials downloaded by Levandowski before he left the company, but Uber had denied they existed. The firing comes after a judge told Uber to compel Levandowski to cooperate, and his lawyer argued that forcing him to choose between his job and constitutional rights was unfair.

images.alt_text: Uber fired Mr Levandowski, a vice-president of technology and the star engineer spearheading the company's self-driving technology, in its efforts to cooperate in its legal wrangle with Waymo.

site_title: Rising business activity bolsters Singapore bank lending in April
summary: Singapore bank lending grew 7% in April, driven by a 9.5% increase in business lending, while consumer credit growth remained sluggish at 3.6%. Lending to financial institutions, business services, and transport sectors surged, while general commerce and building construction saw smaller gains. Despite a stronger global recovery, consumer spending remains weak due to a weak job market, with economists attributing the sluggish growth to uneven and restricted economic expansion.

site_title: Uber posts US$708m loss, finance head leaves: WSJ
summary: Uber reported a first-quarter loss of $708 million, narrower than the previous quarter's $991 million loss. Revenue increased 18% to $3.4 billion. Finance head Gautam Gupta is leaving in July to join another startup. Uber is searching for a new chief operating officer to address its "bro" culture and following the firing of its self-driving unit's leader, Anthony Levandowski, after failing to comply with a court order.

site_title: Maker of Havaianas flip-flops suddenly a steal amid Brazil crisis
summary: Brazil's Alpargatas SA, maker of Havaianas flip-flops, may be sold amid a bribery scandal at parent company J&F Investimentos SA. The company has a market value of $1.72 billion and trades at 12 times its estimated earnings, compared to a median of 19 times for global peers. A sale could be beneficial for Alpargatas, which has a well-managed team and a successful Havaianas brand. Market conditions have improved since the last sale attempt, but the scandal could delay Brazil's economic rebound and impact deals.

site_title: HG Metal, BRC Asia shares jump after activist fund urges sale
summary: HG Metal and BRC Asia shares surged after activist fund Quarz Capital Asia urged HG to consider selling its 22.6% stake in BRC Asia for at least S$30 million. The fund suggested returning excess funds to shareholders, citing undervalued HG shares and structural headwinds in the trading division. As a result, HG shares jumped 28.6% and BRC Asia shares rose 18.7%.

site_title: China arrests activist probing conditions at shoe-making firms
summary: A Chinese activist, Hua Haifeng, was arrested in Jiangxi province on suspicion of using eavesdropping equipment while investigating shoe-making firms, including those producing Ivanka Trump-branded shoes. Two others are missing after checks on the companies. China Labour Watch, a New York-based advocacy group, conducted the probe. The arrests and disappearances highlight the challenges faced by human rights advocates in China.

site_title: Loyz says reviews strategic options regularly as share price climbs in active trade
summary: Loyz Energy reviews strategic options regularly due to a 5% jump in its share price, trading at S$0.020 per share. The company holds discussions with parties about possible transactions, including mergers and acquisitions. This follows a significant 101 million shares changing hands, making Loyz the most actively traded stock on the Singapore Exchange.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: MBS unveils new light and water spectacle
summary: Marina Bay Sands (MBS) unveiled a new light and water spectacle called Spectra, set to debut on Friday evening. The 15-minute show, two years in the making, features technology-enhanced visuals, lasers, and water fountains, replacing the previous Wonder Full show. Spectra showcases Singapore's cultural heritage and future as a global city, and is part of MBS's commitment to refresh its entertainment offerings. The show is produced by Imagination, an Australian creative agency, and will coincide with the second instalment of Open Stage, a music series featuring local and regional artists.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Saudi Aramco trading arm hiring staff for Singapore push -sources
summary: The trading arm of Saudi Aramco is expanding its staff in Singapore, aiming to hire 10-15 employees by year-end, following the office's opening with one person in 2015. The office will employ operational, analytical, and administrative workers, marking a significant push into the regional energy hub. This expansion is part of Saudi Aramco's growing presence in Southeast Asia, as the company seeks to diversify its operations and increase its influence in the region.

images.alt_text: The trading arm of oil giant Saudi Aramco is looking to step up hiring for its Singapore office as it pushes into the regional energy hub, three sources with knowledge of the matter said.

site_title: Android creator unveils ceramic phone, home control device
summary: Android creator Andy Rubin has unveiled two new products: the Essential Phone and the Essential Home. The phone features a nearly full-screen display, titanium sides, and a ceramic back, while the Home device is a voice-activated gadget that controls appliances and provides reminders. Rubin's company, Playground Global, plans to raise $300 million and is betting on taking on Apple and Samsung in the consumer hardware market. The phone is available for pre-order at $699, $50 more than an entry-level iPhone 7, and will be launched in the US.

site_title: Noble shares still on slippery slope; brokers quit coverage
summary: NOBLE Group's shares continued to decline despite a potential refinancing of its borrowing base facility in June, according to DBS Equity Research. The firm has hired a Chicago law firm for restructuring practice and will suspend coverage due to uncertainty over its strategic review, credit rating downgrades, and potential losses in 2018.

site_title: Europe: Shares close with 4th straight month of gains, but on uncertain note
summary: European shares closed the month with a 0.9% gain, their fourth straight monthly rise, despite uncertainty over early autumn elections in Italy and Britain. Investors locked in profits in banks and commodities-related stocks, and shifted to safer, dividend-paying blue chips. The Stoxx 600 index fell 1.4% from its 21-month high, and Italian stocks remained under pressure due to concerns over early elections and banking sector woes.

site_title: MSM's RM34m Q1 loss leans on KL to raise sugar prices again
summary: Malaysia's largest sugar refiner, MSM Malaysia Holdings Bhd, reported a RM34.6 million (S$11.2 million) loss in the first quarter due to higher raw material costs and a weakening ringgit. The company had requested a 40 sen price hike, but Domestic Trade and Consumer Minister Hamzah Zainuddin assured no further price increase, citing a dip in global raw sugar prices. With Hari Raya celebrations approaching, the government is unlikely to adjust prices, and the appreciating ringgit could be another consideration.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Sembcorp Industries announced the retirement of non-executive and non-independent director Tang Kin Fei, effective immediately. Tang, 66, took on the role on April 1 after stepping down as group president and CEO on March 31, after 30 years with the company.

site_title: Japan's factory output surges, offering hope of lasting growth
summary: Japan's factory output surged 4% in April from March, marking the strongest monthly gain in nearly six years, driven by increased production of cars and electronics. The increase offers hope of lasting growth, but slightly below economists' expectations due to rising inventories. Despite a forecasted drop in May, industrial production is expected to remain solid for the second quarter of 2017. Domestic demand for motor vehicles, particularly from Toyota Motor, contributed to the growth, while exports were hindered by the recent foreign exchange rates.

site_title: India's annual growth slows to 7.1%
summary: India's annual growth slowed to 7.1% in 2016, lower than expected but still the fastest among major economies. The slowdown follows the government's currency ban in November, which triggered massive lines outside banks. Despite this, India still outpaced China's 6.7% growth in 2016. Prime Minister Narendra Modi defended the ban as a strike against corruption, arguing it will boost revenues by discouraging tax evasion. The impact of the ban is still being assessed, with some analysts expecting a pick-up in spending in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Bank of Singapore to keep hiring in hunt for growth: CEO
summary: Bank of Singapore plans to continue hiring relationship managers and focus on serving high-net worth clients to drive growth. The bank aims to become top three in Asia for profitability and has already added 20 relationship managers in Hong Kong this year. It plans to raise its minimum client entry threshold to US$5 million in a few years, with the bar rising to US$3 million next year. The bank's assets under management have grown to US$85 billion, driven by high client investment activities. CEO Bahren Shaari aims for each banker to manage US$500 million by 2020, generating US$5 million in revenue.

site_title: STI ETF a possible springboard for starter investors
summary: A Singapore Exchange-listed ETF, SPDR STI ETF, is recommended for starter investors seeking passive investment in the Singapore stock market. The ETF tracks the Straits Times Index, which includes 30 top Singaporean stocks, providing risk diversification across business sectors and geographic terms. Over 15 years, the STI ETF has yielded a 190% return in Singapore dollar terms, beating several major indices, including Japan's Nikkei 225 Index. Investors can employ dollar-cost averaging to minimize risk, and the ETF is available in various investment plans, including regular shares savings plans.

site_title: Deutsche Bank to pay US$41m in latest fine
summary: Deutsche Bank has agreed to pay US$41 million to settle Federal Reserve allegations that its US operations failed to maintain adequate protections against money laundering. The bank's US operations fell short in complying with the Bank Secrecy Act, and regulators imposed a cease-and-desist order requiring it to address "unsafe and unsound practices." Deutsche Bank also agreed to improve controls and boost oversight of senior management. The fine is within the bank's expectations and is part of billions of dollars in fines the bank has paid in recent years.

site_title: US: Wall Street flat as oil offsets gains in tech, healthcare
summary: US stocks remained flat on Wednesday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite poised for their best monthly percentage gain since February. Gains in healthcare and technology shares were offset by a drop in oil prices, which fell over 2% to a three-week low. Analysts expect investors to seek strong economic data and progress on President Trump's pro-business policies for further gains.

site_title: Singapore notches new peak in top cities ranking
summary: Singapore has jumped two spots to rank sixth in AT Kearney's Global Cities Index 2017, its highest ever ranking since the Index's founding in 2008. The city-state topped the global ranking for "online presence" and ranked 11th in the Global Cities Outlook 2017, up from 17th in 2016. Singapore's leadership is attributed to a business-friendly environment, world-class education system, and digital connectivity, making it a clear global leader in improving residents' lives.

site_title: SGX lures tech sector, but getting firms to byte will be tough: observers
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) has unveiled a collaboration with the Singapore Info-communications Media Development Authority to woo tech startups, aiming to attract them to list on the exchange. The initiative, part of SGX's broader technology-sector strategy, involves connecting credentialled companies with industry professionals offering advice on tapping public markets. While observers see promise, they also note that consummating these partnerships will be challenging, given the dominance of New York in tech IPOs and the need to develop the strategy over time.

images.alt_text: The aggressive wooing of the technology sector by Singapore Exchange (SGX) holds promise, but consummating these partnerships will be challenging, say observers and industry stakeholders.

site_title: High-end luxury homes all the rage in Miami
summary: Miami's luxury real estate market is booming, with high-end homes and developments like the Porsche Design Tower, featuring glass-enclosed elevators that bring sports cars to residents' apartments. The city's reputation for flash and ostentatious displays of wealth continues, with developers catering to the super-rich. The market has seen a surge in foreign investment, particularly from Latin America, and experts predict it will stabilize despite recent market fluctuations. The luxury market in Miami is seen as a safe haven for secure investments, with prices adjusted to reflect more supply on the market.

site_title: Citimac up for en bloc sale by public tender
summary: Citimac, a 1.3-hectare freehold industrial site in Tai Seng, Singapore, has been put up for collective sale via a public tender exercise with a minimum price of S$430 million. The site, zoned "Business 1-White," has a potential maximum gross floor area of 489,262 square feet. The tender will close on July 21, 2017, amid rising interest in collective sales, with three en bloc transactions inked this year.

site_title: Alphabet's Nest ends product drought with revamped indoor camera
summary: Nest Labs, a unit of Alphabet Inc, has released a revamped indoor security camera called the Nest Cam IQ. The product, Nest's first redesigned indoor camera since 2014, features a new design based on its outdoor camera and LED lights on the front for recording notifications. The camera's release marks an end to a nearly 11-month product drought.

site_title: Pop-up stores gain traction as America's retail scene convulses
summary: Pop-up stores are gaining traction in the US retail scene as landlords offer short-term leases to fill vacant spaces. These short-term placements, often in dark malls, former grocery stores, or shuttered art galleries, can offer lower rents and less commitment for retailers. Landlords are receptive to these deals as a short-term tenant is better than no tenant at all, especially in areas with high vacancy rates. Brands are using pop-ups to gain quick public exposure or as a stepping-stone to permanent locations.

images.alt_text: The Broadway Market Co in New York is a pop-up with various vendors who sell handbags, jewellery and stationery.

site_title: China manufacturing down for 1st time in 11 months: Caixin
summary: China's factory activity contracted in May for the first time in 11 months, according to the Caixin Purchasing Manager's Index, which fell to 49.6 from 50.3 in April. This marks a shift from official readings that showed expansion in May. The contraction is attributed to weaker global demand, excess industrial capacity, and a debt problem, with manufacturers struggling to replenish stockpiles due to declining sales. This signals a downward trajectory for China's economy, which is transitioning from an investment-driven model to a consumer-driven one.

site_title: Nan Fung wins commercial Hong Kong site for record HK$24.6b
summary: Nan Fung Group has won a commercial site in Hong Kong's Kai Tak area for HK$24.6 billion, the highest amount ever for a commercial site sold by the government. The 177,670 square meter site has a price of HK$12,864 per square foot. This sale comes after Henderson Land Development Co outbid eight other developers earlier in May for a former car park in Central for HK$23.3 billion. The high price is attributed to the high price of the Central site sold earlier.

site_title: Exxon faces key climate change vote at meeting
summary: Exxon Mobil is set to face a key climate change vote at its meeting, where shareholders will consider a measure calling for an accounting of climate policy risk. This comes as institutional investors, who previously supported Exxon, signal a potential break from the company on climate issues. The vote is seen as a test of Exxon's stance on climate change, with some shareholders arguing that the company's assets could become economically unviable under tougher climate policies.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end the day higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index ended the day higher, closing at 1,765.87, after gaining 0.53 points. The market saw 2.73 billion lots traded, valued at RM5.17 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 501 to 437.

site_title: MCL Land tipped as top bidder for Eunosville sale
summary: MCL Land is tipped as the top bidder for the collective sale of Eunosville, with a bid price of S$920 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr). This would translate to a bid price of about S$770 million for the 376,713 sq ft site, averaging S$2.3 million per unit for owners. The tender closed on Wednesday, and the successful bidder is expected to pay a higher lease upgrading premium to the state, with the development expected to be awarded as early as Thursday.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Mapletree Investments reported a record net profit of S$1.4 billion for FY2017, a 46.5% increase from the previous year. Moody's upgraded its outlook for Singapore banks from negative to stable. Meanwhile, a Malaysian agency is set to seize RM3 billion of assets from Daim Zainuddin. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: China's ex-statistics chief jailed for life for graft
summary: China's ex-statistics chief Wang Baoan was jailed for life for accepting 153 million yuan in bribes and using his position to help others with various matters. This conviction is part of President Xi Jinping's anti-corruption campaign, which has resulted in nearly 1.2 million people being punished since 2016. Wang was also expelled from the ruling Communist Party for "superstitious activities" and "insatiably trading power for sex." The conviction marks the latest in a series of senior officials to be brought down by the campaign.

site_title: EU Commission says euro area should consider safe asset creation
summary: The European Commission proposes creating a euro area Treasury-like instrument to help lenders diversify their assets and break the link with sovereigns, potentially issuing US Treasury-like securities. The report, published on May 31, 2017, outlines options for deepening euro-area integration, including a European Monetary Fund and unified external representation. However, the proposal faces resistance from some nations, including Germany, and preparatory work is still needed. The commission invites stakeholders to express their views on the future of the European economic and monetary union.

site_title: Grande, Bieber among stars to front stage for Manchester bomb victims
summary: Ariana Grande, Justin Bieber, and Katy Perry will headline a benefit concert in Manchester, England, on June 4 to support victims of the suicide bombing at Grande's May 22 concert. The One Love Manchester concert will feature a star-studded lineup, including Miley Cyrus, Pharrell Williams, Usher, Coldplay, and One Direction's Niall Horan. Proceeds will benefit the We Love Manchester Emergency Fund, which has already raised over £5 million. Grande will offer free tickets to those who attended her Manchester show on May 22, and the concert will be broadcast live by BBC.

site_title: May market value flat after five months of steady climb
summary: Singapore's market capitalisation remained flat in May, with a 0.1% decrease to S$962.3 billion, after a five-month steady climb. However, it rose 13.7% compared to the same period last year. Financial institutions, such as OCBC, DBS, and UOB, led the gains, driven by strong quarterly results. Non-performing loans and oil and gas sectors improved, while dairy and beverage companies, such as Dairy Farm and Thai Beverage, declined due to various factors, including a slowdown in sales and mourning period.

site_title: MyRepublic said to seek financial backing for M1 deal
summary: MyRepublic Ltd, backed by billionaire Xavier Niel, is seeking a private-equity partner to finance its bid for M1 Ltd, a Singaporean wireless carrier. MyRepublic previously bid for Singapore's fourth mobile operator license last year but was unsuccessful. Warburg Pincus had expressed interest in M1 but is no longer pursuing a deal. M1's largest shareholders may decide not to sell their stakes if offers aren't satisfactory. The process is private, with no certainty of a transaction.

site_title: S'pore to host operating company for JV of big three Japanese shipping lines
summary: Singapore will host the operating company for a joint venture (JV) among Japanese shipping lines Kawasaki Kisen Kaisha, Mitsui O.S.K. Lines, and Nippon Yusen Kabushiki Kaisha, operating under the name Ocean Network Express. The holding company is planned in Japan, and the operating company will be incorporated in Singapore. Regional headquarters will be set up in Singapore, Hong Kong, London, Sao Polo, and Richmond, Virginia. The service is expected to commence on April 1, 2018, pending completion of anti-trust reviews.

site_title: BA says IT collapse came after servers damaged by power problem
summary: A power outage at a data centre near London's Heathrow airport caused a surge that damaged servers, leading to an IT failure that stranded 75,000 British Airways passengers. The airline has apologized and is seeking to limit the damage to its reputation. Hundreds of flights were canceled over the long holiday weekend. BA attributed the damage to an "overwhelming surge" after power was restored, not the initial power outage.

site_title: Trump cryptic tweet 'covfefe' trends on Twitter
summary: US President Donald Trump's tweet containing the word "covfefe" has trended on Twitter, leaving users confused about its meaning. The tweet, sent on May 31, 2017, read "Despite the constant negative press covfefe." The origin of the word remains unclear, with speculation ranging from an acronym to a secret message. Despite the confusion, the tweet sparked a significant internet reaction, with users sharing their interpretations of the mysterious word.

site_title: SIA appoints SC Global chairman as independent non-executive director
summary: SINGAPORE Airlines (SIA) has appointed Simon Cheong as an independent non-executive director, effective June 1, 2017. Cheong is chairman and CEO of SC Global Developments Pte Ltd, a luxury residential developer with 30 years of experience in real estate, banking, and international finance. His appointment brings fresh expertise to SIA's board.

images.alt_text: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has announced the appointment of Simon Cheong as an independent non-executive director to its board with effect from June 1, 2017.

site_title: HG Metal, BRC Asia shares jump after activist fund's open letter
summary: Shares of HG Metal and BRC Asia jumped 28.6% and 18.7% respectively on Wednesday after activist investment fund Quarz Capital Asia published an open letter suggesting HG Metal sell its 22.6% stake in BRC Asia, valued at over S$30 million. The fund cited unsolicited interest from multiple buyers. Following the letter, HG Metal rose to S$0.45 and BRC Asia to S$0.825.

site_title: Singapore shares close six points higher
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 6.03 points to 3,210.82, marking a 0.4% gain, on the last trading day of May. The index had also experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. Notable news included Airalo raising $220 million in funding, lifting its valuation past $1 billion, and US stocks reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: ECB calls for 'clarity' for Greece at June meeting
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is urging Greece's creditors to reach a deal on debt relief by June, citing the need for "clarity" to boost confidence and rebuild trust. The ECB's Benoit Coeure said that any relief measures would not take effect until mid-2018, but clarity on debt measures would help frontload benefits. The Eurogroup meeting on June 15 will be crucial in determining the path forward, as disagreements between the IMF and European creditors over Greek fiscal targets continue to hinder a final accord.

site_title: Two subsidiaries of China Environment lose civil suits in China
summary: China Environment's two subsidiaries, Fujian Dongyuan Environmental Protection and Anhui Dongyuan Environmental Protection, have lost civil suits in China. Fujian Dongyuan will pay 24,432 yuan and 166,576 yuan in monthly instalments, while Anhui Dongyuan will pay 817,630 yuan and 637,380 yuan. The companies also agreed to foot court costs. Additionally, Fujian Dongyuan is liable for a 55 million yuan loan and must pay within 10 days, with the option to sell off Anhui Dongyuan's assets if payment is not made.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower as oil price fall hits energy firms
summary: Tokyo shares closed lower on May 31, 2017, due to a decline in oil prices, which negatively impacted energy stocks. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 0.14% to 19,650.57, marking its fourth consecutive loss. Toyota and several major banks also declined.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end flat
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended flat on Wednesday, capping a fifth month of gains, as steady Chinese money inflows pushed the main share index to its highest in nearly 23 months. The Hang Seng index fell 0.2%, while China's manufacturing sector expanded at a solid pace in May, easing concerns of an economic slowdown. For the month, the Hang Seng rose 4.2%, and the HSCE gained 3.7%.

site_title: Market capitalisation
summary: Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a US$17 billion graft case. OCBC's incoming CEO, Tan Teck Long, is a former DBS veteran. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) will deepen cooperation on green and transition finance. Singapore stocks have notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. Grab's CGS-CIM downgraded its stock to 'hold', citing slowing earnings growth in H2. OCBC CEO Helen Wong is retiring, with Tan Teck Long as her successor. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: GlobalFoundries aims to double Japan revenue, chip away at TSMC's market lead
summary: GlobalFoundries aims to double its revenue from Japan by 2020, targeting clients in the automotive and smartphone sectors. The company, owned by Abu Dhabi's Advanced Technology Investment Co, will compete with Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC), the world's largest contract chipmaker. GlobalFoundries' Japan push comes as it boosts its global presence, including a $10 billion project in China to build a factory in Chengdu. The company plans to enter production with 7-nanometre process technology in the second quarter of 2018, aiming to claw market share from TSMC.

site_title: A handbag? For US$380k, it's yours
summary: A diamond-encrusted crocodile-skin Hermes handbag, known as the Himalaya Niloticus Crocodile Diamond Birkin 30, sold for nearly US$380,000 at a Hong Kong auction, breaking the record for the world's most expensive handbag ever sold. The rare bag, made in 2014, features diamonds, 18 carat white gold details, and is one of only one or two created each year globally. The sale beats the previous record set by an identical bag sold last year for HK$2.32 million, highlighting the growing trend of designer handbags as investment opportunities.

site_title: German unemployment hits new low in May
summary: Germany's unemployment rate hit a new historic low of 5.7% in May, according to official data, with 2.536 million people out of work. This represents a decline of 0.1 percentage points from April and is in line with analyst expectations. The labour market continues to develop favourably, with demand for labour at a high level, particularly in the construction sector. Experts attribute the boost to low interest rates from the European Central Bank.

site_title: CPF Investment Scheme funds rise 5.1% in Q1
summary: CPF Investment Scheme funds rose 5.1% in Q1, driven by equities posting a 6.44% return. For the one-year period, equities outperformed bonds, mixed-asset, and money market funds. Over the past three years, CPFIS-included funds grew 17.11% on average, led by a 20.11% gain in equities. The positive performance is attributed to the growth of CPFIS-included unit trusts and ILPs, with returns of 15.8% and 13.16% respectively over the past year.

site_title: Rocket Internet boosts startup sales, improves profitability
summary: Rocket Internet SE reported a 75% reduction in losses for several startups, including HelloFresh, Global Fashion Group, Home24, and Westwing, in the first quarter. Sales increased 45% for HelloFresh to 205 million euros. The company aims to make three of its bigger holdings break-even by the end of the year. CEO Oliver Samwer declined to comment on possible IPOs, but shares rose 0.2% to 21.40 euros. Analysts suggest a potential IPO of Delivery Hero as a short-term catalyst for Rocket's share price.

site_title: Trouble brews for Opec as expensive deep-sea oil turns cheap
summary: Deep-sea oil drilling, previously thought to be on the decline due to high costs, is showing signs of revival as producers streamline operations and prioritize drilling in core wells. According to Wood Mackenzie Ltd, the break-even price for deep-sea oil projects is expected to drop to around $50 a barrel by next year, making it more viable for investors. This could lead to increased competition with OPEC's oil, potentially exacerbating supply gaps. However, experts believe that the deep-water cost curve is coming down, narrowing the gap between deep-sea and tight oil production costs.

site_title: Global investor confidence up in May
summary: Global investor confidence rose to 102.5 in May, up 5.1 points from April, driven by improved sentiment in North America. This marks the first time investor confidence has surpassed 100 in 10 months. The Global Investor Confidence Index (ICI) has risen for the first time since August 2016, indicating a shift in market sentiment.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: National Wages Council suggests raising basic wage threshold for low-wage workers, proposes S$45-S$60 built-in wage increase
