The notes will be issued on June 6 at an issue price of 100.5% of the principal amount, with net proceeds used for general corporate purposes, including refinancing existing borrowings and capital expenditure requirements. OCBC is the sole global coordinator, lead manager, and bookrunner for the notes.

site_title: Worker demands brake Peugeot's Opel takeover
summary: German carmaker Opel has pushed back the first step in its takeover by France's Peugeot after workers raised concerns over the future of a prized research centre. Workers blocked the firm's legal reorganisation, a vital step in the merger process, citing questions over wage and job guarantees. Opel and American parent company General Motors agreed to sell Opel to Peugeot and Citroen maker PSA in March, with PSA promising to maintain existing job and wage deals. The sticking point now is the future of Opel's 7,700-worker research centre, which designs motors and new car models.

site_title: Belt and Road Initiative is the main global growth engine over next decade
summary: China's Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) aims to create regional connectivity through infrastructure development and promote global economic growth. The 65 participating countries, accounting for 65% of the world's population, 40% of global trade, and 25% of global goods and services, will benefit from the plan. China has pledged $124 billion to finance BRI projects, with the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) and other financial institutions supporting the initiative. Despite challenges and concerns, China's past success in delivering large-scale projects, such as the Three Gorges Dam and high-speed railways, suggests it can successfully implement BRI. The initiative has the potential to create jobs, stimulate growth, and increase trade, benefiting not only China but also participating countries and industries worldwide.

site_title: Steel market at risk of running afoul of price fundamentals
summary: The steel market is at risk of being driven by price fundamentals due to a global oversupply. Despite China's efforts to cut steel overcapacity, the market has seen a retreat in prices in 2017. In 2016, coking coal prices soared to $300 a tonne, driven by China's policy of reducing coal mining operation days and increasing coal imports. However, a credit stimulus by the Chinese government has spurred construction projects, increasing demand for steel, and the market's prices may be at risk of being driven by fundamentals rather than China's intervention.

site_title: Asean firms financially healthy due to low leverage, robust revenue: study
summary: ASEAN firms are in good financial health due to low leverage and strong revenue, according to a Natixis study. Thai corporates ranked the strongest, while Vietnamese firms came in last due to poor debt repayment ability and high leverage. Singapore companies ranked third, with good debt sustainability but weak growth. The study suggests that externally-exposed sectors may perform better in 2017, and that Asean firms are more exposed to domestic-oriented industries.

site_title: Trump communications chief Dubke leaving, White House says
summary: President Donald Trump's communications director, Mike Dubke, is leaving the White House after less than three months on the job. Dubke expressed his desire to leave in a statement, amid negative headlines about the president's Russia connections. Trump has grown frustrated with media coverage, tweeting that "many of the leaks coming out of the White House are fabricated lies." The White House denies a broader staff shakeup, with Kellyanne Conway stating that staff collaborations are more collaborative than reported.

site_title: Dick Lee takes over creative reins of ChildAid
summary: Dick Lee has taken over as the creative head of the annual ChildAid charity concert, set to be held on November 24 and 25 at Resorts World Sentosa. The 13th edition, themed "An Awesome, Amazing Asian Adventure," will feature four young talents traveling through Asia, showcasing musical traditions. ChildAid will search for child performers aged 19 and below, with auditions closing on June 20. The concert aims to raise funds for socially-disadvantaged children through its two charities, having previously raised over S$14 million.

images.alt_text: Dance item (above) at the ChildAid 2016 concert held at Resort World Sentosa in November.
Lee (above) says this year's ChildAid concert "will once again provide a fantastic platform to showcase our bright, young talents in a production that promises to captivate, inspire and surprise".
Dylan Tan

site_title: Slowing inflation in Germany, Spain takes pressure off ECB
summary: Germany's consumer inflation eased to 1.4% in May, below the European Central Bank's 2% target, and Spain's inflation also slowed. This suggests euro zone inflation may fall to at least 1.5% in May, easing pressure on the ECB to wind down its monetary stimulus. ECB President Mario Draghi tempered expectations for a June policy meeting, citing subdued inflation despite improving euro zone growth. The data indicates price pressures remain relatively modest in Germany, despite a booming labor market and the ECB's loose monetary policy.

site_title: China group buys into True Group; IPO on cards
summary: A Hong Kong-listed company, Tongfang Kontafarma, has acquired a 51% stake in Singapore-based fitness and wellness provider True Group for US$36.7 million, paving the way for expansion in China. True Group plans to open over 20 new clubs in China by 2019, with an initial US$5 million investment to fuel growth. The deal, announced on Tuesday, also includes a 29% stake in True's Taiwan operations. True aims to pursue an initial public offering (IPO) on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange within the next two years.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Steel giant trying hip pitch in Shibuya to woo talent
summary: Nippon Steel & Sumitomo Metal Corp, Japan's third-largest steel producer, is struggling to create a brand identity that appeals to young talent. The company's attempt at a glitzy video in Tokyo's Shibuya shopping district was met with confusion, as only two out of 10 people under 30 could correctly identify the company's abbreviation. The company's public profile has declined significantly, with only 50% of people knowing its name, down from 90% in the mid-1980s. This makes recruiting more difficult, especially in a country with a shrinking population and intense competition for young workers.

site_title: Manulife US Reit issues units to pay management fees
summary: MANULIFE US Real Estate Investment Trust issued 1.2 million units to Manufacturers Life Reinsurance Limited (MLRL) on May 30 as payment of its base management fee for the three months ended March 31. The issue price was 83.81 US cents per unit. This is the second issuance of units to MLRL this year, following a payment of 512,024 units in May. The issuance increases Manulife US Real Estate Management Pte Ltd's direct interest in the Reit to 0.197%.

site_title: Pound edges higher as May's lead in election polls stabilises
summary: The pound strengthened for the second day as fears about Theresa May's election lead were alleviated after a television interview. May's lead in polls stabilized at around 10-11 points, despite concerns that it could narrow further. A recent poll showed her party leading by 12 percentage points, which would likely result in a majority in the lower house and reduce opposition to her Brexit negotiation strategy.

site_title: ST Engineering injects another US$21.5m into pilot training unit's capital
summary: ST Engineering has invested an additional US$21.5 million into ST Aerospace Academy Pte Ltd, bringing its total investment to US$34.5 million. The move aims to further support the pilot training unit's capital.

site_title: Tat Hong narrows Q4 loss to S$29.2m on sharp cut in other operating expenses
summary: Tat Hong Holdings reported a narrower Q4 loss of S$29.2 million, or 4.24 Singapore cents per share, despite a 13% revenue decline. The company attributed the improvement to a sharp decline in other operating expenses. For the full year, Tat Hong's net loss narrowed to S$38 million. The company predicted challenging market conditions but expects tower crane rentals in China to be a bright spot. No dividend was declared.

site_title: German inflation slows more than expected in May, state data suggest
summary: German consumer inflation likely slowed to below 2% in May, according to regional data, taking pressure off the European Central Bank to end its monetary stimulus soon. The slowdown was driven by a decrease in energy costs and less sharp price increases in leisure and package holidays. Analysts predict the overall inflation rate for the euro zone will fall to 1.5% in May, supporting the ECB's decision to delay interest rate hikes until 2019, citing subdued underlying price pressures.

site_title: Second Macron minister under scrutiny after ethics claims
summary: France's European affairs minister Marielle de Sarnez has lodged a slander complaint against an MEP of the National Front party, Sophie Montel, who accused her and 18 colleagues of diverting funds. The accusations prompted an investigation into possible breach of trust. This comes after another minister, Richard Ferrand, escaped an investigation into claims of benefiting from a property deal. The scandal has embarrassed President Emmanuel Macron's government as it prepares a new law to clean up politics, with the European Parliament also facing allegations of using parliamentary assistant funds for party work.

site_title: BRC Asia says certain shareholders received unsolicited offer for firm's shares
summary: Certain substantial shareholders of steel mesh manufacturer BRC Asia Limited have received unsolicited offers for the company's shares. The discussions are preliminary and there is no certainty that they will result in a transaction. The company will make announcements when there are material developments on the matter.

site_title: Singapore stocks finish weaker, STI dragged lower by bank selling
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 9.76 points to close at 3,204.79, weighed down by bank selling in thin trading. The closure of Wall Street and Hong Kong markets contributed to the lethargy. Investors await direction from the US market, where they expect large defence and infrastructure spending, and an interest rate hike in mid-June. The STI has now lost 5 days in a row, despite a 0.4% gain on Thursday.

site_title: Nestle's Maggi cuts salt to curry favor with health-conscious
summary: Nestle is reducing salt content in Maggi noodles, soups, and seasonings by 10% by 2020, as part of its effort to offer healthier products. The company aims to cut sodium, saturated fat, and sugar across its range. This move is in line with industry trends and government demands for healthier food options, with Nestle expecting sales to increase as a result. The change will also include adding more vegetables and nutrient-rich ingredients to Maggi products.

site_title: Centurion unveils A$30m plan to build new wing at its Australia student accommodation
summary: Centurion Corporation has launched a A$30 million plan to build a new wing at RMIT Village in Melbourne, Australia. The 11-storey building will feature 160 beds, increasing the total capacity to 616 beds, a 35% rise. The enhancement includes new facilities and communal spaces, and is expected to be completed by the fourth quarter of 2018, ahead of the 2019 academic year.

site_title: JPMorgan upgrades UK stocks, cuts view on European autos
summary: JPMorgan upgraded its outlook on UK stocks, predicting they will recover from underperformance against eurozone and global peers. The strategist believes UK stocks will benefit from a weak sterling, high dividend yield, and potential softening in economic indicators. However, a Labour win in the upcoming UK election could negatively impact domestic plays and sterling. JPMorgan also cut its rating on European autos to "neutral" and shifted focus to defensive sectors like utilities and telecoms.

site_title: TeleChoice's logistics agreement with StarHub to expire on June 30
summary: TeleChoice International announced that its logistics agreement with StarHub is expiring on June 30 and will not be renewed. This contract has been in place since 2001 and only affects logistics services, not other existing contracts. The expiry is not expected to have a significant impact on the company's net tangible assets per share or earnings per share for the current financial year.

images.alt_text: Telecommunications services company TeleChoice International announced on Tuesday that its logistics agreement with StarHub is expiring on June 30 and will not be extended or renewed further.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's proportion of profitable firms decreased to 76% in 2016, down from 79% in 2015. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) imposed financial penalties on Credit Suisse and UOB for 1MDB-related transactions. Singapore Airlines introduced changes to its PPS Club programme, while CapitaLand exceeded its 2020 targets for carbon emissions and water intensity. The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) released three residential sites for sale, and JTC launched sites for sale under the industrial government land sales programme. Singapore stocks finished weaker, with the STI down 9.76 points, following bank selling.

site_title: China is behaving like a "bully" in South China Sea: McCain
summary: US Senator John McCain says China is behaving like a "bully" by militarizing islands in the South China Sea, violating international law. China claims the resource-rich sea, while the US and other countries have claims as well. The US has conducted freedom-of-navigation exercises, and allies are being urged to work together to find a peaceful solution. The comments come just before a regional security conference in Singapore, where delegates from the US and China will attend.

site_title: South Korea's Moon orders probe after missile shield surprise
summary: South Korea's President Moon Jae In ordered an investigation into the deployment of a US missile shield after discovering that four additional launchers were on South Korean soil without his knowledge. The deployment, which had been approved by his predecessor Park Geun Hye, was initially confirmed to be limited to two launchers. Moon criticized the decision as undemocratic and called for a review, seeking China's understanding on the issue. The investigation will examine how the additional launchers were deployed, who made the decision, and why the information was kept from citizens and the new government.

site_title: Europe: Shares head lower for 4th day, banks lead losses
summary: European shares fell for the fourth consecutive day, with the STOXX 600 index down 0.6% and the euro zone blue chip index down 0.7%. Banks led the decline, with Deutsche Bank cutting its rating on the sector to "underweight" and Italian banking shares falling more than 2%. The decline was also attributed to fresh political jitters and a long weekend.

site_title: Fox, Telemundo set for US$500m windfall on 2026 World Cup
summary: FIFA agreed to let Fox and Telemundo buy the 2026 World Cup television rights in a closed auction, avoiding a potential bidding war with ESPN. The networks paid $500 million for the rights, which could have been worth more if an open bidding process was held. The deal was made due to concerns over the extreme temperatures in Qatar, which led to a rescheduled 2022 World Cup. The 2026 tournament is set to return to North America for the first time in over 30 years, with an expanded field of 48 teams.

site_title: Commerzbank said to offer early retirement to 3,000 staff
summary: Commerzbank AG has sent early-retirement offers to approximately 3,000 employees, the first step in a plan to cut 9,600 jobs over four years. Eligible employees born before 1962 can receive a 30,000 euro (S$46,418.4) sweetener, equivalent to a half to a full year's pay. The bank aims to reduce staff at its corporate-client division by 2,400 employees by 2020, and reduce its Frankfurt headquarters staff from 9,840 to 7,419 through 2020.

site_title: British Airways back to normal schedule after IT crash
summary: British Airways resumed normal service after a three-day IT crash affecting 75,000 passengers. The outage caused disruptions at London Gatwick and Heathrow airports, with long queues and some travelers sleeping at airports. The airline attributed the issue to a power surge that affected communication hardware. Compensation for affected customers, including accommodation and food costs, is estimated to be up to £100 million. The incident also led to a 4.23% drop in British Airways' parent company shares. Reuniting luggage with customers continues, with many still waiting for their bags.

site_title: Vietnam digital content startup VNG plans 1st tech IPO in US
summary: Vietnamese digital content startup VNG Corp has signed a memorandum of understanding to list shares on the Nasdaq Stock Market, marking the company's first tech IPO in the US. The process could take 18-24 months and has received support from the Vietnamese government, led by Prime Minister Nguyen Xuan Phuc. VNG forecasts 2017 revenue of $180 million, with its games and chat app Zalo reaching over 230 countries and 70 million users. The company's IPO is expected to be a challenging process.

site_title: Daughter of South Korea's 'Rasputin' set to return home
summary: South Korea's daughter, Chung Yoo Ra, 20, will return home from Denmark on Wednesday after being extradited, where she was being held on questioning. Chung is the only child of Choi Soon Sil, nicknamed "Rasputin" for her influence over former President Park Geun Hye. Chung is alleged to have benefited from millions of dollars paid by Samsung to finance her lifestyle. She will be immediately put into custody upon arrival. This comes after Chung dropped her appeal against extradition and Choi reacted angrily to news of her daughter's imminent return.

site_title: What Noble Group has left in locker as it seeks to exit crisis
summary: Noble Group Ltd is seeking a strategic investor to exit a crisis, with its market value shrinking by over $1 billion this year due to a first quarter loss, risk of default, and cut credit ratings. The company is reviewing options with Morgan Stanley and Moelis & Co, considering selling its remaining businesses, including gasoline blending facilities, petroleum storage, and stakes in Australian and Mongolian coal mines. Its energy segment, accounting for 90% of total sales, includes oil liquids, gas & power, and energy coal units, with operating income from supply chains of $27 million in the first quarter.

site_title: India's monsoon arrives early to give boost to thirsty crops
summary: India's southwest monsoon has arrived slightly ahead of schedule, bringing much-needed rain to the country's parched farmland. The monsoon typically starts on June 1, but has already reached the southern state of Kerala. The early arrival is expected to boost crops, including rice, soybeans, and sugarcane, which account for 70% of the country's annual rain and 14% of the economy. The weather office had forecast a 96% chance of normal precipitation, alleviating concerns about a below-normal season due to El Nino.

site_title: Indian economy rides on consumer spending revival ahead of GST launch
summary: India's economy is experiencing a consumer spending revival ahead of the launch of a multi-rate Goods and Services Tax (GST) on July 1. The revival is driven by a busy wedding season and a heatwave boosting demand for appliances. Consumer spending, traditionally a driver of growth, took a hit after the demonetization of high-value bank notes in November. Economists expect the economy to expand by 7.1% in the January-March quarter, with some predicting growth rates as high as 7.8%. The GST is expected to reduce taxes on essential items, further boosting consumer spending.

site_title: Indonesia's inflation rate seen at 14-month high in May: poll
summary: Indonesia's inflation rate is expected to reach a 14-month high of 4.37% in May, according to a Reuters poll, driven by price pressures during the Muslim fasting month of Ramadan. This would be the highest inflation rate since March 2016. The central bank expects this year's inflation rate to be near the top of its 3-5% target range, prompting the government to delay planned price increases until after Eid al-Fitr holidays.

site_title: Novartis has assets to sell, investors wary of what it might buy
summary: Novartis is considering selling assets worth $50 billion, including its Alcon surgical devices and contact lens businesses, as well as its stake in Roche and over-the-counter drugs venture with GlaxoSmithKline. Investors are wary of the potential for the company to use the cash to make another unsuccessful megadeal, given its recent struggles with Alcon and the patent expiration of its cancer drug Gleevec. Novartis's CEO, Joe Jimenez, has said the company's focus remains on smaller transactions, but some analysts believe the company may be tempted to liquidate assets to finance acquisitions in the hot new therapy area of immuno-oncology.

images.alt_text: As Novartis considers asset sales that could raise US$50 billion, investors are worried any cash raised may give the Swiss drugmaker firepower for another unsuccessful megadeal.

site_title: China to launch cybersecurity law despite concerns
summary: China will implement its controversial cybersecurity law on Thursday despite concerns from foreign firms, which worry about its impact on their business in the world's second-largest economy. The law aims to protect China's networks and user information, following the WannaCry ransomware attack. Companies have pleaded with the government to delay the law's implementation due to unclear provisions and concerns about personal information and cloud computing. The law's implementation raises concerns about its potential impact on China's business relationships with foreign companies.

site_title: Gold hits 1-month high, geopolitical tensions support
summary: Gold prices rose to a one-month high on May 30, driven by geopolitical tensions and investor appetite for safe-haven assets. Spot gold reached $1,267.70 per ounce, with investors seeking refuge from risk amid uncertainty surrounding Britain's elections, Italy's potential early elections, and Greek debt. Analysts attribute the surge to safe-haven buying, with some predicting a potential rise to $1,276 per ounce. The move weighed on Asian stocks and kept the euro under pressure, while other precious metals, including silver and platinum, also saw gains.

site_title: Citi to sell fixed-income index unit to LSE for US$685m
summary: Citigroup Inc agreed to sell its fixed-income analytics and index business to the London Stock Exchange Group Plc for US$685 million in cash. The deal includes Citigroup's fixed-income analytics platform, The Yield Book, and indexes such as the World Government Bond Index. The business generated US$107 million of revenue in 2016 and is expected to close in the second half of the year, with LSE planning to generate US$30 million of revenue synergies and US$18 million of cost savings.

images.alt_text: Citigroup Inc agreed to sell its fixed-income analytics and index business to the London Stock Exchange Group Plc for US$685 million in cash following a strategic review of the unit.

site_title: CapitaLand exceeds 2020 targets for carbon emissions and water intensity
summary: CapitaLand has exceeded its 2020 targets for reducing carbon emissions intensity and water intensity by 26.2% and 21.8% respectively compared to 2008. The company has also avoided S$108 million in utility costs and diverted 4,700 tonnes of recyclable waste from landfills. This is part of its efforts to build a sustainable real estate developer and improve operational efficiency. Despite these investments, CapitaLand reported resilient financial results, with a total revenue of S$5.3 billion and earnings before interest and tax of S$2.4 billion.

site_title: Aussie falls for a 4th day, NZ$ near 2-month peak
summary: The Australian dollar fell for the fourth consecutive day to a near 1-1/2 week low, weakening to US$0.7424, due to continued weakness in iron ore prices. Chinese iron ore futures have declined 28% since mid-March, contributing to the decline. This is the lowest level seen since May 19.

site_title: Crowdfunded lawyer drops case over Brexit U-turn
summary: British lawyer Jolyon Maugham has dropped a Brexit-related case at the European Court of Justice due to high litigation costs and time constraints. The case, which aimed to determine if the UK could reverse Article 50, was launched after a £70,000 crowdfunding campaign in January. Maugham cited the lengthy process and high costs as reasons for discontinuing the case, stating it may not be resolved before the October 2018 Brexit deadline. The leftover funds will be used for other Brexit-related litigation or charity.

site_title: Australia shares rebound a little as financials, miners gain; NZ higher
summary: Australia's shares rose 0.16% to 5,716.30, driven by gains in mining and financial stocks, despite low trading volumes due to US, British, and Chinese market holidays. Housing data showed a 4.4% increase in April building approvals, but a 17.2% decline from last year. Financial stocks rose 0.4%, with the five largest banks gaining between 0.2% and 1%.

site_title: Tokyo: Benchmark index slips, US data in focus
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei 225 index closed flat, down 0.02%, at 19,677.85, while the broader Topix index gained 0.16%, at 1,572.67. Investors await US data, focusing on its impact on markets.

site_title: SIA introduces changes to PPS Club programme
summary: Singapore Airlines introduces changes to its PPS Club programme, effective June 1, 2017. New benefits include non-expiring KrisFlyer miles, priority access to "Saver" award redemptions, and fast-track security and immigration clearance. Members will also have access to complimentary preferred seat selection in premium classes. Additionally, the Solitaire PPS Club membership criteria will be changed to S$50,000 PPS value within a year, allowing members to qualify faster. These changes were made in response to member feedback.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Indian police to investigate US$10.8b plane order from 2005
summary: India's Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) has launched an investigation into a decade-old deal by the national carrier Air India to acquire 111 aircraft worth US$10.8 billion. The probe includes allegations of buying planes at inflated prices, leasing aircraft without consideration, and giving up profit-making routes to private airlines, causing significant losses to the carrier. The investigation was ordered by the Supreme Court in January and the CBI has registered three cases and one preliminary inquiry. The probe aims to determine the financial implications of the deal on Air India.

site_title: 'Dinosaur' Philippine jeepneys face uncertain future
summary: The Philippine government plans to phase out World War II-era jeepneys by 2020 due to pollution and safety concerns. The iconic vehicles, which have been a cultural symbol in the Philippines for decades, will be replaced with more environmentally friendly models. Drivers like Peter Dallos, who relies on the jeepney to support his family, are concerned about losing their jobs and are questioning the cost of safety training. The government aims to help owners sell old jeepneys and provide loans to buy new models, but critics argue that this may not be enough to address the impact on the micro-industry of poor drivers and owners.

site_title: JTC launches Kranji and Tuas sites for sale
summary: JTC launches two industrial sites for sale: a confirmed list site (0.80 ha) at Jalan Lam Huat zoned for Business-2 development with a 20-year tenure and a maximum permissible gross plot ratio of 2.5, and a reserve list site (0.47 ha) at Tuas South Link 3 with a 20-year tenure and a maximum permissible gross plot ratio of 1.4. The tender for the confirmed list site closes on July 25, while the reserve list site will be released for sale if there is sufficient market interest or a minimum acceptable price.

site_title: Australia: Shares end up as big banks gain
summary: Australia's shares ended 0.2% higher on Tuesday, driven by gains in the Big Four banks after the government delayed the payment of a US$4.61 billion bank tax by three months. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose to 5,717.90, reversing Monday's 0.8% drop. The Big 4 banks, including Macquarie Group, rose 1-1.5% as the government excluded some liabilities from the levy. Housing data showed April building approvals rose 4.4%, but declined 17.2% from last year, denting the banks' outlook.

site_title: Australia to strip convicted paedophiles of passports
summary: Australia has introduced new laws to strip convicted paedophiles of their passports, making it illegal for registered offenders to leave or attempt to leave the country. The legislation, set to be introduced to parliament this month, aims to prevent child-sex tourism. Almost 800 registered child sex offenders have travelled overseas from Australia in the past year, with many failing to notify police of their travel plans. The move is seen as a "world first" and is expected to deny passports to around 20,000 people who have served their sentences but are still monitored under the Australian National Child Offender Register.

site_title: Putin, Saudi Prince to meet after extending oil-supply curb deal
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin is set to meet with Saudi Arabia's Deputy Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman in Moscow, following an agreement to extend oil supply cuts for nine months. The deal, reached by Opec and its partners, aims to prop up global oil prices. Saudi Arabia delivered a cut of 600,000 barrels a day, exceeding its pledge, while Russia cut half that amount. The cooperation between Russia and Saudi Arabia has been key to the accord, despite being on opposite sides of the Syrian civil war. The deal is aimed at addressing global oversupply.

images.alt_text: Russian President Vladimir Putin is to meet with Saudi Arabia's Deputy Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman in Moscow Tuesday after the world's biggest oil exporters reached a deal to prolong supply cuts for another nine months.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open flat
summary: Tokyo shares opened flat on May 30, 2017, as investors awaited fresh clues amidst a widening scandal over possible ties between Russia and US President Donald Trump's associates. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index marginally dropped 0.04% and the Topix index edged down 0.03%.

site_title: Asia: Stocks slip, euro falls on Draghi comments
summary: Asian stocks fell, and the euro slipped, amid concerns over rising US borrowing costs. Mario Draghi's dovish comments and Fed Bank of San Francisco President John Williams' call for three interest-rate increases this year contributed to the market volatility. The yen strengthened, while the rand extended losses after President Jacob Zuma survived a bid to oust him. Investors remain cautious, awaiting the US jobs report and other economic data, which may impact interest rates and global growth.

site_title: Malaysia: Market closed today
summary: The article does not mention Malaysia's market, but rather states that Malaysia's market was closed for the Harvest Festival.

site_title: Brazil's Temer urges court to end uncertainty overshadowing growth
summary: Brazil's President Michel Temer urged the electoral court to quickly resolve a case alleging illegal funding of his 2014 campaign, citing the need to lift uncertainty overshadowing the country's economic recovery. Brazil's economy grew 0.7% in the first quarter, with the government forecasting a similar growth rate in the second quarter. Temer's approval ratings are low, and his coalition is considering whether to support him amid a graft scandal and a stalled pension reform proposal.

images.alt_text: President Michel Temer urged Brazil's top electoral court to decide quickly on a case alleging illegal funding of his 2014 campaign in order to lift political uncertainty overshadowing a recovery in Latin America's largest economy.

site_title: Kim Jong Nam murder case moves to Malaysian high court
summary: The case of Kim Jong Nam's murder has been transferred to the Malaysian High Court after a defence lawyer complained of not receiving all requested documents. Siti Aishah and Doan Thi Huong, the two women charged with killing Kim Jong Nam, face the death penalty if convicted. They claim to be unwitting pawns in a North Korean-orchestrated assassination. The case was previously deferred due to document collection issues, and the High Court is expected to notify the parties within a month.

site_title: Deal reached to avert strike at Canadian Rail
summary: Canadian National Railway Co reached a tentative agreement with the Teamsters Canada Rail Conference, averting a strike by 3,000 conductors that was set to begin Tuesday. The deal, pending ratification, would have been Canada's first strike in a decade and could have delayed grain and commodity shipments, affecting businesses such as auto manufacturers and retail importers. The agreement was reached ahead of the strike deadline and a mediator is assisting in the talks.

site_title: URA launches three residential sites for sale at Woodleigh, Serangoon, Yishun
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has launched three residential sites for sale in Singapore. The sites, located at Woodleigh Lane and Serangoon North Avenue 1, are available under the confirmed list, while the site at Yishun Avenue 9 is available for application under the reserve list. Together, the sites can potentially yield around 1,955 residential units. Tender closings are scheduled for July 11 and July 27, respectively.

site_title: Ryanair earnings gain 6% as carrier seeks more Boeing jets
summary: Ryanair reported a 6% gain in annual earnings, increasing net income to €1.32 billion (S$2.03 billion) in the 12 months ended March 31. The carrier is in talks with Boeing to add two or three more jets to its delivery schedule, aiming to capitalize on growth opportunities in Italy, Germany, Poland, and Romania. Earnings are expected to rise 8% to €1.4-1.45 billion in fiscal 2018, driven by a decline in fares due to better supply-demand balance.

site_title: Bitcoin's rapid surge raises reasons to question latest frenzy
summary: Bitcoin's price has surged over 100% in the past two months, drawing comparisons to its 2013 price quadrupling to $1,000. However, skeptics point to past crashes, such as the 2014 Mt. Gox breach and 2016 Bitfinex hack, as evidence of the cryptocurrency's unreliability. The recent surge has also raised concerns about the asset's volatility, with some analysts warning that the bitcoin community's inability to agree on upgrades to the blockchain could lead to a loss of users to alternative cryptocurrencies.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin's astronomical rally has cryptocurrency bulls feeling vindicated. Not so fast, skeptics say.

site_title: Trump has 'weakened' the West, hurt EU interests: German FM
summary: Germany's Foreign Minister Sigmar Gabriel criticized US President Donald Trump's policies, saying they have "weakened the West" and hurt European interests. Gabriel accused Trump of being "short-sighted" and said his refusal to sign the Paris climate accord poses a threat to peace in Europe. The criticism comes amid strained relations between Germany and the US, with Chancellor Angela Merkel warning that the US and Britain may no longer be reliable partners.

site_title: Update: Woods says alcohol not factor in DUI, blames medication
summary: Tiger Woods, former world number one golfer, said alcohol was not a factor in his DUI arrest on Monday, blaming an unexpected reaction to prescribed medications. Woods, who had his fourth back surgery in April, took full responsibility for his actions and apologized to his family, friends, and fans. He was booked at 7:18am and released several hours later on his own recognizance. Woods expressed surprise at the mix of medications affecting him strongly and reiterated that alcohol was not involved in the incident.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index down 4.14 points or 0.13% to 3,210.41. The top five value-traded counters were dominated by local banks, with OCBC, DBS, and UOB experiencing declines. The Monetary Authority of Singapore imposed a S$900,000 fine on UOB for anti-money laundering breaches. In contrast, Tokyo shares remained nearly unchanged, with the Nikkei 225 index opening marginally down 0.04%.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks pull back after solid rally, won edges down
summary: South Korean shares declined 0.6% on Tuesday, following a record-breaking rally this month, after investors took a breather. The Kospi index fell to 2,338.10 points, despite strong corporate earnings expectations for the April-June quarter. The won edged down 0.2% against the US dollar, amid cautious trading ahead of economic data releases, including US jobs and exports data. Market heavyweight Samsung Electronics lost 2.4%, while web portal Naver fell nearly one percent. Analysts expect the Kospi to rebound due to strong fundamentals and upcoming economic data.

site_title: Australia housing construction boom shows signs of slowing down
summary: Australia's housing construction boom is slowing down, with approvals for new projects sinking 17.2% in April. The decline follows a 10.3% drop in March, with multi-unit approvals rising 9.6% in April. Analysts predict a decline in new dwelling investment from late this year, potentially dragging on growth. The Reserve Bank of Australia had forecast continued strength in home building to offset a mining investment boom, but economists now expect slower growth, with some predicting GDP below 3% over the next two years.

site_title: Proportion of profitable firms falls in 2016: MOM
summary: The proportion of profitable firms in Singapore declined from 79% in 2015 to 76% in 2016, according to the Ministry of Manpower's Report on Wage Practices 2016. This decline was observed across major industries, with 38% of establishments not doing as well as the previous year and 21% incurring losses. Meanwhile, the proportion of employees receiving total wage increases declined from 77% to 75%. The decline in profitable firms was attributed to a moderate wage increase and a rise in establishments that did not perform well or incurred losses.

site_title: Spotify agrees to fund to settle copyright suits
summary: Spotify has agreed to fund a US$43.45 million settlement to resolve copyright lawsuits from indie songwriters Melissa Ferrick and David Lowery, who claimed the music streaming service recklessly put music online without securing mechanical rights. The settlement would compensate songwriters for lack of licensing and also pay for streams of the tracks in the future. The move is significant as it addresses concerns of insufficient payment to artists, and hundreds of thousands of songwriters may qualify for payment.

site_title: Robots may help defuse demographic time bomb in Germany, Japan
summary: Robots may help mitigate the demographic time bomb in Germany and Japan, where aging populations threaten economic growth. Moody's Investors Service suggests increased automation could compensate for labor force growth decline, benefiting these manufacturing powerhouses. Germany and Japan have a strong foundation for robotics adoption, with manufacturing exports already significant. However, emerging market countries like Hungary, the Czech Republic, and low-wage countries like India and Indonesia may face challenges as manufacturing processes shift to better-equipped production centers.

site_title: Hundreds of thousands evacuated as cyclone hits Bangladesh
summary: Cyclone Mora made landfall in Bangladesh on May 30, 2017, packing winds of up to 117 km/h, prompting authorities to evacuate over 300,000 people to cyclone shelters. The cyclone made landfall between Cox's Bazar and Chittagong, triggering a 10 weather danger alert. The severe storm caused widespread evacuations in low-lying coastal villages.

site_title: Draghi warns of blockchain risk if euro payment systems fragment
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi warned of the risk of blockchain fragmenting euro payment systems if different distributed ledger technologies become established in parallel across member states. Draghi emphasized the need for constant monitoring of potential risks associated with blockchain adoption, particularly market fragmentation. The ECB is closely watching the development of blockchain innovation to ensure its adoption does not disrupt the euro area's payment systems.

site_title: European stocks tread water as Wall Street takes day off
summary: Eurozone stock markets showed a rangebound picture on Monday, with Frankfurt's Dax index ending the day slightly higher and Paris slightly easier. Asian stocks slipped, with few solid trading cues after a North Korean missile launch, but markets still appeared solid, retaining most of the gains won over the past weeks. US stocks took the day off for Memorial Day and the Spring Bank Holiday, but held onto gains won after a six-day rally, with the Nasdaq and S&P 500 breaking Thursday's all-time highs.

site_title: Oil inches up in quiet holiday trade, focus on crude glut
summary: Oil prices rose slightly on Monday, with Brent crude futures increasing 14 cents to $52.29 per barrel. The market remains cautious due to US drilling activity and uncertainty about the effectiveness of Opec's output cuts. Trading was subdued due to public holidays in China, the US, and Britain. The market awaits the outcome of Opec's efforts to support prices and the impact of the Trump administration's tariffs on oil demand.

site_title: Google linking online and offline worlds in new ad challenge
summary: Google is testing a new ad challenge that links online ads to brick-and-mortar store purchases, allowing advertisers to measure the effectiveness of their campaigns. The tool, described as a "store sales measurement solution," uses real-world customer data and Google's AdWords service to provide a "complete view" of marketing performance. While the move aims to improve ad targeting and sales, it raises concerns about user privacy, with critics warning that it could lead to increased monitoring of individuals.

images.alt_text: Google is testing a way to tie online ads to brick-and-mortar store purchases, a move whetting marketing appetites while fueling privacy worries.

site_title: Prices of completed condos dip 0.6% in April: NUS
summary: Prices of completed private apartments and condominiums in Singapore dropped 0.6% in April, according to the National University of Singapore's flash estimates. Completed units in the non-central region saw the largest decline, 0.7%, while those in the central region fell 0.5%. Small units, however, experienced a 0.7% price increase. The overall Residential Price Index is down 0.3% this year and 2.4% compared to last year.

site_title: Japan's unemployment rate holds at two-decade low in April
summary: Japan's unemployment rate remained at a two-decade low of 2.8% in April, according to the latest data. Household spending, however, continued to slump, falling 1.4% from the previous year. The country's economy expanded for a fifth consecutive quarter, but private consumption needs to gain traction to sustain growth. Economists predict a moderate recovery in private consumption for the second quarter, but warn of a potential slowdown in growth. Japan's labor market remains tight, with a job-to-applicant ratio of 1.48.

site_title: India Tech Giant warns of Trump's 'radical shift' to hurt industry
summary: India's Tech Mahindra warns that US President Donald Trump's visa policies will damage the tech industry, citing a "radical shift" in policies that will lead to tougher application procedures and higher costs for Indian IT companies. The company reported weak earnings and its stock fell 17% as a result. Vice Chairman Vineet Nayyar stated that Trump's "America First" agenda will hurt the IT sector, prompting analysts to cut ratings and price targets for the company. This comes amid a trend of tech services companies cutting positions in India and workers debating the formation of an industrywide IT union.

site_title: British Air meltdown feeds outrage at tight-fisted airlines
summary: British Airways faced widespread outrage after a computer outage grounded its London operations, cancelling nearly 600 flights and stranding thousands of passengers. The airline's CEO, Alex Cruz, attributed the issue to damage at UK data centers, but analysts questioned the explanation. The incident highlights the airline's focus on cost-cutting measures, which critics argue have led to a decline in customer service. Estimated damages for rebooking and compensation are around $155 million, and the airline's reputation may suffer long-term consequences.

site_title: British PM candidates clash over Brexit in TV grilling
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May and Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn clashed over Brexit negotiations ahead of the June general election, with May stating she's "prepared to walk out" of negotiations for a bad deal, while Corbyn insisted on making a deal with the EU before leaving. The debate came after a televised grilling, where Corbyn was also questioned about his relationship with the IRA. Formal Brexit talks are set to start on June 19, just 11 days after the election.

site_title: Female zookeeper dies in UK tiger 'freak accident'
summary: A female zookeeper died in a "freak accident" at Hamerton Zoo Park in south-east England after a tiger entered her enclosure. The incident occurred at 11:15am on Monday, with the zoo confirming no other animals escaped. Police described it as a "serious incident" but stated there's no suspicion. A full investigation is underway, and the zoo will be closed on Tuesday. The zookeeper died at the scene, and all thoughts are with her colleagues' families.

site_title: Pyongyang fires Scud-class test missile; Tokyo protests
summary: North Korea fired a Scud-class ballistic missile off its east coast, with the projectile traveling about 450 kilometers. The test defies world pressure and sanctions, amid a series of fast-paced missile tests. This is not the first time North Korea has tested a Scud-class missile, which was originally developed by the Soviet Union. The incident has sparked Tokyo's protests, adding to the growing tensions in the region.

site_title: Macron, Putin hold 'frank' talks on Syria, Ukraine
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron held "extremely frank" talks with Russian President Vladimir Putin at Versailles palace, addressing strained ties between the two countries. Macron sought to improve relations, particularly on the conflicts in Syria and Ukraine, while Putin admitted to differences in opinion but insisted Franco-Russian ties can withstand friction. Macron called for a democratic transition in Syria and warned against the use of chemical weapons, while Putin defended hosting Macron's far-right rival Marine Le Pen and dismissed allegations of Russian hacking. The two leaders agreed to meet soon for talks on the Ukraine conflict.

site_title: UK parties struggle to convince voters ahead of election
summary: The UK is set to hold a general election on June 8, with polls indicating a substantial Conservative majority but not the landslide Theresa May had hoped for. Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn has been gaining ground, appealing to younger voters with his social equality and globalisation rhetoric. However, concerns over Corbyn's ties to Middle Eastern terrorist groups and his party's handling of social care may not sway voters. The election is also overshadowed by the ongoing recovery from the Manchester terrorist attack, which is unlikely to affect voting intentions.

site_title: Bank of Singapore now the heavyweight in NRI segment
summary: Bank of Singapore has become the leading heavyweight in the non-resident Indian (NRI) segment, following the acquisition of Barclays' Asian wealth business. The bank has doubled its assets under management from this segment over two years, with the estimated total wealth of NRI millionaires set to reach US$1.4 trillion by 2019. This expansion comes as the bank continues to grow its presence in Africa and other regions.

site_title: North Korea says ballistic missile test successful: media
summary: North Korea confirmed a successful ballistic missile test, with the projectile landing in waters near Japan. The test was carried out by leader Kim Jong-Un, defying UN sanctions warnings and US threats of military action. The missile travelled 450 km eastward, with Japan claiming it fell into its exclusive economic zone. The test triggered swift condemnation from US President Donald Trump, who described it as showing "disrespect" for neighboring China. The move further highlights North Korea's ambition to develop an intercontinental ballistic missile capable of delivering a nuclear warhead to the continental US.

site_title: MAS imposes financial penalties on Credit Suisse, UOB for 1MDB-related transactions
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has imposed financial penalties on Credit Suisse and United Overseas Bank (UOB) for their roles in 1MDB-related transactions. The banks were found to have breached anti-money laundering requirements, including weaknesses in conducting due diligence on customers and inadequate scrutiny of transactions. MAS has also issued prohibition orders against three individuals and served notice of regulatory action against three others. Financial penalties total S$1.6 million, with the banks required to appoint independent parties to assess and confirm rectification measures.

images.alt_text: It has imposed financial penalties on Credit Suisse and United Overseas Bank (UOB), as well as issued prohibition orders (POs) against three individuals and served notice of its intention to impose the same regulatory action on three others.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Metro Holdings, Changtian Plastic, StarHub
summary: Metro Holdings reported a 3.5% increase in revenue to S$33.7 million in its fourth quarter due to higher sales. Net profit rose to S$34.2 million, excluding a S$9.5 million impairment. Changtian Plastic & Chemical received a takeover offer worth S$17.2 million. StarHub announced a network upgrade to allow for faster 4G speeds, described as among the "fastest in the world."

site_title: Metro Q4 net profit up on higher revenue, but full-year earnings fall 29%
summary: Metro Holdings reported a 3.5% increase in Q4 revenue to S$33.7 million, driven by higher sales and lower general and administrative expenses. However, full-year revenue fell 15.1% to S$131.2 million and net profit declined 28.7% to S$80.7 million due to the absence of contribution from closed malls. The board recommended a final dividend of five Singapore cents per share.

images.alt_text: Metro Holdings on Tuesday reported a 3.5 per cent increase in revenue to S$33.7 million for its fourth quarter ended March 31, 2017 due to higher sales.

site_title: The e-commerce party... is everyone on the guest list?
summary: The global e-commerce industry is expected to reach $2 trillion this year, growing at a 24% year-on-year pace, with Asia accounting for 50% of the market. Consumers are embracing the convenience, choices, and promotions offered by online shopping, while brand marketers, banks, and IT companies are benefiting from the growth. The industry is also creating new business opportunities and entrepreneurial jobs, with small brands and manufacturers able to reach consumers with ease. However, traditional retailers and physical stores may struggle, with some already closing down, and investors may face challenges as the market consolidates and shareholder value erodes.

site_title: Golf: Tiger Woods charged with driving under influence
summary: Tiger Woods, a 14-time major champion, was charged with driving under the influence in Florida on May 29, 2017. He was arrested near his home in Jupiter, Florida, and booked into the Palm Beach County jail at 7:18 am. Woods was released at 10:50 am and a mugshot was posted online showing him looking unshaven. This incident adds to his struggles to revive his career.

site_title: China, Hong Kong, Taiwan: Markets closed
summary: Financial markets in Hong Kong, China, and Taiwan are closed on Tuesday due to a public holiday. In contrast, Singapore stocks continue their 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday. US stocks also reach fresh records despite ongoing trade uncertainty, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging higher. Meanwhile, Airalo raises $220 million in funding, valuing the eSIM platform at over $1 billion.

site_title: Denver sportswriter out of job after tweet about Japanese Indy 500 driver
summary: Denver sportswriter Terry Frei lost his job after tweeting that he was "uncomfortable" with a Japanese driver's victory in the Indianapolis 500 on Memorial Day weekend. Frei, who wrote about his father's experiences in World War II, sparked a firestorm of criticism for the remark, which he later apologized for. The Denver Post published a statement saying Frei was no longer an employee, without specifying whether he was fired or resigned. Japanese driver Takuma Sato, 40, said he understood the significance of his victory and expressed gratitude for the support of Japanese fans.

site_title: Three interest rate hikes this year makes sense, says key US Fed banker
summary: US Federal Reserve President John Williams says three interest rate hikes in 2017 make sense due to the strong US labor market and economy. The US unemployment rate is 4.4%, and inflation is on track to reach the Fed's 2% goal next year, indicating the economy has fully recovered from the recession. Williams aims for a "Goldilocks economy" - neither too hot nor too cold - and believes a gradual approach to interest rate normalization will benefit both the US and global economies.

site_title: Perpetual issuance in Asia ex-Japan surges amid hot bond market
summary: In Asia excluding Japan, perpetual bond issuance surged in the first half of 2017, with sales reaching US$125.7 billion, more than double the US$64.5 billion sold in the same period last year. Institutional investors, such as fund managers and insurers, are driving demand for perpetual bonds, which offer higher yields and are often unrated. Corporations are issuing perpetuals to lock in cheap funding and take advantage of long-term interest rates seen as benign. Despite concerns about rising interest rates, investors are favoring perpetual bonds due to their yield proposition and rating agency reviews.

site_title: Stephen Lee to join Temasek board from July 1
summary: Temasek Holdings, a Singapore investment firm, will appoint Stephen Lee Ching Yen as a director starting July 1. Lee currently serves as chairman of several companies, including SIA Engineering Company and NTUC Income Insurance Cooperative. This addition comes as Temasek continues to expand its board.

site_title: After the 'pivot', clarity of US policy towards Asia remains elusive
summary: US foreign policy's "pivot" to Asia, initiated by former President Barack Obama in 2011, remains unclear after the transition to the Trump administration. The Obama administration's shift in focus towards Asia was intended to counter China's growing assertiveness but was hindered by Middle East crises and domestic opposition to the Trans-Pacific Partnership. The Trump administration's ad hoc responses to Asian developments, including North Korea and China, have raised concerns about a coherent strategy. The administration's focus on the Middle East and Russia may also divert attention from Asia, leaving allies and trade partners uncertain about the future of US engagement.

site_title: US senator calls for probe into promotion of Kushner Co's deal
summary: US Senator Chuck Grassley is calling for an investigation into the promotion of Kushner Co's deal in China, citing "potentially fraudulent statements and misrepresentations" made by companies marketing the One Journal Square project. Grassley flagged his concerns to the Department of Homeland Security and Securities and Exchange Commission, citing claims made by Chinese migration agency Qiaowai and the US Immigration Fund that promised green card guarantees and safe investments. Grassley argues that these claims violate US securities laws and immigration rules, and has requested a review of the marketing efforts.

site_title: Umbrellas, basketballs join China's sharing economy
summary: China's sharing economy has expanded to include umbrellas, basketballs, and other items, with startups like Zhulegeqiu and Molisan offering rental services. The market has seen significant investment, with venture capital firms pouring in US$31 billion in 2016. However, some critics question the viability of sharing businesses, citing concerns over theft and profit margins. Despite these challenges, entrepreneurs believe the sharing economy has potential, driven by China's huge population, dense cities, and affordable mobile payment systems. The Chinese government also sees promise in sharing, estimating it will account for 10% of economic output by 2020.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: China Everbright Water secured a 42 million yuan (S$8.47 million) upgrading project for a water treatment facility in China, expected to be completed by end-2017. The company will hike water tariffs after the project's completion. Meanwhile, Old Chang Kee posted a loss of S$2.1 million for the fourth quarter, despite a 8.7% year-on-year revenue increase. Frasers Centrepoint Trust priced S$30 million of notes at 2.645% interest rate.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokers predict Japan Foods Holding will continue to expand its local outlets, stabilizing store closures, and remains relatively undervalued. Analysts also turn "positive" on the Singapore property sector, expecting a potential rebound in property prices, and raise target prices for Cambridge Industrial Trust and Ho Bee Land. Sembcorp Industries' new CEO signals a strategic review to improve growth, potentially leading to a higher valuation.

site_title: India's online bond push angers bankers and arrangers
summary: India's Securities and Exchange Board of India (Sebi) has proposed new regulations to increase transparency and price discovery in the bond market, including mandatory electronic bidding for all bond offerings, regardless of size. The proposals have sparked anger among banks and arrangers, who fear it will violate client confidentiality and drive up yields. Critics also argue that the measures could disrupt market functioning and lead to price distortions. Sebi is inviting comments on the proposals before implementing final guidelines.

site_title: Changing salary expectations and job interests among fresh grads
summary: Fresh graduates in Singapore have lowered their salary expectations due to a tight job market, with a range of S$2,000 to S$3,499 per month, down from previous years. The banking and energy industries have declined in popularity, while startups have gained popularity for their flexibility and job roles. Job seekers now prioritize factors like company background, career progression, and stability over salary, citing the economic slowdown and reduced job security in traditional sectors.

site_title: The commodities lull will pass. It's the swing of things
summary: The commodities market has experienced a significant decline in volatility, with the Bloomberg Commodity Index reaching its lowest level since November 2014. This decrease is attributed to the abundance of supply in both agricultural and energy markets, as well as the development of US shale oil, which allows the market to respond quickly to supply shocks. While this is good news for consumers, it is a challenging time for traders who rely on price gaps to make their money.

site_title: Smaller Asian firms offer best long-term potential: Schroders
summary: Schroders believes smaller Asian firms offer the best long-term investment potential, driven by structural themes such as favorable demographics, urbanization, and rising middle-class spending power. Fund manager Paul Rathband notes that smaller companies are creating value for end products and services, and have outperformed larger companies in the past 15 years. He favors family-owned businesses in India and niche players in Taiwan, while being cautious of corporate governance concerns in China. Smaller companies in Asia trade at a discount to their larger counterparts, offering investors an exciting opportunity to tap into the region's growth story.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah
Karex is now the world's largest condom manufacturer, moving on from the early days of condo making - where elderly women would test the viability of the rubber devices with chopsticks.

site_title: Moody's rating downgrade on 'shallow' evidence, says HK financial secretary
summary: Hong Kong's financial secretary, Paul Chan, claims Moody's rating downgrade was based on "shallow" evidence, citing a close economic relationship between Hong Kong and the mainland. Chan asserts that Hong Kong's financial system has policies in place to improve risk management for mainland-related loans, contradicting the downgrade.

site_title: Change management seen as greatest risk for Singapore insurers
summary: Singapore's insurance industry is most concerned about change management, according to a survey by the Centre for the Study of Financial Innovation (CSFI) and PwC. The survey, conducted in January and February 2017, found that change management is the top risk for local insurers, with industry players expressing pessimism about this year's areas of concern. The survey also highlights other risks, including cyber attacks and economic downturns, but change management is the primary concern for the industry.

site_title: Changtian Plastic receives S$17.2m takeover offer from its founders
summary: Changtian Plastic & Chemical has received a takeover offer worth S$17.2 million from its two founders, Yang Qingjin and Chen Yongfu, at S$1.30 per share cash. The offer represents a 45% premium to its last traded price and aims to delist the company. The offeror cited low trading liquidity, management flexibility, and cost savings as reasons for the bid. Trading in the counter was halted pending the announcement.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Homebuyers in HK turning to unregulated shadow lenders
summary: Hong Kong's housing market continues to pose a challenge for the territory's incoming leader, Carrie Lam, as home prices have surged 137% since 2008. Authorities have failed to curb prices despite eight rounds of mortgage tightening, leading finance companies to fill the gap. The unregulated shadow banking industry is expected to increase, spreading risk across the financial sector, and analysts warn that this could hurt confidence in the real estate market. The government's revenue from properties is estimated to have more than doubled in the fiscal year ended March 2017, making it a key concern for Lam's administration.

site_title: Slow start to the week
summary: The Singapore market started the week with a 4.87-point loss, closing at 3,214.55, due to the closure of Wall Street for Memorial Day. Banks had a mixed performance, with DBS and OCBC rising, while UOB fell marginally. Conglomerate Sembcorp Industries (SCI) rose 0.03 cents to S$3.18 on an "accumulate" recommendation with a target price of S$3.50. The Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong rose 62.36 points to 25,701.63. Analysts have turned positive on developers and real estate investment trusts, expecting catalysts from a potential rebound in property prices.

site_title: Opec ponders how to co-exist with US shale oil
summary: Opec is considering how to coexist with the US shale oil industry, which has become a significant rival in the global market. Despite Opec's efforts to cut production and boost prices, shale companies have found ways to slash costs and adapt to the market, making it difficult for Opec to hinder its growth. Opec aims to keep prices below $60 per barrel to limit shale's expansion, but some analysts believe this may not be enough to meet global demand and offset declining traditional oilfields.

site_title: Payment delays soar as EU's small businesses offer reality check
summary: A survey of 10,468 small and medium-sized European companies found that 61% report excessive payment delays, with 40% calling for tougher laws to address the issue. The European Payment Report shows that payment times have worsened, with the public sector averaging 41 days to pay its bills. This has hindered growth and investment, with firms prioritizing cash flows over growth. The survey suggests Europe is failing to meet its goal of protecting smaller companies from liquidity issues, which can lead to bankruptcy.

site_title: Hudson survey finds pay increase not enough to retain Asia staff
summary: A survey by Hudson found that a pay rise does not guarantee employee retention, with only 42% of Asian employees saying it would be enough to stay with their organization for another year. Despite a majority anticipating a base salary increase, 29% were actively seeking a new role. Professionals prioritize job opportunities over current pay, with 25% expecting a 0-5% salary increase and 45% expecting a 6-10% increase. Employers struggle to retain talent due to the need for matching the right skills and cultural fit, rather than just transactional recruitment.

site_title: Swedish art gallery satire The Square wins Palme d'Or at Cannes
summary: Swedish satire film "The Square" won the Palme d'Or at Cannes, beating out "BPM (Beats Per Minute)" for the top prize. Writer-director Ruben Ostlund's film was praised for its surrealism and humor, while Sofia Coppola took home the Best Director award for "The Beguiled". Diane Kruger won Best Actress for her performance in "In the Fade", and Joaquin Phoenix won Best Actor for his role in "You Were Never Really Here". Netflix, which had two films in competition, left empty-handed after Pedro Almodovar stated that the Palme d'Or should only be awarded to films with a theatrical release.

site_title: China Evergrande chairman gains US$10b
summary: China Evergrande chairman Hui Ka Yan's net worth has surged by at least $10 billion this year, reaching $17.2 billion, making him the sixth-richest person in China. His shares have almost tripled, closing 22.8% higher at HK$15.20. This growth is attributed to a string of buybacks and speculation on rising home sales in smaller Chinese cities. Hui's wealth gain is the second-largest in Asia this year, behind Wang Wei's 373% increase after his SF Holding went public.

site_title: Making S'pore's GST system future-proof
summary: The Singaporean government is proposing new rules to impose Goods and Services Tax (GST) on cross-border digital transactions, a move expected to widen the tax net. The "Customer Accounting" system would require customers to pay GST to the government, rather than suppliers. This is aimed at combating GST/VAT carousel fraud, which has resulted in significant revenue losses for governments globally. The proposed rules, set to take effect on Jan 1, 2018, will impact businesses that purchase high-value goods, such as mobile phones, and require them to change their processes and systems.

site_title: Sterling steadies after opinion poll pummelling
summary: Britain's pound steadied on Monday after a weekend of opinion polls showed Prime Minister Theresa May set to win the upcoming election, potentially with a narrower lead than expected. The pound inched up 0.2% in thin trade, trading at US$1.2825 and 87.13 pence per euro. The dollar remained steady, holding above last week's nadir, while the US economy showed modest growth, solidifying expectations for a rise in official interest rates next month.

site_title: China's Fosun among bidders eyeing Origin's energy assets
summary: Origin Energy, Australia's top energy retailer, is seeking bids for its smaller oil and gas assets, valued at A$2 billion, in an initial public offering (IPO) or trade sale. At least five bidders, including China's Fosun International and Beach Energy, have expressed interest. The assets, dubbed Lattice Energy, would more than double Beach's production and are valued at A$2 billion and A$2.3 billion. Origin is expected to decide on a sale or IPO after releasing full-year earnings in August.

site_title: Merkel signals new era for Europe as Trump smashes consensus
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel signaled a new era for Europe, stating that reliable relationships forged since World War II are "to some extent over" due to the US under President Donald Trump's leadership. Merkel emphasized Europe's need to plot its own course, citing Trump's comments on defense spending, climate change, and trade. The comments were seen as a "watershed" moment, highlighting a trans-Atlantic split. Merkel pledged to "fight" in Europe's interest and vowed to stand up for the EU project of "peace and freedom."

site_title: Thailand eyes Singapore's MRO sector with US$5.7b airport revamp
summary: Thailand plans a US$5.7 billion upgrade of U-Tapao International Airport to attract aircraft maintenance, repair, and overhaul (MRO) business, aiming to challenge Singapore's dominance in the sector. The project is part of a broader economic development plan, which also includes US$4.5 billion investment in high-speed rail and US$11.5 billion for new cities. The government aims to raise funds through a combination of public and private investment, despite concerns about the country's political stability and skilled workforce shortage.

site_title: Bank Indonesia sees 5.4% growth this year as too optimistic
summary: Bank Indonesia's senior deputy governor, Mirza Adityaswara, says the country's 5.4% economic growth this year is too optimistic and the nation should aim for higher credit ratings to catch up with South-east Asian peers. Indonesia's credit rating has improved to investment grade, but the economy still needs to diversify into non-commodity exports and strengthen tourism to reach its 7% growth target. The central bank aims to maintain prudentiality in managing inflation and the current account deficit.

site_title: Land of the rising sum: Japan investors just wait
summary: Japan's investors are holding off on reinvesting proceeds from sold bonds, leading to a growing cash pile. Excess reserves at the Bank of Japan reached a 13-month high in April, with a redemption of government bonds in June likely to add to this cash. Despite abundant cash, investors remain cautious due to geopolitical risks and US political turmoil. They are instead focusing on Japanese government bonds, with "super-long" JGBs of 15-20 years maturity being the preferred choice. This cautious approach may lead to a slow increase in purchases, with investors waiting for the BOJ to reduce bond purchases and lift yields.

site_title: Draghi says euro area still needs extraordinary ECB support
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi stated that the euro area still requires exceptional monetary policy support to stabilize inflation, despite the economy's accelerating growth. Domestic cost pressures, particularly wages, are insufficient to achieve a durable inflation convergence. The ECB may maintain its extraordinary support, including forward guidance, to address these concerns.

site_title: US pullout won't sound death knell for Paris climate deal
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to decide whether to maintain US support for the 2015 Paris climate change deal. Despite the potential consequences of withdrawal, the agreement's flexible architecture and global support from countries like China and the EU could help it withstand US departure. The US has been lobbied by fellow G-7 leaders to maintain support, but the administration is divided, with some members favoring withdrawal. A potential third pathway, allowing the US to remain in the Paris framework while re-examining objectives, could keep options open for Trump.

site_title: Yao Capital seeks US$250m for first US dollar fund
summary: Yao Capital, a Chinese private equity firm co-founded by former NBA star Yao Ming, aims to raise US$250 million for its first US dollar fund to invest in overseas sports assets relevant to the Chinese market. The firm, which focuses on sports-related products, plans to launch the fund this year and will make investments in Europe, the US, and China, with targets linked to the Chinese market. The decision to raise a dollar fund comes after Beijing's capital controls made it tougher to do overseas deals.

site_title: No coffee, but all the data you can drink at the Amazon bookstore
summary: Amazon has opened a physical bookstore in Manhattan, stocking 3,000 of its most popular data-tracked titles. The move comes despite criticism of the company's impact on independent bookstores. The store offers a retro shopping experience, with customers able to browse and purchase books over the counter. The opening was met with a crowd waiting outside, sparking debate about Amazon's influence in the publishing industry.

site_title: US might ban laptops from cabins on all flights into and out of the country
summary: The US may ban laptops from aircraft cabins on all flights into and out of the country as part of enhanced airline security measures. Homeland Security Secretary John Kelly stated that the move aims to combat a "sophisticated threat" and is part of a broader effort to tighten security. The ban, which has not been finalized, would follow existing restrictions on large electronic devices on flights from select airports. Airlines are concerned about potential customer demand, but most are willing to comply with the new regulations.

site_title: BHP exploring options for controversial US shale unit, CEO tells investors
summary: BHP Billiton CEO Andrew Mackenzie is exploring options for the company's US shale unit, amid pressure from activist investor Elliott Management Corp. The unit, worth around $6.3 billion, has been criticized for its performance, with Elliott claiming it has destroyed $31 billion in value. BHP is considering selling parts of the onshore portfolio, with the company open to "maximum value extraction" from the business. Elliott wants a spin-off of all US oil assets, while BHP is reviewing its shale operations to address investor concerns.

site_title: Impeachment risks damaging integrity of US ballot
summary: US President Donald Trump's impeachment risks damaging the integrity of the US ballot, undermining the country's democratic system. The article highlights the erosion of bipartisan loyalty and the willingness to question election results, which is a hallmark of a successful democracy. The author notes that impeachment should only be used for serious wrongdoing, with overwhelming evidence, and not as a corrective measure. With Trump's presidency marked by controversy, the author warns that using impeachment as a solution could lead to further polarization and destabilization of the US political system.

site_title: Young men in an old man's trade
summary: The Golden Duck, a Singaporean snack startup, has made a significant impact in the e-commerce scene despite having only two products. Co-founders Chris Hwang and Jonathan Shen attribute their success to spotting upcoming trends and focusing on consumer experience. The company, which started with a capital of S$30,000, has grown rapidly and now has 25 full-time employees. Despite facing challenges, The Golden Duck aims to expand its product line and become a household name, particularly in Asia and internationally, to shake up the food and beverage industry in the e-commerce scene.

images.alt_text: Co-founders Mr Shen (left) and Mr Hwang; naming the brand The Golden Duck was a balancing act between preserving the culture and nostalgia surrounding salted eggs and appealing to the millennial audience.

site_title: Lenovo in big push upmarket as it seeks to revive flagging mobile business
summary: Lenovo is shifting its focus to mature markets to revive its struggling smartphone business. The company, which acquired Motorola three years ago, aims to prioritize brands and innovative products in markets with less fierce competition, such as Samsung and LG. Lenovo plans to have two teams catering to mature and emerging markets with different product lines. The company has seen success in Brazil and India, and chairman Yang Yuanqing aims to meet its goal of turning around the mobile business by the second half of the fiscal year.

images.alt_text: "Our strategy is to prioritise mature markets... which need brands and innovative products," said Mr Yang.

site_title: What is carousel fraud?
summary: GST carousel fraud is a form of missing trader fraud, where goods are imported, sold to a domestic buyer with GST collected, and then the seller disappears without paying the tax to authorities. The goods are then re-exported through a series of businesses, with the last party claiming a GST refund for the goods purchased to be exported. This creates a "carousel" system, allowing the syndicate to continually re-export and re-import the same goods, evading tax payments.

site_title: HK cooling measures fail to deter throngs at property sales
summary: Thousands of buyers in Hong Kong lined up at luxury property sales, despite government cooling measures, indicating no progress in calming the red-hot market. Record-high prices continue, with existing home prices advancing 23% in the past year. Developers sold 8,616 homes in the first five months, more than since new rules were introduced in 2013. Prices of additional units sold by Cheung Kong and K&K Property rose by about 2%. The Hang Seng Properties Index of developers rose 0.8% on Monday, up more than 20% this year.

site_title: Thai central bank chief says worried about strong baht, fund inflows
summary: Thailand's central bank chief, Veerathai Santiprabhob, expressed concerns over the strong baht and short-term capital inflows, citing a 22-month high against the dollar. The baht's appreciation, he said, was driven by incorrect interpretations of the central bank's monetary policy statement, which stated it was unconcerned about the baht's strength. The central bank is ready to act on excessive baht movements with available instruments.

site_title: StarHub says its network upgrade will offer one of fastest speeds globally for 4G
summary: StarHub is set to roll out a network upgrade in Singapore, offering one of the fastest 4G speeds globally by July. The upgrade will use 2.5 GHz LTE TDD technology, increasing network capacity and throughput in congested areas such as the CBD and Changi airport.
