The Straits Times Index has gained 3 points in the previous week, but investors will be cautious due to concerns over the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hike and the ongoing Trump-Russia investigation. Additionally, Brexit anxieties and the UK's snap elections may impact equity markets. Despite this, Singapore's Straits Times Index has outperformed regional counterparts, with a 14.1% year-to-date return.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: China moves to stabilise currency, retreating from effort to ease control
summary: China has retreated from efforts to ease control over its currency, the renminbi, after officials said they are "considering" a change in procedures that would reinforce control. This move aims to bring short-term stability to the financial system, which has been under renewed focus following Moody's downgrade of China's credit rating. Analysts on Wall Street disagree on the degree of the currency's weakness, with some suggesting it should be slightly weaker. The decision effectively reverses China's earlier attempt to loosen its grip on the renminbi.

site_title: Trump's son-in-law sought secret line to Moscow: report
summary: US President Donald Trump's son-in-law Jared Kushner proposed a secret, bug-proof communications line with the Kremlin in December 2016, according to a Washington Post report. Kushner suggested using Russian diplomatic facilities in the US to protect the channel, which was discussed with Russian Ambassador Sergei Kislyak and national security adviser Michael Flynn. The proposal was made at Trump Tower and was met with surprise from Kislyak, who passed it on to the Kremlin. The White House has not commented on the report, which raises questions about the Trump campaign's relationship with Russia and Kushner's role in the matter.

site_title: Two Chinese fighters intercept US plane in South China Sea
summary: The US Navy's P-3 surveillance plane was intercepted by two Chinese J-10 fighters in the South China Sea on May 24, 2017, deemed "unsafe and unprofessional" by the US aircrew. The incident occurred amid a "freedom of navigation" exercise by a US destroyer in disputed waters. The Pentagon expressed concerns through the US government, while the US Navy was able to continue operations unimpeded. The incident occurred ahead of a major regional security summit in Singapore.

images.alt_text: The Pentagon on Friday said it was concerned by an "unsafe and unprofessional" encounter between two Chinese fighters and a US surveillance plane over the South China Sea.

site_title: Trump working to understand EU view on climate, Cohn says
summary: US President Donald Trump is working to understand the European view on climate change, according to his chief economic adviser Gary Cohn. Following the Group of Seven meeting in Sicily, Italy, Cohn stated that Trump "feels much more knowledgeable on the topic today" and is trying to "understand the European position." This comes as European leaders push Trump to remain in the landmark Paris agreement on global warming, which Trump had previously threatened to withdraw from.

site_title: India opens its longest bridge near China border
summary: India has opened its longest bridge, a 9.1km Dhola-Sadiya bridge, near the border with China, marking a strategic move to bolster its defenses. The bridge was inaugurated by Prime Minister Narendra Modi to improve infrastructure in the isolated region, linking Assam and Arunachal Pradesh states. The project aims to enhance connectivity and support the weight of a 60 tonne tank, while also facilitating the transportation of crops and herbs to markets. Experts say the US$318 million project will consolidate India's defenses in the region, countering China's influence.

site_title: The magic of the Masters
summary: The Masters, a prestigious golf tournament, has been described as an "experience of a lifetime" by attendees, including Lyn Sen and C. S. Kong, who shared their unique experiences at the event. The article highlights the emotional and memorable aspects of the Masters, with one attendee having played in her 62nd Masters at Augusta. The article does not delve into the specifics of the tournament itself but instead focuses on the personal and emotional connections made by those who attended.

site_title: Japan's trade policy at odds with business preferences, survey shows
summary: A survey by the Japan External Trade Organization (Jetro) found that 50% of Japanese firms favor China as their most preferred export destination, despite Japan's push for the China-excluding Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP). This contradicts Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's efforts to promote the TPP. The US is the second most favored destination, with 43% of respondents choosing it. The survey's findings highlight the disconnect between Japan's trade policy and business preferences.

site_title: China arrests Taiwanese activist for "subversion"
summary: China has arrested Lee Ming-che, a 42-year-old Taiwanese rights activist, on suspicion of subverting state power. He was detained after entering the Chinese city of Zhuhai from Macau in March and reportedly "confessed" during interrogation. The arrest was announced by China's state news agency Xinhua. Taiwan's government had reported Lee's unreachability since March 19.

site_title: China considers changing yuan-fixing formula to curb volatility
summary: China is considering changes to its yuan-fixing formula to curb volatility, potentially undermining market forces. The new system will include a "counter-cyclical factor" to give authorities more control over the fixing, reducing the influence of market pricing. This move is seen as a step back from President Xi Jinping's 2013 pledge to give markets a central role, and could reduce exchange rate volatility while limiting the yuan's potential to float freely.

site_title: G7 demands internet giants crack down on extremist content
summary: The G7 nations have demanded internet giants crack down on extremist content, following the Manchester attack that killed 22 people. British Prime Minister Theresa May called for increased efforts by internet service providers and social media companies to address terrorist content. The G7 countries also vowed to track down and prosecute foreign fighters returning from conflicts like Syria, and to improve intelligence-sharing and border security methods. They also urged industry to develop and share new technology to detect content promoting incitement to violence.

site_title: US military to test anti-ICBM system
summary: The US military will conduct a landmark test of its Ground-Based Midcourse Defense (GMD) system, aimed at intercepting an intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM) for the first time. The test, scheduled for Tuesday, will check the system's performance against a mock-up of an ICBM fired from the Marshall Islands. The system, which has had a checkered record in previous tests, will use globally deployed sensors to detect and track the missile, and deploy an "Exo-atmospheric Kill Vehicle" to destroy it. A successful test would prove the US has an effective ground-based defence against ICBMs.

site_title: April factory output beats forecasts with 6.7% growth; focus now on weaker clusters
summary: Singapore's factory output in April grew 6.7% year-on-year, beating forecasts, but economists warn that the electronics cluster's expansion is expected to slow down. The electronics sector, which drove growth, increased by 48% year-on-year, while semiconductors expanded 69.1%. Weaker clusters, including transport engineering and biomedical manufacturing, continue to contract. Economists expect the tech cycle to mature, with some predicting a decline in electronics output and a shift towards broader economic growth.

site_title: Oil rebounds but ends week lower as Opec cuts disappoint
summary: Oil prices rebounded 1% on Friday, but ended the week 3% lower after OPEC's decision to extend production cuts fell short of investor expectations. Brent crude rose 69 cents to $52.15 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude gained 90 cents to $49.80 a barrel. The decision led to a 5% drop in oil prices before the cut, as investors had anticipated more aggressive output cuts. Despite this, OPEC and other producers expressed confidence that the plan would bring down crude stocks to their five-year average.

site_title: My favourite book
summary: A 2008 book "The Story of Sushi" by Trevor Corson is highlighted, exploring the history of sushi from a cheap dish to its current high demand.

site_title: Ex-NOL head Ng Yat Chung to replace Alan Chan as SPH CEO
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) announced on May 26, 2017, that former Neptune Orient Lines (NOL) CEO Ng Yat Chung will replace Alan Chan as CEO on September 1, 2017. Ng, 55, will become an executive director from July 1 and will oversee the company's recent expansion into the private nursing home space. Deputy CEO Patrick Daniel, 63, will retire, but continue as a part-time consultant. The changes aim to bring renewal to the company's management and board, following 15 years of Chan's leadership.

images.alt_text: "The media landscape is rapidly evolving with technological convergence in the digital age. There are vast opportunities that can be reaped despite these challenges facing us." - Ng Yat Chung (above), who has also held a number of positions with Singapore government investment company Temasek Holdings, will take over the helm of SPH on Sept 1, 2017, from current CEO Alan Chan Heng Loon.
SPH CEO Alan Chan Heng Loon.

Deputy chief executive Patrick Daniel (right) will retire at the same time as current CEO Mr Chan, but he will continue as a part-time consultant to assist Mr Ng. SPH's other deputy CEO, Anthony Tan (left), will remain at his current post.

site_title: Chipotle says hackers hit most restaurants in data breach
summary: Chipotle Mexican Grill announced a data breach that affected most of its 2,250 restaurants, where hackers used malware to steal customer payment data, including account numbers and internal verification codes, between March 24 and April 18. The breach could lead to identity theft, credit card cloning, and online purchases. Chipotle did not alert customers directly due to lack of collected names and addresses, but posted notifications on its website and issued a news release. The company may face a fine based on the breach size and records compromised, with security analysts estimating a potential fine of $18.5 million.

site_title: Oil, banks trip up European shares
summary: European shares declined 0.2% in thin trade, led by energy firms and banks, which fell 0.6% and hit a one-week low. Concerns over Italy's political situation and regional banks' financial stability contributed to the drop. Oil prices dropped 1% after OPEC's production cut extension, affecting oil stocks like Royal Dutch Shell and Total. In contrast, Britain's FTSE 100 index rose to a record level, driven by a weakening sterling.

site_title: Trump can't add things up
summary: US President Donald Trump's budget is facing criticism for its inaccuracies, including counting $2 trillion twice, and unrealistic spending cuts that would disproportionately affect the poor. The plan aims for "huge economic growth" through tax cuts for the rich, but is expected to be "dead on arrival" in Congress. The budget also proposes to limit food stamp benefits and eliminate government payments to Planned Parenthood, sparking concerns about the administration's intentions.

site_title: US: Wall Street sets fresh records despite little movement
summary: US stocks set new records on Friday, closing at 2,415.82 and 6,210.19, respectively, as the S&P 500 and Nasdaq broke Thursday's all-time highs. The Dow Jones Industrial Average remained virtually flat at 21,080.28. Despite economic data showing the US economy's first quarter was stronger than initially reported, investors appeared unmoved, taking a breather after six days of steady gains ahead of the Memorial Day holiday weekend.

images.alt_text: Wall Street drifted marginally higher to new records on Friday despite finishing virtually flat ahead of a holiday weekend.

site_title: Yancoal Australia not concerned for now over Noble's financial strength
summary: Yancoal Australia is not concerned about Noble Group's financial strength at this stage, despite Noble's recent quarterly loss and downgrade by rating agencies. Yancoal will raise nearly US$2 billion to fund the acquisition of Rio Tinto's coal mines, with Noble expected to contribute around US$260 million to avoid diluting its 13% stake. The acquisition's financing structure will be determined by Yancoal's independent board committee as the deal approaches.

site_title: BOC Aviation orders six Airbus jets
summary: BOC Aviation has ordered six new Airbus planes worth around $1.05 billion, comprising four A320 NEOs and two A330-900s, to be delivered between 2018 and 2020. The aircraft will be leased to Portugal's flag carrier TAP Portugal as part of the airline's fleet renewal plan, which includes 53 new Airbus NEOs.

site_title: Banking On Health
summary: Jeremy Rolleston, a former Olympic athlete, has quit his venture capitalist job to launch Active8me, a digital health platform aimed at encouraging Asians to adopt healthier lifestyles. The platform offers integrated mobile solutions, recipes, exercise plans, and motivational messages to promote holistic health. With a growing interest in fitness and wellness in Asia, Rolleston aims to address the region's high rates of obesity and diabetes. Active8me is now available on Android and iOS, with subscription options starting at S$28.98 per month.

site_title: Masked gunmen kill 28 in attack on Christians in Egypt
summary: Masked gunmen attacked a group of Coptic Christians traveling to a monastery in southern Egypt, killing 28 and wounding 25 others, including many children. The attack, which occurred on the eve of Ramadan, has been condemned by Muslim leaders and the Coptic church. The Egyptian government has launched a hunt for the unidentified gunmen, who arrived in three four-wheel-drive vehicles. The attack is the latest in a series of church bombings claimed by Islamic State, and it has raised concerns about the safety of Egypt's Christian minority.

site_title: Clinton delivers stinging attack on Trump at graduation speech
summary: Hillary Clinton delivered a commencement speech at Wellesley College, comparing Donald Trump to former President Richard Nixon, who resigned due to impeachment. She criticized Trump's assault on fact-based politics, his proposed federal budget, and his handling of the opioid epidemic. Clinton urged the class of 2017 to get involved in politics and to stand up against "alternative facts." Despite her electoral defeat, she expressed optimism and encouraged graduates to make a difference.

site_title: Manchester attack probe: 11 people in detention
summary: Eleven people, including Salman Abedi's father and brother, are in detention in Britain and Libya over the Manchester pop concert bombing that killed 22 people, including seven children. Nine are in custody in the UK, and two in Libya, with police still investigating Abedi's movements and connections. Abedi, a British-born man of Libyan origin, returned from Libya just days before the attack, and his family members are being questioned about his involvement in the Islamic State group. The investigation is ongoing, with police trying to determine if Abedi was part of a wider network.

images.alt_text: A total of 11 people are in detention in Britain and Libya over Monday's suicide bombing on a pop concert in the northwestern English city of Manchester by a British-born man of Libyan origin.

site_title: Developers sidelined in Moscow's planned US$50b programme to resettle residents
summary: Moscow's planned $50 billion programme to resettle almost a million residents will not allow developers to co-invest, but instead, they will only be involved as contractors. The city's deputy mayor, Marat Khusnullin, stated that real estate companies will only be able to sell some of the flats in exchange for building them. This move will deliver lower margins for property firms, with thousands of Muscovites protesting against the scheme. The 15-year programme aims to demolish and replace 350,000 flats with new residential space.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Starhill Global Reit divested its Harajuku Secondo Property for 22.4% premium, with management aiming to streamline its portfolio. Despite operational challenges, the REIT is expected to see a 6.12% rental uplift from August 2017. Analysts maintain a "buy" rating on SGREIT, citing its lower fair value estimate of S$0.81. In contrast, Neo Group reported in-line core profits, driven by a turnaround in its food manufacturing business and new acquisitions. Analysts expect Neo Group to take time to digest its newly acquired U-Market and turn its food manufacturing profitable.

site_title: Dine Now
summary: Award-winning chef Daniel Sia returns to the Lo & Behold Group as culinary director, introducing a new menu featuring premium steaks and unique desserts at The Black Swan. Meanwhile, Blue Lotus Chinese Noodle Bar at Science Park offers modern twists on traditional Northern Chinese flavors. These additions join a growing list of dining options in Singapore, highlighting the city's diverse culinary scene.

site_title: Play it
summary: Raffles Country Club is planning to close its doors within a year, but not before hosting a charity event. The 36-hole golf club aims to go out with a bang, raising funds for a good cause.

site_title: Markets are ignoring serious risks, says Citigroup chief economist
summary: Citigroup's global chief economist Willem Buiter warns that financial markets are ignoring serious risks to the global economy, including China's debt crisis, Brexit's impact on labor markets, the US economy's overvalued stock market, and the threat of trade wars. He also notes that corporate borrowing is in "dangerous territory" and the euro zone's break-up is a risk. Buiter urges caution, citing the 2008 financial crisis as a precedent, and suggests that markets are focusing too much on benign scenarios.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Cortina Holdings reported a 13.4% increase in revenue to S$106.1 million for the three months ended March 31, with a net profit of S$3.8 million. The company's full-year EPS rose to 7.1 Singapore cents from 5.1 cents in the previous year. A final dividend of 2.0 cents and a special dividend of 1.0 cent per ordinary share were declared.

site_title: Rounds unplayed
summary: There is no article content provided to summarize. The text appears to be a collection of news article links and publication dates, but no actual article is present.

site_title: KSH posts 33.4% slump in full-year net profit to S$41m
summary: KSH Holdings reported a 33.4% decline in full-year net profit to S$40.98 million, mainly due to lower group revenue and a 19.1% decline in construction segment contribution. Revenue fell 18.8% to S$199.26 million. Despite the decline, the company's gross profit margin for the construction segment improved to 21.5%. KSH will continue to focus on innovation and automation to achieve greater margin efficiency and capitalize on high-yield projects.

site_title: Open-Air Flair
summary: The Mercedes-Benz C300 Cabriolet is a compact, convertible model with a soft-top, offering a classic and practical design. It features two petrol engine options, the C200 and C300, with the latter providing 245 hp and 370 Nm. The C300 Cabriolet boasts a pleasant cruising experience, agile handling, and a high-end Burmester surround sound system. With a top speed of 250 km/h and CO2 emissions of 155 g/km, it is priced at S$283,888. The model's rigid structure and electrically operated wind deflector provide a comfortable driving experience for all occupants.

site_title: Far from (The) Ordinary
summary: The Ordinary, a skincare brand from Deciem, a Canadian beauty company, offers affordable apothecary-style products with a focus on honesty and integrity. The brand's products are labeled with simple, ingredient-based names and detailed descriptions on their website, making it accessible to both beauty enthusiasts and newcomers. With prices starting at $9.80, The Ordinary's offerings are significantly more affordable than those of high-end brands, making it a low-risk experiment for those trying skincare products for the first time.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: Discount Dilemma
summary: Discount dining apps like eatigo, The Entertainer, and EatPlayLive are gaining popularity, with eatigo seeing 400,000 app downloads and 30,000 new downloads monthly. However, their success raises concerns about the impact on restaurants, as seen with the decline of Groupon. Despite this, the apps' popularity suggests that consumers value dining discounts, with eatigo's co-founder stating that it's about "dining smart." The long-term effects of these apps on the restaurant industry remain unclear.

site_title: Tech entrepreneurs see SGX as attractive IPO destination
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) remains an attractive option for tech startups and "disruptive" companies considering an initial public offering (IPO), according to SGX officials. The bourse offers sufficient liquidity and investor appetite for growth or innovative companies. Key tech entrepreneurs, including 99.co CEO Darius Cheung and MyRepublic CEO Greg Mittman, expressed interest in listing on SGX due to its favorable regulatory environment and local consumer market. The exchange's compactness and global investor base also make it an attractive destination for tech businesses.

site_title: SGX Bull Charge to help the needy
summary: The Singapore Exchange Limited (SGX) has been supporting efforts to help the needy since 2004. The SGX Bull Charge initiative rallies listed companies to contribute to charitable causes. This program demonstrates SGX's commitment to giving back to the community.

site_title: Ensuring a 'safe retirement income floor'
summary: A "safe retirement income floor" (SRIF) is a controlled and consistent income stream designed to meet a retiree's basic needs, regardless of market performance. The SRIF is achieved through investments in CPF Life, a national annuity scheme in Singapore, which guarantees a minimum return of 2.5-4% per annum. The SRIF can be implemented through various CPF Life plans, including the Standard and Basic Plans, which offer different payout structures and bequests upon demise. The CPF Life plan with escalating payouts, set to launch in 2018, also provides a controlled income stream with increasing payouts over time.

images.alt_text: Christopher Tan

site_title: Ageing gracefully: The paradigm shift of aesthetic medicine
summary: Doctors are shifting towards minimally invasive aesthetic treatments that produce natural changes with little downtime, moving away from invasive procedures that were previously the norm. These treatments target bone structure, facial volume, and skin quality, using non-invasive techniques such as dermal fillers, laser treatments, and skin tightening devices. The goal is to achieve a "natural, gradual" look, rather than dramatic results, and to prioritize patient comfort and downtime. With a focus on holistic approaches and effective communication, ageing gracefully is now more possible than ever, with reasonable expectations and a well-trained practitioner being key to a good outcome.

site_title: Els Club gives golfers a tasty choice
summary: The Els Club, developed by golfer Ernie Els, offers a challenging yet realistic golfing experience. The 18-hole course features a mix of big and easy holes, reflecting Els' personal attributes. The club's design allows golfers to enjoy a unique and memorable game.

site_title: Laguna Golf Bintan launches new drive
summary: Laguna Golf Bintan is launching an Annual Membership drive with a special deal for those who sign up and play the SPH Golf Card July Medal event on July 15.

site_title: Wenger seeks solace in quest for record seventh FA Cup
summary: Arsene Wenger hopes to win a record seventh FA Cup with Arsenal in their final against Chelsea at Wembley Stadium. Wenger, whose contract is set to expire, has stated he wants to win the trophy for his club, not personally. Arsenal has improved recently, winning seven of their last eight league matches, and defeated Manchester City in the semi-finals. Chelsea manager Antonio Conte is aiming for a league and FA Cup Double, while striker Diego Costa is likely to leave the club after the final, potentially for the Chinese Super League.

site_title: Indian Hercules vanquishes evil uncle, then clobbers Bollywood
summary: The Indian epic film "Baahubali 2: The Conclusion" has become the country's highest-grossing film, earning almost 16 billion rupees since its release in April. Dubbed into Hindi to give it nationwide appeal, the film's success is broadening the appeal of regional moviemaking in India, challenging Bollywood's hegemony. The film's global distribution is set to include Chinese, Japanese, and Russian markets, and its success may spur greater appreciation for the region's filmmaking among Bollywood devotees, with some studios considering producing in Telugu.

site_title: War over words erupts as World Bank star economist sidelined
summary: World Bank chief economist Paul Romer has been stripped of his management duties after researchers rebelled against his efforts to improve communication, including a ban on using "and" in written reports. Romer will remain chief economist and provide management with "timely thought leadership" starting July 1, when Kristalina Georgieva takes over management of the Development Economics Group.

site_title: What the locker room is saying about the rules changes
summary: Golf's governing body is proposing to simplify The Rules of Golf by reducing them from 34 to 24. The changes aim to make the game more accessible and enjoyable for players. While not everyone agrees with the proposed changes, many see the effort as a positive step towards modernizing the sport. The new rules are expected to be implemented in the future, although no specific timeline has been announced.

site_title: Firm believer in longer-term investments
summary: Billionaire Saurabh Mittal, founder of Mission Holdings, emphasizes the importance of long-term investments, typically lasting five years or longer. He believes businesses generate large multiples on capital only over the long term. In an exclusive interview, Mittal stated, "Fundamentally, businesses produce large multiples on capital only over the long term." This approach is reflected in his investment strategies, which prioritize longer-term bets over quick profits.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: The Art of Flipping
summary: The resell market is booming, with limited edition sneakers, particularly those from Nike and Adidas, being highly traded commodities. The secondary sneaker market is valued at $1 billion, with Nike accounting for 96% of the market. The rise of online marketplaces and social media has fueled the trend, with some resellers making significant profits, including a 16-year-old who reportedly made $1 million from flipping shoes. However, retailers are struggling to cope with the issue, introducing measures such as membership programs, online balloting, and raffles to prevent reselling. The use of bots to cart out hot sneakers is also a problem, but some platforms are using technology to authenticate products and prevent counterfeits.

site_title: Mark Zuckerberg's Great American Road Trip
summary: Mark Zuckerberg embarked on a US road trip to visit every state and learn about Facebook's users. The trip, which began in January, has taken him to roughly half the states, including stops at a rehabilitation center in Dayton, Ohio, and a dairy farm in Blanchardville, Wisconsin. Zuckerberg said the trip has broadened his views on community and purpose, and has led him to realize the importance of churches and civic centers in building strong communities. He denied using the trip as a platform for a potential presidential run, saying it's a way to "get a broader perspective" to inform his work at Facebook and the Chan Zuckerberg Initiative.

site_title: Back With A Sting
summary: Sting is set to perform in Singapore on May 28 at the Singapore Indoor Stadium, supporting his 57th & 9th album. The show will feature a three-piece band, including Dominic Miller, Josh Freese, and Rufus Miller, along with opening acts Joe Sumner and The Last Bandoleros. Tickets are available from S$108 to S$288 through sportshub.com.sg.

site_title: Air-Cooled Beetle
summary: The Volkswagen Beetle Cabriolet, a four-seater open-top model, has been introduced in the market after a four-year delay due to vehicle financing restrictions. The soft-top Beetle features a sportier design, flat profile, and classic fabric roof, while maintaining the same interior design cues as the hardtop version. It is powered by a 1.2-litre turbocharged petrol engine with 105 hp and 175 Nm, and comes equipped with a seven-speed dual clutch transmission and high-end Fender sound system. The cabriolet delivers good ride comfort and quick roof operation, with some buffeting at normal road speeds.

site_title: BT Corporate Golf League tees off at SICC on July 6
summary: The Business Times Corporate Golf League is set to tee off on July 6 at the Singapore Island Country Club's Old Course. The eighth edition will feature 14 competitive teams and nine social teams, showcasing the event's growing popularity among local corporations. The tournament has become a highly anticipated event for companies, solidifying its position as the most interest and popular local golf tournament.

site_title: Adi Tatarko
summary: Adi Tatarko, co-founder and CEO of Houzz, recounts the company's humble beginnings as a side project for a Palo Alto couple in 2009, a platform for home renovation ideas and professionals. Houzz has since grown into a global community with over 40 million monthly users and 1.5 million active professionals, available in 15 countries. The site's success stems from its global community, allowing users to connect with professionals worldwide and find inspiration for their homes. Houzz has expanded its services to include a marketplace where users can buy products directly, and Tatarko credits the platform's impact on users' lives, from renovating homes to finding new business opportunities.

site_title: Temasek's venture arm Vertex to launch new Israel, US funds in 2018: CEO
summary: Vertex Holdings, Temasek's venture arm, plans to launch two new funds in 2018, one for Israel and the US, each targeting $150 million. The funds will focus on cybersecurity in Israel and enterprise and infrastructure software in the US. Additionally, Vertex has existing funds for China ($250 million), India and South-east Asia ($200 million), and a global healthcare fund.

site_title: Howl With Howard
summary: British comedian Russell Howard is set to debut his Round the World tour in Singapore on May 28 at the Kallang Theatre. The tour, his biggest to date, has already gained significant attention, with over three million fans on Facebook and over one million followers on Twitter. Howard has also hosted his own shows on BBC Three and Comedy Central, as well as a travelogue series last year. Tickets for the event are now available from S$88 to S$148 through Sistic.

site_title: Why fake news is almost impossible to kill
summary: A recent conspiracy theory surrounding the unsolved murder of Democratic National Committee staff member Seth Rich continues to spread despite efforts by journalists, academics, and technology experts to debunk it. Despite retraction by FoxNews.com and a statement from Sean Hannity retracting his discussion of the topic, the conspiracy theory persists on social media and other platforms, with various individuals and websites claiming to have evidence of Rich's involvement in the WikiLeaks hack. The story highlights the difficulty in stopping fake news and conspiracy theories, which continue to thrive as long as people are eager to spread and believe them.

site_title: When the world makes even less sense
summary: A series of deadly attacks occurred in the past week, including a bombing at an Ariana Grande concert in Manchester, twin blasts in East Jakarta, and an attack on Coptic Christians in Egypt, resulting in at least 65 deaths and 120 injuries. The attacks underscore terrorism's lack of discrimination and its ability to strike at random, causing widespread fear and concern. Analysts warn that more attacks may be in the pipeline, and the average civilian must fight to prevent paranoia and cede mental real estate to terrorists.

site_title: Bukit Sembawang Estates posts 67.2% drop in Q4 profit
summary: Bukit Sembawang Estates reported a 67.2% drop in Q4 net profit to S$2.26 million, driven by higher operating expenses and tax expense. Revenue rose 24.3% to S$15.21 million. The group's full-year net profit dropped 21.2% to S$72.46 million, while revenue fell 49.2% to S$143.4 million. The company declared unchanged dividends and its share price closed one cent lower at S$6.09. Analysts have valued the company at S$7.55 to S$10.35 per share, citing its substantial landbank and development potential.

site_title: Majestic Goodbye
summary: The New Majestic Hotel in Singapore is hosting its last public event, "Multiply: A Majestic Playground", before closing to become a private members club. The event, taking place on May 27-28, will showcase the Singapore design story through installations, workshops, and show-and-sell showcases featuring over 50 artists, designers, and makers. This is the first time these creatives will come together, celebrating the community's diverse inspirations.

site_title: US malls focus on experiences to woo disappearing shoppers
summary: US malls are shifting their focus from traditional retail to experiences, such as restaurants and entertainment, to attract dwindling shoppers. Companies like Washington Prime Group and CBL & Associates Properties are revamping existing properties with amenities like rock-climbing gyms and jelly bean-dispensing tricycles. This approach aims to inject "kinetic energy" into a stagnant business model, as online sales continue to dominate. Industry experts see this trend as a response to the seismic shift in the retail landscape, with store closures and bankruptcies on the rise.

site_title: My Weekend
summary: Violet Lim, CEO and Co-Founder of Lunch Actually Group, shares her typical weekend routine. She spends Saturdays driving her children to their classes, then exercising with them and watching a family movie night. Sundays involve attending church, having lunch with her extended family, and spending time at the park or trampoline center. Lim values her family weekend rituals, which she believes create lasting memories and strengthen her bond with her husband and children.

site_title: S'pore market takes cues from Wall St this week
summary: Singapore's stock market took cues from Wall Street this week, with the Straits Times Index closing at 3,219.42 after a 14.95-point loss on Friday. The market seems to be glossing over new allegations about Russia's interference in the US presidential election. The Dow Jones Industrial Average reached its second-highest ever, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite closed at new all-time highs. The US Federal Reserve released minutes from its May meeting, stating that interest rates may not be raised until the US economic slowdown is temporary.

images.alt_text: The local stock market this week took its cues from Wall Street, where the political upheaval of a fortnight ago appears to have settled down. Or has it?

site_title: Hawkers' Centre
summary: In 1952, Singapore's street hawkers proliferated to feed a migrant population, offering cheap food and services. However, they posed a health risk due to unsanitary conditions. The Singapore City Council sought to license hawkers, but progress was slow. By the early 1980s, all hawkers had been resettled, leading to improved food safety and sanitation. Today, Singapore's hawker centers provide a safe and affordable dining experience, serving popular dishes like laksa without the risk of waterborne illnesses. The legacy of Singapore's hawkers has transformed the city's food culture.

site_title: What Fitness App Is Best For You?
summary: A fitness app comparison is presented, highlighting three options: Vida, JEFIT, and MyFitnessPal. Vida offers personalized coaching with a monthly fee of $59-$349, while JEFIT provides a wide range of workouts without videos or injury guidance for $4.99-$39.99. MyFitnessPal is a top-rated diet app with exercise features, with a monthly fee of $9.99-$49.99. The choice of app depends on individual preferences and fitness goals.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens flat after six-day winning streak
summary: US stocks opened flat on Friday, ending a six-day winning streak, ahead of a three-day holiday weekend. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dipped 0.04%, the S&P 500 edged down 0.05%, and the Nasdaq Composite gained 0.03%. Investors took a cautious approach amid uncertainty over US-EU trade talks and ongoing tariff tensions.

site_title: Bosses should help ITE be a key anchor in push for life-long learning: DPM Tharman
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam emphasized the importance of employers' role in supporting the Institute of Technical Education (ITE) in its transformation to provide lifelong learning opportunities. Employers must help ITE adapt to fast technological changes, enabling workers to stay up-to-date. Tharman stated that ITE will be a key anchor in Singapore's national push for lifelong learning.

site_title: SIA first Asian airline to offer expedited screening to customers travelling from US
summary: Singapore Airlines has partnered the Transportation Security Administration to offer expedited security screening procedures to customers traveling from US airports under TSA Precheck, becoming the first Asian airline to do so. The program reduces wait times for low-risk known travelers and is open to US citizens and permanent residents. Singapore citizens can apply for the Global Entry Programme, which also offers benefits. The airline will also implement online check-in and mobile boarding passes for US travel.

images.alt_text: Singapore Airlines (SIA) announced on Friday that it has partnered the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) to offer expedited security screening procedures to customers travelling from US airports under TSA Precheck, becoming the first Asian airline to do so.

site_title: US, Japanese leaders agree to enhance sanctions against North Korea: White House
summary: US President Donald Trump and Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe agreed to enhance sanctions against North Korea for its nuclear development and ballistic missile programs. The two leaders vowed to strengthen their alliance to deter and defend against North Korea's threats. They plan to identify and sanction entities that support Pyongyang's nuclear and missile programs. The move aims to prevent North Korea from developing a nuclear missile capable of hitting the US by 2020.

site_title: A business management idea shows up in 3 cultures
summary: A business management concept, "management by walking about" (MBWA), is seen in three cultures: the US, Japan, and Singapore. In the US, it's called MBWA, while in Japan, it's gemba, and in Singapore, it's Kia Lai Kia Kee (KLKK), meaning "walking around." This concept involves executives and managers walking around the company's premises to tune in to business affairs and employees on the ground, regardless of the local phrase's negative association. The idea emphasizes the importance of being present and connected with employees and the business.

site_title: The Simple Life
summary: The Bellarine Peninsula in Victoria, Australia, is attracting city-dwellers with its idyllic countryside, pristine produce, and artisanal producers. The area, a two-hour drive southwest of Melbourne, is home to vineyards, farms, and restaurants serving clean, healthy food. Notable establishments include Igni, Oakdene Vineyards, and Advance Mussel Supply, which showcase the region's unique produce and hospitality. Local producers, such as Chris Balazs' SageChoice Farm and Anna Wilding's Wildings Pantry Essentials, are also making a name for themselves with their grass-fed meats, organic produce, and artisanal goods.

site_title: US takes "full responsibility" for Manchester intelligence leaks: Tillerson
summary: US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson said the US takes full responsibility for leaking private details of the Manchester police investigation into the deadly bomb attack that killed 22 people. The leak occurred after British police briefly suspended intelligence sharing with the US due to repeated appearances of sensitive information in American media. Tillerson condemned the leak and expressed confidence that the close security relationship between the US and UK will withstand the incident.

site_title: BlackRock to pay US$1.25b rent over 20 years for New York HQ
summary: BlackRock has agreed to pay $1.25 billion in rent over 20 years for its new headquarters in the Hudson Yards district of Manhattan, a 847,000 sq ft space. The initial rent is approximately $60 per square foot, increasing to nearly $74 per square foot over the full term of the lease. The company will also cover operating expenses and a share of property taxes. The lease is one of the largest in Manhattan, surpassing the average asking rent of $84.09 per square foot in midtown Manhattan.

images.alt_text: For the time being, BlackRock has offices in two buildings on 52nd Street off Park Avenue, along with other locations.

site_title: Ex-NOL chief Ng Yat Chung to take reins of SPH as CEO, deputy CEO retire
summary: SPH appoints former NOL CEO Ng Yat Chung as its new CEO, replacing Alan Chan, who retires on September 1. Deputy CEO Patrick Daniel will retire and remain as a part-time consultant. Ng will become an executive director from July 1, with current deputy CEO Anthony Tan remaining in his post. Chairman Lee Boon Yang praised Chan's leadership, citing his expansion of SPH's media, retail, and commercial businesses.

site_title: Singapore's Royal Group sells Sydney hotel for A$140m to Chinese consortium
summary: Singapore's Royal Group sold its 5-star InterContinental Sydney Double Bay hotel to a Chinese real estate consortium for A$140 million, believed to be a record price for non-CBD hotels in Australia. The hotel was originally opened as a Ritz Carlton in 1991 and rebranded in 2001. The sale follows the group's strategy of recycling capital, with Royal Group paying A$60 million for the property in 2013. The Sydney hotel market is considered "hot" with the sale marking the first luxury hotel to be sold since 2015, according to a top property executive.

images.alt_text: Royal Hotels Australia Pty, part of Singapore's Royal Group, said it has inked the agreement to sell InterContinental Sydney Double Bay (above) to Shanghai United Real Estate and Zobon Real Estate Group.
Anita Gabriel

site_title: Trump says Germany 'very bad' on trade in G-7 slap at Merkel
summary: US President Donald Trump reportedly told his economic adviser that Germany is "very bad" on trade, particularly with regards to flooding the US with autos. However, his adviser clarified that Trump didn't have a problem with Germany itself, but rather with German trade. This comment was met with criticism from Germany, with the government stating that a trade surplus is a natural result of supply and demand. The incident is part of Trump's pattern of distancing himself from major allies, including during the G-7 meeting in Sicily and the NATO summit.

site_title: Pound falls on tighter polls as traders wake up to election risk
summary: The UK pound fell 1.1% to $1.2798 against the US dollar, its worst week this year, as a poll showed the Conservative Party's lead over Labour narrowed to 5 percentage points, sparking concerns of a hung parliament. The poll's uncertainty prompted a jump in implied volatility, with analysts warning of further sell-offs in the pound if Labour were to win. The UK terror threat remains high, and consumer confidence has fallen to its lowest since Brexit, fueling the pound's decline.

site_title: KSH posts 33.4% drop in full-year profit
summary: KSH Holdings reported a 33.4% drop in full-year net profit to S$40.98 million due to lower revenue and a significant decrease in associate profits. Revenue fell 18.8% to S$199.26 million, while share of results of associates dropped 82.5%. The company proposed final and special cash dividends and a bonus share issue to expand its issued share capital base.

site_title: Manhattan luxury-home sellers are getting the message: cut the price
summary: Manhattan luxury home sellers are experiencing a saturated market, leading them to discount prices to attract buyers. According to Olshan Realty Inc, the median asking price for US$4 million+ homes is the lowest in at least five years, at US$4,997,500. This marks the fourth week since 2013 that the price has dipped below US$5 million. To sell, owners are finding that cutting their price is the most effective way to secure a deal in the highly competitive market.

site_title: China Jinjiang invests in new waste-to-energy project for 325m yuan
summary: China Jinjiang Environment Holding Company Ltd is investing 325 million yuan (S$66 million) in a new waste-to-energy project in Yan'an, Shaanxi Province. The project, under the build-operate-transfer model, will have a capacity of 1,300 tonnes per day and 100 tonnes per day of sludge treatment. Construction is expected to start in the first half of 2019, with operations expected to commence in 2019. The project will have an exclusive right to provide waste treatment services for 30 years before ownership and possession are transferred to local authorities.

site_title: Fitch cuts Noble's ratings again on debt worries
summary: Fitch Ratings has cut Noble Group's rating for a second time in 10 days, citing concerns over its ability to handle US$2 billion in debt maturing over the next 12 months. The Hong Kong-based commodity trader is in talks with banks to renew a borrowing base facility expiring next month, with Fitch expecting a successful rollover but on less favorable terms. This cut adds to Noble's debt worries, highlighting its liquidity issues.

site_title: Former CIMB banker admits to insider trading in two takeover stocks
summary: A former CIMB banker, Alan Tay Yeow Kee, admitted to insider trading in two takeover stocks, Qualitas Medical Group Ltd and Leeden Ltd, in a Singapore State Court. He pleaded guilty to trading on price-sensitive information and was fined S$180,000. Tay, 41, had bought shares in 2011 before the information became publicly available, while working as an associate director at CIMB. This case highlights Singapore's efforts to clamp down on market misconduct and protect its financial hub image.

site_title: StarHub to acquire 51% stake in Accel Systems & Technologies for S$19.4m
summary: StarHub Ltd agreed to acquire a 51% stake in Accel Systems & Technologies Pte Ltd for S$19.38 million. This move will strengthen StarHub's cyber security portfolio, allowing it to offer end-to-end cyber security solutions and services. Following the acquisition, Accel Systems & Technologies will become a subsidiary of StarHub. CEO Tan Tong Hai stated that the deal will enable StarHub to meet the growing demand for cyber security solutions in Singapore's digital economy.

site_title: Raw Appeal
summary: A Singaporean couple, Herbin and Sharon Chia, renovated their 10-year-old flat using a raw, industrial style inspired by Brutalist Architecture. The interior designer, William Chan, stripped away unnecessary details to showcase the flat's assets, using materials like plywood, concrete, and galvanized metal. The result is a minimalist space with a large, modern kitchen and a unique bedroom hidden behind a steel door. The couple, who had previously lived with the flat's original layout, chose to eliminate unnecessary bedrooms to create a more streamlined space.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: China says considering tighter controls on yuan currency
summary: China is considering tighter controls on its yuan currency, introducing a "counter-cyclical factor" to its current system allowing the currency to trade within a 2% daily band. The move aims to hedge against market fluctuations and ease irrational expectations, as the yuan has plummeted to its lowest levels against the dollar since last year. This step back from liberalization pledges may help maintain yuan stability during China's debt-reduction campaign, which has been downgraded by Moody's. The new system would introduce a factor to consider the country's economic fundamentals as a counter to market forces.

site_title: What an attack at an Ariana Grande show means for teen girls and their world
summary: Ariana Grande's concert in Manchester was attacked, resulting in 22 deaths and 59 injuries. The event, which provided a safe space for teenage girls to express themselves, was marred by the loss of innocence and the traumatic experience of the victims. The article reflects on the impact of pop concerts on young women, who often find solace and empowerment in the music and the sense of community it provides. The attack serves as a harsh reminder of the hard world that little girls face, and the loss of innocence that can occur in such traumatic events.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's factory output rose 6.7% year-over-year in April, driven by a surge in electronics production. A former CIMB banker admitted to insider trading, while Singapore Press Holdings appointed former NOL CEO Ng Yat Chung as CEO. Noble Group's rating was cut by Fitch for the second time in 10 days, citing debt concerns. Additionally, Tuan Sing Holdings priced its S$120 million notes and Royal Hotels Australia sold a Sydney hotel for A$140 million.

site_title: Trump: North Korea 'will be solved'
summary: US President Donald Trump stated at the G7 summit in Italy that North Korea "will be solved," amid ongoing missile tests by the nuclear-armed nation. Trump's comments come as the US and its allies, including Japan and South Korea, are concerned about North Korea's unpredictable behavior and its potential threat to the region and the world. The US has opted for sanctions and diplomatic pressure, while looking to China to help rein in Pyongyang, which has accelerated its missile launch program despite UN sanctions.

site_title: Delong Holdings in talks for potential collaboration
summary: Delong Holdings Ltd announced it's in discussions for a potential collaboration with certain parties. No definitive agreements have been reached, and no certainty exists about the outcome. The company advised shareholders to exercise caution and consult professional advisers before taking any action with their securities. This comes as the company makes further announcements as necessary.

images.alt_text: Steel manufacturing and trading company Delong Holdings Ltd announced on Friday that it is in discussions with certain parties relating to a potential collaboration.

site_title: Sunpower Group secures 116.7m yuan in contracts
summary: Sunpower Group secured 116.68 million yuan (S$23.5 million) in contracts with Xinjiang GCL New Energy Material Technology Co and AVIC International Beijing Company Ltd. The contracts involve supplying towers, reduction furnaces, and heat exchangers for Xinjiang GCL's polysilicon project and AVIC International Beijing's projects, respectively. Deliveries are expected this year, with a positive impact on Sunpower's current financial year.

site_title: After UK attack, voter confronts interior minister over police cuts
summary: A British voter confronted interior minister Amber Rudd over police cuts, prompting her to deny a link between falling police numbers and the Manchester suicide bomb attack that killed 22. Rudd stated that counter-terrorism was adequately resourced, while the voter suggested that low-level intelligence was hindered by the cuts. The opposition Labour Party pledged to boost police numbers by 10,000 as campaigning resumed after the attack. Government figures show a 19,000 drop in police officers between 2010 and 2016.

site_title: EU to demand top court enforce citizens' rights after Brexit
summary: The European Union is demanding that its top court enforce citizens' rights in Britain after Brexit. The EU Council has proposed that the European Court of Justice have "full jurisdiction" over EU nationals in the UK, and the European Commission should monitor their rights. This move may conflict with UK Prime Minister Theresa May's promise to end the court's sway over British law. The EU also wants to guarantee the rights of spouses and children of EU workers, including continued family allowances for children of deceased parents.

images.alt_text: The European Union will demand its top court have the power to enforce the rights of its citizens in Britain after Brexit.

site_title: Buy? Sell? Politics may move the market, but rarely for long
summary: US stocks experienced volatility last week after a report on President Donald Trump's alleged attempt to stop an FBI investigation, with the Dow Jones falling 373 points. In contrast, Brazil's market plummeted 10% after news of a bribery scandal involving its president, Michel Temer. Meanwhile, Asia is expected to drive and benefit from dollar asset diversification, with retail investors anticipated to drive growth in ETFs. The S&P 500 reached a record high, with productivity gains seen as key to unlocking wealth creation.

site_title: KS Energy in bonds purchase, warrants subscription agreements with lenders
summary: KS Energy Ltd has proposed issuing S$80.15 million fixed-rate secured bonds due 2020 and 80.15 million non-listed bonus warrants to four lenders, including OCBC and a subsidiary of Kris Wiluan, the group's executive chairman and CEO. The bonds and warrants will be issued simultaneously, with the bonds being repurchased by the group to settle the issuance cost. The warrants will raise gross proceeds of S$3.61 million, which will be used for debt repayments and operating overheads.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end marginally higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the week with a sixth-straight gain, as the Hang Seng Index rose 8.49 points to 25,639.27. A record close on Wall Street was offset by losses in energy firms due to a slump in oil prices.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end lower
summary: Malaysian shares ended lower on Friday, closing at 1,772.3, down 1.66 points. The 2.86 billion lots traded valued RM2.60 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 771 to 208.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific agrees to sell Sydney property to another buyer
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings agreed to sell a Sydney property for A$158 million (S$163 million) after an initial deal fell through. The sale is subject to due diligence and further definitive agreements. The buyer is Fortius Funds Management, and the transaction is expected to proceed. This marks the second attempt to sell the property, following the initial deal's collapse.

site_title: Europe: Stocks steady at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets steadied at the open on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 index 0.1% higher. The eurozone's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indexes eased 0.1% and 0.2% respectively. US stocks reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging up. Investors are awaiting US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Bukit Sembawang Estates posts 67.2% drop in Q4 profit
summary: Bukit Sembawang Estates Ltd reported a 67.2% drop in Q4 net profit to S$2.26 million, primarily due to higher other operating expenses and tax expenses. Revenue rose 24.3% to S$15.21 million. For the full year, net profit dropped 21.2% to S$72.46 million, while revenue declined 49.2% to S$143.4 million. The company maintained final and special dividends at last year's levels.

site_title: Vietnam says Google will cooperate in removal of "toxic" content
summary: Vietnam's communist government has reached an agreement with Alphabet, Google's parent company, to remove "toxic" and illegal content from its platforms. The agreement was made during a meeting between Chairman Eric Schmidt and Prime Minister Nguyen Xuan Phuc, with Google promising to cooperate and potentially opening a representative office in Vietnam. However, Google has stated that it has no immediate plan for an office and relies on governments to notify it of content to be removed. This move aims to address Vietnam's concerns over internet censorship and align with the country's growing economy.

site_title: Ex-CIMB banker admits insider trades in Singapore takeovers
summary: A former CIMB banker, Alan Tay Yeow Kee, pleaded guilty to insider trading in Singapore takeovers. He admitted to buying shares in Qualitas Medical Group Ltd and Leeden Ltd in 2011 before the companies received takeover offers, while working as a banker for CIMB. Tay was fined S$180,000 and has been unemployed. The case highlights Singapore's efforts to clamp down on market misconduct and protect its image as a financial hub. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is also boosting enforcement and surveillance abilities to deter criminal behavior.

site_title: Stuttgart prosecutor puts Bosch under suspicion in Daimler emissions probe
summary: German prosecutors investigating Daimler's diesel emissions scandal are looking into Bosch's involvement, with a focus on aiding and abetting fraud. Bosch, a supplier of engine management software to Daimler, is under suspicion for allegedly helping the carmaker cheat emissions tests. The investigation is separate from a previous probe into Volkswagen. Bosch has not commented on the matter, citing the sensitive legal nature of the investigation. The Stuttgart prosecutor's office is also in touch with US authorities, following a recent search of Daimler's offices.

site_title: Indonesia makes arrests as Islamic State claims Jakarta attacks
summary: Indonesian police arrested three suspects linked to the recent Jakarta bombings that killed three police officers and wounded 12 others. The Islamic State group claimed responsibility for the attack, which was the deadliest in Indonesia since 2016. President Joko Widodo ordered revisions to the country's anti-terrorism laws to prevent future attacks, citing the need for stronger regulations to prevent such incidents. The revisions aim to broaden the definition of terrorism and give police more power to detain suspects without trial.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won close with biggest weekly gains in 2 months
summary: South Korean shares closed at a record high, ending the week with a 2.9% gain, the biggest weekly gains since mid-March. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) rose 0.5% to 2,355.31 points. Offshore investors purchased 111.6 billion won worth of Kospi shares, while the South Korean won edged down 0.4% to 1,120.7 per US dollar. The currency still made its biggest weekly percentage gain since late March.

site_title: G7 leaders brace for clash with Trump on trade and climate
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to clash with G7 leaders over trade and climate change at a summit in Sicily. Trump has criticized NATO allies for not spending more on defense and accused Germany of "very bad" trade policies. Despite this, White House economic adviser Gary Cohn says the US will engage in "fairly robust" talks on cutting greenhouse gas emissions under the Paris Agreement. European leaders are expected to push Trump hard on the Paris emissions deal, which has comprehensive support across the continent.

site_title: Japan: Nikkei slips at the end of trading
summary: Japan's Nikkei share average slipped 0.6% to 19,686.84 at the end of trading, despite a weekly gain of 0.5%. The yen's gains against the dollar accelerated, with the dollar slipping 0.4% to 111.42 yen. Oil and mining shares fell, with the oil and coal subindex dropping 0.4% and the mining subindex tumbling 2%. The losses were attributed to a disappointing OPEC meeting and a decline in oil prices, which skidded 5% on Thursday.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.17% to 25,673.87 on Friday, following Wall Street's gains. In contrast, mainland China markets edged down, with the Shanghai Composite Index down 0.21%. This trend follows a week of gains for Hong Kong stocks.

site_title: Gold steady as Asian stocks slip after oil slump
summary: Gold prices held steady after dipping slightly on Friday as Asian stocks eased following OPEC's extension of output curbs. Oil markets remained weak after tumbling 5% in the previous session. US gold futures gained 0.1% to $1,257.2 an ounce. Analysts attribute the steady gold prices to the risk of a US rate hike and broader weakness in industrial commodities.

site_title: Singapore stocks finish weaker on Friday
summary: Singapore stocks finished weaker on Friday, despite a 5-day rally, amid uncertainty from the Trump administration's budget, which includes large cuts to social spending and military spending increases. The US market had recovered from its wobble two weeks ago, with major indices reaching fresh records. The Singapore Stock Index (STI) ended the day 0.4% higher, but investors remained cautious due to tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Electric cars seen cheaper than gasoline models within a decade
summary: Researchers from Bloomberg New Energy Finance predict that battery-powered cars will be cheaper to buy than conventional gasoline models within a decade, with prices expected to fall by 77% by 2030. This decrease in battery costs will lead to lower upfront prices for electric vehicles (EVs) in the US and Europe by 2025, making them more competitive with gasoline models. Analysts from Renault and Tesla also predict that EVs will become more affordable, with total ownership costs expected to equal those of conventional internal combustion engine vehicles by the early 2020s.

images.alt_text: Battery powered cars will soon be cheaper to buy than conventional gasoline ones, offering immediate savings to drivers, new research shows.

site_title: Singapore factory output up 6.7% y-o-y in April on electronics surge
summary: Singapore's factory output rose 6.7% year-over-year in April, driven by a surge in electronics output. The electronics cluster, particularly semiconductors, saw a 48% increase, while the precision engineering cluster grew 15.7%. Biomedical manufacturing output shrank 23.3%, and transport engineering output contracted 14.5%. The overall industrial output beat the 6% consensus estimate, with March's output revised to 11%. The growth was largely due to the electronics sector's performance, which negated the decline in biomedical output.

images.alt_text: Singapore's electronics output continued its winning streak in April and negated biomedical's shrinkage to push overall factory output higher.

site_title: Fosun, others eye Australia's Origin Energy gas assets worth A$2 b
summary: Australia's energy retailer Origin Energy is attracting interest from potential bidders, including China's Fosun International, for A$2 billion worth of oil and gas assets. Origin plans to spin off the assets, valued at A$2 billion, as part of a debt-cutting strategy. The company, led by CEO Frank Calabria, is open to a trade sale, marking the country's largest oil and gas deal since Apache Corp's 2015 sale. Multiple bidders, including Fosun, have expressed interest in acquiring the assets.

site_title: Italy's 'Queen of Cashmere' Biagiotti dies aged 73
summary: Italian fashion designer Laura Biagiotti, known as the "Queen of Cashmere," has died at 73 after suffering brain damage from a heart attack. Biagiotti pioneered the marketing of cashmere products globally, particularly in China and the former Soviet Union. She began her career in 1965 and launched her first collection in 1972, playing a significant role in shifting Italy's fashion capital from Florence to Milan. Biagiotti's company uses 50,000 kilograms of cashmere annually and staged over 70 fashion shows per year, supporting the arts and sponsoring historic building restorations.

site_title: AirAsia's Fernandes says it'd be 'foolish' not to consider C919
summary: AirAsia CEO Tony Fernandes suggests the airline may consider the Chinese-made C919 aircraft as it expands its fleet and destinations. Fernandes stated it would be "foolish" not to look at new planes, following similar comments from IAG SA's CEO Willie Walsh. The C919 has garnered commitments from 23 customers for approximately 570 units, taking its maiden flight on May 5. AirAsia plans to add 29 planes to its fleet by the end of 2017, following a 30% drop in first-quarter net income.

images.alt_text: "I think as an airline you have to look at everything," AirAsia Group Chief Executive Officer Tony Fernandes said in a Bloomberg Television interview, when asked whether the carrier would consider the C919.

site_title: London's hottest home markets suffer price cuts
summary: London's hottest home markets, including peripheral boroughs such as Barking & Dagenham and Newham, are experiencing significant price cuts due to affordability issues. Sellers are being forced to reduce prices as buyers struggle to afford the average £680,607 price tag. This trend is attributed to the 82% surge in home prices over the past decade, outpacing wage growth and leading to a correction in the market. Experts predict that prices in the capital will stagnate this year before rising 3% in 2018.

site_title: GM accused in owner lawsuit of using VW-like defeat devices
summary: General Motors (GM) is being sued by owners of over 705,000 Duramax diesel trucks for allegedly installing defeat devices to cheat on emissions tests. The 190-page complaint, filed in Detroit federal court, claims GM installed the devices in heavy-duty trucks from 2011 to 2016, allowing them to pass US inspections while emitting up to 5 times the legal limit. The lawsuit asserts environmental damage comparable to Volkswagen's emissions cheating scandal, which led to a $25 billion settlement.

site_title: Flat Q4 profits for Cortina Holdings
summary: Cortina Holdings reported flat Q4 profits of S$3.8 million, with revenue expanding 13.4% to S$106.1 million. Earnings per share rose to 7.1 Singapore cents from 5.1 cents in the previous year. The company's fourth-quarter net profit was unchanged from the year-ago period.

site_title: Tuan Sing sets issue price of S$120m notes
summary: Tuan Sing Holdings priced its S$120 million 6% notes due 2020 at 100% of the principal amount, with interest payable semi-annually. The notes will be issued in denominations of S$250,000 and used for property development, investment, and general corporate purposes. DBS Bank and UOB have been appointed as joint lead managers and joint bookrunners for the issue, which will be issued under Tuan Sing's S$900 million multicurrency medium-term note programme on June 5.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: China's bicycle renaissance is no boon to biggest manufacturers
summary: China's bicycle-sharing phenomenon is disrupting the industry, forcing major manufacturers to adapt. Listed manufacturers, including Giant Manufacturing Co and Shanghai Phoenix Enterprise Group Co, are struggling as their sales decline amid the rise of bike-sharing services. These companies are now seeking cooperation with rental firms, which are relying on smaller manufacturers to supply basic models at a low cost. Analysts predict that big bike manufacturers will need to reorient their production towards low-end models, but long-term, bike-sharing is expected to boost sales of high-end vehicles.

site_title: Aussie stocks dive on weak commodity prices; NZ recoups losses
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.66% to 5,751.7, driven by a downturn in commodity prices, particularly oil. BHP Billiton, the world's largest miner, slid 3.8% due to falling oil and iron ore prices. Despite the decline, the index rose 0.38% on a weekly basis. Opec's modest extension of output curbs disappointed investors, leading to a sharp slide in BHP Billiton's share price.

site_title: Republican wins Montana special election despite assault charge
summary: Republican candidate Greg Gianforte won Montana's special election for the US House of Representatives, defeating Democrat Rob Quist, despite being charged with misdemeanor assault on a reporter. Gianforte led by about 50% to 44% with 75% of the vote counted, and the outcome was not affected by the charge. Gianforte's victory is seen as a boost for Republicans, who are concerned about the impact of the healthcare bill on their chances in next year's elections.

site_title: Trump condemns leaks after UK police briefly halt information sharing
summary: President Donald Trump has condemned "deeply troubling" leaks to US media about the Manchester suicide bombing, calling for an investigation and prosecution of the culprit. British police briefly stopped sharing information with US agencies after the leaks, but resumed sharing after receiving "fresh assurances". The leaks, which included sensitive details about the investigation, were widely criticized by British authorities, who emphasized the importance of keeping intelligence secure. The attack on the Manchester Arena killed 22 people, and police are holding eight suspects in custody.

site_title: Evergrande Group gets into health-care business to boost profit
summary: China Evergrande Group, one of the country's most indebted developers, is expanding into the healthcare industry to boost profits. The company has invested in a luxury plastic surgery hospital and plans to build more medical facilities, including cancer hospitals and health-management centers. The move aims to capitalize on cheaper land prices for healthcare use, generating revenue from medical services and increasing housing prices. This strategy is seen as a way for developers to diversify their revenue streams as the property market is expected to slow down.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars seen with large weekly gains vs pound
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars saw significant weekly gains against the British pound, despite a commodities rout on Friday. The Australian dollar fell to US$0.7431, its weakest this week, after crude oil prices tumbled 5% and iron ore prices slid. The Aussie is on track for a hefty weekly gain against the pound, while the New Zealand dollar also rose.

site_title: SBI said to pick BofA, Deutsche Bank for US$2b offering
summary: State Bank of India (SBI), India's largest lender, has selected Bank of America Corp and Deutsche Bank AG to arrange a US$2 billion share sale, with IIFL Holdings Ltd, Kotak Mahindra Bank Ltd, and SBI Capital Markets Ltd also involved in the offering. SBI aims to bolster loan growth after a fourth-quarter profit more than doubled, amid a surging soured-debt ratio. The share sale, which could raise up to S$3.21 billion, is part of SBI's plan to raise up to S$3.21 billion through various methods, including an institutional share sale and rights offering.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks flat ahead of holidays; TSMC dips
summary: Taiwan's stocks remained flat on Friday ahead of a long weekend holiday, influenced by a 0.5% decline in Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC). The main Taiex index was unchanged at 10,112.38 points, marking a 17-year high reached earlier this month. The Taiwan dollar softened to NT$30.087 per US dollar. The markets will be closed on Monday and Tuesday for the Dragon Boat festival holidays.

site_title: Singapore Royal Group sells Sydney hotel for about A$140m
summary: Singapore's Royal Group sold InterContinental Sydney Double Bay to Zobon Real Estate Group and Shanghai United Real Estate Inc for approximately A$140 million, a record price for a non-CBD hotel in Australia. Royal Group had purchased the vacant property in 2013 for about A$60 million.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Seoul: Stocks at another record high; won flat on oil price drop
summary: South Korea's Kospi index reached a record high, closing at 2,350.15 points, with a 0.3% gain from the previous day. The index has posted its largest weekly percentage gain since mid-March, driven by the Bank of Korea's bullish outlook on the economy and the Wall Street's overnight close higher. Investors are optimistic about the Kospi's potential for further gains, with some predicting it could reach 2,450 this year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down slightly by 0.37 points to 1773.90. Volume was 55 million lots worth RM27.8 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 118 to 84.

site_title: China's latest default flags debt concerns raised by Moody's
summary: China's Dalian Machine Tool Group Corp defaulted on a 543 million yuan bond, citing rising borrowing costs and increasing debt concerns. Moody's Investors Service downgraded China's credit rating to A1, citing growing economy-wide debt. Defaults in China's local public bond market have increased, with 13 defaults this year, and Moody's forecasts debt to continue to rise. The default highlights concerns about China's corporate debt load, which President Xi Jinping is trying to manage without sparking economic growth issues.

site_title: Vanguard starts new China unit as fund management market expands
summary: Vanguard Group has established a wholly foreign owned enterprise in Shanghai, China, as the investment management market expands. The new unit aims to better serve clients in the growing market, which has seen increased openness to foreign investors. This move follows Fidelity International's recent launch of a private fund in Shanghai, and comes as China aims to develop a more sophisticated retail investor base. The expansion is seen as part of China's efforts to promote global use of the yuan and increase capital flow.

site_title: Global deal on Basel bank capital rules is seen within reach
summary: Global regulators are close to agreeing on Basel III bank capital rules, a deal that has been in the works for over a year. The Basel Committee on Banking Supervision has made progress on restrictions, including a key curb to ensure big banks accurately assess risks. The US has defended the measure, known as an output floor, while European and Japanese regulators have opposed it, citing it would punish their banks. Discussions continue, but regulators are optimistic that the deal will be concluded soon, with a key hurdle being the calibration of the output floor.

site_title: America great again in wheat after its exports overtake Russia's
summary: The US has regained its position as the world's largest wheat exporter, surpassing Russia for the first time in three years. The US's dominance is attributed to a weaker US dollar, which made American grain cheaper for overseas buyers, particularly in Egypt. The US is expected to ship 28.2 million metric tons of wheat, 34% more than the previous season, while Russia is forecast to ship 28 million tons. This shift is seen as a result of the FBI investigation into Russia's ties with President Trump's aides, which weakened the greenback and boosted US wheat exports.

site_title: Samsung Elec to set up fund to help suppliers amid Moon's reform push
summary: Samsung Electronics Co Ltd plans to set up a 500 billion won (S$619.2 million) fund to help small suppliers amid President Moon Jae-in's reform push. The fund will provide interest-free loans for a year to help suppliers pay subcontractors promptly. This move comes as Moon has promised to protect small businesses, discourage contract jobs, and raise the minimum wage. Other South Korean firms, including the National Agricultural Cooperative Federation and SK Broadband, have also announced plans to make temporary workers regular employees.

site_title: Australian stocks slip on oil, metals; NZ down
summary: Australian stocks fell 0.71% on Friday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index dropping 41.13 points to 5,748.5, due to a decline in commodity prices, particularly oil, after OPEC's output curbs extension disappointed investors. Oil prices tumbled 5% and iron ore futures slumped 4%, leading to losses for energy and mining companies. Other sectors, including financials and Telstra, also declined. Despite this, an equity strategist predicts a positive end to the month for Australian shares.

site_title: EU offers post-Brexit rights to Britons in Europe
summary: The European Union has proposed protecting the welfare and residence rights of British citizens living in Europe after Brexit, with a draft paper outlining the extent of these rights. The EU aims to safeguard the rights of 3 million EU citizens in the UK, while also reciprocating for over 1 million British expatriates. The proposal includes guarantees for EU citizens in the UK, their families, and those acquiring rights later, such as residence, work, and family allowances. EU leaders insist these rights must be negotiated in detail for them to have any legal value.

site_title: Bechtel, Fluor said to prepare bids for southern nuclear project
summary: Bechtel Corp and Fluor Corp are preparing bids to take over construction of two nuclear reactors at Southern Co's Vogtle plant in Georgia, potentially replacing Toshiba's bankrupt Westinghouse Electric Co unit. The project has been plagued by delays and cost overruns, with Southern estimating $7.75 billion in costs. The companies' bids are expected to be submitted by August, beyond a June 3 deadline, and could impact the fate of the project. Southern's CEO Tom Fanning said the company would likely decide on the project's future in August.

site_title: Commodity currencies nurse losses after oil slumps; pound falters
summary: Commodity currencies declined on Friday after oil prices tumbled 5% due to Opec's decision to extend oil output cuts by nine months. The pound fell 0.3% to US$1.2908, while the Canadian and Australian dollars also lost value. The US dollar gained some respite due to the Federal Reserve's cautious approach to reducing its balance sheet, but its underlying trend remains weak.

images.alt_text: Sterling slipped after an opinion poll showed that Britain's opposition Labour Party has cut the lead of Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservatives to five points ahead of a June 8 national election.

site_title: Trump shames Nato allies on defense spending as unity tested
summary: US President Donald Trump publicly shamed NATO allies for not meeting their defense spending obligations, stating that 23 of the 28 member nations are not paying their "fair share." Trump cited the Manchester terrorist attack and said that if NATO members had lived up to their obligations, the US would have had $119 billion more. Despite this, NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg said that Trump has been clear on his commitment to the alliance's collective defense clause, but also on his expectations for fair burden sharing.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower
