summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index slipping 0.11% to 19,790.70, due to a disappointing Opec decision not to deepen output cuts. Energy shares led the decline. This move followed similar disappointments in other markets, where investors brushed off new Trump threats to extend stocks rally.

site_title: A snapshot of contemporary Mexican cinema
summary: The Mexican Film Festival is set to return at The Projector in Singapore with its third edition, featuring five handpicked films showcasing the diversity and talent in contemporary Mexican cinema. The festival includes tense socio-political thriller "Desierto", romantic drama "You'll Know What To Do With Me", and other notable works such as "Gueros" and "Mr Pig". The event highlights the rise of Mexican cinema and provides a snapshot of the country's newest films.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Manhattan luxury-home sellers getting the message: cut the price
summary: Manhattan luxury home sellers are cutting prices to attract buyers. According to Olshan Realty Inc, the median asking price for luxury homes priced over $4 million has dropped to $4,997,500, the lowest in five years. This represents an 8% average price cut, the largest in six years. The increase in luxury home contracts is 18% compared to the same period last year, with buyers taking advantage of discounted prices to close deals.

site_title: Singapore shares open 7 points down
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened 7.26 points lower at 3,227.11, despite a strong showing in US stocks, which closed at record highs overnight. The weak opening comes despite robust US earnings reports from retailers.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Brazil's JBS to hold first board meeting after scandal
summary: Brazil's JBS SA, the world's largest meatpacker, holds its first board meeting since owners admitted to bribing politicians. The plea-bargain testimony of JBS executives, including brothers Joesley and Wesley Batista, sparked a crisis threatening to topple Brazilian President Michel Temer. Minority shareholders demand the brothers' resignation, citing the company's financial burden. JBS shares have dropped 13.6% since the scandal's release. The company is negotiating a leniency agreement with prosecutors, but minority shareholders refuse to pay the US$1.2 billion fine.

site_title: Trump son-in-law Kushner under FBI scrutiny in Russia probe: media reports
summary: President Donald Trump's son-in-law Jared Kushner, a senior White House adviser, is under FBI scrutiny in the Russia probe due to his interactions with Russians, including the Russian ambassador and a Moscow banker. It's unclear if Kushner has been requested for records. This investigation is part of the ongoing probe into Russia's alleged interference in the 2016 US presidential election.

site_title: Billionaire Slim eyeing electric taxi to reduce pollution in Mexico City
summary: Mexican billionaire Carlos Slim's automaker Giant Motors is developing an electric taxi prototype to reduce pollution in Mexico City. The company, in partnership with Moldex and four Mexican universities, aims to produce a fast-charging electric vehicle to replace the city's gas-guzzling cabs. The project is part of Slim's efforts to address air quality issues in Mexico City, which has been plagued by poor air quality and health warnings. Giant Motors plans to launch the electric taxis this year, with a goal of eventually replacing part of Mexico City's 130,000 registered cabs.

site_title: Ex-Google exec gets US$500m from STC for Mideast tech deals
summary: Saudi Telecom Co has created a $500 million technology fund, STV, to be run by ex-Google executive Abdulrahman Tarabzouni, focusing on areas like AI and virtual reality. The fund aims to make investments over the next four to five years, with the first deal potentially completed by the end of the year. This move comes as investor interest in the Middle East's technology industry increases, following deals such as Amazon's $580 million purchase of Souq.com and Dubai-based tycoon Mohamed Alabbar's $1 billion investment in e-commerce company Noon.

site_title: 13 years after quitting, Zuckerberg gets (honorary) Harvard degree
summary: Mark Zuckerberg, 33, received an honorary doctor of laws degree from Harvard University 13 years after dropping out in 2004 to work on Facebook. In his commencement speech, Zuckerberg urged graduates to "build great things" and create a world where everyone has a sense of purpose. He highlighted themes of equality, inclusiveness, and opportunity, and called for creative solutions to social problems, including universal basic income and a new social contract.

site_title: US: Stocks scale new peaks on retailer results; oil falls
summary: US stocks reached new peaks on Thursday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite indexes closing at record highs, driven by strong earnings reports from retailers such as PVH Corp and Sears. Oil prices plummeted 5.7% to $48.45 a barrel after OPEC agreed to extend output cuts for nine months, disappointing some investors. European shares were little changed, while the US dollar remained steady against major currencies. The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed up 0.34% at 21,082.95.

site_title: UK PM May's lead cut two weeks before election: poll
summary: Britain's opposition Labour Party has narrowed Prime Minister Theresa May's lead to 5 points in a poll released just days before the June 8 national election. The YouGov poll shows May's Conservatives on 43% and Labour on 38%, down from a 9-point lead in a previous poll. The election was suspended after a suicide bombing in Manchester, and May's party has been hurt by the fallout from her manifesto launch. May's personal favorability ratings have risen, while Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn's ratings have fallen by 8 points.

site_title: BT Weekend examines the reselling phenomenon
summary: BT Weekend examines the reselling phenomenon, where items like limited edition sneakers and concert tickets are sold at inflated prices. The market's growth and implications are discussed, but the article does not provide a detailed analysis or conclusions.

site_title: Moody's downgrades Hong Kong's credit ratings on China links
summary: Moody's downgraded Hong Kong's credit ratings to Aa2 from Aa1, citing China's expected economic slowdown and rising debt. The downgrade, which has no significant impact on Hong Kong's short-term, reflects the city's financial and institutional strengths. Hong Kong's government criticized Moody's for overlooking the city's sound economic fundamentals, while analysts noted that Hong Kong's strong fiscal position and large surpluses minimize the downgrade's implications. The move follows Moody's downgrade of China's credit ratings for the first time in nearly 30 years.

site_title: Japan core CPI rises for 4th straight month
summary: Japan's core consumer prices rose 0.3% in April, marking a fourth consecutive month of increases, but largely due to fading energy price falls. Core CPI, excluding fresh food prices, was flat from a year ago. The Bank of Japan's efforts to reach its 2% inflation target remain challenging. Despite a robust economy, inflation remains distant, and analysts expect the BOJ to reduce monetary stimulus in the near future. The economy showed signs of life, with exports and private consumption driving growth, but weak household spending and corporate pricing power keep inflation around zero.

site_title: Two more properties sold en bloc; deals total S$676.5m
summary: Two en bloc sales in Singapore have taken place in quick succession, totaling S$676.5 million. Oxley Holdings' consortium bought Rio Casa for S$575m, while a BBR Holdings unit acquired Goh & Goh Building for S$101.5m. These deals follow the sale of One Tree Hill Gardens in May, showing signs of a pick-up in the en bloc market. The success of these deals may encourage more sites to attempt en bloc sales, but the sustainability of the recovery depends on the reserve price being reasonable.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Accordia Golf Trust reported a 5% drop in operating income to 9.91 billion yen (S$123 million) in its fourth quarter, due to heavy snowfall in Japan and a lack of income refund. The trust's net loss widened to 2.79 billion yen, from 744 million yen a year ago. Meanwhile, OCBC's incoming CEO, Tan Teck Long, previously worked at DBS, and Helen Wong will retire as OCBC CEO. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: More clarity needed on how Reit investors can review managers
summary: A group of Sabana Real Estate Investment Trust (Reit) unitholders attempted to oust the Reit manager in April, but failed to get the required votes due to a lack of support from majority shareholders and no credible alternative management team. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) rules require a manager to have at least three full-time representatives with significant experience, making it challenging to find a suitable replacement. The unitholders' efforts provided a precedent for future shareholder activism, and the MAS is advised to provide guidance on steps unitholders can take to review a Reit's management team.

site_title: Postcards from China's past
summary: German artist Ulrike Ottinger traveled to China in the 1980s to capture intimate moments of everyday life, resulting in thousands of photographs and a handful of documentaries. The works, now on display at the NTU Centre for Contemporary Art Singapore, showcase a side of China fast disappearing as it rapidly modernizes. Ottinger's film practice, which explores the relationship between still life photography and cinema, has been influential in feminist cinephile circles, and her work has undergone a reevaluation 30 years after its initial release.

images.alt_text: Ottinger captured thousands of unguarded moments like these in various parts of China in the 1980s and 1990s. This work is titled Train.
Exile Shanghai shows the details of everyday life. Ottinger feels images like these are fleeting as China rushes towards urbanisation.
Ottinger is fascinated with the traditional aspects of China, such as Kun Opera.
Ottinger, 74, has created a large body of work that includes films, photos, magazine illustrations, postcards and other media.
Helmi Yusof

site_title: Singapore corporate, leisure visitors to UK unfazed by Manchester attack
summary: Singapore corporate and leisure travelers remain unaffected by the Manchester terrorist attack, with many still planning to visit the UK. Despite a raised terror threat, travel agencies report no significant changes in bookings, with some even seeing an increase in interest in certain destinations due to favorable exchange rates. Many travelers are adopting a "carry-on-as-normal" mentality, and demand for travel to the UK has not been significantly impacted by recent terrorist attacks. Some travel agencies have seen bookings for alternative destinations, such as Scandinavia and the Balkans, increase.

images.alt_text: Corporate and leisure travellers in Singapore are still headed to the United Kingdom despite the higher-level alert following Monday's terrorist attack in Manchester.
Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: MTI hints at a higher floor for Singapore's 2017 growth
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to clock its fastest growth rate in three years, driven by a stronger global outlook, according to the Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI). The MTI hinted at full-year growth potentially exceeding 2%, surpassing last year's 2% growth. Economists, however, warn that the Q1 growth rate of 2.7% may be the peak for the year, with lower growth rates expected in the next three quarters. External risks, including China's credit rating downgrade and global trade uncertainty, may also impact Singapore's growth.

site_title: Singapore well placed to be a global currency centre
summary: Singapore has established itself as a global currency centre, driven by its business-friendly policies, reliable infrastructure, and well-educated workforce. The country's financial services sector has grown significantly over the last 30 years, with a large influx of liquidity in foreign currency. Singapore is home to major commodity trading companies, multinational corporations, and is a hub for regional treasury centres, fueling liquidity flows. The country's USD liquidity is expected to remain advantageous due to its position as a strong private wealth centre and major banking hub, with banks providing innovative solutions enabled by technology.

site_title: Europe: Shares sputter near highs but Opec disappointment hits oil stocks
summary: European shares struggled near highs on Thursday, influenced by an Opec meeting that failed to boost oil prices, causing a 4% drop in energy stocks. Despite a strong earnings season, investors have become cautious, with some fund managers downgrading their exposure to euro zone stocks. Key indices, such as the Stoxx and DAX, fell 0.06% and 0.17% respectively, while some companies reported positive results, including Intermediate Capital Group and GVC Holdings. The next focus for investors will be the US Federal Reserve, the ECB meeting, and the UK's general election.

site_title: US Fed: Next rate hike will be soon
summary: US Federal Reserve officials say they will "soon" raise interest rates, but may delay the move to assess if weak growth earlier this year was temporary. The decision comes as planned spending by President Trump's administration could boost the economy, but also raises concerns over potential missteps and increased financial risks. Analysts still expect two more rate increases this year, with the next meeting potentially delayed until after June.

site_title: Optimism among South Korean consumers hits a 3-year high in May
summary: South Korean consumers turned more optimistic in May, with the Bank of Korea's composite consumer sentiment index reaching a 3-year high of 108.0, surpassing the highest level since 2014. This improvement comes after the election of liberal President Moon Jae-in, who promised to add 500,000 jobs per year during his term. The median expectation for inflation over the next 12 months decreased to 2.5%, below the central bank's target of 2.0%. The optimism is seen as a result of President Moon's job creation priorities and stimulus budget plans.

images.alt_text: South Korean consumers turned more optimistic in May than they have been for more than three years, a central bank survey showed on Friday, after the new president made job creation the priority and announced plans for a stimulus budget.

site_title: Oil plunges 5% on disappointment with Opec cuts
summary: Oil prices plummeted 5% on Thursday as Opec and other producers agreed to extend supply cuts by 1.8 million barrels per day until the end of 2018, disappointing investors who had hoped for deeper cuts to drain a global glut of crude supplies. Brent crude settled at $51.46 a barrel, its biggest percentage decline since March 8, and US West Texas intermediate crude futures ended at $48.90 a barrel, breaking below $50 for the first time all week. The cuts are seen as insufficient to balance the market, with some predicting a continued decline in prices.

site_title: Opec meeting weighs on commodity currencies
summary: The Canadian, Australian, and New Zealand dollars fell due to a drop in oil prices as Opec countries are expected to maintain current production cuts. The US dollar fell 0.1% against the index, while the Canadian dollar rose to a one-month high before losing gains. The Norwegian crown also fell initially but recovered. Analysts attribute the market's reaction to short-term dollar movements and the Opec meeting, with some positioning for a potential nine-month extension of oil production cuts.

site_title: Wine is about people
summary: A writer shares their experience with two white burgundies from Domaine Leflaive, a renowned winery in Burgundy, France. The 1983 Puligny-Montrachet 1er cru Clavoillon and the 2008 Puligny-Montrachet 1er cru Les Folatieres were tasted and found to be outstanding, with the 1983 wine still at its peak 34 years after release. The writer reflects on the domaine's legacy, led by the late Vincent Leflaive, and the significance of wine in bringing people together, as he notes that "wine is about people."

site_title: Updated: Noble Group dealt fresh blow as Fitch cuts its ratings yet again
summary: Fitch Ratings has cut Noble Group's rating for a second time in 10 days, citing concerns over its ability to address $2 billion of debt maturing over the next 12 months. The rating cut comes after the company's shares and bonds plunged following S&P Global Ratings' warning of a potential default within a year. Noble Group is in talks with banks to renew a borrowing base facility, but Fitch expects the banks to do so on less favorable terms. The company's shares have lost over 70% this year, and Morgan Stanley has emerged as a major shareholder with a 7.95% stake.

images.alt_text: Noble Group Ltd received a fresh blow as Fitch Ratings Ltd cut the embattled commodity trader's rating for a second time in the space of 10 days, flagging concern over its ability to address about US$2 billion of debt that matures over the next 12 months.

site_title: US lawmakers to fight massive Trump Saudi arms deal
summary: US lawmakers introduced legislation to block part of President Donald Trump's massive arms deal with Saudi Arabia, worth up to $350 billion over 10 years. The deal includes precision-guided munitions and other offensive weapons, with lawmakers aiming to stop about $500 million of the sale. The move comes amid concerns over Saudi Arabia's human rights record and its involvement in the Yemen conflict. The Senate Foreign Relations Committee will review the sale, following a similar resolution last year that was defeated. The lawmakers argue that selling arms to Saudi Arabia is not in the US's best national security interest.

images.alt_text: US lawmakers introduced legislation on Thursday seeking to stop at least a portion of President Donald Trump's sale of weapons to Saudi Arabia.

site_title: Developers, contractors must stop enmity: study
summary: A McKinsey & Company study found that adversarial contracts between developers and construction firms hinder productivity growth in the construction sector globally. The study identified Singapore as a laggard in construction sector labor productivity, despite rapid improvement. The main impediments to productivity growth are a lack of upfront planning and design, and misaligned incentives in adversarial contract regimes. McKinsey proposes a shift towards collaborative tender processes based on value, design, or long-term costs, rather than just construction costs.

site_title: Manufacturing growth surpasses 6.6% forecast, steady growth expected for electronics
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector grew 8% in Q1 2017, driven by the electronics and precision engineering clusters, which saw 33% and 19% increases, respectively. However, the sector contracted 1.5% on a quarter-on-quarter basis. Services-producing industries also showed signs of growth, with a 1.6% year-on-year increase, driven by the transportation and storage sector. Despite the positive indicators, economists warn that the manufacturing rally may be coming to an end due to weakening global consumer demand and private sector construction activities.

site_title: Indonesian police probe Islamic State involvement in bus station blasts
summary: Indonesian police are investigating a twin blast at a Jakarta bus station that killed three police officers and wounded six others, linking it to the Islamic State (ISIS) militant group. The attack, which occurred five minutes apart, is the deadliest in Indonesia since 2016. Authorities believe the attackers were inspired by ISIS and may have been linked to Jemaah Ansharut Daulah, a US-listed terrorist organization. The incident follows a surge in radicalism in Indonesia, with hundreds of Indonesians estimated to have joined ISIS in Syria.

site_title: Advice for Trump from Europe
summary: US President Donald Trump's presidency is facing turmoil, prompting advice from European leaders. Trump may benefit from changing course and cooperating with special counsel Robert Mueller to address allegations of Russian collusion. European leaders, such as Angela Merkel and Theresa May, have reversed policy decisions, emphasizing the importance of adaptability. Trump should also be cautious of the secret service and maintain a strong dollar to support his "America First" economics, as a strong dollar will benefit his economic policies.

site_title: Is BMW's Motorsport heading to Alexandra Rd?
summary: BMW's high-performance M models may relocate from Jurong to Alexandra Road in Singapore, potentially boosting sales. The move comes after BMW Group Asia appointed Munich Automobiles Pte Ltd as the sole distributor for BMW M vehicles and accessories. The change in shareholding and relocation could signal sufficient potential for the M business to be established in the prime motor belt area.

site_title: Muddy Waters: Noble will probably have to be restructured
summary: NOBLE Group, a Hong Kong-based commodity trader, is likely to undergo restructuring due to significant losses and credit-rating downgrades. The company's book value is less than zero, according to Muddy Waters LLC founder Carson Block, who has previously shorted Noble. The crisis has been ongoing for over two years, with the company facing asset sales, attacks from shortsellers, and a recent first-quarter loss. Ratings agencies, including S&P Global Ratings, have flagged a potential default within a year, prompting a rout in Noble's bonds and shares.

site_title: New Zealand unveils tax-cutting election-year budget for families
summary: New Zealand's ruling National Party unveiled a tax-cutting budget for families ahead of the election, benefiting around 1.3 million families with an average NZ$26 weekly increase. The budget includes a NZ$2.0 billion family incomes package to help families with young children and those struggling with high housing costs. However, the financial gains are delayed until April next year, sparking criticism from opposition Labour Party leader Andrew Little, who said it was a "one dollar bill budget" that didn't address the country's housing shortage.

site_title: An Italian food hall opens, sans the cheese
summary: Eataly, an Italian food hall chain, has finally opened its Moscow location after a two-year delay due to a European food embargo imposed by President Vladimir Putin in 2014. The 30,000-square-foot hall, which can seat 950 diners, offers a range of Italian products, including San Marzano tomatoes, pizza, and Lavazza coffee, but excludes Italian cheeses and meats due to trade sanctions. Despite the challenges, Eataly aims to generate 60% of its revenue from restaurants and 40% from shops, with an average ticket price of 1,200 roubles (S$30) per person.

site_title: Embattled Sports Hub chief exits top job
summary: Manu Sawhney, chief of the Singapore Sports Hub, has resigned with immediate effect, following a week of uncertainty. Oon Jin Teik, the hub's chief operating officer, has been appointed as acting CEO for an unspecified period. Sawhney's departure marks a significant change in leadership for the hub, which has been facing challenges in recent years. The exact reasons for Sawhney's resignation are not specified, but his departure has led to a shake-up in the organization's management structure.

images.alt_text: Mr Oon (above) has been appointed as acting CEO following Mr Sawhney's resignation.
Lee U-Wen

site_title: Building trade divided over productivity, measures
summary: A recent study by the Singapore Contractors Association Limited (SCAL) and the Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce and Industry (SCCCI) found that construction companies in Singapore have differing opinions on what constitutes productivity and how to measure it. The study, which surveyed 110 out of 3,032 members, recommended that companies adopt better project planning and management practices, measure productivity at trade, project, and firm levels, and set corporate and project targets to monitor performance. The study also found that many firms do not have productivity policies and that the government needs to devise better policies to enable firms to improve productivity performance.

site_title: Maybank's Q1 profit rises 19%
summary: Malaysia's largest lender, Maybank, reported a 19% jump in first-quarter net profit to RM1.7 billion, exceeding analyst estimates. The bank's loans grew 10.1% and net interest margin improved to 2.43%. A restructuring of troubled loans last year helped cut impairment losses by 38.2%. Maybank expects loan growth of 6-7% for 2017, benefiting from a strengthening domestic economy and recovery in commodity prices.

images.alt_text: Maybank reported on Thursday a net profit of RM1.7 billion (S$550.2 million) for January-March compared to RM1.43 billion a year ago.

site_title: A meeting with giants
summary: A special concert celebrating the inaugural Lion City Youth Jazz Festival will take place this weekend, featuring the mentorship of international jazz legends Benny Golson and Fritz K Renold, alongside local jazz musicians Jeremy Monteiro, Melissa Tham, and Alemay Fernandez. The event aims to nurture young talent and develop skills through bandstand learning, a concept that immerses young musicians in a professional environment. The concert will showcase original compositions and arrangements, with a focus on local and international jazz music.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Relief and sorrow as Geely gets behind Proton's wheel
summary: Malaysia's national car manufacturer Proton has been sold to China's Zhejiang Geely Holding Group Co Ltd in a 49.9% stake deal. The sale, valued at RM1.54 billion, is expected to inject capital and life into the floundering local car manufacturer. Geely will also acquire 51% of Lotus from Proton. The deal has sparked relief among Malaysians frustrated at propping up Proton, but sorrow from Proton's originator, former Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, who lamented the loss of the national car.

site_title: US merchandise trade gap widened to US$67.6b in April
summary: US merchandise trade gap widened to $67.6 billion in April, exceeding the median forecast of $64.5 billion. This represents a 3.8% increase from the previous month. The trade deficit contributed to a slower-than-expected first-quarter GDP growth of 1.82 percentage points.

site_title: CSR may have to go beyond just gestures
summary: Shell's CSR efforts have been met with criticism, with local communities accusing the company of greenwashing and unethical business practices. In contrast, Indorama Corporation has successfully integrated itself into local communities in Nigeria through a public-private partnership scheme, offering local community members a chance to become shareholders. This approach has led to a significant increase in community support and has helped the company avoid conflicts with local groups. Indorama's example suggests that CSR must go beyond mere gestures and involve unconditional concern for local well-being.

images.alt_text: Despite having invested millions in social investment projects in Nigeria, Shell has failed to win the hearts of the communities it operates in.

site_title: O&M sector's turnover down 11.3% last year
summary: Singapore's offshore and marine (O&M) industry experienced a 11.3% decline in turnover to S$13.06 billion in 2016 due to a prolonged winter in oil prices. Shipbuilding and offshore rig-building sub-sectors were significantly affected, with revenue declines of 31% and 13.4% respectively. Despite the downturn, Asmi president Chua San Lye described the industry's performance as "respectable" and called for players to improve operational efficiency and utilize current market lull to mitigate manpower constraints.

site_title: The thrill is definitely gone from this blockbuster franchise
summary: The latest Pirates of the Caribbean film, Salazar's Revenge, fails to recapture the franchise's former magic, with a lackluster storyline and reduced excitement. Despite a massive budget, the movie lacks the thrilling action sequences and memorable characters that defined earlier installments. The film attempts to revive its mojo by incorporating popular characters and a romantic subplot, but ultimately falls flat. With diminishing returns and a tired formula, the franchise may be nearing the end of its run.

site_title: India to build 9.2km bridge along troubled border with China
summary: India is set to open its 9.2km bridge across the Brahmaputra River, spanning the disputed border with China, to ensure smooth movement of troops and resources to Arunachal Pradesh. The bridge is part of a series of infrastructure projects aimed at asserting India's dominance in the region. Analysts believe the bridge will provide a strategic advantage for the Indian military, enabling quick movement of resources in case of a conflict. The move is seen as a significant shift in India's approach to its border with China, which has led to tensions and disputes over the years.

site_title: EY survey shows up irony in millennial employees and ethical behaviour
summary: EY survey reveals millennials in Singapore are more likely to engage in unethical behavior, despite valuing ethics and reputation. 69% of millennials say they would leave a company involved in bribery or corruption. Millennials struggle to identify unethical behavior, but prioritize compliance and good reputation when choosing a workplace. 92% agree that compliance culture is crucial, but existing policies are marred by lack of clarity and consistency, impacting morale and business performance.

site_title: Property development income helps Stamford Land return to the black in Q4
summary: Stamford Land Corporation Ltd reported a net profit of S$8.93 million for the fourth quarter, reversing a net loss of S$5 million a year ago, driven by a surge in property development income. Revenue more than doubled to S$166 million, led by a S$101.35 million increase from the property development segment. The group expects to remain profitable in 2018 and proposed a final dividend of one cent per share.

site_title: An Odd Couple story set in an English garden
summary: A contemporary fairy tale "This Beautiful Fantastic" tells the story of Bella Brown, an obsessive-compulsive recluse who transforms her neglected garden into a haven with the help of her gruff but kind neighbor Alfie. As they work together, Bella overcomes her fears and blossoms as a person, while Alfie becomes her mentor. The film features a charming performance from Jessica Brown Findlay and Tom Wilkinson, and explores themes of friendship, growth, and self-discovery.

site_title: Chinese group buys world's No 2 condom maker
summary: A Chinese consortium, Humanwell Healthcare Group Co Ltd and CITIC Capital China Partners, has acquired Ansell Ltd's condom division for $600 million. The move is driven by increasing demand for condoms in China, where sex is becoming less taboo. Ansell, an Australian firm, is exiting its non-core consumer business to focus on industrial and medical rubber products. The deal marks Ansell's second-largest division sold, with Reckitt Benckiser's Durex being the largest.

site_title: Fresh momentum for freer trade and investment must be sustained
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to grow better than last year's due to a stronger global growth outlook, despite uncertainties from Brexit and US policy flip-flops. However, recent developments in free trade and investment offer positive signs, including China's One-Belt-One-Road initiative, the EU-Singapore Free Trade Agreement's progress, and the remaining TPP countries' agreement to move forward. These developments underscore the need for sustained momentum in freer trade and investment, and governments must continue to build on these early gains to overcome obstacles.

site_title: World's first cyborg can hear colours
summary: Neil Harbisson, 34, is the world's first legally recognized cyborg, having an implanted antenna to "hear" colors due to his color blindness. He spoke at the ArtScience Museum about being a cyborg and the Cyborg Foundation, which he established. This technology allows him to perceive colors through electromagnetic signals, giving him a unique experience of the world. Harbisson aims to raise awareness about his condition and promote understanding of the Cyborg Foundation's mission to enhance human abilities through biomechatronic body parts.

site_title: China's packaged-food sector looks abroad
summary: China's packaged-food sector is shifting its focus to overseas deals due to domestic supply shortages, with companies like Tingyi (Cayman Islands) Holding Corp investing in customer education and food science to promote healthier options. The company aims to "premium up" with its Chinese consumers, seeking to make its instant noodles comparable to those found in noodle shops. This move is part of a broader trend in the industry, with companies looking to adapt to changing consumer preferences and maintain revenue growth.

images.alt_text: The two-car train chugs out of Master Kong's Dream Exploration Park in eastern China, filled with children giddy from shooting cartoon cabbages to dunk in animated pots of instant noodles. Next stop: A factory churning out 4,000 packets of the real thing every minute.

site_title: US home prices website offering US$1m prize for improved algorithm
summary: Zillow, a US home prices website, is offering a $1 million prize for improving its algorithm, known as the Zestimate, which provides estimated home values. The algorithm's accuracy has improved from 14% error rate in 2006 to around 5% in 2017, but still carries significant errors. The contest aims to refine the algorithm, which currently uses data such as square footage, location, and comparable sales. The winner will be announced in the future, and Zillow emphasizes that its estimates should not be used for final pricing decisions, but rather as a conversation point between homeowners and real estate agents.

site_title: GM to cut jobs at international HQ in S'pore
summary: General Motors (GM) will cut approximately 130 jobs at its international headquarters in Singapore by the end of 2017, as part of its efforts to reduce exposure to unprofitable markets. The move is aimed at restructuring operations in India, Africa, and Singapore, with plans to stop selling Chevrolet-brand vehicles in India by the end of the year. The company has been focusing on narrowing its focus on China, North America, Latin America, and vehicle financing, after doubling down on profitability under CEO Mary Barra in 2014.

site_title: ComfortDelGro gets on board Ryde app for taxi booking service
summary: Ryde, a Singapore-based transport app, has partnered with ComfortDelGro, the country's largest taxi operator, to launch a taxi booking service on its app. The partnership will give users access to 16,000 ComfortDelGro taxis in addition to 30,000 private cars. The service, set to launch next week, will offer both flat fare and metered taxi trips, providing users with more choices. The partnership aims to improve user experience, build social capital, and provide a sustainable alternative to car-pooling, helping to solve congestion and pollution issues in cities.

site_title: Surbana Jurong, Safdie Architects team up on Asia-Pacific projects
summary: Surbana Jurong and Safdie Architects have formed a long-term partnership to collaborate on residential, commercial, and institutional projects in the Asia-Pacific region. The partnership, called "Safdie Surbana Jurong," combines Surbana's infrastructure capabilities with Safdie's design expertise. The first joint venture is an integrated resort in Da Nang, Vietnam, and will allow Surbana Jurong's younger architects and designers to learn from Moshe Safdie's team. The partnership aims to put people at the heart of architecture designs, aligning with Surbana Jurong's vision.

images.alt_text: The tie-up will allow Surbana's younger architects and designers to learn directly from Mr Safdie and his team. (From left) Mr Moshe Safdie, Surbana Jurong chairman Liew Mun Leong and Surbana Jurong group chief executive Wong Heang Fine.
Wong Shiying

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings' Q4 FY17 after-tax profits rose to S$24.1 million, driven by higher fair value gains on investment properties and improved gross profit margins. FY2017 revenues increased 11% to S$124.2 million, with 47% attributed to non-real estate businesses. The company remains cautiously optimistic about Myanmar's property market and plans to open its first KFC store in Mandalay in June.

site_title: Neo Group diversifies into food retail
summary: Neo Group, a Singaporean catering firm, has diversified into food retail and focused on profitability. The company reported a 181.1% increase in Q4 net profit to S$2.7 million and a 34.9% rise in revenue to S$48 million. Despite a 29% rise in full-year revenue, net profit fell 46% to S$3.3 million due to one-off items. Neo Group is expanding its Umi Sushi food retail business and automating processes in its food manufacturing segment. The company plans to shift from mergers and acquisitions to consolidating its businesses, focusing on profitability and building its service and branding.

site_title: S'pore Apple store offers creative sparks for tech, retail sectors
summary: Apple's first retail store in Singapore, Apple Orchard Road, has been designed to resemble a modern-day town square, offering free hands-on sessions, free Wi-Fi, and charging points. The two-storey premises, designed by Foster+Partners, features curved Castania stone staircases, a "Today at Apple" space for classes, and a boardroom for companies to use. The store's opening is seen as a boost to the tech, creative, and retail sectors in Singapore, with observers noting that it will give the Orchard Road shopping belt a fillip and provide a new immersive experiential touch point for consumers.

images.alt_text: This space on the second floor of the Apple store in Knightsbridge mall is where hands-on sessions on subjects like coding, music and design will be run.

site_title: Halal travel offers tourism ticket for Asian destinations
summary: US travel restrictions have prompted a surge in Muslim travelers to Asia, with countries like Singapore, Penang, and Mumbai offering halal-friendly features. Asian countries have responded by introducing Muslim-friendly amenities such as halal restaurants, segregated facilities, and prayer mats. This trend is estimated to be worth $220 billion by 2020, driven by the growing importance of Islamic travel. The shift is not seen as a marketing ploy, but rather a genuine response to the needs of Muslim travelers, with many finding it liberating and welcoming.

site_title: Jason Marine turns around in FY17 despite lower revenue
summary: Jason Marine Group reported a net profit of S$363,000 for FY17, reversing a net loss of S$6 million a year ago, despite a 10.8% drop in revenue to S$33.16 million. The turnaround was driven by cost-cutting measures and operational efficiency improvements. The company expects the next 12 months to remain challenging, citing a highly cyclical industry.

site_title: IMF approves US$5.5b bailout package for Mongolia
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has approved a US$5.5 billion bailout package for Mongolia, providing a three-year financial arrangement of US$434.3 million to support the country's economic reform program. The package aims to stabilize the economy, impose fiscal discipline, and boost competitiveness, with conditions including spending cuts, tax increases, and a flexible exchange rate. Mongolia will also build a stronger regulatory environment for banking and finance.

site_title: UK economy slowed more than thought in Q1
summary: The UK economy slowed more than initially thought in Q1, with a 0.2% growth rate, down from an earlier estimate of 0.3%. Rising inflation, boosted by the Brexit vote, took a toll on household spending, which rose only 0.3% after adjusting for inflation. The slowdown was partly due to falling consumer-facing industries and household spending. The Bank of England expects the economy to grow 1.9% this year, but private-sector forecasters predict a slightly sharper slowdown.

site_title: The Hour Glass posts 7% drop in full-year profit to S$48.7m
summary: The Hour Glass, a luxury watch retailer, reported a 7% drop in its full-year profit to S$48.7 million due to tepid economic growth, subdued trading conditions, and waning consumer demand.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Vietnam relooks its foreign policy as China widens hegemonic sphere
summary: Vietnam's foreign policy is shifting as China expands its hegemony in the South China Sea. The Philippines' pivot to Beijing, following a US pivot under former President Barack Obama, has forced Hanoi to reassess its alliances. Vietnam's President Tran Dai Quang's visit to China in May was seen as a sign of the country's attempts to balance its relationships with the US and China. Vietnam is concerned that China's influence in the region could undermine its claim to South China Sea resources. Despite this, the two countries agreed to manage maritime disputes and avoid complicating actions.

site_title: Q1 NODX up 15.2%, 2017 forecast revised to 4-6%
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) rose 15.2% in the first quarter of 2017, exceeding forecasts of 0-2%. The increase is attributed to increased shipments of electronic and non-electronic goods. The country's trade growth forecast has been revised to 4-6% for 2017, up from earlier predictions of 0-2%. This is partly due to improved global economic and trade outlook, with the International Monetary Fund upgrading its global growth forecast to 3.5%.

site_title: The Hour Glass's full-year profit falls 7% to S$48.7m
summary: The Hour Glass reported a 7% drop in net profit to S$48.7 million for the full year ended March 31. Total revenue and other income fell 1% to S$703.95 million. The decline was attributed to tepid economic growth, subdued trading conditions, and weakening consumer appetite for luxury watches. The board recommended a dividend of two Singapore cents per share for FY2017.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Panel urges Tokyo to levy delayed sales tax hike to balance budget
summary: Tokyo's Fiscal System Council advises the government to implement a delayed sales tax hike scheduled for October 2019 to balance the budget. The revenue is needed to cover bulging social security costs and achieve a budget surplus in four years. Failure to meet the target could negatively impact Japan's sovereign credit ratings. The proposal aims to stabilize Japan's fragile economy and mitigate risks, despite previous delays in the tax hike.

site_title: Tiny island off Singapore playing big role in future of energy
summary: A French energy company, Engie SA, is building a small power grid on Semakau Island off Singapore to demonstrate the potential of hydrogen gas for storing renewable energy. The project aims to convert intermittent power from solar panels and wind turbines into stored fuel that can generate electricity days or months later. Hydrogen has "massive long-term potential" for energy storage, but costs must come down to make it viable. The project is expected to be operational by October and could be replicated in other regions, including Indonesia, where nearly 1,000 islands lack access to traditional power plants.

site_title: Forex markets get global code of conduct
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and other central banks launched the FX Global Code, a set of principles for wholesale foreign exchange markets to promote integrity and effective functioning. The code, developed over two years, is voluntary and sets out principles for a robust, fair, and transparent market. The central banks, including the Bank of Korea, Hong Kong Monetary Authority, Reserve Bank of Australia, and Reserve Bank of India, welcomed the code and will engage local market participants to promote adherence. The code aims to encourage ethical behavior and high standards in the FX markets.

site_title: Audacious but solid cooking at Audace
summary: Audace, a restaurant in the Wanderlust Hotel, aims to challenge expectations with its audacious approach to food. However, the experience is marred by a mean-spirited menu, where the server crumples up perfectly good sheets of paper and serves them to diners. The restaurant's contemporary bistro cuisine, made with fresh ingredients from the nearby Tekka market, is decent but predictable. Standout dishes include the well-braised octopus, roast duck breast, and beetroot pork belly, which suffers from an East-West identity crisis. Overall, the restaurant's solid cooking is overshadowed by its audacious but misguided approach.

site_title: Earnest, heartfelt look at prejudice in Singapore
summary: The National Library of Singapore removed three children's books in 2014 due to their depiction of gay parents and single mothers, sparking outrage from the LGBT community and heterosexual individuals alike. A new play, "Tango," by Pangdemonium, explores this incident and prejudice in Singapore, based on a real-life story of a gay couple who faced discrimination in a Chinese restaurant in 2013. The play, directed by Tracie Pang, features a balanced script and controlled performances, tackling the complex issue of freedom of expression and LGBT rights in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Joyas International to sell loss-making subsidiary for HK$15m
summary: Joyas International Holdings agreed to sell its loss-making subsidiary, Joyas Group, for HK$15 million (S$2.67 million). The jewellery and metal gifts business division will cease to be part of the group. The sale comes due to challenging market conditions, with competitors exerting pressure on profit margins and pricing. The company's remaining businesses, including nickel distribution and trading, and financing, will remain intact.

site_title: Valuetronics net profit up 28% for FY2017 as industrial, consumer revenues rise
summary: Valuetronics Holdings reported a 27.9% increase in net profit to HK$154.1 million for FY2017, driven by a 16.5% rise in revenue to HK$2.27 billion. Both industrial and consumer electronics segments saw revenue increases, with a 14.1% rise in industrial revenue and a 19.7% rise in consumer electronics revenue. The company expects to obtain approval from an automaker to supply connectivity modules by late FY2018. A bonus issue of new shares was approved, resulting in an earnings per share increase to 36.8 HK cents.

site_title: A 2% growth isn't difficult. But how bumpy will the ride be till year's end?
summary: Singapore's economy reported a 2.7% year-on-year growth in Q1 2017, exceeding the 2% growth target set by the Ministry of Trade and Industry. Economists believe this growth is the best the country can achieve for 2017, with the remaining quarters needing to sustain a similar momentum to meet the target. However, concerns remain about the unevenness in economic growth, sluggish domestic-oriented sectors, and a slackening labor market, leaving the economy vulnerable to external challenges. A bumpy ride is expected for 2017.

site_title: Pan Hong racks up 25.3% rise in full-year profit
summary: Pan Hong Holdings Group reported a 25.3% increase in net profit to 100.94 million yuan (S$20.35 million) for the full year ended March 31, driven by a 131.3% surge in revenue. The company attributed the growth to the handover of more property units. Pan Hong emphasized the importance of pre-sales and property development in its future strategies, with plans to expand into second-tier cities and consider rental income to provide stable returns.

site_title: Silicon Valley's hot new way to invest comes with a catch
summary: Storj Labs Inc is selling digital coins at 50 cents apiece in an early stage financing round, raising US$30 million. The tokens provide access to data storage on a distributed network and are tradable on dozens of online exchanges. Unlike traditional venture capital investments, the tokens don't confer a claim on Storj's equity or future profits. This is the latest entry in the growing ledger of cryptocurrencies, with investors spending over US$332 million on tokens in the past year, more than double what VCs handed over in seed rounds.

site_title: S. Korea's new president angers small firms he has vowed to help
summary: South Korea's new President Moon Jae-in is pushing ahead with plans to implement labor reforms, which could significantly impact small businesses. The reforms include raising minimum wages, restricting contract staff numbers, and reducing working hours. Small businesses fear these changes could lead to reduced profits and even closures. Despite Moon's promise to boost job prospects for young South Koreans, the impact on small firms is a concern. The reforms are part of his policy to protect workers' rights, but the consequences for small businesses remain uncertain.

site_title: Trump meets Macron, says whole world talking about win
summary: US President Donald Trump met with newly-elected French President Emmanuel Macron, praising Macron's outsider campaign as a model. Trump said "all over the world they're talking about it" and congratulated Macron on his victory. Macron expressed a desire to discuss pressing issues such as terrorism, the economy, and climate change. The meeting comes as France formally joins the US-led coalition against Islamic State, following a drop in opposition to NATO membership.

site_title: Lenovo's profit tops estimates after PC market levels off
summary: Lenovo's quarterly profit fell 41% to US$107 million, beating analyst estimates. The company's revenue increased 5% to US$9.6 billion, while the global PC market grew 0.6% for the first time since 2012. Lenovo narrowly lost its top PC market position to HP Inc. despite increasing market share. The company plans to focus on faster-growing markets, including smartphones, and streamline its product line. Lenovo aims to transform its underperforming smartphone division and mobile business, while improving its server and data center businesses.

site_title: BBR unit snags Goh & Goh Building for S$101.5m in collective sale
summary: BBR Holdings' subsidiary Alika Properties acquired the four-storey Goh & Goh Building in Upper Bukit Timah Road for S$101.5 million through a collective sale. The site can yield around 100 residential units and retail shops, with a plot ratio of 3.0 and 8,604.9 square metres of permissible gross floor area. This is BBR's second collective sale this year, following Lum Chang Holdings' purchase of One Tree Hill Gardens for S$65 million earlier this month.

images.alt_text: In what is this year's first collective sale involving a mixed-use property and the second collective sale, a unit of BBR Holdings (S) is acquiring Goh & Goh Building for S$101.5 million.

site_title: Oil, GDP outlook give STI modest boost
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.1% or 3.13 points to 3,234.37, driven by gains from bank stocks DBS and OCBC. The Ministry of Trade and Industry maintained its forecast for 1-3% economic growth in 2017, matching economists' expectations. Noble Group rebounded 9.09% after five straight declines, while Singapore Telecommunications extended its loss streak to two days. Oil counters held firm ahead of an Opec meeting.

site_title: Ford's Fields may walk away with US$57.5m after his ouster
summary: Former Ford Motor Co CEO Mark Fields may receive approximately $57.5 million in compensation, mainly from unvested stock awards valued at $29.4 million, retirement benefits, and stock options. Fields was ousted after a 37% decline in stock price during his nearly three-year tenure. He agreed to resign and will retain some corporate benefits until August. New CEO Jim Hackett will receive a $13.4 million compensation package, including a base salary and restricted stock grants.

site_title: Vashion announces debt conversion, share consolidation, rights issue and business diversification plan
summary: Vashion Group, a men's apparel retailer, announced a debt conversion, share consolidation, rights issue, and business diversification plan. The company converted debt owed to independent directors into equity, consolidated shares 10-to-one, and proposed a rights issue to raise S$5.3 million. Additionally, Vashion plans to diversify its business into financing and luxury goods, seeking shareholders' approval for the new ventures. The proposed diversification may change the group's risk profile, prompting an extraordinary general meeting to seek shareholder approval.

site_title: Hiap Tong's full-year profit surges 110%
summary: Hiap Tong Corporation reported a 109.6% surge in net profit for the full year ended March 31, reaching S$4.78 million. Revenue rose 3.7% to S$41.55 million, driven by an increase in leasing income. Other income jumped 165.9% due to a net change in fair value of investment properties and equipment disposal gains. The company will continue to explore crane leasing opportunities overseas and improve business efficiency amid a weak local business environment.

site_title: More older workers staying employed till 65
summary: A study by the Ministry of Manpower in Singapore found that the Retirement and Re-employment Act (RRA) enacted in 2012 has positively impacted the employment rate of eligible older workers, with a 1.6 percentage point increase on average each year. The study attributed this to social norms, where workers took the re-employment age of 65 as a mental anchor to retire, rather than the statutory age of 62. The RRA also did not reduce the demand for workers, with private-sector firms already offering re-employment to 97.9% of workers who turned 62 in 2011.

site_title: US: S&P, Nasdaq open at record highs after Fed minutes
summary: The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite opened at record highs on May 25, 2017, after the Federal Reserve's minutes revealed policymakers expect the economy to pick up momentum and plan to raise interest rates soon. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 50.69 points to 21,063.11. The Nasdaq Composite added 19.02 points to 6,182.04, while the S&P 500 gained 4.45 points to 2,408.84.

site_title: Trump shames Nato leaders on defence spending as unity tested
summary: US President Donald Trump publicly shamed Nato leaders for not meeting their defense spending obligations, citing the terrorist threat. Trump said 23 of the 28 member nations owe the US $119 billion if they had lived up to their commitments. German Chancellor Angela Merkel responded by saying member states, including Germany, have already pledged to work towards the 2% target by 2024. Merkel also emphasized the importance of capabilities and contributions, not just spending, in meeting Nato goals. The event risked souring Nato's unity.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end higher
summary: Malaysian shares ended higher on Thursday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index gaining 2.95 points to 1,773.960. The index saw 2.94 billion lots traded, with losers outnumbering gainers 590 to 377. The market's gains came despite global economic uncertainty, with US stocks reaching fresh records despite tariff concerns.

site_title: Women golfers have better shot at that boardroom seat: study
summary: A study by NUS Business School and the Department of Real Estate found that women golfers are 90% more likely to serve on a corporate board compared to non-golfers, with a 54% greater chance than male golfers. Women in golf are also 125% more likely to serve on the board of big firms, while small firms don't seem to favor golf as a prerequisite. The study suggests that women's involvement in golf enhances their chances of being appointed to a board in a large listed company, highlighting the role of social capital in overcoming gender disparity.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Pact to speed up bitcoin drives digital currency to record high
summary: Bitcoin reached a record-high of US$2,690, driven by an agreement to upgrade the speed of processing transactions. The pact, signed by over 50 companies, aims to increase the block size and activate Segregated Witness, a new verification method. The move is seen as significant, as it could potentially disrupt bitcoin's growth and address a backlog of transactions. The agreement represents 83% of bitcoin hashing power and comes after a surge of 10% in the past week, bringing year-to-date gains to 182%.

site_title: Google's AlphaGo clinches series win over Chinese Go master
summary: Google's AlphaGo program defeated Chinese Go master Ke Jie for a second time, taking a 2-0 lead in a best-of-three series. The match, held in Shanghai, marked AlphaGo's victory over the world's top player, with Ke expressing frustration and concern about the AI's rapid improvement. The win is seen as a significant milestone for AI, with implications for China's top policymakers and Google's efforts to expand its presence in the Chinese market.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end up for fourth day
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose for a fourth consecutive day, driven by expectations of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike next month. The Hang Seng Index increased 0.80% to 25,630.78, while the Shanghai Composite Index jumped 1.43% to 3,107.83. Dealers ignored Moody's ratings downgrade, and global stocks also reached record highs despite US trade uncertainty.

site_title: Worldpay looks to bring real payments to virtual worlds
summary: Worldpay, a London-based payments processor, has developed a solution to handle debit and credit card transactions in virtual reality (VR). The company built a prototype using HTC's Vive VR headset, requiring users to stare at a virtual price tag and enter a PIN code. Worldpay believes this method is more secure than traditional stored credit card information, with less risk of hacking and unauthorized purchases. The solution will be marketed to VR game developers and companies experimenting with VR as a sales tool, with varying adoption rates expected by geography.

site_title: UK economy slows more than expected in Q1 as inflation hits
summary: The UK economy slowed more than expected in Q1, with gross domestic product growing at 0.2% compared to an initial estimate of 0.3%. Rising inflation, boosted by the Brexit vote, led to a slowdown in household spending, which rose by just 0.3% after adjusting for inflation. The economy's reliance on consumer spending has been weakened by increased pressure from rising prices.

site_title: ArtiVision sinks deeper into the red
summary: ArtiVision Technologies, a computer video firm, reported a net loss of S$8.67 million in the fourth quarter, compared to S$2.85 million a year ago, due to impairment of assets and a surge in administrative expenses. The company's revenue surged 92% to S$6.23 million in the quarter. For the full year, the net loss was S$15.86 million, with the group equity declining to a deficit of S$4.16 million. The company's controlling shareholder has pledged to provide adequate funds to support operations until August 2018.

site_title: Hedge funds getting priced out in the world's costliest city
summary: Hedge funds in Hong Kong are shifting out of the city's central business district due to soaring office rents, with many opting for cheaper alternatives in neighboring areas like Wong Chuk Hang and Cyberport. The city's luxury landmarks, such as the Mandarin Oriental hotel, are no longer affordable for many hedge funds, with grade-A office rents in Central increasing by 8.7% last year. The industry is under pressure to cut expenses, with global net withdrawals totaling $70 billion last year, and many managers are finding it difficult to afford prime office rates.

images.alt_text: Grade-A office rents in Central climbed 8.7 per cent last year and may jump as much as 15 per cent in 2017, fuelled by Chinese demand and a dearth of new supply, data compiled by CBRE Group Inc shows.

site_title: Rickmers gets US$24.7m from completed sale of five vessels to Navios
summary: Rickmers Maritime's trustee-manager received US$24.7 million from the sale of five vessels to Navios Partners Containers Inc and Navios Partners Containers Finance Inc. The sale, part of a master agreement, was for a total consideration of US$59 million. This exceeds the initial US$20 million indicated earlier. The proceeds will be placed in an escrow account for unsecured creditors, and a buyer-related entity has assumed the secured loan, releasing the trust from its obligations to BNP. The sale of the remaining nine vessels remains pending consent from a HSH Nordbank-led syndicate.

images.alt_text: The trustee-manager of Rickmers Maritime said on Thursday evening it has received US$24.7 million proceeds on completing the sale of five vessels under a master agreement signed with Navios Partners Containers Inc and Navios Partners Containers Finance Inc.

site_title: South Korea's new president draws ire of small businesses he's vowed to help
summary: South Korea's new President Moon Jae-In's labor reforms, including a 55% minimum wage hike and reduced working hours, are sparking concerns among small businesses, which fear they could be forced to close due to increased costs. Chaebol conglomerates, which dominate the economy, are also being targeted for reform. Businessmen warn that these policies could lead to job losses and reduced profits, while the government aims to protect workers' rights and boost job prospects for young South Koreans.

site_title: Football: United, City pledge £1m to Manchester attack fund
summary: Manchester United and Manchester City pledged £1 million to the "We Love Manchester Emergency Fund" in response to the terror attack at Manchester Arena that left 22 people dead and 64 injured. The fund, backed by the British Red Cross, aims to support those affected by the tragedy. The clubs' joint statement emphasized their commitment to supporting the city and its people, with Manchester City chairman Khaldoon al Mubarak praising the city's resilience and solidarity. The donation is seen as a symbol of unity and strength in the face of adversity.

site_title: Dutch funeral expo digs up the latest in death trends
summary: A recent funeral expo in Amsterdam showcased unique and innovative ways to celebrate life and say farewell. Over 3,500 visitors attended the event, which featured coffin designs such as a shuffleboard game and a football boot-shaped casket, as well as a 3D-printed urn and a hollow walking stick with GPS coordinates. A vegetable patch grave, where plants are grown on top of the grave, was also on display. Organizers aim to redefine the traditional funeral experience, focusing on personalization and celebrating the deceased's personality and life.

site_title: Global regulators expect deal soon on finalising capital rules
summary: Global regulators are nearing a deal on finalizing capital rules for banks, with a possible agreement on a capital backstop by the Basel Committee's next meeting on June 14-15. The rules, part of Basel III, aim to ensure banks hold enough capital to withstand market volatility without taxpayer aid. The remaining elements of the reforms focus on risk assessment and capital reserves, with regulators aiming to finalize the remaining elements by 2019. The deal is seen as a significant step in strengthening global banking regulations, but US President Donald Trump's calls to ease regulation have cast some doubt over the reforms.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's 2017 GDP growth is likely higher than last year's 2%, with the Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) raising its forecast range to 1-3%. The city-state's non-oil and non-trade (NODX) expanded 15.2% in Q1. Meanwhile, Malaysia's May industrial production rose 0.3%, below forecast.

images.alt_text: Singapore's economic growth this year is likely to be better than last year's 2 per cent, even as the city-state's Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) keeps its earlier forecast range of 1 to 3 per cent for 2017.

site_title: Banks lead Singapore stocks higher; STI gains 0.1% to 3,234.37
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.1% to 3,234.37, led by gains in bank stocks, including DBS Group Holdings and OCBC Bank. Noble Group rebounded 9.09% after five straight declines. The STI also benefited from a modest economic forecast of 1-3% growth. However, Singapore Telecommunications was a key drag, falling 0.53%.

site_title: Opec meets to extend oil cuts for up to one year
summary: Opec and non-member oil producers are set to extend output cuts for up to 12 months to help clear global oil stocks and prop up crude prices. The cuts, initially agreed upon for six months, are seen as the base-case scenario, with most delegates predicting a nine-month extension. Saudi Arabia and Russia, Opec's de facto leader and top non-Opec producer, have pushed for a longer duration to speed up market rebalancing and prevent prices from falling below $50 per barrel.

site_title: Profit at Malaysia's AirAsia hit by higher fuel costs
summary: Malaysia's low-cost airline AirAsia reported a 30% drop in quarterly net profit to 615.8 million ringgit due to higher fuel costs, despite a 31% increase in revenue to 2.2 billion ringgit. The airline carried 9.15 million passengers, a 6% rise, and a load factor of 89%, up four percentage points from last year. Fuel prices rose 20% to US$67 per barrel, while staff costs increased 76.8 million ringgit. The airline expects to achieve double-digit fleet growth this year.

images.alt_text: Malaysian low-cost airline AirAsia Bhd reported a 30 per cent drop in its quarterly net profit as higher fuel expenses overshadowed the effects of increased passenger numbers and an improvement in its load factor.

site_title: China mulls plans to reform air space management -official
summary: China plans to submit proposals to reform air space management by the end of May to ease flight delays and boost aviation growth. The reform aims to integrate civil and military management of the country's air space and improve the flight route network. The current system is causing severe congestion around Beijing and the Pearl River Delta, requiring modernization. The reform will also adopt airspace classification methods used by the International Civil Aviation Organization. This move is necessary to adjust to the global air traffic management system and accelerate China's transformation into an aviation power.

site_title: Central banks launch code of conduct to promote good practice for FX markets
summary: Central banks launched the FX Global Code, a set of principles promoting good practice for wholesale FX markets globally. Developed through a two-year collaborative process, the code aims to ensure a robust, fair, and transparent market. The voluntary code applies to wholesale FX market participants and is intended to promote integrity and effective functioning of the market. The Monetary Authority of Singapore, Bank of Korea, Hong Kong Monetary Authority, Reserve Bank of Australia, and Reserve Bank of India welcomed the code, with plans to engage local-market participants to promote adherence.

site_title: UK mortgage approvals slip in April, consumer borrowing speeds up - BBA
summary: UK mortgage approvals declined to the lowest in five months in April with 40,750 mortgages approved, down marginally from March. Consumer borrowing grew 6.4% in April, slightly up from 6.2% in March, driven by increased spending on food during the Easter holidays. The data suggests a slowdown in the housing market, with rising inflation and Brexit-related consumer demand weakening.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rise at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose at the open on Thursday, driven by firmer oil prices and expectations of another US rate hike. London's FTSE 100 index gained 0.2%, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices rose 0.4%. Analysts attributed the gains to firm oil prices ahead of the Opec meeting and buoyant sentiment.

site_title: New Zealand posts second straight surplus, targets infrastructure spending
summary: New Zealand's government forecasts a NZ$1.62 billion budget surplus in 2017, exceeding initial predictions, and plans to invest the extra funds in infrastructure to boost the economy. Finance Minister Steven Joyce announced NZ$11 billion in infrastructure spending over four years, including housing and transportation projects. The government aims to reduce net debt to 10-15% of GDP by 2025.

site_title: Accordia Golf Trust's DPU falls to 1.48 cents in Q4
summary: Accordia Golf Trust reported a 25.1% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.48 Singapore cents in Q4, due to heavy snowfall forcing golf course closures and income refunds. Operating income fell 5.1% to 9.91 billion yen, and net loss worsened to 2.79 billion yen, from a net loss of 744 million yen in the previous year.

site_title: DISA will no longer consolidate shares; cites recent price gains
summary: DISA, a supplier of anti-theft technology for retail electronic goods, will no longer proceed with a planned 50-into-one share consolidation due to recent price gains. The company had initially sought to reduce market capitalization fluctuations but will need to obtain shareholder approval again to disregard the plan. The decision comes after the company's share price increased over several months.

site_title: Japan:Nikkei rises as strong-yen trend pauses
summary: Japanese stocks rose 0.4% to 19,813.13, driven by a pause in the strong-yen trend and gains from index-heavyweights like SoftBank, which jumped 3.8% after a reported $4 billion stake in Nvidia. The US dollar-yen remained in a narrow range, limiting gains. Despite this, the broader Topix index rose 0.2% to 1,578.42.

site_title: Australia: Stocks up on boost from financials, materials
summary: Australian shares rose 20.625 points or 0.36% to 5,789.6, driven by gains in financial and material firms, including BHP Billiton, which advanced 1.2% as oil and copper prices rose.

site_title: Oxley-led consortium secures Rio Casa for S$575m in en bloc deal
summary: A consortium led by Oxley Holdings has secured the residential property Rio Casa in Hougang for S$575 million in an en bloc deal. The consortium, comprising Oxley, KSH Holdings, Lian Beng Group, and the Teo family's private investment firm, won the tender with a 35-35-20-10 stake split. The property, a former HUDC estate, will be redeveloped and the buyers plan to apply for a 99-year lease. An estimated S$208 million premium is payable to the state for the top-up of the lease and development of the site to a gross plot ratio of 2.8.

site_title: New Zealand launches into space race with 3D-printed rocket
summary: New Zealand has launched a 3D-printed rocket into space, marking a significant step in its bid to become a low-cost space hub. Rocket Lab, a Silicon Valley-funded company, successfully launched its maiden flight from the Mahia Peninsula, a remote area in New Zealand. The launch is an important milestone for the company, which aims to make space accessible by providing frequent launch opportunities. New Zealand has also established a space agency and created new rocket legislation to support its space industry.

site_title: May to raise US terror intelligence leaks with Trump at NATO
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May will discuss US terror intelligence leaks with President Donald Trump at the NATO summit in Brussels, amid concerns over the sharing of sensitive information related to the Manchester terror attack. The leaks have strained UK-US relations, with Home Secretary Amber Rudd criticizing US officials for breaching trust. The UK government has stepped up its criticism, with police calling the leaks a breach of trust and undermining investigations. The issue may prompt a re-evaluation of the UK's intelligence cooperation with the US.

site_title: Singapore files written observation with ICJ on Malaysia's bid to revise Pedra Branca judgement
summary: Singapore has filed written observations with the International Court of Justice (ICJ) in response to Malaysia's application to revise the 2008 ICJ judgement awarding Pedra Branca to Singapore. The written observations, filed on May 24, are a comprehensive rebuttal to Malaysia's application. Singapore is confident in its case and awaits the ICJ's schedule for oral proceedings, where the parties will present their arguments.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Philippine military seeks to secure troubled city as fighting eases
summary: Troops in the Philippines have begun clearing Marawi City of Islamist militants, easing hostilities after thousands fled and rebels took control. Militants linked to the Islamic State group took Christians hostage and freed over 100 prisoners. Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte imposed martial law in Mindanao, the country's second-largest island, to prevent extremism. Hundreds of civilians, including children, were sheltering in a military camp.

site_title: Taiwan's gay marriage ruling raises hopes across Asia
summary: Taiwan's constitutional court ruled that laws preventing same-sex unions violated the constitution's guarantees of freedom of marriage, paving the way for the island to become the first place in Asia to allow same-sex couples to marry. The decision has sparked hopes across Asia, with activists in countries such as Indonesia, Vietnam, and China expressing optimism about the potential for marriage rights to be reinvigorated. However, challenges remain, with gay sex still illegal in some countries, and activists must win other battles before considering marriage.

site_title: Golf can give women a boost into corporate boards
summary: A study by NUS Business School and the Department of Real Estate at NUS School of Design and Environment found that women who play golf are 90% more likely to serve on a corporate board compared to those who do not. Female golfers are also 54% more likely to serve on a board compared to male golfers, with a greater advantage in larger firms. The study analyzed over 10,580 golfers and 1,640 directors from 2000 to 2014, suggesting that social capital and networking can help women overcome the gender glass ceiling in corporate boards.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Manchester police conduct explosion in terror probe
summary: British police conducted a controlled explosion at an address in Manchester's south side as part of a terror probe into the May 22 suicide attack at a pop concert that killed 22 people. Seven people have been arrested, including six in the Greater Manchester area and one in central England. The investigation is ongoing, and police are keeping an open mind as new leads emerge. The perpetrator, Salman Abedi, was born and raised in the south of Manchester.

site_title: Lenovo's profit tops estimates as pc market levels off
summary: Lenovo's quarterly profit fell 41% to $107 million, beating estimates of $97.9 million. Revenue increased 5% to $9.6 billion, as the global PC market, which grew 0.6%, marked its first growth since 2012. Lenovo narrowly lost its top PC market position to HP but increased market share. The company needs to tap new growth sources, particularly in its smartphone division, which remains underperforming. Lenovo's shares rose 4% in Hong Kong after the announcement.

site_title: Software update can fix Fiat Chrysler's US diesel issue -lawyer
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV believes a software update can resolve US regulators' concerns about excess emissions from its 2014-2016 diesel vehicles, according to a lawyer representing the company. The Justice Department filed a civil suit accusing Fiat Chrysler of using software to bypass emission controls. The company denies wrongdoing and says the software update will address concerns without new hardware. Regulators could approve the update quickly, potentially in a few weeks, allowing the company to certify 2017 diesel models.

site_title: Stamford Land back in the black in Q4 on higher property development income
summary: STAMFORD Land Corporation reported a net profit of S$8.93 million for Q4, up from a net loss of S$5 million a year ago, driven by higher property development income. Revenue more than doubled to S$166 million. The company expects to remain profitable for FY2018 and proposed a final dividend of one Singapore cent per share. Net profit for the full year jumped 54% to S$34.55 million on a 38.9% increase in revenue to S$314.65 million.

site_title: China: Blue-chips have best day in 21 months
summary: China's blue-chip stocks surged 1.8% to a 21-month high, driven by growing hopes that MSCI will add mainland shares to its benchmark next month. The CSI300 index rose, with banking and real estate stocks leading the gains. Investors appear to have shrugged off Moody's downgrade of China's credit rating, and several government officials criticized the decision. Expectations are building for MSCI's annual classification review on June 20, which could lead to China's inclusion in its Emerging Markets Index.

site_title: New Ford CEO eligible for $13.4m in annual compensation
summary: New Ford CEO James Hackett is eligible for at least $13.4 million in annual compensation, including a $1.8 million salary, $7 million in stock-based compensation, and a $1 million bonus. Hackett replaces CEO Mark Fields, who will retire on August 1 and receive pro-rated incentive compensation. The move comes amid investor unease over Ford's slumping stock price and ability to counter rivals.

site_title: Noble Group in need of restructuring: Muddy Waters
summary: Noble Group, a Hong Kong-based commodity trader, is likely to undergo restructuring due to significant losses, credit-rating downgrades, and asset sales. The company has faced a crisis for over two years, with shares losing over 70% this year and S&P Global Ratings flagging the risk of a default within a year. Noble Group has appointed Morgan Stanley and Moelis & Co. for advice and is in talks with potential partners to regain profitability by 2018-2019. Analysts believe the company needs a "white knight" to rescue it, with some warning of potential losses continuing.

site_title: Quick takes: Singapore 2017 GDP growth likely better than last year, Q1 growth higher at 2.7%
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) reported that the country's economic growth is likely to be better than last year's 2%, with Q1 growth revised to 2.7%. Economists have mixed views on the forecast, with some predicting growth will peak and others expecting a sustainable lift. DBS economist Irvin Seah expects an uneven turnaround, while NatWest Markets economist Vaninder Singh revised their forecast to 1.6% due to structural challenges. OCBC economist Selena Ling maintains a 2.5% forecast.

site_title: China says former Shanghai prosecutor suspected of bribe-taking
summary: China has kicked out former Shanghai prosecutor Chen Xu from the ruling Communist Party over alleged violations and suspected bribe-taking.
