An investigation found Chen had damaged the judiciary's credibility and committed multiple party rule breaches, including accepting bribes and using his position to benefit family members. The bribery case will be turned over to the courts. This move follows President Xi Jinping's efforts to combat deep-seated graft in China.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 3.56 points to 1,774.570. The index saw 155 gainers for every 115 losers, with a total trading volume of 135.58 million lots worth RM69.66 million.

site_title: Singapore shipyards secured S$820m in new orders in 2016, down from S$4.9b in 2015
summary: Singapore shipyards secured S$820m in new orders in 2016, a 83% decline from S$4.9 billion in 2015. The industry's total order book fell 57.9% to S$8 billion, with deliveries until 2021. Employment in the local offshore and marine industry dropped 10% to 85,600, while the industry's turnover decreased 11.3% to S$13.06 billion. Shipbuilding and offshore rigbuilding sectors contributed to the decline. The industry faces a challenging environment, with upstream oil and gas activity remaining weak, despite improved prospects in the marine and offshore sector.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Harley-Davidson plans a Thailand factory to serve SE Asian market
summary: Harley-Davidson plans to build a factory in Thailand's Rayong province to serve the Southeast Asian market, avoiding up to 60% tariff on imported motorcycles. The move aims to increase access and affordability for customers in the region. The company's public relations manager stated that the facility will not reduce US manufacturing and will produce motorcycles with the same "authentic look, sound, and feel" as those made in the US. The decision has been criticized by a US labor union, which claims it will harm American workers.

site_title: Moody's downgrades Hong Kong after China ratings cut
summary: Moody's Investors Service downgraded Hong Kong's local and foreign currency issuer ratings to Aa2 from Aa1, citing close economic, financial, and political ties with China. The downgrade follows Moody's first-ever cut to China's credit ratings in nearly 30 years. Hong Kong's credit outlook was changed to stable from negative, reflecting the city's robust economic fundamentals and regulatory regime. The Hong Kong government criticized the move, stating the city is well-equipped to handle challenges, while Moody's warned of potential contagion risks through financial ties with China.

site_title: Bank of Korea keeps rates unchanged for 11th month, in line with forecasts
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, maintained its interest rate unchanged for the 11th consecutive month, at 1.25%. The decision was in line with market expectations. The bank cited stable inflation and a strong economy, with exports surging for a sixth straight month, as reasons for the decision. The decision also reflects the new administration's focus on fiscal policy, with a supplementary budget to aid job creation. The Bank of Korea is expected to hike interest rates next year, but will maintain an easy policy to support growth this year.

site_title: The fidget spinner that has spun teachers into a tizzy
summary: A new anti-fidget toy, the fidget spinner, has sparked controversy in US and European schools, with some banning it due to distractions and others tolerating it for children with ADHD. Teachers, however, recognize the need for students to fidget and are now more open to allowing quiet fidget toys, such as stress balls and fidget cubes. The fidget spinner's success has led to its widespread adoption, with some adults also using it to relieve stress.

images.alt_text: Just months after the "fidget spinner" first whirled its way into the hands of antsy youngsters, some schools have already banned it - prompting a debate about difficulties children experience concentrating.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally after Fed minutes, Opec meeting in focus
summary: Asian markets rose on Thursday, driven by the Federal Reserve's indication that interest rates could rise next month, with minutes suggesting a "soon" timing. Oil prices also rallied ahead of an expected Opec meeting. Despite some economic weakness, the Fed still believes its broad strength warrants reducing its balance sheet, potentially increasing borrowing costs. The Singapore stock market rallied for a fifth consecutive day, with the STI up 0.4% as investors remained positive despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open up after US record
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose for the fourth consecutive day, driven by a US Wall Street record and minutes from the Federal Reserve's policy meeting indicating a June rate hike. The Hang Seng Index gained 0.33% to 25,511.46, while the Shanghai Composite Index eased 0.29% to 3,055.34. The US economy was seen as healthy, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Australia: Stocks lifted by materials on higher commodity prices
summary: Australian shares rose 0.17% on Thursday, driven by gains in mining and oil stocks, which benefited from higher commodity prices. BHP Billiton led the gains, while oil majors Woodside Petroleum and Origin Energy also rose. However, financials stocks fell, weighed down by concerns over new tax levies and banking regulations. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,778.6, with the energy index hitting its highest in 21 months.

site_title: Neo Group Q4 profit rises 181% to S$2.7m
summary: Neo Group reported a 181% increase in Q4 net profit to S$2.7 million due to improved performance in food manufacturing and retail segments. Revenue rose 35% to S$48 million, with a 29% rise in full-year revenue to S$162 million. The company also declared a final cash dividend of one Singapore cent per share.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Brazilian ride-hailing company raises US$100m from SoftBank
summary: Brazilian ride-hailing company 99 raised US$100 million from SoftBank Group Corp to compete with Uber in Latin America's largest economy. The investment comes as SoftBank pours money into various ride-hailing companies, including US$5 billion for China's Didi Chuxing this year. 99 operates in over 400 cities in Brazil and faces increased competition from Uber, which may drive down its margins due to subsidies spent to maintain market share. The SoftBank investment is less than six months after 99 raised US$100 million from Didi and Riverwood Capital.

images.alt_text: SoftBank has been pouring money into various ride-hailing companies not named Uber, including US$5 billion for China's Didi Chuxing this year.

site_title: Singapore shares open 1.5 points up on Thursday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 1.53 points to 3,232.77 on Thursday, driven by a higher overnight closing on Wall Street. The S&P 500 hit a record high after the Federal Reserve's meeting minutes signalled a potential rate hike. Investors remained positive despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views, contributing to the 0.4% gain in the STI.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: US Navy ship sails near South China Sea reef claimed by Beijing: US official
summary: A US Navy ship, the USS Dewey, has sailed near a disputed reef in the South China Sea claimed by Beijing, in a "freedom of navigation operation". The ship sailed less than 12 nautical miles from Mischief Reef, part of the Spratly Islands, marking Washington's first such exercise under the Trump administration. The move is aimed at asserting US rights to navigation in the region, amid rising tensions with China.

site_title: Update: Singapore NODX expand 15.2% in Q1, full year 2017 growth forecast raised
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) expanded 15.2% in Q1 2017, with growth forecasts raised to 4-6% for the full year. This increase was driven by electronic and non-electronic products, with China, Taiwan, and South Korea being key contributors. The International Enterprise (IE) Singapore upgraded its forecast due to improved global economic and trade outlook. Electronic product exports rose 9% and non-electronic product exports grew 17.8% in Q1.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: A tiny island off Singapore may hold keys to energy's future
summary: A French energy company, Engie, is testing a hydrogen-based power storage system on Semakau Island off Singapore. The system aims to convert intermittent renewable energy from solar and wind into stored hydrogen fuel, generating electricity when needed. The project, with Singapore's Nanyang Technological University and Schneider Electric, seeks to overcome the high cost of hydrogen production and demonstrate its potential for widespread use in Southeast Asia, particularly in Indonesia.

site_title: Singapore 2017 GDP growth 'likely higher' than last year's 2%: MTI
summary: Singapore's 2017 GDP growth is likely higher than last year's 2%, according to the Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI). The economy saw a slower but resilient pace of growth in Q1 2017, with estimates showing a 2.7% year-on-year growth. Despite global uncertainties, including protectionism and monetary tightening in China, the external outlook is improving. MTI maintains its forecast range of 1 to 3% for 2017, suggesting GDP growth is likely to exceed 2% from 2016.

site_title: Libya arrests brother, father of Manchester bombing suspect
summary: Libya has arrested Hashem Abedi, the brother of Salman Abedi, the suspect in the Manchester bombing, and Ramadan Abedi, Salman's father. The arrests were made by Libya's Government of National Accord's police. Intelligence services had targeted the suspects in a crackdown related to the bombing, which occurred in May 2017.

images.alt_text: "The father, Ramadan Abedi, has also just been arrested," said Ahmed bin Salem, a spokesman for the police of Libya's Government of National Accord.

site_title: South Korea's 'Rasputin' daughter abandons appeal for extradition
summary: South Korea's "Rasputin" daughter, Chung Yoo Ra, has cancelled her appeal against extradition to Denmark, where she faces charges of overstaying her visa. Chung, 20, is the daughter of Choi Soon Sil, a key figure in the corruption scandal that led to President Park Geun Hye's impeachment. Chung had denied wrongdoing, citing her involvement in equestrian sports, but her lawyer argued the extradition was politically motivated. A Danish court had previously upheld the extradition order, which is now final.

site_title: Australia cuts return target for Future Fund
summary: The Australian government lowered the investment return target for the Future Fund by 0.5 percentage points to 4-5% above inflation, citing difficult global market conditions. The new target will be effective from July 1, following a 7.7% annual return since its inception in 2006. The move reflects changed global investment market conditions and outlook, with Chairman Peter Costello warning of possible lower returns ahead.

site_title: Europe: Banks give stocks stability, autos driven lower by Fiat
summary: European shares ended up 0.1% on Wednesday, despite struggling to gain momentum, due to strength in banks and big oil majors. However, auto stocks fell 0.6% led by Fiat Chrysler and Daimler, while mining stocks declined after a fall in copper. Dixons Carphone's fourth-quarter results boosted its shares, but Kingfisher and Babcock fell after trading updates.

site_title: Digital tokens unlock stakes in blockchain as ICOs proliferate
summary: Storj Labs Inc, a cloud storage startup, is raising $30 million through an initial coin offering (ICO) by selling digital coins at 50 cents apiece. The tokens, tradable on online exchanges, derive their value from utility in the firm's app and access to data storage on a distributed network. This model has seen $332 million in token sales in the past year, with investors spending nearly triple that amount in 2017. The ICO boom has raised concerns of a bubble, but entrepreneurs see the technology as offering a more accessible and efficient way to fund startups.

site_title: Hot stock: Vallianz shares edge higher by 12% on news of settlement agreements
summary: Vallianz Holdings shares rose 12% to 1.9 Singapore cents after the offshore support vessel provider announced settlement agreements, one of the most active trades in the early session. The company had previously released weak results due to a slump in the oil and gas sector, prompting a trading halt on Monday.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open flat on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened flat on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 slipping 0.03% to 19,737.46. Investors focused on US interest rate prospects, particularly a widely expected June hike. The Topix index also fell 0.03% to 1,574.63.

site_title: Policy formation is as important as building infrastructure: Heng
summary: Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the importance of forming policies alongside infrastructure development, citing examples of Singapore's Jurong Industrial Estate and the Jurong Innovation District. He noted that policies such as tackling industrial unrest, education reform, and creating entities like the Economic Development Board are crucial to supporting infrastructure projects. Heng also highlighted the need for lifelong learning through initiatives like SkillsFuture Credit, which encourages people to sharpen and widen their skill sets.

images.alt_text: Mr Heng in a discussion moderated by Rik Kirkland (left), partner and director of publishing at McKinsey & Company, which organised the Global Infrastructure Initiative (GII) summit being held on Sentosa.

site_title: Serious injuries at Tesla plant double industry average: report
summary: A report by the California nonprofit group Worksafe found that serious injuries at Tesla's Fremont factory in California are double the industry average, with a rate of 7.9 per 100 workers compared to 3.9. Total injuries at the plant are a third higher than the industry average. The United Auto Workers union has commissioned the report amid efforts to organize Tesla workers, who have filed charges with the National Labor Relations Board over alleged harassment. Tesla CEO Elon Musk acknowledged the challenges faced by employees but denied allegations of skimping on safety to increase profits.

images.alt_text: The rate of serious injuries at a Tesla factory in California is double the industry average, a worker advocacy group said Wednesday in a report calling for better workplace protections

site_title: Oil pulls back slightly on low US petrol stock draw
summary: Oil prices retreated slightly on Wednesday as US petrol stocks fell 4.4 million barrels, exceeding analyst forecasts. Crude inventories also dropped for the seventh straight week, while gasoline inventories declined 787,000 barrels. Benchmark Brent crude oil settled down 19 cents to $53.96 a barrel, rebounding on expectations that OPEC will maintain output cuts to drain global oversupply. A multination ministerial committee recommended keeping production cuts at the same level, with a nine-month extension considered a "done deal."

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rise for 4th day, heavyweights gain; Sinopac down
summary: Taiwan's main TAIEX index rose 0.5% to 10,094.68 points, its fourth consecutive gain, driven by gains in tech heavyweights like TSMC and Hon Hai Precision Industry. The milestone marked a 17-year-high and was partly fueled by foreign buying into these companies.

site_title: Uninsured rise by 23m under US Republican health bill: forecast
summary: The US Republican health care bill, approved by the House of Representatives, is expected to leave 23 million more Americans uninsured by 2026 than under current law, according to a Congressional Budget Office forecast. The bill would reduce the federal deficit by $119 billion, but would also increase costs for patients with expensive medical conditions. Despite Republican leaders' claims that the bill is a step towards repealing and replacing Obamacare, Democrats criticized the plan, calling it a "nightmare" for those with pre-existing conditions and many seniors.

site_title: Jakarta suicide bombing kills three police officers
summary: A suicide bombing attack outside a bus terminal in Jakarta, Indonesia, killed three police officers and injured several others. The attack, which occurred on Wednesday, was the latest in a series of plots and assaults in the country, and was believed to be linked to the Islamic State group. The Kampung Melayu terminal, a local hub, was busy at the time of the attack, which sent panicked people running for their lives and caused widespread damage.

site_title: Federal Reserve: New US rate hike likely coming 'soon'
summary: US Federal Reserve officials expect a new rate hike "soon" amid weak first-quarter growth, but may delay it until after June to assess the impact of President Trump's administration plans. Despite concerns over the administration's potential missteps and plans to ease bank regulations, policymakers see the economy continuing to grow, with job and wage growth leading to consumer spending and business investment. Analysts expect two more rate increases this year, but the Fed's minutes cast doubt on the timing, citing a need for additional evidence before raising interest rates again.

site_title: San Francisco goes from first to worst in US home-price gauge
summary: San Francisco's home prices plummeted 2.5% in the first quarter, marking the country's worst performance among the 100 largest US metropolitan areas. This decline reverses the city's previous record-breaking gains, which saw home prices rise 10% in the first quarter of 2016 and 15% in the first half of 2015. The median home price in San Francisco reached $1.1 million, making it the most expensive of the 100 largest metros. The decline is attributed to the cooling of the technology industry and soaring home prices that made real estate unaffordable for most buyers.

site_title: US: Stocks up again, S&P hits record on Fed minutes
summary: US stocks rose for the fifth consecutive session, with the S&P 500 hitting a record high, as investors reacted positively to the Federal Reserve's signal that a rate hike is coming "soon". The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.4% and the S&P 500 gained 0.3% to close at 2,404.39. The Fed minutes showed broad agreement on unwinding its massive balance sheet, which economists say will put upward pressure on interest rates.

site_title: Trump's budgets will suffer a double whammy
summary: US President Donald Trump's budgets will face a double whammy due to the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes and balance sheet reduction. Higher interest rates will increase borrowing costs for the US federal budget, while the Fed's smaller balance sheet will reduce its excess earnings, leading to lower payments to the Treasury. This combination will have a negative impact on the US federal budget, which Trump will inherit.

site_title: Canadian real-estate sentiment slips
summary: Canadian real estate sentiment has begun to cool, with price expectations dropping from record levels, according to weekly polling data. This suggests Canadians are anticipating a slowdown in housing markets in cities like Toronto.

site_title: Update: Growth in Singapore's manufacturing sector moderates to 8% year-on-year in Q1
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector experienced moderate growth of 8% year-on-year in Q1 2017, down from 11.5% in the previous quarter. The sector's growth was driven by the electronics and precision engineering clusters, with a quarter-on-quarter contraction of 1.5%. The construction sector contracted by 1.4% year-on-year, while services producing industries grew at 1.6%. These results indicate a moderation in the sector's growth, but still point to a resilient manufacturing sector.

images.alt_text: Moderation is seen in Singapore's manufacturing sector in the first quarter, based on the latest data released by the Ministry of Trade and Industry on Thursday.

site_title: NVPC initiative to groom talents in corporate giving
summary: The National Volunteer & Philanthropy Centre (NVPC) has launched a five-month Company of Good Fellowship programme to groom talents in corporate giving. The programme, with 39 participants and 11 mentors, aims to develop leadership and corporate giving skills. The fellows will engage in seminars, workshops, and action projects, and benefit from networking opportunities. NVPC has partnered with NUS Business School to host the programme. The initiative is expected to help participants develop and implement action projects, fostering co-existence, co-creation, and collaboration in corporate community investment and giving.

site_title: UBS seeks broader dialogue with women wealth clients
summary: UBS is seeking a broader dialogue with women wealth clients, aiming to tap into the growing wealth of female self-made billionaires in Asia, which is expected to reach $18 trillion by 2021. According to UBS, women are more likely to invest in sustainable and socially responsible investments, and the bank plans to engage with female clients to understand their holistic life goals. This move comes as women in Asia are driving their families' businesses and are expected to play a significant role in wealth management.

site_title: Lindt cafe siege: Aussie police waited too long to react, says coroner
summary: A coroner in Australia has found that police waited too long to react during a 2014 siege at a Sydney cafe, where three people were killed. The coroner, Michael Barnes, recommended authorities reconsider their "contain and negotiate" strategy for such attacks. The siege, which lasted over 16 hours, resulted in the deaths of cafe manager Tori Johnson and lawyer Katrina Dawson. Police stormed the cafe after a 10-minute delay, killing the hostage-taker, Man Haron Monis.

site_title: Singapore-based startup Sea Ltd files with US SEC for US$1b IPO: sources
summary: Singapore-based startup Sea Ltd has filed a confidential initial public offering (IPO) with the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC), seeking to raise approximately $1 billion. The company, founded in 2009, is considered South-east Asia's most valuable startup and is working with Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley on the share sale. If successful, the IPO would be the largest technology IPO out of South-east Asia and a boon for backers such as Tencent Holdings Ltd.

site_title: Taiwan court rules in favour of gay marriage in Asia first
summary: Taiwan's top court has ruled in favor of gay marriage, becoming the first place in Asia to legalize same-sex unions. The court gave the government two years to implement the ruling, which was supported by President Tsai Ing-wen and opposed by conservative groups. The decision, which was made by a majority of 10 judges, states that same-sex couples have the right to register for marriage and that the current laws preventing it "violate" the constitution's guarantees of freedom of marriage and equality.

site_title: Six convicted City Harvest Church leaders barred from having control of any charity
summary: The six convicted leaders of City Harvest Church, including founder Kong Hee, have been permanently barred from having overall administrative control of any charity in Singapore. This disqualification, under the Charities Act, protects the charitable assets of the charity from the individuals, who can no longer hold governance or management positions. The decision aims to safeguard the church's assets and prevent further misuse of funds. The Office of the Commissioner of Charities made the announcement in a statement on May 24, 2017.

site_title: SATS seeking to ramp up productivity with innovation
summary: SATS, a ground-handler, aims to boost productivity with new technological solutions, including cooking robots and a smart wheelchair system. The company will invest up to S$110 million in its "TechnIC@SATS" innovation centre, which will spearhead efforts to improve operations amid a tight labour market. The centre will fund up to 200 projects and enhance SATS' operations, furthering its goal to increase productivity.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Healthcare sector to procure S$300m of ICT projects in FY2017
summary: The Singapore healthcare sector plans to procure an estimated S$300 million in ICT projects in fiscal 2017, independent of the government's S$2.4 billion ICT tenders. The Integrated Health Information Systems and public hospitals will helm these projects, aiming to leverage infocomm technology to improve healthcare services.

site_title: Goldman sues ex-VPs over client poaching
summary: Goldman Sachs has sued two former vice-presidents, Jeffrey Friedstein and Joseph Page, for poaching clients and employees to start their own investment advisory business, Grey Street Capital LLC. The men, who led a seven-person team serving 50 wealthy clients, allegedly pursued a plan to set up the new company while still employed at Goldman Sachs, violating their employment agreements. The bank is seeking a court order to temporarily bar them from recruiting their former clients or colleagues, and is pursuing claims against them in arbitration through the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority (Finra).

site_title: UK police make 7th arrest in Manchester terror probe
summary: British police have made their 7th arrest in connection with the Manchester terror probe, a person from Nuneaton, central England. The arrest follows searches at an address in Nuneaton, marking the first outside the Manchester area. The Greater Manchester Police force confirmed the arrest without releasing further details. This latest development comes as the investigation into the May 2017 concert massacre that left 22 people dead continues.

site_title: Why the best restaurant in Asia is shutting down
summary: Bangkok's renowned Indian restaurant, Gaggan, run by Chef Gaggan Anand, is shutting down after winning the Asia's 50 Best awards for the third consecutive year. The restaurant's high demand, with 500 booking requests daily, has become unsustainable, prompting Anand to consider shutting down. A Michelin star is also within reach, but Anand has decided to prioritize his personal well-being and the restaurant's quality over the accolades. The decision is a surprise, given the restaurant's recent successes, and has left fans and critics alike in shock.

images.alt_text: Chef Gaggan Anand's response? Shut it down.

site_title: Asia's development banks pursue different agendas
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has diverged from China's "pragmatic" approach to development, with the US and Japan influencing its policies. Founded in 1966, the ADB's original purpose was to foster economic growth and cooperation in Asia, but it has since pursued a broader development agenda. The ADB's experience is chronicled in a recent book, while China's One Belt-One Road (OBOR) scheme and the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) represent a more ideological and infrastructure-focused approach. The ADB's agility and willingness to adapt to different priorities have allowed it to survive tensions between its shareholders, but the rivalry between the ADB and AIIB is likely to focus on ideological differences in the coming years.

site_title: GM to cut jobs in international HQ in Singapore: source
summary: General Motors (GM) plans to cut approximately 130 jobs at its international headquarters in Singapore by the end of 2017, as part of its efforts to reduce exposure to unprofitable markets. The move is part of GM's restructuring efforts, which include a US$500 million charge in the second quarter to restructure operations in India, Africa, and Singapore. The company aims to focus on more profitable markets such as China, North America, and Latin America, and will stop selling Chevrolet brand vehicles in India by the end of the year.

site_title: Passenger car COE premiums fall
summary: Singapore's passenger car COE premiums fell substantially in the second bidding exercise of May, with the small-car category (Cat A) slumping by nearly S$5,000. Category A shed S$4,617 to S$46,489, while Cat E, the open category, dipped S$3,000 to S$52,000. The drop was attributed to a shift in interest from Cat A to Cat C, with some buyers opting for light commercial vehicle models due to the low COE premium.

site_title: US April home sales fall as tight supply boosts prices
summary: US existing home sales fell 2.3% in April to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.57 million units, despite the sales pace being the fourth highest in the past 12 months. A tight supply of houses on the market, keeping prices elevated, weighed down the decline. The median house price increased 6.0% from a year ago to $244,800, the highest level since June 2016, and it would take 4.2 months to clear the stock of houses on the market at the current sales pace.

site_title: Dollar pinned near 6 ½ month lows, Fed minutes in focus
summary: The US dollar remained near 6 ½-month lows on Wednesday, influenced by a Federal Reserve official's comments on a potential interest rate hike next month. Expectations of a fiscal boost from US President Donald Trump have decreased, while a resurgent euro has eroded dollar gains since Trump's election. Investors are shifting focus to monetary policy, driving the dollar's value.

site_title: Noble says it's still in talks; but market's unmoved
summary: NOBLE Group's shares plummeted 8.3% to 38.5 cents, despite being in talks with strategic partners, after trading was halted and some brokerages imposed trading curbs. The commodity trader's bonds, however, rose. The market's reaction suggests no reprieve for the company, which faces significant challenges.

site_title: From being bullied, he now rings in boxers
summary: Scott O'Farrell, the founder and CEO of Ringstar Management, has come a long way from being bullied as a child. He discovered martial arts, initially focusing on taekwondo, before transitioning to boxing at 18. O'Farrell, now 46, has had a successful amateur boxing career, and his company is promoting the Roar of Singapore II event at Resorts World Sentosa on May 27. The event will feature a sold-out crowd and be broadcast live on Eleven Sports, with a potential global reach. O'Farrell aims to establish Ringstar as the ultimate prize fighter platform, rivaling the UFC.

site_title: GasHub to list on ASX via reverse takeover of Raffles Capital
summary: GasHub, a Singapore-based gas piping and energy services specialist, will list on the Australian Securities Exchange (ASX) via a reverse takeover of Raffles Capital Limited, raising up to A$10 million. The company aims to expand its operations in Singapore and the Asia-Pacific, leveraging its patented 3GEX System and eco-friendly energy solutions. GasHub's annual revenue is expected to increase to A$12 million, with projected net profit before tax of about A$1 million. The company will issue new shares to GasHub shareholders and the public, with the public offer opening on July 13.

site_title: Surbana, CGIF team up to boost local-currency financing for projects
summary: Surbana Jurong, a leading urbanisation consultancy, has partnered with the Credit Guarantee & Investment Facility (CGIF) to boost local-currency financing for greenfield projects in South-east Asia. The tie-up, inked at the Global Infrastructure Initiative, aims to attract investors to use local currency bonds for greenfield projects. CGIF will offer up to $140 million in unconditional guarantees per project, reducing currency mismatch risks. The partnership is seen as a significant boost to local-currency financing, preferred over foreign currencies, to mitigate conversion losses and support infrastructure development in the region.

images.alt_text: The tie-up aims to attract investors to make investments in greenfield projects using local currency bonds by marrying the engineering capabilities of Surbana Jurong with the financial strength of CGIF as a guarantor.
Wong Shiying

site_title: Ex-remisier fined S$9,000 in 1MDB-linked corruption case
summary: A Singapore judge fined former remisier Kelvin Ang S$9,000 for bribing an analyst in 2013 to expedite a favourable research report for PetroSaudi Oil Services, a company linked to the 1Malaysia Development Bhd scandal. Ang pleaded guilty to corruption charges and had already served three weeks in jail before being released on bail. The bribe allowed Ang to collect US$235,000 in referral fees. This conviction brings Singapore's total convictions in the 1MDB probe to five, with Ang not expected to appeal.

site_title: Infrastructure plans help capital markets grow
summary: Singapore's infrastructure development projects, such as the North-South Corridor and the Singapore-Kuala Lumpur High Speed Railway, are expected to trigger more capital markets activity. A strong local currency capital market is crucial for diversifying credit sources, recycling savings, and funding long-dated assets. This will help stabilize credit flows during times of volatility. The projects aim to create an alternative to bank funding, supporting economic growth and development.

site_title: China's agriculture drawbacks: too little land, too many tiny plots
summary: China's agricultural landscape is characterized by limited arable land, with four-fifths of farmland consisting of plots smaller than 3.3 hectares, often less than a football field in size. Most of these plots are used to grow cereals like rice and wheat, with farmers relying on government-subsidized chemicals to boost yields and maintain state grain silos. The country's agricultural challenges, including soil contamination, are attributed to the fragmentation of land and aging population, hindering the country's ability to increase food production.

site_title: M'sian money, opulent ideas, but now a forced sale
summary: A US court has ordered the forced sale of the Park Lane, a luxury hotel in New York, due to allegations that financier Jho Low and his associates diverted billions of dollars from a Malaysian development fund to acquire the property. The hotel was acquired by a group led by developer Steven Witkoff in 2013, with Low providing 85% of the funding. Authorities claim that the money was stolen from the Malaysian people and used for lavish spending and investments. The sale of the hotel is part of a larger investigation into international money laundering schemes.

images.alt_text: The Park Lane Hotel in Manhattan. Developer Steven Witkoff and his partners are being forced by US authorities to put the building up for sale. A marketing book is being sent to prospective bidders this week.

site_title: Jump in Nam Cheong, Sunningdale shares triggers trading queries
summary: Shares of Nam Cheong and Sunningdale Tech surged amid heavy trading in Singapore, with Nam Cheong's shares rising 35% and Sunningdale Tech's shares jumping 8.6%. Nam Cheong's CEO attributed the surge to discussions with lenders to address debt maturities, while Sunningdale Tech claimed to be unaware of any information explaining the trading. Both companies reported financial results, with Nam Cheong posting a net loss and Sunningdale Tech reporting a net profit.

site_title: Google data-mine digs into credit-card privacy
summary: Google has begun using billions of credit-card transaction records to prove that its online ads are prompting people to make purchases, even in offline brick-and-mortar stores. The tech giant's new system connects digital trails to real-world purchase records, allowing it to understand purchase activity beyond location tracking. Google claims to have developed a "double-blind" encryption technology to protect user privacy, but privacy advocates express concern over the handling of sensitive data and the lack of transparency. The move aims to prove the effectiveness of digital ads, but raises questions about consumer consent and data protection.

site_title: Supply constraints dictating the shape of America's growth
summary: US cities are experiencing supply constraints, particularly in expensive coastal areas like San Francisco, where development is limited by geography and local opposition. Despite this, some cities are still seeing growth, with San Francisco adding 5,114 net new housing units in 2016. Similar challenges are being faced by other cities, including Manhattan, which is seeing record rent increases. These supply constraints are driving up housing costs and affecting demand for luxury properties, with some developers selling off assets to adapt to the changing market.

site_title: Samsung investigating Galaxy S8 'iris hack'
summary: Samsung is investigating claims by the Chaos Computer Club that its Galaxy S8 device can be unlocked using a printed photo of the owner's eye, replicating the curvature of a real eyeball. The German hacking group demonstrated this vulnerability in a video, stating that a high-resolution picture from the internet can capture an iris. Samsung has released a statement saying it is aware of the report and will respond quickly if there is a potential vulnerability. The company's iris scanning technology was developed through rigorous testing, and it is urging customers to use traditional PIN protection instead of body features for authentication.

site_title: Noble's rot isn't fatal yet. Just ask John Paul Getty
summary: Noble Group Ltd, a commodities trader, faces a debt crisis with S&P Global Ratings warning of a risk of default within a year. The company's shares and bonds have plummeted, with yields on its bonds rising to 48% and its shares falling 32%. Despite this, Noble's liquidity appears strong, with $1.55 billion in cash and equivalents. The company's lenders are keeping it afloat, but its long-term health remains uncertain due to a costly business model and dependence on commodity prices.

site_title: Trump dumps 'clean coal' research
summary: US President Donald Trump's budget proposes slashing the Energy Department's research on capturing and storing CO2 emissions from coal-fired power plants by 85%, from $200 million to $31 million. The move is seen as a disappointment by coal industry advocates, who argue that the technology is necessary to make coal "clean". Critics, including former Energy Secretary Ernest Moniz, call the move a "retreat of American leadership" on climate change, while Trump claims his administration will bring about "clean coal".

site_title: Trump adds one more Chinese trademark to his portfolio
summary: US President Donald Trump has received preliminary approval for a 116th trademark in China, expanding his business interests in the country. The trademark, for apparel, was filed in June 2016 and approved by China's Trademark Office on May 6. Trump's daughter Ivanka has also secured several trademarks in China through her business. Critics argue that the trademarks could lead to conflicts and perception problems, while others see them as a strategic move to protect the Trump brand.

site_title: Mayor, DC Council pitch builders, retailers in Vegas
summary: Washington D.C. Mayor Muriel Bowser and nine council members, including a supermajority, traveled to Las Vegas for a conference hosted by the International Council of Shopping Centers, funded in part with taxpayer dollars. The trip was aimed at courting national retail chains, with the city seeking to capitalize on its growing retail space and gentrification concerns. Critics argue that the trip was unnecessary and that taxpayer funds should be focused on addressing income disparity and maximizing spending for those in need, particularly in light of the upcoming city budget vote.

site_title: Blackstone, SoftBank deals put Riyadh's sovereign fund on the world map
summary: Saudi Arabia's sovereign wealth fund, the Public Investment Fund, signed billions of dollars in deals with Blackstone Group LP and SoftBank Group Corp, aiming to expand into the world's largest fund. The fund, part of Vision 2030, plans to diversify revenue away from oil and control over $2 trillion. Deputy Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman stated this goal, with the sale of a stake in oil giant Aramco expected to provide funds for investment.

site_title: Keppel O&M wins first LNG carrier newbuild order
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine has secured its first LNG carrier newbuild order, valued at S$103 million, to build two small-scale LNGCs for Stolt-Nielsen Gas BV. The contract, awarded to Keppel Singmarine, is expected to be exercised within six, 12, and 18 months, with deliveries set for 2019. This order marks a significant opportunity for Keppel Singmarine to break into the LNG shipbuilding market in Singapore.

site_title: 'Belt and Road' will carry China far
summary: China's Belt and Road Initiative, a network of roads, ports, and projects connecting Asia, Europe, and Africa, was launched last week with a cumulative total investment estimated in the trillions of dollars. The initiative, championed by President Xi Jinping, aims to elevate China to global leadership, with 68 countries on three continents participating. The project's implications are largely political, and its success is seen as a major win for China, despite criticism from the European Union. The initiative's total value is estimated at over $1 trillion, with China promising to share the benefits with the rest of the world.

site_title: Over 1 in 5 cars registered in Q1 a private-hire vehicle
summary: Over 22% of new cars registered in Singapore's Q1 2017 were private-hire vehicles, with 5,100 registrations, accounting for 22.9% of the total 22,315 new cars. This growth has raised concerns among car distributors about the fate of private car ownership and taxi operators, who face higher COE premiums due to the high demand from private-hire companies. Distributors warn that this trend could lead to a decrease in private car ownership and negatively impact the taxi industry.

site_title: International Healthway Corporation warns of net loss for FY16 ended Dec 31
summary: International Healthway Corporation Limited (IHC) is expected to report a net loss for FY16, primarily due to impairment of goodwill. The company is finalizing its financial results, scheduled for release by May 31.

site_title: CIMB posts record Q1 profit of RM1.18b
summary: CIMB Group Holdings has posted a record Q1 profit of RM1.18 billion, a 45% jump from the previous year, driven by more profitable loans and non-lending activities. The lender's net interest income rose 11.5% and non-interest income surged 32.3%. The company is cautiously optimistic for the rest of 2017, citing stable economic conditions and declining provisions. This follows a strengthening Malaysian economy, which is expected to benefit CIMB and its rival Malayan Banking Bhd.

site_title: Geely to get operating control of Proton under stake-purchase deal
summary: Malaysia's DRB-Hicom Bhd has agreed to sell 49.9% of Proton Holdings Bhd to China's Zhejiang Geely Holding Group Co, gaining management and operating control. Geely will also acquire 51% of Lotus Advance Technologies Sdn Bhd. The deal aims to salvage Proton, Malaysia's first national car.

site_title: Adani may exit US$16.5b Aussie coal project without deal: minister
summary: India's Adani Group may exit its US$16.5 billion Carmichael coal project in Australia unless a royalties deal is reached with the state government. The project's development is contingent on the Queensland government's decision on their royalties policy, according to Federal Resources Minister Matthew Canavan. The project, which could create 10,000 jobs, has been delayed due to protests and court claims over its environmental impact. Adani had initially planned to start mining coal in 2020, but the company has deferred its final investment decision.

site_title: Bernanke urges BOJ to continue with aggressive easing policy
summary: Former US Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke endorsed the Bank of Japan's aggressive monetary easing policy, urging the BOJ to continue pursuing its target of 2% inflation. Bernanke suggested stepping up purchases of Japanese Government Bonds and other financial assets to achieve this goal, which could boost Japan's economy and keep the yen from appreciating. The yen weakened to below 112 to the US dollar following Bernanke's remarks, which may provide the BOJ with ammunition to justify continued monetary easing and delay an exit strategy.

site_title: Asset managers must evolve and adapt to tap Asean growth
summary: The asset management market in South-east Asia is expected to grow to $4 trillion by 2025, driven by changing demographics and the rise of robo-advisers. The "silver tsunami" of an aging population, with 15% of the 1 billion+ aged 50+ by 2025 coming from South-east Asia, will pressure pension funds to seek risk management frameworks. Asset managers must adapt to this shift, using technological innovations such as advanced analytics and cloud computing to boost efficiency. Strategic partnerships and digital services can also help them tap into the growing middle class and digitally-savvy population.

site_title: High ticket prices are fuelling a Broadway boom
summary: The Broadway season ended with a record-breaking box-office gross of $1.449 billion, a 5.5% increase from the previous year. High ticket prices, fueled by dynamic pricing strategies, drove the growth, with average ticket prices reaching a record $109. Despite a slight decrease in overall attendance, the industry's success is attributed to the popularity of hit shows such as Hamilton and Hello, Dolly!, which continue to attract sold-out crowds. However, the industry still faces challenges, with many shows struggling to find success and a lack of new audience growth.

site_title: Rowsley to acquire AC Consortium for up to S$8m
summary: Rowsley Ltd, a Singaporean real estate and investment company, will acquire industrial building design firm AC Consortium for up to S$8 million through its subsidiary RSP Architects Planners & Engineers. The acquisition is conditional upon Singapore Exchange approval and will be immediately earnings accretive. AC Consortium specializes in designing industrial buildings, with significant projects including One Commonwealth and West Park BizCentral. The deal is expected to position Rowsley for growth in the industrial sector and is not expected to impact its net tangible assets or earnings per share for the current financial year.

site_title: RBS talks to settle Goodwin trial hindered by missing investors
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland Group Plc continues to make progress toward settling a lawsuit linked to its near collapse during the financial crisis. Despite reports of stalled talks, lawyers for investors say progress remains good, with RBS doubling its offer to 82 pence per share. The trial, which was set to start Monday, has been postponed until June 7 as lawyers struggle to contact missing investors. A judge has agreed to delay the trial, citing the "substantial importance" of finding all claimants before proceeding.

site_title: S&P affirms 'AA-' credit ratings for 3 Singapore banks
summary: S&P Global Ratings has affirmed the "AA-" credit ratings for DBS, OCBC, and UOB, the only Singapore banks to hold this rating, citing their sound fundamentals and buffers against potential asset quality pressures. The ratings agency expects the banks to maintain adequate capitalization, liquidity profiles, and provisioning buffers, despite weakening asset quality and higher provisioning costs. The outlook on the ratings is stable, with S&P noting that Singapore banks are coming from a position of strength and have sufficient buffers against downside risks.

site_title: Yoma Q4 profit up 171% at S$24m
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings posted a 171% increase in Q4 net profit to S$24.1 million, driven by higher fair value gains on investment properties, particularly in Myanmar. Revenue rose 18% to S$53.8 million, with the non-real estate business segment contributing nearly 47% to group revenue. The company proposed a 0.25 Singapore cent cash dividend per share and maintained its profitability while reducing reliance on real estate businesses.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Up for grabs: S$2.4b of government tenders in Smart Nation drive
summary: The Singapore government plans to invest S$2.4 billion in ICT tenders in 2017 to drive the Smart Nation initiative. This includes projects such as data analytics, cybersecurity, and IoT applications for various government departments, including the National Library Board, Ministry of Education, and Maritime and Port Authority. The government aims to boost digital capabilities and lay the foundation for future growth, partnering with industry and small and medium enterprises to achieve this goal.

images.alt_text: Announcing this on Wednesday at GovTech's annual Smart Nation and Digital Government industry briefing, GovTech chief executive Jacqueline Poh said the government would invest in technologies such as data analytics, sensors and related software and systems.

site_title: Moody's cuts China's rating, warns of fading financial strength as debt mounts
summary: Moody's downgraded China's credit ratings to A1 from Aa3, citing a fading financial strength due to rising debt and slowing growth. The downgrade reflects Moody's expectation that China's economy will continue to rely on stimulus measures to meet growth targets, increasing reliance on debt and potentially leading to a further rise in contingent liabilities for the government. The downgrade is Moody's first in nearly 30 years, with China's Finance Ministry disputing the methodology and arguing that the risks to the economy are overstated.

site_title: Market firm with STI up 8.55 points
summary: The Straits Times Index rose 8.55 points to 3,231.24, tracking overseas market movements, despite a terror attack in the UK and US reports of President Trump's request to push back against the FBI's Russia probe. Banking sector stocks, including UOB, rose, with UOB's net interest income growth outpacing peers. The property sector saw Wing Tai's shares surge after the company announced a takeover offer for its Malaysian-listed counterpart.

site_title: Austria's ams AG unveils S$500 million new plant in Singapore
summary: Ams AG, a leading supplier of high-performance sensor solutions, has unveiled a new S$500 million manufacturing facility in Singapore, marking the largest investment in the precision engineering industry in the country over the last decade. The facility, which will create high-skilled jobs, is part of ams's expansion strategy to meet growing demand for advanced sensor solutions in sophisticated mobile applications. The investment is also seen as a key part of Singapore's Precision Engineering Industry Transformation Map, which aims to transform industries and jobs through collaborative relationships and reskilling programs.

site_title: ECB sounds cautious note on bond markets
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) issued a cautious warning about the potential for withdrawing its ultra-easy monetary policy too early, despite the eurozone's best economic run in a decade. Despite improving data, the ECB remains cautious about inflation, and policymakers are divided on the timing of reducing stimulus. Analysts expect a 50% chance of a rate hike in March 2018, while ECB members emphasize the need to err on the side of caution.

site_title: The US budget: riddled with unreal assumptions and wishful thinking
summary: US President Donald Trump's first budget, released on May 24, 2017, proposes severe cuts in social programs, including Medicaid, student loan subsidies, and foreign aid, while sparing Medicare and Social Security. Spending cuts total $3.6 trillion, with a 10% increase in defense spending and a $1.6 billion outlay for the border wall. The budget assumes 3% economic growth, despite projections of 1.9% by the Congressional Budget Office. Many experts consider the budget unrealistic and politically motivated, with Democrats and some Republicans likely to oppose the cuts.

site_title: ECB: Eurozone growth is improving but inflation is not
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) suggests that Eurozone growth is improving, but inflation remains weak. Policymakers indicate that the ECB will adjust its policy to reflect this growth, but inflation needs a convincing upward trend before stimulus measures are removed. Conservative countries, such as Germany, have been pressing for the ECB to wind down its stimulus measures, including the 2.3 trillion euro asset purchase program and negative interest rates.

site_title: US: Wall St little changed ahead of Fed minutes
summary: US stocks were little changed ahead of the Federal Reserve's minutes from its May meeting, with traders now seeing a 75% chance of a rate hike in June. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.02%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also increased. Despite mixed economic data, the job market continues to strengthen, potentially giving the Fed impetus to continue monetary tightening. Existing home sales are expected to fall in April, but the housing market recovery is driven by low mortgage rates and a tightening labor market.

site_title: Two dead in blasts at bus terminal in Jakarta
summary: Two blasts occurred at a bus terminal in Jakarta, Indonesia, on May 24, 2017, causing casualties. The East Jakarta police chief reported three victims, with two confirmed dead, and described the explosions as "pretty big." The cause of the blasts was unclear, but the Kampung Melayu terminal, which serves mini-vans and buses, was cordoned off by police.

site_title: SIA mulling over possibility of raising funds in US$ bonds
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is considering raising funds in US-dollar bonds to diversify its debt sources and reduce reliance on the local currency market. The airline plans to spend S$30.1 billion over the next 5 years, mainly on planes, which could lead to higher borrowing costs. SIA's Chief Financial Officer, Stephen Barnes, stated that the carrier will take its time to explore options, but a shift to US-dollar bonds is a possibility. This move may increase borrowing costs for the carrier.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: mm2 Asia reported a strong FY March 2017 results with net profit of S$18.8 million (+130% YoY) and revenue of S$95.4 million (+149%). The increase in revenue was driven by its newly acquired subsidiary UnUsUal and cinema business. Analysts at DBS Group Research and RHB Research upgraded their target prices to S$0.70 and S$9.10 respectively, citing growth prospects driven by productions, China expansion, and UnUsUal's contribution.

site_title: EuroSports posts deeper loss of S$7.97m for FY17
summary: EuroSports Global, the agent for Lamborghini, reported a net loss of S$7.97 million for FY17, down from a net loss of S$4.5 million the previous year. Revenue decreased 17.5% to S$52.4 million due to weak market conditions and decreased sales of automobiles and deLaCour watches. The group expects a challenging next year due to intense competition in the Singapore market and potential policies affecting automobile ownership affordability.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended with gains, recovering from an initial sell-off following Moody's downgrade of China's credit rating. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.10% to close at 25,428.50, marking a fourth consecutive gain.

site_title: Pollux Properties posts 55.5% rise in full-year profit
summary: Pollux Properties reported a 55.5% rise in net profit to S$2.58 million for the full year ended March 31, driven by a 51.3% increase in share of results from a joint venture. The surge was mainly due to revenue recognition from the Pavilion Square project. Despite a 38.1% drop in group revenue, the company expects wider revenue streams and stable income from its serviced residences and associate fund management company.

site_title: Sinwa secures A$8m worth of new supply contracts from Shell Prelude FLNG project
summary: Sinwa Limited secured A$8m worth of new supply contracts from Shell's Prelude FLNG project, the largest sum from a single project in Western Australia and Northern Territory. The contracts cater to over 1,000 personnel involved in the project, which is located in the Browse Basin, 475 km northeast of Broome. The company will service clients through its 10,000 sqm Darwin facility equipped with warehousing and storage facilities.

site_title: 2 killed in Jakarta blasts; Manchester bomber had links to ISIS
summary: Two explosions occurred near a bus station in Jakarta, Indonesia, killing a suspected suicide bomber and a police officer. The blasts happened close to each other, near the Kampung Melayu terminal, and caused significant damage. In Manchester, a suicide bomber, Salman Abedi, killed 22 people at a concert, and authorities believe he had links to ISIS. Abedi had recently returned from Libya and was known to security services. The UK raised its threat level to "critical" after the Manchester attack, and troops were deployed to key sites across Britain to prevent further attacks.

site_title: Defiant Duterte threatens harsh measures as thousands flee Philippines unrest
summary: Thousands of civilians fled the Philippines city of Marawi as troops sought to contain Islamic State-linked militants who took over the city, set buildings ablaze, and captured a Catholic priest. President Rodrigo Duterte declared martial law on Mindanao, vowing to rebuff extremists and spare no one who defies the government. The military reported 13 militants and 7 troops killed, with 33 troops wounded. Duterte warned of harsh measures, including checkpoints and searches without warrants, and threatened to declare martial law nationwide if extremists proliferate.

site_title: US existing home sales fall as tight supply lifts prices
summary: US existing home sales declined 2.3% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.57 million units in April, due to a tight supply of houses on the market that is keeping prices elevated and sidelining prospective buyers. This marks the fourth highest sales pace over the past 12 months, despite a slight revision to March's sales pace to 5.70 million units, the highest level since February 2007.

images.alt_text: US home resales fell more than expected in April, weighed down by a chronic shortage of houses on the market that is keeping prices elevated and sidelining prospective buyers.

site_title: Oxley Holdings buys freehold property at East Coast for S$10.5m
summary: OXLEY Holdings Limited has acquired a freehold property at 494 Upper East Coast Road in Singapore for S$10.5 million. The 1,292.1 square meter property is zoned "part residential/part road" and the group plans to redevelop it, subject to necessary approvals. The purchase will be funded by internal resources and bank borrowings.

site_title: Taiwan court rules in favour of same-sex marriage, first in Asia
summary: Taiwan's Constitutional Court ruled in favor of same-sex marriage, becoming the first country in Asia to do so. The court declared that current marriage laws were "in violation of people's freedom of marriage and right to equality" and gave two years for legal amendments. If no changes are made, same-sex couples can register for marriage. Hundreds of supporters celebrated the decision, which was supported by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party. The ruling's lead lawyer stated that it marked a clear victory for equal rights in marriage and a victory for the people.

site_title: Jessica Tan appointed independent director at Capitaland Commercial Trust
summary: Jessica Tan, a former managing director of Microsoft Singapore, has been appointed as a non-executive independent director at Capitaland Commercial Trust (CCT) effective May 25, 2017. Tan brings over 27 years of IT industry experience and a proven track record in management to the board, which will benefit discussions on the future of work and its impact on office real estate.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Keppel Singmarine gets S$103m LNGC order
summary: Keppel Singmarine has secured a contract valued at S$103 million to build two small-scale liquefied natural gas carriers (LNGC) for Stolt Nielsen Gas BV. The company also holds options for three additional LNGCs, with deliveries expected in 2019. Keppel Singmarine is a wholly-owned subsidiary of Keppel Offshore & Marine.

site_title: Former remisier fined S$9,000 after pleading guilty to corruption in 1MDB case
summary: Former Singaporean remisier Kelvin Ang was fined S$9,000 after pleading guilty to a corruption charge related to the 1MDB case. Ang, a former Maybank Kim Eng employee, was charged with paying S$3,000 to a research analyst to expedite a favourable research report. The case is part of investigations into the Malaysian state fund 1MDB.

site_title: Pace of Gulf tech deals heats up as Emaar buys Namshi stake
summary: Emaar Malls will acquire a 51% stake in e-commerce fashion website Namshi from Global Fashion Group for $151 million. The deal marks a growing demand for tech deals in the Middle East and comes two months after Amazon's purchase of Souq.com. The acquisition is expected to allow Namshi to expand to neighboring countries and add more fashion brands. Emaar and GFG plan to jointly develop the business until a possible listing or takeover, benefiting Rocket Internet, which has seen its shares rise after a fundraising round.

site_title: Trustee-manager of RHT Health Trust prices S$60m fixed notes due 2018
summary: RHT Health Trust Manager Pte Ltd priced S$60 million fixed rate notes due 2018 with 4.50% interest, to be issued on May 31. The notes will be the second tranche of the Trustee-Manager's Programme, bringing the total issued to S$120 million. The net proceeds will be used for refinancing or repayment of existing borrowings. DBS Bank and United Overseas Bank have been appointed as joint lead managers.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The S&P Global credit rating agency reaffirmed the credit ratings of three Singapore banks due to their sound financial profiles and stable outlook. Meanwhile, car COE premiums fell, with Category A dropping to S$46,489 and Category B decreasing to S$53,001. In other news, Malaysia's industrial production rose 0.3% in May, while China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Singapore shares finish higher in low volume
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 8.55 points to 3,231.24 at 5pm on May 24, 2017, with a relatively firm broad market. The index initially rose on Dow futures, but slid in the late afternoon as European markets opened in the red. Volume was 2 billion units worth S$994.2 million, an improvement over last year's daily averages.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed higher on Wednesday, up 3.840 points to 1,771.010, with 3.3769 billion lots traded worth RM2.896 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 546 to 419.

site_title: Car COE premiums fall
summary: Singapore passenger car COE premiums fell in the second May bidding exercise, with Category A dropping by nearly S$5,000 to S$46,489. Category B and E premiums also decreased, while Category C saw a rise. Motorcycle COE premiums decreased by S$200 to S$6,101, while goods vehicle and bus COE premiums increased by S$4,571 to S$30,600. The decrease is attributed to reduced demand and increased supply in the market.

site_title: Secura Group in 2-year alliance with ComfortDelGro Insurance Brokers
summary: Secura Group Limited has formed a two-year strategic alliance with ComfortDelGro Insurance Brokers (CDGI), where Red Sentry Pte Ltd, a subsidiary of Secura Group, will serve as CDGI's cyber advisory and consultancy partner. In return, CDGI will act as Red Sentry's insurance and risk consultancy partner, offering insurance broking services to its customers. This partnership aims to provide cyber security related consultancy, products, and services to CDGI's enterprise customers, as well as free vulnerability assessments.

site_title: Tories on the defensive over policy reversals ahead of British election
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May's election plan has been derailed as the Conservative party's lead has halved to 9 percentage points, down from 18, with just over a fortnight until polling day. The Tory majority in seats is expected to be double digits, a significant shift from triple-digit predictions. The election now has the potential to produce an unpredictable outcome, with a possible chaotic coalition of opposition parties, including Labour, Liberal Democrats, and Scottish Nationalists, and the likelihood of an unlikely event, such as a coalition, cannot be ruled out.

site_title: Trump goes back to basics in Middle East
summary: US President Donald Trump has shifted his Middle East strategy, aligning US interests with Arab monarchies and autocratic regimes, a move seen as a return to realpolitik. This approach, which has been criticized by neo-conservatives and liberal internationalists, aims to support regimes willing to cooperate with the US and maintain stability in the region. Trump's decision marks a departure from the failed policies of his predecessors, including regime change and nation-building, which led to increased instability and terrorism. By embracing this strategy, Trump seeks to advance US interests and contain radical Sunni and Shiite forces, while engaging Russia in diplomacy to counter Islamist radicalism.

images.alt_text: President Trump and his wife upon leaving Riyadh for Israel on Monday. The US leader will now focus on supporting regimes willing to cooperate with the US in advancing its interests in the region.

site_title: Japan government keeps its views of the economy unchanged in May
summary: Japan's government has maintained its assessment of the economy as "moderate recovery, but delays in improvement can be seen in some parts" for the sixth consecutive month, according to its May report. The economy is recovering gradually, with exports and factory output benefiting from a recovery in global demand.

site_title: Ikea Group appoints Jesper Brodin new CEO
summary: Ikea Group appoints Jesper Brodin as new CEO, replacing Peter Agnefjall, effective September 1. Brodin, currently head of Ikea of Sweden, will oversee the global company. He will be based in Leiden, Netherlands, and succeeds Agnefjall, who will take time off with his family before his next venture.

images.alt_text: Furniture retailer Ikea Group said on Wednesday it had appointed company veteran Jesper Brodin as new chief executive, replacing Peter Agnefjall.

site_title: SATS introduces innovation centre to spearhead productivity efforts
summary: SATS has launched TechnIC@SATS, a technology innovation centre aimed at boosting productivity and enhancing services. The centre, valued at S$110 million, will spearhead technological solutions for the group's business units. Since 2014, SATS has implemented robotics and automation, resulting in a 13.3% operating margin and a 7.7% increase in value added per employment cost. The centre will build on these efforts to further improve productivity and services.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Thailand holds key rate, stays wary of global risks
summary: Thailand's central bank, the Bank of Thailand, kept its key interest rate at 1.50% for over two years, citing improved economic growth and low demand-pull inflationary pressures. The decision is seen as a prolonged hold, with no incentive to cut rates and no need to raise them. The bank is monitoring external risks, including US rate hikes and geopolitical tensions, but expects the economy to grow at 3.4% this year.

site_title: ECB sees risk higher yields trigger debt sustainability concerns
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has raised concerns about debt sustainability due to potential higher yields and political uncertainty in some countries. The risk of a rapid repricing in global fixed income markets remains significant, with the possibility of spillovers from the US. Euro-area banks are vulnerable due to low interest rates and non-performing loans, but the ECB believes the risk of financial service restrictions after Brexit is limited. The bank urges banks to prepare for a potential relocation of financial services capacity during the transition.

site_title: At technology's fore
summary: A new bridge in Punggol, Singapore, will be built using precast technology, with almost every component made in a factory and transported to the site for installation. Hwa Seng Builder, a local firm, is leading the project. The innovative method, developed by the company's founder, Thomas Ng, replaces traditional construction methods and reduces waste. The bridge's design, featuring Lego-like components, showcases the company's use of cutting-edge civil engineering techniques, marking a significant step forward in Singapore's construction industry.

site_title: China: Stocks steady, small-caps offset
summary: China's main stock indexes ended flat on Wednesday, recouping earlier losses as small-caps offset losses, despite Moody's downgrade of China's debt ratings. The CSI300 index was unchanged at 3,424.17 points, while the Shanghai Composite Index added 0.1% to 3,064.08 points. The downgrade has had a negative psychological impact on the market, with liquidity tightening in the interbank market, and interest rates expected to rise further. Most sectors lost ground, led by defensive consumer and healthcare stocks, while small-caps rallied strongly.

site_title: Australia: Stocks finish modestly higher
summary: Australian shares finished marginally higher on Wednesday, closing up 0.2% at 5,769. Biopharmaceutical company CSL Ltd was the top gainer, rising 1.4%, while testing services provider ALS Ltd reached its highest in 2-1/2 years. Sigma Healthcare plummeted 31% after commencing legal proceedings against Chemist Warehouse Group. The top loser was Rio Tinto, which slipped after China's iron ore futures fell over 5%.

site_title: North Korea balloons prompted warning shots: Seoul
summary: South Korea's military fired warning shots after unidentified flying objects, later identified as propaganda balloons, entered the country's airspace from North Korea. The balloons, which carried leaflets, were described as "balloon-like objects" and were observed flying with the winds in the border area. North Korean defector Lee Min Bok suggested the spherical balloons could be from North Korea, as cylindrical balloons are cheaper and more commonly used by Seoul and southern activists. The incident highlights tensions over North Korea's nuclear ambitions and the ongoing propaganda efforts across the border.

site_title: S&P affirms credit rating of 3 Singapore banks on sound fundamentals, stable outlook
summary: S&P Global Ratings has affirmed the credit rating of three Singapore banks - DBS, OCBC, and United Overseas Bank - due to their sound financial profiles and stable outlook. The rating agency expects the banks to maintain adequate capitalization, liquidity, and provisioning buffers, despite net profits losing momentum due to weakening asset quality and higher provisioning costs. The outlook on the issuer credit ratings remains stable, with S&P noting that the banks have sufficient buffers against downside risks and are well-positioned to continue performing well in 2017.

site_title: Singapore govt to call S$2.4b of ICT tenders in current fiscal year
summary: The Singapore government plans to call for S$2.4 billion of ICT tenders in fiscal 2017 to support the country's digitalization efforts. The investment will focus on data analytics, sensors, and related software and systems. A tender for data analytics and another for communications infrastructure to link data centers with IoT sensors will be included. This move aims to drive innovation and support the country's digital transformation.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei hits 1 week closing high; exporters, financials gain
summary: Japan's Nikkei share average reached a one-week closing high at 19,742.98, driven by a rise in the dollar against the yen and US Treasury yields, which boosted financials. The broader Topix index also advanced 0.6%, while the JPX-Nikkei Index 400 rose 0.6%. This marks the highest closing level since May 17.

site_title: SoftBank said to take US$4b stake in US chipmaker Nvidia
summary: SoftBank has taken a $4 billion stake in US chipmaker Nvidia, becoming the company's fourth-largest shareholder. The investment, worth approximately 4.9% of Nvidia's outstanding shares, is below the threshold for regulatory disclosure in the US. This move aligns with SoftBank founder Masayoshi Son's goal to become the largest investor in technology over the next decade, focusing on emerging trends such as artificial intelligence.

site_title: A new era of growth
summary: Greatearth Pte Ltd, a Singapore-based multi-disciplinary builder, is embracing a new era of growth despite its  venerable past. CEO Chang Chew Kient attributes the company's competitive advantage to its integrated business model spanning property development, engineering, and construction, allowing it to tackle larger and more complex projects. This comprehensive approach enables Greatearth to oversee projects from foundation to completion, providing a unique advantage in the industry.

site_title: UK chides US for leaking Manchester bombing probe details
summary: The UK has publicly criticized the US for leaking details about the Manchester bombing probe, with Home Secretary Amber Rudd stating that such leaks should not happen again. The leaks occurred before British authorities were ready to release information, including the identity of the attacker, Salman Ramadan Abedi. Rudd's rebuke is rare, but she assured that the US did not compromise the investigation and that the relationship between the two countries remains strong.

images.alt_text: UK Home Secretary Amber Rudd (above) criticised US officials for leaking details about Monday's terrorist attack in Manchester, warning Britain's ally that it should not happen again.

site_title: Indonesia's revenue needs override coal curbs as oil take drops
summary: Indonesia will miss its coal production targets as the government leans on coal revenue to make up for declining oil revenues. The country aims to boost coal shipments to meet its 20% increase in non-tax revenues from the mining sector, which includes coal, to replace declining oil returns. This targets exceed planned coal production curbs, undermining Indonesia's policy of using coal as the backbone of its electric power development plans. Coal production is expected to climb 5% in 2017 and 2018, despite a production cap of 400 million tonnes from 2019.

site_title: A smart way to build
summary: China Construction, a leading Singaporean builder, has adopted cutting-edge smart construction techniques, including building information models (BIM) and virtual design and construction (VDC), to raise industry standards. The company's award-winning project, High Park Residences, showcases these methods, resulting in significant productivity gains, cost savings, and improved accuracy. With its expertise in BIM and VDC, China Construction is now exploring prefabricated prefinished volumetric construction (PPVC) and utilizing drones for site monitoring, further solidifying its position as a pioneer in the industry.

site_title: Yoma Q4 net profit jumps 171% to S$24m
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings reported a 171% increase in Q4 net profit to S$24.08 million, driven by a higher fair value gain on investment properties. Revenue rose 18% to S$53.8 million, led by improved sales across all segments. Earnings per share increased to 1.39 Singapore cents from 0.51 Singapore cents a year ago.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Q1 net profit contribution from CIMB Group Holdings' Singapore operation up 121%
summary: CIMB Group Holdings reported a 121% increase in net profit contribution from its Singapore operation to RM137 million in the first quarter of 2017. The bank's record quarterly net profit was RM1.18 billion, driven by improved revenues and lower loan loss provisions. Group CEO Zafrul Aziz attributed the growth to cost management initiatives, asset quality improvement, and better capital management. The bank expects stable economic conditions and improved capital markets to support its financial targets for 2017.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: A German mark of excellence
summary: German switch and systems specialist JUNG has been a mark of excellence for over 100 years, known for its precise workmanship, timeless design, and unparalleled service. The family-run company has a strong presence globally, with luxury condominiums, hotels, and residential homes as clients. JUNG is at the forefront of the "smart home" revolution, providing innovative systems for controlling lighting, blinds, and air-conditioning. The company's commitment to German manufacturing and quality has earned it numerous awards, including the German Design Awards and the Iconic Awards.

site_title: Europe: Big oil helps shares edge up
summary: European shares edged up 0.1% on Wednesday, despite weakness in mining and autos sectors. The STOXX 600 index was supported by a rise in oil producers, while European auto stocks fell 0.9% due to a US government lawsuit against Fiat Chrysler. Mining giant Glencore also declined 1.6% after making an informal approach to USgrains trader Bunge. On the positive side, Dixons Carphone's fourth-quarter results lifted its shares 3%, and Britvic's first-half update boosted its shares.

site_title: Naspers investors see billions trapped by China success
summary: Naspers' 33% stake in Chinese internet company Tencent is now worth approximately $100 billion, surpassing Naspers' value. This investment, made since 2012, transformed Naspers into Africa's most valuable company. The company has invested $3.6 billion to drive growth in e-commerce platforms and reduce its dependence on Tencent and pay-TV. Naspers' long-serving director and chairman, Koos Bekker, has become a billionaire due to this investment, which now dwarfs other parts of the business.

site_title: Gloves off as Trump heads to Vatican
summary: US President Donald Trump visited the Vatican on May 24, 2017, meeting with Pope Francis in a bid to find common ground despite their past disagreements on issues like migration and climate change. The meeting was seen as a historic visit, with Trump emphasizing tolerance and hope. However, human rights groups urged Pope Francis to raise concerns over the US use of the death penalty and targeted assassinations. The meeting came as Trump's poll numbers were at a record low, and he sought to boost his popularity by meeting the pope, who had previously expressed admiration for Trump.

site_title: Newark airport closed after engine fire prompts plane evacuation
summary: Newark Liberty International Airport was temporarily shut down after an engine fire prompted the evacuation of United Airlines Flight 1579, bound for San Francisco.
