site_title: China investigates senior banking regulator
summary: China's anti-corruption watchdog has launched an investigation into Yang Jiacai, the assistant chairman of the China Banking Regulatory Commission, citing a "severe disciplinary violation." This is the latest high-ranking official to be probed in recent weeks, following Xiang Junbo, the head of the China Insurance Regulatory Committee. The investigation comes as President Xi Jinping's anti-corruption campaign continues, with critics arguing it is often used for political reasons. The probe also coincides with a crackdown on the financial sector, including measures to strengthen transparency and halt risky lending.

site_title: Trump condemns 'evil losers' behind Manchester attack
summary: US President Donald Trump condemned the "evil losers" behind a bomb attack in Manchester that killed at least 22 people, calling them "losers" rather than "monsters". Trump made the comments during a visit to the Palestinian territories, where he met with President Mahmud Abbas. He also spoke with British Prime Minister Theresa May to offer condolences and support. The attack, which targeted a pop concert by Ariana Grande, was Britain's deadliest extremist attack in 12 years.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump on Tuesday condemned the "evil losers" behind a bomb attack at a pop concert in the British city of Manchester that killed at least 22 people.

site_title: US:Wall Street edges up at open ahead of Trump's budget plan
summary: US stocks edged up on Tuesday ahead of President Donald Trump's first full budget plan, which aims to slash government spending and trim the deficit. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.16% to 20,928.45, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also increased. The budget proposal includes cuts to healthcare and food assistance programs, with the goal of balancing the budget over the next decade. Despite the uncertainty surrounding the budget, investors remained optimistic, with nine of the 11 major S&P 500 sectors rising.

site_title: GP Industries' losses shrink in Q4
summary: GP Industries reported a 66.5% reduction in losses in Q4, posting S$1.414 million losses compared to S$4.196 million in the same period last year. Revenue rose 12.7% to S$263.2 million. The company attributed the improvement to operational efficiencies and cost management.

site_title: Quick takes: Higher core inflation in April will not alter monetary policy outlook
summary: Singapore's headline inflation in April rose to 0.4% year-on-year, lower than expected, due to a base effect from service and conservancy charges rebates. Core inflation, which strips out accommodation costs, rose to 1.7% year-on-year, driven by higher electricity and gas prices. Economists expect headline inflation to moderate in May and remain low, with no impact on monetary policy, despite slight upside risks from property prices and certificate of entitlement quota premiums.

site_title: Hot stock: Serrano says unaware of reasons why share price up 210%
summary: Serrano, a Singapore-based interior-design contractor, saw its share price surge 210% to S$0.033, amid trading of over 47 million shares. The company stated it was unaware of any reasons for the price increase, following a meeting with creditors on May 2, 2017. Serrano reported significant losses in fiscal 2016, with net losses of S$111.6 million. The company's share price increase came after a halt in trading.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Singapore stocks finish mixed in moderate volume
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 9.12 points to 3,222.69 on Tuesday, driven by gains in DBS and OCBC banks, and Hongkong Land. The moderate volume turnover of 2 billion units worth S$1.1 billion was attributed to overnight firmness on Wall Street, where hopes for a decent budget from the Trump administration contributed to the market's stability. Despite the mixed broad market, the index's gain was largely driven by the two banks and Hongkong Land.

site_title: Meghmani Organics appoints Ankit Patel as CEO
summary: Meghmani Organics has appointed 31-year-old Ankit Patel as its new CEO, replacing Ashish Soparkar. Patel holds a degree in chemistry from Sardar Patel University and a Global Master of Business Administration from the SP Jain Center of Management. Despite being the son of the company's managing director, there is no conflict of interest, according to the company's secretary. Patel will oversee the company's expansion of its agro business.

site_title: Keppel Singmarine to build two dredgers valued at S$120m
summary: Keppel Singmarine has secured contracts to build two trailing suction hopper dredgers valued at S$120 million for Codralux S.A. The first dredger is expected to be completed by the second half of 2019, with the option for a second unit to be exercised within the next six months.

site_title: China's Huawei enters PC market to take on Lenovo, HP, Dell
summary: Huawei, a Chinese telecoms giant, has entered the PC market with three new models targeting the premium consumer segment, challenging Lenovo, HP, and Dell. The Matebook X, E 2-in-1 hybrid, and D notebook will be priced between €1,399 and €1,699, with initial sales in 12 countries. The move comes as the PC market has suffered two years of falling sales volumes, with a predicted flat outcome this year and increasing market consolidation through 2020. Huawei plans to utilize its smartphone business cost-savings and design benefits in its new line of computers.

site_title: In first test, France's Macron opens key labour reform talks
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron has begun labour reform talks, meeting with union leaders and bosses to overhaul the country's labour code. Macron aims to cut red tape and generate jobs, with a September deadline. The reforms are expected to include allowing bosses to negotiate working conditions directly with employees and imposing a ceiling on severance pay. However, unions are wary, fearing new inroads into workers' rights. The talks follow a similar attempt by Macron's predecessor, Francois Hollande, which sparked massive protests and led to the watering down of several measures.

images.alt_text: French President Emmanuel Macron got to work Tuesday on his first major agenda item of overhauling the labour code, meeting with union leaders and bosses on an issue that sparked strikes and protests last year.

site_title: Amazon TV service helps Starz, HBO stand out in Netflix era
summary: Amazon's Prime membership service is expanding its online TV offerings to the UK, Germany, and Austria, featuring 25-42 live and on-demand channels from partners like HBO, Starz, and Gaia. The initiative allows Prime subscribers to choose individual channels instead of bundling with traditional pay TV services. The move has surprised Amazon, which has put off plans for its own live service, and has been successful in driving Prime usage. The expansion aims to provide a more personalized TV experience, with Amazon handling billing and promotions, potentially disrupting traditional media companies' business models.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's April headline inflation eased to 0.4% year-on-year, below expectations. Wing Tai Holdings launched a RM290 million (S$94 million) takeover bid for Malaysian-listed Wing Tai Malaysia Berhad. Keppel Singmarine won contracts to build up to two dredgers valued at S$120 million. Singapore identified four frontier technology focus areas for development. Noble Group halted trading after its share price tumbled on reports of Sinochem's withdrawal. Vallianz Holdings secured long-term charter contracts valued at up to US$115 million for four vessels.

site_title: UK starts new fiscal year with surprise borrowing increase
summary: The UK's new fiscal year began with a surprise increase in borrowing, reaching £10.4 billion in April, the highest since 2014. This was £1.2 billion more than forecast and £3.7 billion above the previous year. Despite a narrower-than-expected deficit of 2.5% of GDP, economists had predicted a £8.7 billion gap. Government revenue rose 3.9% and spending increased 5.9%. The figures suggest the UK's economy remains resilient despite accelerating inflation and depressed consumer spending.

site_title: SingHaiyi Group's Q4 profit soars
summary: SingHaiyi Group's Q4 profit surged to S$22.15 million, a 165% increase from the same period last year, despite a 0.8% decline in revenue to S$8.19 million. Earnings per share rose to 0.77 Singapore cents, up from 0.29 cents in the previous year. The company cited diversified revenue streams and strategic corporate actions for its strong results, with completed unit sales from Vietnam Town and the disposal of its Perennial Somerset Investors stake contributing to its growth.

site_title: Malaysia's Lotte Chemical sets ceiling price for US$1.4b IPO : IFR
summary: Malaysia's Lotte Chemical Titan Holding has set a ceiling price of 8 ringgit per share for its planned IPO, valuing the company at up to 5.9 billion ringgit (S$1.901 billion). The IPO, which could be one of the biggest in years, will see 740.4 million shares sold, with proceeds to be used for a naphtha cracker plant in Indonesia. The listing, originally planned for last year, was delayed due to South Korea's investigations into alleged fraud at Lotte Group.

site_title: UN vows to tighten sanctions on North Korea
summary: The UN Security Council has unanimously agreed to tighten sanctions on North Korea in response to its latest missile launch, with the council instructing the UN sanctions committee to implement tough measures. The US-drafted statement, backed by China, calls for further significant sanctions to force North Korea to change its behavior and end its "highly destabilising" actions. The latest launch, of a medium-range missile, has raised concerns about North Korea's ability to develop an intercontinental ballistic missile capable of hitting the US.

site_title: German business confidence hits highest level since 1991
summary: German business confidence reached its highest level since 1991, rising to 114.6 points in May, according to a survey from the Ifo institute. The positive data is driven by strong manufacturing and construction sectors, with growth rates at record levels since 1991. The German economy expanded by 0.6% in the first quarter and is expected to reach 1.5% growth for the full year. This uptick in confidence is seen as a sign of a still-growing economy, with economists predicting growth to reach at least 1.8% this year.

site_title: UK's consumer slowdown ripples through Britain's economy
summary: The UK's economy has slowed due to a Brexit-induced consumer slowdown, affecting government finances and retailers. Sales tax revenues have declined, widening the budget deficit by over 13% to £10.4 billion in April. Business confidence among retailers has fallen at the fastest pace since 2012, and the economy's growth is expected to more than halve in the first quarter of 2017. This slowdown is attributed to a steady rise in inflation and weak wage growth, posing a challenge for Prime Minister Theresa May's plans to eliminate the budget deficit by the middle of the next decade.

site_title: Update: Suicide bomber kills 22 people at UK concert for teenagers
summary: A suicide bomber killed 22 people, including children, in a concert at Manchester Arena in northern England on Monday. The attack, carried out by one man, was the worst terror incident on British soil since 2005. Fifty-nine others were injured, with some eyewitnesses describing shrapnel wounds consistent with a nail bomb. Prime Minister Theresa May has convened an emergency meeting to discuss the attack, which comes just two months after a similar incident in London and raises concerns about Britain's security ties with the EU.

site_title: Europe: Tech, banks keep stocks afloat
summary: European tech stocks, led by Nokia's 6% jump, helped buoy the STOXX 600 index. Germany's DAX rose 0.2%, while euro zone bluechips rose 0.3%. Basic resources shares fell due to lower metals prices. In the UK, the FTSE 100 rose 0.1%, driven by a weaker sterling. The market was unaffected by a suicide bombing in Manchester, with shares of Merlin Entertainments falling 1%.

site_title: Google AI programme beats top-ranked Go player
summary: Google's AI programme AlphaGo defeated the world's top-ranked Go player, Ke Jie, in a three-game series, marking a significant milestone in artificial intelligence. AlphaGo, developed by DeepMind Technologies, stunned the Go community with its win, re-affirming its capabilities as a ground-breaking new form of AI. This victory follows AlphaGo's previous win over South Korean grandmaster Lee Se-Dol, and sets the stage for a brave new world of AI that can tackle complex scientific, technical, and medical problems.

site_title: War on sugar turns decades of growth into industry tipping point
summary: The global sugar industry is facing a turning point due to declining demand growth, with raw sugar prices dropping 16% to rank bottom on the Bloomberg Commodity Index. Consumers in top markets like India and Europe are cutting back on sugary drinks, and food manufacturers are reformulating products to reduce sugar content. Companies like Coca Cola and Nestle are introducing lower-sugar products, and some countries have implemented "sin taxes" on sugary drinks. The industry's growth, which had been steady for decades, is expected to slow, with some estimates suggesting a 2% annual growth rate decline.

images.alt_text: It's not this year's price crash that haunts the US$150 billion sugar industry. It's the fear of worse to come.

site_title: Australia: 'Big Four' banks drag shares lower
summary: Shares in Australia's 'big four' banks fell on Tuesday due to a government tax proposal, dragging the benchmark index 0.19% lower. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,760.2 points. Commonwealth Bank of Australia and Westpac were among the worst performers, with Commonwealth Bank falling 0.41% and Westpac 1.03%. The banks claimed the new tax would result in A$1 billion in annual costs. Iron miner BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto also declined, with BHP slipping to its lowest in nearly three weeks.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks notch record high
summary: South Korean shares reached a record high on Tuesday, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) rising 0.9% to 2,323.71 points. The gains were driven by domestic institutions buying KOSPI shares and rebounding stocks like Netmarble Games. However, investors were cautious about the possibility of a US interest rate hike, as indicated by the Federal Reserve's last policy meeting. The won also weakened due to investor appetite for safe-haven assets following the Manchester terrorist attack.

site_title: S.Korea's Park abused power to gain bribes, prosecutor tells court
summary: South Korea's former leader Park Geun-hye is on trial for abusing her power to gain bribes from business leaders, including Samsung Group scion Jay Y Lee. Park faces over 10 years in jail if found guilty of taking bribes worth approximately $26.65 million. Park has denied wrongdoing and pleaded not guilty, while her lawyers argue that she had no personal gains from the bribes. The trial comes two weeks after Park's impeachment and follows her arrest in March, during which she was seen reading the English dictionary and avoiding news.

site_title: 24 Asia-Pac banks to boost tracking of cross-border payments
summary: 24 Asia-Pacific banks, including top Chinese banks and DBS, have signed up for Swift's cross-border tracking service, Swift gpi. The service allows real-time tracking of payments, same-day clearance, and upfront fees. Over 110 transaction banks globally have gone live with the service, with flows making up 75% of all cross-border payments through the Swift network. This move aims to meet security and compliance demands using technology.

site_title: China: Stocks fall again, worries about policy tightening linger
summary: China's Shanghai stocks fell 0.4% on Tuesday, marking a second consecutive day of losses, amid lingering concerns over policy tightening. The Shanghai Composite Index dropped to 3,061.95 points, while the tech-heavy ChiNext board closed down 1.7% due to a sharp correction in newly-listed stocks. Authorities are expected to continue implementing monetary policy adjustments to defuse financial risks, with some analysts warning of a possible peaking economy and reduced risk appetites for small-caps.

site_title: Wing Tai Holdings launches S$94m takeover bid for Malaysian-listed counterpart
summary: Wing Tai Holdings launched a S$94 million takeover bid for Malaysian-listed Wing Tai Malaysia Berhad, offering RM1.80 cash per share, a 53% premium over its last traded price. The offer is not subject to minimum acceptances, as the joint offerors already hold over 50% of WTM's voting shares.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei edges down as Manchester blast sours mood
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei stock average fell 0.3% to 19,613.28 on May 23, 2017, due to a suicide bomb attack in Britain, lifting the yen and impacting export-oriented shares. The Topix and JPX-Nikkei Index 400 also declined 0.2% each.

site_title: Manchester concert suicide attack prompts security rethinks worldwide
summary: A suicide bomb attack at an Ariana Grande concert in Manchester, Britain, killed at least 22 people and raised concerns about security worldwide. Countries such as the US, Japan, Singapore, and Hong Kong are considering tightening security measures ahead of major events. The US Department of Homeland Security has increased security monitoring, while Japan has established an information-gathering unit. Event organizers in Singapore and Hong Kong are also reviewing and enhancing security protocols. Australia's Melbourne Cricket Ground and the Philippine Mall of Asia Arena have also announced security reviews and precautions.

site_title: Flynn may have lied in security review, Democrat lawmaker says
summary: Former National Security Adviser Michael Flynn may have lied in his security clearance application by claiming US companies funded a 2015 speech at a Russian TV network gala, according to a Defence Department investigation. Documents obtained by the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee show that Flynn was actually paid by the Russian network, RT. Flynn's attorney has refused to comment on the allegations, and the general has invoked his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination to withhold documents from the Senate Intelligence Committee.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars gain on pound after blast in UK, May's poll setback
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars rose against the British pound after a suspected terrorist attack in Manchester, killing at least 19 people and injuring over 50. The attack raised security concerns ahead of a UK election just 2.5 weeks away, putting pressure on Prime Minister Theresa May. If confirmed as a terrorist act, it would be the deadliest militant assault on Britain since 2005. The attack also came as opinion polls showed May's lead had been halved, further eroding her chances of winning the election easily.

site_title: Australia: Stocks steady despite weaker banks, miners
summary: Australia's shares held steady on Tuesday, with healthcare and consumer stocks supporting gains, while financials and iron miners fell. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 4.105 points to 5,767.1, driven by losses in banks and iron miners. Gold stocks rose on higher bullion prices following a terrorist attack in Britain, with Evolution Mining and St Barbara rising over 3% each.

site_title: Britain suspends election campaign after suspected Manchester attack
summary: Britain suspends election campaigning after a terrorist attack in Manchester that killed 19 people at a concert by US singer Ariana Grande. The incident has been treated as a terrorist attack, and Prime Minister Theresa May has agreed with opposition leader Jeremy Corbyn to suspend all national campaigning for the June 8 election. The Labour Party leader expressed his condolences to the families and friends of those affected.

site_title: Anglo said to get bid for New Largo coal from Seriti
summary: Anglo American Plc has received bids for its New Largo coal project in South Africa, with Seriti Resources Holdings Ltd and Phembani Group among the interested parties. The bid range is approximately 1 billion rand, and potential buyers will need to invest significantly to develop the mine. The sale of New Largo would aid Anglo's exit from South African coal operations, which the company has been scaling back since 2016. The sale process is expected to take another three to four months.

site_title: Update: Attacker died at Ariana Grande concert blast
summary: A suicide attack at an Ariana Grande concert in Manchester, England, on Monday killed 22 people, including children, and injured many more. The attacker, identified as a single male, died at the scene and was believed to have carried an improvised explosive device. British police are investigating whether the attack was a solo incident or part of a larger network. The motive behind the attack remains unknown.

site_title: Singapore headline inflation eases to 0.4% in April due to timing of S&CC rebates
summary: Singapore's headline inflation eased to 0.4% in April, below expectations, due to the timing of S&CC rebates. Core inflation, excluding accommodation and private road transport costs, rose to 1.7% year-over-year. This marks a slight increase from the previous month. The 13 private sector economists polled by Bloomberg had expected overall inflation to be 0.5%.

site_title: Ariana Grande "broken" in tweet after Manchester attack
summary: Pop star Ariana Grande expressed her emotional state as "broken" on Twitter five hours after a bombing at her concert in Manchester, England, killing 19 people and injuring dozens. Grande said she was "physically okay" but struggled to find words to express her condolences. Initial investigation suggests a suicide bomber was responsible for the attack, which British authorities are treating as a terrorist incident. Grande's representatives have confirmed she was not physically harmed.

site_title: Oil producers to extend output curbs at Opec meeting
summary: Oil producers at an Opec meeting are expected to extend their output curbs, aiming to boost the oil price, despite US shale producers increasing production at near-record levels. The deal, initially agreed in November 2016, aims to reduce a global supply glut and lift the oil price. However, analysts predict the agreement may not be successful in achieving its goal, citing US shale producers' ability to pump at high levels and reducing Opec's market share.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks edge up with heavyweights leading gains
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 0.1% on Tuesday, led by TSMC, as investors weighed concerns over a Manchester explosion and potential terrorist attack. The electronics subindex rose 0.2%, while the financials subindex dropped 0.1%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to NT$30.027 per US dollar. Gains were capped by global market uncertainty, with the US and EU trade talks in focus.

site_title: China scrambles to tame rental bike chaos
summary: China is struggling to manage the growing rental bike industry, with packs of cyclists causing chaos on the streets. The authorities are considering new regulations to curb the problem, including capping the number of bikes and barring individuals deemed too big or too small for bicycles. Unlike other cities, China's bike-sharing system has no docking stations, allowing bikes to be left anywhere. The government aims to address the issue before it becomes a major problem, but the current system is proving difficult to manage.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.15% in early trading on May 23, 2017, following Wall Street's gains. The Hang Seng Index increased 37.53 points to 25,428.87, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.20% and the Shenzhen Composite Index slid 0.26%. Energy firms suffered from profit-taking after the previous day's gains.

site_title: Manchester terror attack: What we know
summary: Nineteen people died in a suspected terror attack at a pop concert in Manchester, England, late Monday, May 22, 2017. The blast occurred at Manchester Arena, where pop star Ariana Grande was performing, and is being treated as a terrorist incident. Police say 50 people were injured, and the investigation is ongoing. The attack is the deadliest in Britain since 2005, and British Prime Minister Theresa May condemned it as "an appalling terrorist attack."

images.alt_text: Nineteen people died in a suspected terror attack at a pop concert in the British city of Manchester late Monday.

site_title: Hot stock: Wing Tai trading halt fuels speculation on privatisation of Malaysia counterpart
summary: Wing Tai Holdings halted trading in its shares on Tuesday, sparking speculation about the potential privatization of its Malaysian counterpart, Wing Tai Malaysia Berhad. Analysts at UOB Kay Hian believe a corporate action could occur, citing chairman and managing director Cheng Wai Keung's 66.2% deemed interest in Wing Tai Malaysia. A consolidation of the two companies could prompt an upward re-rating of Wing Tai Holdings, according to UOB Kay Hian analysts.

site_title: Asia: Markets take breather after oil-fuelled rally
summary: Asian markets took a breather on Tuesday after a rally driven by oil prices, with profit-taking offsetting gains. The pound briefly fell after a blast in Manchester was deemed potentially terror-related. Despite US President Donald Trump's overseas trip calming the markets, investors remain cautious ahead of a meeting between Opec and Russia on oil output cuts. The Federal Reserve's policy meeting minutes and Trump's budget release are also expected to impact markets.

site_title: China's troubled LeEco said to plan cutting most of US workers
summary: LeEco, a Chinese technology conglomerate, plans to lay off over 300 US employees, reducing its US workforce to around 50 people. This move significantly scales back the company's ambitions in North America, where it initially showcased a range of products. LeEco has been struggling with financial difficulties, including missed revenue targets and unpaid bills, and has already scrapped a proposed $2 billion acquisition of Vizio Inc. The company's parent company is considering an internal overhaul to address its financial issues.

site_title: 5G airwave fees to be waived in Singapore till Dec 2019 to spur industry trials
summary: Singapore to waive 5G airwave fees until December 2019 to encourage industry trials. The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) aims to improve regulations and airwave allocation to support the development of 5G services, which are expected to be 10 times faster than 4G. This move is intended to foster innovation and bring Singapore closer to the next frontier in ultra-fast mobile surfing and IoT connectivity.

site_title: South Korea tourist numbers hammered by China boycott
summary: Chinese tourists to South Korea plummeted 66.6% in April, with 227,811 visitors, down from 682,318 the previous year, following Beijing's ban on tour groups over Seoul's deployment of the US THAAD system. This led to a 27.2% decline in total visitor numbers to 1.07 million. The ban has heavily impacted duty-free shops, with sales to Chinese visitors down 40% at Lotte Duty Free, resulting in estimated losses of $1 billion for the conglomerate. South Korea is struggling to fill the gap with promotional campaigns.

site_title: Aussie housing risk no deterrent as mortgage bond sales boom
summary: Australian investors are buying mortgage bonds despite regulators' warnings about the nation's housing market risks. Mortgage-backed securities issuance has more than doubled to A$10.5 billion this year, driven by non-bank lenders. Private debt in Australia has reached an average 189% of household income, sparking concerns about a potential downturn in house prices. Regulators are extending powers to control non-bank lending, while credit assessors warn of a "sharp correction" in property prices and "significant rise in credit losses."

site_title: Seoul: Stocks at 2-week high, won flat; Fed minutes awaited
summary: South Korean stocks rose to a two-week high on Tuesday, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) increasing 0.7% to 2,319.95 points. The won remained flat at 1,117.6 against the US dollar. Offshore investors turned to net buyers of local equities, purchasing 13.5 billion won worth of Kospi shares. The Federal Reserve's May policy meeting minutes are expected to be released on Wednesday, potentially influencing the possibility of a June rate hike.

site_title: Short-seller invasion of Hong Kong spurs an unusual defense plan
summary: A Hong Kong property company, Fullshare Holdings Ltd, has proposed an "anti-malicious short selling alliance" to defend against activist short sellers. The plan, unveiled on Monday, involves companies sharing crisis-management advice and, in some cases, offering equity investments to targeted firms. However, short sellers, including Muddy Waters and Glaucus Research, have dismissed the idea, saying it would harm shareholders. The proposal highlights the growing presence of short sellers in Hong Kong, which has weak regulatory practices, particularly in accounting areas.

site_title: Trump administration wants Obamacare subsidy case put on hold, again
summary: The Trump administration asked a federal court to put on hold a major case about the fate of Obamacare cost-sharing subsidies for 90 days, leaving billions of dollars in payments to insurers uncertain. The subsidies support low-income Americans buying individual health insurance. Insurers are concerned that the payments could end, causing premium rates to rise. The administration and Republican lawmakers want more time to discuss alternative funding measures, while some lawmakers and insurers advocate for Congress to appropriate the funds.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open slightly higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.130 points to 1775.580 on Tuesday, with 162 gainers outweighing 79 losers. The shares opened slightly higher, with a trading volume of 73.33 million lots worth RM25.80 million.

site_title: KCG said to eliminate 10% of staff, shut two offices in Asia
summary: KCG Holdings Inc, a trading firm set to be acquired by Virtu Financial Inc for over $1.3 billion, is eliminating 10% of its staff and shutting offices in Singapore and Mumbai. The company will also stop trading currencies and withdraw from European exchange-traded funds. Around 100 jobs will be cut by the end of the week. This move follows the company's struggles with diminished market volatility, with headcount decreasing from 1,229 in 2013 to 923 in March.

site_title: Singapore Exchange said to be near deal with regulator for IPOs
summary: Singapore Exchange Ltd is nearing a deal with the city's technology regulator to develop a system to encourage local startups to list on the bourse. The agreement, with the Infocomm Media Development Authority, aims to pair technology companies with investors to secure listings. This move deepens SGX's sector approach, focusing on four industries, including technology. The deal allows SGX to engage with tech firms earlier, facilitating capital access for startups. The agreement comes as companies with Singapore roots consider listing in Hong Kong or the US.

site_title: Fatalities confirmed at Ariana Grande concert in Manchester
summary: A blast occurred at an Ariana Grande concert in Manchester, England, leaving an unknown number of people dead and injured. The explosion happened near the exit, causing widespread panic. site_title: "Pls help me...": Frantic parents hunt for missing kids after UK concert blast
summary: At least 19 people were killed in a blast at a British concert by Ariana Grande in Manchester, UK. Desperate parents and friends used social media to search for missing teenagers, sharing images and pleas for help. Many hotels opened their doors as shelters for displaced children, with taxi drivers offering free rides and strangers offering free accommodations. The incident occurred in the foyer of the Manchester Arena, where thousands of young fans and parents had streamed out after the concert.

site_title: Singapore shares open 7 points higher on Tuesday
summary: The Singapore stock market opened 7.06 points higher at 3,220.63 on Tuesday, following Wall Street's gains overnight. The Straits Times Index was up 0.4% on Thursday, despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Cathay Pacific to cut another 200 jobs, taking total to 800: SCMP
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd plans to cut an additional 200 jobs on top of 600 already announced, bringing the total to 800, as part of its three-year reorganisation plan to return to profitability. site_title: Lululemon in talks to fill Sephora's Fifth Avenue vacancy
summary: Lululemon Athletica Inc is in advanced talks to lease a 8,000 sq ft space on Manhattan's Fifth Avenue, filling a vacancy left by Sephora's move to another location. summary: South Korean rapper Psy has released his eighth full-length album, "4x2=8", marking a return to his roots after the massive success of his 2012 hit "Gangnam Style". Psy, 39, has moved on from the fame of "Gangnam Style", which holds the world record for most viewed YouTube video, and is now focusing on his live performances and production. He aims to stay on stage as long as possible, but wants to retire before being deemed washed up, and is now prioritizing his personal life and helping younger artists grow.

summary: Japan's Sawai Pharmaceutical Co, the country's second-largest generic drug maker, is set to complete its $1 billion purchase of US-based Upsher-Smith Laboratories Inc, its first overseas acquisition. The deal forecasts 13% annual sales growth in the US market through 2021, boosting revenue for the Japanese firm, which has seen a sevenfold increase in revenue over the last 15 years. Sawai plans to leverage Japan's reputation for high-quality therapies and Upsher-Smith's local expertise to navigate the US market, amid rising competition from Indian and Chinese low-cost copycat medicines.

site_title: Oil rises to month-high with output cut extension expected
summary: Oil prices rose to a month-high on Monday, with Brent futures reaching $53.87 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude settling at $50.73 a barrel. site_title: Four frontier technology areas identified for development in Singapore
summary: Singapore has identified four frontier technology areas for development: artificial intelligence and data science, cybersecurity, immersive media, and Internet of Things (IoT), along with future communications infrastructure. summary: Geo Energy Resources is seeking noteholders' consent for waivers on its S$100 million notes due Jan 2018, citing a planned refinancing of debt papers. The market's reaction was neutral, with no significant changes in stock prices.

site_title: Growing unease over Trump's son-in-law's holdings
summary: Jared Kushner, President Donald Trump's son-in-law and senior adviser, has retained nearly 90% of his vast real estate holdings, worth between $132 million and $407 million, despite pledging to keep his private interests separate from public duties. Kushner sold only one of two luxury apartment projects in Jersey City, One Journal Square, while keeping his stake in the other, 30 Journal Square. Critics argue that his holdings could create conflicts of interest, and Kushner's team has declined to provide detailed information on his investments, citing a need for simplicity and transparency.

site_title: Ford Motor replaces CEO amid declining profits
summary: Ford Motor Co has replaced its CEO, Mark Fields, amid declining profits. Jim Hackett, who oversees autonomous vehicles, will take over from Fields. The move comes after Fields' three-year tenure saw Ford's shares drop 40% and the company faced criticism for failing to expand its core car business and develop high-tech cars. Hackett will focus on developing the company's "smart mobility" operation, including driverless technology, with a goal of having a fully autonomous vehicle on the road by 2021.

site_title: Euro zone ministers eye Greek debt deal with IMF, new loans decision in June
summary: Euro zone finance ministers failed to agree on debt relief for Greece with the International Monetary Fund, leaving no new loans to Athens. Greece needs new cash to avoid a default in July, but must implement 140 "prior actions" to make reforms stick. The IMF wants clarity on debt relief, but the euro zone is hesitant, citing a lack of detail in a 2016 declaration. The ministers agreed on a primary surplus path for Greece, but a deal on debt relief remains elusive, with the IMF pushing for more detail and the euro zone wanting to keep its options open.

site_title: Jury selection underway for Cosby sex assault trial
summary: A US judge has begun jury selection for Bill Cosby's sexual assault trial in Pittsburgh, where the 79-year-old actor faces up to 10 years in prison if found guilty. Over 50 women have accused Cosby of drugging and assaulting them over four decades, with the allegations centered around a 2004 incident at his Philadelphia home. Cosby has denied the allegations, stating that his relations with the alleged victim, Andrea Constand, were consensual. The trial is expected to last two weeks, with jurors facing a significant challenge in remaining impartial due to widespread preconceived notions about Cosby's guilt or innocence.

site_title: Trump budget plan slashes food stamps, healthcare for poor
summary: The White House is set to unveil President Donald Trump's first full budget, proposing cuts of over $800 billion in Medicaid and $192 billion in food stamps for the poor. The plan aims to balance the budget by the end of the decade by trimming $3.6 trillion in government spending. Lawmakers are expected to reject some of the proposed cuts, which are considered politically sensitive. The budget plan's impact on the poor and vulnerable is expected to be significant.

images.alt_text: The White House is set to deliver President Donald Trump's first full budget to lawmakers on Tuesday, a plan that would slash funding for healthcare and food assistance programs for the poor while it trims the deficit.

site_title: Malaysian navy boat, all nine crew found safe
summary: Nine Malaysian navy crew members missing for almost four days have been found safe after being spotted by an airforce plane. They were part of a small boat that vanished during an anti-poaching mission off the southern state of Johor near Singapore. The crew was found in the company of two local fishing boats, approximately 87 nautical miles east of Gelang Cape. Malaysia deployed 11 ships and two helicopters to search for the naval craft, and the incident has been resolved.

site_title: Pound falls versus yen after Manchester blast
summary: The British pound fell 0.45% to 144.07 yen after a blast in Manchester killed at least 19 people, marking a terrorist incident. The hotel is part of the Swiss group Kempinski Hotels and marks a significant development in Cuba's tourism industry.

site_title: Trump asked 2 intel chiefs to deny Russia collusion: report
summary: US President Donald Trump asked two top intelligence officials, National Security Agency chief Michael Rogers and Director of National Intelligence Dan Coats, to publicly deny any evidence of collusion between his campaign and Russia during the 2016 presidential election. The request was made after then FBI director James Comey revealed the agency's investigation into Russian interference. Both officials declined to comply, and Trump had previously asked several congressmen and intelligence officials to contact journalists to deny the allegations. The White House denied any pressure on Comey, but Comey's memos revealed detailed discussions with Trump on the matter.

site_title: China's Hainan Airlines to buy 19 Boeing jets for US$4.2b

The acquisition aims to support China's increasing travel demand and provide the airline with a fleet expansion.

site_title: Insurers have to tackle the uncertainties of autonomous vehicles
summary: Singapore is joining the global movement towards autonomous vehicles, with trials taking place and companies like Tesla investing in the technology. However, questions remain around liability and insurance in the event of accidents, with the industry grappling with how to define responsibility in a non-autonomous vehicle. The insurance industry will need to adapt to new risks, including technology failures and external interference, as the concept of autonomous vehicles becomes more prevalent, and society will look to insurers to provide certainty to policyholders.

site_title: Minister flags cost of living as concern ahead of Malaysian polls
summary: Malaysian Trade Minister Mustapa Mohamed stated that the cost of living is a major concern among voters ahead of the expected 2017 elections. The ruling coalition, led by Prime Minister Najib Razak, aims to extend its 60-year rule, while the opposition seeks to capitalize on discontent over living costs, including inflation and the implementation of a 6% consumption tax. Despite the opposition's divisions, the ruling coalition remains optimistic about its chances, with Mr. Mustapa noting that the opposition is "not as united as we are."

site_title: Branstad, friend of Beijing, confirmed as US envoy to China
summary: The US Senate confirmed Iowa Governor Terry Branstad as the next ambassador to Beijing, a position that could help smooth relations between the US and China. Branstad, a friend of Beijing, has a decades-long connection to China, which the White House hopes will aid in economic pressure on North Korea. The confirmation comes as the White House faces scandal and amid rising tensions in the South China Sea. Branstad will be thrust into a critical role in global diplomacy, navigating complex relationships with China and other global powers.

site_title: Asset impairments drive Vallianz into US$173m loss
summary: Vallianz Holdings reported a net loss of US$173.2 million for the three months ended March, driven by substantial impairments on its assets due to a slowdown in the offshore oil and gas space. Revenue dropped 21.5% to US$38.7 million, mainly due to completed vessel management projects in 2016. Despite new contracts, lower vessel utilisation amid a challenging environment contributed to the loss. The group's vessel chartering and brokerage business remains operationally profitable, with a US$1.03 billion order book valued in long-term charters.

site_title: Weaker sterling gives FTSE edge over Europe, mid-caps take the lead
summary: The FTSE 100 index rose 0.4% on Monday, outperforming the Euro zone Stoxx 600, as the weaker sterling propelled UK stocks higher. site_title: North Korea says missile ready for mass production, US questions progress
summary: North Korea successfully tested an intermediate-range ballistic missile, dubbed the Pukguksong-2, which met technical requirements and can now be mass-produced, according to the country. The test was seen as a demonstration of North Korea's aim to develop an intercontinental ballistic missile capable of reaching the US mainland, with estimates suggesting it could take until 2020 for North Korea to achieve this capability. The UN Security Council is set to meet behind closed doors to discuss the test, which defies resolutions and sanctions.

site_title: Good-looking scientists perceived as 'less able': study
summary: A study published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences found that people perceive attractive scientists as less capable than their average-appearing counterparts, with biases affecting public perception of scientific ideas. Researchers from the University of Cambridge and University of Essex conducted six studies involving over 3,700 participants, who rated scientists' faces for attractiveness and interest in their research. The results showed that attractive scientists were more interesting to learn about, while older and female scientists were less attractive. The study highlights the potential for biases in science, particularly in an era of increasing online engagement.

site_title: Ousted South Korean leader Park faces trial
summary: South Korean ousted president Park Geun-Hye is set to face trial for corruption, with 18 charges including bribery, coercion, and abuse of power. Park, 65, was impeached and detained after revelations of her involvement with friend Choi Soon-Sil and top businessmen, including Samsung's Lee Jae-Yong. Her trial, expected to last months, will shed light on ties between Park and conglomerate bosses who allegedly bribed her. Park denies wrongdoing, blaming Choi for abusing their friendship, and will be joined by Choi and other accused individuals in the courtroom.

site_title: When investors sell businesses on the cheap
summary: Investors selling businesses for "free" by selling shares for only the net cash on the company's balance sheet are essentially giving up potential profits. This occurs when they sell at net cash, disregarding the value of hard and soft assets that could generate future profits. By doing so, investors are essentially ascribing a value of zero to these assets.

site_title: Commodity traders need new model as transparent market cuts margins
summary: Commodity traders are adapting to a more transparent market by diversifying their strategies. As market participants gain access to information, traditional arbitrage-based profits are shrinking. To stay competitive, traders are exploring new opportunities in the supply chain, such as investing in infrastructure and financing asset development. Companies like Mercuria Energy Group and Vitol Group are pooling resources to execute complex deals and invest in assets like pipelines and refineries. This shift is driven by the need to differentiate themselves and secure profits in a market where information is increasingly accessible.

site_title: Symantec says 'highly likely' North Korean hacking group behind ransomware attacks
summary: Cyber security firm Symantec has stated that a hacking group affiliated with North Korea is "highly likely" responsible for the WannaCry cyber attack, which infected over 300,000 computers worldwide and disrupted operations at hospitals, banks, and schools. The attack used hacking tools and infrastructure linked to the Lazarus group, previously associated with North Korea by the US government and cyber security researchers.

site_title: 'Smart genes' account for 20% of intelligence: study
summary: Scientists discovered 52 genes linked to human intelligence, with 40 identified for the first time. These "smart genes" accounted for 20% of IQ test discrepancies among tens of thousands of people. The findings also revealed a surprising connection between intelligence and autism, potentially shedding light on the condition's origins. The research, published in Nature Genetics, suggests a genetic basis for intelligence, challenging the long-held notion that intelligence is solely the result of environmental factors.

site_title: US: Wall Street ends up; defence, tech stocks a boost

site_title: US dollar weak as political risks linger; euro up on Merkel comments
summary: The US dollar fell to a six-month low against a basket of currencies, weakening 0.14% to 97.005, amid uncertain US politics and a buoyant euro. site_title: Japan seeks to help S-E Asia fight growing piracy threat

The initiative is part of Japan's efforts to support maritime security in the region.

site_title: Barclays makes fresh foray into private banking: source
summary: Barclays is expanding its private banking division by hiring 100 new staff, marking the bank's second attempt in seven years to win more business from wealthy clients. The bank will now focus on increasing profits by improving products and cooperation with its investment bank, rather than assets.

site_title: GP Batteries narrows Q4 losses to S$4.02m

site_title: Three Aussie lenders launch fresh attack on new levy on big banks
summary: Three major Australian banks, Commonwealth Bank of Australia, Westpac Banking Corp, and National Australia Bank Ltd, have opposed a new levy on big banks, estimating nearly A$750 million in additional annual costs. The 0.06% levy on deposits will be imposed from July 1, affecting the banks' customers and shareholders. The banks argue the tax is poorly designed and could impact their profitability, with Westpac calling it "inefficient" and NAB saying it cannot be absorbed.

site_title: India's small-town investors piling in as stocks soar
summary: India's small-town investors are flocking to mutual funds as the nation's stock market soars. Flows into mutual funds from outside India's 15 biggest cities surged 41% to a record 3.1 trillion rupees at the end of March, with half of this money invested in equity funds. The trend is attributed to low returns on bank deposits and stagnant gold prices, with stock funds returning an average of 16% annually over the past three years. Industry-wide accounts reached a record 55 million as of March 31, with 80% in stock plans.
