site_title: US-China trade deal to benefit US gas sales
summary: US and Chinese energy firms have signed a trade deal that paves the way for increased US liquefied natural gas (LNG) exports to China. The agreement, announced by the Trump administration and Chinese President Xi Jinping's government, welcomes Chinese investments and purchases of American gas. US LNG exports are expected to play a larger role in US-China trade relations as China seeks to boost the share of natural gas in its energy mix and lower prices. Chinese companies, including Sinopec and China National Petroleum Corp, are considering long-term contracts with US suppliers, potentially easing concerns about access to US gas cargoes.

site_title: Tillerson downplays peace expectations as Trump lands in Israel
summary: US President Donald Trump arrived in Israel on Monday, marking a significant visit to the region, amid hopes of revitalizing a stalled peace process. Despite Secretary of State Rex Tillerson downplaying expectations of major progress, Trump expressed renewed hope for a peaceful resolution. The visit includes meetings with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas, and a symbolic tour of holy sites in Jerusalem. Meanwhile, hundreds of Palestinian protesters held a "Day of Rage" in support of hunger striking prisoners, and the Israeli government has announced economic measures aimed at bolstering the Palestinian economy.

site_title: Europe set to challenge Tesla with own battery-making gigafactories
summary: Europe is set to challenge Tesla's lead in battery-making with the construction of gigafactories in Germany, Sweden, Hungary, and Poland. German Chancellor Angela Merkel is scheduled to break ground on a 500 million-euro plant to assemble lithium-ion energy-storage units for Daimler AG. The facility is expected to cut the cost of lithium-ion packs by 43% and make electric cars a mainstream reality. Europe's battery-making capacity is set to more than double by 2021, reaching 278 gigawatt-hours, and is expected to almost double its market share from 2.5% to 5%.

site_title: Geo Energy plans refinancing and early notes redemption
summary: Geo Energy Resources Ltd, an Indonesian coal producer, plans to refinance and early redeem its S$100 million notes due in January 2018. The move aims to lower interest costs and return capital to noteholders early, showcasing the company's strengthened financial position. Noteholders can redeem the principal early and in full, with interest accrued, by submitting a valid voting instruction by June 5. The company is also making progress in completing its acquisition of PT Tanah Bumbu Resources, which will expand its coal reserves to over 90 million tonnes.

site_title: New chief for Navy and permanent secretaries for several ministries
summary: Singapore's Navy chief, Lai Chung Han, is leaving his post on June 16 and will be replaced by Rear-Admiral Lew Chuen Hong. Lai will then become the second permanent secretary at the Ministry of Education, while Lew will take on the role of chief of Navy. Other government appointments include Png Cheong Boon as second permanent secretary at the Ministry of Trade and Industry and Neo Kian Hong as permanent secretary (defence development) designate at the Ministry of Defence, with concurrent roles at the Ministry of Education.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Samsung Elec to continue looking for M&A opportunities
summary: Samsung Electronics Co Ltd plans to continue seeking acquisition opportunities to build software and services, differentiating its products. Senior vice-president Peter Koo stated the company will be "bullish" on finding suitable targets. No specific companies or technologies were mentioned, but Samsung aims to enhance its offerings in the mobile division. This move is part of the company's strategy to stay competitive in the rapidly evolving technology landscape.

site_title: S'pore's business community ready for Belt and Road projects
summary: Singapore's business community is poised to capitalize on China's Belt and Road Initiative (BRI), a US$100 billion project aimed at strengthening global trade. As a connector between East and West, Singapore's strategic location makes it an ideal hub for the MSR. The country's expertise in financing, insurance, and logistics positions it as a key player in the BRI, with over 200 banks and a strong track record of project financing. Singapore businesses can leverage their expertise to fund BRI projects, while Chinese companies can partner with Singaporean companies to access global markets.

site_title: Sinochem no longer pursuing stake in troubled Noble Group: sources
summary: China's state-owned Sinochem is no longer pursuing a stake in Noble Group Ltd due to concerns over the company's finances and business outlook. The decision comes after Noble posted a shock quarterly loss, sparking a share price rout and cuts in outlooks by rating agencies. Sinochem's move is a setback to the commodity trader, which is set to negotiate a $2 billion credit facility. The decision also reflects Sinochem's heightened focus on domestic priorities and increased scrutiny of overseas investments by Chinese state-owned enterprises.

site_title: OCBC taps Indonesian wealth with new onshore private banking services
summary: OCBC launched its onshore private banking services in Indonesia through its subsidiary OCBC NISP, targeting high net worth individuals with assets over $1 million. The move follows a tax amnesty program that repatriated $8.8 billion from Singapore to Indonesia this year. OCBC NISP has hired industry veteran and plans to double its team size by the end of the year. The launch aims to broaden OCBC's client coverage of high net worth individuals, with Indonesia contributing 5% to the bank's group earnings in 2016, up from 2% in 2010.

images.alt_text: OCBC looks to entrench itself deeper in the wealth management business in this region by tapping into the burgeoning wealth in Indonesia that is held onshore.

site_title: Can a modern data centre help SMEs in a digital economy?
summary: Singapore's SMEs drive the country's economy, with a recent survey showing that leveraging ICT infrastructure can reduce operating and manpower costs. However, SMEs require scalable and reliable IT infrastructure to host critical business data, particularly in regulated industries. Modern data centres can offer high availability, redundancy, and 24/7 monitoring, making them an attractive option for SMEs. Data centres can also provide cross-border network connectivity, enabling SMEs to launch internationalisation plans and reduce costs. By outsourcing to a data centre, SMEs can streamline processes, decrease IT manpower costs, and achieve operational and cost efficiency.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: TTJ Holdings secured new contracts, increasing its order book to S$166 million. Tung Lok Restaurants posted a 30.9% dip in net profit due to decreased revenue from restaurant sales and closed outlets, but offset by revenue from new outlets and catering sales. No dividend was declared.

site_title: Cathay Pacific to axe 600 jobs amid yield, cost pressures on airlines
summary: Cathay Pacific is cutting 600 jobs, its largest cost-cutting exercise in two decades, amid yield and cost pressures. The airline, which posted its first annual loss in eight years, is restructuring its cargo unit and pushing for productivity improvements. CEO Rupert Hogg said the airline will become "leaner, faster and more responsive to customers' needs." The move is part of a three-year transformation program aimed at saving HK$4 billion. Other airlines, such as Singapore Airlines and Emirates, are also facing headwinds due to competition from Chinese carriers and declining business travel.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

A Cathay Pacific flight attendant on one of the airline's new Airbus A350s delivered last year. The airline said no frontline employees, pilots or cabin crew will be affected by this round of job cuts.

site_title: Huntsman and Clariant merging to create US$14b chemicals giant
summary: US-based Huntsman Corp and Swiss Clariant AG are merging to form a US$14 billion chemicals giant. The combined company, HuntsmanClariant, will be 52% owned by Clariant shareholders and valued at around US$20 billion when including debt. The deal comes after years of tentative approaches and will be headquartered in Switzerland with its operational center in Woodlands, Texas. Peter Huntsman will become CEO, while Hariolf Kottmann will be chairman, marking the first time the two have worked together after eight years.

site_title: Singapore banks may miss the O&M boat when sector recovers
summary: Singapore's big three banks are struggling to recover from the debt restructuring of the offshore and marine (O&M) sector, which has left them with significant losses. The banks have foreclosed vessels and taken haircuts, but are now hesitant to participate in the sector's restructuring. Meanwhile, other players, including fund houses and private equity firms, are snapping up assets on the cheap, potentially missing out on a rebound in the O&M market. Experts warn that Singapore's banks may have "missed the boat" if they fail to participate in the sector's recovery.

site_title: Peach first Japan airline to accept bitcoin for payment
summary: Peach Aviation Ltd, a Japanese discount airline, has become the first carrier to accept bitcoin for payment of airline tickets. Starting by the end of the year, bitcoin will be accepted for booking seats, aiming to attract more tourists from Asia. The move is facilitated by a change in Japan's law on fund settlements in April. Peach's CEO, Shinichi Inoue, sees this as a step towards partnerships with local governments and regional companies to promote the use of bitcoin. The airline's move follows airBaltic's adoption of bitcoin payment in 2014.

site_title: Marco Polo places Indonesian shipyard unit under court-led debt revamp
summary: Marco Polo Marine's Indonesian subsidiary PT Marcopolo Shipyard has filed an application to place itself under a court-supervised debt restructuring plan. The shipyard unit, facing debt issues, will be temporarily restrained from legal proceedings for 45 days. This move aims to revamp the debt payment plan and ensure the shipyard's financial stability.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: No time for Brexit delays, says UK's May as poll lead slips
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May urged voters to back her to deliver Brexit, despite a shrinking lead in opinion polls. Her Conservative Party's lead over Labour has fallen to 9-13 percentage points, down from 20 points before the snap election. May plans to begin divorce talks with the EU 11 days after the election, potentially on June 19. May's message emphasizes her ability to secure a good Brexit deal, while Labour's Jeremy Corbyn has been criticized for not opposing her EU exit strategy strongly enough.

site_title: LHN secures first overseas carpark management contract
summary: LHN Limited, a Singapore-based real estate management services group, secured its first overseas carpark management contract in Hong Kong, expanding into the Greater China region. The three-year contract was awarded to a newly incorporated subsidiary, LHN Parking HK Limited, bringing the total number of carpark properties under LHN's management to 42, including 41 in Singapore. This contract follows a proposed dual listing in Hong Kong, marking LHN's entry into the region.

site_title: Filling the gap in world-wide education
summary: Singapore-based social enterprise The Global Citizen has bridged the gap in co-curricular education by offering debate coaching and leadership camps. Founded by Walter Yeo and Jared Yeo in 2015, the firm has partnered with over a dozen schools in Singapore and expanded its regional footprint to Asia. With more than 10 coaches and a team of over 60 employees, TGC aims to develop global skills in students, promoting empathy and public speaking. The firm's revenue has grown 36 times since its inception, and it plans to become a hub for niche academic co-curricular activities in South-east Asia within the next five years.

images.alt_text: Prisca Ang

site_title: China slaps import duties on sugar; experts question impact
summary: China has imposed hefty import duties on sugar, targeting about a third of its annual imports. The tariffs, which will increase to 95% over three years, are seen as insufficient to stem the flow of cheaper sugar imports. Experts predict smuggling and exports through third-party countries may occur, and global sugar prices may need to drop below 15 cents to make imports unprofitable. The move follows lobbying by domestic sugar mills, but analysts say it may not significantly impact the global market.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

Asian stocks close mixed on Monday, with Best World International, SATS, and DBS Group Research being analyzed by brokers. Best World's efforts to raise brand awareness in the Chinese market are bearing fruit, but investors question the direct selling licence and sustainability. SATS reported a 36% year-on-year spike in associates/joint venture profits, but the company's valuation is considered unattractive. DBS Group Research maintained a "hold" target price for the company, while UOB Kay Hian raised its target price for Global Logistic Properties. The market is awaiting Singapore's GDP data, which may impact investor sentiment.

site_title: Greece's creditors seek to break impasse on stalled review
summary: Greece's creditors are considering three scenarios to ease the country's debt burden, which could lead to substantially different levels of relief. The scenarios, outlined in a German finance ministry letter, make different assumptions about Greece's growth outlook and primary surplus. The first scenario would see little or no debt relief, while the second would require a generous restructuring. A deal is expected as euro-area finance ministers gather in Brussels, with European officials seeing a 50-50 chance of an agreement.

site_title: Meets with G-7, Nato will move Trump into world diplomatic spotlight
summary: US President Donald Trump's European tour, starting with Brussels meetings on Wednesday, will mark his first time at the top table of global diplomacy. He will then attend the NATO summit, pushing for the alliance to assume a stronger role in combating the Islamic State, and the G-7 summit, where he will face pressure to maintain US support for the Paris climate change treaty. Expectations are low for the G-7, given Italy's limited engagement with the US and Trump's decision to drop the climate change issue from the agenda.

site_title: Facebook's rules on types of content it allows leaked: Guardian
summary: Facebook's leaked internal guidelines reveal how the social media company moderates issues like hate speech, terrorism, and self-harm, with moderators often facing only 10 seconds to make a decision. The leaked documents show inconsistencies in policies, particularly on sexual content. Facebook confirmed using software to intercept graphic content and prioritizes safety while enabling free speech. Moderators were instructed to escalate content related to 13 Reasons Why due to concerns of copycat behavior.

site_title: Boeing signs commercial, defence deals with Saudi Arabia
summary: Boeing signed defence and commercial deals with Saudi Arabia, including the sale of Chinook helicopters, P-8 surveillance aircraft, and Boeing 777/787 airplanes to Saudi Gulf Airlines. The deals, worth tens of billions of dollars, were announced during US President Donald Trump's visit to the kingdom, as Saudi Arabia seeks closer ties with the US to develop its economy beyond oil. The agreements are expected to create thousands of jobs in both countries and provide sustainment services for military platforms. Details of the deals' total value were not disclosed.

site_title: Trump says he has new reasons to hope for Middle East peace
summary: US President Donald Trump said he has new reasons to hope for Middle East peace during his visit to Israel, following talks with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas. Trump expressed optimism about achieving security, stability, and peace in the region, but noted that progress will require cooperation. His visit comes as the US struggles to contain a scandal at home, and amid tensions with Iran, which Trump has called a threat to Israel's existence.

site_title: US is dangerously dependent on Internet-based systems
summary: The US is dangerously dependent on internet-based systems, leaving it vulnerable to cyber threats. Despite a relatively quick response to the recent global ransomware virus, experts warn that the internet can be used against the US or by malicious actors. The increasing reliance on the internet, including the Internet of Things (IoT), creates more avenues for cyberattacks, threatening social fabric and critical infrastructure. The US must acknowledge its addiction to the internet and take steps to protect itself, but current approaches to cybersecurity are inadequate, and a more comprehensive strategy is needed to address the growing threat.

site_title: China pushes public to accept GMO as Syngenta takeover nears
summary: China will conduct a nationwide poll next month to gauge public acceptance of genetically-modified (GMO) food, as the government pushes for its adoption. The poll, sponsored by the government, will also include a public education drive on GMO technology on social media. The move aims to boost yields and sustainable agriculture in the country, where consumption has increased. The poll will be conducted by three Chinese universities, including Tsinghua University, to gather insights on public perception and concerns about GMO foods.

site_title: M&A deals drive 50% rally in healthcare stocks over past year
summary: Healthcare stocks in Singapore have surged 50% over the past year, driven by a wave of mergers and acquisitions. At least 19 transactions involving the acquisition of clinics by publicly traded companies have been completed in the past 12 months. Experts predict that consolidation in the industry will continue, with doctors attracted to join hospital systems for better care and easier integration into retirement. The optimism surrounding the industry has led to high valuations, but analysts expect organic growth and smooth integration to be key factors in the sector's future performance.

site_title: London house prices recover in May as sellers shrug off election
summary: London house prices rebounded in May, rising 2.1% to a record £649,864, despite the upcoming UK general election. This follows a 0.9% annual rate of price growth, with prices of family-sized homes increasing the most. Homeowners with children under 11 are twice as likely to be moving, according to Rightmove. The election uncertainty has not deterred sellers, with new sellers showing less hesitancy to come to market, defying the usual trend of holding off on transactions before an election.

site_title: Coronary side effects dash Amgen, UCB hopes for osteoporosis drug
summary: Amgen Inc and UCB SA have suspended hopes of obtaining US approval for their osteoporosis drug, romosozumab (Evenity), due to higher-than-expected serious heart-related side effects in a late-stage trial. The drug, awaiting FDA approval, now faces uncertain future. The news has sent UCB's shares down 13% and raised doubts about the company's long-term growth prospects. Analysts estimate annual sales of the drug to reach $720 million by 2023, but now predict a 50/50 chance of market approval.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher as oil prices, defense stocks rise
summary: US stocks rose on Monday as oil prices and defense stocks gained, driven by a $110 billion arms deal between the US and Saudi Arabia. The Dow Jones Industrial Average increased 0.37% to 20,880.91, while the S&P 500 rose 0.33% to 2,389.71. Oil prices rose 0.6% due to expectations of OPEC supply cuts, bolstered by a visit from President Donald Trump to Saudi Arabia. Despite concerns over domestic controversies, investors were boosted by strong quarterly earnings and a shift in focus towards the arms deal.

site_title: Bellwether property stocks beat benchmarks with 21.5% YTD gain
summary: Singapore's real estate developers and operators have outperformed the broader market, with the SGX Real Estate Developers and Operators Index recording a 17.9% gain in the year to date, surpassing the 13.3% return of the Straits Times Index. Five key developers, including Hongkong Land Holdings, CapitaLand, and City Developments Limited, have seen a 21.5% gain, driven by a recovery in the residential market following the easing of property cooling measures in March. Analysts attribute the sector's strong performance to cyclical growth and improving risk appetite for property.

images.alt_text: The shares of real estate developers and operators have outperformed the broader market on the back of a recovery in the residential market.

site_title: Weak earnings, tax bill batter Magnum shares
summary: Magnum Bhd's shares dropped by a tenth to RM1.88 after reporting weaker earnings for the first quarter, with a 56% year-on-year decline and 33% quarter-on-quarter decline. The company also faced a hefty tax bill of nearly RM477 million. This was a particularly disappointing result given that the first quarter is typically its strongest quarter, contributing over 30% of full-year earnings.

site_title: Indian tech firms need to move beyond old IT
summary: India's IT industry is facing an existential crisis due to stagnating markets and US visa restrictions. However, new technologies such as robotics, artificial intelligence, and sensors offer an opportunity for the sector to reinvent itself. Indian IT firms can help American companies modernize their ageing infrastructure and bring manufacturing back from China by mastering robotics technologies and providing programming, installation, and management consulting services. This could create new high-paying jobs and enable India to gain the support of Americans who have been against the industry.

site_title: Encryption inventor sues over alleged Apple Pay violation
summary: A Boston company, Universal Secure Registry, sued Apple and Visa over alleged patent violations of its encryption technology. The company, founded by RSA SecurID inventor Kenneth Weiss, claims its 13 patents for authentication systems, including smartphone-based and biometric identification, were infringed upon by Apple Pay. The lawsuit was filed in US District Court in Delaware.

site_title: Merkel's comments give euro a boost
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel's comments on the euro's value led to a surge in the euro's value, rising 0.2% to $1.1232. Merkel attributed Germany's large trade surplus to a weak euro and loose monetary policy, sparking speculation that the European Central Bank may tighten its monetary policy. The euro's value rebounded from its worst week in over a year, while the US dollar fell 0.1% against a basket of currencies.

site_title: Even UK towns that hated Tories are now happy to vote for Theresa May
summary: In the UK, a shift in voter allegiance is occurring in traditionally Labour-held towns, particularly in Wales, as a result of Theresa May's message resonating with working-class voters. Despite Labour's strong track record in the area, many are switching to the Conservatives due to their perceived stronger leadership and ability to safeguard local economies. The desire to leave the EU has also redrawn the UK's political map, with Conservatives poised to seize the biggest share of the vote and parliamentary seats in Wales for the first time since 1922.

site_title: RHT Health Trust reports 18.8% drop in Q4 DPU
summary: RHT Health Trust reported a 18.8% drop in Q4 DPU to 1.12 cents, attributed to reduced Fortis Hospotel Ltd share and higher corporate taxes and loan interest costs. The management also reduced the payout from distributable income to 95% in fiscal 2017 for capital expenditure and future growth.

site_title: Ten days that shook Washington
summary: US President Donald Trump's first 100 days in office have been marked by legislative achievements, foreign policy successes, and economic growth, but recent developments have raised concerns about his presidency. The firing of FBI Director James Comey has drawn comparisons to the Watergate scandal, with critics accusing Trump of attempting to cover up potential ties to Russia. The Justice Department's appointment of a Special Counsel, Robert Mueller, has been seen as a relief by many, but the ongoing investigation has sparked concerns about the potential for impeachment. The White House's handling of the scandal has raised questions about its ability to advance its policy agenda, and the economic impact of the controversy could be significant.

images.alt_text: Mr Trump and First Lady Melania Trump boarding Air Force One in Riyadh as they head to Israel on May 22.

site_title: Ski slope in Paris? Not yet as promoters face growing outcry
summary: A proposed 3.1 billion euro EuropaCity shopping and leisure complex in Paris's wheat fields has sparked growing outcry. Local officials envision the project as a new destination, but critics argue it disrupts the local setting and doesn't integrate with the surrounding environment. The development, backed by Auchan Holding SA and Dalian Wanda Group Co., remains a topic of debate.

site_title: Setting differences aside, Saudi-Russian courtship underpins oil prices
summary: Saudi Arabia and Russia, two nations with strained relationships, have formed an alliance to stabilize global oil prices by maintaining production cuts for nine months. This move has resulted in a 5% increase in oil prices. The agreement is driven by the two countries' dependence on oil revenues and their desire to maintain their influence in the global energy market. The alliance aims to counterbalance the rising influence of the US shale oil industry and is seen as a calculated attempt to leverage their energy resources for geopolitical gains, particularly in the Middle East.

site_title: SoftBank founder chases boyhood dreams with US$100b Vision Fund
summary: SoftBank founder Masayoshi Son has closed the first round of a planned $100 billion investment fund, the Vision Fund, with $93 billion in committed capital. The fund, backed by Saudi Arabia, Apple, and Qualcomm, aims to invest in artificial intelligence, connected devices, and satellites, with Son betting on the future of tech over the next decade. Critics warn that the influx of capital could lead to overcapitalization and inflated valuations, while Son's 300-year plan for SoftBank and the Vision Fund may be the most ambitious investment strategy in tech history.

site_title: Australia's budget proposals: popular despite some pain
summary: Australia's ruling National-Liberal Party coalition, led by Malcolm Turnbull, has seen a modest increase in opinion polls following the recent budget proposals. Despite increasing taxes on ordinary voters, such as a 0.5% rise in the universal health care levy, the budget is popular due to its non-ideological approach and efforts to extend the state's reach, including stricter regulations on major banks. The budget aims to fund a disability insurance scheme and improve consumer protection, potentially forestalling an opposition inquiry into the banking industry.

site_title: Peach becomes Japan's first airline to accept payment in Bitcoin
summary: Peach Aviation Ltd, Japan's first airline to accept Bitcoin, announced it will allow cryptocurrency payments for airline tickets starting by the end of the year. The move is aimed at attracting tourists from Asia and spreading the currency's usage. A change in Japan's law on fund settlements in April facilitated the move. The airline plans to increase partnerships with local governments and regional companies to promote Bitcoin usage.

site_title: Tung Lok's full-year net profit down 30.9%
summary: Tung Lok Restaurants reported a 30.9% decline in full-year net profit to S$85.1 million due to a 1.2% decrease in revenue, primarily caused by poor restaurant sales and the closure of two outlets. Gross profit margin declined to 71.9% and earnings per share fell to 0.15 Singapore cent. No dividend was declared, and the company's shares traded at S$0.115 on May 12, 2017.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: US hospitals scramble as supplies of sodium bicarbonate solution dwindle
summary: US hospitals are facing a shortage of sodium bicarbonate solution, a critical medication used to treat acidosis and as an antidote to certain poisons. The country's only two suppliers, Pfizer and Amphastar, have run out, leaving doctors to juggle chemotherapy and postpone surgery. Hospitals are scrambling to stockpile the medication, which is used in open-heart surgery and some types of chemotherapy. The shortage is expected to last until June or later for some forms of the drug, affecting hundreds of patients.

site_title: McDonald's in big drive for better tasting food to win back customers
summary: McDonald's is launching a new initiative to upgrade its kitchen equipment and menu offerings in an effort to win back customers. The company is requiring franchisees to spend around $100,000 per store on new equipment, including LED lighting, espresso machines, and baked-goods display cases. The goal is to improve the quality and taste of McDonald's food, including its fried chicken and desserts. The move aims to boost sales and traffic, which have been declining domestically for the past four years, with the company looking to compete with rivals like KFC and Chipotle.

images.alt_text: Balloons outside a McDonald's outlet in New York. The new costs to upgrade would be on top of the chain's ongoing "Experience of the Future" modernisation programme, which can run as high as US$700,000 per restaurant.

site_title: ECB's plan to take euro clearing from London stalled by infighting
summary: The European Central Bank's plan to move euro clearing from London to the eurozone has been stalled due to infighting among the eurozone's three largest countries - Germany, France, and Italy. The ECB has proposed taking over supervision of the largest clearing houses, but national authorities prefer to maintain control. The disagreement risks delaying the European Union's timetable for making a legislative proposal on euro clearing after Brexit. The issue may force the European Commission to make a proposal without ECB input, potentially altering the EU's plans.

site_title: Trump tax reform unlikely to impact municipal bonds, BofA says
summary: Bank of America Merrill Lynch strategists Philip Fischer and Celena Chan say tax reform is unlikely to impact municipal bonds, which are often purchased by wealthy investors seeking tax benefits. Despite concerns over slashing top individual tax rates, municipal bonds have historically priced independently of federal income tax rates. Corporate tax reform may occur by year-end, but it's unlikely to affect municipal bond pricing and flows. Yields on state and local bonds hit a 2017 low last week, and analysts believe this trend will continue.

site_title: Shadow of 1997 bust looms as HK home prices and housing debt hit highs
summary: Hong Kong's housing market is experiencing a boom, with prices at all-time highs, mortgage borrowing booming, and developers bidding up land costs. Experts are concerned about the potential for a repeat of the 1997 Asian financial crisis, which led to a six-year property bust. The city's economy is more vulnerable now, with household wealth tied to property, stagnant wages, and a reliance on cheap credit. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has taken measures to contain risks, including curbs on second-home mortgages and borrowers with overseas income. A potential crash could have severe economic consequences.

site_title: STI slips 0.1% as SIA continues descent
summary: Singapore stocks closed at 3,213.57, slipping 0.1% from the previous day. Despite the decline in the Straits Times Index, most stocks saw gains, with 225 winners surpassing 214 losers. The trading volume was 82% of the daily average, with 2.0 billion shares worth S$1.13 billion changing hands.

site_title: GP Batteries narrows Q4 net losses to S$4.02m from S$10.84m
summary: GP Batteries International Ltd reported narrower Q4 net losses of S$4.02m, down from S$10.84m a year ago, driven by higher revenue and lower operating expenses. The company's full-year net profit grew 45.5% to S$3.49m. GP Batteries declared a final dividend of 1.5 cents, higher than last year, but a lower interim dividend. The company plans to invest in automation, brand-building, and distribution development to improve competitiveness amid slow-growing demand and price competition.

site_title: China's JAC says electric car tie-up with VW approved
summary: China's JAC Motors has received government approval for a $734 million joint venture with Volkswagen to produce 100,000 electric cars per year. The partnership is part of China's push to increase electric vehicle sales, with the country now the world's top market for EVs. Volkswagen, the world's largest automaker, aims to sell 400,000 new-energy vehicles in China by 2020. The joint venture is subject to China's requirement that foreign automakers form partnerships with local manufacturers.

site_title: Shopping centre doom called overblown by Vegas-bound executives
summary: Industry executives attending the International Council of Shopping centres' annual convention in Las Vegas are dismissing concerns about the decline of the American mall, citing trends such as property owners re-leasing stores for more profitable uses like food and entertainment venues. Despite accelerating store closures and declining stocks, vacancy rates for retail properties in large cities remain near the lowest level of the past decade. Executives are exploring ways to combat declining foot traffic and make properties internet-proof, including replacing closing stores with experiential businesses.

site_title: EU's Barnier gets green light for Brexit talks
summary: EU ministers have unanimously given Frenchman Michel Barnier the green light to start Brexit talks with Britain, despite warnings of "very difficult" negotiations. Barnier, representing the remaining 27 EU member states, will conduct talks on behalf of the EU for the next two years. Britain's Brexit minister David Davis has threatened to walk away from the talks if the EU does not moderate its demands, particularly over the cost of Britain's departure, estimated at 100 billion euros. Negotiations are expected to begin in mid-June after the British general election.

site_title: US top court leaves key campaign finance restriction in place
summary: The US Supreme Court has upheld a federal campaign finance restriction that limits the amount of money state and local parties can raise for federal elections. The Republican Party of Louisiana had challenged the 2002 Bipartisan Campaign Reform Act, but the court let stand a lower court's ruling. This decision maintains restrictions on "soft money" donations, which were a key target of the law. The ruling follows the court's recent decisions eroding campaign finance restrictions, including the 2010 Citizens United case that allowed unlimited outside spending.

site_title: US duties to drive Canada wood exports to China
summary: Canada's top trade official, Francois Philippe Champagne, says US tariffs on Canadian softwood will drive an increase in lumber exports to China and other Asian markets, creating an "enormous opportunity" for diversification. The move comes after US President Donald Trump slapped duties as high as 24% on Canadian softwood. Canada's lumber exports to China have increased to 15% of total forestry exports over the past decade, and negotiations on a free-trade agreement between Canada and China are moving forward.

site_title: Under-pressure British PM amends key campaign pledge
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May amended her campaign pledge on elderly care, introducing a cap on what people would be asked to pay, amid criticism of her party's manifesto. The move came after a backlash against proposals to pay for elderly care, and was seen as a U-turn by Labour, who accused May of weak and unstable leadership. The change has raised concerns about May's ability to navigate Brexit negotiations, which are expected to start later this month.

site_title: German exports to US jump despite protectionist threat
summary: German exports to the US surged 8% in the first quarter of 2017, reaching $45.244 billion, despite US President Donald Trump's protectionist rhetoric. This is the largest bilateral trade surplus with a single country for Germany, standing at nearly $14 billion. Germany's export strength and the US trade deficit are set to be discussed in talks between Economy Minister Brigitte Zypries and US counterparts in Washington. Germany advocates for free and open trade based on WTO rules, which will be a key agenda point at the upcoming G20 summit in Hamburg.

site_title: Withers KhattarWong takes stock of its Singapore-global alliance
summary: Withers KhattarWong, a Singapore-based law firm, has formed a global alliance with international law firm Withers, expanding its presence to 18 cities. The union, formed in 2015, has led to a 10% annual growth in fee income despite challenging market conditions. The firm has integrated IT systems, accounts, and offices, and plans to further collaborate. Withers KhattarWong is expected to drive growth for Withers Worldwide in the Asia-Pacific region, with a focus on private wealth, tax, and hospitality practices. The firm aims to become a full-service, one-stop provider, but also acknowledges the value of boutique firms specializing in specific areas.

images.alt_text: Managing partner at Withers KhattarWong Deborah Barker says Withers' forte in private wealth and KhattarWong's tax know-how helped the two firms forge a global path forward through challenging times.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end the day higher
summary: Malaysian shares rose on Monday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index increasing 6.67 points to 1,774.950. A total of 4.09 billion lots, valued at RM2.95 billion, were traded. Gainers outnumbered losers 542 to 420, indicating a positive market trend.

site_title: Subaru mulls electric versions of its cars in R&D push
summary: Subaru is considering electric versions of its existing models as part of its research and development push. The company plans to install electric powertrains in current models rather than designing new cars, allowing it to capitalize on its safety reputation and avoid partnering with another manufacturer. This move is part of Subaru's record investments in R&D this financial year, as the company joins peers worldwide in responding to tightening emissions rules.

site_title: Business air travel taxying to take off again
summary: The business aviation sector, which experienced a decline following the 2008 global financial crisis, may be poised for a rebound as plane makers introduce new features such as onboard connectivity and comfortable seats. Industry experts, including Scott Neal and Peter Likoray, report a solid year for orders, with growth in the US, Asia Pacific, and Europe. Despite some sceptical voices, companies like Dassault Aviation and Embraer are launching new models with advanced technologies, and demand is expected to continue to rise, with growth reaching 6.7% year-on-year in Europe's business air travel market.

site_title: LHN secures its first overseas carpark management contract in HK
summary: LHN Ltd, a real estate management services group, has secured its first overseas carpark management contract in Hong Kong with a three-year contract awarded by the Government Property Agency. The contract, set to commence on May 29, 2017, brings LHN's total carpark properties under management to 42, including 41 in Singapore. This development follows the group's proposal to expand its space optimisation and real estate management expertise into the China market.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Marco Polo Marine has obtained a court order to temporarily restrain creditors as the company undertakes a court-supervised debt restructuring. Singapore Airlines and SATS shares fell amid concerns over falling airline yields. Cathay Pacific Airways is set to cut 600 staff, including 190 management staff, in its biggest job cuts in 20 years. China will allow private companies to invest in oil storage, while LedgerX raised US$11.4 million in funding. Singapore stocks closed 0.1% lower at 3,213.57 points.

site_title: GE said to face probe for misleading EU over US$1.7b deal
summary: General Electric Co is under investigation by the European Union for potentially misleading EU officials during a merger review of its $2.33 billion deal to buy LM Wind Power. The company allegedly claimed it didn't have plans to develop a new offshore wind turbine when it had a project on hold. The European Commission is reviewing the case to determine if GE provided false information.

site_title: Hot stocks: Falling yields of airlines weigh on SIA, SATS
summary: Singapore Airlines and SATS shares fell on Monday due to concerns over falling airline yields. SIA shares dropped 2% to S$9.79, while SATS shares declined 4.35% to S$5.06. The decline comes after SIA reported a loss last week, and SATS shares also fell last week amid increased competition in the airline industry.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: UN urges Indonesia to free jailed Jakarta governor
summary: The UN urged Indonesia to release jailed Jakarta Governor Basuki Tjahaja Purnama, also known as Ahok, and repeal blasphemy laws that undermine religious freedom. The family unexpectedly withdrew an appeal against his two-year jail term for blasphemy, which critics say target religious minorities. UN human rights experts condemned the conviction and imprisonment, calling it a threat to freedom of religion and speech in Indonesia. The government is urged to overturn the sentence or grant clemency to allow for his immediate release.

site_title: France's EDF denies report of "secret plan" to delay scaling back nuclear power
summary: France's state-controlled utility EDF has denied a report that it had a secret plan to delay scaling back nuclear power generation by 25 years. The plan, allegedly reported by French TV station BFM TV, would have reduced the share of nuclear power to 50% by 2050, instead of the 2025 target set by a French law. EDF maintains it is working within the existing framework and aims to meet the 2025 target, with Environment Minister Nicolas Hulot also confirming the goal.

site_title: After 25 years, Singapore boxing lands big punch
summary: Singapore boxing is experiencing a resurgence after 25 years, with local amateurs participating in Ringstar Management's Roar of Singapore II this Saturday. The sport's popularity has increased due to the growing interest in mixed martial arts and kick-boxing. This revival comes after the glamour of boxing faded in the 1960s and 1970s. The renewed interest in boxing is seen as a positive development for the sport, which is now punching above its weight in the country's sporting landscape.

site_title: Boustead Projects' Q4 profit jumps 165%
summary: Boustead Projects reported a 165% jump in Q4 net profit to S$14.3 million, driven by non-recurring compensation from lease termination and the sale of its interest in TripleOne Somerset. Despite a 35% year-on-year drop in revenue to S$38.5 million.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: TTJ Holdings lifts order book to S$166m with new contracts
summary: TTJ Holdings Ltd secured new contracts, increasing its order book to S$166 million as of May 22. The company won contracts for the supply, fabrication, and installation of structural steelworks for the Methionine Plant, East Coast Integrated Depot, and Mandai Depot. This achievement is seen as encouraging, translating into better returns for shareholders, according to Chairman and Managing Director Teo Hock Chwee.

images.alt_text: TTJ's chairman and managing director Teo Hock Chwee said: "Given the increasingly competitive market we face, securing these contracts is an encouraging achievement for us. We hope this will translate into better returns for our shareholders."

site_title: Temasek-backed China genomics firm to raise up to US$200m- sources
summary: A Temasek-backed Chinese genomics firm, WuXi NextCODE, is raising up to US$200 million in its latest fundraising round, with interest from investors including Hillhouse Capital Group and Sequoia Capital China. The proceeds will be used to build its genomics data platform, boost DNA sequencing capabilities, and commercialize products for China. This round follows a US$75 million financing round in March, co-led by Temasek and Jack Ma's Yunfeng Capital. The firm's appeal highlights the growing interest in genomics in China, where understanding DNA data can aid in developing targeted medicines and treatments.

site_title: LafargeHolcim hires Sika boss as next CEO
summary: LafargeHolcim has appointed Jan Jenisch, 50, as its new CEO, effective October 16. Jenisch, who has been Sika's CEO since 2012, replaces the previous CEO who quit after the company made payments to armed groups in Syria. Paul Schuler, Sika's regional manager for Europe, Middle East, and Africa, will take over as CEO at Sika. This appointment comes as LafargeHolcim seeks to address the controversy surrounding its past dealings.

site_title: Move over Tesla, Europe's building its own battery gigafactories
summary: Europe is investing heavily in its own battery gigafactories, challenging Tesla's lead in the US. Germany's Daimler AG is building a 500 million-euro plant to assemble lithium-ion energy-storage units, with other major automakers and power companies following suit in Sweden, Hungary, and Poland. The move is expected to significantly reduce battery costs, making electric cars a mainstream reality by 2030, and could lead to a quicker shift towards green power for both cars and utilities.

site_title: China, Russia formalise Shanghai venture to build wide-body jet
summary: China and Russia have formalized a joint venture to build a wide-body jet, aiming to compete with Boeing and Airbus. The joint venture, established in Shanghai, will produce a 280-seat, 12,000km-range jet, with completion of the maiden flight and first delivery expected between 2025-2028. The project was initially announced in 2014, with Comac and UAC initially targeting 2022 for the maiden flight and 2025 for delivery. The venture holds equal shares and aims to capture 10% of the market from the Boeing 787 and Airbus 350.

site_title: Shareholders take Akzo Nobel to court in effort to aid PPG takeover
summary: Shareholders of Akzo Nobel, a Dutch paint maker, are taking the company to court in an effort to aid a potential takeover by US rival PPG Industries. The shareholders, backed by British hedge fund Elliott Advisors, are seeking an investigation into Akzo's board and a meeting to vote on dismissing Chairman Antony Burgmans. A ruling is expected within a week, with PPG considering whether to submit a formal bid or walk away. Akzo rejected PPG's 26.3 billion euro offer, citing cultural and environmental concerns, but faces skepticism from some quarters, including Dutch shareholders' association VEB.

site_title: China slaps import duties on sugar
summary: China has imposed hefty penalties on sugar imports, introducing an extra tariff of 45% on shipments exceeding 1.94 million tonnes per year. The ruling aims to support domestic sugar mills but may not stem the flow of lower-priced imports, potentially leading to increased smuggling. Global raw sugar prices fell 1% following the announcement, and experts say the move may not be enough to address the issue, with sugar futures down 0.4% at 6,697 yuan per tonne. The tariffs will fall to 90% next year and 85% the year after.

site_title: Australia: Financials, commodity prices lift stock index
summary: Australia's stock index rose 0.81% on Monday, breaking a three-session losing streak, driven by gains in financials, metals, and energy companies. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 46.59 points to 5,774.7. Financials, particularly insurers, led the gains, while energy shares benefited from rising oil prices. Iron miners Rio Tinto, BHP Billiton, and Fortescue Metals also rose, with Rio Tinto shares near three-month highs.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up as oil prices lift energy sector
summary: Tokyo shares rose on Monday, driven by gains on Wall Street due to a jump in oil prices, lifting energy companies. The Nikkei 225 index increased 0.45% to 19,678.28, while the Topix index advanced 0.51% to 1,567.65. The rally follows similar gains on US stock markets, which edged to fresh records despite ongoing US-EU trade uncertainty.

site_title: Australia: Stocks end higher on commodity lift
summary: Australian stocks rose 0.76% to 5,771.2, led by gains in miners and oil companies. Iron ore prices jumped over 3% and oil prices rose on reports of an extended OPEC supply cut. BHP Billiton, Rio Tinto, and Fortescue Metals Group led gains, while Commonwealth Bank and Westpac Banking Corp rose in the financials sector. New Zealand's benchmark index also rose 0.24%.

site_title: China: Stocks end weaker as tighter regulations bite
summary: China's Shanghai stocks ended lower on Monday, reversing earlier gains, as tighter regulations and concerns over economic growth hurt risk appetite. The CSI300 index rose 0.2% and the Shanghai Composite Index lost 0.5%. The State Information Centre predicted China's economy will expand around 6.8% in the second quarter. Regulatory actions, including punishment for brokerage firms and restrictions on home purchases, also contributed to the decline.

site_title: Europe: Stocks climb at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose at the open on Monday, with the FTSE 100 index gaining 0.4% to 7,496.90 points. The DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices also advanced 0.2% each. The gains were attributed to mining and healthcare stocks. The rally comes as investors focus on US-EU trade talks, despite uncertainty surrounding US tariffs.

site_title: China to allow private companies to invest in oil storage
summary: China plans to allow private companies to invest in oil storage, part of a broader effort to overhaul the country's state-owned enterprises. The move is aimed at promoting reform in the heavily monopolized oil and gas industries. The government has previously announced plans to open upstream oil and gas exploration to private companies and split natural gas sales from pipeline operations. This move is part of China's efforts to introduce mixed ownership of state firms and promote private sector investment in the energy sector.

site_title: Three years after coup, rural Thais yearn for democracy
summary: In rural Thailand, three years after a military coup, dissent remains banned, and the junta holds significant power. The northeastern region of Isaan, home to a third of the country's population, is particularly affected by the lack of democracy and free expression. Residents long for an elected government and the ability to voice their opinions, despite the risk of arrest under Thailand's draconian laws. The junta's handling of the economy has also been criticized, with many fearing it will worsen.

site_title: Hackers hit Russian bank customers, planned international cyber raids
summary: Russian hackers used malware on Android devices to steal over $892,000 from domestic bank customers. The hackers, dubbed "Cron," infected over 1 million smartphones, compromising 3,500 devices daily. They planned to target European banks, including French lenders, but were arrested in November. The gang exploited weaknesses in SMS text message transfer services to steal funds. The attack highlights the dangers of using SMS messages for mobile banking, which is favored in emerging countries. 16 suspects were arrested, with one suspected gang leader, a 30-year-old man from Ivanovo, remaining in detention.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rise; NT$ at strongest level vs US$ in 2-1/2 weeks
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 0.3% on Monday, with the main Taiex index reaching 9,975.81 points, driven by foreign fund inflows. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to a 2.5-week high against the US dollar, reaching NT$30.017 per US dollar. This marks an 8% gain for the currency this year, making it the second-strongest in major markets. The central bank has avoided weakening the currency through market intervention, amid concerns of being labeled a currency manipulator by the Trump administration.

site_title: New 'Twin Peaks' wins praise, piques curiosity
summary: David Lynch's 'Twin Peaks' returned after 26 years with an 18-episode run on Showtime, prompting an outpouring of joy and curiosity. The series, a noir soap opera about murder in small-town America, was met with positive reactions, with many praising its surreal style. The show's revival, which includes original cast members and director Lynch, has sparked anticipation and debate among fans, with some questioning the pace and style of the new episodes. The show's revival has made it a top trending US hashtag, with fans eagerly awaiting more.

site_title: Hainan Airlines to buy US$4.2b of planes, issue bonds
summary: Hainan Airlines plans to spend 28.9 billion yuan (S$5.8 billion) on new planes, introducing 19 planes into its fleet to increase annual revenue by 5.14 billion yuan. The airline will raise funds through a 15 billion yuan issue of convertible bonds. This expansion aims to capitalize on strong demand from Chinese travelers.

site_title: Philippines' Duterte heads to Russia in blow to US
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte is visiting Russia for a five-day trip, seeking to strengthen ties with Moscow and pivot his nation's foreign policy away from the US. The visit aims to secure Russian precision-guided bombs to combat Islamic militants in the southern Philippines and to explore new defense deals. Duterte has been critical of the US, describing it as hypocritical and bullying, and has instead sought support from China and Russia, which he believes will help him achieve his goals. The trip marks a significant shift in the Philippines' foreign policy, with Duterte seeking to reduce cooperation with the US and strengthen ties with Beijing and Moscow.

site_title: Philippine minister starts damage control after Duterte's China war remark
summary: Philippine Foreign Secretary Alan Peter Cayetano said talks between President Rodrigo Duterte and Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping were "frank and friendly" with no threats or bullying, contradicting Duterte's statement that he was warned of war if he drills for oil in the South China Sea. Cayetano emphasized mutual respect and trust, but acknowledged the threat of conflict if dialogue is not maintained. A Philippine Supreme Court judge urged the government to file another international arbitration case and lodge a complaint with the UN, citing Duterte's alleged willingness to "sell out" sovereignty for Chinese loans and investments.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars languish near multi-month lows vs euro
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars are near multi-month lows against the euro, with the euro rising to A$1.5034 and NZ$1.6130 due to safe-haven flow amid US political turmoil and improving economic data. The common currency's value is also influenced by anticipation of developments in Washington.

site_title: Seoul: Won rises on Trump turmoil, stocks edge up
summary: The South Korean won surged over 1% to a one-week high, reaching 1,115.0 against the US dollar, amid US President Donald Trump's political turmoil. The dollar weakened following reports of possible coordination between Russia and Trump's election campaign. The won's jump was seen as a positive response to the turmoil, with stocks also edging up.

site_title: Asian energy firms lead market gains on hopes for oil ouput cut
summary: Asian energy firms led a market rally on Monday as oil prices rose due to growing hopes that an Opec-led output cut will be extended for another nine months. The deal, set to finish at the end of June, was boosted by Saudi Arabia's energy minister expressing confidence in an extension. With a meeting between Opec and Russia scheduled for Thursday, investors are optimistic about the agreement's potential to curb a global glut and stabilize oil prices.

site_title: Aussie housing spurs S&P to cut banks; biggest lenders spared
summary: S&P Global Ratings downgraded the credit scores of 23 Australian financial institutions, citing increased risks of a property market downturn. However, the largest banks, including Commonwealth Bank of Australia and National Australia Bank, were spared due to expectations of government support. The agency warned that a sharp correction in property prices could amplify the impact on financial institutions, given the country's external weaknesses. This move follows S&P's previous downgrade of Australia's sovereign rating to AAA with a negative outlook.

site_title: Ford CEO Fields to leave as Hackett takes over
summary: Ford CEO Mark Fields is leaving the company amid a loss of confidence in his leadership, following a 30% decline in shares since his appointment in 2014. Fields will be replaced by James P. Hackett, head of Ford Smart Mobility LLC. Hackett will assume larger roles, including president of Europe, Middle East, and Africa business, and head of Ford Americas. Fields' departure comes as the company struggles with a traditional-car business decline, while investing in self-driving cars and ride-sharing experiments.

images.alt_text: Ford Motor Co Chief Executive Officer Mark Fields is leaving the company amid a loss of confidence in his leadership, and the carmaker is set to make an announcement Monday, Forbes reported on its website, citing a person familiar with the situation.

site_title: Samsung Elec to continue looking for M&A opportunities
summary: Samsung Electronics plans to continue acquiring companies to build software and services, differentiating its products and competing with Apple and Huawei. The company aims to make its products more attractive to consumers through partnerships and acquisitions. Samsung has already completed an $8 billion acquisition of Harman International Industries to enter the automotive components industry. Senior vice president Peter Koo expressed the company's bullish approach to finding companies that fit its strategy, without specifying targets or technologies.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.820 points to 1,771.100 on Monday, driven by gains. Volume reached 176.59 million lots worth RM71.13 million, with 269 gainers and 58 losers.

site_title: India's US$1.3t housing bonanza draws Piramal mortgage bet
summary: Indian billionaire Ajay Piramal is investing heavily in the country's growing housing market, with an estimated $1.3 trillion in potential investments over the next seven years. Piramal Enterprises Ltd is considering affordable housing projects and seeking a license to offer loans to home buyers, while Piramal Realty Pvt Ltd is exploring affordable housing initiatives. The government's push for affordable housing aims to create 60 million new homes by 2024 and drive economic growth. Piramal's efforts are part of a larger trend, with over 75 mortgage financiers operating in India, and the company is well-positioned to capitalize on the opportunity due to its deep pockets and funding.

images.alt_text: Indian billionaire Ajay Piramal wants to sell mortgages and build affordable homes as the drugs-to-data conglomerate seeks to ride an estimated US$1.3 trillion housing-investment boom.

site_title: Chinese paper applauds anti-spy efforts after report of CIA sources killed
summary: China's state-run newspaper, Global Times, praised the country's anti-espionage efforts after a New York Times report claimed China had killed or imprisoned up to 20 CIA sources between 2010 and 2012. The paper said the CIA's spy network was dismantled, giving China a "sweeping victory" over US intelligence operations. However, the paper disputed one part of the report, calling it a "fabricated story" likely based on "ideology." The Chinese government has yet to comment on the report.

site_title: China's yuan weakens against US dollar, hits low against currency basket
summary: China's yuan weakened against the US dollar, reaching a record low against a currency basket, despite a firmer midpoint fix by the People's Bank of China. The yuan fell to 6.8673 per US dollar, down from the previous day's rate of 6.8786. Heavy corporate dollar demand and concerns about China's economic slowdown contributed to the decline. The People's Bank of China set the midpoint rate firmer than expected, but the yuan still dropped against the currency basket.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, tracking gains on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.40% and the Topix index advanced 0.36%. The gains were driven by higher oil prices lifting energy shares.

site_title: Bitcoin options exchange raises US$11.4m in funding
summary: Ledger Holdings, the parent company of bitcoin options exchange LedgerX, raised $11.4 million in funding led by Miami International Holdings and China's Huiyin Blockchain Venture Investments. The funding supports LedgerX's plan to operate a regulated exchange and clearing house for bitcoin and other digital currencies. The company is awaiting regulatory approval from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission to operate the first US regulated exchange and clearing house for bitcoin options. With the funding, LedgerX aims to expand its operations and enter additional marketplaces and territories.

images.alt_text: Ledger Holdings, the New York-based parent company of bitcoin options exchange LedgerX, said on Monday it closed $11.4 million in funding led by Miami International Holdings Inc and China's Huiyin Blockchain Venture Investments.

site_title: Doctors selling clinics spark rally in Singapore health stocks
summary: Singapore's healthcare stocks have seen a significant 50% gain over the past year, driven by acquisitions of local clinics. The surge has been fueled by 19 transactions involving publicly-traded companies acquiring clinics in the last 12 months, more than twice as many as in 2015. Companies like Singapore Medical Group and Singapore O&G have seen substantial gains, with the healthcare index climbing three times as much as the benchmark Straits Times Index. Experts predict further growth as more physicians sell their practices to larger medical care providers.

site_title: Subaru considers electric versions of its cars in R&D push
summary: Subaru is considering electric versions of its existing models as part of its research and development push. The company plans to invest 134 billion yen (S$1.66 billion) in R&D, prioritizing electrification over other technologies. Subaru aims to introduce a plug-in hybrid model next year and an all-electric vehicle by 2021. By adding electric powertrains to existing models, Subaru can capitalize on its safety reputation without partnering with another automaker. The company is weighing options for battery and motor suppliers, with Panasonic and Samsung among possible partners.

site_title: Higher rate of heart problems seen with Amgen bone drug in trial
summary: Amgen's experimental osteoporosis drug, romosozumab, may not win US approval this year due to a higher rate of serious heart-related side effects observed in a late-stage clinical trial. The drug, awaiting FDA approval, showed robust efficacy in reducing vertebral fractures but also raised cardiovascular safety concerns. The new safety data is expected to delay any FDA decision, potentially impacting Amgen's growth prospects. Analysts predict a 3-4% decline in Amgen shares due to the news.

site_title: Oil climbs with Asia stocks on supply speculation
summary: Crude oil prices rose to nearly US$51 a barrel, driven by speculation that cuts to crude supplies will be extended for nine months. Asian stocks also advanced, with the yen declining. The S&P 500 Index closed higher on Friday, despite reports of a White House official being focused on as a person of interest in the Russia probe. Global equities are near a record high as investors bet on sustained growth despite US and Brazilian political turmoil.

site_title: Three climbers die on Everest, one missing
summary: Three climbers died on Mount Everest over the weekend, with a fourth missing, due to altitude sickness. The deaths bring the season's toll to five, with over a dozen climbers rescued in the past three days. The climbers' bodies were found at altitudes of over 8,000 meters, known as the "death zone." A search operation is underway for the missing climber from India's Uttar Pradesh state. The deaths come amid unpredictable weather, strong winds, and cold temperatures, with over 100 climbers expected to attempt to summit from Nepal's south side on Monday.

images.alt_text: Three climbers died on Everest over the weekend and another is missing, officials confirmed Monday, in one of the deadliest episodes on the peak since an avalanche swept through base camp killing 18 two years ago.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.46 points lower on Monday
summary: The Singapore bourse opened 0.46 points lower on Monday, with the Straits Times Index at 3,216.46. Despite this, the market had a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. In other news, Popiah king Sam Goi made a mandatory offer for PSC at S$0.40 a share, and eSIM platform Airalo raised US$220 million in new funding, lifting its valuation past US$1 billion.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Cathay Pacific to cut 600 jobs, including 190 management staff: SCMP
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd is cutting nearly 600 staff, including 190 management positions, as part of a three-year plan to turn around losses. The airline reported its first annual loss since 2008 in March and announced a 30% cost-cutting plan for middle and senior management roles. The cuts will be implemented in two phases, with 400 non-management staff to be let go by mid-June. The move aims to reduce costs and improve the airline's financial performance.

site_title: Marco Polo's shipyard unit gets court order to temporarily restrain creditors
summary: Marco Polo Marine's PT Marcopolo Shipyard has filed a court application to temporarily suspend debt payments, allowing for a 45-day court-supervised debt restructuring process. A supervisory judge has been appointed, and a team of administrators will assist the shipyard in managing its assets. If the debt restructuring plan fails, the shipyard may be placed into bankruptcy. The company is seeking to restructure its debt amid financial difficulties.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher
summary: Hong Kong shares began the week on a positive note, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.32% to 25,255.54. Energy firms were boosted by hopes of an extended Opec-led production cut. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index declined 0.11% and 0.10% respectively.

site_title: London house prices recover as sellers shrug off election
summary: London house prices rebounded in May, reaching a record high of £649,864, despite the upcoming UK general election on June 8. The average asking price rose 2.1% from April, with the annual rate of price growth remaining subdued at 0.9%. Sellers are defying the usual trend of holding off on transactions before an election, with new sellers in the capital showing less hesitancy to come to market. The recovery is attributed to buyers and sellers prioritizing property transactions over electioneering and Brexit worries.

site_title: China pushes public to accept GMO as Syngenta takeover nears
summary: China plans to conduct a nationwide poll to gauge public acceptance of genetically-modified (GMO) food, amid growing concerns and skepticism about the technology. The poll, sponsored by the government, aims to educate the public about GMO technology and boost yields and sustainable agriculture. The country is the world's fourth-largest grower of GMO cotton and top importer of soybeans, but public concern over food safety and misinformation has hindered the introduction of GMO technology for staple crops. The poll is seen as a step towards increasing public acceptance and paving the way for the government to introduce GMO technology for staple crops.

site_title: New Zealand splits with Malaysia over reworking TPP without US
summary: New Zealand's Trade Minister Todd McClay stated that the country won't benefit from significant changes to the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) without the US, as it is "very well balanced" and doesn't need much renegotiation. Malaysia, which is pushing for the pact to be renegotiated, expressed concerns about the deal's viability without the US. The TPP's remaining 11 countries will work on a revised provision to ratify the agreement, with a deadline of November for leaders to decide how to proceed.

site_title: Malaysian minister flags living costs as concern ahead of polls
summary: Malaysian Trade Minister Mustapa Mohamed has highlighted the cost of living as a major concern among voters ahead of upcoming polls, which are expected to be held by mid-2018. The ruling coalition is working to improve voter communications despite divided opposition. Inflation reached an eight-year high in March, and consumer sentiment has been below optimism since mid-2014, with concerns over the government's consumption tax and the value of the dollar. Despite this, the government is optimistic about the economy, which has seen growth and a 3% increase in the ringgit against the dollar this year.

site_title: Mozart junior: Curse of the 'missing spark'
summary: Austrian musician Franz Xaver Mozart struggled to find his place in the world, overshadowed by his famous father Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart. Born months before his father's death, Franz Xaver was warned by his mother that a disappointing child would face disgrace and misery. Despite efforts to make a name for himself, Franz Xaver failed to achieve the same level of success as his father, living a life marked by disappointment and failure. His story serves as a cautionary tale about the challenges of living up to parental expectations.

site_title: KBR's venture in Malaysia stokes fears it will downsize Singapore operations
summary: KBR, a New York-listed engineering firm with hundreds of employees in Singapore, has entered a joint venture with a Malaysian partner. This move comes after other large-cap contracting groups exited Singapore after setting up similar ventures in Malaysia, sparking concerns about potential downsizing of KBR's operations in the country.

site_title: Rural Japan annoyed by casino plan seen favoring big cities
summary: The Japanese government has released a new bidding framework for casino resorts, favoring major cities like Tokyo, Osaka, and Yokohama, sparking criticism from smaller cities that claim it undermines rural revitalization efforts. Global casino operators, including Las Vegas Sands and MGM Resorts, have expressed interest in building resorts in these cities due to their high population and proximity to international airports. The framework requires partnerships between operators and municipalities, but some officials argue it will lead to big operators only partnering with large cities, undermining the government's goal of revitalizing rural areas.

images.alt_text: Tokyo, Osaka and Yokohama are emerging as likely candidates for casino resorts under the Japanese government's new bidding framework, triggering criticism from smaller cities that say it undermines Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's goal of reviving rural areas.

site_title: Australia's Westpac says new bank levy will add US$48m in costs
summary: Westpac Banking Corp, Australia's No.2 lender, expects a new bank levy to result in additional costs of A$260 million (US$48m) in the second half of the financial year. The levy, announced in the annual budget, is equivalent to 8 cents per share or 4.3% of dividends paid. The bank plans to consult with stakeholders to manage the significant impost, despite opposing the idea. The levy is part of the government's efforts to raise revenue from the country's five biggest banks.

site_title: US dollar hovers near 6-month lows amid US political uncertainty
summary: The US dollar hovered near six-month lows against a basket of currencies due to US political uncertainty. The dollar index inched up 0.1% to 97.235, but remained near its lowest since November 9. Investors assessed the impact of US President Donald Trump's recent firing of FBI Director James Comey and the uncertainty surrounding his administration's tax reform and fiscal stimulus plans. The euro also weakened, and net long positioning on the euro rose to its highest in over three years, amid expectations of a possible interest rate hike by the US Federal Reserve next month.

site_title: Junta is now deeply embedded in Thai life
summary: Thailand's military government, led by General Prayuth Chan-ocha, has become deeply embedded in Thai society. The military controls 143 out of 250 parliamentary seats and 12 out of 36 Cabinet members have a military background. The government has also issued 358 orders since 2014, imposing discipline on various aspects of public life. The military's influence extends to institutions such as the Privy Council, cinema, and television, with pro-military themes being increasingly shown. Despite public approval of the military's hard-line tactics, the military's grip on Thai society remains a concern.

site_title: Japan April exports rise 7.5% y-o-y: MOF
summary: Japan's exports rose 7.5% in April, marking the fifth consecutive month of gains, according to Ministry of Finance data. This follows a 12% rise in March. Imports surged 15.1%, exceeding the median estimate of 14.8% increase. The trade balance came to a surplus of 481.7 billion yen, higher than the estimated 521 billion yen surplus.

site_title: Vallianz slips to the red in Q1 with US$173.2m loss
summary: Vallianz Holdings reported a net loss of US$173.2 million for Q1, primarily due to non-cash impairment expenses caused by a sector slowdown. Quarterly revenue fell 21.5% to US$38.7 million, mainly due to completed vessel management projects and lower vessel utilisation. The company's financial year-end shifted to March, which impacted results.
