site_title: Taiwan April jobless rate falls to over 1-1/2-year low
summary: Taiwan's unemployment rate dropped to 3.78% in April, its lowest level in over a year and a half, according to the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics. This is a decrease from March's 3.84% and the lowest since August 2015. The seasonally-adjusted rate reflects a decline in the labor market, indicating improved economic conditions in Taiwan.

site_title: UK threatens to quit Brexit talks if it faces massive bill
summary: The UK is threatening to quit Brexit talks unless the EU drops its demand for a massive divorce payment, estimated to be as high as 100 billion euros. Brexit Secretary David Davis said a £1 billion settlement would be "a lot of money" and Britain would otherwise be plunged into "chaos." Prime Minister Theresa May's government has questioned the EU's preliminary estimates, and the negotiations are expected to be "fairly turbulent." The UK will begin talks on June 19, but only if the EU agrees to a more reasonable payment.

site_title: Japan urges unity among 11 nations left in TPP pact, Seko says
summary: Japan's Trade Minister Hiroshige Seko urged unity among the 11 remaining countries in the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) pact, despite the US withdrawal. Seko met with US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer and agreed to build on the Japan-US economic dialogue. Japan aims to promote the pact's high standards and rules-based approach, which goes further in tackling non-tariff barriers than other trade deals. The TPP member nations agreed to start a process to put the pact into force, with officials to assess how to bring the agreement to life by the Apec leaders' summit in November.

site_title: North Korea says missile test confirms warhead guidance
summary: North Korea successfully tested an intermediate-range ballistic missile, confirming the reliability of its nuclear warhead guidance and solid-fuel engine. The test, supervised by leader Kim Jong Un, verified the ability to hit US targets and marked the second missile test in a week. The launch was seen as a further advancement in North Korea's ability to develop a nuclear-tipped missile capable of striking the US mainland, with US officials warning of continued economic and diplomatic pressure.

site_title: Tokyo intensifies efforts to be global financial centre
summary: Tokyo is intensifying efforts to become a global financial centre, with Tokyo Governor Yoriko Koike aiming to create an agency to promote financial sector development. A panel of experts, including Japanese and foreign experts, is working to address barriers such as onerous tax laws and complex regulations. Despite Tokyo's existing attributes as a major financial hub, including a large stock market and foreign exchange centre, the city faces challenges in competing with other global financial centres, including Shanghai and Frankfurt. The panel is targeting reforms and embracing fintech to enhance Tokyo's financial capabilities.

site_title: Notre Dame graduates walk out on Pence as he touts free speech
summary: US Vice-President Mike Pence's commencement speech at Notre Dame University was disrupted by dozens of students who walked out to protest his stance on free speech. Pence warned of the dangers of suppressing free expression, which some saw as an attack on liberal values. The protesters, many of whom displayed anti-Trump and anti-Pence messages on their graduation caps, cited Pence's advocacy for policies they disagreed with. The incident highlights the ongoing controversy over free speech on college campuses.

site_title: Facebook leaked documents show types of content it allows: Guardian
summary: Facebook's leaked internal documents reveal how the company moderates content on its platform, including hate speech, terrorism, and self-harm. Moderators face challenges in making decisions, with some policies deemed complex and confusing, particularly those related to sexual content. The company uses software to intercept graphic content and prioritizes safety, but critics argue that inconsistencies in moderation can lead to inconsistent results. Facebook confirmed its commitment to safety but did not comment on the authenticity of the leaked documents.

site_title: No time for Brexit delays, says UK's May as poll lead slips
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May urged voters to back her for a successful Brexit, citing a shrinking lead in polls. The Conservatives' lead over Labour has fallen to between 9 and 13 percentage points, down from 20 points before the snap election. May emphasized her commitment to securing a good Brexit deal, contrasting with Labour's uncertain position. EU officials prepare for Brexit talks to begin on June 19, with May set to deliver a speech highlighting her determination to deliver the democratic will of the British people.

site_title: US carmakers downshift on Trump economic plan
summary: US carmakers, including Ford and General Motors, have idled thousands of workers despite President Donald Trump's plans to boost the economy. Sales have dropped 4.7% in April, the largest decline since the 2008-2009 recession, with analysts predicting a decline in US sales for the first time since the financial crisis. Despite job announcements, production cuts have led to grumbling from shareholders, with some calling for changes in leadership.

site_title: AusGroup proposes debt-to-equity conversion on notes, shareholder loan from Ezion
summary: AusGroup, an oilfield services firm, proposes a debt-to-equity conversion for its S$110 million notes due 2018 and a shareholder loan from Ezion Holdings. Noteholders will exchange existing notes for new shares, and the company may issue up to 1.83 billion new shares. The proposed transactions aim to reduce debt and increase paid-up capital, improving the group's balance sheet and ability to raise funds. AusGroup will hold an extraordinary general meeting to seek shareholder approval, with several major shareholders, including Ezion, undertaking to vote in favor of the proposals.

site_title: Protesters call for Temer resignation as uncertainty grips Brazil
summary: Brazilian protesters gathered across the country to call for President Michel Temer's resignation amid a widening corruption scandal. Demonstrations took place in cities like São Paulo and Rio de Janeiro, with chants and banners reading "Temer Out!" The scandal, which involves Temer's alleged condoning of hush money payments, has eroded support for his government's economic recovery measures. The Brazilian Bar Association announced it would join impeachment motions against Temer, citing a dereliction of presidential duties. The protests mark a significant shift in public opinion, with many questioning Temer's ability to lead the country.

site_title: Ghost of '97 stalks Hong Kong economy infected by housing debt
summary: Hong Kong's property market is experiencing a boom, with prices at all-time highs and mortgage borrowing on the rise. Experts warn that the city's economy is vulnerable to another financial crisis, similar to the one in 1997 that led to a six-year property bust. With a huge accumulation of household wealth in property and a reliance on banking, a crash could drag down banks and lead to a full-fledged financial crisis. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has introduced new measures to contain risks, but many predict that the market is economically unsustainable and will eventually decline, potentially triggering deflation.

images.alt_text: In 1997, the Asian financial crisis touched off a six-year property bust in Hong Kong that shaved more than two-thirds off prices and saddled the city with a stagnant economy and deflation.

site_title: The Trump-market honeymoon is officially over
summary: US stocks finished slightly lower last week due to the biggest drop in major indexes since the presidential election, amid a spreading political scandal surrounding President Trump's exertion of pressure on the FBI. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell by over 370 points, and shares of companies perceived as benefiting from Trump's economic policies were among the biggest losers. The market is likely to remain on edge this week as traders await a sense of restored political stability, with the Federal Reserve's rate hike outlook uncertain.

site_title: Boeing signs defence, commercial deals with Saudi Arabia
summary: Boeing has signed defence and commercial deals with Saudi Arabia, including the sale of Chinook helicopters, P-8 surveillance aircraft, and guided weapons systems. The US$3.51 billion deal, announced in December, includes 48 CH-47F Chinook cargo helicopters. The agreement was reached during a visit by US President Donald Trump to the kingdom, marking a significant boost to Boeing's sales in the region.

site_title: Tennis: Zverev stuns Djokovic to win Rome Masters
summary: Alexander Zverev, a 20-year-old German tennis player, won the Rome Masters by defeating four-time champion Novak Djokovic 6-4, 6-3. Zverev claimed his maiden Masters 1000 title and rose to 10th in the world rankings. Djokovic had 27 unforced errors, while Zverev had 16 winners. Zverev's victory marked the youngest player in a decade to reach a Masters 1000 final, surpassing Djokovic's achievement as the previous youngest Masters finalist in 2007.

site_title: 'Foreign invaders' threaten struggling Australian media
summary: Foreign media giants such as The New York Times and Daily Mail are expanding their presence in Australia, threatening the decline of local players. With deep pockets and free content, they are eating into traditional media's revenues, accelerating job cuts and belt-tightening. Analysts warn that foreign invaders are disrupting the market, eroding revenue bases and taking eyeballs away from local mastheads. As advertising revenues are under siege from Google and Facebook, local providers struggle to adapt, with some, like Fairfax and News Corp, axing newsrooms and cutting costs.

site_title: India's snub over 'Belt and Road' forum highlights gulf with China
summary: India snubbed China's invitation to its "Belt and Road" forum, rejecting the offer to join the massive infrastructure project linking China with Asia and beyond due to its territorial disputes with Pakistan over Kashmir. China had offered to rename a key project to persuade India to attend, but New Delhi refused, citing concerns over China's sovereignty and strategic interests in the region. The move risks isolating India and undermines the commercial viability of the project, which could be worth $84-126 billion to India between 2017 and 2021.

site_title: Erdogan's grip on Turkey tightens as he retakes control of ruling party
summary: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan regained control of the ruling AK Party, solidifying his grip on power. The move allows him to appoint loyalists to key positions, further consolidating his authority. Erdogan, who has already neutralized opposition and subordinated the press, will now implement stricter party regulations, including harsh penalties for dissent. The ruling party's congress, held under extraordinary security measures, was seen as a step towards eradicating any remaining opposition within the party, with Erdogan attributing democratic shortcomings to terrorist threats.

site_title: Funds profit from crop price falls but miss gold rally
summary: US hedge funds profited from crop price declines, but missed the gold rally due to misjudging the metal's price movement. Funds were well-positioned for the drop in agriculture, but reduced their gold holdings by 30% in May, missing the metal's best week in over a month. Meanwhile, copper and orange juice prices rose, while coffee prices fell to a one-year low.

site_title: Canberra to tighten screws on banks, raise A$6.2b in a new tax
summary: Australia's government plans to introduce a new tax on the country's five biggest banks, raising A$6.2 billion over four years through a six basis points levy on liabilities over A$100 billion. The tax aims to spur competition, punish banks for misdeeds, and finance infrastructure and health spending. The levy will affect the banks' profitability, potentially leading to higher borrowing costs for customers. The move is expected to be popular with voters, but the Australian Bankers' Association has slammed the tax as a "political tax grab."

site_title: Henkel strides towards Asia-Pac smart factories
summary: Henkel, a German adhesive technologies and consumer goods giant, is expanding its presence in the Asia-Pacific region by implementing Industry 4.0 technologies in its factories and partnering with local startups. Henkel also plans to roll out its smart factory model to all its factories in the Asia-Pacific and worldwide. Additionally, the company has branched out into the local retail sector for its hair products, partnering with retailers such as Watsons and Guardian.

site_title: Trump calls on Middle East leaders to step up in the fight against 'Islamist extremism'
summary: US President Donald Trump called on Middle East leaders to combat "Islamist extremism" in a speech, shifting the burden to the region to fight militant groups while urging unity among religions. This comes despite his previous push to ban many Muslims from entering the US, generating controversy.

site_title: OCBC offers safehouse for 'rebels' to hatch breakthrough ideas
summary: OCBC Bank has created a "safehouse" for "rebels" within the company, allowing employees to experiment with innovative ideas outside of traditional corporate structures. Head of e-business and business transformation Pranav Seth believes this approach will help drive corporate innovation and empower employees to tackle industry problems.

site_title: Bankers fleeing Brexit may find Luxembourg an acquired taste
summary: Luxembourg is attracting bankers fleeing the UK post-Brexit, with firms like JPMorgan Chase & Co, American International Group Inc, and private equity firm Blackstone opening operations in the Grand Duchy. However, the country's lack of a subway and inadequate public transportation system is causing traffic congestion. Despite the drawbacks, many expats, including celebrity artists and financial professionals, are drawn to Luxembourg's cultural and social offerings, including its 11 Michelin-starred restaurants and scenic countryside. The country's house-price index grew 5.6% in the second quarter of last year, with prices ranging from €4,613 to €1 million per square meter.

site_title: This is the only game in town for 3 US counties
summary: The Pueblo Mall in Colorado has become a social hub for the city and surrounding areas, outlasting the decline of traditional retail. Despite the rise of online shopping, the mall has tailored itself to consumers, offering services like barber shops, gyms, and local stores. Its average sales per square foot are healthy, and traffic has increased 3-5% in the past year. The mall's popularity is attributed to its community events, small-town demographics, and proximity to other shopping centers. Its median household income is lower than the state's, making it a safe and accessible destination for residents.

site_title: Trump urges Muslim leaders to confront extremism
summary: US President Donald Trump urged Muslim leaders to confront extremism in a speech to dozens of leaders of Muslim countries in Saudi Arabia, calling it a "battle between good and evil." Iranian Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif criticized the US-Saudi trade deals, while the Council on American Islamic Relations called for concrete actions to reset relations with the Muslim world.

site_title: The logic behind put warrants
summary: Structured puts are options on underlying assets issued by financial institutions, offering the right to sell the asset at a fixed price. They gain value in a falling market, making them less intuitive than calls. The exercise price forms an anchor, locking in a sale price, and if the underlying asset is below the strike price at expiry, the holder can buy it from the market and sell it to the issuer, pocketing a profit. The put generally moves in the opposite direction of the underlying asset, as seen in the example of the Hang Seng Index warrant.

site_title: North Korea fires another test missile
summary: North Korea conducted another ballistic missile test on Sunday, firing a projectile from Pukchang, northeast of Pyongyang, which flew approximately 500 kilometers. The US is aware of the launch, believing the missile has a shorter range than the three tested recently. The missile landed in the Sea of Japan, missing Japan's exclusive economic zone. This latest test ratchets up tensions in the region, with Kim Jong Un persisting with his nuclear program.

site_title: UK threatens to quit Brexit talks

site_title: ISDN gears up for growth in automation era

site_title: High-renters in NYC - they've money to buy, but they ask 'why?'
summary: High-end renters in NYC, like Timothy Brown, 41, who has rented in seven apartments over 16 years, are hesitant to buy, despite having the means to do so. site_title: TPP: 11 nations agree on preparation deadline
summary: Key TPP nations agree on a November deadline to complete preparatory work for the free trade pact, despite the US's withdrawal. site_title: Institutions are net buyers of STI stocks

site_title: Lombard Odier to partner Asean banks for steady growth
summary: Swiss private bank Lombard Odier plans to grow its earnings by at least 10% in Asia this year through partnerships with local banks in Singapore, the Philippines, Indonesia, Malaysia, and Vietnam. site_title: Rooting for urban produce

summary: Google is launching a push to catch up with Amazon in the digital assistant market, leveraging its expertise in artificial intelligence and voice recognition. site_title: How tales of 'flippers' led to a housing bubble and economic flop

This mentality contributed to the rapid price increases and subsequent collapse of the housing market. The prevalence of these narratives highlights the importance of considering sociological factors in understanding economic phenomena.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler to modify 100,000 vehicles after possible emissions cheating

summary: The White House staff is increasingly demoralized and overwhelmed as the administration's domestic woes continue. summary: South Korea's President Moon Jae-in has vowed to reform the country's family-run conglomerates, known as chaebol, which dominate the economy. Research shows that 63% of multinational corporations and 47% of small and medium-sized enterprises are considering giving to the arts.

images.alt_text: Vivien Ang

site_title: EPA under Pruitt is boon to US oil and gas industry
summary: The Trump administration's regulatory reversal under EPA head Scott Pruitt has benefited the US oil and gas industry, particularly Devon Energy. The company, which had been prepared to install an emissions-control system and pay a six-figure penalty, has now re-evaluated its settlement posture and is willing to pay a significantly lower amount. This move is seen as a template for the future, with other independent energy companies following suit. Environmental groups and Democrats are outraged by the rollbacks, which include postponing a rule requiring companies to collect data on methane gas emissions and repealing a rule requiring companies to prevent groundwater contamination caused by fracking.

site_title: China's Q2 GDP growth seen at around 6.8%: official think tank
summary: China's economy is expected to grow around 6.8% in Q2 2017, according to the State Information Center. Consumer inflation is forecast at 1.4% and producer price inflation at 6.5%. The economy is expected to remain stable but with a slightly slowing trend. China's economy grew 6.9% in Q1, supported by government infrastructure spending and a housing market that has shown signs of overheating. Policymakers face pressure to address worsening labor and debt conditions, which may inhibit steady growth.

site_title: Smells like Brown Spirit
summary: Proof & Company is hosting Whiskey Weekend Singapore, a two-day event featuring American whiskey brands, cocktail bars, and food prepared by American chefs. The event, taking place on May 20-21, will include whiskey tastings, master classes, and a selection of spirits, cocktail books, and bar tools for sale. It will be held at The Great Escape, 6001 Beach Road, #05-00, from 3pm till late.

site_title: Travel green, reduce carbon footprints
summary: Travelers are increasingly adopting eco-friendly practices, with nearly two-thirds planning to make more environmentally sound choices in the next year, according to a TripAdvisor survey. Experts recommend choosing destinations with robust green policies, such as Namibia and Ecuador, and opting for green transportation like trains, buses, and cycling. Cruises, however, are still a major environmental concern, with only Disney earning an A-minus grade. To minimize carbon footprint, travelers can book direct flights, offset emissions, and choose hotels with in-house green programs. Even small changes, like using refillable water bottles and recycling, can have a long-term impact on the environment.

site_title: Assange claims victory after Sweden drops rape probe
summary: WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange celebrated after Sweden dropped a seven-year rape allegation against him. Assange, who has been holed up in Ecuador's London embassy since 2012, claimed victory but said the "proper war" over his future was just beginning. The decision does not guarantee his release, as British police could arrest him for breaching bail conditions and US authorities consider him a "hostile intelligence service". Assange's future remains uncertain, with Ecuador urging Britain to let him leave and his lawyers planning a dialogue with British authorities.

site_title: Once-drab Indonesian slum rejuvenated into "Rainbow Village"
summary: A slum area on Indonesia's Java Island, Semarang, has been transformed into "Rainbow Village" after a month-long facelift costing US$22,500. The local government painted homes vibrant colors to boost the area's economy and community spirit. Residents report improved livelihoods through tourism and souvenir sales. The project, led by high-school teacher Slamet Widodo, aims to foster a sense of belonging among the community and promote economic empowerment. The colorful makeover has become a tourist attraction and social media hit, bringing benefits to the previously neglected area.

site_title: US carmakers downshift on Trump economic plan
summary: US carmakers, including Ford and General Motors, have shifted production and idled workers due to declining sales, contrary to President Donald Trump's claims that the auto sector is a success. Sales dropped 4.7% in April, with analysts forecasting a decline in US sales for the first time since the financial crisis. Despite adding jobs in the US, companies have also cut production, idling 3,000 workers at GM plants and 1,400 salaried jobs at Ford. Experts attribute the decline to muted demand and rising interest rates, warning that the sector's recovery is tenuous.

site_title: Five killed in Indonesia boat fire
summary: At least five people were killed in a boat fire off Indonesia's Java island, with 141 rescued and five bodies recovered. The fire is believed to have been caused by a short circuit in one of the trucks on board. This incident is the latest in a series of boat accidents in Indonesia, where water transport is a common mode of transportation due to the country's vast network of islands.

site_title: SoftBank, Saudi Arabia announce 1st round of capital commitments for record tech investment fund
summary: SoftBank and Saudi Arabia have secured over $93 billion in funding commitments for the largest-ever technology investment fund, known as the SoftBank Vision Fund. The fund aims to accelerate financing of cutting-edge technologies and startups, with a target of reaching $100 billion by the end of the year. Backers include major investors such as Apple, Qualcomm, and Foxconn, and will be used to pursue investments in areas like artificial intelligence and the Internet of Things. The fund is expected to help SoftBank founder Masayoshi Son cut even more ambitious deals, with the goal of building and growing businesses that will shape the next stage of the Information Revolution.

site_title: Tide of digitisation to shake up maritime sector
summary: The maritime sector is expected to be slow to adopt digitization, with many companies apprehensive about the changes. However, initiatives by Maersk Line and IBM aim to advance digital and autonomous applications in the sector. Maersk's blockchain collaboration with IBM is seen as a step towards facilitating cross-border trade and digitizing the supply chain. The company's first-mover advantage is expected to lead the pack in embracing e-commerce and digitization, but challenges remain, including the relevance of middle-men and the need for a standard format for electronic bills of lading.

site_title: US immigrant inventor not losing sleep over his travel pillow idea
summary: Ephi Zlotnitsky, a 50-year-old US immigrant from Israel, has invented an airplane pillow called JetComfy, which aims to bring peaceful sleep to airline travelers. The pillow, designed with a compact size and unique shape, has sold over 10,000 units since its launch in January. Zlotnitsky, a former paratrooper and entrepreneur, partnered with a battery engineer to develop the product after a bad flight experience on a diving trip. He plans to expand the business to 25 locations in a year, with sales projected to reach over 350,000 units in the US by mid-2018.

site_title: Cult series 'Twin Peaks' makes long-awaited return
summary: The cult TV series "Twin Peaks" returns with its third season after nearly three decades, premiering on Showtime on Sunday. The 18-episode season, directed by David Lynch, marks the show's revival nearly a quarter-century after its second season concluded. Although details are scarce, the show's original cast, including Kyle MacLachlan as FBI agent Dale Cooper, has largely returned. "Twin Peaks" is widely regarded as a TV masterpiece, defying genre labels and influencing the development of cinematic television.

site_title: Global stocks rally at end of volatile week
summary: Global stock markets rebounded at the end of a volatile week, with US and European stocks finishing higher. The rally was driven by investors seeking to take advantage of depressed prices and a relatively calm news flow. Higher oil prices and a pair of stories involving President Trump, including an FBI investigation and allegations of sensitive intelligence sharing, contributed to the gains. The S&P 500 finished up 0.7% and other major indices also rose, with the dollar falling against the euro and other currencies.

site_title: The Force is still strong as Star Wars turns 40
summary: Star Wars celebrates its 40th anniversary, having grown into the most lucrative and influential movie franchise of all time. The original 1977 film, released with an indie budget of $11 million, grossed $221.3 million domestically and has since become a cultural phenomenon. The franchise has continued to expand, with recent releases such as The Force Awakens and The Last Jedi, and is expected to continue adding billions to its total box office past $7.5 billion. The franchise's influence extends beyond film, with merchandise, books, and video games contributing to its massive success.

site_title: SoftBank-Saudi high-tech vision fund raises US$93bn
summary: SoftBank has raised nearly US$93 billion in pledges for its global high-tech fund, the SoftBank Vision Fund, with participation from industry giants and tech companies like Apple and Qualcomm. The fund aims to invest in long-term, high-tech ventures, targeting a total of $100 billion in committed capital. SoftBank's founder, Masayoshi Son, declared his focus on the "Internet of Things," artificial intelligence, and robotics, with plans to invest US$50 billion in the US.

site_title: AusGroup proposes debt-to-equity conversion on existing notes, shareholder loan
summary: AusGroup, an oilfield services firm, proposes a debt-to-equity conversion for its $110 million notes due 2018 and a shareholder loan from Ezion Holdings. Noteholders will exchange existing notes for new shares, with a proposed issue price of S$0.058 per share, representing a 6.62% premium. The company aims to hold an extraordinary general meeting to seek shareholder approval. Several major shareholders, including Ezion, have pledged to vote in favor of the proposals.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Ex-IBM employee from China pleads guilty to code theft charges
summary: A former IBM software engineer, Jiaqiang Xu, 31, from China, pleaded guilty to stealing proprietary source code from the company. Xu, who worked at IBM in China from 2010 to 2014, stole code related to a clustered file system, which facilitates faster computer performance. He used the code to make software to sell to customers. Xu was arrested in 2015 and is scheduled to be sentenced on October 13. He faces economic espionage and theft of a trade secret charges.

site_title: Pentagon plans to 'annihilate' IS fighters
summary: US President Donald Trump has instructed the Pentagon to "annihilate" the Islamic State group in Syria to prevent escaped foreign fighters from returning home. Defence Secretary Jim Mattis stated the new "annihilation campaign" aims to surround and kill IS fighters in their strongholds, rather than shoving them out of cities. The move reflects an increased urgency to stop battle-hardened jihadists from bringing their expertise and ideology back to European capitals. The US-led coalition has already lost 55% of IS-held territory in Iraq and Syria, with over four million people liberated.

site_title: Oil at one-month high, supply-cut extension expected
summary: Oil prices rose on Friday, closing out a second week of gains, as investors expect OPEC and other producers to agree to extend output cuts. Brent crude rose 2.1% to $53.61, while US crude rose 5.2% to $50.33. The OPEC-led group is set to meet on May 25 to extend output cuts of 1.8 million barrels a day until March 2018, aiming to reduce a global crude glut.

images.alt_text: Oil prices rose on Friday, closing out a second week of gains on growing expectations that Opec and other producing countries will agree next week to extend output cuts.

site_title: Uber extends on-demand service to trucking
summary: Uber has launched Uber Freight, a service allowing truckers to book cargo hauls with simple smartphone taps. The app matches truckers or companies with loads and streamlines payments. Uber Freight vetted truckers before signing them up. The company has also been developing self-driving technology for trucks, but has faced a lawsuit from Alphabet's Waymo alleging stolen technology. A partial injunction ordered Uber to prevent Waymo's stolen data from being used and return all copies by the end of the month. Uber Freight aims to simplify the process of finding and booking freight for truckers.

images.alt_text: Uber is expanding into a new field with a version of its on-demand ride application that lets truckers book cargo hauls with simple taps on smartphones.

site_title: Chinese navy ships visit Myanmar for joint exercises
summary: Chinese navy ships arrived in Yangon, Myanmar on Thursday for a four-day visit, conducting joint exercises with the Myanmar navy. The visit aims to strengthen strategic communication, deepen cooperation, and promote regional peace and stability. China's defense ministry stated that the joint exercises will cover communications, search and rescue, and other areas. The visit is seen as a demonstration of China's growing presence in the Asia-Pacific region and its efforts to expand its influence in the region.

site_title: Two new coffee shops tap technology, automation for greater productivity
summary: Two new coffee shops, "Happy Hawkers" and "FoodTastic", have opened in Singapore, leveraging technology and automation to boost productivity in the tight labor market. Happy Hawkers features cashless payments, digital ordering, and a tray return robot, while FoodTastic has automated floor cleaning, dish sorting, and washing equipment. The coffee shops are jointly facilitated by Spring Singapore and the Housing and Development Board, aligning with the Food Services Industry Transformation Map. A tender for three more coffee shops will be launched in the third quarter of this year.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Beijing denies 'unprofessional' intercept of US plane
summary: China has denied allegations that two Chinese fighter jets acted unprofessionally in intercepting a US reconnaissance plane on May 17, calling the action "professional" and "safe". The US Air Force described the intercept as unprofessional, but China's Ministry of Defence stated that its aircraft were acting in accordance with the law. The incident occurred in international airspace, and China urged the US to halt its frequent reconnaissance operations to prevent future incidents. A diplomatic dialogue between China and the US is set to take place.

images.alt_text: China has denied US allegations that two Chinese fighter jets acted unprofessionally in intercepting an American military plane earlier this week, saying that its aircraft were acting in accordance with the law".

site_title: Singapore supports joint efforts to push ahead with TPP
summary: Singapore supports the 11 remaining nations in moving forward with the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade deal without the US. Minister of Trade and Industry Lim Hng Kiang stated that Singapore will participate constructively in the collective process to harvest the TPP's benefits, emphasizing the importance of maintaining momentum. The 11 nations agreed to "assess options to bring the agreement into force expeditiously" during the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation meeting in Hanoi.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Federal Reserve says 30% of US adults face financial strain
summary: The Federal Reserve reports that nearly 30% of US adults face financial difficulties, with 73 million adults describing their personal financial situation as difficult. The hardship rates are higher in black and Hispanic populations compared to whites. Despite a slight improvement in overall well-being, 44% of respondents could not cover a $400 emergency expense in 2017, down from 50% in 2013. Soaring healthcare costs and higher education debt also pose significant financial challenges for many Americans.

site_title: Greece's bailout review stalls as creditors debate debt relief
summary: Greece's bailout review is stalled as creditors debate debt relief, with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) reluctant to participate unless euro-area countries take further steps to ensure Greece's debt becomes sustainable. Key creditors, including Germany, are resisting changes to Greece's debt profile, which has led to disagreements over the amount of debt relief needed. A deal is seen as within reach, with European officials pointing to a 50-50 chance of an agreement, but the IMF's demands for specified debt relief measures must be met before a new set of rescue loans can be released.

site_title: TPP members aim to revive deal after US pullout: source
summary: Asia-Pacific nations are attempting to revive the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) after the US withdrawal in January, with trade ministers from 11 remaining countries set to meet in Hanoi on Sunday to discuss the deal's future. New Zealand and Japan, the only two countries to formally ratify the deal, have championed its revival. The US door remains open for future return, and the aim is to reach a final agreement by November for an Apec summit where US President Donald Trump is scheduled to attend.

site_title: Europe: Shares claw back gains after worst week in 6 months
summary: European shares rose 0.6% on Friday, ending their worst week in six months, amid concerns over US President Donald Trump's stimulus plans and Brexit. Financials led the recovery, with heavyweight banks BNP Paribas and UniCredit gaining 2%. Spain's Banco Popular jumped 10% after potential acquisition by Santander or Bankia, while airport retailer Dufry rose 5% after Richemont acquired a 5% stake. The STOXX 600 index is now 19.4% higher for the year, despite disappointing first-quarter earnings growth.

site_title: North Korea says linking cyber attacks to Pyongyang is 'ridiculous'
summary: North Korea's deputy UN envoy, Kim In Ryong, stated that linking the WannaCry cyber attack to Pyongyang is "ridiculous." The attack, which infected over 300,000 computers in 150 nations, threatened to lock out victims unless a ransom was paid within a week. Symantec and Kaspersky Lab found similar code in programs used by the Lazarus Group, a North Korea-run hacking operation. A UN expert monitoring sanctions violations was also hacked, but no further details were available.

site_title: US-Saudi ties shift as Riyadh turns to Trump for investments
summary: Saudi Arabia is shifting its focus towards the US as a rival energy exporter, seeking foreign direct investment to transform its economy. The country's sovereign wealth fund is expected to meet with US corporate executives, including Jamie Dimon and James Gorman, to discuss deals worth billions of dollars. The visit comes as Saudi King Salman seeks backing for his economic reform plan, which aims to reduce the role of the state and wean the economy off oil. The US is emerging as a rival energy exporter, with domestic oil production up dramatically, and the kingdom's leverage is shifting towards the Americans.

site_title: Gold set for biggest weekly gain since mid-April
summary: Gold prices surged 0.3% to $1,249.76 per ounce, poised for its biggest weekly gain since mid-April, amid US dollar easing and Asian stocks weakening due to ongoing US political turbulence. Spot gold had risen 1.8% for the week, driven by safe-haven buying and concerns over geopolitical risks. Investors will monitor the Senate testimony by former FBI director James Comey, which may impact gold prices.

site_title: Mortgage rates retreat amid political turmoil in Washington
summary: Mortgage rates in the US have retreated to 4.02% after turmoil in Washington, with the 30-year fixed-rate average falling for the second time in three weeks. The 15-year fixed-rate average dropped to 3.27% and the five-year adjustable rate average slipped to 3.13%. The decline is attributed to investors pulling back from stocks and moving into bonds, causing a decrease in Treasury yields. Analysts predict that mortgage rates will continue to fall in the coming week, with over half of surveyed analysts expecting a decrease.

site_title: STI down 1.2% for week despite US political turmoil
summary: The Straits Times Index fell 1.2% for the week, despite US political turmoil, with the US stock market's concerns over President Donald Trump's handling of the James Comey investigation. Singapore Airlines reported a significant loss, with its stock crashing 7.2% on Friday. Noble Group's shares also plummeted 8.1% on Friday. Despite the market volatility, analysts DBS' Lim Say Boon and Jason Low expect a relatively stable market, citing the lack of new drivers for equities and high expectations.

site_title: Trump's 'huuuuuge' Caribbean estate on the market for US$28m
summary: US President Donald Trump's Caribbean estate, Le Chateau des Palmiers, is listed for sale at $28 million, significantly higher than its estimated value. The property, owned by Trump since 2013, features two villas, a tennis court, and an expansive pool overlooking Plum Bay. Experts say the price is overpriced by about $10 million, and the sale could raise ethical concerns about potential conflicts of interest. Trump's financial disclosures show he earned $200,000 to $2 million in rental fees from 2014 to 2016, but he has not commented on the sale.

site_title: Military jets escort Hawaii flight after fracas involving Turkish man
summary: US military jets escorted an American Airlines flight into Honolulu International Airport after a disturbance involving a Turkish passenger, Anil Uskanil, 25, who allegedly tried to force his way into the cockpit. Uskanil was previously detained at Los Angeles International Airport for allegedly being drunk, but was released with a citation. The incident prompted the military to dispatch two F-22 fighter jets to intercept the plane, which landed safely. No injuries were reported, and authorities are preparing a criminal complaint against Uskanil for interference with a flight crew.

site_title: Buy Local
summary: The Social Kitchen's Open Farm Community is hosting its ninth edition of the Social Market on May 20-21, featuring local businesses selling products such as honey, fish, cheese, and candles. The market will also offer workshops on urban farming and candle-making. The event will take place at 130E Minden Road from 11am to 5pm, with more information available by calling 6471 0306.

site_title: Malaysia's economy grows 5.6% in Q1 on strong domestic demand
summary: Malaysia's economy grew 5.6% in Q1, surpassing expectations, driven by strong domestic demand and exports. This is the strongest quarterly performance in two years, led by robust private sector spending, improved supply side, and higher growth in electronics and electricals. However, the economy is expected to taper in the coming quarters.

site_title: Koh Brothers forays into S Korea with maiden property buy
summary: Koh Brothers, a Singapore-based construction and property development firm, has entered the Korean real estate market with its first property acquisition in Gangnam, Seoul. The firm, in a joint venture with Daeryun D & I Co, has acquired a freehold site for S$119 million to build a 380-unit residential complex and 2,700 sq m of retail space. The project, expected to start in 2018 and complete in 2020, aims to address the demand gap for compact, upscale apartments in Seoul's central business district.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: MM2 Asia Ltd is in discussions to buy Village Cinemas Australia's entire stake in Golden Village Cinema's holding company. Victor Tan was appointed acting CEO of First Reit after Ronnie Tan's retirement. YuuZoo Corp reported a net profit of S$16.3 million for 2016, down from S$34.6 million in February, and revised its 2015 bottom line to a net loss. Meanwhile, Tan Teck Long is set to become OCBC's CEO, replacing Helen Wong.

site_title: Investors cheer Asia's best bourse one year into Tsai rule
summary: Taiwan's benchmark stock index has surged 32% in US dollar terms since President Tsai Ing-wen's inauguration, making it the best performance among Asian peers. Foreign funds have invested a net $16.5 billion in Taiwan equities, boosting the currency to a 8.4% gain since Tsai's inauguration. Despite concerns over trade with China and a strengthening currency, market watchers project the stock index may climb to 10,800 or higher this year due to valuations and dividend yields.

site_title: Surprise Q4 loss sends SIA shares diving 7.25%
summary: Singapore Airlines reported its first fourth-quarter loss in three years, with a net loss of S$138.3 million, due to a sharp drop in operating profit and a S$132 million provision for SIA Cargo. The airline group cut its target prices, with analysts citing deteriorating yields and cost pressures. SIA Cargo is being re-integrated into the group, with the goal of boosting efficiency through greater synergies. The airline will undergo a wide-ranging review of its business to position itself for long-term growth, with no job cuts but some jobs potentially being redesigned.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: GLP posts 61.7% jump in Q4 profit on higher asset values
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) reported a 61.7% jump in net profit for the fourth quarter ended March 31, 2017, to US$247 million, driven by higher asset values in Japan, US, and Brazil. However, core earnings dropped 5% due to a pared-down stake in a US portfolio. Full-year earnings reached a record US$794 million, with core earnings up 12% on rent growth and lease-up. GLP plans to start US$2.2 billion of new developments in 2018 and complete US$1.7 billion of projects, driven by higher completions in Japan.

site_title: China's Future Land warns of property developer price cuts as cooling steps bite
summary: China's property developer Future Land warns of potential price cuts in the market as sales slow and credit conditions tighten, amid government efforts to cool the property market. The company's vice president, Ouyang Jie, predicts a domino effect that could reverse market expectations and trigger a sharp drop in sales. He suggests that a state-imposed price floor could be necessary to counter the risk of sustained downward price momentum, citing concerns about smaller developers' liquidity and the potential for capital chain ruptures.

site_title: Millennials expect to retire by the age of 60: HSBC study on retirement
summary: HSBC's Singapore report, "Shifting Sands," found that millennials (born 1980-1997) expect to retire by 60, earlier than previous generations. Despite acknowledging their long life expectancy, millennials have the worst retirement prospects, entering the workforce during subdued economic conditions. 64% believe their generation will live longer and need to support themselves, while 44% agree they're paying for older generations' economic consequences. A "reality gap" exists between millennials' retirement expectations and reality, with 66% considering saving for retirement a difficult task.

site_title: High iodine prices leave Cambodia without iodised salt
summary: Cambodia's iodised salt production has declined due to high iodine prices following the 2011 Japan earthquake and tsunami, which tripled global iodine prices. The country's use of iodised salt dropped from 70% to 13% of households between 2011 and 2015, threatening the development of children's brains. Experts warn that the IQ of entire nations can be raised 10 points for just a nickel per child per year, and that the situation "may be put in jeopardy" unless action is taken to enforce laws and improve testing.

site_title: Khai Hori
summary: Khai Hori, curator of Chan + Hori Contemporary, has expressed concerns about the state of Singapore's visual arts scene, citing a need for more original and engaging curating. He believes the scene's stability relies on competent leadership and innovative projects. Hori credits his experience at Palais de Tokyo with instilling trust and ownership in leadership and curatorial teams. He has expanded Chan + Hori's programming to include more radical art forms and is focused on developing meaningful projects with artists. Hori advocates for a more generous approach to artistic experimentation and patronage, rather than solely relying on infrastructure and acquisition of artworks.

images.alt_text: Khai Hori, curatorial director of Chan + Hori Contemporary.

site_title: Divestment gain helps IHH double Q1 net profit
summary: IHH Healthcare Berhad's net profit for the first quarter of 2017 doubled to RM470 million, driven by a RM313.4 million gain from divestment of a stake in Apollo Hospitals. Excluding exceptional items, net profit fell 15% to RM201.8 million, mainly due to depreciation and finance costs for new hospitals. Revenue rose 8% to RM2.7 billion, led by growth in inpatient admissions and revenue intensity. The group remains in a strong financial position with a cash balance of RM2.8 billion and improved net gearing.

images.alt_text: Dr Tan said the group continued to grow across all home markets amid "persistently challenging market conditions".

site_title: World's best casino stock on a roll, buoyed by Manila's warming ties with Beijing
summary: Melco Crown Philippines, a casino stock subsidiary of Melco Resorts & Entertainment, has seen a 117% rise in shares this year, driven by warming ties between Manila and Beijing. China's tourism to the Philippines has surged 25% in the first two months of 2017, and the country's gaming revenue rose 20% in the first nine months of 2016. The company's link to Macau, where it owns four casinos, has been a factor in its success, and investors are optimistic about its prospects. Melco Crown Philippines is expected to become the biggest casino operator in the industry.

site_title: Branching Three
summary: Several F&B players in Singapore are opening new eateries with unique concepts. Tono Cevicheria, a Peruvian-style cevicheria, is set to open in June 2017, offering four to five types of ceviche and other Peruvian classics. Meanwhile, Summerlong, the third outlet of The Dandy Partnership, is opening at 60 Robertson Quay with a Mediterranean-inspired menu featuring Persian fried chicken and chargrilled octopus. Steamroom with The Pillar and Stones is a new 5,000 sq ft multi-concept space at Orchard Central, offering a mix of food, coffee, shopping, and art.

site_title: Something to Brae About
summary: Chef Dan Hunter's restaurant Brae, located in Birregurra, Victoria, has been rated one of the world's best, ranking 44th on the World's Best 50 list. The restaurant, which also serves as a boutique property with six luxury villas, is a culmination of Hunter's culinary career and his vision of a self-sustaining farm-to-table experience. Brae is one of only two Australian restaurants on the list, alongside Attica. Hunter's dedication to using local and organic produce has earned him pride and recognition, despite the added pressure of recent accolades.

site_title: More With Four
summary: Lexus has introduced the RC Turbo Sport, a four-seat coupe with a 2.0-litre turbocharged four-cylinder engine, replacing the V6 variant. The new model boasts a more enthusiastic power plant, well-weighted steering, and nimble handling, despite having lower maximum power and torque. The RC Turbo Sport accelerates from 0-100 km/h in 7.5 seconds, only half a second slower than the RC350. The revised model comes with a lower price tag, starting at S$247,000, and features a simpler LED cluster, smaller wheels, and a rotary knob instead of a touchpad for the infotainment system.

site_title: Girl Power
summary: YouTube sensation Lilly Singh is touring her show "How To Be A Bawse" in Singapore on May 24 at the Kallang Theatre, offering entrepreneurial advice and relationship tips. The 28-year-old author of the best-selling motivational book is known for her inspiring message for young girls. Tickets for the show, priced from S$93 to S$244, are available from Sistic.

site_title: Sound giants
summary: Exposure's 3010S2D integrated amplifier, priced at S$3,200, delivers superb sonic quality without frills. The fourth-generation amplifier features six line-level inputs and a pre-amp output, with optional upgrades for vinyl and digital playback. Reviewers praise its powerful and crisp sound, with the US's The Absolute Sound describing it as a "superb combination of poise and dynamically authoritative overall energy". Meanwhile, Mike Oldfield's album "Return to Ommadawn" is released, a faithful remake of his 1975 album, with a focus on acoustic instruments and Oldfield's signature style.

site_title: Just Right For Flight
summary: Australian model and actress Jessica Gomes has launched a skincare range, Equal Beauty, tailored for in-flight convenience. The range, featuring Australian ingredients and Korean-Japanese technology, includes five products that are free of chemicals, paraben, alcohol, and fragrance. Gomes spent three years researching the products, prioritizing hydration and protection. The brand emphasizes equality and inner beauty, and is now available at www.equalbeauty.com, with plans for a Singapore launch later this year.

site_title: Higher petroleum, chemical prices lift Q1 domestic wholesale trade
summary: Higher prices of petroleum and chemical products in Q1 2017 lifted Singapore's domestic wholesale trade by 23.5% compared to the previous year. Excluding petroleum, domestic wholesale trade rose 7.6%. Foreign wholesale trade grew 27.3% year-over-year, with petroleum and chemical products driving growth due to higher prices. Adjusted for price changes, domestic wholesale trade fell 5% and foreign wholesale trade dipped 2.2%.

site_title: Swedish town rejects proposal to grant sex leave to workers
summary: A Swedish town's council rejected a proposal to grant one-hour "sex leave" to workers, citing concerns that if sexual intercourse was subsidized, other personal activities should also be approved. The proposal aimed to boost the town's sagging birthrate, but critics argued it was too intrusive and stigmatizing. The council's decision was seen as a victory for work-life balance and individual freedom, with some acknowledging that the debate had opened up discussions about sex and relationships in the community.

site_title: Open House
summary: A unique home in Telok Kurau estate, owned by Calvin Soh, is open to the public with "doors always open" as part of his "21st century kampung" concept to revive community spirit. The house, which has been in Soh's family since 1969, is not a typical private residence but a public space designed for communal interaction. Soh's goal is to recreate a sense of community in an era of modernization.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Arts and Craft
summary: The Esplanade Annexe officially opens this weekend with an Open House event, featuring workshops, music, and spoken word performances. The event includes coffee appreciation, floral jamming, and aromatherapy workshops, as well as a food trail highlighting dining outlets at Esplanade Mall. Local artists and vendors will also be present, offering knick-knacks and handmade crafts. The festivities run from May 20-21.

site_title: New Asia equities fund with no annual management fee
summary: Former financial journalist Teh Hooi Ling has launched the Inclusif Value Fund (IVF), a new Asia-Pacific equities fund with no annual management fee. Accredited investors can subscribe with a minimum of S$160,000. The fund aims to generate 10-12% returns per year and invests in deep value stocks trading at a 40% discount to net tangible assets. Early investors will receive a 20% discount on performance fees. IVF targets long-term investors and follows three key investment principles: the value approach, clear sell discipline, and valuations.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: SATS Q4 net profit up 31.4% to S$66.6m
summary: SATS, a Singapore-based food solutions and gateway services provider, reported a 31.4% increase in its Q4 net profit to S$66.6 million. The company plans to expand into new locations in the coming year. Shareholders responded positively, pushing its share price up 0.95% to S$5.29.

site_title: When the tech gets tough, go back to basics
summary: The article emphasizes the importance of traditional skills such as human interaction, empathy, and soft skills in the workplace, despite the increasing use of technology. Experts argue that while technology can handle IQ tasks, EQ (emotional intelligence) and social skills are crucial for building trust and success. The article highlights the need for a balanced approach, combining technology with fundamental human skills, to navigate the changing work landscape. It concludes that individuals should focus on learning new skills for personal growth, rather than just keeping up with the latest IT trends.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore Airlines reported a surprise loss of S$138 million in Q4 FY17, despite a 7.5% year-on-year decline in yields. The airline's load factor increased, but at the expense of yields. Global Logistic Properties (GLP) reported a 62% year-on-year increase in Q4 FY17 profit to US$247.1 million, driven by higher asset values. GLP's management is in discussions with shortlisted parties regarding a strategic review, but no assurance is given that a transaction will materialize.

site_title: China exchange traded funds get a boost from One Belt, One Road initiative
summary: China's One Belt, One Road (OBOR) initiative has sparked a surge in Chinese exchange-traded funds (ETFs) on the Singapore Exchange (SGX), with four China ETFs generating total returns of 0.5% month-to-date and 4.4% year-to-date. The initiative, launched in 2013, aims to expand trade links with Asia, Europe, Africa, and beyond, and has attracted a net inflow of $18.9 billion in equity investments. Global mining companies have also benefited from the announcement, with some metals producers experiencing significant gains.

site_title: HSBC celebrates corporate sustainability by raising S$242,000
summary: HSBC Singapore celebrated its 2017 Corporate Sustainability Night with a Scale the Heights for Charity event, raising S$242,000 for The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund and The Business Times Budding Artists Fund. Minister Tan Chuan-Jin, HSBC CEO Tony Cripps, and charity representatives led the fundraising challenge, where teams scaled a wall and collected flags to raise funds. The event was a success, with all funds to be split between the two charities.

site_title: Strong As Steel
summary: The Indian festival of Thaipusam has a long history in Singapore, dating back generations. It celebrates the full moon in the Tamil calendar's 10th month, usually between Jan 14 and Feb 14. Devotees prepare by fasting and praying, then carry decorated kavadis, some with sharp skewers pierced through their tongues, cheeks, or bodies to ask for forgiveness or offer thanks to Lord Subramaniam. The festival's origins are rooted in the word "thai," meaning 10th, and "pusam," meaning "when the moon is at its brightest."

site_title: Pay and embolden ransomware criminals or lose precious data?
summary: A global ransomware attack has affected over 200,000 computers, demanding a $600 ransom per machine by a deadline. Victims face the risk of losing their digital information, including personal photos and hospital records, if they don't pay. Experts warn against paying the ransom, citing the uncertainty of whether the attackers will return control of computers and the potential for further attacks. Only a small fraction of affected individuals have paid the ransom, with some organizations, like the UK's National Health Service, forbidden by law from paying.

site_title: My favourite album
summary: Joni Mitchell's album "Blue" is widely regarded as a masterpiece of singer-songwriting, capturing the complexities of love through songs like "All I Want" and "A Case Of You". The album's themes of love, loss, and disillusionment are said to resonate deeply with listeners. Reviewer Ryan Khor praises Mitchell's ability to "explicate the beauty, mystery and disappointment of love" in her music.

site_title: Milan Elan
summary: The recent Milan Furniture Fair featured innovative designs from top brands. Notable pieces include the 'Lantern Light' floor lamp by neri&hu, the 'Reaction Poetique' tables by Jaime Hayon, and the 'Lune' sofa by W. Atelier. Other standout designs include the 'La Isla' loveseat by Note, the 'Tadaima' console by Space, and the 'Klip' desk by Karim Rashid for Riva 1920. These designs showcase a mix of clean aesthetics, elegance, and functionality, appealing to both home and office spaces.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: The importance of portfolio rebalancing
summary: Investor Ivan, aiming to retire in 20 years, benefits from regular portfolio rebalancing through Avallis Portfolio Asset Management (PAM) strategy. By reviewing and adjusting his portfolio every six months, Ivan maintains a risk level aligned with his original target allocation. PAM's systematic method involves selling underweight assets to buy underperforming ones, resulting in lower volatility and increased returns. As of May 2017, Ivan's total investment value is S$83,325.60, with 2.95% and 5.36% returns for his Asian and Developed Market portfolios, respectively.

site_title: Risky and complex US loan wagers are hot
summary: Asian investors, particularly from Korea, Japan, and China, are increasing their exposure to US collateralized loan obligations (CLOs), driving a doubling of issuance in 2017. These investments have performed well, but some observers worry about the risks, including defaults in the retail and energy sectors. Asian buyers are attracted to the high yields offered by CLOs, which can reach up to 10% for single B-rated tranches. However, experts caution that the products are complex and may pose risks, including refinancing risks and misunderstandings over the values being rated.

site_title: The business of getting fit
summary: Ritual Gym, a boutique fitness studio in Singapore, offers a unique 20-minute high-intensity interval training (HIIT) concept that allows clients to work out in a personalized, 40 sq ft "pod" with various equipment. Founded by CEO Brad Robinson, a former MMA fighter, the gym caters to all fitness levels with four levels of progression. With three locations in Singapore and international franchises in London, Brazil, and Switzerland, Ritual aims to provide exceptional service and personalization to its clients. By focusing on time rather than cost, the gym has attracted a loyal following and plans to expand its operations in Singapore and internationally.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Pro-democracy lawmakers to impeach Hong Kong leader
summary: Hong Kong pro-democracy lawmakers announced they will pursue impeachment of outgoing leader Leung Chun-ying, who intervened in a probe into undeclared payments he received from an Australian company. The payments, totaling HK$50 million, were made in 2011 for a deal involving a company Leung was director and chairman of. The move comes after a document submitted to a legislative committee was found to have been altered by Leung, leading to an impeachment motion expected to be finalized on Monday, with Carrie Lam set to replace Leung on July 1.

site_title: WannaCry hero schools us on education
summary: A 22-year-old from southwest England, known as MalwareTech, became an accidental hero for stopping the WannaCry cyberattack with his $10 and 48 sleepless hours. This incident led the author to reflect on their own education, feeling disillusioned with the system and the emphasis on rote learning. The author believes that the persistent question of "which school you were from" in Singapore is a form of social awkwardness and judgment of underperformance, stifling creativity and freedom. The author suggests that fostering diversity, a genuine hunger for learning, and a generosity towards mistakes is crucial for building resilient leaders in a more uncertain future.

site_title: Judge rules that Prince's six siblings are his heirs
summary: A Minnesota judge ruled that Prince's six siblings, including Tyka Nelson, are his heirs, determining their eligibility to inherit his estimated $300 million fortune. The ruling allows a one-year process for people claiming to be related to Prince to make their appeals, with those not accepted being definitively excluded. The decision provides clarity on control of Prince's unreleased songs and comes after months of claims from individuals, including a woman who claimed a secret wedding to Prince and a musician who alleged a tour bus agreement.

site_title: Dine Now
summary: This article appears to be a collection of unrelated news summaries. However, a single article titled "One Night Only" is available. It discusses a diner serving American classics, including Texan chicken-fried steak and buttermilk fried chicken, with a focus on its hearty and calorie-rich menu. The article does not provide further details.

Aburiya

site_title: Luxe condo deals see higher transactions in 2016
summary: Luxe condo transactions in Singapore increased in 2016, with 36 units sold for S$10 million and above, up from 21 units in 2015 and 24 units in 2014. The growth is attributed to more attractive pricing and the availability of large units in completed projects. However, market watchers do not expect a surge in buyers unless the additional buyer's stamp duty is adjusted. Foreigners and permanent residents are driving the demand, with most buying for owner occupation. The market is expected to remain stable unless changes are made to the ABSD rates.

images.alt_text: The double-volume living area in a five-bedroom duplex garden home in Leedon Residence. The unit is being put up for sale for more than S$11 million.
Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Sexy at 60
summary: The Infiniti Q60 coupe is a luxury sports car praised for its stunning styling, featuring a low and wide design, aggressive front grille, and muscular rear haunches. With its big 19-inch alloy wheels and distinctive fastback-like tail, the Q60 is a visually appealing vehicle. Its sleek profile and premium features make it a contender in the luxury coupe segment dominated by European models.

site_title: Where high-tech meets nature
summary: Microsoft's Hyderabad campus, the company's only Indian facility, stands out for its unique blend of technology and nature. The 22-hectare campus features a 30 million litre reservoir, a nature park with preserved rocks, and recreational facilities such as a cricket field and park. Employees can unwind by the reservoir, take leisurely walks, or engage in sports. The campus design prioritizes bonding, collaboration, and employee well-being, providing a serene and green environment that encourages productivity and happiness. This innovative approach reflects Microsoft's commitment to understanding and adapting to local cultures.

site_title: Branson hints at new US airline venture after spat with Alaska
summary: Billionaire Richard Branson hinted at a potential new US airline venture after a dispute with Alaska Air Group over royalties for his Virgin America brand. Branson stated that Alaska must continue paying royalties unless he starts another airline, saying "watch this space." This comes after Alaska acquired Virgin America in 2017 for $2.6 billion, with plans to retire the brand in 2019. Branson maintains he should be compensated for the brand through 2040.

site_title: My Weekend
summary: Helmi Yusof, Legal Counsel at Zouk, shares her weekend routine, including a visit to Robert Zhao's exhibition at ShanghART, reading Jonah Berger's book "Contagious", and enjoying coffee at Birds Of A Feather cafe. She also appreciates Zouk's classy whisky and cigar lounge, Capital, and values unwinding during the weekend. Yusof believes life is too short not to have a good time and finds inspiration in art and culture to bridge the interests of her parent company with Zouk's vision.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Sweden drops Assange investigation, UK police says he still faces arrest
summary: Sweden has dropped an investigation into WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange over a rape allegation, but British police say he will still be arrested if he leaves the Ecuadorean embassy in London, where he has been in hiding since 2012. Assange, 45, denies the allegation and fears being extradited to the US. The decision comes as Assange has been seeking asylum in the UK to avoid potential extradition to Sweden.

site_title: French researchers find last-ditch cure to unlock WannaCry files
summary: French researchers have found a last-ditch solution to unlock files encrypted by WannaCry ransomware, which has infected over 300,000 computers in 150 nations. The workaround, called Wannakey, can only be used if computers haven't been rebooted since infection and if the fix is applied before WannaCry locks files permanently. The tool was developed by a team of security researchers, including Adrien Guinet, Matthieu Suiche, and Benjamin Delpy, and is available for Windows 7 and older versions.

site_title: First Reit manager appoints Victor Tan as new CEO while Ronnie Tan retires
summary: First Reit's manager, Bowsprit Capital Corporation Limited, appointed Victor Tan as the new CEO, replacing Ronnie Tan, who retired. Tan, who was CEO of Bowsprit since 2006, oversaw First Reit's growth to a market capitalisation of over $1 billion. The succession plan took effect immediately, with Tan serving as acting CEO and executive director of the board.

site_title: Philippines' tough public smoking ban gets broad support
summary: The Philippines' public smoking ban received broad support after President Rodrigo Duterte signed an executive order setting strict guidelines for designated smoking areas. The ban, which was delayed due to corporate resistance, has been hailed by anti-tobacco activists. Industry lobby group, the Philippine Tobacco Institute, also acknowledged the health objectives of the regulation. The move is seen as a victory for anti-smoking efforts, with some smokers expressing readiness to quit the habit.

site_title: Dockworkers' conflict now threatens Swedish economy
summary: A labor conflict between the Swedish Dockworkers' Union and AP Moller-Maersk A/S' APM Terminals in Gothenburg has escalated, threatening Sweden's economy. The port, which handles half of Sweden's container trade, has seen container capacity drop to 80% due to the conflict, with potential further drops to 40% in coming days. Major exporters like SKF AB and Stora Enso Oyj are warning of potential relocation to alternative harbors abroad to safeguard shipments, which could add time and drive up costs. The government is urged to intervene to resolve the conflict, which has severe national consequences.

site_title: China: Stocks end the week higher
summary: China's main stock indexes ended the week higher, with the Shanghai Composite Index flat, as regulatory comments and central bank injections offset concerns over tighter regulations and economic growth. The CSI300 index rose 0.2% to 3,403.85 points, snapping a five-week losing streak. Premier Li Keqiang stated China would balance financial stability, gradual deleveraging, and steady economic growth, while the central bank injected $24.67 billion into the money market to maintain market stability. Despite soothing rhetoric, market sentiment remains fragile, with analysts warning of potential economic slowdown.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end higher
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed higher on Friday with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.11 points to 1,768.280. The market saw 3.27 billion lots valued at RM3.23 billion traded, with gainers outnumbering losers 623 to 302.

site_title: Is this the beginning of the end?
summary: The US is mired in turmoil amid the Trump administration's Russia-related controversies, which have reached "Watergate size and scale." The FBI's investigation into Russian meddling in the 2016 election has led to the appointment of a special counsel, Robert Mueller, who can prosecute anyone suspected of criminal wrongdoing. The scandal has sparked widespread concern, with Trump firing FBI director James Comey, meeting with Russian officials, and allegedly disclosing classified information to the Russians. The investigation's implications go beyond the White House, with Congress and the Justice Department conducting their own Russia investigations.

site_title: Ducati said to attract interest from buyout, motorcycle firms
summary: Volkswagen's Audi division is considering a sale of Ducati, with buyout firms and motorcycle makers such as Permira, CVC Capital Partners, and Hero MotoCorp Ltd showing interest. A formal sale process may start in the next few weeks, with Ducati potentially valued over $1 billion. The company is working with advisers to explore strategic options, but CEO Matthias Mueller may decide to keep the marque, following Volkswagen's efforts to streamline the business after admitting to emissions cheating in 2015. Ducati's elite racing bikes, such as the Panigale R, are used in MotoGP and Superbike events.

site_title: RWE, Engie studying tie-up to create Franco-German energy giant
summary: RWE and Engie are studying a potential share swap that could create a Franco-German energy giant with a market value of 50 billion euros. RWE would swap part or all of its majority stake in renewables and grids firm Innogy for a minority stake in Engie. The deal, if successful, would form the basis of a Franco-German alliance in energy and enhance French-German industrial cooperation. No formal talks are underway, but the two utilities are discussing options with advisers and bankers, pending German elections in September.

site_title: Red Hot Chile Pleasures
summary: Chile, a long, narrow country in southwestern South America, boasts stunning landscapes, rich wine regions, and ancient culture. Despite being often overlooked by tourists, Chile has a reputation for being a resource-rich country with functioning services, including banks, utilities, and transportation networks. With its diverse geography, Chile offers a unique blend of hipster lifestyle and cultural experiences, making it a hidden gem in the region.
