The company will compile high-altitude data from satellites and drones to serve agriculture, insurance, and other sectors.

site_title: Now you can shop at Sainsbury and be fashion forward
summary: Sainsbury's, the UK's supermarket giant, is expanding its fashion offerings to compete with established retailers like Marks & Spencer and Next. The company has created a team of 30 fashion-spotters to identify trends on global runways, resulting in a £1 billion clothing revenue and a 4% growth in sales last year. This move is seen as a threat to the High Street, with Sainsbury's targeting older, more affluent customers with a premium offering and partnering with brands like Russell Athletic.

site_title: Early gains seen for Singapore in EU court ruling on FTA
summary: Singapore is expected to score early gains from a European Union court ruling on its free-trade pact with the bloc, as the EU can now ratify more aspects of the agreement on its own. The ruling, which ends a years-long state of suspension, means that the agreement can now move forward to seek approval from the 28 member states' parliaments. The decision gives the EU more exclusive competence, allowing it to apply certain provisions without approval, potentially shortening the time for the agreement to come into force.

site_title: MAS to create matchmaking opportunities at Fintech Festival
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) plans to create matchmaking opportunities between Singapore-based fintechs and investors at the upcoming Fintech Festival, held from Nov 13 to 17. The festival will feature an Investor Summit, Global Fintech Hackcelerator, Fintech Awards, and a multi-track conference. The MAS also expects greater participation from Asean and other emerging markets. The festival will focus on topics like data analytics, cybersecurity, and regtech, and will showcase investment-worthy startups and disruptive technologies to local and global investors.

site_title: Japan urges Toshiba, Western Digital to get along as chip spat flares
summary: Japan's government urged Toshiba and Western Digital to cooperate amid a dispute over the sale of Toshiba's chip unit, threatening to upend the sale. Toshiba values the unit at at least $18 billion, while Western Digital has submitted a lower offer. The government has considered state-backed funding for a consortium to acquire the unit, but no deal is imminent. Toshiba's shares fell 12% and the cost of insuring against default for its debt spiked 10 basis points higher.

site_title: Boom times for EU's East as GDP growth quickens
summary: The European Union's eastern economies, led by Romania and Poland, experienced a surge in growth in the first quarter of 2017, with GDP growth rates of 5.7% and 4%, respectively. This was driven by increased demand in the euro area and resumed EU development funds. The region's combined economic output is expected to grow at a rate of 3.3% in 2017, with the IMF warning that growth may slow as it reaches capacity constraints.

site_title: Last Vietnamese emperor's Rolex sells for US$5m
summary: The last emperor of Vietnam, Bao Dai, sold his Rolex at auction for US$5 million, becoming the Swiss watchmaker's most expensive wristwatch ever sold. The 1954 Rolex was one of three black-dial models with diamond hour markers and was sold to an unidentified phone bidder after an eight-minute bidding war. This sale marks a victory for Phillips, which dominated the high-end vintage watch market, with its auction total reaching US$32.6 million.

site_title: Intense bidding for GLS sites to continue, analysts expect bigger supply in H2
summary: Intense bidding for Government Land Sales (GLS) sites in Singapore continues, with more bidders and higher price premiums than in previous years. The average number of bidders in the first half of 2017 was 13.3, up from 8.25 in H2 2015. The average price premium paid by winning bidders was 29% in H1 2017, compared to negative 3% in H2 2015. Analysts expect this trend to continue, with developers likely to outbid foreign counterparts in the strong liquidity-driven market, potentially leading to spillover into private land acquisitions.

site_title: Too early to say who is behind cyberattack: Europol
summary: A massive cyberattack, known as WannaCry, has caused global computer chaos, with 163,745 affected IP addresses reported, a 38% decrease from Sunday. Europol says it's too early to determine who's behind the attack, but researchers have reported signs of a possible North Korean link. The attack demands a $300 Bitcoin payment to restore files. Since its launch, 243 payments totaling $63,000 have been made, but the attack is slowing down. An investigation is ongoing, with Europol working to determine the origin of the malware.

site_title: Japan and the US closer to joining AIIB
summary: The US and Japan appear to be moving closer to joining the China-led Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), following a massive global development initiative launched in Beijing. The AIIB has 77 member countries, including China, India, and Russia, and is expected to fund the One Belt One Road (OBOR) project. The US and Japan have been the only holdouts, but a veteran investment banker suggests the US will join the AIIB discussions, and Japan's secretary-general has signalled the country's willingness to join. The AIIB's environmental and economic standards have reassured the US and Japan, and joining the bank could open the door to multi-billion dollar infrastructure projects.

site_title: EasyJet places US$3.8b plane bet after record loss
summary: EasyJet ordered 30 Airbus A321neos for $3.8 billion, betting on a reversal of declining fares. The UK airline, which posted a record winter loss of £212 million, expects revenue per seat to decline by a low single digit percentage. Despite this, bookings are running ahead of last year, and demand to fly remains strong. The new planes will boost seat capacity, improving unit costs and maximizing growth at slot-constrained hubs. EasyJet's CEO, Carolyn McCall, believes the airline will reach its full-year profit expectations.

site_title: China 2017: A good year for the economy, not for investors
summary: China's economy grew 6.9% in the first quarter of 2017, surpassing expectations, but policy measures to curb speculation and financial system risk may reduce investment attractiveness. The government has introduced new rules to deter speculative activities and reduce financial system risk, which could boost asset prices elsewhere. The measures, including higher interest rates and increased supervision, aim to prevent a hard landing, but may result in a growth slowdown or harm to the real economy. This has made 2017 a challenging year for investors in China's financial markets, with the Shanghai Composite stock index experiencing its worst performance in Asia.

site_title: Vodafone's cash flow pledge eases concerns over dividend
summary: Vodafone has pledged to increase free cash flow by 23% to €5 billion (S$7.7 billion) this year, easing concerns over the sustainability of its dividend. CEO Vittorio Colao aims to balance investment needs, rewarding shareholders and paying for spectrum, with cost-cutting measures and deal-making. The forecast, which excludes mergers and acquisitions, spectrum, and restructuring costs, has boosted investor confidence and driven a 4.4% stock gain, its largest in 10 months.

images.alt_text: Vodafone reported fourth quarter organic service revenue growth of 1.5 per cent, matching the average forecast of five analysts.

site_title: GIC sells 2.4% UBS stake at a loss
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund, GIC, has sold nearly half of its stake in UBS Group at a loss, reducing its stake to 2.7% from 5.1%. GIC sold about 93 million shares worth 1.6 billion Swiss francs, or about S$2.3 billion, after the bank's strategy and business have changed fundamentally since GIC's initial investment in 2008. Despite the loss, GIC's overall strategy has generated positive returns on marked-to-market terms, and the fund will redeploy the resources elsewhere.

site_title: South Korea, US to hold Washington summit in June
summary: South Korean President Moon Jae-in will meet US President Donald Trump in Washington in late June, as tensions over North Korea's nuclear ambitions remain high. Moon backs engagement with the nuclear-armed North, while Trump's administration considers military action. The summit comes after North Korea launched its longest-range missile, sparking global alarm and prompting the US to call for tougher sanctions. Moon has expressed willingness to visit the North in the right circumstances, but slammed the launch as a "reckless provocation".

site_title: 2016 profits fall for four of Japan's biggest banks
summary: Japan's four major banks, Mitsubishi UFJ, Mizuho, Resona, and Sumitomo Mitsui Trust, reported a combined 2.52 trillion yen in net profit for the financial year to March 31, down 3.8% from the previous year. Only Sumitomo Mitsui saw a profit increase. The banks forecast a further drop in combined net profits to 2.43 trillion yen for the financial year to April 1, 2018. Japanese lenders are pursuing overseas business to boost profitability, raising concerns at the Bank of Japan about potential risks.

images.alt_text: Nobuyuki Hirano, president of Mitsubishi UFJ. Mitsubishi UFJ and its megabank peers forecast a further drop in combined net profits to 2.43 trillion yen for the financial year to April 1, 2018.

site_title: How Japan proved printing money can be a great idea
summary: Japan's central bank has successfully implemented a policy of printing money to boost the economy, achieving a 22-year low unemployment rate of 2.8% and a super-high employment rate of 83.5%. The monetary stimulus has given businesses the confidence to expand, despite fiscal and structural reforms being implemented under Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's "Abenomics" plan. The economy has grown at least as fast as the US in per-capita terms over the past 15 years, but Japan's working-age population has continued to shrink, making progress "unfinished."

site_title: Indonesia's central bankers hunt 'chili mafia' for stoking inflation
summary: Indonesian central bankers, known as the "chili mafia," are cracking down on wholesalers who manipulate the price of chili, a staple food in the country. The price of chili skyrocketed to a record 200,000 rupiah per kilogram in February, triggering inflation that is restricting the central bank's ability to cut interest rates. The police and competition watchdog have arrested four people suspected of price manipulation, and the central bank is working to combat food inflation by teaching people how to grow their own food and distributing seeds to households.

site_title: Jardine, banks drag STI down
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.12% on May 16, 2017, with Jardine Matheson leading the decline, dropping 4.3% to US$62.29. The index had risen 90 points since the start of the month, driven by banks, but was due for a correction. Brokers noted that the STI's rise was unsustainable and that a correction was expected. The banks' combined loss was 11 points, with UOB and OCBC Bank experiencing notable falls.

site_title: Canada home sales fall in April as market feels the chill of govt cooling measures
summary: Canada's housing market experienced a slowdown in April, with home sales falling 1.7% from March's record level and listings rising 10%. The Ontario government's measures to cool the market, including a 15% tax on foreign buyers, are believed to be contributing to the decline. Toronto sales dropped 6.7% and listings surged 36%, while the national average price rose 10.4% to C$559,317. Experts predict the market may continue to adjust, but the impact of the government measures is uncertain.

site_title: China tightens rules on wealth management products, flags more curbs
summary: China's banking regulator, the China Banking Regulatory Commission (CBRC), has tightened rules on wealth management products (WMPs) to track risky lending practices in the shadow-banking sector. The new rules, launching 46 new or revised guidelines this year, require banks to report underlying assets and liabilities on a weekly basis, aiming to better regulate $6.1 trillion of WMPs. The move aims to slow the growth of WMPs and ensure that financial risks do not become systemic, as policymakers and analysts worry about the potential threat to the world's second-largest economy.

site_title: Kidman is queen of Cannes
summary: Nicole Kidman is the star of three highly anticipated films at the Cannes film festival, including "How to Talk to Girls at Parties," "The Beguiled," and "The Killing of a Sacred Deer." She is in the running for the Palme d'Or award and has been a festival favorite despite never winning a prize. Kidman has had a long and varied career, taking on arthouse roles and working with notable directors, and has been nominated for several awards, including two Oscars.

site_title: Food Empire opens instant coffee plant in India
summary: Food Empire Holdings, a Singapore-based company, has officially opened a state-of-the-art instant coffee manufacturing plant in Mambattu, Andhra Pradesh, India. The plant, which produces 10 types and qualities of spray-dried instant coffee, was inaugurated by Minister for Trade and Industry S Iswaran and Andhra Pradesh Minister for Industries N Amarnath Reddy. The facility is adopting the latest technology to ensure high-quality coffee, with the company already profitable despite being operational for less than a year.

site_title: Brace yourself for worse ransomware attacks to come
summary: A global ransomware attack, dubbed "WannaCry," has infected over 150 countries, targeting banks, hospitals, and government agencies, with over 16 attacks per day reported in Singapore. The attackers, who remain anonymous, demanded a $300 ransom in Bitcoin. Experts warn that this is just the beginning, with more destructive malware and zero-day attacks potentially crippling corporate networks and infrastructure. The attack highlights the need for improved cybersecurity measures, including user education, regular backups, and robust security systems.

site_title: Autos drive April factory output to fastest growth in 3 years
summary: US factory output rose 1% in April, the largest gain in three years, driven by a surge in auto production. Manufacturing production, which accounts for 12% of the US economy, exceeded expectations and followed a slowdown in the first quarter. The Federal Reserve reported a 5% growth in motor vehicles and parts, while mining and drilling activities also increased. However, US homebuilding unexpectedly fell to its lowest level in five months, and the housing market recovery appears to be slowing.

site_title: Knees that creak and pop not always pre-arthritic
summary: A long-term study of nearly 3,500 participants in the Osteoarthritis Initiative found that knee crepitus (creaking and popping sounds) can be an indicator of early arthritis, even if the joint does not hurt. However, not every creaky knee is diseased, and the study's results suggest that most people's knees do not worsen significantly over time. The study's findings indicate that crepitus can be a warning sign for early intervention, but a doctor's evaluation is necessary to determine the cause of the noise.

images.alt_text: The exact nature of the relationship between knee noises and knee health remains enigmatic, and it is unclear what produces those sounds.

site_title: Eurozone expands trade surplus in March despite protectionist calls
summary: The eurozone reported a 30.9 billion euro trade surplus in March, nearly double the February surplus, as exports and imports rose 13% and 14% respectively. This indicates that global commerce has not been affected by growing protectionist calls. The EU expanded its exports to major trade partners, including Russia and China, with a 28% surge in sales to Russia and a 22% increase in exports to China. The surplus with the US increased to 30.6 billion euros, driven by a 11% growth in EU exports to the US.

site_title: Noble shares recover even as rating agencies flag unsustainable debt
summary: Noble Group Ltd shares rose despite Moody's Investors Service warning of unsustainable debt, citing a drop in liquidity headroom from $2.4 billion to insufficient to cover debt by mid-2018. The company's new chairman is prioritizing a strategic review following recent losses.

site_title: Listing hindered ARA's growth: John Lim
summary: ARA Asset Management's growth strategy was hindered by being listed, according to group founder and CEO John Lim. Despite its assets under management increasing from S$10.4 billion to S$36 billion, the company found it difficult to change strategy, introduce products, or invest globally due to listing constraints. Lim attributes the growth to the private consortium taking the company private in April, allowing for greater flexibility and nimbleness.

site_title: When it comes to cutting shipping's CO2, is 'aspirational' good enough?
summary: The International Chamber of Shipping (ICS) has urged the International Maritime Organization (IMO) to adopt three "aspirational" CO2 reduction objectives for the shipping industry, in line with the Paris Agreement on climate change. The ICS aims to remain in control of additional measures to address CO2 reduction, without a binding cap on emissions. The industry will propose these objectives as part of the IMO's initial CO2 reduction strategy in 2018, but environmental groups are likely to call for a binding cap on emissions.

site_title: China quietly releases draft of tough new intelligence law
summary: China has released a draft of its new intelligence law, granting authorities powers to monitor suspects, raid premises, and seize vehicles and devices while investigating domestic and foreign individuals and groups. The law, which outlines national security threats and the need to protect major national interests, could give authorities new grounds to investigate and detain individuals. If passed, it would also allow for administrative detention of up to 15 days and customs and border inspections. The law's passage is seen as part of President Xi Jinping's efforts to bolster national security.

site_title: Olympics: 2024 Olympic fight set to go to the wire
summary: The International Olympic Committee (IOC) is set to make a final decision on the 2024 Summer Olympics host city between Los Angeles and Paris. The IOC's inspection team, led by Patrick Baumann, has praised both cities, stating they present no major risks and have the necessary venues and dedicated teams to host the Games. However, the team noted that the two cities have differing visions, which will be the deciding factor in the vote on September 13. The presence of French President Emmanuel Macron at the vote could potentially give Paris an advantage over Los Angeles.

site_title: Having a meaningful regulatory conversation
summary: Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) aims to have meaningful regulation, focusing on value to all market participants, remaining relevant today and tomorrow, and producing meaningful outcomes. The regulator will balance investor protection with market growth, considering diverse investor needs and engaging with market segments through various channels. Open and transparent policymaking is also crucial, with a focus on precision and proportionality in rule changes. Effective regulation will ensure quality companies list on the exchange, while avoiding over-regulation that may deter investors. SGX RegCo seeks to widen investor choice and facilitate access to capital.

site_title: Australia, HK begin free trade agreement talks
summary: Australia and Hong Kong have begun free trade agreement (FTA) talks, aiming to secure increased access for service providers. The talks, led by Australia's trade minister Steven Ciobo, will focus on improving access for companies in areas such as finance, education, and energy. Hong Kong is Australia's eighth largest export market, with two-way trade worth A$15.3 billion in 2015-16. The agreement could be finalized within a year, with Australia seeking a comprehensive FTA to boost its national exports, which currently account for only 22% of the country's economy.

site_title: Berlin airport terminal evacuated after suspected tear gas outbreak
summary: A terminal at Berlin's Schoenefeld airport was evacuated after a suspected tear gas outbreak, with the fire brigade ventilating the building. The incident may cause delays. This follows a similar incident earlier this year at Hamburg airport, where passengers were affected by a corrosive substance.

site_title: Canberra goes for economic stimulus in A$75b infrastructure plan
summary: The Australian government has unveiled a $75 billion infrastructure plan to boost economic growth, with the goal of creating thousands of jobs. The plan, announced by Treasurer Scott Morrison, includes road, rail, and runway construction projects across the country, from Western Sydney to Western Australia. The forecast deficit for fiscal 2018 is slightly wider than economists predicted, but the government aims to maintain a return to surplus by 2021. Wage growth forecasts are also optimistic, with the government expecting a 3.75% increase in 2021, despite subdued wages in other developed economies.

site_title: Trump claims 'absolute right' to disclose information to Russia
summary: US President Donald Trump defended sharing classified information with Russian officials, stating he has the "absolute right" to do so, citing humanitarian reasons and a desire to combat ISIS. The revelation came after a Washington Post report that Trump shared intelligence about an ISIS plot with Russian Foreign Minister and Ambassador. Trump's top advisors and US officials have denied that intelligence sources or methods were discussed, but experts say the disclosure could jeopardize intelligence capabilities and raise questions about the president's right to release sensitive information.

site_title: Flights delayed after fire at Changi T2
summary: A fire broke out at Changi Airport's Terminal 2 departure hall on May 16, 2017, prompting the evacuation of the terminal and flights being diverted to Terminal 3. The fire alarm was activated due to smoke coming through air vents, and three people were hospitalized for smoke inhalation. The fire was extinguished using a hosereel jet, and flight operations resumed progressively after the all-clear was given. All departing and arriving flights at T2 were moved to T3, with affected passengers experiencing significant delays.

site_title: Hong Kong, China regulators approve 'Bond Connect' scheme
summary: Hong Kong and Chinese regulators have approved the 'Bond Connect' scheme, allowing foreign and Hong Kong investors to trade Chinese bonds without quotas. This is a key step in opening up China's capital markets. The programme was first proposed in 2014, and its approval marks another milestone in China's efforts to increase financial integration with the world.

site_title: Agha Steel plans Pakistan's largest IPO in a decade in response to China boom
summary: Agha Steel Industries Ltd is set to launch Pakistan's largest-ever private sector initial share sale, raising up to 10 billion rupees (S$133 million) to fund a US$50 million expansion. The company aims to triple its production to 500,000 tonnes within two years, driven by China's infrastructure projects and a buoyant stock market. This IPO will surpass the 12 billion-rupee government stake sale of Habib Bank Ltd in 2007, marking the country's largest IPO since then.

site_title: Japan's 'Superhuman' athletes mix legends with high tech
summary: A Tokyo-based group, the Superhuman Sports Society, has certified 12 new sports with a 21st-century twist, including HADO, a virtual reality game where players dodge waves of light and fire energy balls, and Rock Hand Battle, a low-tech game where players wear oversized arms and try to knock off small rocks. Inventions like Bubble Jumper and Slide Lift use technology to enhance human abilities, while Carry Otto is a motorized wheel device that allows riders to compete regardless of age, gender, or disability. Players report feeling "superhuman" and immersed in virtual worlds, blurring the lines between human and machine.

site_title: Bitcoin: Hackers' 'anonymous' currency
summary: Hackers behind the WannaCry cyberattack demanded $300 in Bitcoin for the release of encrypted files, but experts say Bitcoin's anonymity is not impenetrable. Transactions are traceable through blockchains, and holders can be monitored. The use of "tumblers" on the dark web can offer additional anonymity, but investigators can still track the hackers' Bitcoin addresses. The hackers' true aim may be to gain notoriety and sell other services, rather than spending the ransom money. European police agency Europol has not confirmed North Korea's involvement in the attack.

site_title: Singapore a 'global leader' in embracing technology: Deloitte
summary: Singapore has been hailed as a "global leader" in embracing technology, according to a report by Deloitte. The country ranks first on the World Economic Forum's Networked Readiness Index and has implemented initiatives such as the Smart Nation program to leverage digital technologies. Deloitte notes that Asia is at the forefront of global economic growth, with Singapore and other Asian economies continuing to invest in technological development. The report suggests that Asian economies will lead global economic growth over the coming decade, with digital technologies playing a key role in driving innovation and efficiency.

images.alt_text: Singapore has been touted as a "global leader" when it comes to embracing technology in order to stay competitive and to drive economic growth for the long haul.
Lee U-Wen

site_title: France's Macron to name ministers Wednesday as rivals fear "dynamiting"
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron is set to announce his government on Wednesday, drawing in former rivals from both left and right to break through the left-right divide in the country's politics. The move has sparked alarm among the Socialist and conservative parties, who fear he will poach their leading figures. Macron aims to build a team of maximum 15 ministers, including veteran socialists, centrists, and conservatives, to carry out his pro-business, pro-EU policies ahead of crucial parliamentary elections in June.

site_title: MMP Resources wins appeal to defend claim for S$5.2m
summary: MAINBOARD-LISTED MMP Resources has won an appeal to defend a S$5.2 million claim filed by Edward Lee against the company. The earlier judgment requiring the company to pay the sum, along with interest and costs, has been set aside. MMP Resources will continue its investigations into 2014-2015 events and take actions against wrongdoers, vowing to defend the company's interests.

site_title: Vodafone powers Britain's FTSE to new record high
summary: Britain's main share index, the FTSE 100, reached a new record high, driven by Vodafone's forecast of earnings growth and stronger free cash flow. Telecoms stocks and consumer staples provided the main impetus, while energy stocks supported gains due to rising crude prices. The FTSE 100 rose 0.9% with Vodafone jumping 3.9%, despite a 6.1 billion euro loss for the year to the end of March.

site_title: Facebook adds Snapchat-like camera filters to Instagram
summary: Facebook has added Snapchat-like camera filters to Instagram, allowing users to choose from quirky face-tracking filters and other humorous effects. The new features include a rewind mode for videos and hashtag stickers to visit hashtag pages. This move aims to compete with Snapchat's features, which are popular among Instagram's teenage and millennial users. The update follows Instagram's existing "Stories" feature, which allows users to upload pictures and videos that disappear after 24 hours, with over 200 million people using it daily.

site_title: Delphi joins self-driving alliance with BMW, Intel
summary: BMW, Intel, and Delphi form a self-driving alliance to develop a highly-automated platform for BMW, with Delphi handling integration of components and software. The platform, targeted for 2021 production, will be sold to other vehicle manufacturers. The collaboration aims to reduce costs and accelerate development of self-driving vehicles, with a goal of a small number of shared self-driving platforms among major carmakers. This move follows similar alliances between Daimler and Robert Bosch, Baidu and other companies, and Waymo and Lyft.

site_title: Facebook gets France's maximum fine for privacy violations
summary: Facebook has been fined the maximum amount of 150,000 euros (S$230,081) by French authorities for violating privacy laws, specifically for combining user data for targeted advertising and tracking users with cookies. The company also faces scrutiny from Dutch, Spanish, Belgian, and German regulators, with potential further sanctions. Facebook has agreed to stop using user data for targeted ads in the Netherlands and has pledged to address other privacy issues, but has disputed some findings.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Asian pay TV trust Bumitama Agri's Q1 2017 revenue and Ebitda met estimates, but earnings were lowered by 18% due to non-cash items. Golden Agri-Resources reported revenue up 37% and core profit up 70%, but earnings were 60% lower due to a forex loss. Bumitama Agri's earnings forecast was maintained, while Golden Agri-Resources' production growth forecast was lowered. Analysts maintain their target prices for the companies.

site_title: Japan firms turn to robots as labour shortage bites
summary: Japan's mid-sized companies are planning to invest heavily in automation to overcome a growing labor shortage, with a 17.5% increase in spending on equipment and robots in the fiscal year starting April. This is expected to boost efficiency and contribute to economic growth, as the country struggles with an aging population. Companies are turning to robots for tasks such as manufacturing, earth-moving, and hotel service, with some seeing increased demand for labor-saving gear.

images.alt_text: Tokyo's Hen na Hotel uses egg-shaped robots called Tapia to serve guests in its 100 rooms. These robots can wake guests up, manage their schedule and control devices such as the TV and air conditioning.

site_title: The priming of Donald Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump has expressed willingness to pursue tax cuts despite increasing deficits, citing the need to "prime the pump" to boost economic growth. However, economists argue that this approach is misguided, particularly at a time when unemployment is near historic lows and the economy no longer needs a fiscal jump-start. Trump's proposal to cut taxes on the wealthy, financed by exploding the deficit, is seen as economically irresponsible. Critics also accuse the news media of perpetuating a myth about a powerful faction of deficit hawks among Republican lawmakers, which they claim is a delusion of Trumpian proportions.

site_title: Singapore fends off ransomware, but needs to be ready for APTs
summary: Singapore has successfully defended against the WannaCry ransomware attack, with only about 500 local IP addresses potentially affected. However, the country's robust cyber defenses are a stark contrast to the global impact of the attack, which affected over 200,000 computers in 150 countries. Experts warn that more serious cyber threats, such as advanced persistent threats (APTs) and distributed denial of service (DDoS) attacks, pose a greater risk to organizations. Singapore's cybersecurity landscape is highlighted as a model for other countries to follow, with the need for industry-wide collaboration and cooperation to prevent future cyber attacks.

site_title: Trump claims 'absolute right' to disclose terrorism secrets
summary: President Donald Trump claimed an "absolute right" to share classified information about terrorism with Russian officials, despite reports that he disclosed highly classified material in an Oval Office meeting. The Washington Post reported that Trump shared information about an Islamic State plot with Russia's foreign minister and US ambassador, which could compromise US intelligence operations. Trump denied the report, but lawmakers from both parties expressed alarm, calling for a fuller accounting. The controversy has added to Trump's challenges ahead of his first overseas trip as president, where he will meet with Saudi Arabia and Israel.

site_title: Elliott steps up call for BHP to ditch petroleum
summary: Elliott Management, a prominent activist investor, has urged BHP to conduct an independent review of its petroleum business, citing "extremely broad and deep-rooted support" for strategic changes to boost shareholder value. The call comes after Elliott has built a 4.1% stake in BHP's UK-listed arm and has previously proposed selling the company's US oil and gas assets and collapsing its dual-listed structure. BHP has rejected these proposals, but is expected to meet with Elliott in Barcelona. Analysts predict BHP could generate billions of dollars by selling its petroleum business, but caution that this would be a one-off benefit.

site_title: When it comes to leveraged loans, active beats passive
summary: Leveraged loan exchange-traded funds (ETFs) have outperformed index-tracking loan ETFs since their inception in 2013, with actively managed portfolios delivering higher returns due to individual selection and expertise. The actively managed funds have a lower volatility profile, with "down-market capture ratios" indicating better performance in down markets. While past performance doesn't guarantee future results, leveraged loan ETFs are poised for further growth, with US$30 billion in inflows since the middle of last year, and are expected to benefit from rising interest rates and investor interest in less liquid assets.

site_title: EU court says Singapore trade deal needs national ratification
summary: The European Union's top court ruled that a free trade agreement with Singapore cannot fully enter force until all EU countries ratify it, potentially delaying other planned EU trade deals. The agreement was completed in 2014, but EU member states must now provide national ratification before it can be implemented. This decision may impact the EU's ability to finalize trade agreements with Japan, Mexico, and the Mercosur quartet, as well as a deal with post-Brexit Britain.

site_title: Yahoo to buy back US$3b shares
summary: Yahoo Inc plans to buy back US$3 billion of its common shares, providing liquidity to stockholders ahead of its pending deal with Verizon Communications Inc. The buyback will be conducted between US$50.79 and US$44.74 per share, based on calculations considering Alibaba's share price and timing. This move aims to ease selling pressure and stabilize the stock price.

site_title: Indian police raid homes of ex-finance minister, son
summary: Indian police raided the homes of former finance minister P Chidambaram and his son Karti Chidambaram as part of an investigation into suspected corruption during Chidambaram's time in government. The Central Bureau of Investigation is probing whether Karti's company helped a client to circumvent foreign investment limits. Chidambaram denied the allegations, while his son Karti also denied any wrongdoing. The raids come amid a larger trend of corruption investigations targeting opposition leaders, with similar raids also targeting former government minister Lalu Prasad Yadav.

site_title: NAB bolt-on right for OCBC but test lies ahead
summary: OCBC Bank has acquired a mortgage loan book worth US$1.7 billion and a US$3.05 billion deposit portfolio from National Australia Bank, primarily serving affluent customers in Singapore and Hong Kong. The deal will increase OCBC's housing loan portfolio by 4% and provides a boost to its mortgage loans book. However, OCBC faces challenges in cross-selling to this new customer base and may struggle to compete with rivals, particularly DBS, which has a strong three-year fixed rate package. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move to gain market share in the home loans stake, but its long-term effectiveness is unclear.

site_title: Sunvic Chemical narrows Q1 loss as revenue rises
summary: Sunvic Chemical Holdings reported a narrowing of its fiscal first-quarter losses, with a net loss of 3.7 million yuan (S$750,600) compared to a net loss of 60.9 million yuan in the same period last year. Revenue grew 40% to 589.0 million yuan, mainly due to increased sales of acrylic acid and acrylate esters. The company expects the operating environment of the AA industry to remain challenging due to oversupply and excess production capacity in China.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: UOL Group and its associate complete acquisition of Raintree Gardens
summary: UOL Group and its associate United Industrial Corporation have completed the en bloc purchase of Raintree Gardens in Potong Pasir for redevelopment into a project with approximately 750 units. The project is expected to begin sales in 2018.

site_title: GIC faces possible US$4b loss on UBS bet
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC Private Limited is facing a potential loss of over US$4 billion on its 9-year-old investment in Swiss bank UBS Group, according to IFR calculations. GIC cut its stake in UBS by selling 93 million shares at 16.10 Swiss francs each, resulting in a loss. The fund had initially invested 11 billion Swiss francs in UBS in 2007, but has since realized a total return of 5.2 billion Swiss francs, leaving it with a current loss of 4.1 billion Swiss francs.

site_title: Austria snap elections set for October 15
summary: Austria's snap election has been set for October 15, following the collapse of the centrist "grand coalition" between Chancellor Christian Kern's Social Democrats and the People's Party. The far-right Freedom Party, led by Heinz-Christian Strache, is running neck-and-neck with the Social Democrats in opinion polls, potentially entering government. The early election is seen as a result of months of bickering between the two main parties, which have governed Austria since 1945. The vote could lead to a shift in power, with the Freedom Party's anti-immigration stance and youthful leader Sebastian Kurz gaining traction.

site_title: Hong Kong, China regulators say approve "Bond Connect" scheme
summary: Hong Kong and Chinese regulators have formally approved the "Bond Connect" scheme, connecting China's $8 trillion bond market with overseas investors. The scheme, which began in 2014, allows for two-way trading between Hong Kong and Shanghai stock markets. Initially, only foreign and Hong Kong investors will be able to trade Chinese bonds, with the launch date to be announced later. This milestone marks another step in China's efforts to open up its capital markets.

site_title: Singapore looks towards provisional application of FTA with EU
summary: Singapore hopes to partially enforce its free-trade pact with the European Union (EU) after the EU's top court ruled that the agreement cannot fully enter force until all 28 EU countries ratify it. The EUSFTA, signed in 2017, requires only two aspects for national ratification, while the rest can be enforced by the EU alone. Singapore is committed to working with the European Commission to ratify the agreement expeditiously and has provisionally applied parts of the deal to allow businesses to utilize the agreement.

images.alt_text: Singapore hopes to have a proposed free-trade pact with the European Union (EU) partially enforced as the deal awaits national and sub-national approval from the regional bloc's 28 member states.

site_title: Fire at Terminal 2 under control: Changi Airport
summary: A fire broke out at Changi Airport's Terminal 2 on Tuesday evening, prompting the evacuation of the terminal. The fire alarm was activated due to smoke coming through the air vents at 5:40pm. The situation is now under control, and the cause of the fire has been identified. Flight operations at Terminal 2 are affected.

images.alt_text: A fire broke out at Changi Airport's Terminal 2 on Tuesday evening, prompting the evacuation of the terminal.
Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Unusual to bring in Foo Fighters to Singapore in August
summary: Foo Fighters, a 11-time Grammy Award-winning American rock band, will perform a concert in Singapore on August 26 at the National Stadium, marking their first Western act promotion since Unusual Entertainment's listing in April. This is their first show in Singapore since 1996.

site_title: CSC Holdings issues profit warning
summary: CSC Holdings, a geotechnical engineering specialist, has issued a profit warning, expecting to report a loss for the three months ended March 31. Further details on the group's performance will be disclosed when it announces its results.

site_title: Sunvic Chemical narrows losses in Q1
summary: Sunvic Chemical Holdings reported a narrowing of its first-quarter losses, with net losses decreasing to 3.7 million yuan (S$750,500) from 60.9 million yuan in the same period last year. Revenue grew to 589 million yuan, while loss per share narrowed to 0.7 RMB cents from 11.4 RMB cents.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: Oil output spike brightens North Sea's twilight years
summary: North Sea oil output is expected to increase by 400,000 barrels per day, defying gloomy forecasts, due to new projects in the West Shetlands and Arctic Ocean. The addition of 1.2 million barrels per day will offset the decline in output from older fields, resulting in a production level of approximately 2 million barrels per day. This development is seen as a positive turn for the oldest deepwater basin, which has been experiencing declining output.

site_title: Uber, Starbucks, Twitter join drive to boost UK youth vote
summary: Uber, Starbucks, and Twitter have joined forces to encourage UK youth to vote in the June 8 general election, targeting the 18-24 age demographic who tend to be left-leaning. Uber will send voting reminders via text, while Uber Eats users will receive similar prompts. Starbucks is hosting "Democracy Cafes" and Twitter will promote voter registration on May 22nd. The move comes as 26% of eligible 18-24-year-olds remain unregistered to vote.

images.alt_text: Mobile-phone text prompts while you wait for your Uber. Election chat over a cappuccino. Uber Technologies Inc, Starbucks Corp and Twitter Inc have joined forces to get British youngsters to take part in the June 8 general election, even if it means they might vote for the candidate that wants to tax them the most.

site_title: US home construction slows unexpectedly in April
summary: US home construction slowed in April, falling to its lowest pace in five months, according to the Commerce Department. The rate of 1.172 million was 2.6% below March's revised figure, with analysts attributing the decrease to a tight housing market and rising prices. Supply has not kept pace with demand, driven by rising wages and steady job creation. Building permits also fell short of expectations, but a rise in apartment construction suggests the rental market remains a driver of construction. The slow pace may indicate a broader housing market slowdown.

site_title: HP Enterprise unveils computer 'for era of Big Data'
summary: Hewlett-Packard Enterprise unveiled a new computer system called "the Machine" capable of handling vast amounts of data at supercomputing speeds. The system uses "memory-driven computing" and light waves to transmit data, bypassing a major obstacle to boosting computing speeds. The prototype contains 160 terabytes of memory, equivalent to processing the contents of 160 million books. The system is designed for Big Data applications and has the potential to analyze health studies, genetics, and personalizing medical treatment, potentially shortening the time to develop medicines.

images.alt_text: Researchers from Hewlett-Packard Enterprise on Tuesday unveiled what they claimed was a breakthrough in computing with a new machine capable of handling vast amounts of data at supercomputing speeds.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end lower, snap six-day win streak
summary: Hong Kong shares ended lower on Tuesday, snapping a six-day winning streak, as profit-takers moved in. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.14% to 25,335.94, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.74%. Energy firms rose on oil price advances. The losses marked the first drop in six days, as investors reacted to profit-taking.

site_title: Chat service Symphony raises US$63m, builds office in Singapore
summary: Symphony Communication Services, a US-based online chat service for Wall Street traders, has raised US$63 million in new funding led by BNP Paribas SA. The latest investment values the service at over US$1 billion, bringing total funding to US$233 million. Symphony aims to expand into new global markets, particularly in Asia, where it is building a large office in Singapore. The service competes with Bloomberg LP and Thomson Reuters Corp, and is looking to disrupt the financial market messaging space.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end flat on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index ended flat on Tuesday, closing at 1,778.150, after 3.52 billion lots valued at RM3.84 billion were traded. Losers outnumbered gainers 497 to 412.

site_title: Singapore stocks finish weaker; STI loses 1.1%, dragged lower by JM, banks
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.1% to 3,227.71, dragged down by Jardine Matheson's 4.3% drop and banks' losses. The index had risen 90 points since the start of the month, leading to a correction. Turnover was moderate-to-heavy, with 2.3 billion units traded. Brokers attributed the decline to the index's strong rally over several weeks.

site_title: GIC tells why it is still under-invested in real estate
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC is struggling to increase its real estate allocation from 7% to 9-13% due to high asset valuations and competition from other capital sources. GIC aims to sell non-core assets, such as hotels and industrial properties, to free up funds for real estate investments. Despite making significant investments, including purchasing European industrial developer P3 Logistic Parks and US student housing assets, GIC faces challenges in achieving its target allocation. The fund must navigate a rapidly changing market landscape with increased competition and lower expected returns.

site_title: Coffee maker Lavazza counting on acquisitions to help boost sales
summary: Lavazza, an Italian coffee maker, aims to boost sales to 2.2 billion euros by 2020 through organic growth and potential acquisitions. The company, which rose 29% to 1.9 billion euros in 2017, plans to focus on the US, Canada, Germany, and Britain. With a net financial position of nearly 700 million euros, Lavazza can devote to potential mergers and acquisitions (M&A). The company is considering acquisitions in the organic and fair-trade coffee businesses, particularly in fast-growing markets.

site_title: New South Korean president seen hindering country's nuclear ambitions
summary: South Korea's new president, Moon Jae-in, has been seen hindering the country's nuclear ambitions, promising to scrap or suspend new atomic plants. This stance is a threat to South Korea's ambitions to become a bigger exporter of nuclear equipment and technology, valued at up to $740 billion over the next decade. Despite its success in designing and starting up advanced nuclear reactors, South Korea's domestic industry may suffer from the new government's anti-nuclear stance, potentially narrowing its market share in the global nuclear industry.

site_title: Football: Man United predict record revenue for 2017
summary: Manchester United has predicted a record rise in annual revenue to between £560 million and £570 million for the 2017-18 financial year, up from £530-540 million previously forecasted. The increase is attributed to a 12.9% rise in broadcast revenue due to the Premier League's new television rights deal. United will face Ajax in the Europa League final on May 24, with a 30% reduction in sponsorship deal with Adidas if they fail to qualify for the Champions League.

site_title: Euro tops US$1.10 for first time since French election results
summary: The euro reached a 6-month high of US$1.1024, surpassing the $1.10 mark for the first time since the French presidential election results on May 7. The US dollar weakened due to doubts over a potential interest rate hike in June and political concerns. The euro's gain was attributed to a 73% chance of a June interest rate hike, down from 80% last week, according to the CME's FedWatch tool. The decline in the US dollar also saw it sink against the yen.

site_title: JP Morgan shuffles Asia investment bankers
summary: JP Morgan has made significant changes to its Asia investment banking division, appointing new heads of equity capital markets and mergers and acquisitions. Daniel Darahem becomes head of ECM for Asia Pacific, while Kerwin Clayton and Rohit Chatterji co-head M&A. Mac El-Omari has been appointed vice chairman of global investment banking for Asia Pacific, and Brian Gu is now chairman of Asia Pacific investment banking. The moves aim to strengthen client dialogue, streamline coordination, and integrate industry groups with client coverage groups.

site_title: Australia: Shares firm as resources share gains offset weak bank stocks
summary: Australian shares remained flat on Tuesday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index rising 0.07% to 5,842.7, as resource stocks gained ground due to a recovery in iron ore and copper prices. BHP, Rio Tinto, and South32 advanced, while mining heavyweights lifted the energy index to a record high. Bank stocks, however, fell, with National Australia Bank trading ex-dividend and dipping 3.3%. Investors took cues from Wall Street's fresh closing highs and the market's bounce from the 5,800 support level.

site_title: easyJet first-half loss widens, says pricing pressures easing
summary: British budget airline easyJet reported a wider first-half loss of £212 million, mainly due to the weak pound and late Easter timing. However, the airline said pricing pressures within the industry were easing and strong cost control allowed it to meet full-year targets. Analysts had estimated a pretax loss of £195.75 million. Despite the loss, easyJet remains optimistic about its prospects, citing stabilizing industry pricing.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: GIC sold nearly half of its UBS stake for a loss, while Singapore's housing market appears to be recovering due to developers' demand for land. Noble Group's shares rose despite Moody's warning of a US$900m funding gap. The EU court ruled that a Singapore-EU trade deal requires national ratification. Singapore fintech firm CCRManager launched the first digital platform for trade finance assets. The Straits Times Index fell 1.1% due to Jardine Matheson's 4.3% decline.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end see-saw session higher, Toshiba dives
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher after a seesaw session, driven by record highs on US and European markets and a rally in oil prices. Toshiba, however, fell after warning of huge losses. The news followed a similar trend in Frankfurt, London, and New York, where energy companies benefited from the crude price surge. The price increase was partly due to Saudi Arabia and Russia's announcement of considering an output cut extension into 2018.

site_title: UK inflation jumps more than expected in April to hit highest since 2013
summary: British inflation rose to its highest level since 2013, increasing by 2.7% in April, exceeding economists' expectations. The weakening of the pound since the UK's Brexit decision and rising oil prices contributed to the surge. The Bank of England's inflation figures show core consumer prices rising to 2.4% and services prices jumping 3.0%, the largest increase since 2013. Economists predict inflation will peak at nearly 3% by the end of the year, and the central bank expects it to remain high due to the ongoing impact of the fall in sterling.

site_title: Sunpower unit clinches contracts worth 154m yuan
summary: A wholly owned subsidiary of Sunpower Group clinched 154 million yuan (S$31.25 million) worth of contracts from repeat customers, including Wanhua Chemical Group Co, Sichuan Yongxiang New Energy Co, and Jiangxi LDK PV Silicon Technology Co. The contracts involve the supply of fluidised bed reactors and heat exchangers for various projects. This deal is seen as a testament to Sunpower's technological and manufacturing capabilities, with chairman Guo Hongxin stating the company will maintain stable performance and growth in its high-end equipment manufacturing business.

site_title: Europe: London stocks hit new peak, Frankfurt and Paris sag
summary: London's FTSE 100 index reached a new record high, closing at 7,467.47, up 0.2% from Monday. In contrast, Frankfurt's DAX 30 fell 0.2% to 12,787.69, and Paris' CAC 40 dropped 0.4% to 5,398.15. The decline in European markets follows a strong rally in US stocks, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records.

site_title: Singapore fintech firm launches 'first digital platform' for trade finance assets
summary: Singapore-based fintech firm CCRManager Pte Ltd launched the world's first digital platform for trade finance assets, backed by the Monetary Authority of Singapore's Financial Sector Development Fund. Supported by 16 financial institutions, the platform aims to hit $10 billion in transaction volume in the first year and $250 billion by year five. It enables users to list assets, negotiate deals, and manage supporting documentation in a secure environment, providing transparency and facilitating access to trade markets for investors. The platform has already been tested by 14 countries and is expected to address the cumbersome manual process of trade finance distribution.

site_title: Singapore property comeback fuelled by developers hungry for land
summary: Singapore's housing market is showing signs of a comeback after three years of price declines, driven by developers' hunger for land. New home sales more than doubled in April, with a record 24 bidders at a recent land auction. Developers have paid a 29% premium for land, the highest in five years, and are eager to build their land banks. The market's recovery is expected, but the government's efforts to avoid overheating remain a concern, with most cooling measures still in place.

site_title: Australia shares eke out marginal gains, NZ falls
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.2% to 5,850.5, driven by recovering commodity and metal prices. National Australia Bank fell 3.5% after trading ex-dividend, while Macquarie Group dropped 2.1%. Resource stocks, including Rio Tinto and BHP, gained 1.4% and 0.8% respectively. New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 index fell 0.3%.

site_title: South Korea, US to hold Washington summit in June: Seoul
summary: South Korean President Moon Jae-In will travel to the US for a summit with President Donald Trump in late June, amid high tensions over North Korea's nuclear ambitions. The summit aims to reduce tensions and cement personal ties between the two leaders. Moon backs engagement with North Korea, while Trump's administration considers military action. The announcement comes after North Korea successfully launched its longest-range missile, sparking global alarm and prompting the White House to call for tougher sanctions. The two allies will seek a "bold and practical" approach to curb North Korea's military ambitions.

site_title: Seoul: Won ends at 6-week high on stronger risk appetite
summary: The South Korean won reached a six-week high at 1,116.0 to the US dollar, driven by firmer global oil prices and improved investor appetite for riskier assets. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) ended 0.2% higher, while foreign investors sold Kospi shares for the third consecutive session, netting 106.5 billion won.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks ease at open
summary: Hong Kong shares opened slightly lower on Tuesday, easing a six-day rally, as energy firms extended gains due to lifted oil prices. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.08% to 25,351.11, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.27% down on Tuesday
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.27% lower on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index at 3,255.51. Gainers outnumbered losers 94 to 63, with Noble Group easing 1.7% and blue chips OCBC Bank and DBS Group Holdings gaining 0.3% and 0.2% respectively.

site_title: Australia and Hong Kong begin free trade agreement talks
summary: Australia and Hong Kong began free trade agreement talks, aiming to secure increased access for service providers. The talks, led by Australian Trade Minister Steven Ciobo and Hong Kong's Secretary for Commerce and Economic Development Gregory So, focus on improving access for financial, education, travel, and construction companies. Hong Kong is Australia's eighth-largest export market, with two-way trade valued at A$15.3 billion. The agreement could be finalized within a year, with a focus on comprehensive negotiations.

site_title: Noble climbs even as Moody's flags US$900m funding gap
summary: Noble Group shares rose despite Moody's downgrading its rating to Caa1 from B2, citing a liquidity gap of US$900 million due by mid-2018. The commodity trader reported a quarterly loss of US$130 million and faces mounting difficulties, including a debt load deemed unsustainable by S&P Global Ratings. New Chairman Paul Brough is reviewing strategic options, including exploring "strategic alternatives" that could lead to a buyer.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 7.810 points to 1785.030 on Tuesday, driven by a 198-63 gain-to-lose ratio. The index's value was RM99.29 million, with 130.66 million lots traded.

site_title: Samsung looks beyond smartphones to next-gen biologics
summary: Samsung is expanding its pharmaceutical sector by investing $740 million in a US factory to produce biologics, a type of medicine derived from mammal cells, aiming to become the world's No 1 producer by volume. The company, which is diversifying from its smartphone business, plans to increase production and secure over 15 new contracts. Biologics market is projected to exceed $223.7 billion by 2021, driven by growing demand for cancer and arthritis treatments. The move is seen as crucial for Samsung, which faces intense competition in the smartphone market, and for South Korea, which needs new industries to drive growth.

site_title: Sterling hits five-week low against resurgent euro
summary: Sterling hits a five-week low against the euro, falling over 50 cents to around $1.2950, as investors bet against the pound topping $1.30 this year due to Brexit concerns. The pound rose after inflation data showed a 2.7% increase in April, but traders sold hard after the euro bounced above $1.2950. This reflects market conviction that sterling will struggle to reach $1.30 this year, adding to pressure on Bank of England policymakers.

site_title: 22-year-old whiz kid foiled WannaCry cyberattack
summary: A 22-year-old British cybersecurity researcher, known as @MalwareTechBlog, discovered a weakness in the WannaCry malware, slowing its spread and halting its attack in Europe. The researcher, not an employee of the National Cyber Security Centre, found a "kill switch" introduced by the hackers themselves to stop the malware. This led to a stable situation in Europe and a slowdown in the malware's spread in China. The incident highlights the importance of collaboration among cybersecurity experts, who often share research and findings through social media platforms like Twitter.

site_title: Philippines' Duterte open to South China Sea deals
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte expressed openness to exploring the South China Sea's natural resources with China and Vietnam, despite international tribunal rulings that deemed China's claims unlawful. Duterte stated that a deal would need to be "fair and balanced" and made no mention of Malaysia and Brunei. He returned from Beijing with billions of dollars in Chinese investments and aid, and agreed not to raise the tribunal ruling, instead focusing on a code of conduct for the sea.

site_title: Japan urges Toshiba, Western Digital to get along as chip spat flares
summary: Japan's government urged Toshiba and Western Digital to cooperate as a dispute between the two escalated, threatening the sale of Toshiba's chip unit. Western Digital sought international arbitration to stop Toshiba from selling the unit without its consent, citing contract violations. The Japanese government expressed concern, but did not intend to intervene, amid reports of a potential state-backed consortium led by Innovation Corporation of Japan and US private equity firm KKR. Toshiba's shares fell 12% as the company considers blocking Western Digital employees from the plant if the US company does not sign a collaboration agreement.

site_title: GIC explains why it remains under-invested in real estate
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC aims to increase its real estate allocation from 7% to 9-13%. However, high asset values worldwide hinder this goal. GIC's Chief Investment Officer, Lee Kok Sun, attributed the under-investment to the high market values, stating the fund sells non-core assets when values exceed intrinsic levels. Despite selling assets, GIC seeks to raise its real estate allocation, but faces the challenge of keeping pace with market changes. GIC's total assets under management are approximately $353.6 billion.

site_title: Man who helped bury Lehman turns to saving troubled Noble
summary: Noble Group Ltd, a struggling commodities trader, has appointed Paul Brough, a former KPMG executive, as chairman amid plummeting stock and bond values. Brough has a history of restructuring failed companies, including Lehman Brothers and Sino-Forest Corp. The company faces significant challenges, including falling commodities prices, mounting debt, and liquidity issues. Moody's Investors Service has downgraded Noble to junk, warning it may not have enough money to cover its debts. Brough's first task will be conducting a strategic review of the business, which may include exploring strategic alternatives, such as finding a buyer or selling assets.

site_title: Listing a hindrance to its growth strategy: ARA
summary: ARA Asset Management's growth strategy was hindered by being listed, according to founder and CEO John Lim. Despite assets under management (AUM) increasing to S$36 billion at the time of privatisation, being a listed company limited the company's ability to be nimble and flexible, hindering its ability to introduce new products and invest globally. Lim maintains a bullish outlook on the China market and Asia, seeing it as a great opportunity for growth.

site_title: Europe car sales drop 6.8% in April on VW, British slump: ACEA
summary: European car sales dropped 6.8% in April due to a decline in demand for Volkswagen-branded cars and a double-digit sales drop in Britain. Registrations fell to 1.23 million, down from 1.32 million a year earlier. This was the first monthly drop this year, limiting a four-month increase to 4.5%. The decline was attributed to Easter being in April, leading to depressed sales figures. Nearly every auto brand except Toyota and Kia saw falling sales, with the main reason being the decline in Germany and the UK.

site_title: United says cockpit door codes may have been published online
summary: United Airlines confirmed that codes to access cockpit doors may have been published online, but stopped short of confirming a report that a flight attendant posted the codes. The airline is working to resolve the issue, and while it may not be able to keep its flight decks secure through the codes alone, it has other measures in place to prevent unauthorized access.

images.alt_text: Codes to gain access to United Airlines cockpits may have been made public, the carrier said on Monday, but it stopped short of confirming a report that a flight attendant inadvertently published the codes online in a potential threat to air security.

site_title: Australian dollar treads water after RBA minutes, NZ dollar firms
summary: The Australian dollar remained steady at US$0.7412 after the Reserve Bank of Australia's minutes reiterated that interest rates will remain at record lows for the foreseeable future. The decision was based on housing and labor market stability. The New Zealand dollar, however, firmed up, likely due to the RBA's stance, and technical analysts expect stiff resistance at US$0.7450.

site_title: Australia new vehicle sales up 0.3% m-o-m in April
summary: Australia's new vehicle sales rose 0.3% in April from March, despite reduced selling days due to holidays. Sales of 97,136 vehicles were up 0.1% from the same period last year. Sports utilities fell 2.8% month-on-month, while passenger vehicles and other vehicles rose 2.1% and 2.8% respectively. Toyota retained the top spot with 19.4% market share, followed by Mazda and Hyundai. The decline in sales was attributed to the timing of holidays and a school break.

site_title: Australia unveils massive new shipbuilding plan
summary: Australia has unveiled a massive A$89 billion shipbuilding plan to replace its ageing fleets, with plans to construct dozens of new submarines and frigates. The program, which will produce nine frigates, 12 offshore patrol vessels, and 19 Pacific patrol boats, is expected to create up to 10,000 jobs and transform the local shipbuilding industry. The plan includes 12 new submarines at a cost of A$50 billion, with construction set to begin around 2022. The program aims to boost Australia's defence capabilities and ensure the country has the most capable and agile military force.

site_title: Ford Motor to slash workforce by about 10%: WSJ
summary: Ford Motor Co plans to cut about 10% of its global workforce, targeting salaried employees, to boost profit and address a sliding stock price. The company aims to achieve US$3 billion in cost cuts for 2017, with the goal of improving profitability in 2018. The job cuts are expected to be revealed as early as this week.

images.alt_text: Ford Motor Co is set to cut about 10 per cent of its global employee headcount in an effort to boost profit and its sliding stock price, the Wall Street Journal reported on Monday.

site_title: Disney blackmailed over apparent movie hack: reports
summary: Disney is being blackmailed by hackers claiming to have access to an unreleased movie, although the target has not been confirmed. The hackers are demanding a "huge" ransom in Bitcoin, threatening to release five-minute segments of the movie until the ransom is paid. Disney's Bob Iger said the company will not give in to the blackmail attempt, and federal agents are working with the company to monitor for leaks online.

site_title: Trump revealed intelligence secrets to Russians in Oval Office: officials
summary: President Donald Trump shared highly classified information about a planned Islamic State operation with Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov and Ambassador Sergei Kislyak, according to two US officials. The intelligence was shared at a meeting last week, contradicting White House claims that the allegations are incorrect. The US ally who provided the information remains unnamed, and it is unclear what specific details were shared with the Russians. The incident raises concerns about Trump's handling of sensitive information and his relationships with foreign leaders.

site_title: Facebook still accessible in Thailand as government deadline passes
summary: Facebook remains accessible in Thailand after the telecoms regulator gave the company until Tuesday to remove 131 web addresses deemed threatening to national security or violating lese majeste laws. Despite concerns of a block, Facebook took down the content, and the site remains available. This decision is seen as a positive outcome for Facebook users in Thailand, who are among the most active in Asia. The move is also a relief for the tech giant, which has a large user base in the country.

site_title: Ex-Nomura traders latest sued by SEC over lies about bonds
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has sued two former Nomura Holdings Inc traders, James Im and Kee Chan, for allegedly lying to clients about bond prices to inflate the bank's profits. Im misrepresented bond prices, generating an extra $750,000 in profits, while Chan settled allegations without admitting or denying them, paying over $200,000 in penalties. The case is part of the US government's crackdown on the opaque market for securitized debt, with over 20 Wall Street traders placed on leave or dismissed since the 2008 financial crisis.

site_title: China's Xi seeks to rewrite global trade rules as US retreats
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping aims to rewrite global trade rules as the US retreats into "America First" policies. At a Beijing summit, Xi promoted his One Belt, One Road initiative, a plan to revive ancient trade routes. Analysts see this as a bid to cast himself as a champion of globalization. However, the US's shift in trade policy may give China an opportunity to push its own agenda, potentially altering the global trade landscape.

site_title: US dollar languishes near 1-week low after weak US manufacturing activity
summary: The US dollar traded near a one-week low against a basket of major currencies due to a weak US manufacturing report, which saw the New York Federal Reserve's barometer on business activity in New York state fall into negative territory for the first time since October. Analysts caution that this downturn could signal a deterioration in the manufacturing sector. Despite this, the US dollar index remains supported by market expectations of a potential interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve in June.

site_title: Asia: Stocks climb as oil spurs commodities rally
summary: Asia-Pacific stocks rose as oil prices surged, lifting US stock indexes to fresh highs. The S&P 500 Index closed above 2,400 for the first time, while the dollar weakened for a fifth straight day. The yen strengthened with other currencies. The oil price rise, supported by Saudi Arabia and Russia's output cuts, helped keep the global equities rally alive despite concerns over the global economy.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, following record closings in Europe and the US, driven by a rally in oil prices. The Nikkei 225 gained 0.45% and the Topix index rose 0.50%. This comes amid a global stock rally, with the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite trade uncertainty.

site_title: Kushner real estate project still seeking first Chinese investor
summary: US presidential adviser Jared Kushner's family real estate project remains without a first Chinese investor despite presentations in four Chinese cities. About 50 people attended a presentation in Guangzhou sponsored by QWOS Group, an immigration consulting company. The project is seeking early financial commitments, but no deals have been secured. The Kushner project is part of a broader effort to attract foreign investment in China's real estate market.

site_title: Update: GIC sells 2.4% UBS stake for a loss
summary: GIC, Singapore's sovereign wealth fund, has sold nearly half of its 5.1% stake in UBS Group, reducing its ownership to 2.7% for a loss of about US$1.6 billion. GIC cited changing market conditions and UBS' strategy as reasons for the sale, despite initial investment in 2008. The move is part of GIC's long-term investment strategy, which has also generated profits from investments in Citigroup and other asset classes.

site_title: Smog in key northern China region rises in first four months of year
summary: Air pollution in northern China's Beijing-Tianjin-Hebei region worsened in the first four months of 2017, with average PM2.5 concentrations rising nearly 20% year-on-year to 85 micrograms per cubic meter. Despite campaigns to enforce green regulations, the region still faces pressure to cut 2012 levels of small particulate matter by 25% by the end of the year. Average PM2.5 readings in Beijing also rose, with the city aiming to keep rates below 60 micrograms per cubic meter.

images.alt_text: In the Beijing-Tianjin-Hebei region, average concentrations of small breathable particles known as PM2.5 rose nearly 20 per cent year-on-year to 85 micrograms per cubic metre from January to April, said the Ministry of Environmental Protection.

site_title: Snap rebound accelerates as big-name funds disclose stakes
summary: Snap Inc. shares surged 8.4% to $20.74 after big-name funds such as Fidelity Management & Research, Coatue Management, and Temasek Holdings disclosed stakes in the messaging service. The move follows a 21% drop in shares last week after Snap's revenue missed estimates. The disclosed stakes make Fidelity and Coatue among the top holders, while Temasek holds a 300,000-share stake. Snap's CEO Evan Spiegel had previously dismissed concerns about the competitive threat from Facebook.

site_title: HK, China firms plan joint bid for S'pore-KL high-speed rail project
summary: Hong Kong's MTR Corporation and China Railway Corporation plan to join forces for a joint bid on the high-speed rail project between Singapore and Kuala Lumpur. The 350km rail link is valued at billions of dollars. Industry observers believe a successful partnership could benefit from the collaboration. MTRC chairman Frederick Ma has confirmed the company's intention to partner with CRC.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks fall; TSMC down on profit taking
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell on Tuesday, with the Taiex index down 0.3% at 10,002.27, due to profit taking on Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co Ltd (TSMC). The index had closed above 10,000 for the second time in two weeks on Monday. The decline marks a reversal from the previous session's 0.5% gain.

site_title: Brazil economy expected to show exit from recession
summary: Brazil's economy is expected to exit a two-year recession, according to the Central Bank, which reported 1.12% growth in the first quarter of 2017. The growth is attributed to agriculture, with the services sector still weak. President Michel Temer's government is pushing through reforms to bring finances under control, despite a record 13.7% unemployment rate. The economy is expected to grow overall by 0.5% this year, marking a slow recovery from the worst recession on record in 2015 and 2016.

site_title: GIC sells 2.4% stake in UBS for a loss
summary: Singapore sovereign wealth fund GIC has sold nearly half of its 5.1% stake in UBS Group for a loss, reducing its stake to 2.7%. The sale, worth around US$1.6 billion, was made despite the loss due to fundamental changes in UBS' strategy and business since GIC's initial investment in 2008. GIC cited the need to redeploy resources and take advantage of changing market conditions, with the Citi investment generating sufficient returns to offset the UBS loss.

site_title: North Korea link emerges in global cyberattacks
summary: US security researchers have found potential links to North Korea in the global cyberattack that affected 300,000 computers worldwide, causing widespread disruptions. The "WannaCry" malware showed similarities to a hacking effort attributed to Pyongyang. Experts at Kaspersky and Intezer Labs confirmed the possible North Korea link, while US officials denied any US government involvement. The attack, which demanded ransom payments in Bitcoin, affected hospitals, car factories, and banks worldwide, with some experts warning of a potential "second wave" of attacks.

site_title: Vietnam-aligned hackers attack foreign firms, FireEye says
summary: A group of hackers "aligned with Vietnamese state interests" has been conducting cyberespionage attacks against foreign companies in Vietnam since at least 2014, according to a report by FireEye. The attacks, attributed to APT32, targeted companies in various sectors, including manufacturing, consumer products, and hospitality, as well as foreign governments and journalists. The Vietnamese government has denied involvement in the attacks, but the incident highlights a growing threat of cyberespionage in the region.

site_title: Europe: Shares supported by oil bounce; cybersecurity stocks gain
summary: European shares rose 0.1% on Monday, supported by a 2% surge in oil prices, with Saudi Arabia and Russia pledging to extend supply cuts into 2018. Commodity-related stocks and cybersecurity firms also gained, with some investors citing the need for improved cybersecurity as a growing business opportunity. Despite the gains, investors remained cautious due to the ongoing "ransomware" attack. Meanwhile, Italian motorway company Atlantia rose 2.5% after launching a 16 billion euro bid for Spanish rival Abertis, and German utility RWE posted core profit slightly above expectations.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq end at records as oil shares gain
summary: US stocks ended at records on Monday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq rising 0.5% to new highs. Oil prices surged after a joint statement from Russia and Saudi Arabia called for continued production restraint, boosting energy shares. Chevron, Marathon Oil, and Halliburton rose 0.8%, 1.8%, and 3.0% respectively. Cybersecurity companies advanced following a global cyberattack, while Johnson & Johnson and Thermo Fisher Scientific also saw gains.

site_title: US says Trump did not discuss intel 'sources, methods' with Russians
summary: US President Donald Trump discussed specific terror threats with Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov and Moscow's envoy to the US in the Oval Office, but not "sources or methods" or military operations. National Security Advisor HR McMaster stated that the president and foreign minister reviewed common threats from terrorist organizations, including aviation. The White House confirmed that no classified information was shared and no military operations were disclosed. This comes after The Washington Post reported that Trump revealed classified information to the Russians about a threat posed by the Islamic State group.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump discussed specific terror threats with Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov and Moscow's envoy to the US in the Oval Office last week, but not "sources or methods," senior officials said Monday.

site_title: Oil rises 2% after Saudi Arabia and Russia back longer supply cut
summary: Oil prices rose 2% to their highest in three weeks after Saudi Arabia and Russia announced a nine-month supply cut extension, aiming to support prices beyond the initial six-month deal. The deal, which aims to reduce output by 1.8 million barrels per day, may not be enough to stabilize the market, with analysts suggesting deeper cuts may be needed to counter rising US production.
