The extension is set to last until March 2018, but its success remains uncertain as other producers, including Kazakhstan, have expressed reservations about joining the prolonged reduction.

images.alt_text: Oil jumped more than 2 per cent to its highest in more than three weeks on Monday, topping US$52 a barrel after Saudi Arabia and Russia said that supply cuts need to last into 2018, a step towards extending an Opec-led deal to support prices for longer than first agreed.

site_title: China, India surpass US as most attractive renewables markets: report
summary: China and India have surpassed the US as the most attractive countries for renewable energy investment, according to a report by Ernst & Young. China ranked first, followed by India, while the US fell to third place due to changes in US energy policy under President Trump. China plans to invest $363 billion in renewable power capacity by 2020, and India aims to generate 175 gigawatts of renewable energy by 2022. This shift is attributed to the US's roll back of climate change policies and Trump's focus on reviving the coal industry.

site_title: Who's to blame for ransomware outbreak?
summary: A global ransomware attack, known as "WannaCry," crippled thousands of businesses and public organizations worldwide, exploiting security flaws in Windows versions discovered by the National Security Agency (NSA). Microsoft blames the NSA for the vulnerability, while experts argue the fault is distributed among multiple parties, including the US government, computing public, and businesses that failed to install a patch. The attack highlights the risks of an overreliance on insecure computer systems and the need for improved cybersecurity measures, with no single entity capable of fixing the problem in the near future.

site_title: SPH officially migrates to G Suite
summary: SPH, a Singapore-based media company, has officially migrated to Google's G Suite, replacing Lotus Notes. The move aims to enhance collaboration and productivity across the company. Google Guides were deployed to assist staff with the migration. Deputy CEO Anthony Tan emphasized the importance of digital transformation, stating it will help SPH serve its readers and audiences better. The G Suite migration marks a significant step towards SPH's digital focus, with the goal of becoming a more collaborative and innovative company.

site_title: Starhill Global Reit divests 4th property in Tokyo
summary: Starhill Global Reit divested its 4th property in Tokyo, Harajuku Secondo Property, for 410.2 million yen (S$5.1 million), at a 22.4% premium to its latest valuation. The sale reduces SGReit's Japan portfolio to three properties, lowering its exposure to Japan by 0.1%. The net proceeds will be used to repay yen borrowings and/or for working capital purposes, with minimal impact on SGReit's distribution and net asset value per unit.

site_title: Trump travel ban back in court
summary: A US government attorney defended President Donald Trump's revised travel ban, stating it was not motivated by anti-Muslim bias, in a court hearing in Seattle. The ban, which targets six Muslim-majority countries, was blocked by a Hawaii-based judge in March, citing unconstitutional grounds. The 9th Circuit Court of Appeals is now considering the challenge. The government argues the ban is based on national security concerns, while the state of Hawaii and an imam argue it is a Muslim ban in disguise. The court's decision could reach the Supreme Court, with over a dozen states and companies challenging the ban.

site_title: Yuuzoo Q1 profit falls 13% on loss of client, new accounting policy
summary: Yuuzoo Corp's Q1 net profit fell 13% to S$11.2 million due to a 58% decline in revenue to S$18.9 million. The company lost a major client and adopted a more conservative accounting policy, which resulted in a non-cash revenue of S$14.4 million. Yuuzoo also incurred a net outflow of S$654,000 in cash from operating activities during the quarter. Despite this, the company established a new franchise in the Democratic Republic of Congo and launched a new platform in India.

site_title: Western Digital seeks arbitration in row over Toshiba's chip unit sale
summary: Western Digital has initiated international arbitration against Toshiba, seeking to stop the sale of their joint semiconductor plant without its consent. Toshiba is trying to sell its chip unit to accelerate the sale and secure a capital injection, but Western Digital claims this is a breach of their contract. The arbitration process could delay Toshiba's sale and impact its listing on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. Toshiba values its chip unit at $24.66 billion, with a consortium of US private equity firms and Japanese investors seen as the most likely buyers.

site_title: Macron wins Merkel backing for bid to shake up Europe
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron secured backing from German Chancellor Angela Merkel for his bid to shake up Europe, despite skepticism over his proposed eurozone reforms. Merkel expressed willingness to consider treaty changes if they make sense, but warned that deep-reaching reforms would require significant concessions. Macron proposed setting up a separate budget, parliament, and finance minister for the eurozone, but Merkel's approach suggests that any reforms will be held off until after her reelection in September, limiting Macron's room for maneuver.

site_title: All Industry Transformation Maps have tangible indicators and targets
summary: The Industry Transformation Maps (ITMs) in Singapore have tangible indicators and targets to measure their effectiveness. The ITMs, developed through close consultation with stakeholders, aim to create sustainable growth and good jobs for Singaporeans. The four key areas include transforming the hotel industry to create 200 new PMET jobs annually, increasing retail productivity by 1% annually, and others. The success of the ITMs depends on the ability of all parties to work together in partnership.

site_title: Wal-Mart pushes to catch up with Amazon in e-commerce
summary: Wal-Mart is making a push to catch up with Amazon in e-commerce, spending billions to acquire smaller online players and improve its own platform. The company aims to become a go-to place for "essential" products, such as groceries and holiday gifts, with free shipping and pickup options. Despite its efforts, overtaking Amazon appears unlikely, and the tech giant remains the market leader. Wal-Mart's online investments are a significant shift from its initial reticence in e-commerce, and analysts say it's still early in the game.

site_title: UBS launches new anti-money laundering programme
summary: UBS has launched a three-year anti-money laundering (AML) programme in partnership with the Wealth Management Institute (WMI). The programme aims to enhance AML competencies in the wealth management industry and reinforces Singapore's efforts to fight financial crime. The initiative includes technology-enhanced learning modules, research papers, and forums for senior compliance decision makers. An expert panel of international specialists, including HMRC and Commercial Affairs Department officials, will also be involved. The programme is accredited by the Institute of Banking & Finance and will be made available to industry participants.

site_title: Rules of capitalism are being re-written by the cloud
summary: The digital economy is redefining capitalism, driven by cloud computing, mobility, and the Internet of Things (IoT). This shift has leveled the playing field, enabling startups to compete with established players, and empowering users to determine how and where they consume products and services. As a result, power is shifting to the user, and enterprises must optimize assets, share them with others, and innovate to stay ahead. The combination of cloud, IoT, artificial intelligence, and APIs is creating a platform economy, where fundamental rules of capitalism are being rewritten.

site_title: A US$1 trillion pain trade in the Treasuries divides top bond dealers
summary: The US Treasury is facing a $1 trillion pain trade as the Federal Reserve prepares to unwind its crisis-era bond holdings, potentially disrupting the market. The Fed's pullback and Treasury's increased debt issuance could lead to higher borrowing costs, complicating the Trump administration's pro-growth agenda and public debt. Dealers are divided on which market segments will feel the most pain, with five to seven-year notes and longer-term Treasuries potentially bearing the brunt. The Treasury may need to increase debt issuance by up to 25% over the next two years to fill the funding gap.

site_title: Xi Jinping puts forth a vision of globalisation at Beijing summit
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping positioned himself as a champion of free trade at the one-belt-one-road summit in Beijing, calling for global leaders to fight against protectionism. He outlined the ambitious project to build trade routes from Asia to the Americas via Europe and Africa, with estimated investments of up to $503 billion. The summit aimed to boost investment and trade, with key announcements including additional funding for the Silk Road Fund and financing schemes from China's state-led banks. However, the project faced resistance from some countries, including India and EU nations, which expressed concerns over public procurement and environmental norms.

site_title: Austria heads for snap election as coalition shatters
summary: Austria is heading for a snap parliamentary election after a coalition between the centre-left Social Democrats and the conservative People's Party (OVP) shattered. Chancellor Christian Kern has admitted he can't prevent the election, which could give the far-right Freedom Party (FPO) a chance to enter national government. OVP leader Sebastian Kurz, 30, has been appointed as the party's leader and has been handed sweeping new powers, including the ability to pick the party's list of candidates. The election is seen as a power grab by Kurz, who plans to include people from outside the OVP in the party's list of candidates.

site_title: Forget Russia, US should focus instead on North Korea
summary: The US should focus on North Korea instead of Russia, given the mounting threat of the country's nuclear military program and missile development. Despite President Trump's bombastic rhetoric and incoherent response, the administration's efforts to pressure North Korea have been ineffective, leading to diplomatic tensions with Seoul. The recent election of left-leaning President Moon Jae-in has further complicated the situation, as he has called for a diplomatic détente between Seoul and Pyongyang. With no signs of new strategies to resolve the crisis, the US's approach to North Korea remains unsustainable and could ignite diplomatic tensions.

site_title: Tibetan medicine lures patients seeking drug-free cures
summary: Tibetan medicine, also known as Sowa-Rigpa, is gaining popularity worldwide for its drug-free cures. The ancient practice combines blood-letting, cupping, and moxibustion with spiritual practices like meditation and Buddhist prayer to treat ailments such as back pain, cancer, and degenerative diseases. Devotees claim its effectiveness, although few scientific studies have been conducted. As its popularity grows, nations like China and India are scrambling to claim it as their own, with India officially recognizing Tibetan medicine as a "science of healing" in 2010.

site_title: CDL launches sustainability blueprint for its business
summary: City Developments Limited (CDL) has launched its sustainability blueprint, CDL Future Value 2030, aiming to reduce carbon emissions by 38% and waste by 50% by 2030, aligning with Singapore's commitments to the Paris Agreement and Sustainable Singapore Blueprint. The company's long-term ESG goals and targets are set to support its growth while building a sustainable future, as CEO Grant Kelley noted that businesses can no longer ignore the impact of climate change risks on their bottom line.

images.alt_text: Aligning with the nation's commitment to the Paris agreement, Climate Action Plan and the Sustainable Singapore Blueprint, City Developments Limited (CDL) introduced its new sustainability blueprint CDL Future Value 2030 on Monday.

site_title: Noble shares continue to sink
summary: Noble Group's shares plummeted 11% on concerns over its future profitability and debt obligations, extending a 48% decline. The stock hit its lowest in over 15 years, closing at 59 cents. The company reported a US$129.3 million loss despite revenue growth, attributing it to coal market dislocation and higher oil prices. Analysts warn that Noble might need to restructure if operations don't improve, with a potential strategic investor identified as China's Sinochem Group.

site_title: Businesses in Asia face disruption from malware
summary: Cybersecurity experts warn of a wider impact from the WannaCry ransomware worm, which has locked up over 200,000 computers in 150 countries, mainly spread by e-mail. The Asian region, including Singapore, experienced disruptions as employees checked e-mails and turned on computers. The ransomware affected various sectors, including factories, hospitals, shops, and schools worldwide, but the extent of the disruption remains relatively contained.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Several Singaporean companies reported mixed quarterly earnings. Straits Trading Company's net profit fell 2.7% to S$21.9 million, while Sinarmas Land's net profit surged 136.6% to S$37.2 million. Yongnam Holdings posted a net loss of S$1.5 million, while UOB Kay Hian's net profit rose 39.4% to S$19.7 million. ASL Marine and Mermaid Maritime also reported losses, with ASL Marine posting an S$11.7 million loss and Mermaid's net profit shrinking 41.7% to US$735,000.

site_title: Olam's Q1 earnings up 26.5% at S$143.8m
summary: Olam International reported a 26.5% increase in Q1 net profit to S$143.8 million, driven by a 21.9% rise in sales revenue and 50.5% growth in sales volumes. Three of five segments achieved healthy growth, with the edible nuts, spices, and vegetable ingredients segment experiencing an 18.8% revenue increase and 72.1% Ebitda growth. The company's earnings per share rose to 4.79 Singapore cents, and no dividend was declared.

images.alt_text: Mr Verghese says the first-quarter results reflect continued progress in pursuing growth in "priority clusters" and constant rebalancing of portfolio mix.
Anita Gabriel

site_title: China real estate investment up in April despite curbs
summary: China's real estate investment rose 9.6% in April from the same period last year, despite government curbs aimed at cooling the market. Sales growth slowed to 7.7% in April, the lowest since December 2015, but new construction starts increased 11.1% in the first four months. Analysts suggest the market may have peaked, and investment lags behind sales trends. Tightened liquidity and lending restrictions have been implemented to curb credit risks, but prices in China's biggest cities are likely to rebound if government curbs are relaxed.

site_title: Spackman achieves Q1 profit on revenue from Master
summary: Spackman Entertainment Group reported a first-quarter net profit of US$4.8 million, a significant improvement from a net loss of US$966,000 in the same period last year, driven by distribution revenue from the 2016 film Master. The company's per-share profit was 1.04 US cents, up from 0.21 US cents per share a year ago. This marks a substantial turnaround for the film production company, which had previously reported a net loss.

site_title: Chinese money setting sail for Caribbean with new bank
summary: The British Virgin Islands (BVI) has launched the Bank of Asia (BVI) Ltd, its first bank in over 20 years, to cater to the growing demand from Chinese companies and wealthy individuals seeking tax-friendly jurisdictions for overseas acquisitions. The bank aims to receive a huge flow of funds from China and help restore the BVI's dwindling source of revenue, which depends on incorporations for half its budget. The bank's launch has been delayed due to regulatory approval, but it will offer online banking services and require customers to pass at least four layers of identity and compliance checks to mitigate transparency issues.

site_title: Croesus available DPU for Q3 up 15.2%
summary: Croesus Retail Trust reported a 15.2% increase in available distribution per unit to 2.05 Singapore cents for Q3, driven by acquisitions and improved tenant sales. The trust's distributable income rose 25.4% to 1.28 billion yen, with a 9-month income available for distribution of 3.61 billion yen.

site_title: STI gets surprise boost from Genting
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) saw a surprise boost from Genting Singapore, with the casino operator's S$0.07 jump to S$1.15, driving the index's gain of 8.92 points. However, the broad market did not mirror the STI's strength, with 202 rises versus 271 falls. Genting's first-quarter net profit more than tripled, with analysts maintaining "buy" calls and target prices. Despite the STI's strength, the broad market's performance was muted, with turnover at 2.8 billion units worth S$1.4 billion.

site_title: Greater digitisation 'could increase cybersecurity risk for aviation sector'
summary: The aviation sector's increasing digitisation may raise cybersecurity risks due to modernised air traffic control systems, inflight entertainment and wi-fi connectivity, and electronic flight bags. These systems, which rely on various networks and the Internet, can create vulnerabilities for hackers. Industry watchers warn that the growing digitisation of the aviation sector may lead to an increase in hacking opportunities.

images.alt_text: An announcement of the encryption of data on an electronic timetable display at Frankfurt's railway station. Cyber-attacks can range hacking aircraft navigation and control systems or airport ground systems to stealing data linked to credit cards or frequent-flyer programmes.
Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: SMRT should consider farming out retail space ops
summary: SMRT Corporation may consider farming out its retail space operations to focus on its core business of delivering high-quality rail services. With the Land Transport Authority (LTA) now owning SMRT's rail operating assets, the company can concentrate on operations and maintenance. SMRT may adopt a mall management contract approach or appoint a master tenant to manage its retail space at train stations, offering a fixed rental payment and potential for higher rewards if occupancy rates improve. This move could help SMRT navigate the structural downturn in the retail sector in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Use of large-scale surgery database grows in Japan
summary: Japan is progressing in utilizing a large-scale database of nearly all surgical procedures performed in the country to better understand data and analyze trends in surgical outcomes. The National Clinical Database, operated by the Japan Surgical Society, aims to improve the quality of medical care at individual hospitals and help patients select hospitals. The database records data on surgeries performed nationwide and is accessible to individual doctors via the internet. This initiative is expected to enhance the accuracy of national average mortality rates and provide valuable insights into surgical outcomes.

site_title: US firms want in on One Belt, One Road spending
summary: US firms are seeking to participate in China's One Belt, One Road initiative, which aims to invest over $1 trillion in infrastructure across Asia, Africa, and Europe. Despite skepticism that Chinese companies will dominate the effort, US companies like General Electric are placing large orders for equipment, with a total of $7 billion in orders planned in the next 18 months. The initiative could lead to significant global trade and economic growth, but also poses risks of debt and uncertainty for businesses involved.

site_title: China's high-stakes game poses major challenge to US
summary: China's One Belt One Road (OBOR) initiative, a modern-day Silk Road, aims to link Asia, Africa, and Europe with investments exceeding $1 trillion over the next decade. The initiative involves capturing logistics and supply chains in the South China Sea, and beyond, including the Mediterranean and East Africa. China has already invested $50 billion in OBOR-related projects and dominates trade with Southeast Asian countries. The US needs to devise a strategy to compete with China and maintain its role as a Pacific power, particularly in Southeast Asia, where Chinese influence is growing.

site_title: April new home sales more than double year-ago showing: URA
summary: Singapore's new home sales more than doubled in April from the previous year, with 1,555 private homes sold, excluding executive condominiums. This represents a 12.6% drop from March, but is a significant increase from the 750 units sold in April 2016. The market remains sensitive to loan curbs and cooling measures, with median unit prices ranging from S$870,000 to S$1.37 million. The number of new units released in April dropped by 52.9% compared to March, but demand for previously launched developments remains stable.

site_title: Maersk may scale down reliance on debt markets in the near future
summary: Maersk, the world's largest container shipping company, may scale down its reliance on debt markets in the near future due to ample liquidity and plans to cut capital expenditure. CFO Jakob Staus-holm cited the company's energy business divestment plans as a complication in tapping debt markets. Maersk has not issued any bonds since the first half of 2016 and instead turned to banks for financing, including a recent $4 billion syndicated loan facility for a US acquisition. The company aims to list, sell, or split off its energy units by the end of 2018.

site_title: SGX says its trading systems well-protected
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has assured investors that its trading systems are well-protected from cyber attacks, particularly the ransomware bug that blocks access to data until a ransom is paid. In a statement, SGX's head of information security, Tee Chun Meng, confirmed that the exchange has taken necessary measures to secure its technology environment against the threat.

site_title: Luxembourg lurks in the dark as regulators light up shadow banking
summary: Luxembourg, a major hub for non-bank lending in the EU, has not contributed data to the Financial Stability Board's (FSB) annual study on global trends and risks in shadow banking. The country, home to significant investment funds and securitisation vehicles, remains in the shadows, unlike other countries such as Singapore and Brazil that participated in the review. The FSB has cited data gaps as a challenge, with regulators seeking to better understand the risks posed by shadow banking, which helped cause the 2008 credit crisis.

site_title: Expanding beyond Singapore
summary: Singapore businesses are expanding beyond the home market, driven by technology, but also face challenges. Industry leaders discuss opportunities and pitfalls in internationalization, including navigating complex regulatory environments and managing cultural differences. Meanwhile, Singapore's financial sector continues to thrive, with key developments including the appointment of Tan Teck Long as OCBC's incoming CEO and Helen Wong's retirement. The country's economic growth is also under scrutiny, with China's GDP growth expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Japan's ramen chain takes on US foodie scene for overseas growth
summary: Ippudo, a Japanese ramen chain, plans to open its first US outlets in San Francisco and Berkeley this year, marking a global expansion effort that aims to quadruple overseas shops in 20 countries by 2025. The company, which raised $8.5 million in its March IPO, has faced challenges adapting its rich tonkotsu pork broth and noodle styles to Western tastes. With plans to open additional locations in New York City and tap emerging markets like South-east Asia, Ippudo is targeting the US foodie scene to boost its international presence.

images.alt_text: Chikaranomoto operates about 130 restaurants in Japan.
A bowl of Akamaru Shin-aji ramen.
Mr Kiyomiya says South-east Asia is another international market the company plans to tap.

site_title: Oil bounce drives up Canadian, Aussie dollars
summary: The Canadian dollar reached its highest level in over two weeks and the Australian dollar hit a 12-day high due to a 2% increase in oil prices, which pushed up commodity-linked currencies. The Canadian dollar rose 0.7% to C$1.3609 per dollar, while the Australian dollar rose 0.8% to US$0.7444. This recovery is attributed to Saudi Arabia and Russia's agreement to extend oil output cuts until March 2018, with speculators also taking a more optimistic view on the euro following Emmanuel Macron's victory in France's presidential election.

site_title: Guten Gefilte! Jewish delicacies beguile Berlin
summary: In Berlin, a resurgence of Jewish cuisine is underway, thanks to the influx of young Jewish immigrants from North America, Israel, and Eastern Europe. Chefs like Jeffrey Yoskowitz and Laurel Kratochvila are reviving traditional dishes like gefilte fish, bagels, and blintzes, while also incorporating local ingredients and modern twists. The Nosh Berlin festival, which celebrated Jewish cuisine, marked a turning point in the community's efforts to reclaim its cultural heritage. With increased visibility and tourism, Berlin's Jewish community is experiencing a revival, but some worry about cultural appropriation and superficiality.

site_title: Perennial sees Light in northern Malaysian state of Penang
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings Ltd has invested in an RM4.5 billion integrated waterfront development in Penang, Malaysia, called The Light City (TLC). CEO Pua Seck Guan believes the project will add value and be monetized in the future. The joint venture with IJM Land will feature a retail mall, convention center, luxury hotels, office tower, and residential towers. Perennial expects an internal rate of return of at least 12% in Malaysia, with plans to market residential units in Singapore later this year. The project aims to capitalize on Penang's tourism boom and growing MICE market.

images.alt_text: On the joint-venture The Light City, Mr Pua said "long term, we think we can create one of the best projects in the region".

site_title: S'pore consortium named master developer for India city
summary: A Singaporean consortium, comprising Ascendas-Singbridge and Sembcorp Development, has been named master developer for India's new capital city, Amaravati, in the southern state of Andhra Pradesh. The 6.84 sq km financial district will be developed over 15-20 years and is expected to spur economic growth across an 8,000-sq-km region, home to over 10 million people by 2050. The development is part of a strategic partnership between Singapore and Andhra Pradesh, with the aim of creating a "People's Capital" that showcases India's economic potential.

site_title: How US$74b in bonds bankrupted Puerto Rico
summary: Puerto Rico's debt crisis began with a massive borrowing spree, resulting in $74 billion in bonds that bankrupted the island. The debt was used for grand projects, everyday expenses, and bureaucracy, with officials failing to track expenditures. The island's government has no central office overseeing bond spending, leading to widespread corruption and mismanagement. The debt has doubled since 2006, with the commonwealth's outstanding debt now exceeding $74 billion, and the rating has fallen to junk status. Thousands of people have fled the island, and the economy remains struggling.

site_title: Riyadh, Moscow agree to extend oil supply cuts till March 2018
summary: Saudi Arabia and Russia agree to extend oil supply cuts until March 2018 to reduce global crude inventories to their five-year average. The deal, which aims to rein in a global glut, follows a previous agreement and is expected to secure support from other producers. The move is seen as a bid to push up prices, which have languished around $50 per barrel, and to secure access to the Asian market. The agreement is expected to push the market into a small deficit by the fourth quarter if maintained at current levels, but the impact may be undermined by US shale producers, which have ramped up output this year.

site_title: Carney's optimism on UK wage growth challenged by report
summary: The UK's labour market is expected to face a "rockier" future, limiting wage growth, according to EY Item Club's forecasts. In contrast to Bank of England Governor Mark Carney's medium-term outlook, EY predicts negligible real wage gains and nominal improvements of less than 3% through 2020. The economic forecasting group attributes this to a slowing economy and lower demand for workers, leading to a potential drop in joblessness and stagnating real pay growth.

site_title: Keeping things clean and clear at Porcelain
summary: Porcelain, a Singapore-based skincare business, is undergoing a transformation to simplify its treatment menu and customer experience. Co-founder Pauline Ng aims to eliminate redundancy and make choices clearer for customers. The company values transparency, autonomy, and teamwork, and has implemented a system where employees are trusted to work independently. Ng also emphasizes the importance of communication and understanding in family businesses, advising her mother to trust her and give her confidence. Porcelain is rebranding itself as "Porcelain 2.0," introducing customized treatment plans and streamlining its operations to better serve customers.

images.alt_text: Ms Ng says the company does not track staff attendance. Instead, employees have scorecards for goals and performance. She also strives to keep negativity and politics out, and has let go even high performers, because their attitude and behaviour were causing problems.

site_title: Three Wharton dealmakers set sights on China trucking industry
summary: Three Wharton graduates, Richard Peng, Richard Ji, and Richard Zhang, have co-founded Truck Alliance Inc, a company aiming to disrupt China's trillion-dollar trucking industry. The company uses an Uber-like platform to match drivers with cargo, reducing the time spent by drivers searching for shipments. With a valuation of over $1 billion, Truck Alliance has raised $270 million, competing with other startups and government-funded services. The company faces challenges, including competition, dirty tricks from rivals, and potential job losses for brokers, but its founders are optimistic about the potential for significant returns.

site_title: Australian gas squeeze bolsters Chinese turbine maker's southern push
summary: Australia's rising natural gas prices are driving up power tariffs, boosting prospects for China's wind turbine maker Goldwind Australia. The company secured the rights to build the 530MW Stockyard Hill project in Victoria for A$110 million, beating at least 10 rivals. The project is the largest wind farm in the southern hemisphere and marks Goldwind Australia's expansion in the region. The move is seen as a significant opportunity for the company to establish a presence in the Australian market.

site_title: Cruise ships navigate geopolitics, local competition to tap vast Chinese market
summary: Luxury cruise lines, including Royal Caribbean and Carnival Corp, are navigating the Chinese market, which has seen a 10-fold increase in passengers over the past five years. To cater to Chinese tastes, these companies are adapting their offerings, tailoring their ships with authentic Chinese cuisine, entertainment, and activities. They are also focusing on multigenerational holidays, with family-oriented cruises becoming increasingly popular. However, local Chinese companies are also entering the market, with Shanghai Waigaoqiao Shipbuilding Co building two big cruise ships worth $1.5 billion, posing a challenge to foreign operators.

site_title: GIC to sell up to 2.4% stake in UBS
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC plans to sell up to 2.4% stake in UBS through an accelerated bookbuild offering to institutional investors. The sale is equivalent to 93 million existing shares and will be conducted in Zurich. UBS shares initially fell 1% before recovering to 0.7%.

site_title: CNMC Q1 profit down 99% on lower ore grades
summary: CNMC Goldmine Holdings reported a 99% decline in Q1 net profit to US$54,834, due to lower ore grades affecting production and sales volume. Revenue fell 44% to US$4.73 million, and all-in costs of production rose to US$983 a tonne. To improve gold recovery, the company plans to build a carbon-in-leach plant, which will be operational later this year. The plant aims to achieve a 95% gold recovery rate, with a higher grade ore feed from the southern part of the Sokor project.

site_title: How ransomware works
summary: A ransomware attack involves a cybercriminal encrypting a victim's files and demanding payment in exchange for the decryption key. The attacker typically gains access through phishing, malware, or exploited vulnerabilities. Once the files are encrypted, the attacker demands payment, often in cryptocurrency. If the payment is not made, the attacker may delete or destroy the files, leading to significant data loss. Effective prevention measures include regular backups, secure software updates, and employee education on cybersecurity best practices.

site_title: SingPost slides to 12-month low after TradeGlobal writedown
summary: SingPost shares hit a 12-month low of S$1.29 after the company reported disappointing results, including a S$185 million writedown on TradeGlobal and a cut in dividend payout. Analysts downgraded the stock, citing concerns over the company's e-commerce business growth and valuation. SingPost has launched a review of the TradeGlobal acquisition. The company's cash flow generation remains strong, but an earnings turnaround is expected in FY18.

site_title: China's economy loses steam as policymakers clamp down on debt risks
summary: China's economy experienced a slowdown in April, with factory output, investment, and retail sales all showing below-forecast growth. The country's policymakers have tightened regulations on debt risks in an effort to prevent a potential economic hit. Despite this, China's central bank is guiding short-term interest rates higher to contain debt risks while avoiding harming economic growth. The country's growth target has been cut to 6.5% for the year, and analysts predict a continued investment-driven growth strategy.

site_title: Brazilian banks turn up heat on scandal-hit Odebrecht
summary: Brazilian conglomerate Odebrecht SA has agreed to accelerate asset sales and surrender dividends from its petrochemicals unit Braskem SA to creditor banks as part of a deal to resolve its financial woes. The agreement, reached after a plea deal with prosecutors, allows Odebrecht to keep US$800 million from the sale of its water and waste unit, enough to fund its cash needs for two years. The deal marks a tougher stance by creditor banks, who have grown increasingly assertive in their demands for the company to put its house in order.

site_title: US homeowners are now staying put longer
summary: Homeowners in the US are staying put longer, with the median tenure rising to 8.5 years in 2017, up from 3.5 years in 2008. This trend is attributed to higher interest rates, which make it more expensive for homeowners to refinance or upgrade. As a result, the economy is experiencing a drag, with fewer commissions for brokers and a competitive market for first-time homebuyers. Economists expect this trend to continue for the next decade, weighing on consumer spending and the economy.

site_title: Insurers dragging their feet over new accounting standard: PwC
summary: Insurers are struggling to prepare for the International Finance Reporting Standard (IFRS) 17, which aims to improve transparency and comparability of profit reporting. The new standard, set to take effect in 2021, will require insurers to value all insurance liabilities, increasing comparability between insurers and other financial institutions. Insurers have been slow to adapt, citing concerns about granularity, retrospective adjustments, and high implementation costs, estimated to be in the hundreds of millions. Experts warn that insurers will need to update systems and train staff to meet the new standard, which will also impact tax assessments and regulatory returns.

site_title: GoldenAgri hit by absence of forex gain
summary: Golden Agri-Resources reported a 60.1% year-on-year decline in net profit to US$37.6 million in Q1 2017, despite revenue growth of 37% to US$2 billion. The absence of a foreign exchange gain in the current quarter compared to a US$51.9 million gain in the year-ago period contributed to the decline. Revenue and gross profit rose, but lower margins resulted in a 10.9% increase in gross profit. The company maintained its strategy to enhance integration and operational excellence to improve margins in the long term.

site_title: Merkel's hand strengthened by German voters ahead of summits
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel is gaining momentum ahead of Germany's September election, strengthening her position at home and globally. Her party's recent victory in a key state election highlights her popularity among voters. Merkel is expected to defend the European Union, free trade, and rebuff US President Donald Trump's pressure to accelerate defense spending.

site_title: Vietnamese emperor's Rolex sells for record US$5m
summary: A Rolex owned by Vietnam's last emperor, Bao Dai, sold for a record US$5 million at Phillips Geneva auction. The 1954 Rolex, known as the "Bao Dai", is one of three black-dial models with diamond hour markers and was sold to an unidentified phone bidder. The sale marks a victory for Phillips, which dominated the high-end market for vintage watch auctions, beating larger rivals Sotheby's and Christie's, which had failed to sell several high-end timepieces, including a Patek Philippe pocket watch estimated at US$6.4 million.

site_title: Injunction hearing on Rickmers' proposed US$113m asset sale adjourned
summary: A Singaporean High Court has adjourned the hearing of an injunction filed by a noteholder against the proposed $113 million sale of the Rickmers Maritime shipping trust's fleet. The injunction, filed by Peter Kwok Kian Tow, sought to block the sale, claiming it would result in under-valued prices and insufficient cash recoveries for creditors. The adjournment was granted to May 22, with directions for parties to exchange affidavits. The case may test the limits of noteholders' rights against insolvent entities.

site_title: US, EU to meet on airline security on Wednesday: EU Commission
summary: US and EU officials will meet on airline security on Wednesday to discuss a possible extension of the laptop ban and address new threats. The US has restricted passengers from bringing devices larger than cellphones onto flights from 10 airports, citing fears of bomb concealment. The EU is concerned about fire risks from lithium-ion batteries in the hold, and regulators are exploring solutions such as new fire extinguishing systems and stronger baggage containers. The meeting aims to jointly assess new threats and work towards a common approach to address them.

images.alt_text: European Union and US officials will meet on Wednesday to discuss airline security, including a possible extension of a ban on passengers carrying laptops in aircraft cabins, a European Commission spokesman said.

site_title: Golden Energy's coal mining division boosts Q1 profit
summary: Golden Energy and Resources (GEAR) reported a 11,000% increase in Q1 net profit to US$19.0 million, driven by a 48% year-on-year revenue boost from its coal mining division. Revenue from coal mining rose to US$129.4 million, while coal trading and forestry revenue declined. The company expects the global coal industry's outlook to remain positive, with robust thermal coal demand in key export markets, particularly China and India.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: WannaCry, variants could escalate as many users yet to apply patches
summary: The WannaCry ransomware attack, affecting 200,000 computers in 150 countries, including Singapore, has not yet escalated significantly. Despite a lack of critical sector hits, less than US$50,000 in ransom is believed to have been paid. The virus, which restricts access to computers until a ransom is paid, is a type of malicious software that uses bitcoins as payment. The Singapore Cyber Security Agency has confirmed no critical sectors have been hit, and efforts to patch affected systems continue.

site_title: Big banks would have beefed up their security: IBM official
summary: Big banks in Singapore may have beefed up their security measures amid the WannaCry ransomware outbreak, according to IBM official Gene Ng. Despite the absence of major global banks being hit, heightened awareness of cyber threats suggests financial institutions are taking proactive steps. Ransomware, a form of malware that demands payment in exchange for file access, has seen a surge in recent years, with its presence in spam emails increasing from 0.6% in 2015 to 40% in 2016.

images.alt_text: While organisations are expected to be on high alert over the rapid spread of ransomware known as WannaCry, the absence of large global banks as confirmed hits over the weekend may speak of the heightened awareness of financial institutions of cyber threats, for now.

site_title: Dual-class shares: Commercial viability shouldn't be equated with corporate governance
summary: A Singaporean columnist, Jackson Lim, argues that the proposed implementation of dual-class shares (DCS) in the local market is being unfairly portrayed by a recent letter to the editor, which he believes is biased towards DCS. Lim questions the assumption that DCS is commercially viable and equates it with good corporate governance, citing potential risks and detriments. He also highlights the need for prudential concerns to be prioritized over the desire to remain competitive, and suggests that the link between DCS and investment merits is tenuous at best.

site_title: Feasting on art at the Venice Biennale
summary: The 57th edition of the Venice Biennale opened to the public, featuring a central exhibition and 85 national pavilions showcasing contemporary art. Germany won the top prize for its pavilion, which included a performance work by young artist Anne Imhof. The event drew large crowds and was marked by a festive atmosphere, with collectors and partygoers attending the preview. The Biennale is considered the world's most distinguished exhibition of international contemporary art, attracting museum exhibitions, pop-up shows, and public sculptures. It is seen as an art-world Olympics, with prizes awarded for the best pavilions and main show participants.

site_title: Will robots destroy jobs and result in high joblessness?
summary: A study by the Information Technology & Innovation Foundation found that technological disruption, including automation, has not led to high joblessness in the US economy. Since 1850, technological advancements have created new job opportunities, offsetting job losses in other sectors. The study's authors, Robert Atkinson and John Wu, analyzed how technology affected occupations in each decade, finding that the impact is often less than in the past. The US economy's ability to adapt and create new jobs has been a strength, with technological changes creating consumer demand for new goods and services.

site_title: Lyft, Waymo launch self-driving vehicle partnership
summary: Lyft and Waymo, a self-driving car unit of Alphabet Inc, have launched a partnership to develop and deploy self-driving vehicles. The deal allows Waymo's technology to reach more people and places, while Lyft will continue its existing self-driving partnership with General Motors. The partnership comes as the ride-sharing industry and technology companies compete to develop self-driving technology, expected to transform transportation in the coming years. Neither company disclosed details of the agreement, which was reported earlier by the New York Times.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Indonesia detains a Trafigura employee in a US$17 billion graft case. Meanwhile, OCBC's incoming CEO Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, will succeed outgoing CEO Helen Wong. Singapore stocks continue their 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. CGSI downgrades Grab to 'hold' due to expected earnings growth slowdown in H2. Sats CEO Kerry Mok's pay rises 30.5% to S$3.1 million. MAS and PBOC to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: The Twilight Zone aka Trump's Washington
summary: US President Donald Trump's administration may be stuck in a "Twilight Zone" of politics, where Americans are unable to escape the turmoil. This is reminiscent of the classic TV series, where characters found themselves trapped in alternate realities with no escape. The comparison is drawn by the author, referencing Trump's Washington as a "political nightmare" post-Watergate. The article suggests that Trump's policies and actions have led to a sense of hopelessness among Americans, with no clear way to move forward or escape the current situation.

site_title: Chinese dental group Aoxin Q&M unveils two possible acquisitions
summary: Chinese dental group Aoxin Q&M plans to acquire two companies: Shenyang Qingaomei Oral Restorative Technology Co for 16.9 million yuan, and Zhuanghe City Chengguan Street Jiadawei Dental Clinic for 8.4 million yuan. The acquisitions aim to expand Aoxin's presence in dental-related industries in northern China, with synergy between dental services and laboratory services. The deals are expected to be completed through cash and investment in the target companies.

site_title: Local organisations must do better in cybersecurity war
summary: Singaporean organizations, including startups, must prioritize cybersecurity to tackle the increasing threat of cyberattacks. Despite 81% confidence in cyber resilience, only 53% actively check for security, according to a study by LogRhythm. Experts warn that prevention alone is not enough, and detection and neutralization of threats are crucial. The Singapore government is closely monitoring the situation, while smaller companies, including startups, are urged to adopt proportionate cybersecurity measures and build integrated responses to cyber threats.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: Indonesia has detained a Trafigura employee in a US$17 billion graft case. Helen Wong will retire as OCBC CEO, with Tan Teck Long named her successor. Singapore stocks have seen a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. MAS and the PBOC plan to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. CGSI has downgraded Grab to 'hold' due to expected earnings growth slowdown in H2. Sats CEO Kerry Mok's pay has increased by 30.5% to S$3.1 million.

site_title: Google's job security, work-life balance top draw for local undergrads
summary: Google has been chosen as the best company to work for by business and commerce students in Singapore's four main universities for the third consecutive year, surpassing A*Star. Attracting students is not just about pay and perks, with 67% citing work-life balance as their top priority. This marks the fifth year in a row that work-life balance has been the top concern for students polled. Google's enduring popularity is attributed to its commitment to providing a balance between career and personal life.

site_title: Cyberattacks level off after global pushback, but fears persist
summary: A global ransomware attack, affecting 150 countries, has largely subsided in Europe after cyber security officials pushed back. The attack, which hit hundreds of thousands of computers, was attributed to the US, not Russia, by Microsoft. President Vladimir Putin denied Russia's involvement. Despite the decrease in attacks, fears persist, with Microsoft urging governments to take action to prevent future attacks.

site_title: Noble Group saviour Brough is turnaround specialist
summary: Noble Group Ltd has appointed Paul Brough, a renowned turnaround specialist, as chairman amidst the company's precarious situation. Brough, who has a history of restructuring Asia's highest-profile corporate collapses, aims to conduct a strategic review and explore strategic alternatives to revive the embattled commodity trader. Noble Group faces significant challenges, including falling commodities prices, mounting debt, and accusations of improper accounting, with its stock and bonds plummeting. Moody's Investors Service has downgraded Noble to Caa1, citing insufficient liquidity to cover its debts.

site_title: China Jinjiang Environment's Q1 profit up 6.8%, secures second project in India
summary: China Jinjiang Environment's Q1 profit rose 6.8% to 127.4 million yuan, despite revenue dipping 3.6% year-over-year. The company secured a concession for a waste treatment project in India, with a 22-year build-operate-transfer model. Total investment in the project is approximately 2.53 billion rupees. This marks the company's second project in India, following a previous one.

site_title: AIG CEO Duperreault says he's not planning to break up insurer
summary: AIG CEO Brian Duperreault stated that he has no plans to break up the company, contradicting activist Carl Icahn's call for a split into three firms. Duperreault emphasized the benefits of AIG's multi-line structure and pledged to deploy capital to expand and grow businesses, aiming to build long-term shareholder value. He succeeds Peter Hancock, who departed due to insufficient investor support. Icahn expressed satisfaction with AIG's recent changes, stating that the activist strategy continues to create value for all shareholders.

site_title: Oil rises above US$52 as Saudis and Russia back longer supply cut
summary: Oil prices rose to their highest in three weeks, surpassing $52 a barrel, after Saudi Arabia and Russia announced they would extend supply cuts until March 2018. Energy ministers from the two countries stated that the cuts should last nine months to support prices. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and other producers initially agreed to cut output by 1.8 million barrels per day for the first half of 2017, with a possible six-month extension. The move aims to stabilize prices, but analysts remain skeptical about Russia's willingness to actively participate in extended cuts.

site_title: How to sell stuff to the millennial customer
summary: Millennials, born between 1982 and 2000, are the largest population worldwide, with over 83 million in the US alone, boasting $600 billion in consumer buying power. SMEs must adapt to their needs, which include instant gratification through self-service solutions and live chat, as well as social media engagement and a commitment to socially responsible practices. To serve millennials effectively, businesses must prioritize quick responses, align with their values, and demonstrate a higher purpose beyond profits. By doing so, SMEs can build a loyal customer base and stay competitive in the market.

site_title: Valuemax's Q1 profit surges 41.1% to S$4.9m
summary: Valuemax Group's net profit for Q1 2017 increased 41.1% to S$4.9 million, despite a 9.2% drop in revenue to S$61.1 million. The company's earnings per share rose to 0.93 Singapore cents and net asset value per share edged up to 31.98 Singapore cents. Valuemax shares finished at S$0.265, 1.852% lower, on the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Dyna-Mac sinks deeper into the red with S$13.9m Q1 loss
summary: Dyna-Mac Holdings reported a widened net loss of S$13.9 million for Q1 2017, with revenue plummeting 88% to S$10.1 million due to lower project volumes. The company currently has a net order book of S$6.3 million and is bracing for a challenging market environment. Management is focusing on right-sizing the group to secure potential projects amidst the difficult market conditions.

images.alt_text: ENGINEERING and fabrication firm Dyna-Mac Holdings' loss widened in the first quarter of 2017, as revenue plunged 88 per cent.

site_title: Vodafone sells US$2.6b Safaricom stake to South Africa unit
summary: Vodafone Group Plc sold a $2.6 billion stake in Safaricom Ltd, Kenya's largest mobile operator, to its majority-owned unit Vodacom Group Ltd in an all-share deal. The transaction gives Vodacom a 70% stake in Safaricom and access to its M-Pesa mobile-banking service. The deal simplifies Vodafone's African holdings and concentrates its assets in Vodacom, allowing for greater management control. Vodacom plans to grow the M-Pesa business across Africa, positioning itself as the continent's largest financial services player.

site_title: 'Excess' car pollution killed 38,000 in 2015: study
summary: A study published in the journal Nature estimated that excess car and truck pollution, primarily from nitrogen oxide emissions, caused approximately 38,000 premature deaths worldwide in 2015. The majority of these deaths occurred in the European Union, China, and India, with commercial trucks and buses accounting for the largest share of excess emissions. The study found that diesel vehicles emitted at least 50% more nitrogen oxide emissions under real-world conditions than reported by manufacturers. The researchers predict that diesel NOx pollution will cause over 183,000 premature deaths per year by 2040.

site_title: Canada home resales fall in April as market cooling begins
summary: Canada's home resales fell 1.7% in April from March record highs, marking the beginning of a market slowdown. New listings spiked, easing the sales-to-new listings ratio to 60.1% from 67.3% in March. Sales declined in 70% of markets, led by Toronto, where new measures were introduced to cool the market. Despite slower sales, home prices surged 19.8% from last year, and the national average price rose 10.4% to C$559,317.

site_title: Straits Trading Q1 net profit slips 2.7%
summary: Straits Trading Company's Q1 net profit decreased 2.7% to S$21.9 million, down from S$22.6 million last year, with revenue falling 4.7% to S$130 million. The real estate investment vehicle, Straits Real Estate, continues to seek new opportunities, while Malaysia Smelting Corporation faces volatile market conditions. The company's stock closed unchanged at S$2.31.

site_title: Li Ka-shing exploring options for fixed-line Hutchison unit sale
summary: Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing is exploring options for selling his fixed-line phone business, Hutchison Global Communications Ltd, which may fetch at least $1 billion. The move follows a similar sale by local tycoon Peter Woo and comes amid declining sales and earnings for Hutchison Telecom. The company's shares have lost over half their value since 2013, and experts say the business has reached its peak. A potential sale would be the latest in a series of disposals by Li's conglomerate, CK Hutchison Holdings Ltd.

site_title: China, Vietnam agree to keep South China Sea tensions in check
summary: China and Vietnam agreed to manage and control their maritime disputes in the South China Sea, avoiding actions that could complicate the situation. The joint statement, released after talks between Chinese President Xi Jinping and Vietnamese President Tran Dai Quang, stressed the need to maintain peace and stability in the region. China claims 90% of the South China Sea, while Vietnam, along with other countries, lays claim to parts of the route through which $5 trillion of trade passes annually. The agreement aims to prevent further escalation of tensions in the region.

site_title: mm2 ties up with Turner Asia Pacific to produce five films
summary: mm2 Entertainment Pte Ltd, a wholly owned subsidiary of film producer mm2 Asia, has agreed to co-produce five cinematic films with Turner Asia Pacific, a Time Warner company, over the next three years. The collaboration aims to maximize commercial value and audience reach. The first film, Wonder Boy, a biopic about Singaporean singer Dick Lee, is scheduled for release on August 3. mm2 CEO Chang Long Jong expressed excitement about the partnership, stating they look forward to co-producing an exciting slate of films.

site_title: Singapore 'vending machine' dispenses Ferraris, Lamborghinis
summary: A luxury car vending machine in Singapore, operated by Autobahn Motors, allows customers to select a vehicle from a touchscreen display, with the chosen car arriving within one to two minutes. The 15-storey showroom features 60 slots displaying luxury vehicles, including Ferraris, Lamborghinis, and Bentleys. This futuristic concept is marketed as the "world's largest luxury car vending machine."

site_title: PTC Logistics posts 21% drop in Q1 profit
summary: PTC Logistics reported a 21% drop in Q1 profit to S$3.62 million, primarily due to a decline in volume handled by its transportation division. Revenue fell 4% to S$35.5 million. The company attributed its performance to factors such as diesel prices, labor market tightening, and interest-rate fluctuations. It plans to be prudent with costs and explore synergies to increase competitiveness, with a redevelopment project expected to contribute positively to results upon completion in 2018.

site_title: Singapore stocks finish mixed; STI gains but broad market weakens
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) ended mixed, with a gain of 8.92 points to 3,264.21, driven primarily by Genting Singapore's 6.5% surge to S$1.15. However, the broad market was weaker, with 202 gains versus 271 falls, and 2.8 billion units of turnover worth S$1.4 billion. This contrasts with the previous day's 0.4% gain. The STI's performance was likely influenced by the uncertainty surrounding US tariffs and the split views among US Federal Reserve members.

site_title: Frankfurt, London stocks reach record peaks
summary: Frankfurt and London stock markets reached record peaks on Monday, driven by rallying oil prices, China's infrastructure spending plans, and upbeat German election news. The FTSE 100 index hit a record high of 7,460.20 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 reached a new pinnacle at 12,832.29 points. China's President Xi Jinping pledged $124 billion for the Silk Road project, boosting commodity gains. Most Asian markets also rose, with Hong Kong achieving a sixth consecutive gain.

site_title: France's Macron picks PM from the right, blowing apart old boundaries
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron appointed conservative Edouard Philippe as prime minister, marking a significant departure from his centrist party's usual right-wing affiliation. Philippe, a moderate Republican and former mayor of Le Havre, is expected to broaden Macron's appeal and weaken opponents before June's legislative elections. The move also strengthens ties with former Prime Minister Alain Juppe, who supports Macron's efforts to end left-right politics in France. Philippe's appointment is seen as a key step in Macron's efforts to unite the country and establish a new political landscape.

site_title: US judge demands Uber return downloaded documents to Waymo
summary: A US judge ordered Uber to return over 14,000 confidential documents downloaded from Waymo, a self-driving car unit of Alphabet Inc, by May 31. The judge found Uber likely knew or should have known that former Waymo engineer Anthony Levandowski took the files, which may have been used to accelerate Uber's autonomous car technology. Uber can continue work on its autonomous car technology, but Levandowski must be removed from Lidar work. The ruling did not shut down Uber's self-driving car lab, and Waymo welcomed the decision.

site_title: HK's MTR Corp plans joint bid with mainland rail giant to build KL-S'pore link
summary: Hong Kong's MTR Corp plans to join forces with China Railway Corporation to bid on a multibillion-dollar rail line connecting Kuala Lumpur and Singapore, a 350km high-speed rail link. MTR Corporation chairman Frederick Ma Si-Hang expressed interest in partnering with China Railway Corporation. This partnership would aim to build the rail link, marking a significant transportation project between Malaysia and Singapore.

site_title: Yongnam posts S$1.5m loss for Q1
summary: Construction firm Yongnam Holdings reported a net loss of S$1.5 million for Q1 2017, a 12% decrease from the previous year. Revenue rose 24% to S$91.5 million, driven by its structural steelworks business. Gross profit fell 57.8% due to lower margins and increased overhead costs. Loss per share was 0.31 Singapore cent, compared to a 0.37 cent earnings per share in Q1 2016.

site_title: Malaysia April inflation rate seen easing to 4.5% y-o-y: poll
summary: Malaysia's April inflation rate is expected to ease to 4.5% y-o-y, down from March's 5.1%, according to a Reuters poll. Lower fuel prices and moderating food prices, partly due to the removal of cooking oil subsidies, are contributing factors. This rate matches February's 4.5%, the highest since 2009.

site_title: Golden Energy sees Q1 revenue boosted by coal mining division
summary: Golden Energy and Resources (Gear) reported a 48% increase in revenue for Q1 2017, reaching US$143.2 million, driven mainly by its coal mining division. The company's net profit jumped to US$19 million, up from US$1.7 million the previous year. The earnings per share also increased to 0.35 US cents from 0.03 US cents.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: Cosco Corp's yard affiliate bags FSRU module contract
summary: Cosco Corp's affiliate, Cosco (Qidong) Shipyard Co, has won a contract to build a module for a floating storage regasification unit (FSRU) for a European buyer. The delivery is scheduled for the first quarter of 2018. Cosco Corp did not disclose the contract price or the buyer's identity due to confidentiality.

site_title: UBS, WMI launch anti-money laundering risk management programme
summary: UBS and the Wealth Management Institute (WMI) have launched a three-year anti-money laundering (AML) risk management programme. The programme aims to enhance AML competencies in the wealth management industry and adhere to high standards as a financial centre. WMI will create technology-enhanced learning modules, commission research papers, and host forums for senior compliance decision-makers. The programme will be accredited by the Institute of Banking & Finance and made available to industry participants, including private bankers and compliance professionals. This initiative will deepen AML knowledge and share global best practices in combating financial crime.

images.alt_text: UBS and the Wealth Management Institute (WMI) on Monday announced the launch of a new initiative, a programme on anti-money laundering (AML) risk management.
Genevieve Cua

site_title: Lyft, Waymo to cooperate on self-driving cars
summary: Waymo, the self-driving car unit of Alphabet, has partnered with Lyft to test self-driving car technology. The move aims to counter Uber's development of self-driving vehicles. The collaboration will focus on making roads safer and increasing transportation accessibility. No specific details on the scope of the partnership or timeline have been announced.

site_title: Starhill Global Reit divests Tokyo property for 410m yen
summary: Starhill Global Reit has divested its Tokyo property, Harajuku Secondo, for 410.2 million yen, a 22.4% premium to its valuation. The transaction translates to a 2.5% yield based on net property income. This sale reduces SGReit's Japanese portfolio to three properties and its exposure to Japan by 0.1% of its asset value. The divestment is expected to decrease SGReit's gearing from 35.3% to 35.2%.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares rise to 21-month highs, shrug off cyber threat
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose for the sixth consecutive session to 21-month highs, defying threats from global cyber attacks and North Korea's missile test. Investors were aided by steady money flows from mainland China and stabilization in the China market. The Hang Seng index rose 0.9%, while the China Enterprises Index gained 1.6%. Chinese investors bought Hong Kong stocks, signaling continued southbound money flows and diversification away from domestic exposure. Most sectors rose, with financial shares leading the gains.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close slightly higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.780 points to close at 1,778.650 on Monday, driven by a slight increase in shares. The index saw 3.74 billion lots valued at RM3 billion traded, with losers outnumbering gainers 508 to 421.

site_title: Western Digital takes legal action to block sale of Toshiba's chip unit
summary: Western Digital Corp has taken legal action against Toshiba Corp, seeking international arbitration to block the sale of Toshiba's chip unit without its consent. The move could delay or derail a potential $18 billion sale, with major bidders including KKR & Co LP, Foxconn, and Broadcom. Toshiba is under pressure to raise funds to cover billions in cost overruns at its US nuclear unit Westinghouse, and the sale is seen as crucial to its survival.

images.alt_text: Western Digital Corp has sought international arbitration to stop partner Toshiba Corp from selling its chips arm without its consent, potentially derailing a much-needed capital injection for the Japanese conglomerate.

site_title: S'pore consortium given masterbuilder rights to India's Amaravati City start-up area
summary: A Singapore consortium, comprising Ascendas-Singbridge and Sembcorp Development, has been awarded master development rights to the Amaravati City Start-up Area in India's Andhra Pradesh state. The 684-hectare area will be developed over 15-20 years, creating centers of activity and attracting settlers and investment. The contract was signed at a ceremony attended by Andhra Pradesh Chief Minister Chandrababu Naidu and Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry S Iswaran, with a memorandum of understanding also agreed upon to identify economic development opportunities.

site_title: Golden Agri-Resources' Q1 profit hit by forex loss
summary: Golden Agri-Resources (GAR) reported a 60.1% decline in Q1 net profit to US$37.6 million due to a US$1.2 million forex loss, despite a 37% revenue increase to US$2 billion. EBITDA rose 28.8% year-over-year to US$182.8 million. The company's financial position strengthened with an adjusted net gearing ratio of 0.40 times and total consolidated assets growing to US$8.4 billion. GAR's CEO Franky Widjaja expects performance to be supported by increasing production volume for the rest of the year.

site_title: Mermaid Maritime's Q1 profit down 41.7% as associate's profit falls
summary: Mermaid Maritime's Q1 2017 net profit declined 41.7% to US$735,000, largely due to its associate company Asia Offshore Drilling's reduced profit. The subsea and offshore drilling services company attributes the decline to lower oil prices and reduced day rates for a renewed contract. Despite this, Mermaid achieved cost savings and increased Ebitda to US$5.8 million, driven by lower costs in its subsea business. The company believes the market has turned a corner, with oil prices stabilizing and consolidation ending, and secured several contract extensions.

site_title: Europe: London stocks hit record high on rallying oil price
summary: The London stock market reached a record high, with the FTSE 100 index surging 0.3% to 7,455.21 points, driven by a jump in oil prices. Eurozone equities also rose, with Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices increasing 0.4% and 0.1% respectively. The rally came as investors continued to brush off new US trade threats, focusing on the energy sector's boost from rising oil prices.

site_title: Sinarmas Land posts 136.6% surge in Q1 profit
summary: Sinarmas Land reported a 136.6% surge in Q1 profit to S$37.2 million, driven by higher revenue from its Indonesia division and better operating performance. Total revenue rose 31.8% to S$237.1 million, with recurring income climbing 2.9% to S$38.7 million. Group executive director Margaretha Widjaja expects stronger economic recovery in Indonesia due to government infrastructure spending and increased direct investments, positioning the group to take advantage of the property sector recovery through joint ventures and land sales.

site_title: UOB Kay Hian's Q1 profit rises 39.4%
summary: UOB Kay Hian reported a 39.4% rise in net profit to S$19.7 million for the first quarter, with revenue expanding 19.3% to S$91.4 million. Earnings per share increased to 2.52 Singapore cents. The brokerage's shares finished at S$1.35, 0.4% lower.

site_title: ASL Marine posts S$11.7m loss for Q3
summary: ASL Marine reported an S$11.7 million loss for its third quarter ended March 31, 2017, due to a 6.6% decline in revenue and higher administrative expenses. The loss was attributed to a lumpy ship-repair and conversion business, engineering segment, and one-off costs related to debt restructuring. The company expressed concerns about the operating environment and vowed to seek cash flow positive business opportunities with careful cost control and increased financial flexibility. The net asset value per share was S$0.70.

site_title: Box trade, bunker sales on a roll at the Singapore port
summary: The Port of Singapore reported a fourth consecutive month of increased container throughput and marine fuel sales in April. Container throughput exceeded 2.72 million TEUs, up from 2.52 million in April 2016. Marine fuel sales also rose, reaching 4.25 million tonnes, a year-over-year increase.

site_title: Australia: Shares end steady as financials support; Fairfax Media jumps on M&A
summary: Australian shares ended steady on Monday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index closing 0.03% higher at 5838.402. Financials and telecom stocks held on to their gains, while Fairfax Media surged on a takeover bid. The "Big 4" banks led the gain, with Commonwealth Bank of Australia rising 1%. The materials sector pressured the index, but overall, the market remained stable.

site_title: JPMorgan to buy Dublin office for more than 1,000 workers
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co. has agreed to purchase an office building in Dublin, Ireland, that can accommodate over 1,000 workers. The 200 Capital Dock building, valued at over $200 million, was purchased from Kennedy Wilson, Fairfax Financial Holdings, and the National Asset Management Agency. The US bank plans to expand its custody business in Ireland and hire new workers as part of the growth. The purchase is part of rising demand for office space in Dublin, driven by Brexit-related searches for office space. The deal will fund the majority of the remaining cost of developing the wider Capital Dock project.

site_title: LG SIGNATURE is the essence of style
summary: LG Electronics introduces LG SIGNATURE, an ultra-premium brand of home appliances and consumer electronics. The brand features four products: an OLED TV W7, InstaView Refrigerator, TWINWash Washing Machine, and LG SIGNATURE Air Purifier. These products embody LG's philosophy, "The Art of Essence," which prioritizes design excellence, top performance, and usability. The LG SIGNATURE products aim to transform everyday items into sophisticated and reliable inventions that serve users stylishly. They boast minimalist yet elegant aesthetics, intuitive designs, and advanced features, offering a hassle-free, efficient, and luxurious experience.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower as yen stays firm
summary: Tokyo stocks closed marginally lower on May 15, 2017, as the yen strengthened, pressuring exporters. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.07% and the Topix index slipped 0.04%. The weaker yen and disappointing US data also revived concerns over North Korea's latest missile launch, contributing to the market's decline.

site_title: Some businesses in Asia disrupted by cyber attack, authorities brace for more
summary: A global ransomware attack, known as WannaCry, has disrupted businesses and governments in Asia, with hundreds of thousands of computers locked worldwide. The attack, mainly spread by e-mail, has affected factories, hospitals, shops, and schools in over 150 countries, including China, Japan, and South Korea. While the impact in Asia appears contained, experts warn of potential risks as more systems come online. Companies in the region have been advised to be cautious and install patches to prevent further damage.

site_title: Sterling revisits US$1.30 after significant speculative shift
summary: Sterling rose to US$1.2925, a 0.3% gain, against the US dollar, as speculators cut bearish bets by 34,566 contracts, the third largest position shift in favor of the pound since 1995. The move follows British Prime Minister Theresa May's snap general election call, which has abated negative views on the pound since Brexit. Sterling's net short position has more than halved, from 107,117 contracts at the end of March, with the bulk of the reduction coming after May's election announcement.

site_title: Indonesia's April export, import growth slower than expected
summary: Indonesia's exports and imports grew more slowly than expected in April, with a trade surplus of $1.24 billion, slightly larger than forecast but smaller than the revised March surplus. Imports rose 10.31% to $11.93 billion, while exports rose 12.61% to $13.17 billion, both below March levels. Consumer goods imports increased 26% year-over-year, while capital goods and raw materials imports grew at a slower rate.

site_title: Malaysia seizes smuggled tortoises worth US$300,000
summary: Malaysian customs officials seized 330 endangered tortoises, including 330 ploughshare and radiated tortoises, worth US$276,784, at Kuala Lumpur International Airport on Sunday. The smuggled reptiles were found alive, foiling an attempt to bring them into the country from Madagascar. Abdul Wahid Sulong, deputy director of the customs department, made the announcement on Monday.

site_title: China's Xi says Belt and Road needs to reject protectionism
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping urged major multilateral institutions to join his Belt and Road Initiative, stressing the need to reject protectionism for global economic growth. Xi pledged $124 billion for the Silk Road, aiming to bolster China's global leadership by expanding links between Asia, Africa, and Europe. He emphasized the importance of policy coordination and open cooperation, contrasting with US President Donald Trump's "America First" approach. The initiative aims to address global development challenges and promote win-win results, but some Western diplomats have expressed concerns about Chinese influence and transparency.

site_title: NZ, Australian dollars regain ground on firmer commodities, China
summary: The New Zealand and Australian dollars regained ground against the US dollar on Monday, driven by firmer commodity prices and improved perceptions of China's economic health. New Zealand's retail sales data exceeded expectations, while iron ore prices and emerging markets indices rose. China's economic health concerns eased, supporting the Aussie dollar. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand's assistant governor is set to comment on monetary policy, while Australian government bond futures rose. The Aussie dollar edged up to US$0.7400, and New Zealand's dollar rallied to US$0.6876.

summary:

Genting Singapore drove the STI's gain, while Citigroup set a mid-2026 target for MSCI's global equity index. Meanwhile, international news includes Malaysia seizing assets, China's GDP growth expected to slow, and the UK economy shrinking for the second month.

site_title: Gold firm on weak US data, North Korea concerns
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% on Monday as weaker-than-expected US economic data and North Korea's missile test pressured the US dollar, supporting the metal. US retail sales data showed a smaller-than-expected increase, while consumer prices raised concerns about the retail sector and broader economy. Gold is sensitive to rising rates, which lift the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding assets. The metal may end its current bounce in a narrow range and revisit its May 9 low, according to Reuters technical analyst.

images.alt_text: Gold prices inched up on Monday as weaker-than-expected economic data from the US and a missile test by North Korea over the weekend pressured the US dollar.

site_title: Malaysia's Felda Global Ventures exploring China expansion
summary: Malaysia's Felda Global Ventures Holdings Bhd signed a memorandum of understanding with Sinograin Oils, a subsidiary of China's state-owned China Grain Reserves Corp, to expand its palm oil supply and distribution network in China. The deal aims to integrate Felda Global's Chinese unit with Sinograin's domestic operations, marking the company's entry into its second-largest market. Felda Global, the world's third-largest palm plantation operator, hopes to increase its crude palm oil exports to China, currently 308,040 metric tonnes in 2016.

site_title: Thai Q1 GDP grows 1.3% q-o-q, slightly above forecast
summary: Thai Q1 GDP grows 1.3% q-o-q, slightly above forecast. The economy expanded at its fastest pace in four years, driven by stronger exports, household spending, and tourism. The government revised quarterly growth to 0.5% for October-December 2016, up from 0.4%. This growth is a welcome boost to Thailand's economy, which has lagged regional peers in recent years.

site_title: New private home sales in Singapore down 12.6% in April: URA
summary: Singapore's private home sales dropped 12.6% in April, with 1,555 units sold, compared to 1,780 in March and 750 in April 2016. Excluding executive condos, 1,926 units were sold. Top-selling projects included Frasers Centrepoint's Seaside Residences and City Developments' Commonwealth Towers. Median prices for ECs in April were S$787 per square foot, with MCL Land's Sol Acres selling 122 units.

images.alt_text: Developers in Singapore sold 1,555 private homes in April 2017, 12.6 per cent lower than the 1,780 private homes sold in March, but it was more than double the 750 units sold in April 2016.

site_title: Hot stock: Noble shares drop 12%, extending last week's fall
summary: Noble Group shares dropped 12% in early trade on Monday, extending last week's decline amid growing market concern over the company's outlook. The shares plunged 53% in the last two sessions following a profit warning that took its shares to the lowest in 15 years. Noble is struggling to repair investor confidence after past setbacks, including a questioning of its accounts and a commodities downturn.

site_title: Seoul: Won's gain capped by North Korea worries, market cautious
summary: South Korea's won traded flat on Monday, capped by concerns over North Korea's missile test. The won rose 0.1% to 1,126.3 against the US dollar, despite US dollar weakness. The military needs more analysis to verify North Korea's claim of a technical advancement during the test-launch.
