Market sentiment remains cautious amid tensions, offsetting support from the weaker US dollar.

site_title: China April factory output rises 6.5% y-o-y, investment up 8.9%; miss expectations
summary: China's factory output rose 6.5% in April, below expectations of a 7.1% increase, marking a cooling of growth. Fixed-asset investment grew 8.9% in the first four months, also missing forecasts of a 9.1% increase. The disappointing numbers may put pressure on policymakers, who are already concerned about slowing GDP growth.

site_title: New Zealand service activity falls sharply in April: BNZ survey
summary: New Zealand's services activity declined sharply in April, reaching its lowest level in almost five years, according to a survey. The Bank of New Zealand-Business NZ's seasonally adjusted performance of services index (PSI) fell six points to 52.8. Economists expect a bounce back in May, citing the temporary impact of public and school holidays and severe weather. The drop is a concern, but a rebound would be a positive sign for the country's economic growth.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher on Monday
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.51% on Monday, extending a six-day winning streak, with the Hang Seng Index reaching 25,283.75. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains, driven by a record close in Europe. The rally comes despite US trade tensions and uncertainty.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks and won gain, look past cyber attack, North Korea risks
summary: South Korean stocks rose 0.2% on Monday, despite concerns over the "Wannacry" cyberattack and North Korea's missile test. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) reached a record high, while foreign investors sold 95.9 billion won worth of Kospi shares. The South Korean won gained 0.34% against the US dollar, shrugging off North Korea's missile test. The market appears resilient, with investors focusing on other economic indicators and global market trends.

site_title: Russia, Saudi Arabia agree to extend oil output cuts until March 2018
summary: Saudi Arabia and Russia agree to extend oil output cuts until March 2018 to rebalance the global crude market. The deal, which will keep output cuts at the same level as the current agreement, aims to reduce global inventories to their five-year average. Oil prices rose over 1.5% in Asian trading following the announcement. The agreement, which includes OPEC and other producers, aims to address oversupply in the market and stabilize prices.

site_title: Toshiba delays results again, warns of US$8.4b net loss
summary: Toshiba delays reporting its annual earnings for the past fiscal year, citing an auditor's review, and warns of a net loss of 950 billion yen (S$11.8 billion). The delay comes after two previous postponements, raising concerns about the company's shares being delisted from the Tokyo Stock Exchange. Toshiba's operating profit is now expected at 270 billion yen, down from a previous forecast of 500 billion yen in loss. The company's struggles stem from huge writedowns at its US nuclear unit Westinghouse Electric.

site_title: CNMC Q1 profit falls 98.8% to US$54.8m on poorer ore grades
summary: CNMC Goldmine Holdings' Q1 profit plummeted 98.8% to US$54.8m due to lower ore grades and reduced sales volumes despite higher gold prices. Revenue fell 43.8% and all-in production costs increased to US$983 per ounce. The company is building a new carbon-in-leach processing plant to enhance gold recovery rates, aiming for an initial capacity of 500 tonnes per day.

site_title: Philippine lawmakers hear impeachment complaint against Duterte
summary: Philippine lawmakers began hearing an impeachment complaint against President Rodrigo Duterte, alleging he betrayed public trust by his approach to China and abused power during a bloody anti-drugs campaign. The complaint, filed by Gary Alejano, accuses Duterte of "high crimes" including hiding wealth, ordering police to murder, and failing to protect maritime sovereignty. However, lawmakers and Duterte's office dismiss the complaint as "black propaganda," with many expecting it to be thrown out due to Duterte's huge support in the house and among the public.

site_title: Oil stable on expectations of extended Opec-led production cut
summary: Oil prices remained steady on Monday, supported by expectations that Opec and Russia will extend their production cut agreement beyond the first half of the year. Brent crude futures were little changed at $50.86 per barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures were also unchanged at $47.88 per barrel. Analysts attributed the stability to the agreement, which could provide support to oil prices this week. However, rising US drilling activity weighed on markets, with US energy firms adding oil rigs for a 17th consecutive week.

site_title: Asia: Most markets start week with gains
summary: Asian markets rose Monday, with Hong Kong and Shanghai gaining 0.4% and 0.3% respectively, despite disappointing US economic figures. China's factory output and retail sales slowed more sharply than expected, while North Korea's missile test was ignored by investors. Tokyo ended lower due to a stronger yen, while Sydney was flat. The Dow ended in the red on Wall Street, adding to concerns about the US retail sector and the Federal Reserve's rate plans.

site_title: North Korea's 'new missile' has unprecedented range: experts
summary: North Korea successfully tested a new long-range ballistic rocket, the Hwasong-12, with unprecedented range capabilities, bringing US bases in the Pacific within reach. The launch, overseen by leader Kim Jong-Un, was seen as a significant development by analysts. The rocket's capabilities raise concerns about the potential threat to regional security.

site_title: New Zealand slashes Chinese tourism forecast, denting outlook
summary: New Zealand has lowered its forecast for Chinese tourist spending to NZ$3.73 billion by 2022, down 30% from previous projections. The Ministry of Business, Innovation and Employment attributes this to geopolitical risks and a short-term slowing of the market. Chinese arrivals are expected to reach 812,000 in 2022, down from 921,000 last year, with average spending per day forecast at NZ$343. This reduction affects overall revenue from tourists, with visitor spending projected to rise to NZ$15.3 billion in 2023.

site_title: Brexit sparks debate on united Ireland vote
summary: Britain's vote to leave the EU has sparked debate over a potential referendum on a united Ireland, with Irish nationalists calling for a border poll after the UK's only land border with the EU will be between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland. EU leaders have stated that Northern Ireland would be automatically welcomed back into the bloc if it voted to become part of the Republic. However, the prospect is currently far off, and Irish Foreign Minister Charlie Flanagan has dismissed the idea of a referendum as "not now."

site_title: It's getting harder for CEOs who lie or cheat to escape the axe
summary: US and Canadian CEOs who lie or cheat are facing increased scrutiny, with the number of firings for ethical lapses more than doubling over the past five years. According to a PwC study of 2,500 global companies, 14 CEOs were ousted for misconduct from 2012 to 2016, up from six in the preceding period. This trend suggests that corporate directors are becoming less tolerant of misbehavior, with researchers attributing the shift to increased pressure on companies to maintain high ethical standards.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks trade above 10,000 mark amid cyberattack concerns
summary: Taiwan's main TAIEX index rose 0.2% to 10,010.13, trading above the 10,000 mark for the first time in 17 years, amid concerns over a global ransomware attack and North Korea's missile test. The electronics subindex gained 0.3%, while the financials subindex rose 0.2%. No major issues were reported by market participants, with the central bank confirming it was not affected by the ransomware malware. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to NT$30.167 per US dollar.

site_title: Singapore shares open up 0.21% on Monday, led by blue chips
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.21% on Monday, led by blue chip stocks, with 75 million shares worth S$125.4 million changing hands. Telco Singtel and Spackman Entertainment Group were among top gainers, with Singtel rising 0.5% and Spackman gaining 0.6%. The rally follows a 5-day streak ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Hot stock: SingPost slides 4.3% after TradeGlobal writedown
summary: SINGAPORE POST shares fell 4.3% after the company incurred a $185 million writedown on its TradeGlobal unit, citing a $25.8 million loss. The company also cut its dividend payout to half a cent and launched a review of the acquisition. Analysts downgraded the stock following disappointing results, with the stock price closing at $1.33.

site_title: Facebook's Sandberg urges family-friendly policies on Mother's Day
summary: Facebook's Sheryl Sandberg urges the US government and employers to implement family-friendly policies, including a minimum wage increase, mandated paid parental leave, and affordable childcare, to support working parents, particularly single mothers. Sandberg, a widowed mother of two, believes these policies are necessary to balance work and home responsibilities. The US is one of the few developed countries without guaranteed paid family or maternity leave, and Sandberg criticizes the high cost of childcare, which can be more expensive than the median annual rent in the US.

site_title: Spackman posts US$4.8m Q1 profit on revenue from Korean film Master
summary: Spackman Entertainment Group reported a net profit of US$4.8 million in Q1 2017, a significant improvement from a net loss of US$966,000 in the same period last year. Revenue doubled to US$8 million, driven by film production revenue of US$3.8 million, primarily from the 2016 film Master. This marked a substantial increase from the US$1.7 million in revenue from the same film last year.

site_title: Olam Q1 profit up 26.5% to S$143.8m
summary: Olam International reported a 26.5% increase in first-quarter net profit to S$143.8 million, driven by stronger performance in food segments. Revenue rose 21.9% to S$5.8 billion, with Ebitda increasing by 72% in edible nuts and spices. The company attributed the growth to higher sales volumes.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Monday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened flat on Monday, down 0.130 points to 1775.400, with 167 gainers outnumbering 57 losers. Trading volume reached 93.69 million lots worth RM35.08 million.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Olam, CNMC, Spackman
summary: Olam International reported a 26.5% increase in first-quarter net profit to S$143.8 million, driven by stronger performance in food segments. CNMC Goldmine Holdings' first-quarter net profit dropped 98.8% to US$54.8 million, due to lower ore grades and sales volumes. Spackman Entertainment Group swung into a first-quarter net profit of US$4.8 million, driven by distribution revenue from the 2016 film Master.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 0.67% due to a stronger yen and geopolitical risks from North Korea's continued missile tests. The benchmark index closed at 19,750.40, while the Topix index fell 0.54%. This comes as traders brush off new Trump threats to extend the stocks rally, and amid mixed signals from the US Federal Reserve.

site_title: Miner BHP Billiton rebrands as BHP
summary: BHP Billiton rebranded as BHP, dropping the name Billiton to emphasize its Australian roots. The decision comes as the company faces pressure from US-based hedge fund Elliott Advisors to restructure. BHP will launch a new "Think Big" advertising campaign to promote its Australian heritage and community involvement. The rebranding is seen as a way to boost the company's standing as a major Australian player rather than a multinational giant.

site_title: Macron's win adds to Poland's worries about its place in EU
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron's election has heightened concerns among Poland and Hungary about losing influence within the EU. Macron's vision of a "multi-speed" Europe, which favors deeper integration among Western EU countries, has led to fears that Eastern European nations may be excluded from key decision-making circles. Poland and Hungary, in particular, worry that a common eurozone budget and finance ministry could reduce financial support for less-wealthy countries and undermine the single market. Macron's win has also raised concerns about double standards and the erosion of EU principles.

site_title: Australia: Shares steady, as financials' gains offset weak resource stocks
summary: Australian shares traded little changed on Monday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index dipping 0.1% due to a slump in materials. Gains in financials, led by the "Big 4" banks, offset the decline. The benchmark fell 0.7% on Friday due to concerns over slow economic growth and the Federal Reserve's interest rate outlook. Iron ore prices dropped to near four-month lows, dragging down mining stocks, while gold prices failed to rise despite weak US economic data and a North Korean missile test.

site_title: US dollar starts week under shadow of underwhelming data, North Korea
summary: The US dollar started the week under pressure after US economic data fell short of expectations and North Korea conducted a mid-to-long range missile test. The US dollar index fell 0.1% to 99.226, while the yen rose 0.1% to 113.28 yen against the dollar. The disappointing data included a smaller-than-expected 0.4% increase in April retail sales and a disappointing report on consumer prices. The Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates next month, which may impact the dollar's value.

site_title: SunMoon receives in-principle nod to list placement shares, warrants
summary: SunMoon Food Co has received in-principle approval from the Singapore Exchange to list shares and warrants worth S$23 million as part of a S$23 million placement to Shanghai Yiguo E-Commerce Co. The placement agreement has been amended to protect Shanghai Yiguo from dilutive equity derivatives, ensuring it will not be worse off. The amendment also removes the fixed price for adjustment shares and prohibits the issuance of dilutive equity derivatives.

site_title: Australia and NZ largely escape global cyber attack
summary: Australia and New Zealand appear to have escaped a global cyber attack, with only three businesses affected in Australia and no reported cases in New Zealand. The ransomware worm, dubbed WannaCry, locked up over 200,000 computers worldwide, but its spread slowed on Sunday, with experts warning of potential new attacks on Monday. Australia's critical infrastructure and health systems remained unaffected, with the government confident that the worst of the attack had been missed.

site_title: Japan ramen chain Ippudo takes on US foodie scene for overseas growth
summary: Japan's Ippudo ramen chain is expanding its US presence, opening its first outlets in San Francisco and Berkeley, California, as part of a global push to quadruple its overseas shops in 20 countries by 2025. The chain, which raised 690 million yen in an initial public offering in March, is adapting its rich tonkotsu pork broth and noodle lengths to suit local tastes. With a focus on the US market, Ippudo aims to leverage the growing popularity of Japanese cuisine worldwide, with plans to also expand into Southeast Asia and other emerging markets.

site_title: Multinationals in Vietnam targeted by hackers linked to government: report
summary: Hackers linked to the Vietnamese government have targeted multinationals in Vietnam, including a German manufacturing company, a Chinese hotel developer, and a British consulting firm, according to a report by FireEye. The hackers, known as APT32, have been targeting foreign corporations with interests in Vietnam's manufacturing, consumer products, and hospitality sectors since 2014. The attacks are believed to be state-motivated, with the hackers seeking information about the companies' operations and adherence to local regulations. The Vietnamese government has denied the accusation, but the report marks the first time a cybersecurity company has pointed to Vietnam as the source of state-motivated cyber-attacks.

site_title: Microsoft says cyberattack should be wake up call for governments
summary: Microsoft's president and chief legal officer, Brad Smith, warned governments to treat the largest ransomware attack, crippling over 200,000 computers, as a wake-up call. He urged governments to report vulnerabilities to vendors instead of exploiting them, calling for a "Digital Geneva Convention". The attack, which used a leaked NSA-developed digital code, highlights the danger of government-developed exploits falling into the hands of hackers. Smith argues that governments should apply rules similar to those in the physical world to prevent widespread damage in cyberspace.

site_title: A minor meltdown that's left Canada looking frail
summary: Canada's economy appears fragile following a minor meltdown at Home Capital Group Inc, a mortgage lender. The crisis has raised concerns about the country's housing market, which is contributing 20% to the economy. Household debt levels are record high, with many households indebted to unprecedented levels. Moody's downgrade of the banking system and expectations of 2% GDP growth may be unsustainable, according to experts. The economy's reliance on real estate and consumer spending, rather than high-tech industries, is also a concern.

site_title: Ontario agency spurns Bombardier for France's Alstom
summary: Ontario's transit agency, Metrolinx, has placed a firm order with French company Alstom for 61 light-rail cars valued at 355 million euros, replacing Bombardier Inc as its supplier. The deal aims to ensure the timely opening of a planned transit line in four years. This decision adds to pressure on Bombardier, which is already facing criticism from investors over governance and executive compensation. Bombardier had been involved in a dispute with Metrolinx over the late delivery of light-rail cars for Toronto, which is now set to be completed by Alstom.

site_title: Australia's Fairfax Media gets revised US$2b offer from TPG-led group
summary: Australia's Fairfax Media received a revised A$2.76 billion (US$2b) cash offer from a TPG-led group, valuing the company at A$1.20 a share. This represents a 12% premium to Fairfax's A$1.07 closing price. The offer is subject to conditions, including due diligence, shareholder vote, and foreign investment approvals. The TPG consortium would acquire Fairfax's top mastheads, property listings unit, and other assets, ending the company's plan to spin off its valuable Domain unit. Fairfax's board will review the offer and update shareholders accordingly.

site_title: Boeing's 737 Max returns to flight as plane delivery looms
summary: Boeing's 737 Max jetliners resumed limited flights after a potential engine flaw temporarily grounded the aircraft. Regulators cleared the planes to fly with spare engines that don't include the possibly defective part. The issue was reported by supplier CFM International, a joint venture of General Electric and Safran, and affects low pressure turbine discs in the Leap engines. The move sets the stage for the first commercial delivery of the 737 Max.

site_title: Merkel's party secures key victory in bellwether state vote
summary: Chancellor Angela Merkel's Christian Democratic Union (CDU) secured a strong win in North Rhine-Westphalia, Germany's largest state, with 34.3% of the vote, surpassing the Social Democratic Party (SPD) by 3.7 percentage points. The result marks a significant blow to Merkel's main rival, Martin Schulz, and raises questions about the SPD's strategy ahead of national elections in September. The CDU's victory also gives Merkel an extra boost, while the SPD struggles to close the nationwide gap with the CDU.

site_title: Growing global cyberattack hits 200,000 victims so far
summary: A global cyberattack, targeting over 200,000 victims in 150 countries, has begun, exploiting vulnerabilities in old Microsoft operating systems. The attack has affected banks, hospitals, and government agencies, with an international manhunt underway for the perpetrators. Europol warns the situation could escalate when people return to work. The attack is considered the world's biggest-ever computer ransom assault, with indiscriminate strikes on critical infrastructure worldwide.

images.alt_text: The unprecedented global cyberattack has hit more than 200,000 victims in scores of countries, Europol said Sunday, warning that the situation could escalate when people return to work.

site_title: May pledges new right-to-buy plan to boost UK social housing
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May has pledged a new right-to-buy plan for social housing, aiming to boost home-building and alleviate the shortage of low-cost housing. The programme will provide government funding and permitting help to local authorities and housing associations, requiring a proportion of homes to be sold after 10-15 years. Existing tenants will have priority, and the plan is expected to result in thousands of new homes. The move aims to address Britain's housing shortage, which has pushed up rents and house prices, and is seen as a key part of the Conservative Party's efforts to win over Labour heartlands.

site_title: Canada's largest petrol station owner may set sights on the US next
summary: Parkland Fuel Corp, Canada's largest petrol station owner, may set its sights on the US market after a successful acquisition spree in Canada. Under CEO Bob Espey, Parkland has tripled its market value by acquiring petrol stations, propane distributors, and other fuel sellers across Canada. The company has a significant presence in the US, particularly in the Northern Plains states, and is eager to expand its operations in urban centers, including Calgary. Analysts praise Parkland's ability to wring out synergies from acquisitions and negotiate better fuel prices, but note that the company's debt levels are at the top end of its comfort range.

site_title: More Asean companies tapping US$ bond markets as they go offshore
summary: Southeast Asian companies are increasingly tapping international bond markets, with the US$144.9 billion in bonds sold in the Asia-Pacific excluding Japan surpassing 70% of 2016 levels. Standard Chartered Bank and Citibank are among the top banks in the region, with StanChart ranking first in Asean USD bond stakes. Indonesian companies, such as Star Energy Geothermal Ltd., are also using international bond markets to fund their operations, with StanChart playing a key role in these deals. The growth in international bond markets is driven by companies seeking to match funding in USD for overseas operations.

site_title: China craves foreign goods; students in Australia supply them
summary: A Melbourne college student, Zhang Yuan, started a business selling Australian products to Chinese consumers, capitalizing on the booming grey market. Last year, her business estimated to have sent $600m worth of Aussie products to China. The business thrived through word-of-mouth, with Zhang sourcing popular items such as vitamins, jewelry, and brand-name goods. As she struggled to find a lucrative job after graduation, Zhang stayed in Melbourne and continued her business, which has grown significantly. The grey market for Australian goods in China has created a lucrative opportunity for students and entrepreneurs.

images.alt_text: Uki Shao, a business major who describes herself as the "best daigou at my college", shopping at a Chemist Warehouse outlet in Melbourne. Tens of thousands of Chinese who are students at Australian universities or recent graduates have built a cottage industry to meet the demand of consumers in China.

site_title: BOJ's exit strategy - out of the frying pan and into the fire
summary: BOJ Governor Haruhiko Kuroda hinted at revealing the central bank's exit strategy from massive monetary easing, potentially exposing market attention to problems such as absorbing huge amounts of government and corporate debt securities. This could coincide with central banks reducing or reversing purchases of debt and non-debt securities, making it difficult for governments and corporate borrowers to roll over debt. The move could renew market anxieties as record levels of debt among public and private entities are at risk of being exposed.

site_title: Lawyer regulates banking industry he spent his career protecting
summary: Keith Noreika, a lawyer who spent his career protecting banks, has been appointed to regulate the banking industry as the new head of the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency (OCC). Unlike his predecessor, Thomas Curry, Noreika does not have to sign the ethics pledge and will not face the same restrictions on lobbying and lawyering when he returns to the private sector. Noreika has signaled plans to unwind some Obama-era banking regulations and has expressed support for reducing regulatory burdens on banks. The appointment has raised concerns among Democrats, who argue that it is an "apparent political power grab" and may circumvent the confirmation process.

site_title: HK curbs lending to developers as risks soar
summary: The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has tightened lending limits to property developers, cutting construction finance caps to 40% of site value and 80% of construction cost, starting June 1. This move aims to contain risks in the city's booming real-estate market, where developers have been aggressively offering funding to buyers. The HKMA expressed concerns over the riskiness of high-loan-to-value mortgages and warned of potential liquidity issues in the banking system. Analysts predict that external shocks could trigger tighter liquidity and increase home buyers' borrowing costs.

site_title: HK growth may taper off in coming quarters, warn analysts
summary: Hong Kong's latest quarterly economic report showed growth, but analysts warn it may taper off in coming quarters due to uncertainties surrounding US and European policy developments. The growth is relative, coming from a tough period last year. Analysts also express concerns about China's GDP growth slowing, which may put pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Indonesian maids now paid to take jobs abroad, activists say
summary: Activists claim that people smugglers in Indonesia are now paying rural women cash to secure overseas maid jobs, reversing the traditional practice of women paying exorbitant fees. The payments, ranging from $209 to $9 million, are used to persuade families to let their members work abroad. This trend has accelerated since Indonesia banned new maids from going to the Middle East in 2015. Many women are tricked and become trafficking victims, exploited and underpaid, with over half of the 21 million global forced labor victims found in Asia-Pacific.

site_title: US used-car glut good news for dealers, buyers
summary: The US used-car market is experiencing a glut, with an estimated 12 million low-mileage vehicles coming off leases in 2019, benefiting used-car dealers and buyers. However, this oversupply is causing stagnating stock prices for carmakers such as GM, Ford, and Fiat Chrysler, as demand for new vehicles slows after seven consecutive years of rising sales. Used-car prices are expected to drop around 3% annually for the next couple of years, further hurting carmakers' in-house lenders.

site_title: Macron takes power as French president
summary: Emmanuel Macron, 39, became France's youngest president on May 14, 2017, succeeding Francois Hollande. Macron, a centrist, promised to restore confidence and relaunch the European Union in his inauguration speech. He defeated far-right leader Marine Le Pen in the election, which was watched worldwide. Macron took the reins of power at the Elysee Palace, waving to small crowds along the Champs Elysees after a private meeting with his former mentor Hollande.

site_title: Analysts see features in China helping to soothe credit bubble concerns
summary: China's credit bubble concerns have sparked debates among economists, with some, like Simon Hunt of Simon Hunt Strategic Services, arguing that the country's authorities are tightening controls and cleaning up the financial system, which will spur growth. However, others warn of potential financial dislocation, bankruptcies, and an economic slowdown. A New York Federal Reserve analysis found that non-financial debt in China increased from $3 trillion to nearly $22 trillion between 2005 and 2016, raising concerns about the country's financial stability. China's authorities are seen as having tools to mitigate risks, but reforms in the banking and financial sector are also needed.

site_title: CRYPTIC CROSSWORD
summary: A cryptic crossword puzzle was published on May 14, 2017, but no clues or solution were provided. The crossword contained Across clues for words related to coastal features and insect-killing items, but no solution was given.

site_title: Anthem ends battle for Cigna after court ruling
summary: Anthem Inc. has ended its nearly two-year effort to buy rival insurer Cigna Corp after a Delaware judge ruled Cigna can walk away from the $48 billion health insurance merger. The judge's decision means Anthem could be on the hook for a $1.85 billion break-up fee, and both companies will now fight over who's to blame for the deal's collapse. Cigna seeks damages and a termination fee, while Anthem countersues, seeking damages as well. The decision frees both companies to pursue other acquisitions, with Cigna expected to be more acquisitive.

site_title: North Korea says missile test aimed at testing carrying large nuclear warhead
summary: North Korea conducted a mid-to-long range missile test on Sunday, verified to carry a large nuclear warhead, according to the country's KCNA news agency. The missile landed in the sea near Russia, with a range of 787km and an altitude of 2,111.5km. The test was supervised by leader Kim Jong Un, who accused the US of "browbeating" non-nuclear countries and warned Washington not to misjudge the North's mainland as a target. The launch was seen as a message to South Korea, days after the new president took office, pledging to engage Pyongyang in dialogue.

site_title: Mexico's wind turbines seeping oil
summary: Wind turbines in Mexico's southern coast are leaking oil, sparking local opposition. The leaks, likely posing no immediate health risk, occurred at a generator owned by Electricite de France (EDF) in the town of Juchitan. A clean-up effort was underway, with workers using protective gear to scrub off the lubricant. The incident is a setback for Mexico's efforts to increase its use of renewable energy, which aims to make the country's power industry cleaner.

site_title: Foreclosed home sales in US to come under closer scrutiny
summary: US lawmakers are scrutinizing the sale of foreclosed homes to investment firms that promise homeownership to those unable to secure traditional mortgages. Local authorities are taking legal action against firms accused of engaging in predatory practices, reselling run-down houses "as is" through rent-to-own transactions. Regulators are concerned that these firms are taking advantage of vulnerable individuals, often with little financial oversight. The issue highlights the need for closer monitoring of the housing market and stricter regulations to prevent exploitation.

site_title: London landlord home sales slump on tax changes
summary: London landlords are selling their rental properties due to tax changes, with the proportion of homes bought to rent out in the city dropping to 12% in February from 20% a year earlier. The introduction of an additional 3% tax on second-home purchases in 2016 and a reduction in tax relief for rental income have made it unprofitable for many landlords. As a result, the average asking rent for homes in Greater London fell 4.2% in the first quarter, and some landlords are considering selling their properties and reinvesting in their pension plans.

site_title: Eurostar taps surge in UK business travel as Brexit blues fade
summary: Eurostar International reported a 9% surge in corporate bookings in the first quarter, led by the fashion, technology, and creative sectors. This marks a significant acceleration from a 4% gain in the initial 10 weeks. The financial services industry, a focus of Brexit speculation, also saw a boost in demand. CEO Nicolas Petrovic attributed the increase to fading worries about the Brexit vote.

site_title: New versions of ransomware worm expected worldwide
summary: A new version of the WannaCry ransomware worm is expected to spread globally on Monday, potentially causing more damage as employees log back into computers. The virus, which infected over 100,000 computers worldwide, has slowed its spread but experts warn that new versions are likely. Companies and organizations, particularly in Asia, are bracing for a busy day as they patch systems and install software updates to prevent further infections. Governments and cybersecurity firms are urging users to be cautious and report any attacks to the authorities.

site_title: Turbulent decade for Bordeaux ends with a new 2016 high
summary: The 2016 Bordeaux vintage is expected to be the best in at least six years, with prices reaching new highs. Producers and critics assess the vintage as a success, despite challenges during the harvest. Prices for 2016 wines have increased by 10% or more compared to 2015, with some estates pricing their wines at record levels. The favorable weather conditions, including warm temperatures and ample sunshine, contributed to the high-quality crop.

site_title: Brexit threatening London's place as banking hub
summary: London's status as a global banking hub is under threat due to Brexit, with between 15,000 and 80,000 finance jobs potentially leaving the city over the next two years. The uncertainty surrounding the UK's exit from the European Union has led to a rush of other European cities, such as Frankfurt, Paris, and Dublin, to capitalize on the opportunity. Global banks like Citigroup are already planning to move staff to these new hubs to ensure trading can continue without disruption. London's financial industry employs over 1.1 million people and generates £205 billion in annual revenues.

site_title: Top enabler of change
summary: Artificial Intelligence (AI) is transforming various industries, from healthcare to self-storage, and is expected to bring significant changes in the future. Companies are leveraging AI to improve marketing effectiveness, streamline processes, and enhance customer experiences. Key enablers of AI include machine learning, big data, and cloud computing. While AI has the potential to disrupt core business, it also provides opportunities for innovation and growth. To fully tap into AI's potential, organizations must blend human and digital assets into a cohesive operating model, and address issues such as algorithmic development and data application.

site_title: China pledges US$124b for new Silk Road as champion of globalisation
summary: China's President Xi Jinping pledged $124 billion for the "Belt and Road" initiative, aiming to expand global development through infrastructure investment. The plan, which aims to create a path of peace and inclusiveness, is seen as a challenge to the US's "America First" approach. Xi emphasized the importance of open development and fair trade rules, calling for global cooperation and mutual benefit. The initiative is expected to boost trade between Asia, Africa, Europe, and beyond, with China planning to import $2 trillion of products from participating countries over the next five years.

site_title: Melbourne undergoes a renaissance
summary: Melbourne is experiencing a renaissance, with its population forecast to surpass Sydney's in the decades ahead. The city is attracting high-tech firms, such as software maker Geli, and is growing at the fastest pace in Australia due to its booming demand for workers. Melbourne's transformation from a rust-belt region to a hub for education and high tech has made it an attractive location for businesses.

site_title: Portugal wins Eurovision contest for first time
summary: Portugal won the Eurovision Song Contest for the first time on May 14, 2017, with 27-year-old Salvador Sobral's melancholy ballad "Amar Pelos Dois." Sobral, who is awaiting a heart transplant, scored a crushing victory with his fado-tinged song composed by his sister Luisa. Sobral's performance was praised by executive supervisor Jon Ola Sand, who said the winner was "bringing music back to the Eurovision Song Contest." The contest was hosted by Ukraine, despite ongoing fighting with Moscow-backed separatists, and was watched by 200 million TV viewers.

site_title: Dyna-Mac warns of Q1 loss
summary: DYNA-MAC Holdings expects to report a first-quarter net loss on Monday, citing reasons not disclosed. The company advised investors to exercise caution when dealing with its shares.

site_title: It's calm on Wall Street - too calm, according to some strategists
summary: US stocks remained flat last week, with the Chicago Board Options Exchange's volatility index hitting a two-decade low, indicating a lack of concern among investors. Analysts at Goldman Sachs warn that this calm may be a sign of complacency, as rising policy uncertainty and the Trump administration's unclear stance on trade policy could lead to a major retreat in US stocks. Retailers continue to struggle, and a potential collapse in tax reform may further exacerbate the market's downturn. Meanwhile, a possible resurgence in China's economic growth could provide a glimmer of hope for global markets.

site_title: Chemist who sought to bring LSD to the world dies at 75
summary: Nicholas Sand, a chemist who sought to bring LSD to the world, has died at 75. Sand, a Brooklyn-born son of a Soviet spy, took his first acid trip in 1964 and became fascinated with psychedelic drugs. He went on to experiment with various substances, including mescaline and peyote. Sand's story highlights his early experiences with LSD, which was still legal at the time.

site_title: Platinum weaker as miners meet in London
summary: Platinum prices have fallen by over 20% from their highs nine months ago due to soft demand, currency fluctuations, and uncertain market outlook. The commodity, mainly used to cut pollution from diesel cars, is now trading at around $919 an ounce, lower than during 2016's event. Hedge funds have taken a net-short position on platinum, betting on falling prices, and some analysts predict palladium prices may surpass platinum for the first time in 15 years.

site_title: Heeton's Q1 profit falls 56% to S$2.6m
summary: Heeton Holdings' first-quarter net profit fell 55.9% to S$2.56 million due to recognised profit from completed projects. Revenue increased 12.4% to S$15.49 million, driven by sales proceeds from the Onze@Tanjong Pagar project. The company stopped recognising profit from completed projects, resulting in a 66.2% decline in share of profit from associate companies and joint ventures. Despite this, Heeton remains cautiously optimistic about the short-term outlook for the Singapore residential property market, citing stabilised private home prices.

site_title: Washington home to America's super-rich
summary: Washington state is experiencing a surge in wealth, with the region's affluent residents transforming it into a hub for the super-rich. The four highest-earning counties in the US, all located near DC, have median incomes that exceed the national average. This boom is driven by government-related businesses and tech firms, with the area becoming a hotspot for high-net-worth individuals. The combination of these factors is redefining the state's affluence into opulence, solidifying its position as one of the most affluent regions in the country.

site_title: Investing, come what May
summary: Investors are advised to remain invested in the stock market despite a decline in value stocks. A synchronized economic upswing is evident in both developed and emerging worlds, with improved sentiment and rising order enquiries. However, the domestic economy in Singapore remains subdued, with rising unemployment. To navigate this environment, investors should stay invested, put numbers to names, and prune speculative bets. This involves analyzing financial ratios, identifying coherent stories behind companies, and scaling back speculative bets on low-margin, high-debt companies with mysterious business models.

site_title: US politics may keep investors wary
summary: US politics may continue to weigh on investors' psyche due to potential uncertainty after President Donald Trump's dismissal of the Federal Bureau of Investigation director James Comey. Despite this, corporate earnings and soft economic data have led to a decline in the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500. Investors are also keeping an eye on upcoming European and UK elections, as well as data releases from major economies, including China and Malaysia. Markets may experience volatility ahead of the UK General Election in July.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Marco Polo Q2 loss widens to S$8.2m, negative working capital persists
summary: Marco Polo Marine reported a widened net loss of S$8.2 million in its second fiscal quarter, driven by higher expenses and unchartered vessels. Revenue rose 8% to S$12.8 million, but the company's gross loss was S$1.3 million due to depreciation of newly built vessels. The company's negative working capital persisted at S$18.7 million as of March 31. Marco Polo has suspended trading to negotiate with creditors and will conduct an informal dialogue with note holders on May 18.

site_title: Trading group seeks to win the 'microseconds' war
summary: A US-based trading firm, Jump Trading LLC, has erected antennas next to the world's biggest futures exchange, CME Group Inc, in an effort to shave off milliseconds in trading speed. The move is part of a high-stakes "microseconds" war among traders to gain a competitive edge. Other firms, including McKay Brothers and Webline Holdings, have also installed microwave technology to reduce data transmission time. The goal is to be just a fraction of a second faster than competitors, with potential financial implications for traders.

site_title: Small, quiet Montana city fast becoming a startup hub
summary: Bozeman, Montana, is transforming into a startup hub for technology and young companies, despite its small size. The city boasts a median annual household income of $60,000 in the technology sector, a higher figure than the state average. Its airport offers direct flights to major cities, and the city has areas zoned for multi-story development and a growing fibre-optic network. Montana State University is also located there, contributing to the city's growing tech presence.

site_title: OCBC starts buybacks under new mandate
summary: OCBC Group started its share buyback program under a new mandate, repurchasing up to 209,124,917 shares worth S$9 million. The Straits Times Index rose 1.3% in four trading sessions, driven by institutional inflows into OCBC and DBS Group. Notable transactions included Capital World's listing, SIIC Environment's placement of new shares, and Union Steel's share buyback by veteran investor Sam Goi. Meanwhile, Singapore Reinsurance Corporation's non-executive director Hwang Soo Jin resumed buying shares in the company.

site_title: Jardine Matheson lends its heft to mental health cause
summary: Jardine Matheson, a Singapore-based conglomerate, has lent its support to mental health through its Jardine Engineering division. The company offered Jana, who had struggled with depression for six years, a job as an administrative assistant, which led to her recovery and eventual permanent employment. This initiative demonstrates Jardine Matheson's efforts to prioritize employee well-being and promote mental health. The company's support has helped Jana find a new focus in life and overcome negative thoughts.

images.alt_text: Jardines organises outings and activities - such as cake-making (above) for mental health clients.

site_title: Higher Q1 profits meet analysts' forecasts, but valuations still lofty
summary: Singapore-listed companies reported a combined S$7.8 billion in first-quarter net profits, up 18.5% year-on-year. The banking sector, particularly DBS, UOB, and OCBC, delivered strong performances, with net profits rising 1%, 5.4%, and 14% respectively. However, analysts warn that valuations remain lofty and the rest of the year is expected to be bumpy, with earnings remaining muted due to a challenging operating environment.

site_title: GSS taps tech to make S'pore sale great again
summary: The Great Singapore Sale (GSS) has launched a digital transformation to boost sales in a softened retail market. The 24th edition, starting June 9 and ending August 13, aims to improve brick-and-mortar retailers' sales through the introduction of the GoSpree mobile app, offering eCoupons and QR codes. Retailers expect a 20% sales boost, with March 2017 sales increasing 2.1% compared to the previous year, totaling S$3.7 billion. The event is supported by Singapore Tourism Board and Union Pay.

site_title: Rickmers bondholder seeks to stop vessel sales
summary: A Rickmers Maritime Trust bondholder, Peter Kwok Kian Tow, is seeking an injunction to halt the sale of vessels as the shipping trust is being wound up. The sale, expected to be completed on Monday, would see 14 vessels sold to Navios Partners Containers Inc and Navios Partners Containers Finance for $113 million. The bondholder claims the sale would "seriously" jeopardize unsecured noteholders' partial recovery of their investment, and the trust manager describes the action as wrongful and violating the trust deed.

site_title: Tapping Myanmar's growth potential
summary: Singapore Myanmar Investco is a diversified business group with a primary focus on Myanmar, aiming to capitalize on the country's growth potential. The company, led by CEO Mark Bedingham, has narrowed annual comprehensive net losses and reported a gross profit, with revenue more than tripling in the past year. SMI has secured key contracts, including a 10-year supply agreement with DFS for the Yangon International Airport, and plans to introduce major F&B franchises and retail brands. The company's businesses, including duty-free travel retail, food and beverage, auto services, construction services, and infrastructure, are expected to drive growth in the country, with the World Bank projecting a 7.8% real GDP growth in the 2016-2017 fiscal year.

images.alt_text: "Our mission is very simple - to play an active role in the modernisation of Myanmar, and to bring in products and services that are not present," says Mr Bedingham.

site_title: France's youngest president takes charge of a divided country
summary: France's 39-year-old President Emmanuel Macron took office as the youngest president of the country, inheriting a sluggish economy and a nation still under emergency rule. Macron won the election with a 66% margin, defeating the National Front's Marine Le Pen, but faces significant challenges, including a 10% unemployment rate and a need to form a majority government after parliamentary elections. Despite this, business confidence is at its highest level since 2011, and Macron's pro-European and pro-business platform has resonated with voters.

site_title: Update: Spotify, valued at US$13b, to launch direct listing on NYSE
summary: Spotify, valued at $13 billion, is set to become the first major company to launch a direct listing on the New York Stock Exchange, eliminating the need for a Wall Street bank or broker to underwrite an initial public offering (IPO). The move, which could change the way companies approach selling shares, is being advised by Morgan Stanley, Goldman Sachs, and Allen & Co. A direct listing allows a company's existing shares to be made immediately available to the public, bypassing underwriters and associated fees.

images.alt_text: Music streaming service Spotify, most recently valued at US$13 billion, will be the first major company to carry out a direct listing on the New York Stock Exchange when it goes public later this year or early next year, two sources familiar with the situation said on Friday.

site_title: Hamilton wins thrilling Spanish Grand Prix
summary: Lewis Hamilton won the Spanish Grand Prix, recovering from a lost lead to secure a thrilling victory for Mercedes. Hamilton finished 3.5 seconds ahead of Sebastian Vettel, regaining the lead after 44 laps. The win brought Hamilton within six points of Vettel in the title race, with Hamilton now 98 points behind the championship leader. Hamilton's second win in five races this year, it marked his 55th career win.

site_title: Heeton's Q1 profit falls 56.8% in absence of sales from completed projects
summary: Heeton Holdings' Q1 profit dropped 56.8% to S$2.52 million due to the absence of sales from completed projects. Revenue increased 12.4% to S$15.49 million, mainly from the Onze@Tanjong Pagar residential project. Share of profit from associated companies fell 66.2% to S$2.11 million due to stopped recognising profit from completed projects NEWest, KAP, and KAP Residences.

site_title: Tharman receives NTUC's highest May Day honour
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam received the Medal of Honour from the National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) for his contributions to improving the lives of Singapore workers. The award recognized his efforts in developing and launching policies, chairing committees, and advising unions. Tharman was credited with implementing national schemes such as the Jobs Credit Scheme, Progressive Wage Model, and Special Employment Credit scheme to support workers. He was also praised for his role in promoting quality growth and lifelong learning opportunities.

site_title: JES International posts RM221,000 profit from newly acquired plastics business
summary: JES International Holdings posted a net profit of RM221,000 (S$71,000) from its newly acquired plastics business, with revenue reaching RM7.8 million. The company continues to have a net liability position of RM48.2 million. JES chairman Audrey Jin believes the acquisition will increase shareholders' value. The acquisition is subject to shareholder approval and full completion conditions, which include the unwinding of the consolidated business if not completed.

site_title: Dollar bulls approaching square one again after strong rally
summary: Dollar bulls are at risk of being back at square one after a strong rally, with the US dollar rising 3.8% to 113.30 yen in the past month, the biggest advance among major currencies. Traders are looking to key retracement points of 114.54 yen and 115 yen, levels the dollar failed to sustain momentum beyond previously.

site_title: With a threat of 'tapes', Trump tells ousted FBI chief not to talk to media
summary: US President Donald Trump warned ousted FBI Director James Comey not to talk to the media, a move seen as an attempt to silence the man investigating possible collusion between Trump's campaign and Russia. Trump tweeted that if Comey gave his version of their conversations, the administration might produce tapes, although it's unclear if such tapes exist. The FBI is investigating alleged Russian meddling in the 2016 US election and possible Moscow ties to the Trump campaign. Democrats are calling for a special counsel to investigate the Russia issue and accuse Trump of trying to dent the probe by firing Comey.

site_title: DFI warrants have time on their side
summary: Duty Free International (DFI) has issued 477.7 million warrants with a 5-year expiry period, offering investors leverage and potential for long-term growth. The warrants have an exercise price of S$0.43 and are currently out-of-the-money due to the shares' current price of S$0.38. DFI's recent financial performance, including a 24.8% increase in net profit, suggests a positive outlook for the company, making this warrant a potentially attractive option for risk-averse investors.

site_title: Giving precision its name
summary: Micro-Mechanics, a precision engineering firm, supplies tiny parts for the world's sensors and memory chips. The company's machines, including a $500,000 drill, create microscopic holes in metal pieces for machines to pick up semiconductor chips. Micro-Mechanics supports other electronics firms, making critical components for machines used to make and test semiconductor products. The company's business model is niche, with no direct competitors, and its replaceable rubber tips have been sold since the 1980s. Micro-Mechanics' share prices have reached a historic high, driven by the semiconductor industry's rebound and growth in demand for consumer electronics.

site_title: Red tape, taxes, bribes put brakes on Make In India drive
summary: India's "Make In India" drive is being hindered by red tape, taxes, and bribes, according to the World Bank, ranking the country 130 out of 190 for ease of conducting business. Entrepreneurs like Saurabh Ahuja face challenges importing goods, with Ahuja spending an additional $900 in taxes and bribes to import a $600 3D printer for drone manufacturing. This gridlock discourages innovation and hinders the growth of startups, despite the government's efforts to promote the "Make In India" initiative.

site_title: Business sentiment in Singapore improves in Q1
summary: Business sentiment in Singapore improved in the first quarter of 2017, with 24% of firms expecting better business prospects over the next six months, up from 15% in the previous quarter. Sales, profits, and orders also showed significant improvements, with a sales net balance of -23% and a profits net balance of -28%. The survey predicts GDP could accelerate further in the second quarter, with a 3.1-3.3% year-on-year growth rate predicted in Q2, according to regression analysis. Economists are cautiously optimistic, with some predicting a growth rate of around 3% in Q2.

site_title: Evans says risks to Fed inflation outlook still on downside
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago President Charles Evans stated that downside risks to inflation remain a concern, despite a healthy US economy, as inflation pressures continue to fall short of the 2% objective. He emphasized that the risks still predominate, indicating a potential delay in interest rate hikes.

site_title: HPE bullish on growth, will deepen S'pore ties
summary: Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) has reaffirmed its confidence in its growth strategy, with plans to deepen its partnership with Singapore. The company will invest $140 million in the country over the next five years and provide resources to foster local talent. HPE has recently closed a significant data center deal with a global logistics services provider and has a long association with Singapore, where it first started operations in 1970. Despite a 10% decline in first-quarter revenue, HPE remains optimistic about its future, citing strong results in key areas such as technology services and Aruba.

site_title: Richemont cautious after fall in watch sales dents results
summary: Richemont, the owner of Cartier, reported a 15% decline in watch sales and a 46% drop in net profit in its latest financial year, despite a recovery in the US and strong growth in China. The company expects trading to remain volatile and has avoided setting specific targets for trading. Chairman Johann Rupert cited geopolitical uncertainty and the need to protect the group's brands, while outgoing CFO Gary Saage expressed concerns about the Hong Kong market. Richemont announced a new share buyback and higher dividend, but shares fell 5.3% after the earnings report.

site_title: US dollar slips after weaker-than-expected US inflation, sales data
summary: The US dollar fell against the yen and euro after weaker-than-expected US inflation and retail sales data, raising doubts about the Federal Reserve's hawkish stance. The core consumer price index rose 1.9% year-on-year, below expectations, and retail sales increased 0.4%, also below projections. This led traders to reduce their expectations of two Fed rate hikes by the end of 2017, with the euro rising as a result.

site_title: China's Xi offers indebted Greece strong support
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping offered strong support to Greece, citing the importance of Greece in China's Silk Road strategy. Xi proposed expanding cooperation in infrastructure, energy, and telecommunications, with a focus on turning the Piraeus port into a key transhipment hub. China has been investing heavily in Greece, including a 3 billion euro deal with a Greek infrastructure development group and a 320 million euro stake in a power grid operator. The move comes as Greece seeks to clinch a deal with its creditors to release new loans.

site_title: Pope greeted by thousands on Fatima pilgrimage
summary: Pope Francis arrived in Portugal's Fatima pilgrimage site, marking the 100th anniversary of child shepherds' visions of the Virgin Mary. He was greeted by thousands of pilgrims and called for harmony among all people. The Pope traveled through town in his "Popemobile" before arriving at the Sanctuary of Our Lady of Fatima, where he met with pilgrims from around the world.

site_title: US nears US$100b arms deal for Saudi Arabia: White House official
summary: The US is close to completing a $100 billion arms deal with Saudi Arabia, which could exceed $300 billion over a decade, to boost Saudi's defensive capabilities and maintain Israel's edge. The deal includes arms, maintenance, ships, and security systems, intended to address regional threats. US President Donald Trump's visit to Riyadh on May 19 is expected to finalize the agreements, which will be discussed with Saudi officials and Gulf leaders.

images.alt_text: The United States is close to completing a series of arms deals for Saudi Arabia totalling more than US$100 billion, a senior White House official said on Friday, a week ahead of President Donald Trump's planned visit to Riyadh.

site_title: United Global buys 95% stake in related Indonesia business for S$18.2m
summary: United Global acquired 95% of PT Pacific Lubritama Indonesia for S$18.24 million in cash and stock. The deal was facilitated by the Wiranto family, controlling United Global, and involves S$8.2 million in cash and 11.8% of new shares valued at 30 Singapore cents apiece. The acquisition includes Pacific Lubritama's net asset value of S$9.3 million and net profit of S$25.9 million in 2016.

site_title: China says all welcome at Silk Road forum after US complains over North Korea
summary: China has welcomed all countries to participate in its Belt and Road forum, despite US concerns over North Korea's attendance, which the US sees as sending the wrong message at a time of international pressure on Pyongyang. China's Foreign Ministry stated that the Belt and Road initiative is open and inclusive, and that North Korea will send a delegation to the summit. The forum, attended by leaders from 29 countries, aims to promote China's vision of expanding links between Asia, Africa, and Europe.

site_title: Uncertainty vanishes with Macron win
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron won the presidential election, eliminating uncertainty and boosting financial markets. The VIX volatility index plummeted to a 23-year low, while US indices near records, including the tech-heavy Nasdaq. Other markets, such as Taiwan, Japan, and Hong Kong, also hit highs not seen in years. Analysts attribute the rally to improved economic data and evidence of a real economic recovery, but warn that China's slowdown could dampen hopes.

site_title: North Korea says will have dialogue with US under right conditions: Yonhap
summary: North Korea's Choe Son Hui, director general for US affairs, stated that the country will engage in dialogue with the US administration under the right conditions, according to Yonhap. This comes amid international efforts to ease tensions over North Korea's nuclear ambitions. US President Donald Trump has warned of a "major, major conflict" but prefers a diplomatic outcome. Meanwhile, South Korea's President Moon Jae-in has expressed willingness to engage in dialogue with North Korea under the right circumstances, with sanctions to be used in parallel.

images.alt_text: The comments by Choe came amid international efforts to ease tension over North Korea's pursuit of nuclear arms.

site_title: 'Awesomesauce,' proclaims US astronaut on historic spacewalk
summary: US astronaut Jack Fischer made history with his first-ever spacewalk, describing the experience as a "ginormous fondue pot, bubbling over with piping hot awesomesauce." During the 200th spacewalk, Fischer and colleague Peggy Whitson worked to build and maintain the International Space Station. The live broadcast was carried on NASA television, marking a notable milestone in space exploration.

site_title: Researcher finds 'kill switch' for cyberattack ransomeware
summary: A cybersecurity researcher discovered a "kill switch" that can prevent the spread of WannaCry ransomware by registering a domain name used by the malware. The domain registration stops the malware from spreading, but warns that affected computers will not be helped and that the attackers can change the code and try again. The attack exploited a flaw in leaked NSA documents and affected numerous countries, including hospitals, government agencies, and major companies. The crisis is not over, and people are advised to update their systems immediately to avoid further attack.

site_title: Nasa delays debut launch of US$23b moon rocket and capsule
summary: NASA has delayed the debut launch of its $23 billion moon rocket and capsule until 2019, pushing back the initial flight from November 2018. The Space Launch System (SLS) rocket, which will send the Orion capsule on a high lunar orbit, will now not carry astronauts due to the added cost and delay. The delay is attributed to technical issues and tornado damage to the manufacturing plant, with the agency expecting a more specific launch timeframe in about a month.

site_title: Hollywood's Walk of Fame, the biggest star of all
summary: The Hollywood Walk of Fame, launched in 1958, has immortalized over 2,600 stars of public figures in the entertainment industry. The iconic walk of fame, featuring terrazzo and brass stars, has more staying power than individual celebrities. Each star represents a tribute to a contributor in film, television, music, radio, or live theatre. The walk of fame continues to attract visitors worldwide, cementing its place as a lasting symbol of Hollywood's enduring legacy.

site_title: Oil up slightly, low US inventories weigh on high rig counts
summary: Oil prices rose slightly on Friday, with benchmark Brent crude settling up 7 cents at $50.84, amid lower US crude inventories and support for Opec-led production cuts. The Organization of Petroleum Producing Countries is set to meet on May 25 to decide on extending output cuts. Despite this, analysts remain skeptical about the long-term impact of Opec's efforts, citing rapid US oil production growth. US drillers added oil rigs for the 17th straight week, with US crude production rising over 10% since mid-2016.

site_title: Neighbourhood Watch
summary: Japanese artists Eitaro Ogawa and Tamae Iwasaki, along with lecturer Tomohisa Miyauchi, captured 118 HDB homes in Singapore over three years, showcasing unique and distinct interior spaces. Their photographs are now on display in an exhibition at SPRMRKT until June 27, featuring selected images from a 700-page photobook available for sale at $50.

site_title: Medal of Honour conferred on DPM Tharman at May Day Awards 2017
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam received the Medal of Honour at the May Day Awards 2017 for his exceptional contributions to the labour movement. He has driven national initiatives to support workers, advocated for quality growth, and promoted tripartism. Tharman has reinforced labour-management relations, contributed to building a fair workplace, and ensured workers benefit from economic transformation. The Medal of Honour is the highest of the May Day Awards, recognizing his unassuming and approachable nature, as well as his dedication to workers' welfare.

site_title: Space for Change
summary: Architects are transforming rural communities in Japan and Malaysia through innovative design and architecture. In Japan, Airbnb's Samara studio has designed the Yoshino Cedar House, a property that promotes "rural revitalization" and supports local economy. In Malaysia, landscape architect Ng Sek San has created Sekeping Kong Heng, a hotel that conserves and restores old buildings, and architecture professor Teoh Chee Keong has built Project Kaktao46, an environmental classroom that brings together the community. These projects aim to address social and economic issues in rural areas, such as brain drain, and promote community engagement and cultural preservation.

site_title: Rolex Rarities
summary: A travelling exhibition, "Contemporary Watch Portraits," featuring 30 first-generation automatic Rolex Daytona watches, will showcase the legendary sports chronograph. The exhibition, curated by collector Pucci Papaleo and Italian photographer Fabio Santinelli, runs in Geneva, Hong Kong, London, and New York, highlighting the rarity and elusiveness of the watches, which were introduced in 1963 and have since become highly prized by collectors.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Global cyber attack fuels concern about US vulnerability disclosures
summary: A global cyber attack fueled concerns about the US National Security Agency's (NSA) vulnerability disclosures, with hacking tools believed to belong to the agency leaked online. The attack, which affected Europe and beyond, is linked to the leaked NSA hacking tools, raising fears of the spy agency's powerful cyber weapons being stolen and repurposed by hackers. This highlights a flawed US approach to dedicating more cyber resources to offense rather than defense, making the internet less secure.

site_title: The sweet sound of (man-made) silence
summary: The article reviews Sony's MDR-1000X noise-cancelling headphones, praising their luxury feel and high-quality sound. The headphones feature an ad-hoc listening mode, allowing users to pause music and hear external sounds with a simple hand gesture. The noise-cancelling technology is deemed superior to competitors, effectively blocking out background noise. While it struggles with higher frequencies and sudden bursts of noise, the headphones are a respite from everyday life and a great investment for those seeking a premium audio experience.

site_title: Europe: Stocks upbeat but retail earnings weigh on Wall Street
summary: European stocks closed at records, driven by Germany's robust 0.6% economic growth and a more upbeat mood following France's market-friendly presidential election. The euro advanced against the US dollar. In contrast, US stocks fell for a second straight session due to weak retailer earnings, with the Dow and S&P 500 finishing lower. London's FTSE 100 index reached a new record high due to sterling weakness boosting exporter earnings. Asian markets retreated, with Tokyo's Nikkei index closing down 0.4% despite Hong Kong's 0.1% gain.

site_title: Mexico foreign minister keen to start Nafta talks in US
summary: Mexico's foreign minister, Luis Videgaray, expressed optimism about starting North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) talks with the US after the Senate approved Robert Lighthizer as US Trade Representative. Mexico's economy minister, Ildefonso Guajardo, said talks would likely begin in late August, but only if all parties recognize Nafta's positive contributions. The US has threatened to withdraw from the deal if it cannot be changed, affecting Mexico's growth forecasts and peso value. Mexico is seeking to negotiate changes to the agreement, which has underpinned regional trade since 1994.

site_title: US: Stocks mostly down as retailers hit again
summary: US stocks finished mostly lower on Friday, with major retailers experiencing significant drops after disappointing earnings reports from JC Penney and Macy's. JC Penney plummeted 14% and Nordstrom 10.8%, while Best Buy, Gap, and Macy's fell more than 1.5%. Despite weak retail reports, first-quarter earnings for S&P 500 companies are on track for the best growth since 2011. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.1%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes also declined, with technology companies Apple and Amazon experiencing gains.

site_title: Far East Hospitality Trust's DPS down 13.9% in Q1
summary: Far East Hospitality Trust's distribution per stapled security (DPS) fell 13.9% to 0.93 Singapore cents in Q1 due to soft demand for its hotels and serviced apartments. Net property income dropped 10.4% to S$22.12 million, while gross revenue declined 9.5% to S$24.78 million. The trust attributed the decline to weak corporate demand and increased competition from new hotel supply. Despite this, the trust plans to refresh its properties and maintain a strong debt position to stay competitive.

site_title: Hackers exploit stolen US spy agency tool to launch global cyberattack
summary: A global cyberattack leveraging hacking tools believed to have been developed by the US National Security Agency hit nearly 100 countries, infecting FedEx, Britain's health system, and computers in Russia, Ukraine, and Taiwan. The ransomware, dubbed "WannaCry," encrypted data, demanding payments of $300 to $600 to restore access. The attack was sparked by exploiting a known bug in Microsoft's Windows operating system, and Microsoft pushed out automatic updates to defend against the malware. The hackers, not identified, likely made it a self-spreading malware by exploiting NSA code, with only a small number of US-headquartered organizations targeted due to spam filters identifying the threat.

site_title: My Weekend
summary: A local author and poet, Christine Chia, discusses the importance of weekends for her sanity, highlighting the need for sleep amidst the stresses of weekdays. The article lacks specific details about Chia's weekend activities or plans, instead focusing on her personal perspective on the value of weekends.

images.alt_text: CHRISTINE CHIA

site_title: Three common mistakes investors should avoid
summary: Investors often make three common mistakes: imprudent portfolio construction, chasing top performers or trendy products, and neglecting portfolio maintenance. Investors should construct portfolios holistically, diversifying assets and geographic locations to suit their risk appetite. Chasing trendy products can be difficult to differentiate and may expose investors to high risk. Neglecting portfolio maintenance can lead to irrelevance and poor performance. To mitigate these pitfalls, investors can consider using a robo-adviser like Fundsupermart.com's My Assisted Portfolio Solution, which provides diversified portfolio management and rebalancing.

site_title: Building Against The Odds
summary: A French architect, studioMilou, designed a unique home in Singapore for a couple despite the challenges posed by the land's triangular shape, wet conditions, and conservation rules. The firm restored the 1930s British civil servant's house, adding a two-storey building with a screen-like glass structure and a rooftop garden. The design seamlessly integrates the old and new buildings, creating a sense of transparency and fluidity. The lush greenery and wildlife attracted to the garden path and rooftop garden enhance the home's unique charm, making it a standout in the neighborhood.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Olympics: Los Angeles throws down gauntlet to Paris in 2024 hosting battle
summary: Los Angeles 2024 made a final pitch to the International Olympic Committee's Evaluation Commission, showcasing a plan with no major risks and existing world-class facilities. The bid, budgeted at $5.3 billion, calls for no new venue construction. Paris, the other city in the running, will present its bid next week. The IOC will present their report in July, with a final vote set for September 13. Los Angeles mayor Eric Garcetti has left the door open for the 2028 Olympics if Paris wins the 2024 bid, adding intrigue to the bidding process.

site_title: S'pore on track for record real estate deals in 2017: RCA
summary: Singapore is on track to achieve record real estate deals in 2017, with a 170% increase in total deal value to US$2.3 billion in Q1. The top five deals include a potential sale of Asia Square Tower Two and Jurong Point, with 18 deals worth US$5.3 billion in contract as of April. This growth contrasts with other markets in the Asia-Pacific region, which saw a decline in investment volumes due to a shortage of investment-grade properties.

site_title: Cooking Like Mum
summary: Five Singaporean personalities share their comfort foods from their youth, showcasing the influence of their mothers' cooking. Michelle Chong credits her mum's positivity and cooking skills for her love of food. Lynn Yeow swears by her mother's braised pork belly, while Sebastian Ng reminisces about his mother's petai dish. Julien Royer's mother's Le Pate de Pomme de Terre is a family favorite in his hometown of France. These comfort foods are often passed down through generations, highlighting the importance of family and tradition in Singaporean cuisine.

site_title: UOL plans to launch 3 projects in Singapore, London next year
summary: UOL Group plans to launch three projects in 2018: a 99-year leasehold private housing project in Singapore, a freehold project in Singapore, and a 43-storey tower with 160 residential units and 237 hotel rooms in London. The projects will have a total of about 1,050 apartments. The company's net profit increased 4% to S$80.3 million in the first quarter, driven by contributions from ongoing and new property development projects.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Genting Singapore's Q1 net profit up 17 times
summary: Genting Singapore's Q1 net profit surged 17 times to S$181.1 million, compared to S$40.23 million in the same period last year. The company's total net profit, including perpetual capital securities, reached S$210.17 million.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Noble Group Ltd reported a net loss of US$129 million in Q1 2017 due to dislocation in coal markets and decoupling of key price indices impacting hedges. The company is in discussion with banks on its base borrowing facility, with rising balance sheet risk. Credit Suisse lowers its target price to S$0.80, citing challenging operating environment and reduced 2018-19 estimated earnings per share.

site_title: Zero to Niro
summary: The Kia Niro hybrid is a zippy crossover with robust styling, distinct from its Hyundai Ioniq counterpart. The Niro boasts a 6-speed dual clutch transmission, sporty driving experience, and impressive fuel efficiency, with a claimed 3.8 litres per 100 km and 26.3 km per litre. Its average open market value is around S$31,000, with standard equipment like blind spot detection and seven airbags. The Niro's unique design and features have made it a hit, with authorized dealers reporting a high demand, leading to a swift sell-out.

site_title: Investing amid geopolitical storm clouds
summary: Three key geopolitical risks to consider for investors include Euro area politics, US trade policy concerns, and the risk of escalation on the Korean peninsula. Euro area politics appear to be receding, with pro-EU parties winning elections, while US trade tensions remain a concern, particularly for Emerging Markets. The North Korean threat poses the biggest challenge, with a higher-than-usual risk of escalation, making safe-havens like gold or high-quality bonds a viable option. A diversified investment allocation considering multiple scenarios is recommended to mitigate potential market damage.

site_title: A Sushi Obsession
summary: A 23-year-old chef, Aeron Choo, has dedicated her life to her omakase restaurant, Kappou Japanese Sushi Tapas Bar. She works 20 hours a day, sleeps 12 hours a week, and lives off leftover food from service. Choo's passion for Japanese food is all-consuming, and she sacrifices her personal life to pursue her dream. Her restaurant offers high-end sushi experiences, with menus ranging from $68 to $128. Choo emphasizes the importance of experience and patience in preparing high-quality sushi.

site_title: The International
summary: Nikko Asset Management CEO Takumi Shibata emphasizes the importance of observing body language and behavior in meetings to gauge employee performance and identify areas of improvement. In his 2013 leadership change, Shibata met with every employee at the Tokyo headquarters, including one-on-one meetings and group sessions, to foster a culture of transparency and problem-solving. This approach allowed him to quickly identify underperforming divisions and encourage employees to escalate concerns up the command chain, ultimately driving positive change within the organization.

site_title: My favourite book
summary: The Last Lecture, a book by Randy Pausch, is a memoir about a man's honest emotions after being diagnosed with pancreatic cancer. It explores childhood dreams and serves as a motivational read for those feeling uninspired.

site_title: Sumitomo Mitsui may be in talks to lease new London HQ
summary: Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group's European banking unit is in talks to lease approximately 150,000 square feet at 100 Liverpool Street in London, a project currently under redevelopment. The lease, if finalized, would be the bank's new headquarters, with plans to move staff from two existing City offices. The move comes despite expectations that the Brexit vote would deter demand for London offices.

site_title: Scoot touches down in Changi with its 14th Dreamliner
summary: Scoot, a budget carrier, has taken delivery of its 14th Boeing 787-8 Dreamliner, bringing its fleet to 14 aircraft. The airline plans to launch long-haul operations to Athens from June, with plans for two more routes by the end of the year and three to four routes within the next two to three years. Scoot aims to operate long-haul flights with crew bunk beds, a feature that will enable more efficient operations. The airline is also exploring routes in Europe, including Berlin and Vienna.

site_title: QT Vascular to sell non-drug coated product to Medtronic for US$28m
summary: QT Vascular has agreed to sell its non-drug coated Chocolate PTA product to Medtronic for US$28 million. The sale is part of a five-year distribution agreement that will be replaced by business agreements following the closing. QT Vascular plans to use the sale proceeds to reduce existing borrowings and liabilities. Medtronic has also entered into a loan and security agreement with QT Vascular, with the consideration of the sale potentially adjusted according to repayment of a US$1.25 million loan and other expenses.

site_title: Staycays For Mum
