summary: Oil prices rose for a second day, closing over 1% higher, as support for Opec output cuts and optimism about a US crude draw boosted confidence in diminishing a global glut. US light crude oil ended the day up 50 cents, or 1.6%, at $47.83, while Brent settled at $50.77, up 55 cents or 1.1%. Opec producers, including Iraq, Algeria, and Kuwait, have voiced support for extending last year's deal to cut supply by almost 1.8 million barrels per day, with a meeting set for May 25 to determine policy for the second half of 2017.

site_title: Systra, Meinhardt win design contracts for HSR
summary: Systra and Meinhardt have won design contracts for the Kuala Lumpur-Singapore High Speed Rail (HSR) project. The two firms will provide a range of multi-disciplinary services and expertise under the contracts, covering civil reference design works for two stations in Malaysia and 38km of the rail line. The 350km project aims to cut travel time between the two cities to 90 minutes and is slated for completion by end-2026. This marks the latest in a series of contracts awarded for the HSR project, with others awarded in February and January to various firms.

site_title: Norwegian wealth fund gets reprieve as recovery curbs withdrawals
summary: The Norwegian government reduced expected withdrawals from its US$930 billion wealth fund by 41% due to an economic recovery in western Europe's largest crude producer. The revised budget cuts structural oil-corrected deficit by almost five billion kroner to 220.9 billion kroner, or 7.7% of mainland GDP. Finance Minister Siv Jensen said the reduced withdrawals will boost aggregate demand, pushing up economic activity and reducing unemployment. The government also cut taxes further by 1.75 billion kroner.

site_title: Condo and HDB rental volumes see double-digit falls in April: SRX
summary: Condo and HDB rental volumes in Singapore decreased in April, with private non-landed rentals down 18.7% to 3,653 units and HDB rentals falling 17.2%. Despite lower volumes, rental values rose 0.1% compared to March.

site_title: Green thumbs up for AVA's release of new agriculture land
summary: Singapore's Agri-Food and Veterinary Authority (AVA) has announced the release of new agriculture land for food farming in Lim Chu Kang and Sungei Tengah, set to be tendered from August. The new land will be released on a 20-year lease, with a focus on productivity gains and a fixed price method for certain crops. The fixed price method will eliminate land price competition, allowing farmers to compete purely on tender proposals. The move aims to increase local food production and reduce reliance on imports, with the goal of achieving 30% of total food production by 2030.

site_title: Fed official says trade barriers a 'dead end'
summary: Federal Reserve official William Dudley stated that trade protectionism is a "dead end" that may score short-term political points but will ultimately hurt the US economy and global living standards. Dudley argued that protectionism blunts export opportunities, makes everyday goods more expensive, and can harm workers who can no longer compete in a global economy. The Fed's strong defense of open borders comes as the US economy experiences roughly 2-per-cent growth and low unemployment, with interest rates expected to tighten further this year.

site_title: OCBC buys Australia bank's retail, wealth business in Singapore, HK
summary: OCBC Bank has acquired the retail and wealth business in Singapore and Hong Kong of Australia's National Australia Bank (NAB) for approximately US$1.7 billion. The deal adds 11,000 new customers, primarily from Singapore and Hong Kong, and increases OCBC's mortgage portfolio by 4%. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move to expand OCBC's presence in Asia's wealth management space, where foreign banks face high costs competing with local players. The deal is expected to be earnings accretive to OCBC within the first year of completion.

site_title: Wilmar's Q1 net profit jumps 51% to US$361.6 million
summary: Wilmar International's Q1 net profit jumped 51% to US$361.6 million, driven by strong performance in oilseeds & grains, tropical oils, and higher contributions from associates. Revenue increased 17.4% to US$10.6 billion, led by higher commodity prices and sales volumes for tropical oils and sugar businesses. The company reported a 40.5% increase in core net profit to US$312.6 million, with pretax profit rising in several segments, including tropical oils and oilseeds & grains.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: A biopic celebrating small pleasures
summary: The biopic "The Happiest Day in the Life of Olli Mäki" tells the story of Finnish boxer Olli Mäki's two weeks leading up to his World Championship bout against Davey Moore in 1962. The film focuses on Mäki's personal life, including his romance with schoolteacher Raija, and the conflict between his sporting celebrity and personal happiness. The movie, written and directed by Juho Kuosmanen, celebrates small pleasures and human moments, earning the 2016 Cannes Film Festival's Un Certain Regard Prize and several Jussi Awards. The film features Jarkko Lahti as Mäki and Oona Airola as Raija.

site_title: China building a Disney world of winemaking
summary: China has built a series of European-style wineries, including a "Disney world" of winemaking, as part of its ambitious wine industry expansion. The 600 million yuan (S$122.4 million) complex, called Chateau Changyu Reina, near Xi'an, Shaanxi province, is home to over 2,000 acres of vines and produces 5,000 bottles of mostly Merlot wine annually. Italian winemaker Augusto Reina has partnered with Changyu to improve wine quality, and a second site, Wine City, is under construction in Yantai, with plans to produce 450,000 tons of wine and brandy per year.

site_title: More technology expertise needed in company boardrooms
summary: A global company's chief technology officer notes that every enterprise is now a technology company, and technology is disrupting all industry verticals. Fintechs are changing the rules for established banks and insurance companies, while new technologies like blockchain are changing traditional ledger systems. A survey by Calastone found that 44.6% of Singapore Exchange-listed companies have a technologist in leadership, but none have one in the boardroom, highlighting a need for more technologists in leadership positions to guide companies through technological changes.

site_title: EU passports for sale in sunny Cyprus lure rich Russians' cash
summary: Cyprus has been attracting rich Russians seeking EU passports, with about half of the 2,000 issued passports going to Russians since the government streamlined its money-for-passports program in 2013. The program allows foreigners to become citizens in less than six months by investing at least 2 million euros in property or government bonds. This has led to about 4 billion euros of foreign investment, equivalent to a quarter of Cyprus' annual economic output. Critics argue that this practice opens gateways into the EU, allowing individuals to buy citizenship and access visa-free travel without living in the country.

site_title: Trump is lying again, this time about Comey's firing
summary: US President Trump has been accused of lying about his reason for firing FBI Director James Comey. Trump claimed Comey was unable to effectively lead the FBI due to his handling of the Hillary Clinton email investigation. However, there is no evidence to support this claim, and many believe Trump is lying. This is not the first time Trump has been accused of lying, as he frequently chooses falsehoods over the truth.

site_title: Noble shares down 32% in largest one-day dive; posts Q1 loss of US$129m
summary: Noble Group, a Singapore-based commodity trading firm, announced a Q1 loss of US$129.3 million, despite a 10% year-over-year revenue increase to US$12.6 billion. The loss was attributed to a dislocation in coal markets and higher oil prices, which led to a 32% decline in its shares. The company plans to reduce costs and focus on its balance sheet and liquidity, with co-CEO Will Randall stating that a fundamental change in coal markets has been forced upon the company.

site_title: A-HTrust's DPS for Q4 up 5.4% to 1.37 cents
summary: Ascendas Hospitality Trust (A-HTrust) reported a 5.4% increase in distribution per stapled security (DPS) to 1.37 Singapore cents for the fourth quarter, driven by strong portfolio performance in Australia, China, and Japan. The trust's full-year DPS of 5.68 Singapore cents was a record high. Gross revenue grew 7.5% to S$57.4 million, and income available for distribution rose 4.9% to S$16.2 million, largely due to a 10.1% growth in net property income.

site_title: CDL's Kwek sanguine about residential market; group's Q1 net down 19%
summary: City Developments Ltd (CDL) reported an 18.9% drop in Q1 net earnings to S$85.5 million, mainly due to exchange losses and the absence of contributions from completed projects. Despite this, executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng remains optimistic about the Singapore residential market, citing stabilization of property prices and increased investor confidence. CDL has also announced a S$30 million refurbishment of Le Grove Serviced Apartments and delayed some UK residential launches until after the general election.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: 17 mentor partners appointed to Startup SG Founder
summary: SPRING Singapore has appointed 17 Accredited Mentor Partners (AMPs) to Startup SG Founder, a scheme providing mentorship support and S$30,000 startup capital grants to first-time entrepreneurs. The AMPs, including incubators, accelerators, and venture capital firms, will evaluate startups based on uniqueness, feasibility, management strength, and market potential. The 12-month program aims to create a self-sustaining startup ecosystem, with the government acting as a catalyst and the private sector playing a key role. The scheme is seen as a replacement for the ACE Startups Grant and iJAM scheme, which ceased last year, and aims to boost the number of Singaporean-founded startups.

site_title: Aldi raises stakes in US price war with Walmart
summary: Aldi, a German grocery chain, plans to expand its US operations with 400 new stores and remodel 1,300 existing ones, aiming to sell groceries at a 21% discount to rivals like Walmart. The company aims to further disrupt the US grocery market, which has seen 18 companies go bankrupt since 2014. Aldi's strategy focuses on adding more private-label goods to win over price-sensitive customers and is willing to adjust prices more frequently to respond to rivals. The company's growth potential has competitors taking notice, with Walmart and other retailers launching price tests to match Aldi's low prices.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Sabana Shari'ah Compliant Reit's manager waives 75% of base fee to cushion dilutive effect on distribution per unit. PhillipCapital reiterates "trading buy" call and unchanged target price of S$0.54. Meanwhile, Helen Wong retires as OCBC CEO, with Tan Teck Long named as her successor.

site_title: Nordea wooed with 'no new rules' pledge
summary: Nordea Bank AB, the largest Nordic bank, is considering relocating its headquarters to Denmark or Finland in search of a more favorable business climate. Denmark and Finland have promised not to introduce new regulatory rules if Nordea moves to their countries, while Sweden has proposed stricter regulations. The bank's CEO, Casper von Koskull, plans to make a decision before the summer, citing a desire to cut costs and increase profits. The move has raised concerns about Nordic regulatory divisions and the need for better cross-border coordination to handle the bank's significant size and complexity.

site_title: Tax headache in India a bonanza for global accounting firms
summary: India's implementation of the Goods and Services Tax (GST) is creating a lucrative opportunity for global accounting firms, generating an estimated $3.3 billion in extra consulting fees. International firms like PricewaterhouseCoopers and KPMG are hiring experts to help Indian companies transition to the new tax system, with Ernst & Young also fielding calls for help. The complex process has bolstered demand for enterprise resource planning, and businesses are spending significantly on accounting services, which may double in the first year of implementation.

site_title: China's tech money heads for Israel as US welcome wanes
summary: Chinese investment in Israel surged to a record $16.5 billion in 2016, with tech startups being a major focus. The increase was driven by Chinese companies seeking warmer welcomes in Israel due to tightened US regulations. This shift comes as US protectionism and regulatory scrutiny have made it more difficult for Chinese companies to secure deals in the US. As a result, Chinese firms are now looking to Israel as an alternative, with many already having invested in the country's tech startups.

site_title: A simple sense of well-being
summary: Chef Sebastian Ng returns to the culinary scene with his new restaurant, Venue by Sebastian, at the Downtown Gallery. The restaurant features a stripped-down concept with a no-frills menu, where dishes are served in a "first-come, first-served" order. The chef's simple yet familiar dishes, such as grilled lamb and roasted chicken, showcase his ability to evoke a sense of well-being and contentment through food. The restaurant's casual atmosphere and reasonable prices make it a promising addition to the dining scene.

site_title: Street Capital sees openings as Home Capital deposits fall
summary: Street Capital Group Inc reported a Q1 net loss of C$2.57 million, citing "sustained margin pressure" amid regulatory changes. Despite this, the company is treating recent turbulence in the Canadian mortgage lending market as an opportunity, with plans to expand into uninsured mortgages and evaluate non-government sponsored residential mortgage-backed securities. In contrast, Home Capital Group Inc saw its deposits dwindle, with available liquidity and credit capacity totaling C$1.61 billion, following a run on deposits after an internal probe into falsified mortgage applications.

site_title: Banks drive STI to 22-month high
summary: The Straits Times Index reached a 22-month high, driven by gains in three local banks: DBS, UOB, and OCBC. OCBC announced the acquisition of National Australia Bank's private wealth business in Singapore and Hong Kong, with minimal expected impact. Noble Group's shares plummeted 32% after reporting a preliminary net loss of around $130 million. The market's gains were not widespread, with the advance-decline score showing 239 to 268.

site_title: SLO to perform Donizetti work for first time
summary: Singapore Lyric Opera (SLO) is staging Donizetti's comic operetta L'elisir d'amore for the first time, marking a significant milestone in the company's repertoire. The production, directed by Tom Hawkes, will feature a modern urban setting and a talented cast, including Elena Xanthoudakis as Adina and Kee Loi Seng as Nemorino. The opera, known for its light-hearted and happy ending, will be performed with a focus on bel canto singing and will include a 45-strong adult chorus and 25 children from the SLO Children's Choir.

site_title: NZ$, C$ sink on domestic woes
summary: The New Zealand dollar and Canadian dollar plummeted due to domestic concerns, with the kiwi sinking 1.5% and the Canadian dollar by roughly half a per cent. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand's decision to maintain a neutral policy stance and its warning to investors that they were misinterpreting the outlook led to the currency's decline. Oil prices bounced, but domestic issues took precedence, affecting the commodity-focused currencies.

site_title: Fraud rates of US car loans soaring
summary: US car loan fraud rates are surging, approaching levels seen in the 2009 housing bubble, with as much as 1% of applications containing material misrepresentations. Lenders' losses may double to $6 billion this year, with 3% of dealers responsible for all fraudulent applications. The total amount of car debt outstanding has risen 50% since 2010, and delinquencies among subprime borrowers are increasing. While the impact on the economy may be muted compared to the housing crisis, "extraordinary" levels of hidden fraud are seen between the auto and mortgage industries, with lenders tightening underwriting standards but not necessarily preventing repeat incidents.

site_title: US diesel car market shrinks further with Mercedes exit
summary: Mercedes-Benz has paused its US diesel plans due to the technology's small market share and regulatory hurdles. The luxury car brand cited the need for increased approvals from US environmental regulators as the reason for halting efforts to sell 2017 model year diesel versions of its C-Class sedan, GLE SUV, and other cars. This decision represents another blow to the shrinking US diesel car market, further diminishing its already small share of auto sales in the country.

site_title: SBS Transit's Q1 profit up 26.6% to S$10.2m
summary: SBS Transit's Q1 profit rose 26.6% to S$10.2 million, driven by a 7.6% increase in revenue to S$283.4 million. The bus contracting model and higher rail ridership contributed to the growth. Operating costs rose 7.1% to S$270.4 million, but operating profit increased 18.1% to S$13.0 million. The company expects higher revenue from public transport services and rail services, despite a potential decrease in advertising revenue.

site_title: A classy horror flick, in spite of all its philosophising
summary: Ridley Scott's Alien: Covenant, a prequel to Alien, follows the crew of a spaceship, the Covenant, as they face a deadly alien threat in 2104. A solar flare causes an incident, and android Walter brings crew members out of stasis several years before reaching their destination. The film focuses on visceral horror, with the crew being picked off one by one. Fans of the original Alien series will find this installment appealing, but critics may still be left pondering high-minded existential issues.

site_title: ExxonMobil emerges as white knight for Jurong Aromatics
summary: ExxonMobil has agreed to acquire Jurong Aromatics Corporation's assets on Jurong Island, beating five other bidders, including Lotte Chemical Corp and SK from Korea. The deal is expected to give the beleaguered firm a new lease of life. ExxonMobil plans to integrate the assets with its existing facility to enjoy synergies, marking a strategic move in the energy sector. The acquisition is a significant win for ExxonMobil, solidifying its position in the market.

site_title: Japan's rising current account surplus spells tensions with the US
summary: Japan's current account surplus reached 20 trillion yen ($248 billion) in the financial year to March 31, its highest level in nearly a decade. The surplus is largely driven by falling import costs, not exports, and could exacerbate tensions with the US under President Donald Trump, who aims to cut trade surpluses with Japan and others. Analysts warn that Trump's "zero-sum game" approach to trade policy could lead to "trade wars." Japan has accepted an economic dialogue with the US, but is resisting demands for reciprocal trade balances.

site_title: EU to probe tech companies' trading practices
summary: The European Union's executive plans to prepare an initiative by the end of the year to address unfair trading practices by tech companies, including Apple and Google, amid complaints about contractual clauses. The European Commission's midterm review of its digital strategy prompted strong criticism from the tech industry. The proposed law aims to tackle unfair trading practices in relations between platforms and businesses, but details remain unclear. The move is seen as a response to growing concerns over the dominance of tech giants in the market.

site_title: China's US$246b foreign buying spree is unravelling
summary: China's record-breaking $246 billion foreign acquisition spree is unraveling due to tightened capital controls and wary counterparties. Cross-border purchases plummeted 67% in the first four months of 2017, with many deals cancelled or delayed. Chinese regulators are making it difficult for acquirers to move money overseas, and foreign sellers are imposing high break fees to protect against offer falling through. This slowdown in deals is expected to help stabilize China's currency and reduce capital flight, but may also undermine global corporate valuations.

site_title: Can technology-enabled urban farms be a winner for S'pore?
summary: Singapore can benefit from technology-enabled urban farms, also known as smart food zones, to deepen its food production capabilities and reduce reliance on imports. With advancements in LED technology and digital farming strategies, urban farming can be more efficient and productive, with benefits including reduced water usage and increased crop yields. Consumer demand for high-value, nutritious, and certified produce is on the rise, and Singapore can capitalize on this trend with strategic partnerships and investments in agtech. A potential partnership between Singapore and Western Australia, such as the Peel Food Zone, could help scale up commercial urban farms and address the country's land constraints.

site_title: 3-month SOR continues to fall on benign financial market conditions
summary: Singapore's three-month swap offer rate (SOR) has fallen to 0.7683% as of May 9, returning to early February levels. This decline is attributed to benign financial market conditions and low expectations of a US dollar rally, which has led to increased liquidity and depressed interest rates. Strategists expect another two US rate hikes this year, but warn that the current market sentiment may not be sustainable.

site_title: Meeting Singapore's changing taste buds with a taste of New Zealand
summary: Singapore consumers are increasingly seeking food products with environmental, social, and cultural values that match their own. This trend is driven by digital and social media, where consumers can easily verify a company's story. New Zealand, known for its quality dairy and meat, is meeting this demand by highlighting its sustainability, food-technology innovation, and food safety. The country's FernMark programme allows consumers to verify the products they buy, and over 40 companies have registered since its launch. Imports of New Zealand food and beverages to Singapore have more than doubled in the past 10 years, driven by consumer interest in the story behind their food.

site_title: The singer who saved The Platters
summary: The Platters' lead singer Sonny Turner, 78, will perform a Mother's Day concert this weekend, marking the only surviving member of the legendary doo-wop group. Turner joined the group in 1960 and turned their fortunes around after internal band troubles. He attributes his longevity to great songs with strong melodies and beautiful lyrics. The Platters, formed in 1952, shot to fame with hits like "Only You" and "The Great Pretender," and Turner still writes and records music to this day.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Trump is insulting our intelligence
summary: US President Donald Trump fired FBI Director James Comey, citing the director's inability to effectively lead the Bureau. The decision was made after Attorney General Jeff Sessions and Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein found Comey unsuitable for the job. Critics argue that Sessions, who had recused himself from the Trump campaign, made a recommendation to fire Comey despite his own involvement in Russian dealings. The move has sparked outrage, with many questioning the president's motives and integrity, and calling for an independent investigation.

site_title: ThaiBev's net profit takes a hit
summary: Thai Beverage's net profit declined 23.5% to 6.56 billion baht in the second quarter due to a decline in domestic consumption during the mourning period for the Thai king. This brings the half-year net profit to 14.3 billion baht, 2% lower than the previous year.

site_title: Working poor of Germany's rust belt desperate for change
summary: In Germany's rust belt, the working poor face desperation as Chancellor Angela Merkel's Social Democrats seek to unseat her in September's legislative elections. Petra Vogel, a 60-year-old hospital cleaner, exemplifies this struggle, having spent half her life working in the same clinic in Bochum, North Rhine-Westphalia. The region's economic decline has led to widespread discontent among voters, highlighting the need for change in Germany's politics.

site_title: FCL Q2 profit slips 42.2% on lower recognition of development profits
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Limited (FCL) posted a 42.2% decline in Q2 net profit to S$71.2 million due to lower recognition of development profits from Singapore. However, the company's fiscal H1 profit rose 16.6% to S$258.8 million, driven by growth in Australia and China. FCL's overseas markets generated over 60% of its profit before interest and tax in the first half. The company plans to leverage its management capabilities to expand in South-east Asia and Europe, and is seeking to accelerate asset divestments to fund new acquisitions.

site_title: Belt and Road Initiative - a project worth more than the sum of its parts
summary: China's Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) is a historic economic project worth more than the sum of its parts, showcasing major infrastructure projects to advance global integration. The forum, announced by President Xi Jinping, comes at a time of uncertainty with the US reversing past policies and countries shifting towards nationalism. China aims to stimulate cross-border trade by investing in rail, ports, and power plants along centuries-old silk routes, with the goal of boosting trade to $2.5 trillion annually by 2027. The initiative will redefine trade by including services, and China pledges to help its Asian neighbors and trading partners develop.

site_title: Diplomacy trumps trade rhetoric
summary: US President Donald Trump's diplomatic efforts have shown that his earlier threats were empty, contrary to his presidential campaign rhetoric. Unlike his predecessor, Trump has opted for peaceful negotiations with foreign governments and world leaders. His approach has been effective, as evidenced by his successful diplomatic tours and the upcoming EU-China summit. Trump's style, coined as "speak softly and carry a big stick," has yielded results, highlighting the importance of diplomacy in international relations.

images.alt_text: Mr Trump, in one of his first decisions after entering office, announced the establishment of the National Trade Council office.

site_title: Revisiting familiar characters after 30 years
summary: A 30-year sequel to the hit local theatre production Army Daze is set to premiere in Singapore, directed by Beatrice Chia-Richmond and produced by Annie Lek. The new production will follow the lives of the next generation, including the son of the original main character, as they navigate National Service and the impact of social media. The original characters, including Malcolm Png, Ah Beng, Kenny, Johari, and Krishna, will also return, with contemporary elements added to the story, including the introduction of a social media influencer. The sequel aims to remain relatable to the original, which has become a staple of Singaporean culture.

site_title: Building on change in BT Weekend
summary: A French architect helped a couple in Singapore overcome building obstacles to build their dream home on a plot of land off Holland Road. The article highlights the growing community of women chefs in Singapore, and how the city is reaching out to younger golfers to revitalize the sport. Additionally, it touches on various lifestyle topics, including a new restaurant showcasing mod-Indian cuisine, a zero-waste initiative, and a partnership between CMC Markets and Sophia Women to promote financial literacy for women.

site_title: Acting FBI chief contradicts Trump over Bureau support for Comey
summary: Acting FBI Chief Andrew McCabe contradicted President Trump's claim that the FBI had lost confidence in James Comey, who was fired as director. McCabe stated that Comey enjoyed broad support within the FBI and still does, and promised to protect the investigation into Russia's role in the presidential election. McCabe's comments came at a Senate Intelligence Committee hearing, where he also refused to comment on whether Comey had told Trump he was not under investigation. The FBI's rank-and-file had lost confidence in Comey, according to White House spokeswoman Sarah Sanders, but McCabe's statements suggest a different narrative.

site_title: Putrajaya refunds RM741m Bandar Malaysia deposit to axed consortium
summary: Malaysia's government has refunded a deposit of RM741 million (S$240.2 million) to the axed consortium of Iskandar Waterfront Holdings (IWH)-CREC for the Bandar Malaysia project. The consortium had bid RM7.42 billion for 60% of the 485-acre site, but the deal was cancelled by state-owned TRX City due to payment obligations not being fulfilled. Deputy Prime Minister Zahid Hamidi denied that Prime Minister Najib Razak was behind the cancellation, stating it was a commercial decision. The move has left shareholders reeling and has raised concerns about the relationship between Malaysia and China.

site_title: Aetna exiting all ACA insurance marketplaces in 2018 on rising losses
summary: Aetna will exit the Affordable Care Act (ACA) insurance exchanges in 2018 due to financial losses and uncertainty about the marketplaces' future. The insurer will stop selling individual health plans in Delaware and Nebraska, leaving a single insurer in Delaware's marketplace. Aetna lost $450 million in 2016 and expects to lose an additional $200 million in 2017. The decision has sparked political backlash, with the Trump administration and Republicans calling for the repeal of the ACA, while Democrats criticize the administration's sabotage of the insurance marketplaces.

site_title: Venice art fest a tonic for global woes
summary: The 57th Biennale art festival, "Viva Arte Viva", in Venice promises to lift spirits amidst global conflicts and woes. The festival, featuring 120 artists from 50 countries, emphasizes rediscovering overlooked artists and showcases topics such as forced migrations, mass surveillance, and inequality with a humorous and warming approach. Curator Christine Macel aims to give a global picture of the artistic situation, with notable exhibits including Olafur Eliasson's green light installation, which encourages refugees and visitors to share stories and assemble lamps. The festival runs until November 26.

site_title: Snap shares plummet as investors mark down first earnings report
summary: Snap shares plummeted 23% after the company's first earnings report as a public company, missing Wall Street's estimates. Revenue jumped 4-fold to $149.6 million, but fell short of forecasts. Net loss widened to $2.21 billion, and the stock fell to $17.66, wiping $6 billion from its market value. Daily active users rose 36.1% to 166 million, but missed expectations. The decline echoes previous IPOs of Facebook and Twitter, which also underperformed after their debut reports.

site_title: Scoot keen to add Honolulu as second long-haul point
summary: Scoot, a budget carrier, plans to add Honolulu as its second long-haul point by year-end. The airline has submitted an application to the US Department of Transportation to operate flights via Osaka to the Hawaiian city. Scoot aims to leverage its parent airline Singapore Airlines to fill seats on its long-haul flights. The airline has taken delivery of its 14th Dreamliner aircraft, which will be used for Athens flights starting in June. Scoot plans to scale back its Athens flights from four weekly to twice weekly from October due to seasonal demand.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Steel industry cheers for Trump as it envisages a new dawn
summary: US steel industry optimistic about President Trump's plans to protect domestic manufacturers, with stock prices rising 13% since Election Day. Trump's vow to invest up to $1 trillion in infrastructure and lower taxes is seen as a boon to the industry. American steel-makers are also benefiting from trade actions taken against foreign producers, including China. Industry leaders, including Nucor CEO John Ferriola, expect significant growth in 2017, citing lower imports and inventories. Despite concerns about the impact of Trump's policies on the economy, employees at Nucor plant in South Carolina remain confident in the president's agenda.

site_title: Engine snag forces Boeing to halt test flights of 737 Max
summary: Boeing is temporarily suspending flights of its 737 Max jetliner due to a potential manufacturing flaw in the engines. The issue, affecting the Leap engine's low-pressure turbine discs, was discovered during inspections and hadn't affected flight testing. The grounding adds to concerns about supplier strain as Boeing and Airbus unveil new aircraft models. Despite the halt, Boeing has several unaffected engines available to avoid delays, and some airlines, such as Norwegian, expect only minor disruptions. The 737 Max remains on track for its commercial debut later this month.

site_title: Ex-London oil and gas trader ordered to pay £453m divorce bill
summary: A former London oil and gas trader has been ordered to pay his estranged British wife £453 million (S$827.17 million) in one of the biggest divorce settlements in English legal history. The 61-year-old man, who met his wife in 1989, earned a fortune in Russia's energy sector, selling shares for US$1.37 billion in 2012. The woman, who became a British citizen in 2000, claimed equal contributions to their wealth and a luxurious lifestyle, including a villa in France and a modern art collection.

site_title: US labour market tightening; inflation pressures building
summary: The US labour market is tightening, with new jobless benefit applications unexpectedly falling and the number of Americans on unemployment rolls reaching a 28-1/2-year low in April. Producer prices rebounded strongly, pointing to rising inflation. The Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates in June, with some economists predicting another rate hike. This tightening labour market and inflation pressures could prompt the Fed to take action, despite concerns over the global economy.

site_title: Noir thriller with an ominous sense of place
summary: The 2015 Spanish noir thriller "Marshland" won 10 Goya Awards, including best film and director for Alberto Rodríguez. The film follows two Madrid homicide detectives investigating the disappearance of two teenage sisters in a remote Andalucía village. They uncover a dark history of adolescent girls being raped and murdered, with many victims subjected to sadistic mutilation. The film's gripping storyline and ominous sense of place leave a lasting chill.

images.alt_text: Raul Arevalo (left) and Javier Gutiérrez in Marshland, a gripping Spanish crime drama.

site_title: EU advised to rank Uber as transport, challenging business model
summary: The European Union's top court advised EU countries to license Uber as a transport service, subjecting it to local regulations, in a potential blow to the US firm's business model. The non-binding opinion, from Advocate General Maciej Szpunar, concludes that Uber's electronic platform falls within the field of transport and must be regulated accordingly. This could lead to Uber being required to obtain licenses and authorizations under national law, despite its claims of being a digital enabler.

site_title: ThaiBev's net profit slips 23.5% to 6.56b baht in Q2 as domestic consumption declines
summary: Thai Beverage's net profit declined 23.5% to 6.56 billion baht in Q2, primarily due to a 8.8% drop in revenue from domestic consumption, mainly affected by the period of mourning for the Thai king. Revenue also fell in the spirits, beer, and non-alcoholic beverages businesses, while the food business saw a rise in sales. Earnings per share decreased to 0.26 baht and an interim dividend of 0.20 baht was proposed.

site_title: UK watchdog opens broad review into retail banking
summary: Britain's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) is launching a broad review of how retail banks make money, focusing on the business models of high street banks, building societies, and credit unions. The review aims to address concerns that banks are under pressure to pay for free banking by increasing prices for products, leading to mis-selling scandals. The FCA will study the sector, which is dominated by the "Big Four" banks, and consider the experiences of challenger banks. Initial findings are expected to be published in the second quarter of next year.

site_title: Moon may succeed in pushing business reforms
summary: South Korea's new president, Moon Jae-In, has vowed to reform the country's dominant conglomerates, known as "chaebols," which have been accused of corrupt business practices and stifling innovation. Analysts say there is more momentum for change now, following public anger over the Park Geun-Hye scandal and the chaebols' cosy ties with the political elite. Moon has promised to promote transparent corporate governance, break up family succession, and restrict presidential pardons for business leaders, increasing the chances of meaningful reform.

site_title: Formula One: Alonso tells McLaren - speed up or I'm off
summary: Fernando Alonso, two-time Formula One champion, has warned McLaren that he will consider leaving the team if they fail to improve next season. Alonso, who is in the final year of his contract, expressed his desire to win a third drivers' world title and stated that he will be open to offers from rival teams if McLaren continue to struggle. Alonso has already had his Indianapolis 500 car written into his contract and plans to display it in his personal museum.

site_title: Pound extends losses as BOE says hikes depend on smooth Brexit
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) voted to keep interest rates unchanged at 0.25% in a 7-1 decision, disappointing those betting on a rate hike and causing the pound to fall 0.7% to $1.2852, its largest one-day drop in a month. The decision is contingent on avoiding a 'cliff edge' Brexit scenario, and analysts believe a smooth Brexit is necessary for a rate hike. The pound's decline is attributed to skepticism about the UK's relationship with the EU and market expectations of a rough Brexit.

site_title: Eurofighter delays threaten German Nato contribution: report
summary: Germany's promised contribution to Nato's rapid reaction force in 2018 may be delayed due to Eurofighter jet adaptation issues. The aircraft's ground-bombing capabilities will only be tested in September, leaving limited time for completion. The German government's report highlights other shortcomings, including outdated jets, a shortage of computing power, and munitions shortages. Despite a defense ministry spokesperson claiming the air force is on track for deployment, the report suggests a potential blow to the German armed forces' ability to play a larger role in European security.

site_title: Mun Siong Engineering receives letter of demand for compensation paid over Pulau Bukom fire
summary: Mun Siong Engineering has received a letter of demand from Berkshire Hathaway Specialty Insurance seeking S$488,457.47 in compensation for a 2015 fire at Pulau Bukom, where six contractor workers were injured. The US insurer claims the company paid excessive compensation to employees under the Work Injury Compensation Act. Mun Siong has notified its insurer and referred the demand, but no further action has been taken.

images.alt_text: Mun Siong Engineering has received a letter of demand from Berkshire Hathaway Specialty Insurance seeking a recovery of compensation paid arising out of a fire accident at Pulau Bukom in 2015, based on a Singapore Exchange filing on Thursday evening.

site_title: Disney uses glow of Shanghai resort to pump up Pirates opening
summary: Disney's latest Pirates of the Caribbean film, Dead Men Tell No Tales, is set to gross more in China than in the US, thanks to the success of its Shanghai resort. The film's world premiere in Shanghai marks the first time a Hollywood movie has held a formal opening event in mainland China. Analysts predict the film could pull in 1.56 billion yuan (S$320 million) in China, exceeding US$212 million in North America. The Shanghai resort's attendance has outpaced projections, making it a national destination in China and a key factor in the film's expected success.

site_title: Malaysia PM rallies supporters ahead of possible snap polls
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak rallied supporters at a rally in Bukit Jalil stadium, vowing the ruling party would triumph despite corruption allegations. He called former premier Mahathir Mohamad a traitor and attacked the Chinese-dominated opposition Democratic Action Party. Najib, who faces allegations of corruption over 1MDB, claimed Umno would remain in power for another 100 years. The rally came ahead of a widely expected snap election this year, with Najib signaling he may bring forward polls in December. The event was marked by a carnival-like atmosphere with supporters wearing red Umno t-shirts.

site_title: US stocks slide as weak Macy's results hit retailers
summary: US stocks slid on Thursday, with the Nasdaq retreating from a record, amid weak Macy's earnings. Macy's reported a 39% drop in first-quarter earnings to $70 million, sparking concerns about retailers. The disappointing results pushed shares of Nordstrom, Best Buy, and Gap into negative territory. Meanwhile, Snapchat parent Snap plummeted 20.1% after posting a $2.2 billion loss. The decline contributed to a US stock market downturn.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: Indonesia has detained a Trafigura employee in connection with a US$17 billion graft case. Meanwhile, OCBC Bank announced Helen Wong's retirement as CEO and named Tan Teck Long as her successor. Singapore's MAS and PBOC are set to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks have seen a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. CGSI downgraded Grab to a 'hold' rating, citing expected earnings growth slowdown in the second half. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. Sats CEO Kerry Mok's pay rose 30.5% to S$3.1 million.

site_title: Adidas CEO rejects shareholder calls to sell Reebok
summary: Adidas CEO Kasper Rorsted rejected shareholder calls to sell the loss-making Reebok brand, stating confidence in a restructuring plan to restore profitability. Rorsted announced plans to overhaul Reebok, including moving staff, cutting jobs, and accelerating store closures, following a 13% sales increase in the first quarter. Despite Reebok's struggles, Rorsted is committed to the brand for three to four years, citing the potential for turnaround. The company has also sold its golf equipment business and is exploring the sale of its ice hockey brand CCM.

site_title: Siemens to cut 1,700 German jobs in efficiency drive
summary: Siemens plans to cut 1,700 jobs in Germany, approximately 1.5% of its workforce, as part of an efficiency drive. The company will also transfer 1,000 positions to external service providers or other units within Siemens. The restructuring includes consolidating storage sites, cutting jobs at its Mobility business, and bundling training centers. Despite the layoffs, Siemens aims to hire 9,000 new employees in Germany, with a focus on retraining current employees. The company's goal is to improve profitability through cost-cutting measures.

site_title: Kushners abandon New Jersey property bid
summary: The Kushner family, related to President Donald Trump's son-in-law Jared Kushner, has withdrawn their bid to purchase a 95-acre industrial site in New Jersey for $1.4 billion. The site, known as Bayfront, was to be developed into a residential community for Orthodox Jewish residents in Brooklyn. The withdrawal comes amid pressure over the family's business-expansion efforts, which have raised concerns about entanglements. The site will remain available for sale, with other bidders potentially emerging.

site_title: Fragrance Group's revenue surges 92.2%; net profit up 1.8%
summary: Fragrance Group's revenue surged 92.2% to S$43.66 million in Q1 2017, driven by the City Gate project. Net profit rose marginally to S$5.39 million. Earnings per share remained unchanged. Despite expecting losses in certain quarters, the company expects to remain profitable for the year.

site_title: Bank of England: interest rates may need to rise before late 2019
summary: The Bank of England warned that it may need to raise interest rates before late 2019, contrary to market expectations, due to the economic impact of Brexit. The bank's latest forecasts show inflation peaking at over 2.8% late this year, and growth expected to slow to 1.9% in 2017. Despite this, the bank expects a pick-up in foreign trade and investment, and a sharp increase in wage growth. The decision to raise interest rates is expected to be made in the final three months of 2019, nine months later than initially predicted.

site_title: Use local currencies in China's Silk Road initiative for financial stability: central bank officials
summary: China's central bank officials recommend using local currencies in the Belt and Road initiative to ensure financial stability. This move would reduce dependence on major currencies and lower exchange rate risks. The use of local currencies would also enhance confidence and attractiveness of local currencies, according to officials. China has signed local currency swap agreements with 21 countries along the Silk Road route and has increased investment quotas for six countries. The move is seen as a step towards promoting yuan internationalisation and China's capital account opening.

images.alt_text: The use of local currencies instead of the US dollar or other major currencies in China's Belt and Road initiative will help to ensure financial stability, officials at China's central bank said this week.

site_title: Jackie Kennedy watch, painting could fetch US$120,000 at NY auction
summary: Jackie Kennedy's Cartier wristwatch and a painting she created in 1963 are set to be auctioned in New York on June 21 for up to US$120,000. The watch was given to her by her brother-in-law Prince Stanislaw "Stas" Radziwill, and the accompanying painting was made to commemorate a 50-mile hike. Christie's describes the watch and painting as "two of the most important historic artifacts" from the Kennedy era, capturing the spirit of friendship and optimism. The auction will benefit the National Endowment for the Arts, with proceeds to be donated to the organization.

site_title: SBS Transit's Q1 profit up 26.6% to S$10.2m
summary: SBS Transit's Q1 profit increased 26.6% to S$10.2 million, driven by a 7.6% rise in revenue to S$283.4 million. The bus contracting model and higher rail ridership contributed to the growth. Earnings per share rose to 3.30 cents, while the net asset value per share increased to S$1.38. No dividend has been declared for the current period.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets mixed before BoE rate call
summary: Europe's main stock markets experienced a narrow mixed opening on Thursday ahead of the Bank of England's interest rate decision. London's FTSE 100 index fell 0.1% to 7,379.23 points, while the eurozone's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices rose 0.1% and 0.2% respectively. Global markets reacted positively to higher oil prices and US President Donald Trump's recent statements, with Asian equities advancing and the dollar gaining against the yen.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rally for fourth day
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose for the fourth consecutive day, with the Hang Seng Index increasing 0.44% to 25,125.55, driven by a surge in oil prices. The Shanghai Composite Index also rose 0.29%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.19%. The rally comes as traders brush off new US threats to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: Snap CEO dismisses growth shortfall, scoffs at Facebook
summary: Snap CEO Evan Spiegel confidently addressed the company's disappointing earnings, attributing the shortfall to a lack of understanding of the platform's value and the need for "education" for advertisers. He deflected concerns, including Facebook's copying of Snapchat's features, by saying that being copied is a sign of success. Despite this, Snap's stock plummeted over 25% in after-hours trading, with Spiegel and co-founder Bobby Murphy losing over $1 billion each. The company has no plans to provide financial guidance, instead focusing on surprising its community with future product releases.

site_title: Haw Par Corp's Q1 profit up 21.8% on higher sales of Tiger Balm products
summary: Haw Par Corp reported a 21.8% increase in Q1 net profit to S$17.3 million, driven by higher sales of Tiger Balm products, which rose 16.3% to S$60.8 million. Earnings per share increased to 7.9 Singapore cents from 6.5 Singapore cents last year. The company's leisure business segment was negatively impacted by the closure of Underwater World Singapore in June last year.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 8.83 points to close at 1,775.39 on Thursday, with 3.55 billion lots valued at RM3.48 billion traded. Gainers outnumbered losers 560-376. The rally follows Asia's overall stocks rally despite US President Trump's new threats.

site_title: Operations at China Star Food's new plant halted; lower profit expected for FY17
summary: China Star Food's new manufacturing plant in Lian Cheng county has been halted due to a delay in the county's waste water treatment plant. The plant's operations will resume only when the treatment plant is completed by the third quarter of this year. This halt is expected to impact the company's revenues and profits, leading to a "significantly lower" profit for FY17. The closure also follows a directive from the local government to tighten pollution control requirements. The company has advised shareholders to exercise caution due to the uncertainty surrounding the treatment plant's completion.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: Commercial vehicles' COE premium falls further
summary: The Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premium for commercial vehicles in Singapore fell slightly in the first bidding exercise of the new quota. Category C vehicles saw a decrease of S$472 to S$26,029, while Category D motorcycles were S$411 lower at S$6,301. In contrast, Categories A and B saw increases, with Category A slipping S$494 to S$51,106 and Category B rising S$1,008 to S$55,414.

site_title: Food Empire's Q1 net profit up 58.8%
summary: Food Empire Holdings posted a net profit of US$6.31 million for its first quarter ended March 31, 2017, up 58.8% from a year ago. Revenue rose 23.6% to US$62.44 million, driven by increased sales in Russia and Kazakhstan. The company plans to ramp up production scale and explore strategic mergers and acquisitions to improve profitability and expand into new markets. Earnings per share increased from 0.75 US cents to 1.18 US cents for Q1 2017, with no dividend declared for the quarter.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: OCBC Bank agreed to buy National Australia Bank's private wealth business in Singapore and Hong Kong for US$3.05 billion, gaining access to 11,000 affluent customers. This move aims to expand the Singapore bank's customer base. Meanwhile, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. The UK economy contracted for the second month, while Malaysia's industrial production rose 0.3% in May. South Korea's trade chief seeks a 'landing zone' in US trade talks, and Malaysia is seizing assets worth RM3 billion from Daim Zainuddin.

site_title: 3-month SOR tumbles amid flush liquidity conditions, back to early Feb level
summary: The three-month Singapore Overnight Rate (SOR) has fallen to 0.7683% as of May 9, returning to early February levels, amid flush liquidity conditions. The SOR is a benchmark for corporate loans. Interest rate strategists attribute the decline to low financial market volatility, attracting emerging market inflows, and decreased expectations of the US dollar's strength. Despite a rise in the US dollar, strategists expect two more rate hikes from the US Federal Reserve this year, but at a slow pace.

site_title: Opec sees more oil supply outside the group, countering its cuts
summary: Opec sharply raised its forecast for non-member oil supply in 2017, citing higher prices encouraging US shale drillers to pump more oil. The group now expects outside producers to boost supply by 950,000 barrels per day, up from 580,000 previously. This counters Opec's efforts to clear a glut and support prices by cutting output, leading to a revised 2017 demand forecast of 300,000 barrels per day lower than initially expected.

site_title: AVA to launch tenders for new agriculture land, focusing on productivity
summary: The Agri-Food and Veterinary Authority of Singapore (AVA) plans to launch tenders for new agriculture land in Lim Chu Kang and Sungei Tengah, focusing on productivity gains. This marks the first tenders in about two decades and comes as existing leases are set to expire. The tenders will use new methods, with a focus on productivity, and will be awarded based on proposals rather than land price alone. A total of 36 plots of land will be tendered, with advisory sessions to be held for farmers to help them prepare.

site_title: Maersk soars as CFO says liner business 'definitely' improving
summary: Maersk's shares jumped 5.5% as CFO Jakob Stausholm said the company's container business is "definitely" improving, despite missing analyst estimates in its first-quarter results. The company reported a 16% increase in profit to $245 million, but revenue rose only 5% to $8.96 billion. Maersk expects the global container market to grow 2-4% in 2017, with its liner unit improving its underlying result by over $1 billion. The company is on track to separate its energy units by the end of 2018.

site_title: European airlines bracing for expansion of Trump's laptop ban
summary: European airlines, including Air France-KLM and Lufthansa, are preparing for the potential expansion of the US laptop ban to their hubs. The ban, initially targeting Middle East and African airports, could affect major carriers and impact global travel. The European Commission has urged cooperation with the US on any new measures, and airlines are working internally to respond to the possibility of an extension. The US Department of Homeland Security has not confirmed a decision on the expansion, but officials are considering a broader application of the measures.

site_title: Somalia asks world to help stabilise ravaged nation
summary: Somalia's President Mohamed Abdullahi Mohamed urged world powers to help stabilize the crisis-wracked nation at a London conference, calling on international support to combat terror, corruption, and poverty. The one-day conference aims to strike a new agreement to speed up progress on security, development, and the economy by 2020. The UN Secretary-General appealed for $900 million to prevent a famine, while the US has deployed hundreds of troops to counter terrorism. The conference seeks to ensure Somalia takes greater responsibility for its own security and rebuilds its economy.

site_title: Grand tour for G-7 begins as Italy seeks to dazzle amid woes
summary: Italy hosts the G-7 meetings this month, seeking to divert investors from its banking woes and economic sluggishness amid political turmoil. The country's economy, the euro region's third-largest, faces challenges including a high debt-to-GDP ratio and a banking system saddled with bad loans. The meetings, starting in Bari, aim to discuss inclusive growth while tackling rising inequality. Italy's former Prime Minister Matteo Renzi, set to run again, faces a strong challenge from the anti-establishment Five Star Movement, which has called for a referendum on Italy's euro membership.

site_title: Nordic Group secures S$38.9m worth of contracts
summary: Nordic Group Limited's subsidiaries, Austin Energy and Multiheight Scaffolding, secured approximately S$38.9 million worth of contracts from repeat and new customers. Austin Energy secured a three-year contract worth S$35 million for a petrochemical industry project, while the two subsidiaries also secured smaller projects totaling S$3.9 million. The contracts are expected to be completed by the second quarter of 2018 and are not expected to significantly impact Nordic's financial performance.

site_title: Wing Tai's net profit surges to S$7.4m, revenue slips 35% to S$73.5m in Q3
summary: Wing Tai Holdings reported a net profit of S$7.4 million in Q3, a 255% surge from the previous year. Revenue slipped 35% to S$73.5 million for the quarter, and 49% to S$204.6 million for the nine months. The decline in revenue was attributed to lower contributions from development properties. This brings the company's nine-month net profit to S$10.6 million, a 104% increase from the previous year.

images.alt_text: Property and retail company Wing Tai Holdings posted a net profit of S$7.4 million in its third quarter, a surge of 255 per cent from the previous year, the group said in a Singapore Exchange filing on Thursday evening.

site_title: Singapore stocks close mixed despite banks, Jardine stocks pushing STI to 22-mth high
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) reached a 22-month high, closing at 3,271.11 points, driven by gains in three banks (DBS, UOB, and OCBC) and the Jardine stable. The index rose 21.14 points or 0.65% despite mixed investor sentiment. Heavy trading volume of 2.1 billion units contributed to the increase.

site_title: Noble incurs Q1 net loss of US$129.5m despite rise in revenue
summary: NOBLE Group reported a net loss of US$129.5 million for the first quarter despite a 10% year-on-year increase in revenue to US$12.6 billion. The operating environment was challenging due to dislocated coal markets and thin liquidity, leading to a decline in supply chain operating income. The company also announced various board changes, including the appointment of Paul Brough as new chairman.

site_title: A Bible and a cell: a new life for Jakarta's high-flying Christian governor
summary: Jakarta's former Christian governor, Basuki Tjahaja Purnama, has been transferred to a high-security detention center after being convicted of insulting Islam in Muslim-majority Indonesia. His conviction sparked widespread protests and a harsh two-year imprisonment sentence. Purnama's sister, Fifi Lety Indra, said he is being treated well in the facility, where he has a Bible as his only comfort. His legal team is preparing an appeal and has submitted a request to commute his sentence to a ban on traveling outside Jakarta.

site_title: City Developments' Q1 net profit shrinks 18.9% to S$85.5m
summary: City Developments Ltd (CDL) reported a 18.9% drop in Q1 net earnings to S$85.5 million, due to factors such as the absence of contribution from completed joint-venture projects and exchange losses. The group's London-listed hotel subsidiary, Millennium & Copthorne Hotels, also underperformed. CDL attributed the weaker bottomline to various factors, including the repayment of a New Zealand dollar-denominated loan and lower investment income.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Broker's take: OCBC's purchase of NAB's private wealth business positive
summary: OCBC Bank has agreed to purchase National Australia Bank's private wealth business in Singapore and Hong Kong for an undisclosed amount. Analysts at RHB Research Institute believe the acquisition could expand OCBC's share of loans to the housing mortgage space, potentially increasing its overall wealth management business. However, the impact of the acquisition is expected to be small, accounting for only 1.1% of OCBC's current loans and 1.6% of its deposits. The acquisition is expected to increase OCBC's mortgage portfolio by 4%.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 10.580 points to 1776.290. The index saw 138.54 million lots traded worth RM61.07 million, with 228 gainers outnumbering 55 losers.

site_title: Xi, Moon agree denuclearising North Korea 'common goal': Seoul
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping and South Korean President Moon Jae-In agreed that denuclearizing North Korea is a "common goal" in their first phone conversation, according to Seoul. The two leaders also agreed to engage in bilateral talks to address concerns over the US anti-missile system, Thaad, and proposed a special delegation to discuss the issue. Xi officially invited Moon to visit Beijing, marking a thaw in ties between the two countries. The agreement aims to strengthen cooperation and address tensions over North Korea's nuclear ambitions.

site_title: Nissan warns profit growth set to stall
summary: Nissan warned that its profit growth will stall this year, citing a decline in operating profit and revenue due to a stronger yen. The company reported a net profit of $5.82 billion in the fiscal year to March, driven by gains from the sale of its stake in an auto parts supplier. For the current year, Nissan expects net profit to fall 19.4% to $535 billion, with operating profit and revenue also declining. The forecast comes as the company navigates changes in the market, including the departure of CEO Carlos Ghosn.

site_title: Wilmar's Q1 net profit leaps 51% to US$361.6m
summary: Wilmar International's net profit surged 51% to US$361.6 million in Q1, driven by strong performance in oilseeds, grains, and tropical oils, as well as higher contributions from associates. Core net profit rose 40.5% to US$312.6 million, while revenue increased 17.4% to US$10.6 billion. Earnings per share rose to 5.7 US cents, but Wilmar shares fell 1.15% to S$3.43.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Emirates airline annual profit falls for the first time in 5 years
summary: Emirates airline reported its first annual profit decline in 5 years, with a 82% drop in net profit to 1.3 billion dirhams. The decline was attributed to a slowdown in demand for travel and the relentless rise of the US dollar. Despite an 8% rise in passengers carried, the airline's load factor fell 1.4 percentage points. Revenue remained flat at 85.1 billion dirhams, while fuel costs increased 6% to 21 billion dirhams. Emirates Chairman Sheikh Ahmed bin Saeed al-Maktoum expressed optimism for the future, but acknowledged the challenges faced by the airline industry.

images.alt_text: Emirates, the Middle East's largest airline, reported a decline in annual profit on Thursday for the first time in five years.

site_title: McDonald's Singapore looking to hire
summary: McDonald's Singapore is holding its first large-scale National Hiring Day on May 13, 2017, aiming to hire at least 200 permanent positions, including service crew, restaurant management trainees, and McDelivery riders. The company, with 9,000 employees across 130 restaurants, seeks 2,000 new crew member applicants.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Scoot to expand long-haul routes; collects second Boeing 787 fitted with crew bunks
summary: Scoot, a low-cost carrier, plans to expand its long-haul routes, aiming for 3-4 routes in the next 2-3 years. The airline recently collected its second Boeing 787, fitted with crew bunks, and is set to launch its longest service, a Singapore-Athens flight in June. This expansion marks a significant shift in the airline's network, with long-haul routes expected to account for a major part of its operations.

site_title: Maersk Q1 net profit above forecast, container unit reports loss
summary: Maersk Q1 net profit exceeded forecasts at $253 million, beating the $199 million average forecast. However, its container unit, Maersk Line, reported a $66 million loss due to a higher fuel bill. CEO Soren Skou stated that the result is "as expected" but the company remains unsatisfied with overall profitability, reaffirming its year-end guidance.

site_title: Seoul: Won, shares gain on hopes for expansionary policies
summary: The South Korean won rose 0.7% to 1,127.9 to the US dollar, driven by hopes for expansionary fiscal policies under President Moon Jae-In's government. Local equities rebounded, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) closing up 1.1% at 2,295.49 points. Foreign investors extended their buying spree, purchasing a net 105.1 billion won worth of Kospi shares.

site_title: Toyota rebounds as Nikkei 225 ends higher
summary: Toyota rebounded as the Nikkei 225 index rose 0.31% to 19,961.55, closing near the 20,000 level. The broader Topix index inched up 0.11% to 1,586.86. Toyota's share buyback news was seen as a positive, but investors also weighed concerns about the company's potential for a second straight year of profit decline. Despite this, Tokyo's benchmark index ended the day higher, with the STI also up 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks push rally into fourth day
summary: Hong Kong shares rose for a fourth consecutive day, reaching near two-year highs, driven by a surge in oil prices. The Hang Seng Index increased 0.19% to 25,063.28, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.52%. This rally comes despite uncertainty surrounding US trade policies, which has affected global markets.

site_title: FBI's Comey says won't dwell on sacking, will "be fine"
summary: Former FBI director James Comey has written a farewell letter, stating he won't dwell on his firing by President Donald Trump and will "be fine." In the letter, Comey expressed his gratitude for the mission and colleagues but didn't comment on the reason behind his dismissal. He also stated that a President can fire an FBI Director for any reason, and he won't spend time on the decision.

site_title: Noble announces board changes; Paul Brough to replace Elman as chairman
summary: NOBLE Group has appointed independent non-executive director Paul Brough as its new chairman, replacing founder Richard Elman, who will transition to a non-executive role as chairman emeritus. Elman cited the firm's focus on lower-cost platforms as a reason for his departure. Other board changes include the departure of directors Iain Bruce, Irene Lee, and Richard Margolis, and the addition of Jamie O'Donnell and representatives from CIC, Benjamin Bao and Winston Ma. The changes are effective immediately, following Elman's initial announcement in June 2016.

site_title: China said to prep Hong Kong stock support for Handover Day
summary: China has prepared to support Hong Kong's stock market ahead of the 20th anniversary of the city's handover to China on July 1. State-backed institutions have set aside funds to ensure stable trading, but the government's involvement risks provoking critics who say China is interfering too much in Hong Kong's affairs. The move may also fuel debate over Hong Kong's future as a financial center, which relies on its strong rule of law and minimal government interference. China has a history of influencing domestic markets during important political events, and any intervention in Hong Kong's stock market may be seen as a departure from the "one country, two systems" principle.

images.alt_text: China's government has made preparations to support the Hong Kong stock market if needed to create a positive atmosphere before July 1, when Xi Jinping is expected to visit the city for the first time as president to mark 20 years of Chinese rule.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rise, retest key 10,000 level
summary: Taiwan's main Taiex index rose 0.39% to 10,007.16, driven by gains in semiconductor and plastics makers. The index also touched a key 10,000 points level earlier in the week. The rally was also fueled by MSCI's global stocks benchmark hitting a record closing high, supported by strong oil prices.

site_title: Uber says to partner with taxis in Myanmar expansion drive
summary: Uber has partnered with taxis in Myanmar to expand its services, hiring only government-accredited drivers to avoid regulatory hurdles. The move is unique to Myanmar and allows Uber to comply with existing regulations. Uber's expansion follows Grab Taxi, a rival service provider, and aims to tap into Myanmar's growing mobile services market, where internet penetration is nearly 90%. The partnership may also help upgrade Yangon's 70,000 taxis, and Uber plans to integrate its services with the bus network.

site_title: Renting a no-doorman apartment in Manhattan has never cost more
summary: Manhattan apartment rents have hit a record high for no-frills buildings without doormen, with median rents increasing 5.8% to $2,995 in April. In contrast, luxury buildings with doormen saw a 3.1% decline in median rents to $3,758. Landlords are offering concessions such as free rent and broker fees to attract tenants, while new construction is providing more options for renters. The surge in supply is expected to continue, with over 5,500 new units added to Manhattan's market-rate rental inventory in 2017.

site_title: LVMH raises luxury e-commerce stakes with multi-brand website launch
summary: LVMH launches its first multi-brand luxury e-commerce site, 24Sevres.com, featuring over 150 luxury brands including Louis Vuitton, Gucci, and Prada, after an 8-year hiatus. The site will ship to over 75 countries and focus on womenswear, with 68 brands contributing exclusive products. The move aims to compete with established luxury brands and newcomers in the growing digital luxury industry. The site is LVMH's first major multi-brand e-commerce platform since 2009, marking a significant step up in competition.

site_title: ExxonMobil confirms acquisition of Jurong Aromatics Corp
summary: ExxonMobil has confirmed the acquisition of Jurong Aromatics Corp, an undisclosed sum deal that presents operational and logistical synergies for its refining and petrochemical complex in the region. The integration of the aromatics plant with ExxonMobil's existing facility will enable growth and competitiveness, according to ExxonMobil Asia Pacific chairman Gan Seow Kee. The acquisition is expected to enhance ExxonMobil's capabilities in the region.

site_title: UK telecoms group BT to cut 4,000 jobs in restructuring after "challenging year"
summary: BT, a UK telecoms group, plans to cut 4,000 jobs in its Global Services unit, scaling back its operations to recover from an accounting scandal and a profit warning. The restructuring, costing £300 million, aims to simplify the business and improve financial performance. The company also lowered its dividend growth ambitions, citing a "challenging year" marked by headwinds in the UK public sector and international corporate markets. The job cuts and reduced dividend growth are part of efforts to address the impact of the Italian accounting scandal, which wiped £8 billion from the company's value.

site_title: Gold inches up from 8-week low as US dollar weakens
summary: Gold prices edged up 0.2% to US$1,220.56 per ounce, holding above an eight-week low, as the US dollar weakened against the yen. A moderation in Trump's foreign policy rhetoric and a potential "market-friendly" French election result reduced demand for gold to hedge against political risk. The US Federal Reserve is expected to hike interest rates three more times this year, which could cap gold demand in the near term.

site_title: Malaysia March factory output up 4.6% y-o-y, meets forecast
summary: Malaysia's industrial production in March rose 4.6% from the previous year, meeting a forecast, driven by growth in the manufacturing and mining sectors. Manufacturing output increased 5.9% year-on-year, while electricity output declined 0.2%. Exports rose 24.1% in March, but slowed from the previous month. This growth is supported by new orders and output expansion, as seen in the IHS Markit manufacturing purchasing managers' index, which showed Malaysian factory activity expanding for the first time in over two years.

site_title: Seoul: Won strengthens on expansionary policy hopes, stocks rebound
summary: The South Korean won strengthened 0.7% to 1,128.0 against the US dollar as investors bet on expansionary fiscal policies under President Moon Jae-In's government. Global risk sentiment also rose, driven by a rise in oil prices, supporting the currency. South Korean shares rebounded 0.9% at 2,289.74 points, with LG Electronics and Samsung SDI gaining 3% and 4.2% respectively. However, offshore investors were set to end a buying spell, and market analysts noted that the won's rise depends on decisive momentum and a firm gain.

site_title: Acclimatise in bed, climb Everest in half the time
summary: A Singapore-based businessman, Brooks Entwistle, is attempting to summit Mount Everest in just 35 days, using a pre-acclimatization method that involves spending time in a hypoxic tent to mimic high-altitude conditions. This method, also known as "flash Everest," is gaining traction among expedition organizers, with several companies offering packages that allow clients to pre-acclimatize at home before ascending the mountain. Proponents claim it reduces the risk of frostbite, accidents, and extreme weight loss, but critics, including veteran expedition operator Simon Lowe, dismiss it as "quack medicine" that only works due to supplemental oxygen.

site_title: Taiwan: Stock index rises above 10,000 for first time in 17 years
summary: Taiwan's benchmark stock index, the Taiex, has risen above 10,000 for the first time in 17 years, driven by a global rally in technology shares and foreign investor interest. Net inflows into Taiwan equities have reached over $15 billion in the past 12 months, with Apple Inc suppliers such as Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co being favored targets. The island's currency has also surged 7.7% against the US dollar, posing a threat to its export-reliant economy. The Taiex closed at 10,001.48, up 0.3% for the day and 8% for the year.

site_title: Delong unit to buy 51% stake in Anhui steel maker
summary: Delong Holdings unit agreed to acquire 51% stake in Anhui Shoukuang Dachang Metal Materials Limited Company from Beijing Shougang Mining Investment Co. for 10 million yuan (S$2 million). The target company, currently constructing an integrated steel plant, will have an annual production capacity of approximately 3.05 million tonnes once completed. The acquisition aims to expand Delong's core business and serve as a new engine of growth.

site_title: 'King Arthur' director says David Beckham 'great on screen'
summary: Director Guy Ritchie praised David Beckham's performance in the film "King Arthur: Legend of the Sword," calling him "great on screen" and "very talented." Beckham played the role of Trigger, a soldier who pulls the Excalibur sword from the stone. Despite receiving scathing reviews, Beckham said it was "nice to be involved" in the film and expressed confidence that audiences would enjoy it. The film, which also stars Charlie Hunnam and Jude Law, began its global rollout in some countries and hits North American cinemas on Friday.

images.alt_text: David Beckham has received some scathing reviews in the British press for his cameo in the film King Arthur: Legend of the Sword, but director Guy Ritchie has given the former soccer star the thumbs up for his performance.

site_title: Australia shares steady; NZ ends at 8-month high
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index ended 0.05% higher at 5,878.3, despite shedding earlier gains, due to strength in financials, healthcare, and consumer stocks. Consumer non-cylicals led the way, with Graincorp Ltd rising 8.3% to a near-two-year high. In contrast, the telecom sector declined, led by Telstra Corp's 1.4% drop. Meanwhile, New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.9% to an eight-month high, driven by broad-based gains across sectors, with Reserve Bank of New Zealand signaling a neutral bias on interest rates.

site_title: Updated: OCBC to buy National Australia Bank's private wealth business in Singapore, HK
summary: OCBC Bank has agreed to buy National Australia Bank's private wealth business in Singapore and Hong Kong for the book value, approximately US$3.05 billion. The acquisition will add 11,000 new affluent customers and increase OCBC's mortgage portfolio by 4%. The business, which includes a US$1.7 billion mortgage portfolio and US$3.05 billion deposit portfolio, has a strong track record with negligible delinquencies. The deal is expected to be completed before the end of the year, subject to regulatory approval.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Asia: Stocks edge higher, kiwi slides
summary: Asia's stocks rose, with global equities near record levels, while oil rebounded. The New Zealand dollar fell after the Reserve Bank of New Zealand kept rates at a record low for an extended period. The S&P 500 Index edged higher, closing at a record for the second time this week. Shares in Australia, New Zealand, and South Korea advanced, while Japan's Topix index traded near its highest level since December 2015. Gold extended its decline to a seventh day.

site_title: Toyota Motor chief looking at spending cuts as profit slides
summary: Toyota Motor Corp's president Akio Toyoda announced plans to review investments amid a forecasted second consecutive annual decline in profit. The automaker's sales have stagnated, and it faces a decline in US sales, with used-car prices also falling. To address this, Toyota may cut spending on conventional cars and focus on hybrid and electric vehicles. The company plans to automate production at home and increase production capacity overseas, while also buying back shares and reducing capital expenditure.

site_title: Aldi raises stakes in US price war with Wal-Mart
summary: Aldi, a German grocery chain, aims to sell groceries at a 21% discount to its US rivals, including Wal-Mart, to win over price-sensitive customers. The company plans to spend $1.6 billion to expand and remodel 1,300 US stores and open 400 new stores by the end of 2018. Aldi's growth potential has competitors taking notice, with Wal-Mart running price tests and Lidl planning to open up to 100 US stores in a year. The price war risks a "race to the bottom" that could lead to more retailers shutting their doors.

images.alt_text: German grocery chain Aldi Inc is trying to beat the world's biggest retailer at its own game: low prices.

site_title: Flash: OCBC to buy National Australia Bank's private wealth business in Singapore, HK
summary: OCBC Bank has agreed to acquire National Australia Bank's private wealth business in Singapore and Hong Kong, marking a significant expansion for the Singaporean bank. Helen Wong, OCBC's current CEO, will retire and be succeeded by Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran. The deal is expected to enhance OCBC's wealth management capabilities in the region.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: G7 finance ministers to avoid trade spat, US official says
