site_title: Facebook fights fake news, cuts accounts ahead of UK election
summary: Facebook has taken steps to combat fake news ahead of the UK general election, removing tens of thousands of possibly fake accounts and tweaking its algorithms to reduce misinformation. The company published advertisements in British newspapers advising users on how to spot misinformation online. Despite these efforts, policymakers and experts remain skeptical about Facebook's ability to effectively combat fake news, citing concerns over the company's responsibility and the lack of transparency in its moderation processes.

site_title: OCBC beats expectations with 14% rise in Q1 profit to S$973m
summary: OCBC Bank reported a 14% year-on-year increase in first-quarter net profit to S$973 million, beating average forecasts of S$845 million. Strong earnings were driven by sustained growth in wealth management income, higher profits from insurance operations, and increased earnings from overseas banking subsidiaries. Loans grew 5% year-on-year, mainly from housing and consumer loans, while non-interest income rose 30% to S$977 million. The bank's private banking business saw a significant increase in assets under management to US$85 billion.

site_title: Deconsolidation of M'sian unit hits QAF's Q1 gain
summary: QAF, a Singapore-based bread maker, reported a 13% drop in net profit to S$14.2 million for its first quarter, due to the deconsolidation of a Malaysian unit. Revenue fell 15% to S$212.7 million. The company attributed the decline to the exclusion of profits from its joint venture, Gardenia Bakeries (KL), which was sold in 2016. Despite an increase in sales from its bakery, primary production, and trading & logistics segments, the company faces challenges from competition, currency volatility, and rising costs.

site_title: China skincare glow rubs off on Best World
summary: Best World International, a Singapore-based beauty products distributor, posted a 63% increase in net profit to S$9.7 million for the first three months of 2017, driven by China sales more than doubling to S$20 million. Revenue rose 27% to S$44.7 million, exceeding analysts' expectations. China sales of the "DR's Secret" skincare range were a key factor, with each set costing 3,998 yuan (S$816). The company plans to expand into new markets, including India and Japan, to replace those that are slowing down.

site_title: Fannie-Freddie look to provide financing for factory-built homes
summary: Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac may begin providing financing for buyers of manufactured homes, aiming to ease burdens on low-income borrowers. The move, part of broader plans to address affordable housing challenges, is subject to public comment and review by the Federal Housing Finance Agency. The two mortgage-finance giants plan to collect data on chattel loans to ensure responsible lending practices, following criticism of discriminatory lending practices by some mobile-home manufacturers. The pilot program could start in January and involve purchasing 350-425 chattel loans annually.

site_title: Moon declares election win, pledges to unify divided South Korea
summary: South Korea's Moon Jae-in declared victory in the presidential election, winning 39.5% of the vote and pledging to unify the nation. Moon, a centrist, defeated conservative Hong Joon-pyo and centrist Ahn Cheol-soo, vowing to be a "president of cohesion" who serves all citizens. The election comes after nine years of conservative rule and a massive corruption scandal involving former president Park Geun-hye. Moon's victory may lead to a new chapter in relations with the US, as he seeks to engage with North Korea while the Trump administration calls for pressure and punishment.

images.alt_text: "I felt the people's earnest desire for government change to create a country worthy of being called a nation," Mr Moon told reporters after he cast his vote with his wife at a middle school in central Seoul on Tuesday morning.

site_title: DBS in 'go green' partnership with DHL
summary: DBS Bank has partnered with DHL Express for a three-year "go green" initiative, allowing DBS international shipments to be delivered via DHL's carbon-neutral service. The service, which calculates and offsets emissions, is part of DHL's goal to reduce logistics-related emissions to net zero by 2050. This collaboration makes DBS the first Asian bank to fully utilize DHL's GoGreen offering, and complements DBS's own efforts to manage its carbon footprint.

site_title: Flyer owner Straco's profit up 7% in Q1
summary: Straco Corporation, a tourist attraction operator, reported a 7% increase in profit for the first quarter of 2017, driven by growth in visitor numbers at its China attractions and higher food and beverage revenue at the Singapore Flyer. The company's net profit rose to S$8.91 million, with revenue increasing 4.2% to S$27.54 million. Visitor numbers to Straco's assets increased by 7.8% to 1.07 million, with the Shanghai Ocean Aquarium reporting double-digit growth in visitor numbers.

site_title: British Columbia's business temptation: an opaque array of tax breaks
summary: British Columbia offers tax breaks to businesses in an opaque arrangement, critics claim it hasn't led to job creation. The incentives operate under secrecy, raising concerns about transparency. Despite the province's reputation for its natural beauty and urban lifestyle, the tax breaks have not yielded significant economic benefits, sparking criticism of the government's economic policies.

site_title: Forget taxes, the real problem is healthcare, says Warren Buffett
summary: Warren Buffett, chairman and CEO of Berkshire Hathaway, has expressed concern that the rising cost of maintaining the US healthcare system is eroding companies' profits, rather than corporate taxes. He notes that healthcare costs as a percentage of GDP have skyrocketed from 5% in the 1960s to 17% today, outpacing tax rate reductions. Buffett argues that US businesses pay a significant portion of healthcare costs, which he believes should be a priority for lawmakers and CEOs.

site_title: Emerging markets moving towards debt crisis: BOJ chief
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhoko Kuroda warned of a potential debt crisis in emerging economies, citing high and fast-rising dollar-denominated debt and currency mismatch. He drew parallels with the 1980s Mexican debt crisis and urged vigilance as the US embarks on monetary policy normalization. Global debt has reached a record $217 trillion, with emerging economy non-financial firms carrying a significant portion of this debt. Experts warn of a threat to these firms as interest rates rise and central banks taper their purchases of corporate bonds.

site_title: To eat or not to eat before a workout
summary: A study published in The American Journal of Physiology - Endocrinology and Metabolism found that skipping breakfast before exercise may be beneficial for health. Researchers from the University of Bath recruited 10 overweight men and tested their fitness, resting metabolic rates, and fat tissue after exercising on an empty stomach or after a 600-calorie breakfast. The results showed that fasting before exercise increased the production of genes associated with improved metabolic health and fat burning, but did not accelerate weight loss. The study suggests that working out on an empty stomach may be a more efficient fuel source and have long-term implications for physical well-being.

site_title: Why Warren Buffett hasn't delivered a big deal lately
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway is struggling to find a meaningful acquisition due to diminishing relative buying power. Despite having a cash pile of $96.5 billion, Buffett's efforts to find a suitable target have been unsuccessful. He hinted at considering returning some cash to investors via buybacks or a dividend, a move he has historically opposed. The billionaire's failure to deliver a big deal has led to a 1% gain in Berkshire shares this year, trailing the S&P 500 index. Buffett's high bar for deals and the shrinking list of suitable targets are contributing to the delay.

site_title: Condo resale prices unchanged in April but volumes down: SRX
summary: Resale condo prices in Singapore remained unchanged in April, with a 1.2% dip in the prime Core Central Region (CCR) being the only notable decrease. The city-fringe and suburban areas saw increases of 1.2% and 0.1%, respectively. This marks the worst performance of SRX's resale price index in 6 months.

images.alt_text: Non-landed resale prices in the Core Central Region showed their first decrease in six months, according to SRX.

site_title: Hair transplant boosting Istanbul's receding tourism
summary: Istanbul is becoming a hub for hair transplantation, with over 300 clinics specializing in the procedure, attracting patients mainly from the Middle East and Gulf. The city's growing popularity in the industry is boosting its tourism, with tourists like Jameel seeking the treatment as part of their visit. This trend is expected to continue, with the city's hair transplant clinics catering to an increasing number of international patients.

site_title: Southwest braces for upgrade of reservation system
summary: Southwest Airlines is upgrading its domestic reservation system to a new platform, aiming to avoid the issues experienced by other carriers during similar transitions. The system overhaul is expected to take place on Tuesday. According to Bob Edwards, a former chief information officer, transitioning reservation systems can be complicated. The upgrade is a significant change for Southwest, which will shift away from its current system.

site_title: Tryb seeks funds for fintechs already in a good place
summary: Singapore-based investment holding company Tryb Capital is seeking to raise US$100 million to invest in mid-market fintech companies with turnovers of US$5 million to US$10 million and cash flow positivity. The company focuses on companies that have been in business for five to 10 years and have a presence in one to two markets. Tryb aims to tap into the growing demand for financial services in emerging markets such as Cambodia and Myanmar, where digital access is rapidly expanding. The company will take strategic stakes in portfolio companies, avoiding high fees and focusing on long-term growth.

images.alt_text: The four partners, from left, Veiverne Yuen, Magnus Böcker, Markus Gnirck and Nels Friets, are upbeat about what fintech's expansion into Asean can mean for employment and intellectual property in Singapore - and for Tryb as well.

site_title: US$, euro up against safe-haven yen, Swiss franc
summary: US and European currencies, including the dollar and euro, rose against safe-haven currencies like the yen and Swiss franc, driven by bets on improving growth and tighter monetary policy. The euro and dollar gained against the yen, while the Swiss franc fell to its lowest against the euro since mid-October. Investors are pricing in a 75-80% chance of a US rate hike in June and expect the European Central Bank to start tapering later this year, leading to increased demand for dollar and euro.

site_title: US overtures in North-East Asia: War could break out by chance
summary: The US has eased its South China Sea patrols, allowing China to maintain control over disputed islands in exchange for China's help in resolving the North Korean issue. US President Trump has also downplayed China's currency manipulation and unfair trade policies. China has applied economic pressure on North Korea, but its involvement is limited. The situation remains volatile, with a war breaking out by accident or miscalculation possible. The US may revert to anti-China policies once the North Korean issue is resolved, posing a risk to regional stability and potentially leading to conventional warfare.

site_title: Powerful clans skirt restraints in South Korea
summary: South Korea's richest business clans, such as Samsung and Hyundai, have found ways to maintain control despite rising investor anger and family squabbles. They achieve this through charitable maneuvers, where family members park their stakes in business empires in philanthropic nonprofits, allowing them to keep control while minimizing tax payments. This strategy enables the clans to maintain their grip on power, even as external pressures mount.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: CWT Limited posted a 28% year-on-year increase in net profit to S$30.2 million in Q1 2017, driven by strong commodity marketing and logistics businesses. Aspial Corporation's net profit jumped 111.1% to S$6.3 million, while Rotary Engineering's net profit rose to S$3.7 million, with both companies reporting improved gross profit margins.

site_title: Dodging illicit cash, Pakistan startups seek VCs for funds
summary: Pakistan's startups face significant challenges in securing funding due to the reluctance of commercial banks, which prioritize investments in government notes and bonds over venture capital. As a result, many startups rely on illicit funding sources or turn to angel investors like Faraz Khan's Seed Ventures, which has invested 78 million rupees (S$1.7 million) in 135 startups. To address this issue, organizations like The Nest, a Karachi-based incubator, are emerging to provide seed finance and support to young entrepreneurs, with the goal of creating a vibrant venture-capital scene in the country.

site_title: Givaudan breaks ground for new fragrance centre
summary: Givaudan, the world's largest fragrance and flavor firm, has broken ground for a new fragrance encapsulation centre in Singapore. The 500-square-meter facility, valued at S$21 million, is expected to begin production in 2018 and will serve as a regional manufacturing hub for Asia-Pacific. The centre will employ 10 new professionals and reduce turnaround time for perfumes from creation to market. This investment marks Givaudan's commitment to its customers in the region and demonstrates its growing presence in the Asia-Pacific market.

site_title: Trump acts, and Kushners stand to gain
summary: US President Donald Trump signed a major appropriations bill, renewing a program offering permanent residence to affluent foreigners investing in US real estate projects. The program, EB-5, has been criticized for being abused and supporting luxury projects rather than job creation in rural areas. Jared Kushner, Trump's son-in-law and top adviser, is set to benefit from the program through a luxury apartment tower project in Jersey City, New Jersey, where he is urging wealthy Chinese investors to invest $500,000 each. Critics say Kushner's close ties to his family's business interests create a conflict of interest, and some call for his recusal from China policy.

site_title: Crown exits decade-long Macau venture with Melco buyback
summary: Crown Resorts is exiting its decade-long gaming partnership with Melco Resorts & Entertainment in Macau, selling its remaining stake for approximately US$987 million. The deal allows Melco to pursue Japan alone, a strategic move that Melco CEO Lawrence Ho believes will drive long-term shareholder value. The partnership's end is seen as a net positive for Melco, cementing its control and allowing it to determine strategies going forward.

site_title: Cheap Chinese aluminum threatens US national security
summary: The US is facing a national security threat due to the decline of its domestic aluminum industry, with only one remaining manufacturer, Century Aluminum, operating at 40% capacity. Cheap Chinese aluminum has flooded the market, leading to factory closures and job losses, and poses a significant risk to the production of high-purity aluminum needed for military jets and armoured vehicles. The Trump administration has launched a probe into aluminum imports under a Cold War-era law, which could lead to tariffs, quotas, or other remedies to address the issue.

site_title: A step for India's banks, but no giant leap for bad debt
summary: India's central bank, RBI, can now push lenders to start insolvency proceedings for bad debts, with changes to legislation. This move aims to tackle the country's $150 billion bad loan problem, which is hindering new credit and economic growth. However, the issue is not yet resolved, and the government's efforts are seen as a step in the right direction, but not a solution. The move is expected to lead to writedowns and errant borrowers being pushed into insolvency.

site_title: When things go wrong
summary: Shipping accidents are on the rise, with major vessel casualties increasing for the second consecutive year in 2016. Weather-related accidents remain the main cause, but losses from grounding or machinery damage are growing faster. Cargo insurers are concerned about the high value of goods on large vessels, with the potential for significant losses. Salvage companies are also facing financial pressure, with gross revenues falling 47% in 2016. Despite this, salvors remain essential for mitigating losses and protecting the shipping industry. Insurers and salvors must innovate and provide cost-effective solutions to address these challenges.

site_title: Preparing today's corporations for navigation of compliance maze
summary: Regulators worldwide are increasing their focus on corporate compliance with financial crime regulations, with potential fines and reputational damage. A study by Asia Risk and Wolters Kluwer found that 60% of portfolio managers in the Asia-Pacific region consider compliance a major challenge. Corporations can mitigate risks by screening financial transactions, especially customers and suppliers, and staying up-to-date with changing sanctions lists. As regulations evolve, companies must incorporate financial crime compliance into their day-to-day management to avoid reduced coverage from banks and increased costs.

site_title: Coach bags Kate Spade brand for US$2.4b
summary: Coach has acquired Kate Spade for $2.4 billion, aiming to expand its portfolio and carve new territory in the crowded fashion accessories market. The acquisition, announced on Monday, confirms months of speculation and will help Coach build a luxury group with an identifiably American aesthetic and price. The deal is expected to generate about $50 million in savings within three years, and will bring together complementary brands. Coach's extensive retail presence and brand-building experience are expected to unlock Kate Spade's largely untapped global growth potential.

site_title: Dell Technologies combines venture capital units of its two predecessors
summary: Dell Technologies has combined its venture capital units from Dell Inc and EMC Corp, creating Dell Technologies Capital. The new unit will invest around $100 million annually in startups, with a portfolio of 70 existing and prior investments, including Arista Networks and Anobit. The combined venture capital operations will invest $3-10 million in early- and late-stage startups, focusing on companies that support the data centre ecosystem. Dell Technologies Capital will be headed by Scott Darling, previously at EMC.

site_title: It's all about May as UK premier brands upcoming election her own
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May is running her own campaign ahead of the June 8 general election, focusing on her personal brand rather than the Conservative party. Her popularity surpasses that of Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn, and her team's loyalty is expected to be stronger due to her emphasis on personal leadership. May's campaign aims to secure a larger majority and a more compliant parliament, with her speeches often highlighting her own achievements and policies.

site_title: Frustrated with Tesla and GM, David Einhorn amps up pressure
summary: Hedge fund manager David Einhorn is increasing pressure on General Motors (GM) and Tesla, two of his most frustrating trades. Einhorn, who owns 3.6% of GM, is pushing for a dual-class common stock proposal that he claims would boost the share price. Despite GM's $20.4 billion cash hoard, Einhorn believes the company is not using it to lift the share price. Tesla's shares, which have surged 40% this year, are also under Einhorn's criticism, whom he calls "hypnotized" by CEO Elon Musk. The proposal and resulting proxy battle will be decided by shareholders on June 6.

site_title: Gold stays steady even in the face of war
summary: Gold prices remain steady despite rising tensions and global uncertainty, with narrow price swings seen in May 2017, the smallest in over a decade. The metal's value is less affected by war threats, terrorist attacks, and trade disputes, as investors seek alternative safe havens. This trend is attributed to easing ETF cash, reducing price volatility.

site_title: Banks continue to drive STI up
summary: OCBC's Q1 earnings beat expectations, rising 14% year-over-year to S$973 million, contributing 6 points to the STI's 12.99-point rise to 3,249.97. UOB and DBS shares also rose, adding 5.6 points. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed with 222 gains versus 235 falls excluding warrants.

site_title: US regulators launch probe into property bonds sold using overvalued assessments
summary: US regulators are investigating whether bonds backed by single-family rental homes sold by Wall Street's biggest residential landlords used overvalued property assessments. The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) sent a request for information to Radian Group's Green River Capital unit, one of the market participants involved in securitisations. The probe may expand to an industry-wide investigation, with similar letters sent to other companies. The SEC is looking into whether BPOs, a cheaper and less-stringent way to evaluate property values, were wrongly inflated, potentially contributing to the housing bubble.

site_title: US$1.3t housing boom set to be India's next growth driver
summary: India's housing market is poised to become a significant economic growth driver, with a US$1.3 trillion investment expected over the next seven years. The government's "Housing for All" program aims to construct 20 million homes and has granted affordable-housing builders infrastructure status, making them eligible for state incentives. With rising incomes and affordable housing on the rise, 60 million new homes are expected to be built between 2018 and 2024, creating 2 million jobs annually and boosting GDP by up to 75 basis points.

site_title: Carney keeps cards close to his chest on BOE's policy plans
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) is expected to publish its interest-rate decision and quarterly Inflation Report on Thursday, with Governor Mark Carney keeping his policy plans under wraps. Despite a strong economy, inflation is above target, and the BOE may be hesitant to act amid Brexit uncertainty. Economists expect a cautious approach, with some members voting against a rate hike in March and others predicting a faster inflation pick-up. The BOE's decision is seen as a sign of the central bank's cautious approach to tightening monetary policy until the end of 2018.

site_title: Warmer weather causing Alaska's tundra to release more CO2
summary: A new study reveals that carbon emissions from Alaska's North Slope tundra have increased by 70% since the 1970s, shifting the state from a net sink to a net source of carbon dioxide. Warmer temperatures are causing the tundra to release carbon dioxide through plant respiration and microbial decomposition, potentially exacerbating climate change. The study suggests that Alaska's tundra may be releasing more carbon dioxide than it stores, contributing to the state's increasing role as a source of greenhouse gas emissions.

site_title: China's Alipay grabs slice of US market with first deal
summary: Alipay, a Chinese mobile-payments giant, has reached a deal with First Data Corp to allow its users to shop at 4 million US merchants. The rollout begins with businesses using First Data's Clover products, marking Alipay's entry into the US market. This deal puts Alipay on par with Apple Pay in terms of acceptance, with the ability to hold cards from major credit card companies. Alipay aims to leverage its 100,000 international retailers to expand its reach globally.

site_title: Cortana to have its own smart speaker
summary: Microsoft partners with Harman Kardon to release a smart speaker, the Invoke, featuring its Cortana voice assistant. The speaker will allow users to control smart appliances, access news and schedules, and use Skype like a phone. This move positions Microsoft in direct competition with Amazon's Echo and Google Home, and analysts predict a fierce battle for dominance in the home hub space. The Invoke will be available in the fall, but a price has not been released. This is Microsoft's first smart speaker, following the introduction of Cortana in 2013.

site_title: Greener pastures abroad, wealth fees drive profits for Singapore banks
summary: Singapore banks have reported strong first-quarter results, beating analyst expectations, driven by growth in wealth management and a decrease in non-performing loans. OCBC's net profit surged 14% to S$973 million, while DBS and UOB also reported higher profits. The banks' overseas expansion, particularly in China's One-Belt-One-Road initiative, is expected to drive loan growth. With the worst of oil-and-gas woes believed to be over, banks are poised for a cyclical recovery, with analysts predicting mid-single-digit loan growth for the full year.

site_title: Hertz shares slump after loss outstrips estimates in CEO's debut quarter
summary: Hertz shares plummeted 18% in extended trading after the company reported a significant loss of $1.61 per share in its first quarter under CEO Kathryn Marinello. The loss far exceeded estimates, with Hertz struggling to make money on each car rental and facing lower used car prices due to a glut in the US market. The company is trying to adapt its fleet to include more compact cars, but this is taking a financial hit. Marinello cited "headwinds related to used car residual values" as a major challenge.

site_title: Stars align for South Korea's president-elect Moon
summary: South Korea's president-elect Moon Jae-in has declared victory with 40% of ballots counted, winning the eyes of 51 million South Koreans. As a liberal idealist, Moon favours dialogue with North Korea to ease rising tension, reform powerful family-run conglomerates, and boost fiscal spending to create jobs. A human rights lawyer and former top aide to former liberal president Roh Moo-hyun, Moon has a history of advocating for pro-bono service and peaceful reunification with North Korea.

site_title: Singapore elevates status as SEA visual arts hub
summary: Singapore has solidified its position as a South-east Asian visual arts hub, boasting a variety of museums, galleries, and art fairs. The city-state has seen a surge in contemporary art exhibitions and events, including the annual Singapore Art Week, which draws over 100,000 visitors. The Gillman Barracks, a visual arts cluster established in 2012, has played a key role in developing Singapore's art scene. The Singapore government's investment in world-class institutions, such as the National Gallery and the Singapore Art Museum, has reinforced the city's position as a major arts destination in the region.

site_title: Banks take a hit as Australia raises billions to fund new projects
summary: Australia's budget allocates billions to fund new infrastructure projects, including a second Sydney airport and an inland freight rail line, to create jobs and secure essential services. The government aims to return a surplus by 2020-21, despite a projected 2017-18 deficit of $29.4 billion. Levies on banks and foreign workers will help fund these projects, along with measures to tackle housing affordability, such as introducing tax cuts and increasing regulations on foreign investors. Treasurer Scott Morrison described the budget as "fair and responsible."

site_title: The war of the dual-class shares rages on in Singapore
summary: A contentious debate over dual-class shares (DCS) in Singapore's stock market continues, with asset managers opposing the proposed framework due to concerns over unequal voting power and potential for mismanagement. Proponents, including investment bankers and tech investors, argue that DCS is necessary to attract high-growth companies and prevent them from listing in foreign exchanges. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has proposed rigorous safeguards to protect investors, but critics question whether these measures are sufficient. The debate highlights the challenges of balancing the interests of various stakeholders in the Singaporean financial sector.

site_title: China's deleveraging pain puts investors on alert for signs of contagion
summary: China's deleveraging efforts, aimed at controlling its credit boom, have already caused $500 billion in financial damage domestically. Investors are monitoring the yuan's exchange rate and cross-border capital flows for signs of contagion. Despite recent stability in growth, regulators are taking steps to squeeze leverage from bond and property markets. China's economic indicators, due May 15, will be closely watched for signs of softening, but investors remain cautious, noting that the country's growth slowdown is expected to trend between 6.5-7%.

site_title: Trade creditor files court application to wind up Emas Offshore's subsidiary
summary: A trade creditor, Hai Jiang 1401, has filed a court application to wind up Lewek Champion Shipping, a subsidiary of Emas Offshore Limited, due to unpaid debts. The application, filed on May 5, 2017, seeks Soo Hon Weng as the liquidator. The matter is set for a hearing on May 26, 2017.

site_title: Big oil betting on electric vehicles
summary: Big oil companies, including Royal Dutch Shell and Total SA, are betting on electric vehicles (EVs) to make up 15-30% of global new vehicle sales by 2030, according to forecasts. Oil demand for transportation fuel is expected to "flatten out" after 2030, with companies investing in hydrogen-as-a-transport-fuel efforts. Despite barriers such as high battery costs, longer-range EVs and declining lithium-ion battery prices are expected to drive adoption, with carmakers like Volkswagen and Toyota committing to electrify their line-ups.

site_title: e-commerce GeTS simpler with new trade platform
summary: Global eTrade Services (GeTS) has launched a new trade platform, aiming to simplify e-commerce trade by streamlining processes and ensuring regulatory compliance. The platform, a subsidiary of CrimsonLogic, allows businesses to handle multiple clearing systems in one go, reducing paperwork and increasing efficiency. GeTS claims to save businesses up to 15% of the value of traded goods, with 60% time savings and 1.5 times productivity gains. The platform is seen as a key solution to support Singapore's growth as a global trading and logistics hub.

site_title: Defeated Jakarta governor jailed two years for blasphemy
summary: Indonesia's Jakarta governor Basuki Purnama, also known as Ahok, was jailed for two years for blasphemy after a five-judge panel ruled he had made a blasphemous quip. The ruling has sparked concerns about the country's record for religious tolerance and may distract President Joko Widodo from his reform agenda. The decision could also set Widodo to work on his re-election campaign, potentially halting deregulation efforts. The blasphemy law has been used to bludgeon opposition, with over 120 people convicted since 2004, and has become a cudgel for radical Islamists.

site_title: JD.com posts first quarterly profit since listing
summary: JD.com, China's second-largest e-commerce company, has reported its first quarterly profit since listing in 2014, with a net profit of 355.7m yuan. The company attributed the profit to its expanded product line-up, which lured more active users. However, JD.com cautioned that the cost of expanding at home and abroad could crimp future income growth due to fierce competition in China and Southeast Asia.

site_title: Indonesia strives to build a financial market to match its size
summary: Indonesia is working to develop its financial market to match its size, with a focus on increasing trading volume, hedging activity, and derivatives. The central bank has allowed a wider scope of derivatives and given the market a boost by ordering companies to hedge currency exposure. The goal is to create a market where investors can get competitive prices and execute trades in a timely fashion, attracting much-needed funding for President Joko Widodo's infrastructure-investment plans. The central bank aims to grow Indonesia's foreign-exchange market to 3% of the country's trade value by 2020.

site_title: Challenger's Q1 profit down 15% on weak retail and corporate sales
summary: Challenger Technologies reported a 15% decrease in net profit for its Q1 2017, reaching S$3.2 million, due to weak retail and corporate sales. Revenue fell 15% to S$76.5 million, with IT products and services seeing a 16% decline. The online marketplace, Hachi.tech, contributed 10% of total retail and online sales revenue. Despite this, the company plans to enhance its online marketplace and has seen encouraging sales figures from its new flagship store.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: YuuZoo seeks legal advice on former exec
summary: YuuZoo Corp is seeking legal advice after former group financial controller Thai Youn Fatt's exit due to "generally unacceptable behaviour in the workplace" and allegations of harassment. Thai Youn Fatt had previously disputed the company's characterization of his actions and claimed he was terminated after submitting a resignation letter. The company has acknowledged Thai Youn Fatt's termination and confirmed he signed a termination letter, stating he did not have issues with the company's accounts. The incident is ongoing, with YuuZoo currently in its annual audit.

site_title: Grammys to move to New York for 60th edition in 2018
summary: The Grammys will move to New York for its 60th edition in 2018, marking a change from its 14-year stay in Los Angeles. The ceremony will take place at Madison Square Garden on January 28, following a campaign by New York Mayor Bill de Blasio to bring in an estimated $200 million to the city's economy. The Recording Academy announced the change on social media, with a video by director Spike Lee, and expects the Grammys could return to Los Angeles in subsequent years.

site_title: SEC probes rental home values in private-equity bond deals
summary: US securities regulators are investigating whether bonds backed by single-family rental homes sold by Wall Street's biggest residential landlords used overvalued property assessments. The Securities and Exchange Commission is looking into broker price opinions (BPOs) used to value real estate in securitizations, potentially leading to an industrywide probe. Several firms, including Radian Group's Green River Capital, received requests for information from the SEC about BPOs. The probe aims to determine whether BPOs were wrongly inflated, contributing to inflated property values in securitizations.

site_title: Macron and a multi-needs Europe
summary: Emmanuel Macron's victory in the French presidential election signals Europe's potential regaining of self-confidence after a series of crises. Macron's centre-right victory fended off electoral assaults from both sides, but the EU's circumstances remain precarious. Despite recognition of the need for bold action, there is no agreement on what action to take. Macron's victory comes as the European Union faces challenges from global politics, including the presidency of Donald Trump, and a growing global AI talent war. Macron's leadership may bring stability to the EU, but the road ahead remains uncertain.

site_title: More national oil companies may set up in Singapore
summary: Singapore may become a hub for more national oil companies (NOCs) as they seek to commercialize and expand globally. The prolonged oil slump has forced NOCs to re-evaluate their business models, with some considering initial public offerings (IPOs) to raise capital. EY consultants predict that Singapore will be a prime location for NOCs to set up shop, with Saudi Aramco's planned IPO and other countries like Indonesia, Brazil, and Nigeria also exploring IPOs. This shift could lead to increased economic activity and investment in the country.

site_title: Powerful sway of China's govt felt at US schools
summary: US universities are facing pressure from China's government, as student groups on Western campuses work in tandem with Beijing to promote a pro-Chinese agenda and suppress anti-Chinese speech. The Chinese Students and Scholars Association (CSSA) at the University of California, San Diego, threatened "tough measures" against the university after it invited the Dalai Lama, a Nobel Peace Prize winner, to speak. The CSSA's ties to the Chinese government are not secret, and similar groups have been accused of spying, censoring comments, and intimidating critics of China.

site_title: Jewellery scandal shows path to power as Danes redefine socialism
summary: Denmark's Social Democrats, under new leader Mette Frederiksen, are redefining socialism by embracing a more pragmatic approach, including cooperation with the anti-immigration Danish People's Party. This shift has boosted their support and may lead to a potential alliance between the two parties. The move could signal a broader transformation in European progressive politics, where traditional left-wing parties are hemorrhaging working-class votes. The cooperation may disrupt Danish political alliances and strain the country's relationship with the European Union, but it could also provide a lesson for other progressive leaders struggling to address voters' frustration with globalization.

site_title: Independence seen as election challenge for Scottish nationalists
summary: Scottish nationalists face a challenge in the upcoming election as the debate over independence from Britain overshadows key local issues. Despite polls showing most Scots do not support another referendum, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon has championed it, citing Scotland's vote to stay in the EU. The SNP's focus on independence has been criticized by some nationalists, who worry it may harm their chances. Meanwhile, farmers in Scotland express concerns about losing EU subsidies and financial support post-Brexit, with some calling for the government to step in to mitigate the effects.

site_title: India's IndiGo to fly to smaller cities in strategy shift
summary: IndiGo, India's largest airline, plans to start flying smaller planes to second-tier towns and cities later this year, shifting its strategy from a single type of jet. The airline has ordered 50 ATR 72-600 turboprop aircraft worth over $1.3 billion. This move is part of the government's scheme to make air travel cheaper for people in smaller towns. IndiGo's net profit fell 25% in the quarter, but the company expects a 22% increase in available seat kilometres in the April-June quarter. The airline plans to set up a separate unit to manage the ATR fleet to reduce complexity.

site_title: Home Capital says unnamed party plans to buy C$1.5b in mortgages
summary: Home Capital Group Inc. announced a third-party intention to purchase up to C$1.5 billion in mortgages, including uninsured and insured mortgages. The company aims to restore confidence after a deposit run and regulator charges of misleading investors. Deposits have fallen to C$146 million, down from C$192 million. Home Capital will continue to offer mortgages at reduced volumes and tighten lending criteria. The company has also introduced new board directors and chairwoman as part of its management overhaul.

site_title: Canadian Pacific changing tracks to win customers
summary: Canadian Pacific Railway Ltd is shifting its strategy from cost-cutting to focus on top-line growth, following the departure of former CEO Hunter Harrison. New CEO Keith Creel has appointed a chief marketing officer and hired executives to expand sales staff and steer business onto rail cars. The company's efforts are seen as a response to the Canadian government's planned legislation that could impose penalties for poor railway service. With improved grain-handling performance and increased customer engagement, CP's new direction is yielding results, but it still faces competition from rival Canadian National Railway Co.

site_title: Cosco Shipping International CFO resigns due to 'personal reason'
summary: Cosco Shipping International's CFO, Ma Hong Han, has resigned due to personal reasons, effective immediately. Liang Jianfeng, a 40-year-old general manager at China Shipping Regional Holdings, has been appointed acting CFO after a selection process. Ma, 46, was appointed CFO in 2012 and will not be replaced.

site_title: CEO of Sabana Reit manager quits; Changi South deal scrapped
summary: Sabana Reit's manager has accepted the resignation of CEO Kevin Xayaraj, effective by end December 2017. The resignation comes after unitholders' revolt over the proposed acquisition of 47 Changi South Avenue, which has been terminated. Xayaraj has been with the manager since 2010.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

KEVIN Xayaraj, the embattled chief executive officer and executive director of Sabana Shari'ah Compliant Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust's manager which had drawn unitholders' revolt has tendered his resignation.

site_title: Rotary Engineering net profit in Q1 surges to S$3.7m as gross profit margin improves
summary: Rotary Engineering's net profit surged to S$3.7 million in Q1 2017, driven by improved gross profit margin of 25%, up from 18% in the same period last year. Revenue fell 8% to S$59.6 million due to completion of major projects.

site_title: Obamacare premiums rise as insurers fret over law's shaky future
summary: Health insurers are requesting significant premium increases for Obamacare plans in Maryland, Virginia, and Connecticut due to uncertainty about the law's future and rising medical costs. Insurers are blaming the Trump administration's reluctance to enforce the individual mandate, which they say will lead to healthier individuals dropping coverage. The increases, averaging over 20% in the affected states, follow years of rising premiums under the Affordable Care Act. Insurers are seeking support from the government to stabilize the market, with some predicting the individual market will continue to shrink.

site_title: Noble likely to record net loss of US$130m for Q1
summary: NOBLE Group is likely to record a net loss of approximately US$130 million for the first quarter of 2017 due to challenging market conditions, particularly in the coal sector. The company has taken measures to realign its portfolio and reduce costs, which have made significant progress. The group will announce its Q1 results on May 11.

site_title: India's record jet fuel exports set to fall as air travel soars
summary: India's record jet fuel exports of 741,000 tonnes in March may decline this year due to an expanding middle class and cheaper air travel. The government's Regional Connectivity Scheme, launched by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, aims to boost air travel between smaller cities, reducing jet fuel consumption and exports. This could help raise jet fuel margins, which have plummeted to a nine-month low, according to refinery executives and analysts.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: Indonesia detains a Trafigura employee in a US$17 billion graft case. OCBC's incoming CEO is Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran. Helen Wong will retire as OCBC CEO, succeeded by Tan Teck Long. Singapore stocks experience a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. Grab's earnings growth is expected to slow in H2, prompting a downgrade to 'hold' by CGSI. Sats CEO Kerry Mok's pay increases 30.5% to S$3.1 million.

site_title: Kimly posts net profit of S$4.5m in Q2 as revenue rises
summary: Kimly Limited, a newly-listed traditional coffee shop operator, reported a net profit of S$4.5 million in its Q2, down 25.3% from S$6.1 million in the same period last year. Revenue rose 12.4% to S$47.4 million, driven by sales of cooked food, beverages, and tobacco products, as well as increased rental income and utility services. The company's half-year revenue reached S$94.3 million, a 14.4% increase from the previous year. A tax-exempt interim cash dividend of 0.28 Singapore cent per share was declared.

site_title: Sabana unveils steps to soothe unitholders
summary: Sabana Reit's Q1 DPU fell 24% due to a one-time base fee cut and dropped acquisition. The Reit manager's CEO quit following a shareholder meeting where unitholders failed to unseat the manager. Unitholders, who had campaigned for improvements, were instead in a celebratory mood. The Reit's poor performance is the latest in a string of setbacks for the trust.

images.alt_text: In a slew of announcements issued by Sabana Reit's manager on Tuesday described by the investors as "the right thing to do", it was announced that the embattled chief executive officer and executive director of the Reit manager, Kevin Xayaraj, has decided to quit "to pave a way for change" after serving the manager for seven years.
Anita Gabriel

site_title: CWT posts 28% rise in Q1 net profit
summary: CWT Limited reported a 28% year-over-year increase in Q1 net profit to S$30.2 million, driven by strong performances from its commodity marketing and logistics businesses. Revenue surged 39% to S$2.6 billion, mainly due to higher trading volume and commodity prices. The company's logistics business also saw improved profit, while engineering services and financial services operations were affected by weaker demand and fewer opportunities, respectively.

site_title: Chinese property buyers lead foreign investors in Australia
summary: Australia approved foreign investments worth nearly A$248 billion in 2016, a 29% increase from the previous year, driven by Chinese buyers. China was the largest source of approved investment, accounting for A$47.3 billion, or 20% of total foreign investment. The majority of Chinese investments, US$31.9 billion, went into real estate. The rise in foreign investment approvals for new homes is seen as a policy effort to encourage residential real estate investment and increase housing supply.

site_title: Update: Muslim militants may be behind car bomb attack in southern Thailand
summary: A car bomb attack in southern Thailand's city of Pattani wounded 60 people, with 21 hospitalized, authorities said. Muslim militants, suspected of carrying out the attack, were believed to have fled the scene. This is the first car bomb in Pattani since August, amid a decades-old separatist insurgency that has killed over 6,500 people since 2004. The government condemned the attack, calling it a grave violation of human rights, and rejected a conditional offer for peace talks from one of the main insurgent groups.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 1.590 points to close at 1,766.560 on Tuesday, with 3.23 billion lots valued at RM2.74 billion traded. Losers outnumbered gainers 455 to 427.

site_title: Double bombing outside supermarket hits Thailand's troubled south, injures 40
summary: A double bombing outside a supermarket in Thailand's southern town of Pattani injured at least 40 people, with one in serious condition. The attack is the latest suspected rebel assault in the insurgency-plagued region, which has seen near-daily shootings and bomb attacks claim over 6,800 lives since 2004. The incident undermines stalled peace efforts in the Muslim-majority border region, where ethnic Malay insurgents battle the Buddhist-majority state for more autonomy.

site_title: Moon declares election win, pledges to unify divided South Korea
summary: Moon Jae-in, the Democratic Party of Korea candidate, won South Korea's presidential election with 39.5% of the vote, defeating conservative Hong Joon-pyo with 26.5%. Moon pledged to unify the nation and has vowed to take a softer approach with North Korea, while cracking down on family-run conglomerates. He faces the task of healing a nation still reeling from corruption scandals, and his policies may put him at odds with US President Donald Trump. Moon will begin his single five-year term immediately, without a transition period, and aims to create jobs and bolster the economy.

site_title: Aspial Corporation's net profit leaps 111% to S$6.3m in Q1 on better revenue
summary: Aspial Corporation reported a 111.1% increase in net profit to S$6.3 million in Q1, driven by better revenue from its real estate and financial service businesses. Revenue rose 12% to S$140.9 million, with progress recognition of sales from CityGate and Waterfront@Faber contributing to the increase. Earnings per share jumped to 0.33 Singapore cent, while net asset value per share rose to 16.77 Singapore cents.

site_title: Parkson Retail's net loss deepens to S$9.1m in Q3, revenue edges up 0.2% to S$98.6m
summary: Parkson Retail Asia reported a net loss of S$9.1 million in Q3, a 24.4% increase from the same period last year. Revenue edged up 0.2% to S$98.6 million. The company attributed the decline in sales to an increasingly crowded retail scene, especially in Vietnam, and uncertainties in Indonesia. Same-store sales declined across its operations in Malaysia, Vietnam, Indonesia, and Myanmar, but were less severe in Malaysia due to the effects of GST implementation.

site_title: India's top court rules tycoon Mallya guilty of contempt
summary: India's top court has ruled tycoon Vijay Mallya guilty of contempt for sending millions of dollars to his children despite court orders. Mallya, who fled India in 2016 with over $1.3 billion in unpaid debts, was found to have transferred $40 million to his three children after receiving a payout from British spirits firm Diageo. The court has ordered Mallya to appear before it on July 10, following a contempt charge for deliberately concealing his assets and withholding information from the court.

site_title: Australia goes for stimulus in A$75b rail, road plan
summary: Australia's government unveiled a $75 billion infrastructure plan in its annual budget, aiming to stimulate economic growth through road, rail, and runway construction from Western Sydney to Western Australia. The plan promises to create thousands of jobs and bridge a forecast deficit of $29.4 billion for fiscal 2018. The government seeks to calm rating agencies by returning to surplus by 2021, with a heroic assumption of accelerating wage growth rates to above 3% from under 2%.

site_title: Zalando reports solid growth helped by male shoppers
summary: Zalando, Europe's largest online fashion retailer, reported a 23% increase in first-quarter sales to 980 million euros, driven by a marketing campaign targeting male customers. The company, which delivers 1,500 brands in 15 countries, saw flat adjusted earnings before interest and taxation. Zalando reiterated its 2017 sales growth forecast of 20-25% and EBIT margin of 5-6%. The company's active customer base exceeded 20 million, surpassing British rival ASOS' 14 million.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end sharply higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose sharply on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index climbing 1.27% to a 2-year high. The rally follows another record close on Wall Street. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose, with the Hang Seng Index's best close since mid-2015. The gains are attributed to the strong performance of US stocks, which extended their rally despite uncertainty over US trade policies.

site_title: Airbus looks to upgrades to counter Boeing's new mid-market jet
summary: Airbus is upgrading its A320neo family in response to Boeing's plans to compete in the narrow market between large and small jets. The company is considering enhanced versions called A321neo-plus and A321neo-plus-plus, which would include a new carbon-composite wing to reduce costs. Airbus aims to defend its main cash cow against Boeing's potential new mid-market jet, which could seat 220-260 passengers and offer the space of a twin-aisle jet in a single-aisle cabin. Airbus dismisses the threat, citing its own A321neo's capabilities, but is working on upgrades to thwart Boeing's move.

site_title: China sales drive Best World's Q1 net profit up 63% to S$9.7m
summary: Best World International, a beauty products distributor, reported a 63% increase in net profit to S$9.7 million for Q1 2017, driven by sales of its DR's Secret skincare range in China, which more than doubled to S$20.7 million. Revenue rose 27% to S$44.7 million. Management expects China to be the key driver, while Taiwan growth will be subdued.

site_title: Qantas chief Alan Joyce gets pie in face
summary: Qantas CEO Alan Joyce was attacked at a business breakfast in Perth, Australia, with a cream pie forcibly shoved in his face. The 65-year-old Irishman, who was discussing new flights to London, left the stage to clean up before police detained an elderly man over the incident. Joyce refused to comment on the motive, saying it was up to the police. He joked about needing a good dry cleaner in Perth to clean his glasses and glasses frames. No charges have yet been laid.

site_title: Hyundai-Kia lead drop in China auto sales
summary: Hyundai-Kia auto sales in China declined in April, falling 1.7% to 1.69 million units, as consumers shunned Korean brands due to geopolitical tensions. This is the second consecutive month of decline for the brands. Great Wall Motor, a Chinese automaker, posted its first monthly drop in over two years, while Japanese brands such as Nissan and Geely Automobile Holdings Ltd gained market share. The slowdown is attributed to a consumer backlash against Korean-branded cars following China's decision to host the US missile-defense system Thaad, which could last up to a year.

site_title: British fugitive drug 'kingpin' nabbed in Thailand
summary: British fugitive Jonathan Moorby, 47, was arrested in Thailand on Monday after years on the run. He was convicted of a US$1.3 million narcotics ring and sentenced to nearly 20 years in jail in absentia. Moorby was found in possession of a fake Belgian passport and was a major drugs kingpin in the UK's northeast. He will be prosecuted for illegal entry and using a false passport before being extradited. Thailand's Narcotics Suppression Police vowed to end the country's reputation as a haven for wanted criminals, citing corruption and weak law enforcement as major issues.

site_title: Singapore stocks close mixed despite banks driving STI higher
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 12.99 points to 3,249.97, driven by gains in the three major banks - OCBC, UOB, and DBS - which posted better-than-expected first quarter earnings. OCBC's shares rose S$0.16 to S$10.46, adding 6 points to the STI, while UOB and DBS added 5.6 points. Turnover was S$1.4 billion, with 222 rises versus 235 falls excluding warrants.

site_title: India finding it hard to end love affair with cash
summary: India's six-month effort to curb the black market by demonetizing 86% of its currency has largely failed, with most businesses continuing to operate primarily in cash. Despite government incentives for digital payments, at least 80% of business in India is estimated to be conducted in cash, often to avoid tax and fuel corruption. The government reported a 10% increase in tax collection, but sales in the gold market and real estate have slowed, with some businesses even benefiting from the initial chaos.

site_title: Early humans co-existed in Africa with human-like species 300,000 years ago
summary: Scientists have discovered evidence that early humans co-existed with a human-like species, Homo naledi, in Africa 300,000 years ago. The species, previously thought extinct, was found to have lived between 236,000 and 335,000 years ago, overlapping with the emergence of modern humans. This discovery raises questions about human evolution and the development of behaviors attributed to humans. The finding also suggests that Homo naledi may have been driven to extinction by early modern humans, with possible gene exchange between the two species.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks rally fizzles on profit-taking after Macron win
summary: Tokyo stocks closed 0.26% lower on Tuesday, snapping a 17-month high after investors took profits following Emmanuel Macron's election victory. The Nikkei 225 index fell to 19,843.00, its lowest level since December 2015, after reaching a 17-month high on Monday. The Topix index also declined 0.26% to 1,581.77.

site_title: US: S&P, Nasdaq hit record highs as volatility drops
summary: US stocks hit record highs on Tuesday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching new peaks, as market volatility dropped to a decade low following Emmanuel Macron's victory in the French presidential election. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.1% to 21,033.78, while the S&P 500 gained 0.11% to 2,401.95 and the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.19% to 6,114.38. The decline in VIX, a measure of market fear, and the rise in 10-year US Treasury yields indicate a shift towards riskier assets.

site_title: China's yuan slips, offshore spot faces pressure on looser outflow curbs
summary: China's yuan fell against the US dollar on Tuesday, reaching a one-month low, after the central bank fixed its midpoint at 6.9037 per dollar. The yuan slipped further in offshore trade, with the offshore yuan trading 0.05% weaker than the onshore spot at 6.9095 per dollar. The People's Bank of China relaxed capital outflow controls in April, which is expected to weigh on offshore spot rates.

site_title: German industrial output falls less than expected in March
summary: German industrial production fell by 0.4% in March, beating expectations of a 0.6% drop. The decline was driven by a 2.5% fall in energy output, while manufacturing production decreased 0.5% and construction output rose 1.5%. This data supports the robust performance of Europe's largest economy in the first quarter, despite trade proving resilient.

site_title: Toshiba warns Western Digital to stop impeding chip sale
summary: Toshiba warned Western Digital to stop interfering with its plans to sell its memory chip business, threatening to take legal action if the US company continues to impede the sale. The Japanese company sent two letters to Western Digital, asserting its right to sell the business despite objections from the US hard-disk maker. Toshiba aims to complete the sale by March 2018 to raise much-needed cash after multibillion-dollar losses in its nuclear business. Western Digital is in talks with state-backed investment funds and has also explored joining a bid by KKR & Co, INCJ and DBJ.

site_title: Mitsubishi Motors sees profit surge on higher Asia sales, cost savings
summary: Mitsubishi Motors forecasts a near 14-fold rise in operating profit to 70 billion yen (S$869.1 million) for the year to March, driven by higher Asia sales and cost savings from its alliance with Nissan Motor Co. The automaker expects global vehicle sales to hit 1.03 million vehicles, a 11% increase from last year, with a 23% jump in sales expected in Asia. Mitsubishi has reorganized its engineering division and improved testing processes to prevent another mileage cheating scandal. The company's net profit is expected to turn a profit of 68.0 billion yen after a net loss of 198.5 billion yen last year.

site_title: Strong quake hits southern Japan, no tsunami risk
summary: A magnitude 6.0 earthquake struck southern Japan on May 9, 2017, at a depth of 10km off the island of Miyako, with no tsunami warning or reported damage. Japan's Meteorological Agency deemed the risk of a tsunami as low, citing small changes in sea levels. The quake, which occurred at the junction of four tectonic plates, is not unusual for Japan, which experiences relatively violent quakes annually due to its location.

site_title: Hair therapy boosts Istanbul's receding tourism
summary: Istanbul is becoming a hub for hair transplantation, with over 300 clinics specializing in the treatment. The city attracts patients from the Middle East and the Gulf, particularly Palestinians, who undergo 1,500 strands of hair implanted one by one. This trend is driving the growth of the industry in the Turkish metropolis.

site_title: Landslide win for Moon in South Korea election: exit poll
summary: Left-leaning former human rights lawyer Moon Jae-In won South Korea's presidential election by a landslide, according to an exit poll, following the ousting and indictment of President Park Geun-Hye for corruption. The scandal galvanized voters' anger and frustrations over jobs and slowing growth. The election took place amidst high tensions with North Korea. Moon's landslide victory seals momentum for change in South Korea, ending a tumultuous period.

images.alt_text: Left-leaning former human rights lawyer Moon Jae In won South Korea's presidential election by a landslide on Tuesday, according to an exit poll, sealing the momentum for change after a tumultuous scandal.

site_title: Gold holds near 7-week low as safe-haven demand fades
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,228.20 per ounce, near a seven-week low, as safe-haven demand decreased after France's presidential election. The move came despite ongoing uncertainty from US President Trump's trade policies, including fresh tariffs on Canada. Gold prices have been volatile in recent weeks, influenced by global economic and geopolitical events.

site_title: Europe: Shares hold at 21-month highs, Micro Focus slides
summary: European shares rebounded early Tuesday, holding at 21-month highs, driven by a recovery in resources stocks and gains among energy firms. The pan-European STOXX 600 index rose 0.3% and France's CAC 40 index gained 0.4%. However, Micro Focus fell 12% after reporting a 10% drop in Hewlett-Packard Enterprise's revenue. Basic resources stocks, including Glencore, also rose, with copper prices increasing.

site_title: Taiwan blames China for WHO invite snub
summary: Taiwan blamed China for its exclusion from the World Health Organization's major meeting for the first time in eight years, citing China's pressure on the WHO. Relations between Taiwan and China have worsened since President Tsai Ing-Wen took power, with China viewing Taiwan as part of its territory awaiting reunification. Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council expressed strong dissatisfaction and protested the snub, while China accused Taiwan's pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party of damaging cross-strait relations.

site_title: Malaysia March industrial output seen slowing to 4.6% y-o-y: poll
summary: Malaysia's industrial output in March is expected to have slowed to 4.6% year-over-year, down slightly from the previous month's 4.7% growth. This follows a rebound in February. Exports rose 24.1% in March, driven by higher shipments of manufactured goods and commodities. The slower industrial growth may put pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Indebted Huishan Dairy under pressure as Bank of China calls in loan
summary: China Huishan Dairy Holdings Co Ltd, a dairy firm facing debt crisis, has been asked by Bank of China to repay a US$50 million loan with interest by May 16. The company's shares are suspended indefinitely, and its board has resigned, with creditors including HSBC, China Citic Bank, and Hang Seng Bank closely monitoring the situation. Failure to repay may prompt other creditors to take similar action, and analysts warn that Huishan may not be able to restructure its debt.

site_title: Western shoppers are fuelling a bounce in made-in-Asia goods
summary: Asia's export engines are experiencing a resurgence, driven by US and European demand, with shipments of goods such as cars and clothing reaching multi-year highs. Chinese manufacturers are benefiting from the demand for smartphone components, while Indian exporters like Orient Craft Ltd. are also seeing growth. However, the trade rebound is fragile, with rising protectionism and concerns over a fragile global economy raising questions about how long the good times will last.

site_title: UK Labour leader Corbyn: I won't quit if I lose election
summary: UK Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn has stated he won't quit as leader if he loses the June 8 national election, despite opinion polls predicting a landslide victory for the ruling Conservatives. Corbyn, who has pledged higher taxes on the wealthy and a crackdown on corporations, will officially launch Labour's election campaign on Tuesday, saying he's serious about winning the election and wants to transform Britain into a more equitable society. Corbyn has faced criticism for his unclear stance on Brexit, but claims it has been settled.

site_title: Credit Suisse said to plan cutting 35 Asia equities jobs by June
summary: Credit Suisse plans to cut up to 35 positions in its Asian equities business by June, mainly in trading, sales, and research roles, following a 16% drop in revenue in the Asia-Pacific region. The cuts are part of the bank's efforts to restructure its markets business, which was deemed unprofitable and suffering from reduced client activity. The move comes as Credit Suisse seeks to shrink its Asian equities unit's balance sheet by 15-18% to free up capital.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.31 points to 1,768.46. The market saw 111 gainers for every 51 losers, with a trading volume of 84.5 million lots worth RM54.2 million.

site_title: Jokowi ally found guilty of blasphemy, gets 2-year jail sentence
summary: An Indonesian court found Jakarta's outgoing Christian governor Basuki Tjahaja Purnama, nicknamed Ahok, guilty of blasphemy, sentencing him to 2 years in jail. Ahok was charged after saying voters were deceived by Koranic verses, dominating the recent election and prompting President Jokowi to call for unity. Ahok, a Jokowi ally, initially held a double-digit lead but lost the run-off to Anies Baswedan, securing 57.96% of the vote.

images.alt_text: An Indonesian court found Jakarta's outgoing Christian governor Basuki Tjahaja Purnama guilty of blasphemy, sentencing him to two years in jail.

site_title: Singapore condo resale prices unchanged in April: SRX Property
summary: Resale prices of non-landed private homes in Singapore remained unchanged in April compared to March, according to SRX Property flash estimates. Prices were 1.8% higher year-over-year, driven by increases across regions. Fewer resale transactions occurred in April, with a 21% decrease compared to March, but resale volume was 48% higher compared to the same period last year.

site_title: Australia shares slide as banks plummet; NZ falls
summary: Australian shares fell 0.3% on Tuesday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index dipping 19 points to 5,851.8, as the "Big Four" banks slid 2.3% amid cost-cutting efforts to maintain earnings momentum. The banks face challenges including a new government inquiry and a possible levy, which could drive up interest rates. New Zealand's benchmark index also fell 0.4% as healthcare and materials sectors were hit.

site_title: Asia: Stocks, US dollar subdued as market seeks next catalyst, oil rises
summary: Asian stock markets were mixed on Tuesday, following a flat close on Wall Street, as investors await the next catalyst after France's presidential election. Oil rose, driven by expectations of OPEC supply cuts being extended. South Korea's stock market is closed for the presidential election, with liberal Moon Jae-In widely expected to win. Most Asian markets, except for Taiwan, fell, while the US dollar and euro remained steady. Oil prices edged higher, lifted by statements from major oil-producing countries.

site_title: Former top HK official and property tycoon appeal landmark graft conviction
summary: Former Hong Kong official Rafael Hui and property tycoon Thomas Kwok have appealed their corruption convictions, arguing that payments made to Hui before he took public office were not sufficient to constitute the offense. Hui was sentenced to 7.5 years imprisonment, while Kwok was jailed for 5 years. The landmark trial exposed the cozy relationship between powerful tycoons and officials in Hong Kong, tarnishing the city's reputation for clean governance. A decision on their appeal is expected soon, with Kwok's release possible if cleared.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OCBC, F&N, Ezion, ASL Marine
summary: OCBC Bank posted a 14% rise in first-quarter 2017 net profit to S$973 million, driven by sustained growth in wealth management income and increased earnings from overseas banking subsidiaries. The non-performing loans ratio remained unchanged at 1.3%.

site_title: Oil gives up earlier gains as rising US output, China concerns weigh
summary: Oil prices fell on Tuesday as concerns over slowing demand and rising US output weighed on the market. Brent crude futures dropped to $49.37 per barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures fell to $46.46 per barrel. Opec-led production cuts, which could be extended into 2018, were unable to prop up prices due to US shale oil production's rapid growth and China's economic slowdown. Analysts attribute the decline to the low oil demand growth and oversupply in the market.

site_title: European banks warn of London exodus if told to convert branches to subsidiaries
summary: European banks, including Deutsche Bank, BNP Paribas, and Societe Generale, are warning that they will have to relocate thousands of staff from London to maintain EU access after Brexit. If British regulators demand that they reinforce London operations with fresh capital, estimated to be around 40 billion euros, the banks may be forced to set up full-blown subsidiaries in Britain. This could accelerate an exodus of bankers from the City of London and impact the EU's financial services.

images.alt_text: European banks are privately warning they will have to shift thousands of people out of Britain if Brexit negotiations push the Bank of England to demand that they reinforce London operations with fresh capital, executives have told Reuters.

site_title: Australia dollar slips to 4-month low after weak retail sales, NZD steady
summary: The Australian dollar fell to a four-month low of US$0.7355 after disappointing retail sales figures reinforced expectations of steady interest rates. The Reserve Bank of Australia kept rates at 1.5% last week, and economists predict no rate changes this year. The New Zealand dollar recovered some ground, but remains in a relatively stable range, with all 26 economists polled by Reuters forecasting a steady rate outlook for New Zealand.

site_title: IMF says Asia facing risks from rise in protectionism
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has warned that Asia's economic outlook is uncertain and faces downside growth risks due to potential tightening in global financial conditions or rise in protectionist trade policies. The IMF raised its 2017 Asia-Pacific growth forecast to 5.5% from 5.4% in April, citing loose monetary and fiscal policies and a high trade openness ratio that makes the region vulnerable to a decline in global trade. The IMF advises maintaining exchange rate flexibility and judicious foreign exchange intervention to mitigate risks.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks build on gains at open
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.32% at the start of trade on Tuesday, extending gains from a record close on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index reached 24,656.95. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index declined 0.45% and 0.39%, respectively. The rally comes despite US trade tensions and uncertainty.

site_title: China said to mull 3 mega power firms in 5.9t yuan remix
summary: China is considering creating three mega power firms through mergers of eight state-run power generators with combined assets of nearly 5.9 trillion yuan. The proposed mergers aim to restructure the state-run power sector and reduce overcapacity. The three planned power giants would have 297 gigawatts of capacity and 2.04 trillion yuan in assets, and would be created through combinations of China Huadian Corp, China National Nuclear Corp, and China Datang Corp. Analysts believe the mergers could lead to more efficiency and profitability in the industry, but also raise concerns about market monopolies.

images.alt_text: China is considering plans to create three power giants through mergers of eight generators with combined assets of almost 5.9 trillion yuan (S$1.2 trillion).

site_title: Oxley prices US$100m four-year notes with 6.375% interest
summary: Oxley Holdings priced its US$100 million four-year notes with a 6.375% interest rate, maturing in 2021. The notes, guaranteed by the group, are intended for general corporate purposes, working capital, and capital expenditure. DBS Bank is the sole arranger and lead manager of the program.

site_title: Cambodia seizes 68 tonnes of fake cosmetic products
summary: Cambodian authorities have confiscated 68 tonnes of fake cosmetic products worth millions of dollars, the country's largest bust of counterfeit make-up. The products, including hair dye, skin-whitening creams, and shampoo, were produced locally but labelled as products from countries like Japan, South Korea, and China. Three people, including two Chinese nationals, were detained in raids on warehouses in March and April. Authorities will investigate health hazards linked to the fake products, which have been linked to side effects and deaths in the past, particularly among women who use skin-whitening lotions.

site_title: Indian man in US for nearly two decades ordered deported
summary: An Indian man, Gurmukh Singh, who fled persecution in his country and has been in the US for nearly two decades, was detained in California after losing his latest appeal over a deportation order. Singh, a married father of two US-born daughters, had applied for asylum but failed to properly pursue his case. He was ordered deported after a 9th Circuit Court of Appeals denied a request to quash the deportation order, and will face potential removal from the US.

site_title: Shanghai: Stocks end flat, regulatory worries linger
summary: Shanghai stocks ended flat on Tuesday, snapping a five-day losing streak, but concerns over tighter financial regulations persisted. The CSI300 index fell 0.2%, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.1%. The tech-heavy ChiNext board briefly hit a 27-month low before closing up 0.8%. The flat market came after earlier losses, with investors waiting for clarity on regulatory changes.

site_title: Singapore shares open 8.9 points higher on Tuesday
summary: Singapore shares opened 8.92 points higher on Tuesday at 3,245.9, with about 77.5 million shares worth S$105.4 million traded. Gainers outpaced losers 90 to 36. This follows a flat closing on Wall Street overnight, offering little directional cues.

site_title: Update: Police slowly reopen Paris train station after security alert
summary: Police have slowly reopened Paris' Gare du Nord train station after evacuating the platforms due to a security alert. The alert, which occurred ahead of Sunday's presidential runoff, prompted a gradual return to normal. Authorities did not disclose the nature of the operation, but security measures have been increased across France following the country's recent string of Islamist militant attacks.

site_title: Philippines' incoming central bank head: Expect policy and reform continuity
summary: Philippines' incoming central bank governor Nestor Espenilla has stated that markets can expect continuity in monetary policy and reforms under his leadership. Espenilla, who takes over in July, will build on the strong foundations laid by outgoing Governor Amando Tetangco, maintaining stable banks, the peso, and inflation while sustaining economic growth. Espenilla has driven recent banking reforms and plans to continue advocating for financial inclusion and competition, with a focus on innovative ways to make the financial system responsive to the broader Philippine community.

site_title: Top Global swings into the black in Q1
summary: Top Global, a Singapore-based property developer, reported a net profit of S$326,000 in the first quarter, reversing a net loss of S$857,000 in the same period last year. Lower cost of sales for development properties offset a 21% drop in revenue to S$25.46 million. The company is undertaking a delisting to avoid extension charges for unsold units in two projects.

site_title: Australia's Crown Resorts quits Macau as Packer sells Melco stake
summary: Australian billionaire James Packer's casino group Crown Resorts has agreed to sell its remaining stake in Macau-focused Melco Resorts and Entertainment Ltd for $1.16 billion, ending its exposure to the Asian gaming hub. The move comes after a Chinese crackdown on graft and capital flight hit casino profits, and as Packer pays down debt to focus on Australian businesses. Crown will sell 165.3 million shares, initially using the proceeds to cut debt, with the sale expected to be completed on May 15.

site_title: Debao Property's Q1 profit triples to 108.3m yuan
summary: Chinese developer Debao Property Development reported a 213% increase in Q1 net profit to 108.3 million yuan, driven by higher revenue and other income. Revenue grew 44% to 24.2 million yuan, while other income jumped 171% to 150.9 million yuan. Debao Property has six development projects under development, expected to be completed in phases up to 2022, providing secure business growth opportunities.

site_title: Japan real wages growth slowest in nearly 2 years, to chill spending
summary: Japan's real wages grew at the slowest pace in nearly 2 years, falling 0.8% in March due to low nominal pay hikes and rising consumer prices. This setback poses a challenge to Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's efforts to revitalize the economy. The data also suggests that the exit from the central bank's quantitative easing programme may be delayed. The decline in real wages and core consumer prices has raised concerns about household spending and inflation.

site_title: Nicki Minaj becomes college benefactor through Twitter
summary: Nicki Minaj has pledged to pay tuition for dozens of fans after a promotional contest on Twitter. The contest, which began as a way to generate buzz for her performance at the Billboard Music Awards, encouraged fans to create videos for one of her new songs. Over 20 million followers participated, and Minaj has chosen to reward the most creative submissions with free college tuition. The gesture aims to support talented students and demonstrate Minaj's commitment to giving back to her community.

images.alt_text: Hip-hop star Nicki Minaj has promised to pay university tuition for dozens of fans after a promotional contest metamorphosed over Twitter.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks trade above 10,000 mark for first time in 2 years
summary: Taiwan's main index broke above the 10,000 mark for the first time in two years, rising 0.6% to 10,001.94. This milestone came after April's exports showed continued recovery, and foreign investors remained net buyers, with the Taiwan dollar maintaining its position as Asia's strongest currency.
