The move is seen as a sign of momentum for the trade-reliant economy.

site_title: Philippines' Duterte picks central bank 'co-pilot' for smooth economic take-off
summary: Philippines President Rodrigo Duterte has appointed Nestor Espenilla, a 36-year veteran of the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas, as the country's new central bank chief. Espenilla, known as "Nesting," brings monetary policy clout and a background in banking supervision to help steady the fast-growing economy. He is seen as a key figure in managing inflation and driving growth amid the country's "Dutertenomics" infrastructure splurge. Espenilla's promotion caps a steady climb through the BSP ranks, starting in the 1980s, and is expected to help maintain economic stability under the new administration.

site_title: Australia's Big Four banks look to cut costs as challenges rise
summary: Australia's Big Four banks, Commonwealth Bank of Australia, Westpac Banking Corp, National Australia Bank Ltd, and Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd, are cutting costs to maintain earnings momentum amid rising challenges from regulatory action and a possible new levy. Despite flat revenue, the banks' cash earnings rose 6.2% to A$15.6 billion in the first half of the financial year. Analysts forecast record cash profits for the banks this year and next, with ANZ expected to be the only exception due to asset sales. The banks aim to maintain earnings momentum despite growing challenges.

images.alt_text: Australia's 'Big Four' banks say they are working hard to cut costs to maintain earnings momentum as they combat rising challenges from regulatory action.

site_title: China's Alipay grabs slice of US market with First Data deal
summary: China's Alipay, owned by Ant Financial, has partnered with First Data to allow its users to shop at 4 million US merchants, marking a significant expansion into the US market. This deal will enable Alipay to accept payments at locations similar to Apple Pay, which can be used at 4.5 million locations. The partnership aims to leverage Alipay's 100,000 international merchants and 90% share of China's mobile-payments market.

images.alt_text: China's mobile-payments king wants a piece of the world's biggest consumer market.

site_title: Tennis: Eugenie Bouchard beats fallen idol Sharapova in Madrid
summary: Eugenie Bouchard defeated Maria Sharapova 7-5, 2-6, 6-4 in the Madrid Open second round on Monday. Bouchard, ranked 60, was motivated to beat her former idol after criticizing Sharapova's doping ban and return to tennis. The match lasted nearly three hours, with Bouchard showing signs of her past form. The win marks a significant upset in the tournament, with Bouchard advancing to the next round.

site_title: JPMorgan tells banks to partner up as US deposit drain looms
summary: JPMorgan warns US midsize banks that a deposit drain may occur in December due to the US Federal Reserve's plan to reverse quantitative easing, which left the industry with $2.5 trillion in excess deposits. The bank estimates 60% of this money, $1.5 trillion, will be withdrawn in the next 4-5 years, potentially leading to loan growth lagging deposit growth by $200-300 billion a year. To mitigate this, JPMorgan advises banks to consider partnerships or mergers to bulk up on retail deposits and offset the loss of funding.

site_title: Marriott profit beats on higher occupancy
summary: Marriott International Inc reported a higher-than-expected quarterly profit driven by higher room rates and occupancy. The company's revenue per available room (revPAR) rose 3.1% in the first quarter, exceeding expectations. Net income rose to $365 million, or 94 cents per share, and total revenue increased 47.4% to $5.56 billion. Marriott expects revPAR to rise 1-3% this year, up from its previous forecast of 0.5-2.5%. Shares were up 4.1% in extended trading.

site_title: Car rental company Hertz falls on bigger-than-expected loss
summary: US car rental company Hertz reported a bigger-than-expected quarterly loss and revenue below estimates, hit by lower pricing in the US. The company's shares fell 15.2% to $12.64. Net loss widened to $223 million, or $2.69 per share, from $52 million, or 61 cents per share, a year earlier. Revenue fell to $1.92 billion from $1.98 billion. Analysts had expected a loss of 91 cents per share and revenue of $1.94 billion.

site_title: Indonesia strives to build financial market to match its might
summary: Indonesia is working to develop its financial market, aiming to match its large economy. Over the past four years, the rupiah's daily trading volume has increased by over 40%, and the central bank has allowed more derivatives trading. The goal is to create a market where investors can get competitive prices and execute trades quickly, which would offer new funding channels for Indonesian companies. Regulators are overhauling customs, such as easing trading restrictions and introducing a clearing house, to achieve this goal by 2020, with the aim of growing the foreign-exchange market to 3% of the country's trade.

site_title: IMF warns Asia to act early on rapidly-ageing population
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has warned Asian economies to take action early to cope with rapidly ageing populations, citing Japan's experience as a reference. Asia's demographic dividends are dwindling due to a growing elderly population, which will create a "demographic tax" on growth. The IMF stated that some countries in Asia are "getting old before becoming rich," emphasizing the need for early adaptation to address this challenge.

site_title: Great Eastern rebrands OAC as it focuses on general insurance
summary: Great Eastern composite insurer has rebranded its Overseas Assurance Corporation Limited (OAC) as Great Eastern General Insurance Limited, positioning it as the group's core general insurance business. The move aims to boost synergies and operational efficiencies. Life insurance policies under OAC will be transferred to The Great Eastern Life Assurance Company Limited on July 1. Policyholders will continue to enjoy the same benefits and coverage, and the insurer has set up a dedicated hotline service to assist with queries. The changes follow the group's reorganisation last year to focus on bancassurance and general insurance.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open flat
summary: Tokyo stocks opened flat on May 9, 2017, after reaching a 17-month high the previous day, driven by a weak yen and relief over Emmanuel Macron's victory in the French presidential election. The Nikkei 225 index gained 0.05 points to 19,895.75, while the Topix index was down 0.73 points at 1,585.13.

site_title: Pandora steps up hunt for buyer, gets US$150m from KKR
summary: Pandora Media Inc, facing widening losses and a tepid outlook for its online music business, is shaking up its board and stepping up efforts to find a possible buyer. The company received a $150 million infusion from private equity firm KKR & Co, with the option to increase to $250 million. Pandora's struggling financials and stock price have prompted investors to urge a possible sale, with some speculating that Sirius XM Holdings Inc may be a potential buyer. The company's cash and short-term investments have dwindled, and it faces looming payments to major record labels.

site_title: Owners of dead giant rabbit on United flight seek damages, probe
summary: United Airlines faces a lawsuit after the death of a 1-metre-long giant rabbit named Simon, who was found dead after a flight from London to Chicago. The owners claim Simon died after being placed in a freezer for 16 hours and that the airline destroyed his remains without permission. The owners demand an outside investigation, compensation for potential economic losses, and damages. United Airlines denies the claims, stating Simon arrived in good condition and that his death was due to natural causes. The airline is reviewing the owners' letter and will respond within seven days.

site_title: Canada flood damage worsens but heavy rains subsiding
summary: Severe flooding in eastern Canada worsened, with thousands affected and schools closed, but authorities expect the situation to improve as heavy rains subside. Several rivers and lakes reached near 50-year peak levels in Quebec, with the Canadian army deploying troops to help stem the flooding. The ground is saturated, and the Canadian army's ranks are expected to swell to 1,650. Although the situation is unlikely to worsen, it will last for a few weeks, according to Quebec's public safety minister. The flooding is attributed to exceptional circumstances, including a month of rain after a severe winter.

site_title: HP Enterprise to invest US$140m in Singapore
summary: Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) is investing US$140 million in Singapore over five years, including US$16 million for local startups. The investment includes opening a new Asia-Pacific and Japan headquarters and launching the InnovateNext program, an incubator that partners with local companies to co-innovate and commercialize new technologies. HPE aims to work with 12 startups and develop 10 vertical offerings with enterprise customers. The company sees Singapore as a hub for innovation, citing its university system, venture capital, and existing companies like HPE.

site_title: Magnus Energy sinks deeper into the red in Q3
summary: Magnus Energy Group reported a net loss of S$1.01 million in Q3, down from a loss of S$544,000 a year ago, due to weaker revenue and higher operating expenses. The group's revenue declined 38.7% to S$3.3 million and gross profit margin fell to 14.5%. The Mid-Con Group's weak performance is a significant drag on the company. Magnus is seeking to raise funds to complete a microalgae oil cultivation project in Malaysia, which is expected to have a positive impact on its net tangible assets and earnings per share once production starts.

site_title: Fed's Mester sees US economy warranting gradual rate increases
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland President Loretta Mester suggests the US economy warrants gradual rate increases, citing robust employment data and a strengthening labor market. However, she notes that wage growth remains tepid, which she believes doesn't justify a rapid pace of rate hikes. Mester also expresses openness to re-evaluating her estimate for the level at which unemployment triggers inflation, currently set at 5%. The Federal Reserve is set to meet in June to decide on its next rate move, with some policymakers leaning towards a rate increase and others citing weak wage growth.

site_title: Hollande makes emotional final foreign stop in Berlin
summary: Outgoing French President Francois Hollande made an emotional final foreign trip to Berlin, where he met with Chancellor Angela Merkel to seal an unlikely friendship. The pair, from different political families, built mutual trust over Hollande's five years in office, particularly on the Ukraine crisis. Merkel praised Hollande's successor, Emmanuel Macron, for his "courageous pro-European campaign" and Hollande expressed his gratitude for Merkel's support during his presidency, which included a notable gesture of empathy after terrorist attacks in 2015.

images.alt_text: Outgoing French President Francois Hollande made an emotional final foreign trip on Monday to Berlin, ahead of the transfer of power to his successor Emmanuel Macron next week.

site_title: Stagnant or falling income puts squeeze on American middle class, economists show
summary: A new research paper suggests that Americans have faced stagnant or falling income for much longer than thought, with workers born in 1942 earning as much or more over their careers than those born in any year since. This trend has put pressure on working- and middle-class households, leading to economic struggles. The study also indicates that workers on the job today are unlikely to catch up with their predecessors in their remaining years of employment.

site_title: Bill Clinton co-writes White House thriller
summary: Bill Clinton is co-writing a thriller novel with bestselling author James Patterson, titled "The President is Missing". The book, set to be published in June 2018, will offer a unique blend of intrigue, suspense, and behind-the-scenes global drama from the highest corridors of power. The novel will draw on Clinton's insider knowledge of the White House and Washington, drawing from his eight-year presidency. Clinton called the collaboration "the highlight" of his career, with Patterson praising Clinton's first-hand experience as uniquely informing the writing of the novel.

images.alt_text: Bill Clinton might have hoped to spend this year back in the White House as America's "first gentleman" should his wife Hillary have won the 2016 election.

site_title: Austrian court rules Facebook must delete 'hate postings'
summary: An Austrian court has ruled that Facebook must delete hate postings across the platform, not just in Austria. The ruling comes as part of a case brought by Austria's Green party over insults to its leader, Eva Glawischnig. The court ordered Facebook to remove postings deemed as hate speech, including verbatim repostings, and said the company can automate this process. The ruling has international ramifications, with European legislators considering ways to force social media companies to rapidly remove hate speech. The Greens hope to strengthen the ruling further.

images.alt_text: Facebook must remove postings deemed as hate speech, an Austrian court has ruled, in a legal victory for campaigners who want to force social media companies to combat online "trolling".

site_title: Ex-Nomura trader says he was trained to lie to customers
summary: A former Nomura Holdings Inc bond trader, Frank DiNucci Jr, testified at the trial of three former colleagues, Ross Shapiro, Michael Gramins, and Tyler Peters, accused of lying to customers about mortgage-backed securities prices. DiNucci claimed he was trained to misrepresent prices and lied to customers, despite knowing it was wrong. He worked at Nomura from 2009 to 2012 and pleaded guilty to conspiracy to commit securities fraud. DiNucci's credibility has been questioned, with prosecutors stating he has lied to investigators, while his lawyers claim he is a "desperate" witness willing to cooperate for leniency.

site_title: Toronto's Pearson airport said to be worth C$5b in possible sale
summary: Canada is considering selling a minority stake in Toronto Pearson International Airport, valued at approximately C$5 billion. The potential sale could free up billions of dollars for new infrastructure projects, reducing costs for travelers and creating opportunities for more shops and services. The Canadian government has declined to release a report outlining the potential benefits and pitfalls of airport privatization, with Prime Minister Justin Trudeau downplaying expectations for the sale.

images.alt_text: Selling slightly less than half of Pearson International Airport is seen as the easiest of several scenarios that Credit Suisse presented to Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's government in a report last year.

site_title: Dutch open 'world's largest offshore' wind farm
summary: Dutch officials have opened the Gemini windpark, a massive offshore wind farm with 150 turbines, 85km off the northern coast of The Netherlands. The wind farm, expected to last 15 years, will meet the energy needs of 1.5 million people, generating 600 megawatts of power and supplying renewable energy to 785,000 Dutch households.

site_title: Three ways to firmly control rising medical claims
summary: Integrated Shield Plan (IP) insurers face a shrinking pool of young, affordable consumers due to low birth rates. To sustain their business, controlling rising medical claims is crucial. Industry sources cite spiraling medical claims from private hospitals and "first dollar private hospital riders" as a major concern. Proposals include making consumers pay IP premiums out of pocket, the government taking over private hospital insurance schemes, or government-run tenders to set benchmarks for cost. These measures are seen as necessary to tackle the issue of rising medical claims.

site_title: White House was told Trump aide Flynn 'could be blackmailed'
summary: The White House was warned in January that President Donald Trump's national security advisor Michael Flynn was vulnerable to Russian blackmail, according to former acting attorney general Sally Yates. Yates testified before the Senate Judiciary Committee that Flynn had not been honest with Vice President Mike Pence about his discussions with the Russian ambassador, leaving him open to leverage from Moscow. This revelation comes as the issue of Moscow's meddling in the US election resurfaces.

site_title: UBS Asia-Pac AUM crosses 300b Swiss francs
summary: UBS Wealth Management's Asia-Pacific assets have surpassed 300 billion Swiss francs for the first time, driven by 17% year-on-year growth in assets under management (AUM) to 311 billion francs. Adjusted profit before tax grew 30% to 263 million francs, with Asia-Pacific contributing 36% to wealth management operating profits. UBS plans to focus on China, Japan, and Taiwan, as well as regional wealth management hubs, to consolidate growth in the region.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: Swissco vessel sale to go ahead without needing shareholders' approval
summary: Swissco Holdings has been granted permission to sell its vessel, Coral Knight, to Australian Maritime Systems Asset Holdings Pty Ltd (AMSA) without shareholder approval. The sale, valued at US$5 million, is part of Swissco's efforts to pay down debts to OCBC Bank. The sale will also discharge a mortgage on another vessel, Swissco Synergy, as security for the OCBC facilities. The waiver was granted after the Singapore Exchange (SGX) did not object to the application, and the sale is expected to help Swissco pay off its debts.

site_title: Coach buys Kate Spade in "bargain" deal
summary: Coach Inc. has acquired Kate Spade & Co for $2.4 billion, with Kate Spade shareholders receiving $18.50 per share. The deal brings a high-profile brand to Coach, aiming to appeal to millennials and remedy the handbag industry's woes. The acquisition is expected to bring cost savings of $50 million and double-digit accretion to earnings by the following year. Coach CEO Victor Luis cited Kate Spade's strong position amongst millennial consumers and global growth potential as key factors in the deal.

site_title: Europe: Stocks dip after Macron relief rally, CAC sinks from highest since 2008
summary: European stocks fell on Monday, with the pan-European Stoxx 600 index down 0.2% and France's CAC down 0.9% after Emmanuel Macron's victory in the French presidential election. Despite the relief rally, strong earnings growth continued to support demand for the region's equities, with average earnings growth for major euro zone blue-chip firms exceeding 20%. Markets are now focused on legislative elections in June, which Macron's En Marche movement must win to ensure his ability to deliver reforms.

site_title: Polls open in South Korea's presidential election
summary: South Korea held its presidential election on May 8, 2017, with left-leaning candidate Moon Jae-In leading with 38% support in the final Gallup Korea survey. Moon, a former human rights lawyer, advocated for dialogue with North Korea and greater independence in relations with the US. The election comes after Park Geun-Hye's ouster and indictment for corruption, with voters prioritizing economic concerns, including slowing growth, unemployment, and air pollution. A Moon victory could lead to a sea change in Seoul's approach towards both Pyongyang and Washington.

site_title: In Discover, Snap sees a bright spot as it tries to fend off Facebook
summary: Snapchat's Discover platform has emerged as a bright spot for the company, generating revenue and attracting premium advertisers. Since its introduction in 2015, Discover has expanded to over 60 publishers, TV networks, and studios, including major news outlets like The Washington Post and The Wall Street Journal. The platform's curated content, unique formatting requirements, and strict ad policies have helped Snap retain a loyal audience and differentiate itself from Facebook. Discover's success may also lead to more deals for original television shows and help Snap reach more advertisers, despite its smaller user base compared to Facebook.

site_title: Euro tumbles from 6-month peak as Macron win in France spurs profit-taking
summary: The euro fell 0.6% to US$1.0932 after Emmanuel Macron's victory in France's presidential election, reversing a 3% gain since his win in the first round. Investors took profit on the currency, which briefly reached a six-month peak of US$1.1023. The safe-haven yen and Swiss franc also fell as risk appetite improved. Despite Macron's win, analysts say threats to the euro remain, citing the need for him to gain support within the French government to further his pro-euro agenda.

site_title: Hackers find celebrities' weak links to bypass digital defences
summary: Hackers successfully bypassed digital defenses by exploiting weak links in the supply chain of major entertainment companies, including Universal Music Group and Netflix. A hacker impersonating an executive at Interscope Records obtained sensitive files from Lady Gaga's team, while another hacker, "TheDarkOverlord," leaked unreleased episodes of Netflix's Orange Is the New Black after breaching a postproduction studio. Hollywood studios refuse to pay hackers' ransom, but the threat of lost revenue and viewers remains. The vulnerabilities in the system are exploited by hackers targeting soft targets, including content collaborators and postproduction studios.

site_title: Verdict expected in blasphemy case against Jakarta's Christian governor
summary: An Indonesian court is expected to decide on Tuesday whether Jakarta's Christian governor, Basuki Tjahaja Purnama, is guilty of blasphemy against Islam. The trial is seen as a test of religious tolerance in Indonesia, the world's largest Muslim-majority nation. Thousands of police will be deployed to prevent clashes between supporters of Governor Purnama and hardline Islamists. Prosecutors have called for a suspended one-year prison sentence, while opponents believe it is too light. Governor Purnama has denied wrongdoing and apologized for comments criticizing his opponents' use of the Koran.

site_title: OCBC posts 14% growth in Q1 net profit
summary: OCBC Bank reported a 14% increase in its first-quarter net profit to S$973 million, driven by sustained growth in wealth management income, higher insurance profits, and increased earnings from its Indonesian banking subsidiaries. The bank's non-interest income rose 30% to S$977 million, led by a 70% increase in wealth management fee income. Despite a 3% decline in net interest income, OCBC's private banking assets under management grew 49% to US$85 billion. The bank maintained a stable loan portfolio quality and a strong capital and liquidity position.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Australia to start new inquiry into 'Big Four' banks' conduct
summary: Australia will launch an inquiry into the conduct of the country's four major banks, known as the "Big Four," amid concerns over market power and abuse. The inquiry, to be led by the Productivity Commission, will examine competition in personal deposits, mortgages, and other areas. The move follows recent scandals and public allegations against the banks, which control 80% of Australia's lending market and have posted record profits. Treasurer Scott Morrison has tasked the inquiry to ensure the financial system is competitive and innovative.

site_title: China eyes up to 85% of strategic port in Myanmar
summary: China is set to negotiate a stake of up to 85% in Myanmar's strategic Kyauk Pyu sea port, as part of its "One Belt, One Road" infrastructure investment plan. A consortium led by Citic Group has proposed taking a 70-85% stake in the $7.3 billion deep sea port, with funding split between Myanmar and the Citic-led consortium. The move has raised concerns about China's growing economic clout in the country, despite opposition from Myanmar's leaders who have traditionally been wary of Chinese domination.

site_title: Noble up in second trading day after 10-to-1 consolidation
summary: NOBLE Group shares rose 5.5% to S$1.34 on their second trading day after a 10-to-1 share consolidation. The move aims to reduce volatility and improve liquidity, with the group citing a drop in net debt-to-capital ratio to 42% from 55% at the end of 2015. Trading of the shares commenced two days before the effective date of the consolidation on May 9.

site_title: Trump to hold crunch meeting on Paris climate deal
summary: US President Donald Trump will hold a meeting with top climate and economic advisors to discuss the country's participation in the Paris climate accord. The meeting comes as Trump appears to be edging toward a decision on whether to honour the 2015 deal to limit global warming. A US withdrawal would undermine global efforts to limit carbon emissions, echoing George W Bush's withdrawal from the 1992 Kyoto Protocol. The Paris accord was hailed as the last chance to stave off worst-case-scenario global warming, but Trump has yet to make a move, with a decision expected within the next couple of weeks.

site_title: Brokerage firms, representatives must adjust to new environment
summary: Singapore's stockbroking industry is evolving with the adoption of technology, including Internet trading and robo-advisers. The Society of Remisiers, Singapore (SRS) believes the traditional transaction-based model must change to include fee-based transactions with advisory services and multiple products. SRS president Jimmy Ho Kwok Hoong argues that human services are still essential alongside technology, and decent margins are necessary to sustain the industry. He warns that businesses offering meagre or zero commissions risk failing, as seen in past examples, and urges authorities to prevent "dumping" that destroys domestic industries.

site_title: As you grow from startup to SME, your IT department needs to grow along too
summary: As companies grow from startups to SMEs, their IT departments must also evolve to support documented procedures and repeatable processes. This transformation often overlooked, IT departments require growth to keep up with the company's increasing needs. A well-managed IT department is crucial for a company's success as it enables the adoption of new technologies and supports business operations.

site_title: Bank distribution leads in Q1 new insurance sales
summary: Singapore's life insurance industry saw a 19% year-on-year growth in Q1, driven by higher uptake of single and annual premium products. Banks contributed 46% of new sales, while tied agents led in total sum assured, accounting for 43%. The industry is expanding its product offerings and distribution channels, with increased engagement through activities across tied agents, banks, and financial advisers. Private health insurance premiums rose 40.4% year-on-year, with 2.91 million lives covered as of March.

site_title: US: Wall Street flat; fear barometer falls to 1993 low
summary: US stocks ended flat on Monday, briefly touching a record high, while the CBOE Volatility index (VIX) dropped to its lowest in over 20 years following Emmanuel Macron's victory in the French presidential election. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite edged up, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average also rising slightly. However, the S&P 500 is trading at 17.8 times expected earnings, suggesting it remains expensive, and a decline in VIX is sounding caution for some investors.

site_title: Higher water, car park charges to have 'small' impact on inflation: Koh Poh Koon
summary: Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry Koh Poh Koon stated that the government's price increases for water and car park charges will contribute to a "temporary increase" in inflation of about 0.2 percentage points this year. He emphasized that the impact will be "small" and attributed the main driver of inflation to rising global oil prices and electricity costs. The government has projected a 0.5-1.5% inflation rate for 2017, and measures will be taken to cushion the impact, including raising water prices in two phases.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Beijing's clampdown on leverage costing China markets billions
summary: China's clampdown on financial leverage has resulted in a $453 billion loss in the value of Chinese stocks and bonds since mid-April, with the Shanghai Composite index dropping for four straight weeks. The People's Bank of China has injected $48 billion into money markets to stabilize the financial system, while lenders have reduced sales of asset-management products by over 30%. The government's goal of curbing leverage while maintaining economic growth is seen as a balancing act, with some investors bracing for further turbulence if the Shanghai Composite falls below 3,000.

site_title: Better margins and JV gain lift OKP's Q1 earnings
summary: OKP Holdings, a Singapore-based infrastructure and civil engineering firm, reported a 172.7% jump in first-quarter net profit to S$5.05 million, driven by higher revenue and margins. Revenue rose 21% to S$29.7 million, with a gain of S$1.6 million from a joint venture. Gross profit margins doubled to 20%, and earnings per share rose to 1.64 Singapore cents. The company attributed its success to a pipeline of projects with good revenue visibility and a focus on core business and innovation.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Fraser & Neave posted a Q2 net profit plunge of 67.1% to S$3.8 million, with revenue dropping 5.8% to S$451.3 million. Ezion Holdings reported a net loss for Q1 due to foreign exchange losses. ASL Marine is expected to report a net loss for Q3. MIT secured new orders worth S$18 million for its semiconductor equipment.

site_title: Global Premium Hotels Q1 earnings down 4.9%
summary: Global Premium Hotels (GPH) reported a 4.9% decline in net profit to S$3.19 million for the first quarter, mainly due to lower hotel-room rates. Revenue fell 3.8% to S$13.99 million. The decline is attributed to increased hotel rooms and shorter stays by tourists, leading to lower average room rates. GPH chairman Koh Wee Meng is set to take the firm private, offering a cash deal of 36.5 Singapore cents per share, as he seeks to cut compliance costs and gain more flexibility in managing the business.

site_title: Divestment gains bolster Q1 bottom line of Perennial Real Estate Holdings
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings reported a four-fold jump in Q1 net profit to S$38.7 million, driven by divestment gains from the sale of a 20.2% stake in TripleOne Somerset. Revenue declined 31.4% to S$20.2 million due to lower project management fees and rental revenue from the same property. The company's operational assets in China contributed S$7.6 million, and asset enhancement works at TripleOne Somerset and AXA Tower are progressing well, with strata sales totaling S$17.7 million and S$41 million respectively.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Netmarble founder urges South Korea to support startups
summary: Netmarble founder Bang Jun-hyuk, now a billionaire, is urging South Korea to support startups as an alternative to the country's reliance on chaebol industrial conglomerates. Bang, a high-school dropout with two business failures, believes the government should revive support for startups to create new businesses and drive growth. He points to the success of startups like Naver and NCSOFT, which were founded in the late 1990s with state investment and infrastructure. Bang's own company, Netmarble, has grown to become a leading mobile gaming firm, and he is seeking a stronger startup ecosystem to drive future growth.

site_title: Moving a beloved home in India more than 2,000 km to save it
summary: A 300-year-old Indian house, named Meda, was moved 2,400km from its flood-prone location in Kerala to a farm in Sadhrana village, south of Delhi. The house, which had been empty for years, was dismantled and reassembled at its new location by architect Pradeep Sachdeva, who wanted to preserve its traditional Kerala architecture. The move was completed in 2011, and the house has been renovated to include modern amenities, including a bathroom and kitchen, while maintaining its historic charm. The relocation was done to save the house from being destroyed due to the unstable land and lack of interest from potential buyers.

site_title: Are all great leaders male? Don't take it at face value
summary: A letter to the editor criticizes an opinion piece suggesting that CEOs with wider faces are more likely to be successful leaders, citing a study that only examined male CEOs. The writer, a woman CEO, questions the study's methodology, suggesting that biases against female leaders may have influenced the results. She proposes possible explanations for why the study's findings may have been skewed, including the impact of makeup, plastic surgery, and diet on facial measurements. The writer calls for future studies to consider these factors and avoid reinforcing unconscious biases.

site_title: Thieves in US eyeing used restaurant grease
summary: Thieves in the US are targeting used restaurant grease, with 44 similar thefts reported in the weeks leading up to a Knoxville, Tennessee, bust. The stolen grease, valued at over $600, is being sold on the black market to meet growing demand for biodiesel, which is used to comply with government mandates for renewable fuels. The value of stolen grease has increased due to rising biodiesel prices, with the benchmark for yellow grease now at 25 cents a pound, up from 8 cents in 2000.

site_title: Indonesia to disband hardline Islamist group Hizb ut-Tahrir
summary: Indonesia's government plans to disband Hizb ut-Tahrir, a hardline Islamist group, citing concerns it undermines the country's secular state ideology and promotes an Islamic caliphate. The decision comes amid rising influence of Islamist groups in the country. The group's activities have been deemed a threat to security, unity, and social justice, leading to the disbandment of its Indonesian branch.

site_title: Vancouver plans more Airbnb limits to ease near-zero home supply
summary: Vancouver is set to impose more restrictions on short-term rental operators like Airbnb, requiring a business license for those renting out properties. The city aims to ease its near-zero home supply, with a goal of taxing short-term rentals like the hospitality industry. The new rules, expected to be unveiled in a few months, will prohibit standalone apartments or houses from being rented out. This move follows similar efforts in Toronto and potential plans for Montreal, as Canada's priciest housing market seeks to address housing supply issues.

site_title: Expect next American president to be boring
summary: The next American president is likely to be a conventional politician with executive experience, not a charismatic leader like Obama or Trump. After two divisive presidencies, Americans are seeking "normalcy" and stability. Unlike Obama, who had limited experience, and Trump, who lacks expertise in politics and public policy, the next president will likely be a former governor with a track record of governing and making deals. This conventional approach is expected to be a departure from the dramatic and chaotic style of the past two presidencies, potentially leading to a more stable and effective administration.

site_title: Legal war over Trump's halted travel ban resumes without fanfare
summary: A federal appeals court in Richmond, Virginia, is set to hear arguments on Monday over President Donald Trump's revised travel ban, which aims to temporarily halt travel from six mostly-Muslim countries. The ban, revised in March, was blocked by federal courts in March, and the court's decision could define the powers of the presidency for years to come. The case centers on whether Trump's campaign promise to enact a "Muslim ban" betrays the stated purpose to keep the country safe, with some arguing that his silence on the issue has heightened suspicions.

site_title: Chinese developers seek funding alternatives
summary: Chinese property developers are seeking funding alternatives due to government measures to rein in soaring house prices. Many are raising funds offshore in the form of US dollar bonds or syndicated loans, while others are exploring onshore alternatives such as asset-backed notes and medium-term notes. Despite policy tightening, average new home prices in China's 70 major cities rose 0.6% in March, and analysts expect liquidity for developers to tighten gradually.

site_title: China's April trade growth slows as demand for commodities, electronics cools
summary: China's April trade growth slowed, with imports rising 11.9% and exports increasing 8.0% year-over-year, missing expectations. The trade surplus widened to $38.05 billion, up from $35.50 billion in March. Commodity imports, including iron ore and copper, declined, while electronics exports rose 2%. Analysts expect export growth to hold steady due to a bright global economic outlook, but warn of further headwinds for imports due to policy tightening.

site_title: Another problem for New Jersey Transit: collecting riders' fares
summary: New Jersey Transit, one of the US's busiest commuter railroads, is facing criticism over its handling of fare collection, with over 240,000 fares not collected in 2016 due to understaffing and crowded trains. The railroad lost an estimated $5.5 million in revenue from uncollected fares. Meanwhile, the agency is facing steep bills for providing alternative transit options for commuters during recent disruptions. Governor Chris Christie has blamed Amtrak for the problems, but transit advocates say New Jersey Transit faces long-term challenges due to underinvestment and mismanagement.

site_title: Macron must now build machinery for effective governance
summary: Emmanuel Macron won France's presidential election with 66% of the vote, defeating Marine Le Pen of the National Front by a significant margin. Macron's centrist platform, EU ties, and inclusive social policies were key factors in his victory. The outcome is seen as a relief for Europe and the world, with Macron's inclusive approach expected to shape his effective governance.

site_title: Macron the Redeemer sweeps to victory
summary: Emmanuel Macron, a 39-year-old former economy minister, has won the French presidential election with a 65% to 35% margin. As the eighth president of France's Fifth Republic, Macron will focus on tackling social divisions, improving labor markets and public services, and strengthening ties with Germany. He will form a government with figures from various parties and aims to resume an activist domestic and European stance. Macron's agenda includes measures to bolster small businesses and education, and he will meet with German Chancellor Angela Merkel to discuss economic and monetary union strategies.

site_title: Venice Biennale curator wrests focus away from politics to art
summary: Christine Macel, the curator of the 57th Venice Biennale, has shifted the focus from politics to art, aiming to create a space where artists and artistic practices are prioritized. The exhibition, titled "Viva Arte Viva," features 120 artists, including 103 first-time participants, and showcases a range of styles and mediums. Macel, who is the fourth woman to lead the Biennale, has emphasized the importance of art in everyday life, stating that it has "saved a lot of lives" despite not being able to "save the world." The Biennale has sparked debate about the role of national pavilions and the art world's response to global issues.

images.alt_text: Christine Macel, chief curator of the Pompidou Center in Paris and curator of this year's Venice Biennale, said: "I'm very interested in politics. But not all art should be about politics. It's only one dimension."

site_title: Patel's war on delinquent Indian borrowers gets boost from Modi
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has amended a law to give the central bank power to spur lenders and borrowers to take write-downs on stressed assets, a move aimed at addressing India's high bad-loan ratio. RBI governor Urjit Patel will now have the authority to set up panels to vet non-performing loans and prompt lenders to take write-downs, with the goal of resolving 60 bad-loan cases in nine months and 100 cases by the end of 2018. The move is seen as a boost to Patel's efforts to tackle the non-performing loan issue, which has been a major challenge for the economy.

site_title: Demand for goods vehicles skyrockets
summary: Singapore's demand for commercial vehicles has skyrocketed, with orders for goods vehicles increasing "easily three to four times" due to lower list prices. Despite this, certificate of entitlement (COE) premiums for commercial vehicles are not expected to rise due to a large supply of COEs available in the next three months. The Category C COE premium for commercial vehicles has plummeted to S$26,501, and dealers are selling vehicles based on bidding due to the stock mismatch, where demand exceeds supply.

site_title: Macron needs parliamentary support to push for reforms
summary: Emmanuel Macron won France's presidential election comfortably, but faces a challenge in garnering parliamentary support to carry out economic and labor reforms. Macron's market-friendly policies, including reducing public spending and easing labor laws, have been met with muted response, with the euro and French stock market already pricing in the win. Macron's En Marche party is unlikely to win a majority in the National Assembly, making a coalition with Socialists and Republicans necessary to govern. Moody's has rated his policies as credit-positive for France, while experts see his election as a positive for Europe and the markets.

site_title: Macau raids casinos, plans tracking of withdrawals at ATMs
summary: Macau plans to add security features to ATMs to monitor withdrawals, requiring users to scan their identity card and use facial recognition technology to verify their identity. The move is part of a broader effort to tighten restrictions on cash flows out of the mainland and follows a visit by China's parliament head, Zhang Dejiang. The new measures coincide with a raid on casinos, cafes, and bars, investigating 790 people suspected of various offences, including human trafficking and illegal business operations. The plan aims to strengthen anti-money laundering laws and counter the use of UnionPay cards to circumvent cash withdrawal limits.

site_title: Fairfax shareholders cool to TPG's A$2.2 billion play for publishing giant
summary: US buyout firm TPG Capital Management has made an A$2.2 billion approach for most of struggling Australian newspaper publisher Fairfax Media Ltd, but the offer was quickly rebuffed by shareholders, citing a low price of 95 Australian cents per share. The proposal, which would involve selling Fairfax's New Zealand titles and its stake in an online television streaming startup, has raised concerns about the structure of the deal. Fairfax shareholders are now urging the company to explore alternative offers, following a regulator's rejection of its plan to sell its New Zealand arm due to competition concerns.

site_title: Macron win shows up governability gap in France
summary: Emmanuel Macron won the French presidential election, defeating far-right candidate Marine Le Pen. Macron's success is seen as a relief, but his ability to govern is uncertain, particularly with his new movement, En Marche!, having no seats in the legislature. The upcoming legislative elections on June 11-18 will be crucial in determining the balance of power, with three possible scenarios: En Marche! securing a working majority, forming the largest group without an absolute majority, or experiencing a hostile majority. Macron's agenda, including labor law reform and public spending cuts, may be stymied, and he faces the risk of "cohabitation" with a prime minister from another party.

site_title: S Korea's dispirited young voters demand societal and economic change
summary: South Korea's dispirited young voters are demanding societal and economic change, frustrated with stagnant growth and declining job prospects. Unemployment among 20-30-year-olds has reached a record 9.8%, with many struggling to find decent jobs despite attending top universities. The country's rigid class structure and intense competition are exacerbating feelings of social unfairness, with some comparing it to the "spoon theory" of being born into a privileged family. The upcoming presidential election promises to bring about tangible change, with front-runner Moon Jae-In promising a "people-centred economy" and job creation. However, some are skeptical that the election will address the underlying issues.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Regional brokerages predict Indonesia's biodiesel demand will fall short of expectations, negatively impacting the sector. Meanwhile, Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust (FLT) reported Q2 FY17 results beating forecasts, with a higher distribution per unit and lower finance costs. Riverstone Holdings upgraded its buy rating for FLT, citing strong cleanroom demand and a new expansion plan. The sector's outlook remains positive, with FLT's portfolio expected to remain resilient with minimal lease expiries.

site_title: Activist groups have a US$1b plan to save DC's subway
summary: Activist groups in Washington D.C. have proposed a $1 billion annual plan to save the city's subway system, Metro, through a mix of sales, gas, and property taxes. The plan, backed by 500,000 people from across the region, includes a one percent sales tax, fare share tax, and gas tax increase to raise $750-840 million annually. The funds would be used for capital investments and operations, aiming to restore service cuts, improve fares, and preserve jobs.

site_title: Yo-Yo Ma reunites with Condoleezza Rice to perform at Kennedy Center event
summary: Cellist Yo-Yo Ma reunited with pianist Condoleezza Rice at the Kennedy Center Arts Summit, performing Schumann's Fantasiestücke, Op 73. The pair also sat on a panel discussing "Shared Values and Social Goals in Cultural Disciplines," emphasizing the importance of risk-taking. Rice shared her insights on Brahms, describing his music as "passionate without being sentimental," while also referencing Ingmar Bergman's film Autumn Sonata about Chopin. Ma praised Rice's abilities, calling her "amazing." The event highlighted the intersection of music, culture, and risk-taking.

site_title: Beijing in major drive to clean up hutongs
summary: Beijing is conducting a major cleanup of its historic hutongs, home to millions of migrant workers and small businesses. Authorities have started brick-in doors on properties along narrow passageways, many dating back to the 13th century, and cracked down on illegal shopfronts to restore original facades. The effort aims to curb population growth and improve the city's image.

site_title: Vicom's Q1 profit down 6.3% at S$6.85m
summary: Vicom, a unit of transport giant ComfortDelGro, reported a 6.3% decline in its first-quarter net profit to S$6.85 million, driven by lower business volumes and staff costs. Revenue fell 4.9% to S$24.13 million. The company expects challenging business conditions, citing a high deregistration rate for vehicle testing and a general slowdown in non-vehicle testing businesses.

site_title: Sinclair said close to buying Tribune for about US$4 billion
summary: Sinclair Broadcast Group Inc is close to acquiring Tribune Media Co for approximately $4 billion, with Sinclair paying about $45 per share. The deal, facilitated by the Federal Communications Commission's easing of TV-station ownership limits, would give Sinclair access to major media markets like New York, Chicago, and Miami. Tribune's flagship cable network, WGN America, and its minority stakes in the Food Network would also be part of the acquisition.

site_title: Warren Buffett slams Wells Fargo leadership
summary: Warren Buffett criticized Wells Fargo leadership for failing to stop employees from signing up customers for bogus accounts, despite learning about the issue. Buffett, Berkshire's chairman, said the company gave employees too much autonomy to engage in "cross-selling" to meet sales goals, leading to the scandal. Berkshire's annual meeting also discussed succession plans, its partnership with 3G Capital, and potential dividend payments or acquisitions. Buffett praised top executives, including Ajit Jain, who could be a potential successor, and expressed confidence in Berkshire's airline investments and its ability to make strategic acquisitions.

site_title: China said to mull over three mega power firms in 5.9t yuan remix
summary: China is considering plans to create three mega power firms through mergers of eight coal-fired and nuclear generators with combined assets of almost 5.9 trillion yuan. The proposal, subject to change, involves combining China Huadian Corp, China Guodian Corp, and China National Nuclear Corp, as well as China Datang Corp, China General Nuclear Power Corp, Shenhua Group Corp, and China Huaneng Group with State Power Investment Corp. The goal is to restructure the state-run power sector and reduce the country's reliance on coal, with the aim of rebalancing the economy towards services and consumer spending.

site_title: Church in Changsha infuriates Mao admirers
summary: A new Protestant church in Changsha, China, has sparked outrage among Mao admirers, who see it as an ideological challenge to their hero. The 80-meter-tall church, built in a public park, has been criticized for its size and symbolism, with many calling it a misappropriation of resources in an officially atheist state. Despite the controversy, residents in the city seem largely indifferent, with some even viewing it as a normal part of life in the region. The church's construction has been met with censorship, with news reports and public debate being stifled. The future of the church remains uncertain, with some speculating that it may be walled off from the rest of the park or have its cross removed.

site_title: Market up on Macron's election victory
summary: The Straits Times Index rose 7.25 points to 3,236.98 on Monday, driven by Emmanuel Macron's election victory in France. Trading was slightly firm, with 250 gains and 211 losses, and 2.6 billion units worth S$1.34 billion traded. DBS dropped S$0.12 to S$20.30, while OCBC announced Helen Wong's retirement and named Tan Teck Long as her successor.

site_title: Euro retreats after hitting six-month high
summary: The euro retreated 0.4% to US$1.0953 after hitting a six-month high following Emmanuel Macron's victory in France's presidential election. Investors took profit on a roughly 3% gain for the currency since Macron's first-round win two weeks ago, shifting focus to economic fundamentals and monetary policy normalization. The euro had risen to US$1.1024 and 124.58 yen, but markets largely priced in Macron's victory, with short positions on the euro at their lowest level since May 2014.

site_title: Singapore to showcase clean energy solutions at Astana Expo
summary: Singapore will showcase its clean energy solutions at the Astana Expo 2017 in Kazakhstan from June 10 to September 10, with a 385 sq. m. pavilion featuring six zones on sustainable energy and innovations. This event aims to deepen bilateral ties and promote best practices in sustainable development and energy solutions. Singapore has strong ties with Kazakhstan, with bilateral trade reaching S$23.5 million in 2016, and is exploring a Free Trade Agreement with the Eurasian Economic Union.

site_title: Australia could energise global market for battery power
summary: Australia's state of South Australia is set to install grid-scale batteries by December, potentially solving energy problems and driving the growth of renewable energy across Australia and Asia. The $150 million project aims to store 100 megawatt hours of surplus electricity generated by wind and solar power, which could help countries like Indonesia, the Philippines, and Chile follow suit. The project is expected to help reduce costs for energy storage, with prices having fallen 90% over the past decade, and could lead to the widespread adoption of battery technology in the region.

site_title: Brokers, fund managers reviewing their research bills before new EU rules kick in
summary: Brokers in the EU have until September to implement new rules requiring a separate price for bundled investment research. Fund managers are reviewing their research bills, weighing costs against the value of the research. Discussions have been slow, with brokers concerned about losing revenues and clients. Meanwhile, OCBC's incoming CEO, Tan Teck Long, was announced after Helen Wong's retirement, and Sats CEO Kerry Mok's pay rose 30.5% to S$3.1 million.

site_title: Sinclair Broadcast nears deal for Tribune Media: sources
summary: Sinclair Broadcast Group Inc is nearing a deal to acquire Tribune Media Co for approximately $4 billion, surpassing the US Federal Communications Commission's 39% cap on companies owning television stations. The deal, valued at around $44 per share, represents a 30% premium over Tribune Media's share price on February 28. Despite potential regulatory challenges, Sinclair's acquisition could hinder Rupert Murdoch's ambitions to expand Twenty-First Century Fox's broadcast assets. Negotiations between the two companies are ongoing, with a potential deal expected soon.

site_title: Katoen Natie to test driverless trucks on Jurong Island
summary: Katoen Natie, a logistics service provider, plans to test self-driving trucks in Singapore starting September 2017. The Belgium firm will initially deploy one autonomous truck on Jurong Island for a few months, with the goal of equipping 11 more trucks with self-driving technology if the trial is successful. This move aims to address difficulties in hiring truck drivers in Singapore.

site_title: Retail wars add to Australia's worries over weak inflation, soft demand
summary: Australia's central bank is expected to hold interest rates despite weak inflation, as a fierce price war among retailers threatens to keep prices under pressure. The country's biggest retailers are suffering from deflation, with global retailers like Amazon and Kaufland entering the market. This could lead to a move downwards in interest rates, which would weaken the Australian dollar. Consumer prices rose in the first quarter, but five sectors saw price falls, including women's clothing. The Reserve Bank of Australia expects underlying inflation to return to its 2-3% target band by mid-2019.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed higher on Monday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index gaining 5.410 points to 1,768.150. A total of 4 billion lots worth RM2.43 billion were traded, with gainers outnumbering losers 546 to 388.

site_title: Proportion of private homes grows to 27%
summary: Singapore's proportion of private homes increased to 27% in 2017, up from 22% in 2006, with 372,000 private condominium units and landed homes. HDB flats, however, decreased from 78% to 73% of the total housing stock. Despite this, 80% of the population still lives in flats. Under 2% of Build-to-Order flat buyers requested deferments, with 45 opting to cancel new flat bookings and continue living in existing flats due to financial or personal reasons. Minister Lawrence Wong advised buyers to exercise prudence and consider market changes when purchasing a home.

site_title: MAS a strong supporter of fintech: Ong Ye Kung
summary: MAS does not have to choose between established financial institutions and new fintech players, according to Ong Ye Kung, a board member of the central bank. He emphasized the need for competition, collaboration, and innovation among both old and new players in the fintech industry, encouraging them to work together to drive growth and stability in the financial sector.

site_title: Prolonged audit behind delayed AGM: YuuZoo
summary: YuuZoo Corp, a Singapore-listed company, is delaying its annual general meeting (AGM) and annual report due to delays in its audit by RT. The company adopted conservative accounting policies in 2016 to address concerns raised by its previous auditor, Moore Stephens, over the valuation of its franchisees' shares and receivables. As a result, Yuuzoo's 2015 net profit was restated from S$32.7 million to S$15.9 million. The company expects to hold its AGM by May 30, 2017.

site_title: How to compete and win in the global war for talent
summary: Companies can compete and win in the global war for talent by investing in their employees, involving them in decision-making, and giving them due credit for their contributions. SMEs can differentiate themselves by offering academic upgrades, career advancement opportunities, and a positive work culture. Recognizing and rewarding employees' good work, providing opportunities for growth and learning, and creating a culture that makes employees feel valued and respected are key to retaining talent. Companies can also provide on-the-job training and skills upgrading to keep employees motivated. To increase female representation in management, companies should focus on qualities that truly matter for the role and avoid biases.

site_title: UBS wealth management assets in Asia-Pac push past 300b Swiss franc mark
summary: UBS Wealth Management has surpassed 300 billion Swiss francs in Asia-Pacific invested assets for the first time, driven by 17% year-on-year growth. Adjusted profit before tax rose 30% to 263 million francs in the first quarter. The company attributes this growth to clients consolidating their accounts due to the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts, a trend expected to continue this year.

site_title: GNC struggles for breathing room on debt as retail loses muscle
summary: GNC Holdings Inc is struggling to pay off its $1.35 billion debt, which it incurred through a $500 million share repurchase plan. The company is seeking to extend its loan by three years, offering an extra 200 basis points to investors. Despite a 9% increase in same-store transactions, the total value of sales has fallen due to price cuts. Investors are skeptical about GNC's ability to meet its debt obligations, citing concerns over its free-cash flow and the impact of the wider retail sector.

site_title: Petronas presses on with cost-cutting measures
summary: Malaysia's national oil company Petronas continues its cost-cutting measures, aiming to save RM5 billion by 2017, amid a "lower for longer" oil price environment. The company has already trimmed thousands of jobs in its upstream operations and is considering a cost rationalization drive in its downstream division. Petronas also seeks to develop in-country oil and gas core competencies, balancing cost-cutting with local development. The company aims to achieve sustainable cost savings from its Coral 2.0 initiative, which includes reducing unit production costs to US$5.

site_title: F&N Q2 earnings drop despite exceptional gain
summary: F&N Q2 earnings dropped 67.1% to S$3.8 million, with revenue declining 5.8% to S$451.3 million. Despite an exceptional gain, earnings per share shrank to 0.6 Singapore cents from 0.8 cents in the previous year. The company declared an unchanged interim dividend of 1.5 Singapore cents.

site_title: Negotiating with someone like Trump
summary: Negotiating with someone like Donald Trump requires a unique approach in today's VUCA world. The author suggests four key rules: be clear about your goals, know the other party's position, read people's emotions and body language, and stay focused yet open-minded. When dealing with an unreasonable and uncompromising counterpart, remain calm and politely assertive, and don't fall for emotional manipulation. Additionally, don't resort to lies, instead ask for the information you lack and question their reply to confuse them. By outwitting your opponents while maintaining self-respect, you can successfully navigate complex negotiations.

site_title: Euro Zone may get another giant bank as Finns build Nordea case
summary: Nordea Bank AB is considering moving its headquarters from Sweden to Finland or Denmark, citing regulatory risks. If it moves to Finland, it would be part of the euro zone's banking union, reducing regulatory uncertainty. The move could also give the bank a clearer picture of what rules it needs to comply with. However, Finland's smaller economy and limited access to euro-area support if Nordea failed are concerns, raising the risk that taxpayers could be on the hook. The decision is expected to be made by CEO Casper von Koskull before summer.

site_title: Coach will acquire handbag maker Kate Spade for US$2.4b
summary: Coach Inc. agreed to acquire handbag maker Kate Spade & Co for US$2.4 billion, following months of talks. The deal aims to help the luxury brand cope with an industry plagued by deep discounting and sluggish demand. Coach plans to finance the deal with senior notes, bank term loans, and cash, with expected cost savings of US$50 million in three years. The acquisition is expected to add to earnings from fiscal 2018 and lead to "double-digit accretion" by the following year.

site_title: Canada's housing starts fall in April after surge in March
summary: Canada's housing starts fell to 214,098 units in April, slightly above analysts' expectations, after a surge in March. The seasonally adjusted rate is near a five-year high, with most strength coming from apartment construction in British Columbia and Quebec. The Canadian housing market has shown signs of slowing due to government moves to cool lending and impose foreign buyer taxes in Toronto and Vancouver.

site_title: Global sugar market firmly on path to surplus in 2017/18
summary: The global sugar market is expected to return to surplus in 2017/18, with a forecasted surplus of 1.82 million tonnes, following two consecutive deficit years. Global sugar production is forecast to rise 6.9% to 186.35 million tonnes, driven by increased output in India, the European Union, and other countries. Consumption growth is expected at 1.2%, above the prior season's 0.8%, but below the long-term trend rate.

site_title: Philippines picks central bank insider Espenilla as next governor
summary: The Philippines has named Nestor Espenilla, a 58-year-old deputy central bank governor, as its next governor, succeeding Amando Tetangco who steps down in July. Espenilla, known for his expertise in banking supervision, was chosen by President Rodrigo Duterte, who praised Tetangco's legacy of maintaining strong economic growth and low inflation. The appointment is seen as a smooth transition, ensuring continuity of policy and thought process, and comes ahead of a policy meeting on Thursday.

site_title: Meet Hikari Azuma, the cute digital assistant you can date
summary: Hikari Azuma, a Japanese digital assistant, is being developed by Vinclu Inc to be more than just a utility tool, but also a whimsical and dateable companion. Unlike Siri, which deflects dating questions, Hikari aims to engage in conversations and build a connection with users. This approach is seen as a refreshing change in the digital assistant landscape, where utility is often prioritized over personality.

site_title: Amazon sweeps US market for voice-controlled speakers -study
summary: Amazon dominates the US market for voice-controlled speakers with its Echo and Echo Dot devices, holding a 70.6% share. Alexa, the voice-controlled aide, will see its active US users more than double to 35.6 million this year. Google Home has a 23.8% share, while other tech companies' offerings trail behind. Device sales and revenue from Alexa are expected to reach $10 billion by 2020, with Google's share expected to grow as its technology is shown to match or be superior to competitors.

site_title: Tycoons from China planting money management flags on Wall Street
summary: Chinese tycoons are expanding their presence on Wall Street, with billionaire Cai Kui's Westfield Investment and HNA Group's Chen Feng opening US money management firms. The influx of capital from China, fleeing concerns over bank debt, a real estate bubble, and the yuan's decline, has led to over 324 firms with financial ties to the mainland and Hong Kong registering with US regulators. These firms plan to invest in US assets, such as real estate and venture capital stakes, and are taking advantage of the US's more favorable regulatory environment.

site_title: Singapore tech startups shift gear to tap region's exploding e-commerce
summary: Singapore tech startups, including Garena, Lunch Actually, and Anchanto, are aggressively expanding their presence in South-east Asia's growing e-commerce market. Garena, rebranded as "Sea", raised $550 million in funding to expand its e-commerce arm Shopee, with a focus on Indonesia. The country's e-commerce market is expected to grow significantly, with Shopee's annualized gross merchandise value of over $3 billion. Meanwhile, Lunch Actually acquired an Indonesian dating platform and Anchanto secured investments from major players to expand its e-commerce logistics solutions across the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: US: S&P, Nasdaq pare gains after hitting record highs
summary: US stocks, including the S&P 500 and Nasdaq, reached record highs before paring gains following Emmanuel Macron's victory in the French presidential election. Comcast and Amazon.com were top drivers, while the euro surged to a six-month high against the dollar. Investors sought fresh catalysts after Macron's win, despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Ezion issues profit warning
summary: Ezion Holdings, an offshore services group, has issued a profit warning for its first quarter ended March 31. The company attributed the net loss to a "material foreign exchange loss" due to the depreciation of the US dollar, affecting its unsecured financial liabilities denominated in Singapore dollars. The result is scheduled for release on May 12.

site_title: Firms must put in place sufficient cybersecurity measures
summary: The threat of data breaches is imminent, with the global data creation predicted to soar to 180 zettabytes by 2025. Firms must implement sufficient cybersecurity measures to protect personal data and comply with legal regulations such as the General Data Protection Regulation and Singapore's data protection law. Failure to do so can result in severe financial penalties and irreversible damage to a company's reputation. Organisations must ensure they understand data protection regulations, conduct regular audits, and work closely with professionals to ensure compliance and mitigate the risk of data breaches.

site_title: Manufacturing Integration Technology bags S$18m semiconductor equipment orders
summary: Manufacturing Integration Technology (MIT) secured S$18 million in orders for its semiconductor equipment, bringing its total outstanding order book to S$23 million. The orders are expected to be delivered in the next two quarters and will contribute positively to the group's financial results. The equipment will primarily be used to produce devices for mobile communication and memory sectors.

site_title: Delfi's net profit dives 33.4% to US$5.6m in Q1 on lower sales, higher tax
summary: Delfi Limited's net profit plunged 33.4% to US$5.6 million in Q1 due to lower sales in Indonesia and higher effective tax rate. Revenue fell 10.1% to US$93.1 million, attributed to an ongoing product portfolio rationalisation and review of trading terms.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: Indonesia detains a Trafigura employee in a US$17 billion graft case. Helen Wong to retire as OCBC CEO, with Tan Teck Long named successor. Singapore stocks notch a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. CEO salaries in Singapore increase, with Sats CEO Kerry Mok's pay rising 30.5% to S$3.1 million.

site_title: German companies plan European online personal data firm
summary: German companies Allianz, Axel Springer, Daimler, Deutsche Bank, and technology firm Core, along with location services provider Here Technologies, plan to establish a European online personal data firm to securely store customer data. The platform aims to provide a competitive response to the US's Facebook Connect, allowing customers to log in to multiple sites with a single identity. The initiative aims to guarantee high data security and protection standards, with the goal of boosting the European digital economy's growth.

site_title: OKP posts 172.7% rise in net profit to S$5.1m in Q1
summary: OKP Holdings reported a 172.7% increase in net profit to S$5.1 million in Q1 2017, driven by strong revenue growth from its maintenance segment. Revenue rose 21% to S$29.7 million, while basic earnings per share increased to 1.64 cents. Net tangible assets per share also rose to 38.18 cents.

site_title: Comics legend Stan Lee announces new Latin superhero
summary: Comic book legend Stan Lee has announced a new Latin superhero, set to be released by the end of the year. The character is being created to address social problems in Mexico, where Lee was speaking at a convention in Querétaro. Lee, 94, said he wants the hero to be "as good as I can, as different as I can." Fans from across Latin America and even Belgium attended the convention, praising Lee's enthusiasm and the event. The new hero is a surprise, but Lee is personally working on the character.

site_title: Mount Alvernia Hospital appoints Lam Kian Ming as new CEO
summary: Mount Alvernia Hospital appointed Lam Kian Ming as its new CEO, effective May 2, 2017. Lam brings over 20 years of experience in the healthcare industry, previously serving as CEO of Thomson Medical Group and group director of the Applied Sciences Group & Blood Services Group at the Health Sciences Authority of Singapore. He vowed to build upon the hospital's legacy, delivering development plans and continuing its mission to provide outstanding care to patients and their families.

site_title: Facebook warns of fake news danger ahead of British election
summary: Facebook launches a British newspaper advertising campaign to warn users of fake news ahead of the June 8 parliamentary election. The campaign urges users to be sceptical of headlines that look unbelievable and to check other sources before sharing news that may not be credible. Facebook has also developed new ways to identify and remove fake accounts and will delete bogus profiles and stop promoting implausible posts. The effort builds on the company's efforts to identify fake news and crack down on automated profile pages.

site_title: Warm weather and low energy prices hurt Centrica's margins
summary: Britain's largest energy supplier Centrica reported that warm weather and weaker commodity prices in the first quarter hurt its energy supply business margins. The company stopped short of revising annual financial targets despite warning against a government cap on energy tariffs. Centrica CEO Iain Conn stated that price regulation is not beneficial for consumers and transmission and government policy costs are to blame for rising bills. The company maintained its financial targets, including debt reduction, and cut its dividend for the second year due to weak energy prices.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end at 17-month high after Macron win
summary: Tokyo stocks reached a 17-month high after Emmanuel Macron's victory in the French presidential election. The Nikkei 225 index surged 2.31% to 19,895.70, while the Topix index climbed 2.29% to 1,585.86. The strong US jobs report and Macron's pro-European stance contributed to the market's optimism.

site_title: Singapore stocks close slightly higher after Macron wins French election
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 7.25 points to 3,236.98 on Monday after Emmanuel Macron's win in the French presidential election, which was seen as positive for the market. Trading was firm, with 250 rises and 211 falls, and turnover reached S$1.34 billion. The 7.25-point gain brought the index to a 5-day rally ahead of upcoming GDP data.

site_title: Yuuzoo says audit delay due to 'intense interaction' with auditor
summary: Yuuzoo Corp is delaying its annual general meeting (AGM) and annual report publication due to audit delays caused by "intense interaction" with auditor RT. The company had missed its April 30 deadline and now expects to hold its AGM by May 30, 2017. Yuuzoo adopted more conservative accounting policies in 2016 to address concerns raised by its previous auditor, Moore Stephens, which led to its withdrawal as auditor. The company's fiscal year ends on December 31, 2016.

site_title: Buffett says United made 'terrible mistake' with passenger clash
summary: Warren Buffett criticized United Airlines for a passenger clash, calling it a "terrible mistake." The incident involved a passenger being dragged off a plane after refusing to give up his seat. Buffett said the airline's initial response was problematic, but CEO Oscar Munoz later apologized. The incident led to global condemnation, industry changes, and changes in United's policies, including increased payouts to passengers and a reduction in overbooking. Buffett, who oversees 360,000 employees, said he's never met Munoz but acknowledged the airline's mistake.

site_title: Swissco waived from obtaining shareholders' approval for vessel disposal
summary: Swissco Holdings has been granted a waiver by the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to dispose of its vessel Coral Knight without shareholder approval. The waiver was sought due to the vessel being mortgaged to OCBC Bank, which could claim ownership if shareholders do not approve the sale. The sale price of $5 million is lower than the agreed $7.2 million with AMSA. The decision allows Swissco to proceed with the sale, estimated to be a forced sale under the circumstances.

site_title: Taiwan's April imports jump, signalling more gains for exports
summary: Taiwan's exports grew 9.4% in April, the seventh consecutive month, but imports jumped 23.5%, raising the prospect of stronger shipments ahead. This narrowed Taiwan's trade surplus to $2.78 billion, its smallest since November 2015. Exports to China and the US rose 10.3% and 7.6% respectively, while technology-related goods showed strong double-digit gains. The data suggests optimism in exports, but the US Treasury remains on Taiwan's watch list as a possible currency manipulator.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's real estate investment deals surged 67.4% in Q1, reaching S$4.99 billion, with banks dominating new life insurance sales. Noble Group shares rose 6.3% after trading on a consolidated basis. France elected Emmanuel Macron as president, signaling pro-business reforms and deeper European integration. Hewlett Packard Enterprise launched a 3-year incubator program in Singapore. Mount Alvernia Hospital appointed Lam Kian Ming as new CEO.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start week with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.41% on Monday, following solid US jobs data and Emmanuel Macron's victory in the French election. The Hang Seng Index closed at 24,577.91, while the Shanghai Composite Index slipped 0.79%. The Shenzhen Composite Index fell 1.99%. The gains came despite US President Trump's new threats to extend a stocks rally.

site_title: UK house prices post first quarterly decline since 2012
summary: UK house prices recorded their first quarterly decline in over four years, falling 0.2% in the three months to April, according to Halifax. This marks the first time prices have declined since 2012. The decline is part of a broader slowdown in the property market, with annual growth at its weakest in almost four years and mortgage approvals at a six-month low. Experts attribute the decline to weak wage growth and increasing inflation, which has curbed demand and pushed home ownership out of reach for many.

site_title: ASL Marine expected to report Q3 net loss
summary: ASL Marine is expected to report a net loss for the third quarter of FY2017 due to lower operational profit, increased administrative expenses, unrealised foreign exchange losses, and higher share of losses from its joint venture and associated companies. The company attributed the loss to challenging market conditions in the marine industry. ASL Marine will disclose further details on May 15. The group advised shareholders and investors to exercise caution when dealing in its shares.

site_title: Vicom's Q1 profit down 6.3% to S$6.85m
summary: Vicom, a unit of ComfortDelGro, reported a 6.3% decline in Q1 net profit to S$6.85 million, due to lower business volumes and a 4.9% drop in revenue to S$24.13 million. Earnings per share fell to 7.73 cents, while net asset value per share rose to 176.75 cents. No dividend was declared for the current period.

site_title: Australia to hold new inquiry into 'Big Four' banks
summary: Australia will hold an inquiry into competition in the country's financial system, focusing on the "Big Four" banks, amid public concerns over market power and scandals. The inquiry comes after a series of high-profile cases, including scams, misleading financial advice, and interest-rate rigging. The move is part of government efforts to alleviate public concerns and alleviate power of the big banks. The inquiry is expected to examine the banks' market power and potential abuse of it.

site_title: Thailand delays launch of 100b bhat infrastructure fund to Q3
summary: Thailand has delayed the launch of a 100-billion baht infrastructure fund to September, the latest in a series of delays. The "Thailand Future Fund" was initially announced in 2015 to finance investment projects and lift economic growth. The delay is due to concerns over the high cost of launching the fund, with the transport ministry and a relevant agency citing high costs. The finance ministry is ready to launch the fund but is waiting for the transport ministry's approval. The fund aims to provide a 7-8% return to investors.

site_title: Macron won 66.1%, Le Pen 33.9% in French vote: final results
summary: Emmanuel Macron won France's presidential election with 66.1% of the vote, defeating far-right leader Marine Le Pen's 33.9%. Macron received 20,753,797 votes, while Le Pen received 10,644,118. The abstention rate was 25.44%, the highest since 1969, with 22.23% in the first round. This year's second round saw a quadrupling of blank ballots, likely due to the unprecedented situation of no mainstream parties making it to the run-off.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip from highs as Macron win seen priced in
summary: European shares slipped from their highs after the election of Emmanuel Macron as French president, with the pan-European STOXX 600 index down 0.2% and France's CAC falling 0.4%. Macron's business-friendly vision of European integration was seen as largely anticipated, leading to modest profit-taking.
