Banks, which are sensitive to political factors, also fell, with the euro zone bank index down 0.7% and French banks BNP Paribas and Societe General more than 1% lower.

site_title: Hot stock: Noble shares up 6.3% after trading on consolidated basis
summary: Noble Group shares rose 6.3% on Monday after trading on a consolidated basis, with the share price reaching S$1.35 at 12:26pm. The 10-to-one share consolidation began on Friday, following a recent annual general meeting where management reiterated progress, including a drop in debt-to-capital ratio and a reduction in staff. Founder Richard Elman urged patience, stating the company may need several years to recover from its ailing commodities business.

site_title: Perennial Real Estate Q1 net profit more than quadruples to S$39m
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings reported a quarterly net profit of S$38.7 million, a four-fold increase from the previous quarter, driven by divestment gains and re-measurement gains. Revenue fell 31.4% to S$20.2 million due to lower project management fees and rental revenue from TripleOne Somerset. Earnings per share rose to 2.32 Singapore cents, with no dividend recommended. The counter ended at 85.5 Singapore cents, down 0.5 cents or 0.6%.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Etihad accelerates reset as interim CEO takes reins immediately
summary: Etihad Aviation Group has named interim CEO Ray Gammell, taking over from James Hogan, effective immediately. Hogan's departure is set for July 1. The move is seen as a strategic reset, with the company still searching for a permanent CEO. Etihad's state owners are reevaluating the group's direction, including its Equity Alliance strategy, amid mounting losses at its minority stakes in Alitalia and Air Berlin. A new permanent CEO is expected to be named in a few weeks.

site_title: Asia: Markets rise on US jobs data, euro dips after Macron rally
summary: Asian markets rose on Monday following a strong US jobs report, with Tokyo's Nikkei index surging 2.3% to a 17-month high. The euro initially jumped above US$1.10 after Emmanuel Macron's victory in France's presidential election, but fell back to US$1.0990 due to expectations of the outcome. European markets also rose, with the CAC 40 index in Paris up 0.2%, while London and Frankfurt gained 0.3% and 0.3% respectively. The US market also ended with healthy gains, with the Nasdaq posting a record close.

site_title: Chinese bank payment networks surge as Western lenders cut ties: study
summary: Chinese banks have significantly expanded their overseas payment and trade networks, with correspondent banking relationships surging over 3,300% since 2009, reaching 2,246 in 2016. This growth contrasts with a 25% decline in global relationships, largely due to Western banks cutting ties with smaller clients in Asia and Africa. Chinese lenders, such as ICBC and Bank of China, are fast-globalizing to support Chinese companies as they push overseas, potentially at the expense of EU and US global banks.

site_title: Hewlett Packard Enterprise unveils 3-year incubator programme in Singapore
summary: Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) has unveiled a 3-year incubator programme in Singapore called InnovateNext, aiming to partner with local companies to develop and commercialize new technologies. The programme, valued at US$140 million, will support 12 startups and co-innovate 10 vertical solutions with enterprise customers. HPE will lead the programme in collaboration with Singapore's Economic Development Board to focus on hybrid IT, IoT, and data analytics solutions across industries. The goal is to create viable global market solutions.

site_title: Singapore real estate investment deals jump 67.4% in Q1 from a year ago: JLL
summary: Singapore saw a 67.4% surge in real estate investment deals in Q1, reaching S$4.99 billion, a 40.9% drop from the previous quarter. The private sector accounted for 90% of sales, with the office sector driving growth, accounting for 47.5% of total sales. Notable deals included the sale of PwC's building to Manulife for S$760.6 million and the sale of GSH Plaza to Fullshare Holdings for S$725.21 million, both entity sales.

site_title: Made in North Korea: As tougher sanctions loom, more local goods in stores
summary: North Korea is increasing the availability of domestically produced goods in its shops and supermarkets, shifting away from mostly Chinese imports. The move is part of the country's dual strategy to develop both its military and economy. The effort aims to avoid currency outflows and promote the national ideology of self-reliance. Locally made products include toothpaste, charcoal masks, motorcycles, and solar panels, which are seen as attempts to reduce reliance on China and bolster the economy under leader Kim Jong Un.

site_title: The Laos Connection: Mr X and the cartels hooking Southeast Asia on pills
summary: A Laotian man, known as "Mr X", was arrested in Thailand for allegedly using his connections in Laos to distribute methamphetamine pills across Southeast Asia. Mr Xaysana Keophimpha, 42, was arrested at Bangkok's airport on January 19 while en route to Laos. Authorities believe he used his country's lax law enforcement to smuggle narcotics into Thailand and Malaysia. His downfall highlights the role of Laos in the region's illicit drug trade, with the country's corrupt officials and lax laws making it a hub for cartels.

site_title: Petronas remains committed to 20,000 bpd of crude oil cut: CEO
summary: Malaysia's state-owned oil company Petronas has reaffirmed its commitment to a 20,000 barrels per day (bpd) crude oil production cut, according to CEO Wan Zulkilflee. This pledge was made in December 2016, and Petronas will stick to it, regardless of any potential extension of the global production cut pact. The pact, which includes Opec and non-Opec oil-producing countries, aims to cut output and ease the supply glut.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks end at record high on French election relief, won firmer
summary: South Korean stocks ended at a record high on Monday, closing 2.30% higher at 2,292.76 points, driven by Emmanuel Macron's French presidential election win and a firmer won. Market heavyweight Samsung Electronics gained 3.3% to a record, while LG Electronics jumped 7.39%. Foreign investors bought 544.9 billion won worth of KOSPI shares. The won was quoted at 1,131.4 to the dollar, up 0.11% from Thursday's close.

site_title: Gas leak kills 18 miners in central China
summary: A gas leak at a coal mine in central China's Hunan province killed at least 18 miners, with another 37 rescued and taken to hospital. Investigators are testing the gas and have detained an unspecified number of people in connection with the accident.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rise with broader Asia; semiconductors, electronics up
summary: Taiwan's main Taiex index rose 0.1% to 9,910.32 points, mirroring broader Asia's gains. Investors were relieved after Emmanuel Macron's win in the French presidential election. The semiconductor subindex gained 0.9% and the electronic subindex rose 0.4%, while the transportation and construction indices fell. The Taiwan dollar strengthened against the US dollar. Catcher Tech, an electronic component manufacturer, surged 2.7%.

site_title: Nepal fines solo Everest climber without permit US$22,000
summary: A South African solo climber, Ryan Sean Davy, has been fined $22,000 and ordered off Mount Everest after attempting to climb the mountain without a permit. Davy, 43, was caught at base camp and had his passport confiscated. He had set up an isolated camp to avoid officials and claimed he couldn't afford a flight to retrieve his passport, planning to walk and catch a bus instead. Davy faces a possible 5-year ban from Nepal or a 10-year ban on climbing in the country.

site_title: Malone's Liberty Global pares growth target
summary: Liberty Global, a European cable carrier, has lowered its growth target for 2017 to 5% operating cash flow growth, down from 6-7% previously, due to weaker-than-expected start in the UK. The company attributed the decline to customer losses and mobile revenue decline, despite a £3 billion expansion project, Project Lightning, being delayed. CEO Mike Fries described the target as "conservative" and not material to the company's overall targets.

site_title: Record haul of pangolin scales seized in Malaysia
summary: Malaysian customs officers seized a record 712kg of pangolin scales, worth RM9,184,800, in two separate seizures at Kuala Lumpur airport. The scales, believed to have originated from Ghana and DR Congo, were bound for Vietnam and China, where they are touted to have medicinal properties despite being made of keratin. The seizure is the country's largest and comes as international trade in Asian pangolins is banned under the UN's Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species. The incident highlights the ongoing threat of poachers and smugglers in Southeast Asia.

site_title: Chinese developers look for alternative fundraising strategies
summary: Chinese property developers are seeking alternative fundraising strategies due to government measures to curb soaring house prices. Over 45 cities have introduced home-purchase restrictions, and authorities have tightened requirements for bond issues and barred access to the banking system for developers buying land. Some developers are turning to onshore alternatives like asset-backed notes and medium-term notes, while others are exploring offshore funding options like US dollar bonds and syndicated loans. Despite policy tightening, many developers still aim to capture additional market share through high sales growth in 2017.

site_title: Australia's Fairfax Media reviews takeover offer
summary: Australia's Fairfax Media has received an unsolicited partial buyout offer from US private equity giant TPG Capital for its newspapers and Domain Group, valued at A$2.5 billion. The proposal would see TPG take over mastheads including the Sydney Morning Herald and The Age, along with the company's events and digital ventures businesses. Fairfax is reviewing the plan, citing complexity and potential negative impact on shareholder value, and would need government approval for the deal. Existing shareholders would retain Fairfax's New Zealand arm.

site_title: Banks continue to dominate in new sales of life insurance in Singapore
summary: Banks dominated life insurance sales in Singapore, accounting for 46% of new business premiums, followed by tied agents (33%) and financial advisers (17%) in the first quarter of 2017. The industry saw a 19% year-on-year growth in weighted new business premiums, driven by increased uptake in single and annual premium products. Life insurers introduced new products and channels, with 20,000 residents buying additional health insurance coverage in Q1. The industry aims to bridge Singapore's protection gap, leveraging digitalization to innovate and respond to demographic shifts.

site_title: Indonesia central bank intervening in FX market to prevent rupiah appreciation
summary: Indonesia's central bank has intervened in the foreign exchange market to curb the rupiah's appreciation, citing concerns it could harm exports. The rupiah has gained 1.1% this year, but movement has been limited in recent months. Deputy Governor Sugeng stated that the central bank aims to convince investors that Indonesia is taking steps to improve its fundamentals. The intervention aims to prevent the rupiah from becoming too strong and to support the country's exports.

site_title: China's yuan firms as banks sell US dollars, trade data taken in stride
summary: China's yuan strengthened against the US dollar as banks sold US dollars amid a firmer euro following France's presidential election. The yuan opened at 6.8990 per US dollar, 16 pips stronger than the previous close, but 0.09% weaker than the midpoint. Weaker-than-expected Chinese trade data and a rise in China's 10-year treasury yields were met with a shrug from traders. The results of the French election, which met market expectations, prevented a spike in volatility.

images.alt_text: China's yuan firmed against the US dollar on Monday as banks sold the US currency amid a firmer euro after centrist Emmanuel Macron's victory over the far-right Marine Le Pen in France's presidential election.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OUE, LHN, Addvalue, A-Sonic
summary: OUE reported an 85% surge in net profit to S$15.4 million for the first quarter, driven by stronger revenue and lower finance expenses. LHN is seeking a dual primary listing on the Hong Kong mainboard, aiming to widen its investor base and enhance its profile. Addvalue Technologies secured an initial US$1 million trial order for its maritime communications system, while A-Sonic Aerospace warned of expected net loss for the first three months.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks jump 1.35% after Macron wins French presidency
summary: Tokyo stocks surged 1.35% on Monday after Emmanuel Macron won the French presidential election, boosting investor confidence. The Nikkei 225 index rose 263.31 points to 19,709.01. Macron's pro-European stance is seen as favorable to the EU and its economic policies, which may positively impact global markets.

site_title: Gold firm on euro strength after Macron wins French elections
summary: Gold prices edged up 0.3% to $1,230.88 per ounce after dipping to a seven-week low, following Emmanuel Macron's victory in the French presidential election, which strengthened the euro. The euro reached a six-month high against the US dollar. Uncertainties surrounding Macron's ability to deliver policies and potential interest rate hikes in the US also supported gold prices.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Monday, rising 1.64 points to 1,764.38. The market saw 158 gains and 61 losses, with a trading volume of 111.4 million lots worth RM31.58 million.

site_title: Macau introduces new ATM rules to deter Chinese money laundering
summary: Macau introduces new ATM rules requiring facial recognition and identification card checks for Chinese UnionPay cardholders to curb money laundering. The measure applies to ATM cash withdrawals in casinos and will eventually be applied to all ATMs. The Macau government aims to implement anti-money laundering and anti-terrorism rules, stating it "spares no effort" to do so.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars sag on commodities; China data fails to support
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars plummeted to near multi-month lows on Monday, driven by falling commodity prices and euro strength. Despite upbeat Chinese trade data, investors focused on a surprise drop in Australian building approvals and lower iron ore prices. The Aussie slipped 1% last week, its third consecutive week of decline, while the Kiwi edged down amid waning commodity prices and a hawkish Fed hint.

images.alt_text: The Australian and New Zealand dollars languished near multi-month lows on Monday as falling commodity prices and euro strength eclipsed upbeat Chinese trade data.

site_title: Comcast and Charter to announce wireless partnership on Monday
summary: Comcast Corp and Charter Communications Inc are set to announce a wireless partnership on Monday. The deal will impose a one-year moratorium on material transactions, preventing either company from partnering with Verizon Communications Inc. The partnership aims to identify efficiencies in billing practices and product offerings. The agreement will also restrict either company from entering into material transactions without the other's consent. Details of the partnership have not been disclosed yet.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rally as Macron elected president of France, won steady
summary: South Korean shares surged 0.5% to a record high of 2,253.04 points, driven by Emmanuel Macron's election as French president, seen as business-friendly and pro-European integration. This boosted investor confidence, attracting offshore investors and fueling demand for riskier assets. Analysts attributed the positive market flow to Macron's victory over far-right nationalist Marine Le Pen.

site_title: Australia business activity at decade-high in April: NAB
summary: Australia's business activity reached a decade-high in April, according to a National Australia Bank survey, with a +14 index of business conditions and +13 measure of business confidence. The results are driven by strong sales and employment levels, which suggest a potential pickup in economic growth. The better-than-expected outcome may be partly due to the minimal impact of Cyclone Debbie on Queensland's business conditions.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally on US jobs data, euro dips after Macron rally
summary: Asian markets rallied on Monday following a strong US jobs report, with Tokyo's Nikkei index rising 1.8% and Hong Kong adding 0.1%. The euro briefly jumped above $1.10 after Emmanuel Macron's victory in France's presidential election, but soon fell back to $1.0970. Analysts attributed the muted reaction to the euro's widespread expectation. The US jobs data strengthened prospects for two more interest rate hikes this year, boosting investor sentiment and risk-on trades.

site_title: 'Stranger Things,' 'Beauty and the Beast' win big at MTV awards
summary: Stranger Things and Beauty and the Beast dominated the MTV Movie and TV Awards, with Stranger Things winning best show and best actor in a show for Millie Bobby Brown, and Beauty and the Beast winning best film and best actor in a movie for Emma Watson. Watson praised her character's determination to seek knowledge and opportunities, saying it was grounds for alienation.

site_title: Update: Hong Kong's regulator orders suspension of all Huishan trading
summary: Hong Kong's Securities & Futures Commission has ordered the suspension of all Huishan trading due to a 85% drop in shares on March 24. The regulator can only resume trading if Huishan provides evidence that its information is not misleading, false or incomplete. This decision follows a similar case in 2015 involving Hanergy Thin Film Power Group Ltd.

site_title: Singapore shares open marginally higher on Monday
summary: Singapore shares opened slightly higher on Monday, extending the rally from Wall Street on Friday, after US jobs data showed a rebound in payrolls and energy shares recovered. The Straits Times Index rose 8.46 points to 3,238.19.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.25% in the first few minutes of trade on Monday, following a Wall Street rally, while investors celebrated Emmanuel Macron's victory in France's presidential election. The Hang Seng Index reached 24,537.54. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.42% and 0.28% respectively.

site_title: Taiwan wants 'friendly' China ties amid tilt to South-east Asia
summary: Taiwan's premier, Lin Chuan, has expressed openness to strengthening economic ties with China, despite concerns over China's opposition. Lin believes that maintaining friendly relations with China is essential for Taiwan's economy, and that diversifying trade links with other nations can help counter domestic objections. The move comes as President Tsai Ing-wen's administration seeks to balance economic cooperation with China and strengthen ties with the US and South-east Asia. Lin's comments aim to address concerns over Taiwan's high reliance on China for exports.

site_title: Taiwan's Premier Lin says immigration is needed to boost economy
summary: Taiwan's Premier Lin Chuan emphasized the need for immigration to boost the economy, citing the country's slow growth and talent exodus to other cities. Lin believes immigration can provide immediate solutions and counter the brain drain affecting Taiwan. His administration has implemented various reforms, including those on trade, taxes, and infrastructure, but Lin sees immigration as a crucial aspect to achieve economic growth and innovation.

site_title: Pan Asian unit sells 35% interest in Tianjin subsidiary for 4.38m yuan
summary: Pan Asian Holdings' subsidiary Duvalco Valves & Fittings Pte Ltd sold a 35% interest in DWK Valves (Tianjin) Co for 4.38 million yuan. The sale was agreed upon with Zhao Xiu Ying on April 25, allowing the group to reallocate resources to focus on core businesses and enhance shareholder value. The divestment decision was made due to the company no longer needing a majority stake in DWKTJ, which manufactures valves and fittings.

site_title: SIA Engineering appoints former Sembcorp CEO as deputy chairman
summary: SIA Engineering has appointed Tang Kin Fei, former CEO of Sembcorp Industries, as deputy chairman, effective immediately. The non-executive role is intended to augment the company's core competencies and set directions. Tang, 66, previously served as group president and CEO at Sembcorp Industries and is currently an adviser. His appointment is seen as a strategic move to bring in extensive management and business experience to the company.

images.alt_text: SIA Engineering Company has appointed the former chief executive officer of Sembcorp industries, Tang Kin Fei, as deputy chairman.

site_title: Euro gives up gains as Macron seals French election victory
summary: Emmanuel Macron's victory in France's presidential election has brought relief to investors, who had feared another populist upheaval after Britain's Brexit vote and Donald Trump's election. Macron's 65.5% margin of victory over Marine Le Pen has led to a decline in the euro, which had been on a rising trend ahead of the election. The euro slipped 0.2% to $1.0975 against the US dollar, while the US dollar index fell 0.1% to 98.737. The victory is seen as a boost to the European economy, and investors are now positioning for a Macron-led government to implement policies that will support growth.

site_title: Third of French voters spoiled ballots or abstained
summary: A third of French voters, or 24.52%, abstained or spoiled their ballots in Sunday's presidential election, a record rate since 1969. Emmanuel Macron claimed a 65% victory, but participation in the second round was lower than the first, with abstention rates higher than in the 2002 election. The high abstention rate may be attributed to the expected presence of far-right leader Marine Le Pen, rather than a shock effect. This marks a significant decline in voter engagement in the election, with one French person out of three choosing not to participate.

site_title: North Korea detains another American citizen, KCNA reports
summary: North Korea has detained another US citizen, Kim Hak Song, on suspicion of "hostile acts" against the state, marking the fourth American to be held by the isolated country. Kim Hak Song, who worked at the Pyongyang University of Science and Technology, was detained on Saturday, while a third US citizen, Kim Sang Dok, was detained in late April for similar offenses. The US State Department confirmed the detention and expressed concern for the safety of its citizens in North Korea amid heightened tensions on the Korean peninsula.

site_title: SoftBank pushing ahead in Indian online shake-up
summary: SoftBank is pushing ahead with its plans to consolidate India's e-commerce sector by acquiring stakes in leading startups. The Japanese conglomerate is seeking to merge Snapdeal with market leader Flipkart, while also investing in digital payments firm Paytm and grocery delivery group Grofers. SoftBank's founder Masayoshi Son aims to create a tech behemoth in India, rivaling Alibaba's success. The deals could be finalized as soon as next week, with SoftBank already in talks to buy a stake in Flipkart's largest investor, Tiger Global.

site_title: Brigitte: from teacher to France's new first lady
summary: Brigitte Trogneux, 64, will become France's first lady as she accompanies her husband, Emmanuel Macron, who won the presidential election. She was a teacher before marrying Macron in 2007, and they have been together since he was 15. Brigitte was born into a prosperous family and has three children from her previous marriage. She has pledged to support her husband and help disadvantaged young people as first lady, and will take on an official role at the presidential palace.

site_title: OUE posts 85% surge in Q1 profit
summary: OUE reported an 85% surge in Q1 net profit to S$15.4 million, driven by stronger revenue from property development and investments divisions. Revenue jumped 60% to S$196.3 million, with OUE Twin Peaks contributing significantly. The group has sold 411 units at OUE Twin Peaks, generating revenue. Property investments division revenue rose 6% and hospitality division revenue increased 0.4%.

site_title: Quick take: Macron's win spells pro-business reforms, deeper European integration
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron won the presidential election with 66.06% of valid votes, defeating far-right nationalist Marine Le Pen. Macron's pro-business vision and commitment to European integration are expected to lead to labor market reforms and a focus on meeting the EU's 3% deficit target. Economists predict a mild risk-on reaction in markets, with potential for renewed investor inflows and attractive valuations in cyclical shares. Macron's victory marks a shift in the narrative around European politics, with a focus on deeper integration and cooperation between EU countries.

images.alt_text: Emmanuel Macron, a 39-year-old former investment banker, was elected president of France on Sunday (May 7) defeating Marine Le Pen, a far-right nationalist who threatened to take France out of the European Union.
Angela Tan

site_title: Big investors urge Trump to stick with Paris climate accord
summary: Big investors, with over $15 trillion in assets, urged US President Donald Trump to stick with the Paris climate accord despite his threats to pull out. In a letter to governments, they emphasized the importance of implementing the accord to mitigate climate change. The letter was signed by 214 institutional investors, including pension funds from Sweden to Australia, and was addressed to the Group of Seven and Group of 20 leaders. The investors urged nations to stand by their commitments to the Paris Agreement, which aims to limit temperature rise by phasing out fossil fuels.

site_title: What world leaders say about Macron's victory
summary: French centrist Emmanuel Macron won the presidential election, defeating far-right candidate Marine Le Pen in a run-off vote. World leaders, including US President Donald Trump, Chancellor Angela Merkel, and Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, congratulated Macron on his victory, praising his commitment to a strong and united Europe. Many leaders also expressed support for Macron's progressive agenda, including Swedish Prime Minister Stefan Lofven and Brazilian President Michel Temer. Macron's victory was seen as a vote for European cooperation and a rejection of the politics of hate, with leaders like New York City mayor Bill de Blasio and Dutch far-right leader Geert Wilders offering their congratulations and reflections on the election results.

site_title: Australia's Westpac Bank interim net profit up 6%
summary: Australia's Westpac Bank reported a 6% increase in interim net profit to A$3.90 billion, driven by strong performance from institutional operations. Cash profit rose 3% to A$4.01 billion, with impairment charges falling 26%. The bank left its dividend unchanged at 94 Australian cents. Westpac cited improved credit quality and customer transactions as key factors in its earnings. The result follows similar performances from ANZ and NAB, with the Commonwealth Bank posting a record interim cash profit of A$4.91 billion in February.

images.alt_text: Australian banking heavyweight Westpac posted a six per cent rise in interim net profit to A$3.90 billion (S$4.06 billion) Monday on the back of a strong performance from institutional operations.

site_title: HKEX to unveil mainland commodity trading platform this week
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing (HKEX) is set to unveil its Qianhai commodity trading platform this week, aiming to establish a presence in mainland China. The platform will connect with the London Metal Exchange (LME), offering customers opportunities to trade in both domestic and international markets. HKEX CEO Charles Li hopes to attract an industrial base to use the platform's commodity contracts, backed by warehousing and logistics chains. Industry insiders are skeptical about the platform's relevance, citing a market shift towards tailored investment products.

site_title: LNG for greener maritime future
summary: Tesla has officially entered the Indian market with a launch event in Mumbai. The company plans to expand its robotaxi services to California and Arizona. FedEx is partnering with a Singapore startup to deploy robots for deliveries in commercial areas. Delta Air Lines has raised its travel demand outlook, boosting its shares. Japan's carmakers have cut export prices to the US to offset the impact of tariffs. Meanwhile, BYD and other electric vehicle battery makers are facing increased pressure to reduce emissions.

site_title: Fed's Williams stands by hike outlook as unemployment declines
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco President John Williams maintained his outlook for three or four interest rate hikes in 2017, citing a strengthening labor market and inflation near the 2% goal. Despite a disappointing first quarter, Fed officials described the slowdown as "transitory" and emphasized the need for rate hikes to control inflation. The decision not to raise rates this week indicates that the Fed is still committed to its expansionary monetary policy.

site_title: German army calls for searches of all barracks after Nazi memorabilia found
summary: Germany's head of armed forces, General Inspector Volker Wieker, has ordered a search of all barracks after Nazi-era military memorabilia was found in a garrison in southwest Germany. The discovery was made in an investigation into a soldier suspected of planning a racially motivated attack. Defence Minister Ursula von der Leyen has vowed to root out right-wing extremism in the military, stating that the military must investigate with rigor and candour. A preliminary report on the search is due on May 16.

site_title: 'Tonight France won', Macron tells victory rally
summary: France's Emmanuel Macron has won the presidential election, becoming the nation's youngest president at 39 years old. Macron addressed a victory rally at the Louvre museum, declaring "Tonight, France won." Thousands of supporters cheered as he took the stage, following a decisive victory. Macron's pro-EU stance is expected to shape France's future under his leadership.

site_title: Australia's retail slugout adds to worry over weak inflation
summary: Australia's retailers are engaged in a fierce price war, threatening to keep inflation low despite an uptick in consumer prices. The competition from global retailers such as Amazon and Kaufland is expected to keep prices under pressure, making it less likely for the Reserve Bank of Australia to cut interest rates this year. The RBA expects underlying inflation to return to its 2-3% target band by mid-2019, and warns that subdued consumer prices could become a trigger for a move lower and push the Australian dollar weaker.

site_title: Trump's appointment delay stalls US$50b of energy investment projects
summary: US energy investment projects worth $50 billion are stalled due to a delay in President Trump's appointment of key vacancies at an energy regulator. Pipelines, such as the $2 billion Nexus pipeline, are unable to secure permits to begin construction, threatening to meet winter demands. The delay affects projects across the country, with many facing uncertainty about their future. The situation is expected to remain unchanged until Trump fills the vacancies, which could take several months.

site_title: UK consumer spending growth slows in April: Visa
summary: UK consumer spending growth slowed to 0.5% in April, the lowest rate in three years, as higher inflation and weak wage growth squeezed household disposable income. This was below the historic average of 1.4% and the lowest rate since January. Sterling's fall since the Brexit vote contributed to the rise in inflation, now at its highest level since 2013. Businesses are not investing in staff and wages, and policymakers face pressure to address the economic slowdown ahead of the June 8 UK election.

site_title: Tee International to sell 37.2% stake in associate CMC Infocomm for S$5.37m
summary: Tee International agreed to sell a 37.21% stake in associate CMC Infocomm to Yinda Pte Ltd for S$5.37 million. The sale will leave Tee International with 7.45 million CMCI shares. CMCI, listed on Singapore's Catalist board, will cease to be an associate company of Tee International after the sale. The transaction was entered into on Friday.

site_title: Macron remains favourite as France votes for new president
summary: France's presidential election saw a strong turnout of 65.3% of voters by 11pm Sunday, with Emmanuel Macron leading Marine Le Pen by a significant margin. Macron's pro-European Union stance and deregulation plans are expected to win over voters, potentially contrasting with recent nativist voting trends. The outcome could have significant implications for the European Union, with Le Pen's eurosceptic views posing a threat to the EU's future. Macron is predicted to win with around 61.5-63% of the vote, while Le Pen is expected to secure about 39%.

site_title: East meets West in Indonesian fusion food
summary: In Jakarta, a new wave of innovative chefs is modernizing Indonesia's traditional food by incorporating foreign elements, such as noodles in burgers and pizzas. This trend reflects the growing consumer class in the capital, which has emerged after a long economic boom. Restaurants are now offering a range of foreign dishes to cater to this new market, showcasing the fusion of East and West in Indonesian cuisine.

images.alt_text: Indonesian food stylist Dade Akbar hopes he can help raise the profile of humble Indonesian street food.

site_title: NY Residential Reit seeks US$50m to buy costly Manhattan apartments
summary: NY Residential Reit, a new US-based real estate investment trust, is seeking $50 million to purchase costly Manhattan apartments. The company, which owns no assets, is courting online investors based on its management team's expertise. This move is partly driven by Manhattan's growing supply of expensive apartments and the recent easing of Securities and Exchange Commission rules for small companies to access capital.

images.alt_text: A new real estate investment trust opened shop last week, seeking to raise US$50 million from investors online. It plans to use the money on some of the most sought after properties in the world: New York apartments.

site_title: With Macron win secured, France and Germany look to EU future
summary: Chancellor Angela Merkel expressed relief and support for Emmanuel Macron's win in France's presidential election, acknowledging the EU's future was at stake. Macron's victory over far-right challenger Marine Le Pen was seen as a victory for a strong and united Europe. Merkel had previously thrown her weight behind Macron to prevent a far-right, anti-EU government in France. The two allies now face challenges in shaping the EU's future, with Macron's presidency likely to have significant implications for European politics.

site_title: China's forex reserves up in April
summary: China's foreign exchange reserves rose US$21 billion in April to US$3.03 trillion, beating market expectations, due to balanced foreign exchange supply and demand and the appreciation of currencies against the dollar. This marks the third straight month of growth, reassuring policymakers after the yuan steadied following US President Donald Trump's comments on the dollar's strength. Economists had expected a US$11 billion increase. China's central bank sold a small amount of foreign exchange in March, supporting the yuan's stability, and the regulator plans to improve macro-prudential management and diversify foreign exchange reserves.

site_title: Bank pay: The top cut is the deepest
summary: Senior executives at Singapore's top two banks, DBS and OCBC, took the largest pay cuts, with DBS's CEO Piyush Gupta's pay dropping 23% to S$8.44 million. OCBC chairman Ooi Sang Kuang took a 26% pay cut. The banks' decision to cut pay reflects accountability for higher bad loans and shrinking profits. The move also reflects a shift towards performance-based pay, with bonuses for senior staff falling in some cases "very significantly."

site_title: Zcash makes its mark, wants recognition from businesses
summary: Zcash, a new virtual currency, has gained popularity since its launch seven months ago due to its promise of unrivaled privacy protection. It has attracted users in Russia, China, Venezuela, South Africa, and Brazil, with some even using it to pay taxes and electricity bills. However, its lack of transparency raises concerns about money laundering and terrorism financing. Despite its efforts to protect users, Zcash's encryption has been questioned, and it may be vulnerable to hacking and counterfeiting. Experts doubt its ability to integrate into the wider financial system due to the lack of transparency and regulatory hurdles.

site_title: Merkel's party scores strong win in state poll test
summary: Chancellor Angela Merkel's conservatives secured a strong win in state polls in northern Germany, with 32.3% of the vote, surpassing the centre-left Social Democratic Party's 26.9%. The result boosts Merkel's bid to retain power in national elections in September. This marks a blow to the Social Democrats, who had seen a surge in support since their new leader Martin Schulz was chosen in February.

site_title: Euro rallies after Macron wins French presidency
summary: The euro surged to a six-month high against the US dollar after Emmanuel Macron's decisive victory in the French presidency, effectively eliminating the risk of France leaving the single currency bloc. Macron's win saw the euro reach US$1.1023, its highest level since November, as markets largely anticipated his victory over far-right rival Marine Le Pen.

site_title: 120 beneficiaries enjoy breakfast at The Great Egg Cookout
summary: OCBC Bank hosted a charity event, The Great Egg Cookout, at Hotel Jen Orchardgateway, providing breakfast and a mini-carnival to 120 beneficiaries. The event aimed to distribute 300,000 eggs to 2,500 needy families over 12 months. OCBC's revamped CSR program expanded its focus to include other organizations supporting the youth, elderly, and environmental causes. Minister Desmond Lee praised the initiative, encouraging more private sector involvement in community outreach efforts.

site_title: Modi's think-tank prioritises electric cars over hybrids in green car plan
summary: India's government think-tank, Niti Aayog, has recommended prioritizing electric cars over hybrids in a plan to make all vehicles in the country electric by 2032. The report suggests lowering taxes and interest rates for electric vehicles, capping sales of conventional cars, and opening a battery plant by the end of 2018. The plan aims to reduce emissions and cut India's oil import bill, but faces challenges such as high battery costs and a lack of charging infrastructure.

site_title: Fears of possible debt crisis haunt ADB meet
summary: The Asian Development Bank's annual meeting in Yokohama was overshadowed by concerns over a possible debt crisis in Asia and globally. Global debt has reached a record $217 trillion, with much of it in emerging non-financial corporations. Finance ministers from Asean, Japan, China, and South Korea agreed to bolster regional financial safety nets and strengthen surveillance. They also warned of the need for increased vigilance to prevent a new debt crisis, citing soaring levels of corporate debt and the potential for "shock and volatility" from within and outside the region.

site_title: China's insurance regulator calls for systemic loopholes to be plugged
summary: China's insurance regulator has called for the elimination of systemic loopholes and strengthened supervision to address shortcomings in the industry. The regulator aims to improve the regulatory system, increase oversight of shareholder ownership and fund authenticity, and raise the bar for overseas investments by insurance funds. Insurers will face stricter punishments for rule-breaking, and the regulator will closely monitor investments. The move comes amid a regulatory crackdown on excessive use of universal life products and as China seeks to curb financial risk.

site_title: Mexican engineers flood Tesla hiring event in Monterrey
summary: Mexican engineers flooded a hotel lobby in Monterrey for a Tesla hiring event, amid a tight labor market in Mexico and US President Donald Trump's "buy American, hire American" policy. The event aimed to attract talent for Tesla's electric vehicle operations in the region. This move may be a strategic effort by Tesla to tap into Mexico's engineering talent and bypass the US immigration rules that are currently limiting high-skilled foreign workers.

site_title: Tapping the appeal of sports to grow brand awareness
summary: Singapore's robust sports infrastructure and healthy appetite for sports events are attracting major marquee sports events, including the FIFA World Cup, WWE, and the Singapore Grand Prix. MP & Silva's Wu Swee Sin attributes the success to commendable collaboration between the government and commercial stakeholders. However, Wu warns that the current business model may not be sustainable without government support, and brands need to find creative ways to add commercial value to sponsoring sports events. He highlights opportunities for businesses to engage with fans, connect with the wider community, and demonstrate corporate values through sports sponsorships.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Giving cover to all walks of life
summary: NTUC Income, a Singapore insurance cooperative, is expanding its coverage to underserved groups, including people with autism and Down Syndrome, as well as senior citizens with old-age diseases. The company offers industry-first policies, such as Silver Secure and Silver Protect, which provide coverage for dementia, Parkinson's Disease, and early and advanced-stage cancers. CEO Ken Ng emphasizes the need to cater to the growing silver population, and the company is continually exploring opportunities to shield vulnerable individuals. Income's efforts aim to provide affordable insurance and support to those in need, demonstrating its commitment to social impact.

images.alt_text: Vivien Ang

site_title: Najib vulnerable on rising costs as election looms
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak faces a challenge as rising living costs threaten his ruling coalition's support among public servants, who make up a key vote bank. The 5.1% inflation rate, the highest in eight years, has left many government workers struggling to afford basic necessities. Najib's United Malays National Organisation (Umno) clings to rural Malay Muslim heartlands and civil servant votes, but analysts predict a possible internal leadership challenge if the party fails to address the issue. With the next election expected in 2018, Najib may consider calling an early election to capitalize on opposition disarray.

site_title: UPP's warrant: time is on your side
summary: UPP Holdings Ltd issued 836.7 million warrants in October 2017 with an exercise price of S$0.37, compared to its current share price of S$0.29. The warrants cannot be exercised for six months and expire in February 2020, giving holders time to perform. The conversion premium is 40% and the gearing is 8.1 times, offering high returns to buyers.

site_title: TPG Capital makes offer to buy part of Fairfax Media: reports
summary: US private equity giant TPG Capital has made an offer to buy part of Fairfax Media, valued at around A$2.5 billion, in a bid to take over the company's newspapers and Domain Group, a lucrative property advertising business. The offer comes after a tumultuous week for Fairfax, which has been struggling with job cuts and slumping revenues. The deal would leave out other parts of the business, including its New Zealand arm, which recently faced competition issues. Fairfax management is reportedly meeting to discuss the offer amid ongoing staff protests over job cuts.

site_title: Pacific Overtures revival is bare yet flowering
summary: The Pacific Overtures revival at Classic Stage Company is a stripped-down production that takes a "less-is-more" approach, with a single set and minimal costumes. The show, written by John Weidman and composed by Stephen Sondheim, tells the story of Japan's "opening" to the US in 1853, focusing on two characters, a samurai and a fisherman, whose lives intersect as the US and Japan navigate cultural differences. The production, directed by John Doyle, features Sondheim's complex and nuanced songs, which explore themes of cultural identity and the consequences of historical events. Despite some cuts and simplifications, the show remains powerful and thought-provoking.

site_title: Hainan's US$3b injection to turn itself into medical tourism hotspot
summary: China's Hainan island is investing $3 billion in a medical tourism hub, aiming to attract wealthy Chinese patients seeking cutting-edge treatments not yet approved in the country. The hub, which includes hospitals and plastic surgery clinics, has already seen the import of a US-approved cancer drug and plans to draw over 1 million tourists annually by 2025. However, challenges remain, including a shortage of qualified doctors and a patchy record of managing economic zones. Success will depend on the quality of service, medical technology, and costs, according to analysts.

site_title: Reviving Orchard Road
summary: Singapore's Orchard Road shopping belt is struggling to regain its former buzz, with experts suggesting a vehicle-free zone may not be the solution. Instead, retailers should adopt an omnichannel strategy, leveraging technology to enhance the shopping experience, and creating unique experiences that go beyond physical stores. Solutions proposed include creating a "linear park" where retailers can curate different pockets of spaces, integrating retail technology, and designing the area with green and sustainable solutions. Some experts suggest repackaging Orchard Road as a unique destination, incorporating elements like flower domes and local food options, to make it a destination for experiential retail.

site_title: Making 'ownself check ownself' work
summary: A self-governing board is crucial for effective governance, requiring clear guidelines, third-party checks, and objective decision-making. However, as the highest governing body within a corporation, the board itself needs to be governed and subject to checks. This creates a "corporate version of 'ownself check ownself'", where the board's governance and checks are largely self-imposed, raising concerns about its effectiveness. To address this, boards must adopt a more objective approach to decision-making and consider external benchmarks to ensure accountability and good governance.

site_title: Digital trading platform for spot LNG starts up in Singapore
summary: A digital trading platform for spot liquefied natural gas (LNG) has launched in Singapore, aiming to disrupt the current trading system. The Global LNG Exchange (GLX) allows LNG traders to buy and sell cargoes through online auctions, replacing the current system of buy and sell tenders. The platform, which went live in the first quarter, is expected to see its first trade by the end of the current quarter. GLX hopes to provide price transparency and connect buyers and sellers efficiently, with the data collected from trades potentially forming price indices for various locations.

site_title: US firm cancels bid to buy Sri Lanka's airline
summary: US private equity firm TPG has withdrawn its bid to buy a 49% stake in Sri Lanka's loss-making national airline, Sri Lankan. The airline, which has accumulated debts and losses of over $2 billion, is now in talks with Dubai's Emirates, which had previously managed and owned a minority stake. The withdrawal comes after TPG deemed allocating resources to make the airline profitable would not yield sufficient returns, citing other investment opportunities. Talks with Emirates are ongoing, with the carrier seeking a new partner to revive its operations.

site_title: Star of HBO comedy Silicon Valley gives tech-investment advice - no joke
summary: Actor Thomas Middleditch, who plays a struggling startup CEO in HBO's Silicon Valley, has begun investing in tech companies in Silicon Valley. He focuses on environmental and aviation-related startups, such as Beyond Meat and Wright Electric. Middleditch has a diverse portfolio, including real estate and stocks, and aims to avoid investing in companies that he believes are moving the needle backwards in society. He has also invested in a green-conscious fund and plans to be a venture capitalist for seven years, a journey he often jokes about on TV.

site_title: Investors rush to develop rental housing as China's home prices surge
summary: Investors are rushing to develop rental housing in China as home prices surge. The country's high home ownership ratio of 90% has led to a shift towards rental apartments, driving investment by foreign private equity funds and Chinese developers. This trend is fueled by China's millennials seeking alternative options. Foreign investors are capitalizing on the opportunity, while domestic developers are also increasing their focus on rental properties. As a result, rental apartments are becoming an attractive option for those who cannot afford to buy.

images.alt_text: The Soho China's Wanjing Soho project in Beijing. A two-bedroom new home in Beijing costs around 6 million yuan.

site_title: Shanghai tightens supervision over property market, moots sales lottery
summary: Shanghai's housing authority has tightened supervision over its property market, introducing a sales lottery system to govern new home sales. The move aims to cool the market and prevent a crash, following a series of measures to curb speculation and prioritize genuine buyers. The lottery system will ensure fairness, while a notary office will handle the allocation process. The measures also ban property speculation and implement a real-name purchasing system to prevent circumvention of ownership restrictions, with local governments expecting stable house prices in 2017.

site_title: Italy's flag carrier Alitalia is 3 billion euros in debt
summary: Alitalia, Italy's flag carrier, is 3 billion euros in debt as of February, with current liabilities of 2.3 billion euros and assets worth 921 million euros. The airline has filed for special administration for the second time in less than a decade after workers rejected its latest rescue plan. The Italian government has ruled out re-nationalizing the airline and has provided a 600 million euro bridge loan to see it through the process. Three commissioners will assess whether the airline can be restructured or liquidated, with potential buyers showing little interest in taking on the airline's debts.

site_title: Delta said to consider delaying US$3b Airbus order
summary: Delta Air Lines is considering delaying deliveries of 10 Airbus A350 jetliners worth $3 billion, initially set for 2019 and 2020. The airline plans to take five A350s this year as planned, but wants to postpone deliveries of the remaining 50 wide-body aircraft. This move reflects Delta's review of its international flying capacity and demand, amid competition from Boeing. The decision highlights Airbus' challenges in the US market, where other carriers have also slowed their A350 orders.

site_title: Credit to Singapore's blue-collar workers
summary: A Singaporean fintech startup, Onelyst, has successfully matched over 30,000 loan applications worth S$8 million between lower-income borrowers and licensed moneylenders. The platform, founded by two 26-year-old entrepreneurs, aimed to address the issue of credit access for blue-collar workers who face difficulties in securing loans from traditional banks. Onelyst charges a fee to licensed moneylenders and has helped drive credit decisions for them. The startup is also working on a second platform, Rely, which offers short-term loans to workers for luxury items such as smartphones and laptops.

site_title: Time running out for Chong Wei's World Championship hopes
summary: Malaysian badminton player Lee Chong Wei's chances of winning his first World Championship title are dwindling. With a career spanning over two decades, Chong Wei must now instill fear in his opponents to secure the elusive title. His past successes, including a legendary match with Wong Peng Soon, have prepared him for the challenge. However, the pressure is mounting, and Chong Wei's time is running out to achieve his long-held goal.

site_title: Australia proposes scrapping media ownership restraints
summary: Australia is proposing to scrap media ownership restraints, which could lead to increased interest in acquiring Ten Network Holdings, the country's third-largest free-to-air television network. Federal Communications Minister Mitch Fifield announced the plans, which require parliamentary approval. The move is expected to have significant implications for the media industry, potentially leading to increased consolidation and changes in ownership structures.

site_title: Repeal of Obamacare seen hurting US job engine
summary: The US healthcare industry is poised to become the second-largest source of employment, with healthcare jobs in northeastern Ohio increasing by over 30% since 2000, while manufacturing employment has fallen nearly 40% over the same period. Repealing the Affordable Care Act could hurt the job engine, particularly in areas with high healthcare employment. Economists warn that the repeal could undermine overall economic growth, with potential effects on individual consumers, including increased financial insecurity and higher medical bills.

images.alt_text: The US healthcare sector accounts for one in eight private-sector jobs which could be threatened if the Affordable Care Act were repealed.

site_title: S'pore to gain importance as trading hub as LNG becomes commoditised (Amended)
summary: Singapore is poised to gain importance as a trading hub for liquefied natural gas (LNG) due to its commoditization. Over 10 new companies have set up shop in the country in the past three years, bringing the total number of LNG companies to almost 40. Singapore's IE Singapore official, Amreeta Eng, attributes this growth to the increasing need for trading activities in a trade hub for optimization. The city-state's LNG terminal on Jurong Island has excess capacity, and the government agency aims to focus on three areas: attracting market participants, building awareness of LNG derivatives, and helping Singapore companies gain a foothold in the emerging LNG value chain.

site_title: CBI appeals to Brexit negotiators to stop hostile rhetoric
summary: The Confederation of British Industry (CBI) has urged Brexit negotiators to focus on economic growth, jobs, and trade, rather than engaging in hostile rhetoric. The CBI's director-general, Carolyn Fairbairn, warned that such rhetoric could harm UK businesses and economies. The appeal comes after EU politicians and officials made negative comments about UK Prime Minister Theresa May and the UK's position in Brexit talks. The CBI's call is backed by the Association of German Chambers of Commerce and Industry, which also wants to minimize tariff and non-tariff barriers in a future trade deal between the UK and EU.

site_title: Shareholder adviser challenges Linde board over merger with Praxair
summary: Linde's planned $65 billion merger with Praxair has faced opposition from shareholders and investors, citing issues with corporate governance and management's handling of the deal. Shareholder adviser Ivox Glass Lewis advised investors to vote against the merger, citing problems with the planned deal, including hasty management changes and strong labor opposition. Many investors, including Union Investment, have expressed concerns over the lack of transparency and unclear roles within the company's management and supervisory board.

site_title: Singapore reaffirms support for ADB initiatives
summary: Singapore reaffirmed its support for the Asian Development Bank's (ADB) initiatives, particularly in catalyzing private sector funding and providing sustainable urban solutions. Finance Minister Heng Sweet Keat emphasized the need for infrastructure financing, which is expected to rise to $26 trillion by 2030. He also highlighted the importance of sustainable urban solutions and the potential for knowledge sharing through research institutions and platforms. Singapore will continue to collaborate with the ADB to address these challenges and promote environmentally sustainable practices.

site_title: Yinda makes mandatory offer for CMC Infocomm
summary: Yinda Pte Ltd, a subsidiary of Shanghai Yinda Science and Technology Industrial Co Ltd, is making a mandatory unconditional cash offer for all shares of Singapore-listed CMC Infocomm Limited. The offer, valued at S$10.8 million, represents an 18.8% premium over the benchmark price. Yinda already owns 74.41% of CMC Infocomm's shares and aims to acquire the remaining shares. The company has appointed an independent financial adviser and will send a circular to shareholders for their consideration.

site_title: Director buying falls but selling rebounds
summary: Singapore's director buying was at its lowest in four weeks, with 10 companies making 17 purchases worth S$0.52 million. In contrast, selling rebounded after no sales in the previous week, with three firms making five disposals worth S$10.62 million.

site_title: Commodities, currencies will dictate mood
summary: Stock markets are expected to be influenced by the outcome of the French presidential election, with Emmanuel Macron's likely victory potentially boosting trading sentiment. In the US, a unified Republican legislature has passed a bill amending the Affordable Care Act, and economic data showed a return to form with a strong jobs report. The earnings season has been positive, with tech companies like Apple and Facebook performing well, and analysts predict a "reflation" under President Trump. Investors are awaiting stability in commodities and currency markets, which could be influenced by the French election outcome.

site_title: Chinese tech investments spur huge returns for pint-sized ETF
summary: The US$48 million Emerging Markets Internet and E-commerce ETF (EMQQ) has seen a 32% return this year, making it one of the top-performing equity ETFs globally. The fund focuses on technology companies from the developing world, particularly those in China, and has attracted significant inflows since October. Its largest holdings include Tencent Holdings and Alibaba Group, and it has 62% of its portfolio in Chinese companies, compared to 23% for the iShares MSCI Emerging Markets ETF. The fund's success is attributed to its niche strategy, which has become timely given investors' shift away from US stocks and expectations of reduced spending under President Trump.

site_title: All eyes on French election outcome
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron is poised for a potential win in the presidential election, with opinion polls suggesting a clear victory over far-right rival Marine Le Pen. A hacking attack on Macron's campaign has raised concerns, but analysts expect a relief in global financial markets if he secures an overwhelming mandate. Meanwhile, the US jobs report showed a surge in job creation, supporting the Federal Reserve's decision to potentially raise interest rates in June. Global markets are also awaiting China's trade and price inflation data, as well as monetary policy meetings in the Philippines and Malaysia.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Opec is missing a return ticket for its trip back to 2014
summary: Opec's agreement to cut oil output has failed to materialize, with the oil price nearing its pre-cut price of $30 US cents a barrel. The group's next meeting is just over a week away, and oil producers are struggling to find a solution. Despite efforts to cut output, the oil price has remained relatively stable, indicating a lack of compliance with the agreement. This has raised concerns about the effectiveness of the deal in addressing global oil market issues.

site_title: HK Disneyland? Let it go
summary: Hong Kong's Disneyland has been a financial burden, with the government considering relinquishing ownership. The theme park has struggled to attract visitors and generate revenue, leading to calls for the government to reevaluate its investment. With the park's financial performance continuing to decline, it may be more cost-effective for the government to sell its stake and cut its losses.

site_title: Qatar Airways signs World Cup sponsorship deal with FIFA
summary: Qatar Airways has signed a two-year sponsorship deal with FIFA as the official partner and airline for the 2018 World Cup in Russia and the 2022 World Cup in Qatar. The deal covers multiple FIFA events, excluding the 2026 World Cup. This marks a return for Qatar Airways, which previously partnered with FIFA through Emirates, a Middle Eastern carrier that ended its deal in 2014 amid bribery allegations. The sponsorship deal was announced on May 7, 2017.

site_title: Saudi's Kingdom Holding Q1 profit rises 12.7%
summary: Saudi Arabia's Kingdom Holding reported a 12.7% increase in Q1 net profit to 129.1 million riyals ($48.3 million), driven by higher income and gains on investments. The investment firm, owned by Prince Alwaleed bin Talal, owns minority stakes in top companies such as Citigroup, News Corp, and Twitter.

site_title: Update: China's Tencent 'deeply sorry' for Russia WeChat block
summary: Chinese internet giant Tencent apologized for blocking its messaging app WeChat in Russia, stating it was not properly registered with Russian regulators. The block was due to a lack of understanding of Russian regulations, which require online service providers to register with the government. WeChat has 889 million global users and was not clear how many of those were in Russia. Tencent is in touch with authorities to resolve the issue, which is related to Article 15.4 of the Russian law on information, information technologies, and information security.

site_title: Macron's French presidential campaign emails leaked online
summary: French presidential candidate Emmanuel Macron's campaign was targeted by a massive computer hack, resulting in the release of nine gigabytes of data online, just days before the election. The leak included campaign emails, which were later mixed with fake ones to sow doubt and misinformation. Macron's team confirmed the hack, stating that it was a "massive and co-ordinated" attack, and vowed to not tolerate any threats to democracy. The hack comes amid concerns of cyber manipulation in the election, with polls showing Macron set to beat far-right rival Marine Le Pen.

site_title: Australia will ban gambling ads for daytime live TV sports
summary: Australia will ban gambling advertisements on daytime live TV sports before 8:30pm, as part of a broadcasting industry overhaul. The ban applies to TV, radio, and internet ads, with the exception of horse racing. The move aims to reduce the country's high per-capita gambling spending, which ranks among the highest globally. The restrictions are part of a broader reform package, including changes to media ownership laws and the abolition of free-to-air broadcasting license fees.

site_title: Fuel tanker gas leak in New Delhi puts 30 school pupils in hospital
summary: A fuel tanker gas leak at a school in New Delhi, India, hospitalized 30 students, who complained of breathlessness and eye irritation. Over 100 students were evacuated from the Rani Jhansi school, but the cause of the leak was unclear.

site_title: Kanye West exits social media
summary: Kanye West has exited social media after months of erratic behavior. The rapper, who had 27 million followers on Twitter, deleted his accounts and those of his wife Kim Kardashian, who remains active on social media. West's disappearance comes after a series of bizarre incidents, including a breakdown in 2017 following a robbery of Kardashian's jewelry and tabloid rumors of marital problems. His exit from social media follows a quieter approach to online presence after previously praising Donald Trump and deleting pro-Trump tweets.

site_title: Japan, China to hold finance talks amid concerns on protectionism, North Korea
summary: Japan and China will hold their first bilateral financial dialogue in two years on Saturday, discussing risks to Asia's economic outlook, including protectionism and North Korea tensions. Chinese Finance Minister Xiao Jie will meet with Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso to address concerns over China's growing infrastructure finance presence and potential impact on Japan's economy. The dialogue aims to strengthen financial cooperation and respect for free trade, following a trilateral agreement to resist protectionism. The talks will take place on the sidelines of the Asian Development Bank's annual meeting in Yokohama, Japan.

site_title: FBI warns of surge in wire-transfer fraud via spoofed emails
summary: The US Federal Bureau of Investigation warned of a surge in wire-transfer fraud via spoofed emails, with scammers attempting to steal $5.3 billion in business email compromise schemes from 2013 to 2016. The number of cases nearly doubled to 40,203, with the US being the biggest target market. Authorities estimate actual losses could be double the reported figures, with one in four US victims wiring money to fraudsters. Scammers are becoming more sophisticated, targeting corporate finance departments and expanding to other developed countries.

site_title: Macron favourite in opinion polls as France elects new president
summary: France's presidential election has seen Emmanuel Macron, a 39-year-old centrist, lead in opinion polls, bridging the left-right divide. Macron, who wants to resist an anti-establishment tide, faces Marine Le Pen of the National Front, an anti-EU far-rightist. If Le Pen wins, the EU's future could be at risk. Macron's centrist stance aims to unite the nation, while Le Pen's platform emphasizes anti-immigration and anti-EU sentiments. The outcome will determine France's leadership and its stance on European integration.

site_title: Mr Jobs
summary: ManpowerGroup Chairman and CEO Jonas Prising says disruptions in the labor market will result in more jobs if people prepare for them. Despite the Fourth Industrial Revolution bringing significant changes, Prising believes that globalisation and digitisation will create greater prosperity and economic growth. He notes that while technology may replace some jobs, it will also create new ones, and workers must train to up-skill and re-skill to stay employed. Prising advocates for a "skills revolution" that balances technology, talent, and human connection, and emphasizes the importance of lifelong learning and education system reform.

site_title: Toronto airport said worth C$5b in possible sale
summary: Canada is considering selling a minority stake in Toronto Pearson International Airport, valued at approximately C$5 billion, to free up funds for infrastructure projects. The sale, proposed by Credit Suisse Group AG, could also create opportunities for more shops and services, reducing costs for travelers. A report by the CD Howe Institute estimates the privatization of Canada's eight major airports could generate C$7-17 billion, with Pearson alone potentially fetching C$6 billion.

site_title: Trump's pick for Army secretary drops out: official
summary: US President Donald Trump's nominee for Army secretary, Mark Green, withdrew his name from consideration due to criticism over past comments regarding minorities and the LGBTQ community. Green cited "false and misleading attacks" as the reason for his withdrawal. This marks the third Trump nominee for a service secretary position to step down. Senate Democratic leader Chuck Schumer welcomed the decision, stating it was "good news for all Americans" who were affected by Green's disparaging comments.

site_title: US trade panel affirms Argentina, Indonesia biodiesel probe
summary: The US International Trade Commission voted 5-0 to continue an investigation into alleged dumping and unfair subsidies of biodiesel fuels from Argentina and Indonesia. US biodiesel producers claimed that imports from these countries were dumped at prices below production costs, harming their ability to produce the fuels. The next step is for the US Commerce Department to determine whether to impose preliminary anti-dumping duties and anti-subsidy duties. US biodiesel makers praised the vote, citing unfair trade practices by Argentina and Indonesia.

site_title: Scotland's Nationalists dealt a blow in UK local elections
summary: Scotland's National Party lost seven council seats and the Conservative Party gained 164 in local-government elections, while the Labour Party lost control of Glasgow. The results suggest the SNP will retain its parliamentary seats next month, but the question is by how much. The vote was framed as a protest against a potential second independence referendum, and the SNP won the largest number of seats overall. The party's leader, Nicola Sturgeon, hailed the results as a "clear and emphatic victory," while the Conservative leader, Ruth Davidson, said the party is strong enough to lead a fight back against the SNP.

images.alt_text: Scotland's nationalists failed to gain ground in local-government elections as Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservatives cemented themselves as the biggest threat to their dominance after campaigning against another independence referendum.

site_title: Europe: Shares charge to fresh highs, CAC 40 shines ahead of French vote
summary: European shares surged to a fresh 21-month high on Friday, driven by strong earnings updates, supportive economic data, and easing political worries ahead of the French presidential election. The Stoxx 600 index gained 0.6% and the CAC 40 jumped 1.1% to a new 9-1/2-year high, as investors' optimism over European stocks grew. Strong earnings updates from European companies and a decline in US non-farm payrolls data boosted equities globally.

site_title: Addvalue Tech gets order for maritime communications system
summary: Addvalue Technologies has secured a US$1 million trial order for its maritime communications system, Wideye iFleetONE terminal. The company is also in talks for US$3.5 million in orders from potential customers. Chairman and CEO Colin Chan Kum Lok believes the bundling of the product with value-added features will bolster revenue and position the company for growth in the small vessel market. This is part of the company's transformation strategy, focusing on commercial refocusing to maintain growth and deliver long-term value to shareholders.

site_title: Former Petrobras executive: Lula knew about massive corruption scheme
summary: Brazil's former President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva is accused of having "complete knowledge" of a massive corruption scheme at state-run oil firm Petrobras, according to a former top executive, Renato Duque. Duque testified in Lula's corruption trial, stating Lula had "command" of the scheme, but emphasized his intention to cooperate and reduce his prison sentence. Lula's lawyers maintain his innocence, and a ruling is expected by July. The Petrobras probe has led to over 80 convictions, billions in bribes paid, and investigations into nearly one-third of President Michel Temer's Cabinet.

site_title: Athletics: Kenyan Kipchoge runs quickest marathon in just over two hours
summary: Kenyan Eliud Kipchoge ran the quickest marathon time in just over two hours, completing the 26.2-mile course in 2:24 seconds at the Monza circuit in Italy on May 6, 2017. His time surpassed the previous record of 2:02.57 set by Dennis Kimetto in 2014, but was deemed non-compliant due to pacemaking rules. The event, sponsored by Nike, was part of the "Breaking2" project aimed at breaking the two-hour marathon barrier.

images.alt_text: Kenya's Eliud Kipchoge crosses the finish line to win the elite men's race of the 2016 London Marathon in central London on April 24, 2016.

site_title: Irish mortgage drawdowns improve 40% in first quarter
summary: Ireland's mortgage drawdowns increased 40% year-over-year in the first quarter, driven by surging demand and a chronic housing shortage. House prices are accelerating above 10% growth, with 20,000 mortgages approved for first-time buyers and investors in the past 12 months. Experts warn that prices will continue to rise due to low new supply, with only 10,000 of these approvals expected to be met by new homes. Analysts forecast lending to reach 7-8 billion euros this year, exceeding pre-2007 levels.

site_title: Looting ravages Venezuela, unrest death toll hits 36
summary: Violence and looting in Venezuela have resulted in at least 36 deaths, with 70 stores raided since Tuesday. Protests against President Nicolas Maduro's government have been ongoing since April 1, with demonstrators demanding elections. Maduro has resisted opposition demands for elections, and the government has accused the opposition of using armed groups to sow violence. The opposition has called for a march on Saturday, while Maduro's supporters have the backing of the military high command. The economic crisis has caused shortages of food, medicine, and other basics, with residents stockpiling food, water, and fuel.

site_title: IBM falls as Buffett reports reduced stake ahead of meeting
summary: Warren Buffett, chairman and CEO of Berkshire Hathaway, sold about a third of the company's IBM investment in the first half of 2017, reducing its stake from 81 million shares. The move led to a 3.8% drop in IBM's stock price to $153.00. Buffett stated that he no longer values IBM the same as he did six years ago, citing tough competitors such as Amazon Web Services. Analysts predict IBM's transition to cloud computing will take longer than expected, and Berkshire's reduced stake may lead to increased scrutiny on the company's growth prospects.

site_title: UPS contract plane crash lands in West Virginia, killing two
summary: A UPS contract plane crashed and skidded down a hillside at Yeager Airport in Charleston, West Virginia, killing two crew members. The Short 330 twin turboprop, operated by Air Cargo Carriers, touched down at the beginning of the runway and veered off, falling 75-125 feet into a wooded hillside. Investigators are reviewing surveillance footage to determine the cause of the crash, which occurred during approach and landing. The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) has launched an investigation, which will examine factors such as crew operation, plane function, weather, and air-traffic controller actions.

site_title: How to live to 100
summary: Scientists believe the human body can reach a maximum age of 120, and certain communities, such as Okinawans, Ikarians, and Sardinians, often live to 90 or 100 due to their lifestyles and habits. The longest living person on record was Jeanne Calment, who lived to 122 and remained active until her death. Aiming to live to 100 requires a healthy lifestyle, including physical and mental well-being. With advances in medicine and scientific breakthroughs, achieving this goal is becoming more accessible, and many people around the world are now living to 100 or beyond.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Fruit producer Dole said to target US$400m in third IPO
summary: Dole Food Co, a 94-year-old fruit producer, plans to raise approximately US$400 million in its third initial public offering. Led by Morgan Stanley, Bank of America Corp., and Deutsche Bank AG, the offering is subject to a final decision and may change in size. This would be Dole's third IPO in its 166-year history, following a 2009 offering of US$446.4 million. The company's chairman and owner, David H Murdock, is bringing the company to market for the third time.

site_title: Toronto April home price gains slow, new listings increase
summary: Toronto's housing market showed signs of cooling in April, with home prices jumping 25% from last year, but at a slower rate than March. New listings surged 34% to 21,630 units, the highest in seven years, while sales fell 3.2% to 11,630 units. The Ontario government's new measures, including a 15% tax on foreign buyers and rent controls, may be curbing price gains. The market is expected to continue slowing, with annual home price growth remaining "well-above the rate of inflation" for now.

site_title: Home improvement (Amended)
summary: ACTUS häuse, a Singapore-based furniture brand, promotes a relaxed lifestyle similar to the Nordic concept of hygge. The brand's products aim to help individuals unwind and reduce stress. ACTUS häuse is available at Mandarin Gallery in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: First US military death in Somalia since 'Black Hawk Down'
summary: A US soldier has been killed in a night-time raid in Somalia, marking the first US military death in combat there since the 1993 "Black Hawk Down" incident. The soldier was part of a team training Somalian troops to fight Shabaab militants. Two other US soldiers were wounded in the operation. The Shabaab claimed responsibility for the death, saying it repelled the US attack. The incident occurred three weeks after the US deployed a few dozen troops to Somalia to support local forces.

images.alt_text: An American soldier has been killed in a night-time raid in Somalia, in what is believed to be the first US military death in combat there since the infamous events of "Black Hawk Down" 24 years ago.

site_title: My Favourite Album
summary: Kendrick Lamar's album "Damn." debuted with all its songs on the Billboard charts, earning him a spot as a hip-hop artist with complex music. Vic Tan praises the album as the "album of the year".

site_title: Flea-market magnate's Ferrari might break US$100m mark
summary: Flea-market magnate Preston Henn, a Ferrari enthusiast, has died at 86, leaving behind his prized 1964 Ferrari 275 GTB/C Speciale, one of only three in the world. This rare Ferrari could break the $100 million mark if sold at auction, with estimates ranging from $50 million to $75 million. The car has a rich history, including winning the 24 Hours of Le Mans in 1965, and has been displayed proudly at Henn's Swap Shop in Florida.

site_title: The remarkable final days of the French presidential race
summary: France's presidential election is nearing its conclusion, with centrist Emmanuel Macron expected to retain his front-runner status after a fiery debate with far-right candidate Marine Le Pen. Macron has filed a defamation lawsuit against Le Pen, who has been criticized for plagiarizing former candidate Francois Fillon.
