Polls suggest Macron will win by a significant margin, with a possible victory seen as a relief for France and the EU. The election marks a significant shift in French politics, with voters rejecting the two dominant parties and choosing between Macron's open and modern vision and Le Pen's inward-looking stance.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq end at records after solid US jobs data
summary: US stocks closed at records on Friday, driven by a solid jobs report and rebounding oil prices. The S&P 500 rose 0.4% to 2,399.29, while the Nasdaq Composite Index climbed 0.4% to 6,100.76. The jobs report showed a 211,000 net new positions added in April, with the jobless rate falling to 4.4%. Analysts expect the report to support the Federal Reserve's plan for two more interest rate hikes in 2017. Energy shares, including Chevron and ConocoPhillips, led the gains, while IBM fell after Warren Buffett sold a portion of his stake.

site_title: Jamie Oliver sparks fish fuss in Iceland
summary: Celebrity chef Jamie Oliver has sparked controversy in Iceland after posting a photo of a salmon farming cage on Facebook, which is seen as a threat to the country's wild salmon population. The move has angered critics who claim fish farming is an environmental hazard. Oliver's restaurant, "Jamie's Italian," is set to open in Reykjavik on June 17, and may serve salmon on occasion. The company behind the farm, Arnarlax, defends its practices, but acknowledges the need for better education about salmon farming.

site_title: Nun on the run
summary: Theatre: Sister Act, a stage musical with original music by Alan Menken, is coming to Singapore for the first time, running from May 9 at the MasterCard Theatres at Marina Bay Sands. The show follows a lounge singer who disguises herself as a nun to avoid being killed after witnessing a murder, inspiring the church choir to great heights. Tickets are available from S$65 via MarinaBaySands.com/ticketing or Sistic.

site_title: DBS to seek bids for general insurance distribution deal
summary: DBS Group plans to invite bids from insurers to sell general insurance products across Southeast Asia, potentially worth up to $350 million. The 15-year deal, expected to be completed by the end of the year, will cover key markets including Singapore, Hong Kong, and Indonesia. DBS has partnerships with Japanese insurer MS&AD and is likely to partner with other major insurers such as AXA, Generali, and QBE. The deal aims to boost business as rising incomes generate demand for property, motor, and travel insurance products.

site_title: FLT Q2 DPU marginally above forecast (Amended)
summary: Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust (FLT) reported fiscal second-quarter results slightly above forecast, with a distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.75 Singapore cents, exceeding projections of 1.64 Singapore cents. The trust's bottomline fared better due to an exemption for an "absentee landlord tax levy" in Australia, lowering operating expenses. FLT's portfolio occupancy stood at 99.3% as of March 31, and its weighted average lease expiry was 6.7 years. The trust's shares closed 1% lower at S$1.015 following the results.

site_title: Let's tear down the idol of 'shareholder value'
summary: The concept of "maximising shareholder value" is being reevaluated for its potential harm, as it can lead to executives prioritizing profits over other goals. This approach, which was prevalent in the 1970s and 1980s, allowed CEOs to make decisions without fear of consequences, resulting in companies failing to slim down or deploy capital efficiently. The shift in focus is seen as a response to the negative consequences of prioritizing shareholder value above all else, with some arguing that it can blind people to more important goals.

site_title: French, Europe markets unfazed by French elections
summary: French and European markets remained unfazed by the outcome of the French presidential election, with investors showing comfort with either Emmanuel Macron or Marine Le Pen. Market indexes, such as the CAC and DAX, indicate a strong trend support and confidence in a non-disruptive election outcome. A potential Macron victory is anticipated, with the French and German markets suggesting a euro exit is unlikely. The French public also believes a euro exit is a low probability, and investors are applying good stops to protect open positions.

site_title: Kimmel gets to the heart of the matter
summary: Jimmy Kimmel shared a personal and emotional monologue on his late-night show, revealing that his newborn son Billy was born with heart defects and nearly died. Kimmel apologized for getting emotional during the segment, which lasted for 13 minutes. He opened up about the challenges of being a new father and the importance of honesty and vulnerability. The monologue was a departure from Kimmel's usual lighthearted humor, showcasing his ability to tackle tough topics and connect with his audience on a deeper level.

site_title: Brooklyn's hip, its office supply is rising, but big Manhattan tenants still not biting
summary: Brooklyn's efforts to attract large office tenants have been unsuccessful, with no non-government employer signing a lease for more than 100,000 sq ft since mid-2015. Despite 23 office projects planned, the borough's location and softer Manhattan market have deterred big companies, with most opting for smaller operations in Brooklyn. Developers face a challenge in attracting tenants due to limited supply of existing buildings with large spaces, and the "prestige element" of a Manhattan address. Brooklyn's business ecosystem, which nurtures startups, is expected to eventually lure office tenants, but for now, the borough's office market remains underdeveloped.

site_title: House repeals major parts of Obamacare; measure goes to Senate
summary: The US House of Representatives narrowly approved a bill to repeal and replace major parts of the Affordable Care Act, passing 217-213. The measure faces uncertainty in the Senate, where several Republican senators rejected it. The bill would eliminate tax penalties for uninsured individuals, roll back Medicaid expansions, and offer tax credits to individuals. Despite initial failures, President Trump hailed the passage as a significant step towards reshaping US healthcare. The bill's fate now hinges on Senate negotiations, which could lead to a new version of the bill.

site_title: Cosco Corp to sell loss-making shipyard operations
summary: Cosco Corporation (S) Ltd has agreed to sell its loss-making shipyard operations to an affiliate for 1.46 billion yuan (S$300 million) as part of a restructuring plan. The deal comes after the group posted a Q1 net loss of S$78.93 million. The sale-and-purchase agreement was entered into with Cosco Shipping Heavy Industry (CSHI). The move is aimed at improving the group's financial performance and reducing losses.

site_title: Blurring the lines between fiction and reality
summary: Two recent books, "Exit West" by Mohsin Hamid and "The Way of the Strangers" by Graeme Wood, offer unique perspectives on the human experience during uncertain times. "Exit West" is a poignant love story that explores the turmoil of lives in transit, delving into themes of migration, refugees, and the human crisis gripping the world. In contrast, "The Way of the Strangers" provides a sobering look at the minds of those who have pledged their sympathies to extremist groups, such as ISIS, shedding light on the complexities of extremism.

site_title: DBS to ramp up cashless transactions with QR codes
summary: DBS aims to increase cashless transactions in Singapore by utilizing QR codes, with plans to have over 30,000 acceptance points by the end of the year. The bank plans to partner ComfortDelGro to implement QR code payments in its 16,300 taxi fleet and encourage hawkers to use the payment mode. DBS will hire 1,000 "ambassadors" to promote cashless adoption and address common concerns about the process. This move follows a 2016 report showing that 60% of consumer payments in Singapore are still in cash.

site_title: Shareholder yields aren't as low as you think
summary: Investors are underestimating the true yields of stocks, as dividend yields are lower than historical averages. However, when considering the buyback yield, today's yields don't look as poor as expected. Research shows that the top 20 companies in the S&P 500 have repurchased over $622 billion in stock over the past five years, contributing to a 42% increase in total dividends and share buybacks. These buybacks have helped drive the stock market's 70% return, despite not keeping pace with dividends. Investors should consider the total shareholder yield, which combines dividends and buybacks, to get a more accurate picture of the market's performance.

site_title: Not your usual Mercedes cab
summary: The Mercedes-AMG C43 4Matic Cabriolet is a surprisingly practical and desirable open-top vehicle. Powered by a 3.0-litre turbocharged V6 engine, it boasts 520 Newton-metres of torque and a 9-speed automatic transmission, providing invigorating driveability. The rear-biased all-wheel-drive system and adaptive suspension ensure confident handling, even on wet roads. The C43's responsiveness, responsiveness, and responsiveness also make it a pleasure to drive, with a rev-happy gearbox and a low growl from the sports exhaust.

site_title: What's the matter with Europe?
summary: French presidential candidate Emmanuel Macron is expected to defeat far-right nationalist Marine Le Pen in Sunday's runoff. Macron's victory would be a relief for Europe and the world, but also raises concerns about the EU's handling of the crisis. Macron's party represents a centrist approach, while Le Pen's campaign has been fueled by cultural anxiety and perceived EU arrogance. Macron's own party has been criticized for its handling of the EU's austerity measures, which critics argue have been economically disastrous. A Le Pen victory would be a disaster, but Macron's win may not address the underlying issues.

site_title: US unemployment rate drops to 10-year low of 4.4%
summary: US unemployment rate dropped to a 10-year low of 4.4% in April, with nonfarm payrolls rising 211,000 jobs, exceeding the monthly average of 185,000. Job gains were driven by the leisure and hospitality sector and business services. The labor force participation rate fell to 62.9%, and average hourly earnings rose 0.3% due to a calendar quirk. The strong job growth supports a moderate economic expansion and could lead to an interest rate increase next month, despite moderate wage growth.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Riverstone Holdings' Q1 FY17 results beat expectations, driven by strong volume growth in its high-margin cleanroom segment. The company's core earnings grew 19% year-over-year and exceeded forecasts. Maybank Kim Eng Research raised its FY17 to FY19 estimates by 17-18% and set a target price of S$1.05. OUE Hospitality Trust's DPU is expected to grow 5% in 2017, despite a delayed recovery in the Singapore hospitality market. Dairy Farm International's Q1 results showed improved margins, despite slower sales growth.

site_title: A toast for charity
summary: Four well-known sommeliers in Singapore are hosting wine dinners from May 8 to July 10 to raise funds for the Society for the Physically Disabled. The five-course dinners, priced from S$168, will feature wine pairings and stories shared by the sommeliers, with a silent auction to raise additional funds. Guests can also win a bottle of wine. The events will be held at various restaurants, and reservations can be made by emailing mohamadfazil33@gmail.com.

site_title: Most US homes worth less than before the crash
summary: US home values have not fully recovered from the 2008 recession, with only one in three homes worth more now than they were at their peak. Nationally, median home values are US$78,000 below pre-recession levels. In some cities, like Las Vegas and Fresno, fewer than 10% of homes have recovered their value. Coastal markets have experienced the most appreciation, but many homes in pricey areas, such as New York and Los Angeles, are still worth less than a decade ago. The slow recovery may be due to a lack of homes for sale, causing homeowners to delay listing their properties.

site_title: Capital World slips on Catalist debut
summary: Capital World, a Malaysian property developer, slipped 7.14% on its debut on the Catalist board, closing at S$0.182 per share. The company listed via a reverse takeover of marble company Terratech Group and has a market value of over S$250 million. Despite an initial 1% rise, the stock declined throughout the day, with 26.3 million units changing hands. Capital World executive director Siow Chien Fu attributed the listing to access to the capital market and diversified financing options to fund future growth.

site_title: Sounds and sights of Sydney
summary: Vivid Sydney, the world's largest festival of light, music, and ideas, returns to Sydney from May 26 to June 17. The event features over 65 lighting installations, 250 music events, and various fringe activities. Goldfrapp and Fleet Foxes are among the performers. Qantas is offering flights from S$599 to attend the festival.

site_title: STI up 1.7% over the week in mainly mixed trading
summary: The Straits Times Index rose 1.7% over the week, its highest in almost 22 months, driven by a surge in local banks' trading. Despite the index's momentum faltering in the second half of the week, it ended with a 1.11-point rise on Friday. The week also saw the debut of Johor-based Capital World Ltd on Catalist, an integrated property developer. Meanwhile, the Singapore Exchange issued a public reprimand to SingPost for breaching listing rules, and Sembcorp Industries' strategic review sent its shares surging. Global equities are expected to rise due to increasing earnings revisions, according to Pioneer Investments.

site_title: Boss fight on Emirates pitch
summary: Arsenal and Manchester United face off in a crucial English Premier League match at the Emirates Stadium, with both teams vying for a top-four finish and a spot in the Champions League. Arsenal, currently sixth, is trying to overtake fifth-placed Man U, while the Red Devils are struggling at home after 10 frustrating draws. The match is also a rare opportunity for Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger to prove himself against Jose Mourinho, with whom he has a history of disagreements. The winner will gain ground in the pursuit of a top-four place, with the Europa League semi-final also looming for both teams.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: QAF Limited is conducting a strategic review of its Australian production business to enhance shareholder value, which may result in listing or complete sale of the business segment. In other news, Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, is set to become OCBC's CEO, replacing Helen Wong, who will retire. Additionally, Singapore stocks are on a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, while China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: IWH, China Railway consortium rejects TRX's termination of Bandar Malaysia deal
summary: A Malaysian-Sino consortium, IWH CREC Sdn Bhd, is contesting the termination of the Bandar Malaysia deal by TRX City, citing that it has fulfilled payment obligations to acquire 60% of the company. The consortium claims the decision is "unacceptable" and against the contract spirit. It asserts sufficient financial resources to complete the development.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific Q1 net profit down 40%
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings reported a 40% decrease in Q1 net profit to S$5.91 million, mainly due to a 36% fall in revenue to S$65.43 million, primarily from property development and hotel ownership segments.

site_title: Nothing up my sleeves?
summary: Leaders and politicians who roll up their sleeves may appear less authoritative, as seen in Speaker Paul Ryan's cringe-worthy photo. Mastering the roll-up requires skill, with some opting for simple cuff-over methods, while others use the "master roll" technique. Experts argue that rolled-up sleeves are fine for informal settings but detract from formality in formal statements.

site_title: Driving the future
summary: Singapore's government must remove roadblocks to support the development of autonomous and electric vehicles, which could drive the country's future. The industry is hindered by regulatory hurdles, high costs, and limited infrastructure. To succeed, Singapore must create a favorable environment for innovation and investment. This could involve simplifying regulations, investing in charging infrastructure, and providing incentives for companies to develop and deploy autonomous vehicles. By doing so, Singapore can position itself as a leader in the global automotive industry and reap the economic benefits of this emerging sector.

site_title: My weekend
summary: CEO of The RICE Company Limited, Colin Goh, prioritizes spending weekends with friends to integrate technology into arts and culture. He organizes long walks and breakfasts at local eateries, such as Mr and Mrs Mohgan's Super Crispy Prata and Mei Yuen, to foster meaningful conversations and idea generation. Goh finds that people in Delhi and Hanoi spend more time chatting, which he attributes to the importance of face-to-face interactions in sparking creativity.

images.alt_text: COLIN GOH

site_title: Indonesia records 5.01% growth in Q1 on higher prices of commodities
summary: Indonesia's economy experienced a 5.01% growth in the first quarter of 2017, driven by firmer export prices of commodities like palm oil and coal, as well as stronger demand from major trading partners. The growth was seen as a slight improvement from the previous quarter, but analysts were divided on how far this momentum will carry through the rest of the year. The country's private consumption and investment remained sluggish, while the mining sector contracted due to lower production.

site_title: Here be dragons
summary: A super yacht, Rascal, offers private charters to explore the Komodo National Park in Indonesia, where visitors can see Komodo dragons in their natural habitat. The 31-meter yacht, built in traditional Indonesian style, offers luxurious accommodations and amenities, including snorkeling and diving opportunities to explore the park's marine biodiversity. Guests can design their own itinerary and enjoy activities such as kayaking, paddleboarding, and watching the sunset. The yacht is offering a complimentary night for every three nights booked between January and June 2017.

site_title: Star Media to mull over interest in its Cityneon stake
summary: Star Media Group, which owns 52.51% of Cityneon Holdings, has received an "expression of interest" from Bird & Bird ATMD LLP to buy the entire equity interest in the Singapore-listed creative agency. The offer is for 128,458,590 ordinary shares, representing about 52.51% of Cityneon's issued share capital. Star Media's board will deliberate on the matter and make an announcement in due course, halting trading of Cityneon's shares pending the release of the announcement.

site_title: Dixon Chan
summary: Dixon Chan, co-founder and CEO of Burpple, a food-sharing network app, reminisces about his early struggles with missing local Singaporean food while living abroad. He launched Burpple in 2012 to solve the problems of finding authentic reviews and recommendations. The app has since evolved into a "food discovery" platform with 5.5 million users and 3 million restaurant reviews. Chan emphasizes the importance of a strong team and purpose in entrepreneurship, and critiques food apps for lacking emotional connection and relevance. He credits his Singaporean upbringing and personal experiences with shaping his passion for food and entrepreneurship.

site_title: Macron extends lead in polls over Le Pen on final day of French election campaign
summary: French presidential candidate Emmanuel Macron has extended his lead in polls over far-right rival Marine Le Pen on the final day of the election campaign, with four polls indicating Macron will win 62% of the votes in the second round, compared to 38% for Le Pen. Macron's strong performance in the final debate and his party's expected success in the June legislative elections have boosted investor confidence, with European shares easing. Le Pen has vowed to win, despite criticism of her aggressive approach to the debate, while Macron has announced his plans for a prime minister if he wins.

site_title: BT Budding Artists Fund marks 12th anniversary with two new centres
summary: The Business Times Budding Artists Fund (BT BAF) is celebrating its 12th anniversary with the opening of two new training centers in the northern part of Singapore. The centers, The Little Arts Academy North Campus 1 and 2, will provide arts training for financially-disadvantaged children, increasing the annual intake by 300. UOB donated S$400,000 to BT BAF, supporting its mission to provide a level-playing field in the arts for disadvantaged children. The fund, founded in 2005, aims to make arts education more accessible to families in the north and north-east of Singapore.

site_title: Thailand revokes wanted Red Bull heir's passport over hit-and-run case
summary: Thailand has revoked the passport of Vorayuth "Boss" Yoovidhya, heir to the Red Bull fortune, over a 2012 hit-and-run case in which he allegedly crashed a Ferrari into a policeman, killing him. Vorayuth, 32, had previously missed court summons eight times and left Thailand for Singapore before being formally charged. The move is seen as a rare move against the wealthy and powerful. An arrest warrant was issued last week, and Vorayuth's passport was revoked effective immediately, leaving his international travel options uncertain.

images.alt_text: Thailand has revoked the passport of an heir to the Red Bull fortune who has been accused of a deadly hit-and-run but has several times failed to turn up in court.

site_title: Pipe Dreams
summary: Standpipes in Singapore's kampongs, introduced in the 1940s, provided free water to residents, allowing them to carry as much as they could. This marked a significant improvement over drawing well water and waiting for city council workers. Standpipes became social hubs, where neighbors would gather to chat and gossip, foreshadowing the concept of office water coolers. This infrastructure served as a precursor to modern public water facilities, offering a vital service to the community during droughts and other water scarcity periods.

site_title: Modern Romance
summary: Hong Kong director Pang Ho Chueng's latest film "Love Off The Cuff" is a romantic comedy featuring Shawn Yue and Miriam Yeung reprising their roles as Jimmy and Cherie. The movie is the third installment of Pang's "Love In A Puff" franchise and explores the challenges of Jimmy and Cherie's relationship when his attractive 'godmother' and her philandering father visit unexpectedly. The film screens in cinemas now, maintaining its witty and crowd-pleasing tone despite some lost Cantonese slang in the Mandarin translation.

site_title: China, Japan, South Korea to jointly combat financial instability
summary: China, Japan, and South Korea have agreed to cooperate on preventing financial instability in the face of increased uncertainty and geopolitical tensions. The three-way talks were held on the sidelines of the Asian Development Bank's annual meeting in Yokohama, where finance ministers and central bank governors reaffirmed their commitment to high-level communication and coordination. Japan proposed a new currency swap arrangement worth 4 trillion yen, which was positively received by participants. The move aims to build on Japan's efforts to establish a multilateral currency swap agreement since the Asian currency crisis in the late 1990s.

site_title: Driving Style
summary: Horst Herdtle, 54, is the managing director of Performance Motors, an authorized BMW dealer in Singapore. Born in Germany, Herdtle chose the automotive industry over computers in 1986, after graduating from the University of Cooperative Education. He has held various positions, including CEO of Euro Auto Corp, and has seen the global automotive industry's shift towards innovation in areas like autonomous driving, electrification, and connectivity. Herdtle emphasizes the importance of delivering outstanding customer experience in the competitive Singapore market, where luxury cars are expensive and customers expect top-class service.

site_title: Sweet life
summary: In Singapore, several entrepreneurs are capitalizing on the growing interest in exotic honey, with unique properties and flavors. Anaya sells Trigona honey from the Philippines, which is extracted from the hive structure and has antibacterial properties. Go Pure offers organic honey from Linden and Acacia flowers, while Cerana sources honey from Southeast Asia, promoting farm-to-bottle production and diverse flavors. As consumers become more knowledgeable about honey's benefits, these businesses aim to change the perception that honey from non-traditional sources is inferior, with younger generations driving the demand for authentic, high-quality products.

site_title: When the gospel of minimalism collides with daily life
summary: The article discusses the concept of minimalism as a lifestyle, which suggests that owning fewer possessions leads to greater happiness. However, research suggests that experiential purchases, such as memories, provide deeper emotional satisfaction than material items. Studies have found that even luxurious items, like designer furniture, can lose their appeal over time, while experiences like hiking can yield long-lasting psychological benefits. The article concludes that minimalism may not be the only path to happiness, and that sometimes, a little more stuff can actually bring immense comfort.

site_title: Patek precision
summary: Patek Philippe has unveiled a new watch range at Basel 2017, featuring a sporty Aquanaut Travel Time Reference 5650 that boasts a two-time zone function, a new balance spring, and flexible mechanisms. The watch retails for $77,700, significantly less than a traditional tourbillon. This is part of Patek's 20th anniversary of the Aquanaut line and also marks the 40th year of the ultra-thin self-winding movement Caliber 240. Three new watches featuring Caliber 240 are also released, including a limited edition Ref 5180/1 "Squelette" in rose gold.

site_title: Kingboard Copper Foil net profits jump 179.4% to HK$4.4m
summary: Kingboard Copper Foil's net profits surged 179.4% to HK$4.4 million in the first three months of 2017, driven by a 12.36% revenue increase to HK$163.9 million. The company attributed the growth to a HK$30 million licence fee and the sale of polyvinyl butyral (PVB) resin for HK$134 million. Shares closed flat at S$0.400.

site_title: Dine now
summary: A Japanese restaurant is highlighting the freshness of Hokkaido seafood until May 31, featuring dishes like herring and flatfish sashimi. Meanwhile, Grain Traders is introducing a new breakfast program, allowing customers to mix their own bowls starting at S$12. The program offers various base options, egg styles, proteins, and vegetables.

site_title: Millennium & Copthorne Hotels posts net profit of £3 million in Q1
summary: Millennium & Copthorne Hotels (M&C) reported a net profit of £3 million in Q1 2017, down 50% from £6 million in the same quarter last year. Total revenue rose 16.1% to £223 million, driven by increases in London and New Zealand. Group RevPAR inched up 4.6% in constant currency, but Singapore RevPAR slipped 0.9%. The company attributed poor performance in the US region to geo-political tensions and is reviewing its US management structure.

images.alt_text: Singapore RevPAR slipped marginally by 0.9 per cent. While occupancy rose 4.7 percentage points, average room rate dropped by 6.3 per cent.

site_title: Big boys in power market being zapped by new players
summary: New entrants in Singapore's power sector are gaining market share, with Hyflux's Tuaspring power plant growing its share to 3.7% and PacificLight Power increasing its market share for the fourth straight year. The three big power-generation companies, Tuas Power, Senoko Energy, and YTL Power Seraya, saw their combined market share fall by 1.3 percentage points to 57.7% last year, while new entrants PacificLight and Hyflux gained market share in both generation and retail markets. The incumbents are facing "severe financial strain" due to depressed wholesale electricity prices, with Tuas Power's CEO warning that the current market situation is unsustainable.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific Q1 net profit down 40%
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings reported a 40% decrease in net profit to S$5.908 million for its first quarter ended March 31, due to lower contributions from its property development segment. Revenue fell 36% to S$65.43 million, and earnings per share decreased to 0.50 Singapore cent. No dividends were declared for the period.

site_title: Noble beast, noble band
summary: MBL's N-51 Integrated Amplifier is a high-end, single-box amplifier that combines power and precision, offering 285 Watts into 8 Ohms and constant output impedance via its LASA 2.0 technology. This reduces strain on loudspeakers and provides pure and precise sound. The amplifier features a color motion-sensitive screen, motion-sensitive remote control, and six analog inputs, including 1 XLR. Available for S$18,500, the N-51 is part of MBL's "Noble" range, which fits between the entry-level Corona and top-of-the-line Reference line.

site_title: Ascott to open first Citadines serviced residence in US
summary: Ascott, a serviced residence arm of CapitaLand, has purchased a property on New York's Fifth Avenue for "close to" US$50 million. The 125-unit Hotel Central Fifth Avenue New York will be renovated and rebranded as Citadines Fifth Avenue New York in 2018, marking Ascott's first Citadines serviced residence in the US.

site_title: Vogue editor Anna Wintour made a dame by Britain's queen
summary: Anna Wintour, editor of US Vogue, was made a dame by Queen Elizabeth II for services to fashion and journalism. The 67-year-old British-born editor, who has led the magazine for nearly 30 years, received the honor at a ceremony at Buckingham Palace. Wintour quipped about the queen's difficulty in pinning the brooch to her award. She attended the ceremony with her daughter and smiled broadly after receiving the recognition for her influential voice in high-end fashion.

site_title: Air Canada reports loss in Q1 versus year-ago profit
summary: Air Canada reported a net loss of C$37 million in the first quarter, compared to a net income of C$101 million in the same period last year, primarily due to a 48% increase in fuel costs. Operating revenue increased 8.9% to C$3.64 billion. The airline attributed the loss to rising fuel costs and increased competition in the market.

site_title: Influence of English is fading, says EU chief Juncker
summary: European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker stated that English is losing importance in Europe, following Brexit. He said he would not give a speech in English, instead opting for French to be better understood in France ahead of the country's presidential election. This comes at a time of heightened tensions between Brussels and London over Britain's withdrawal from the EU. Juncker's comments reflect a shift away from English as the primary language in international gatherings.

site_title: US:Wall St edges up on strong jobs data
summary: US stocks rose slightly on Friday after a robust April jobs report, with nonfarm payrolls rising 211,000 and the unemployment rate falling to a near 10-year low. The Dow index edged up 0.04%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite rose 0.19% and 0.26%, respectively. The strong jobs report reaffirmed the strength of the labor market, and the odds of a rate hike in June jumped to 75%. Apple and Cognizant were top gainers, while IBM's shares fell 3.3% due to Warren Buffett's stake sale.

site_title: Qantas says Japan, Singapore budget airline offshoots can fund their own growth
summary: Qantas CEO Alan Joyce stated that its budget offshoots, Jetstar Japan and Jetstar Singapore, are financially stable enough to fund their own growth plans, no longer requiring significant capital injections from Qantas. Jetstar Japan plans to expand its fleet to 28 A320 aircraft over the next two years, while Jetstar Pacific in Vietnam aims to double its fleet to 30 aircraft by 2020. Qantas shares rose 2.3% following the announcement, with the airline expecting its second-best annual profit.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: Indonesia has detained a Trafigura employee in a US$17 billion graft case. OCBC's incoming CEO, Tan Teck Long, is a former DBS veteran. Singapore stocks have notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. OCBC's current CEO, Helen Wong, is set to retire and has been replaced by Tan Teck Long. Sats CEO Kerry Mok's pay has risen 30.5% to S$3.1 million. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Lum Chang acquires One Tree Hill Gardens for S$65m in first en bloc deal this year
summary: Lum Chang Holdings Limited acquired One Tree Hill Gardens for S$65 million, the first en bloc deal in 2017, below the asking price of S$72.8 million. The site, located at the junction of One Tree Hill and Jalan Arnap, has a land rate of S$1,664 per square foot. The Lum Chang Group plans to redevelop the site into residential landed homes for sale, subject to Strata Titles Board approval.

images.alt_text: In what is the first collective sale this year, Lum Chang Holdings Limited is acquiring One Tree Hill Gardens for S$65 million, below the owners' asking price of S$72.8 million.

site_title: A self-cleaning, talking robovac
summary: A China-made robotic vacuum cleaner, the Deebot R98, has been released with advanced features. The device, made by Ecovacs Robotics, can speak in a woman's voice, navigate using a proprietary laser scanning system, and empty its own trash compartment. It also features a mop attachment, a cordless handheld stick vacuum, and can be controlled remotely using a smartphone app. The device's suction power is strong but noisier, and its anti-collision sensors provide safe navigation. The Deebot R98 is priced at S$1,049, significantly higher than its predecessor.

site_title: Mixed to weak trading for Singapore stocks despite STI's gain
summary: Singapore stocks experienced mixed trading, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 54 points or 1.7% for the week despite weak trading in the second half. The index surged in the first two days due to a rush to buy local banks, but momentum faltered as investors reassessed the market outlook. Trading in the banks was the most active, with the highest turnover on Tuesday. The STI closed at 3,229.73 on Friday, after dropping into the red for most of the day.

site_title: QAF conducts strategic review of primary production business in Australia
summary: QAF Limited is conducting a strategic review of its primary production business in Australia to enhance shareholder value. The review may result in a listing or sale of the business segment, pending shareholder and regulatory approvals. The company has confirmed that the proposed listing does not meet SGX-ST's chain listing criteria. Further announcements will be made as the review progresses.

site_title: Lufthansa CEO says next move in Air Berlin talks up to Abu Dhabi
summary: Lufthansa CEO Carsten Spohr said talks with Abu Dhabi over taking over Air Berlin are ongoing, with debt and costs remaining major obstacles. Abu Dhabi's government is believed to be necessary to resolve Air Berlin's debt problem. Spohr also expressed optimism for bookings, echoing rival Air France-KLM.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares ended higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's stock market ended higher on Friday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 4.070 points to close at 1,762.740. A total of 3.57 billion lots valued at RM2.49 billion were traded, with gainers outnumbering losers 617 to 327.

site_title: Agrocorp unit opens rice mill in Myanmar
summary: AGRASTAR, a unit of Agrocorp International, opened a 250-tonne-a-day rice mill in Myanmar's Ayeyarwaddy region. The facility can produce 75,000 tonnes of high-quality parboiled, brown, and white rice annually. Plans include doubling production by year-end and expanding to other sites in the delta. The mill aims to increase production capacity and capitalize on Myanmar's growing rice market.

images.alt_text: Agrastar, an associate company of privately owned Agrocorp International, on Friday opened a parboiled rice production and export facility in Myanmar.

site_title: Rickmers Maritime says no AGM to save cash for creditors
summary: Rickmers Maritime's trustee-manager has decided not to convene an annual general meeting (AGM) to save costs for creditors. This decision comes after the trust's failed debt restructuring and winding-up processes. The trustee-manager has kept unitholders updated through announcements and allowed them to raise queries. The trust will not report quarterly financial results as it is being wound up, marking the first listed shipping trust to be wound up in Singapore.

site_title: OUE Commercial Reit posts 6.8% fall in Q1 DPU
summary: OUE Commercial Reit reported a 6.8% fall in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.23 Singapore cents for Q1 2017, down from 1.32 cents in the previous year. Revenue rose 4.4% to S$44.8 million, driven by strong performance from its properties. Net property income grew 4.2% to S$34.6 million.

site_title: Lum Chang snags first en bloc site this year for S$65m
summary: Lum Chang Auriga Pte Ltd has acquired a freehold site in One Tree Hill Gardens for S$65 million, marking its first en bloc purchase this year. The 3,629.1 sq m site is expected to accommodate up to 15 landed units and will be developed into bespoke homes. The purchase price translates to a land rate of S$1,664 per square foot, below the owners' asking price of S$72.8 million. The transaction is subject to Strata Titles Board approval and is expected to result in gross sale proceeds of between S$4.3 million and S$9.1 million for the owners.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks down on profit-taking, tracking overseas caution
summary: Taiwan's main Taiex index fell 0.4% to 9,928.61 on Friday, following a nine-session winning streak, amid profit-taking and overseas market caution. The electronics and financials subindexes also declined. The index gained 3.5% in the previous nine sessions. The Taiwan dollar softened to NT$30.148 per US dollar.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks dive more than 1% by break
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted more than 1% on Friday morning, led by energy firms hit by a decline in oil prices. The Hang Seng Index fell 1.16%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined. Investors await US jobs data later in the day, which may impact market sentiment.

site_title: Indonesia's Q1 GDP growth up slightly, supported by higher commodity prices
summary: Indonesia's Q1 GDP growth rose 5.01% annually, beating expectations, driven by higher commodity prices. This is above the fourth quarter's 4.94% pace and a quarterly contraction of 0.34%. The government's growth target for 2017 remains 5.1%, while Bank Indonesia forecasts 5.0-5.4% growth.

site_title: US job growth rebounds sharply, jobless rate hits 4.4 per cent
summary: US job growth rebounded sharply in April, with nonfarm payrolls increasing by 211,000 jobs, the highest monthly gain this year. The unemployment rate dropped to 4.4%, its lowest level since May 2007. Despite moderate wage growth, the labor market is tightening, supporting the Federal Reserve's case for an interest rate increase next month. Average hourly earnings rose 0.3% and private sector wages recorded their biggest gain in 10 years. Job growth supports a "moderate" pace of economic expansion, but payroll gains may slow amid growing labor shortages.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks drop the most in 2 weeks as resources shares tumble
summary: Hong Kong stocks experienced their largest daily percentage decline in two weeks, falling 0.8% to 24,476.35, due to a drop in resources shares amid weaker oil and commodity prices. The decline was also influenced by a bearish Chinese stock market, which reached three-month lows. Global economic concerns and lower oil prices further contributed to the market's decline.

site_title: Norway's wealth fund excludes India's Bharat Heavy Electricals from investments
summary: Norway's sovereign wealth fund has excluded India's Bharat Heavy Electricals from its $935-billion investment portfolio due to concerns over the company's ethical guidelines, specifically its production of nuclear equipment. Bharat Heavy Electricals is among several companies under observation for potential exclusion. Other companies, PetroChina and Leonardo, are also under scrutiny. The fund will, however, continue to engage with these companies to encourage improvements.

site_title: BOJ's Kuroda confident inflation will accelerate 'significantly': CNBC
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda expressed confidence that inflation will accelerate "significantly" due to continuous accommodative monetary policy and fiscal support. Japan's economy has shown a strong recovery trend, which will help narrow the output gap and push up inflation to 2%. Kuroda believes this will address the cautious mindset of the Japanese public regarding inflation expectations.

site_title: India moves resolution of $150b bad debt problem into RBI's court
summary: India has amended its Banking Regulation Act to give the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) greater authority to resolve $150 billion in troubled bank debts. The RBI can now direct banks to initiate insolvency resolution processes for defaulted loans and specify authorities or panels to advise on stressed asset resolution. The changes aim to tackle India's record bad debt problem and enhance the RBI's power to enforce resolution on specific soured loans.

site_title: GSH posts S$1.35m net loss in Q1
summary: GSH Corporation, a Singapore property company, reported a net loss of S$1.35 million in Q1, down from a S$2.8 million profit in the same period last year. Revenue fell 10.5% to S$21 million, with the hospitality business contributing S$17.7 million, up 16% from the previous year. The company attributed the loss to higher administrative expenses and finance expenses, and stated a positive outlook for the hospitality industry in Malaysia.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Strong maritime force needed to protect Singapore's sovereignty and trade: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Long emphasized the need for a strong maritime force to protect the country's sovereignty and trade, as an island nation heavily reliant on sea trade. He highlighted the importance of a robust naval presence in safeguarding Singapore's lifeblood, trade. The Singapore Navy celebrated its 50th birthday on May 5, 2017, with PM Lee making the statement.

site_title: Britain awaits local election results in test for PM
summary: Britain awaits local election results on Friday, which will serve as a key indicator of Prime Minister Theresa May's chances in the upcoming Brexit-dominated national election. Voters across England, Scotland, and Wales chose nearly 5,000 new local councillors, with local issues and Brexit on voters' minds due to May's surprise snap general election call last month. The results will provide insight into May's popularity and the public's stance on Brexit ahead of the June 8 general election.

site_title: China: Stocks down for 4th week on worries over economy, policy tightening
summary: China's main stock indexes fell to fresh three-month lows, posting their fourth weekly loss in a row, due to lingering worries over economic growth and tighter regulations. The CSI300 index fell 0.6% and the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.8%, marking their worst week this year. Analysts attribute the decline to tightening regulations and regulatory measures expected in the second half of the year.
