China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. Meanwhile, OCBC's new CEO Tan Teck Long will succeed Helen Wong, while Sats CEO Kerry Mok's pay rose 30.5% to S$3.1 million.

site_title: China's yuan steadies, US jobs and French election in focus
summary: China's yuan steadied against the US dollar on Friday, with the People's Bank of China setting the midpoint rate at 6.8884 per US dollar, firmer than the previous fix of 6.8957. The yuan's steady rate was attributed to improved market sentiment and authorities' efforts to signal a stabilizing currency. Investors have also increased bullish bets on the yuan, partly due to a favorable outcome in the French presidential election and US non-farm payrolls data later in the day.

site_title: ChemChina clinches landmark US$43b takeover of Syngenta
summary: ChemChina clinches a $43 billion takeover of Syngenta, a Swiss pesticides and seeds group, after receiving over 80% support from shareholders. The deal, announced in 2016, aims to improve China's domestic agricultural output by leveraging Syngenta's portfolio of top-tier chemicals and patent-protected seeds. The acquisition is part of a trend towards market consolidation in the agricultural chemicals, seeds, and fertilizers sector, which has raised concerns among farmers about reduced innovation. The transaction is set to close on May 18, with Syngenta shares to be delisted from the Swiss bourse.

images.alt_text: ChemChina has won more than enough support from Syngenta shareholders to clinch its US$43 billion takeover of the Swiss pesticides and seeds group, the two companies said on Friday.

site_title: US opens criminal investigation into Uber
summary: The US Justice Department has launched a criminal investigation into Uber for using secret software to operate in areas where it was banned or restricted. This probe is the latest blow to the company, following recent disclosures about sexism and workplace tactics, as well as a lawsuit from Google's parent company accusing Uber of stealing technology. The investigation is in its early stages and is focused on the use of this secret software.

site_title: Rosneft net income lower than expected, hit by stronger rouble
summary: Russia's largest oil producer Rosneft posted a worse-than-expected rise in first-quarter net income, despite higher output and crude prices, due to a stronger rouble. The currency's strength negatively impacted Rosneft's performance, reducing revenue from exports and lowering payments of debt denominated in foreign currencies. The company's net income rose 28% year-over-year in rouble terms, but the impact of the stronger rouble outweighed the benefits of higher oil prices.

site_title: Cosco (S) Q1 net losses deepen to S$78.9m
summary: Cosco Shipping International (Singapore) reported a net loss of S$78.9 million in Q1 2017, a 4.5-fold increase from the same period in 2016. Losses were attributed to shipyard and shipping operations, with inventory writedowns and allowances for expected losses. The company's order book remains strong at US$5.8 billion, but operating margins are expected to face downward pressure due to weak global markets. Turnover decreased by 44% to S$401.8 million.

site_title: US employment growth seen rebounding, wages increasing
summary: US job growth likely rebounded in April with a gain of 185,000 jobs, according to a Reuters poll of economists. This marks a rebound from the smallest gain in 10 months in March, where 98,000 jobs were added. The rebound in job growth and increase in wages point to a tightening labor market, potentially paving the way for the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates next month.

site_title: BA-owner reports profits dive as weak sterling bites
summary: IAG, parent group of British Airways and Iberia, reported a 74% slump in first-quarter net profit to €27 million (S$41.5 million) due to a weak pound. The decline was largely attributed to currency exchange, with a €32 million impact in the quarter. This marks a significant decrease from €104 million in the same period last year. IAG chief executive Willie Walsh stated that the impact of currency exchange was a major factor in the profit decline.

site_title: RBA lifts Australia growth forecast
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia raised its growth forecast for the next financial year to 2.75-3.75% due to expected increases in liquefied natural gas exports. The central bank left interest rates unchanged, citing uncertainty surrounding consumer spending. It also warned that household debt could impact consumer spending, but noted that wage growth is expected to pick up gradually. The RBA attributed the forecast boost to the end of the mining investment boom and the ramp-up in resource exports.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets drop at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets dropped at the start of trading on Friday, awaiting US jobs data amid falling oil prices. London's FTSE 100 fell 0.3%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 lost 0.4%, and Paris' CAC 40 dropped 0.5%. The declines came ahead of France's presidential election and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: C919 jet set for maiden flight, in test of China's aviation ambitions
summary: China's C919 passenger jet is set to make its maiden flight on Friday, marking a major step in Beijing's aviation ambitions. The narrow-body aircraft, capable of carrying 158-168 passengers, will compete with Boeing's 737 and Airbus A320. Despite production delays, the C919 has 570 orders from 23 customers, but faces a lengthy journey to commercial usage due to technological lag and the daunting task of selling the jet in a global market dominated by Boeing and Airbus.

site_title: South Korea to draw line under Park scandal with vote
summary: South Korea holds a presidential election on May 9, following months of political turmoil under ousted President Park Geun-Hye. The country's economic and social frustrations, fueled by growing inequality and unemployment, remain unaddressed. Left-leaning candidate Moon Jae-In is expected to win with a crushing victory, according to final opinion polls, as conservatives struggle to recover from Park's scandal. The winner will face daunting tasks, including reforming powerful family-run conglomerates and addressing tensions with North Korea and the US.

site_title: Australia shares down, post worst week since Feb; NZ lower
summary: Australian shares fell 0.7% to 5,836.6, marking their steepest weekly decline since early February, amid a dip in oil and metal prices. Energy stocks Woodside Petroleum and Oilsearch dropped 2.7% and 1.8%, respectively. The S&P/ASX 200 index logged a 1.5% loss for the week.

site_title: As US jobs move to high skill, men join college at record pace
summary: US men are enrolling in college at record levels, with 67% of 1.5 million high school graduates in 2016 attending institutions, surpassing recession-era levels and the highest share on record since 1993. This trend is a promising sign that men are catching up with female peers in educational attainment, as employers increasingly value degrees in a job market requiring more complex entry-level skills. The increase in male college enrollment could help reverse the decline in labor force participation among men in their prime working years.

site_title: Trump meets Australia's Turnbull, says spat 'all worked out'
summary: US President Donald Trump met with Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull in New York, saying a telephone spat over a refugee deal was "all worked out". Trump previously called the deal "dumb" and cut off the call, but claimed the media exaggerated the incident. The two leaders put aside their differences and reaffirmed their strong relationship, with Trump saying he loves Australia and wants to visit the country. The meeting came as tensions between the US and Australia had soured due to disagreements over trade and security issues.

site_title: Looking for love will cost you more in Zurich than anywhere else
summary: Zurich has been named the most expensive city for a date, with a night out costing $195.90, 147% more than in New York. The city's strong currency contributes to its high prices. Other cities with high costs for a date include Oslo and Melbourne, where a night out costs 119% and 104% more than in Manhattan, respectively. In contrast, cities like Kuala Lumpur, Jakarta, and Manila offer the cheapest options for a date. The study suggests that exchange rates may not adjust to correct large price differentials across countries and time.

site_title: Japan to offer patrol planes to Malaysia: report
summary: Japan plans to donate retired military patrol aircraft, including decommissioned P-3C planes, to Malaysia as part of its defense cooperation with the Southeast Asian country. The move comes in response to China's aggressive stance on the South China Sea. Japan's parliament is currently deliberating a bill to provide military equipment to other countries at no cost, with Malaysia likely to be the first beneficiary. This donation is seen as a strengthening of alliances between the two countries against Beijing's maritime claims.

site_title: Sterling inches higher after upbeat week of data
summary: The pound has inched higher on Friday, reaching recent highs around $1.2950, after a week of generally upbeat business sentiment surveys. Sterling has surged almost 3% since Prime Minister Theresa May's surprise national parliamentary election announcement, which is seen as strengthening her hand in Brexit talks. Despite record bets against the currency, markets are unwinding their short positions, with analysts predicting a neutral level around $1.30-$1.31. Data showing a four-month high in the Markit/CIPS Services Purchasing Managers' Index has also boosted the pound.

site_title: Hundreds march against Trump ahead of NY visit
summary: Hundreds of protesters marched in New York City against President Donald Trump on Thursday, as he made his first return to his hometown since taking office. The demonstration, which was smaller than expected, voiced criticism of Trump's policies, including his stance on immigration and healthcare. Trump, who arrived late, was set to meet with Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull before departing for a weekend at his golf club in New Jersey. The city has seen frequent anti-Trump demonstrations in recent weeks.

site_title: US trade deficit edges lower in March
summary: The US trade deficit decreased 0.1% in March to $43.7 billion, despite record imports from Mexico and a drop in total exports. Total exports fell 0.9% to $191 billion, while imports dropped 0.7% to $234.7 billion. The deficit with Mexico reached a 10-year high, while exports to the EU and South Korea hit all-time monthly records. The trade gap remains a focus for the Trump administration's nationalist economic agenda, with President Trump poised to renegotiate the North American Free Trade Agreement.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.210 point to 1758.830. A total of 107.33 million lots were traded worth RM47.82 million, with 115 gainers and 100 losers.

site_title: Tritech completes sale of Terratech stake for the unit's reverse takeover
summary: TRITECH Group has completed the sale of its majority stake in Terratech Group, resulting in Tritech holding about 4.37% of the company. Terratech has also changed its top management, with Siow Chien Fu as CEO and Kenny Zhang Da as CFO. Tan Eng Kiat Dominic, 73, has been appointed non-executive chairman and independent director.

site_title: Oil tumbles amid oversupply fears, unlikelihood of deeper Opec cuts
summary: Oil prices plummeted to five-month lows, falling below $50 a barrel, amid concerns of oversupply and the unlikelihood of deeper Opec cuts. Opec delegates downplayed the possibility of further output reductions, stating current cuts would be extended. This move erased market gains following a 2016 output cut announcement. The slide was attributed to record trading volume in Brent crude, which worsened fears of a persistent global crude glut.

images.alt_text: Oil prices plunged to five-month lows on Thursday amid record trading volume in Brent crude, as Opec and other producers appeared to rule out deeper supply cuts to reduce the world's persistent glut of crude.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.1% higher on Friday
summary: Singapore stocks opened 0.1% higher on Friday, with the Straits Times Index rising 4.17 points to 3,232.79, as fears over the French presidential election outcome lessened. About 83.8 million shares were traded, with SingTel and Blumont being the most actively traded counters. Despite this, losers outnumbered gainers 78 to 60, indicating a mixed market.

site_title: Spain probes ex-HSBC executives over money laundering
summary: A Spanish court is investigating seven former HSBC executives on suspicion of money laundering related to the "Swissleaks" scandal, which involved tax evasion and unreported accounts. The investigation, based on the "Falciani list," accuses HSBC of collaborating with Santander and BNP Paribas to transfer funds to conceal them from the Spanish treasury. The executives, including former chairman Peter Widmer and CEOs Christopher Meares and Clive Bannister, face charges of "persistent money laundering and criminal association." The investigation is part of a larger scandal that has triggered proceedings in multiple countries.

site_title: Warren Buffett says he sold a third of stake in IBM: CNBC
summary: Warren Buffett sold about one-third of Berkshire Hathaway's stake in IBM, reducing his bet on the company. Buffett initially bought 81 million shares in 2011, but now owns around 50 million shares. He cited a decrease in his valuation of IBM due to increased competition and weak demand in its IT services business. Buffett has stopped selling and considers IBM a "big strong company," but notes it faces strong competitors.

site_title: US jury convicts ex-Guinea minister over China bribes
summary: A former Guinean cabinet minister, Mahmoud Thiam, was convicted in New York of money laundering over a scheme to launder $8.5 million in bribes from a Chinese conglomerate in exchange for mining rights. Thiam, 50, faces a maximum sentence of 20 years for the conviction on one count of money laundering and 10 years for transacting in criminally derived property. He is scheduled to be sentenced on August 11. Thiam was accused of using bribes to fund his lavish lifestyle, including buying a multi-million dollar estate in New York state.

site_title: Euro near 6-month high ahead of French election
summary: The euro traded near a six-month high against the US dollar on Friday, supported by expectations of centrist Emmanuel Macron's win in France's presidential election. Macron consolidated his position in a TV debate, leading to a rise in the euro to US$1.0979. This is the highest level since early November, as investors anticipate Macron's centrist policies. The euro eased 0.1% to US$1.0979, holding near Thursday's high.

site_title: At one with nature
summary: The Fondation d'entreprise Hermes presents "Oneness" by Kim Minjung, a series of contemporary ink paintings on Korean mulberry hanji paper, at its five international art spaces. The works, featuring undulating washes of color, evoke a sense of unity with nature and explore the balance between freedom and control. Inspired by the artist's childhood memories and experiences, the exhibition reflects the union between artist and material, highlighting the unique qualities of hanji paper and its ability to absorb pigment.

site_title: Asian markets closed for holiday
summary: Asian markets closed on Friday for public holidays in Japan, South Korea, and Thailand. In contrast, Singapore stocks rallied for a 5-day streak ahead of GDP data, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday. Meanwhile, US stocks edged to fresh records despite ongoing US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty. eSIM platform Airalo raised $220 million in funding, lifting its valuation past $1 billion, and a Singapore company, PSC, received a mandatory offer from Popiah king Sam Goi at S$0.40 a share.

site_title: US Congress passes spending bill averting govt shutdown
summary: The US Congress passed a spending bill, averting a government shutdown, with a 79-18 vote in the Senate and broad bipartisan support. The $1.16 trillion bill keeps the government funded through September and ignores President Trump's promise to build a border wall. The bill now heads to the White House for Trump's signature ahead of a Friday night deadline.

site_title: FLT's Q2 DPU slightly above projection at 1.75 Singapore cents (Amended)
summary: Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust (FLT) reported a Q2 DPU of 1.75 Singapore cents, exceeding projections of 1.64 Aussie cents. The distributable income was 5.9% above forecast at A$25.1 million, with gross revenue and net property income also surpassing projections. FLT's results were driven by a 1.6% increase in gross revenue and a 2.4% increase in net property income. The trust's DPU exceeded expectations, providing a positive update for investors.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SingPost, OUE H-Trust, Chip Eng Seng, NeraTel
summary: The Singapore Exchange issued a public reprimand to SingPost for breaching listing rules in 2014. Meanwhile, OUE Hospitality Trust reported a 19.1% increase in distributable income to S$23.5 million for Q1 2017, while Chip Eng Seng saw a 647.9% increase in net profit to S$6.1 million. Nera Telecommunications reported a 40.8% rise in net profit to S$2.86 million. These earnings reports come ahead of GDP data and amid ongoing market volatility.

site_title: Ascott to open first Citadines in US in 2018
summary: Ascott Limited, a serviced residence arm of CapitaLand, plans to invest around US$50 million in a property on New York's Fifth Avenue. The 125-unit Hotel Central Fifth Avenue New York will be renovated and rebranded as Citadines Fifth Avenue New York in 2018, marking Ascott's debut of the Citadines brand in the US.

site_title: Family says booted off Delta flight over child's seat they paid for
summary: A California couple, the Schears, were kicked off a Delta flight after refusing to give up their 2-year-old son's seat, which they had paid for. The family was on an overbooked flight from Hawaii to Los Angeles. After a confrontation with a flight attendant, the couple was removed from the flight and had to scramble to find a hotel room. Delta apologized and offered refunds and compensation. The incident has sparked outrage and could be a public relations nightmare for the airline industry.

site_title: Hot stock: Capital World slips on post-RTO Catalist debut
summary: Capital World, a Malaysian property developer, made its debut on Singapore Exchange's Catalist board with shares opening at S$0.198 apiece. The company has a market value of over S$250 million and is developing a shopping mall in Johor Baru. Its shares dropped 5.1% to S$0.186 after trading 7.4 million shares.

site_title: J&J ordered to pay US$110m in US talc-powder trial
summary: A Missouri jury ordered Johnson & Johnson to pay $110 million to a Virginia woman who claims she developed ovarian cancer after decades of using the company's talc-based products. The verdict, the largest so far in a US lawsuit, awards $5.4 million in compensatory damages and $105 million in punitive damages. The jury found J&J 99% at fault and Imerys Talc 1% at fault. J&J plans to appeal the verdict, which comes after the company secured its first trial win in the Missouri litigation in March.

site_title: Europe: Stocks climb after French presidential debate
summary: European stock markets rose on Thursday following a strong performance by French presidential frontrunner Emmanuel Macron in a debate ahead of Sunday's run-off vote. The Paris CAC 40 index climbed 1.4% and Frankfurt's DAX 30 reached a new record close, while the US market finished little changed. The euro strengthened above US$1.09, and shares in HSBC and Adidas rose. However, the FTSE 100 index was penalized by a drop in oil and metals prices. Analysts attributed the European market's performance to Macron's perceived victory in the debate, which was seen as a call for openness and pro-market reforms.

site_title: Demand for gold plunges after Trump win: data
summary: Global gold demand fell 18% in the first quarter of 2017 due to US investors abandoning the precious metal after Donald Trump's election win. This decline was largely attributed to a decrease in demand from professional investors, particularly in the US, who focused on Exchange Traded Funds (ETFs) in 2016. The World Gold Council attributed the weak quarter to a shift in investor sentiment following Trump's election.

site_title: BlackRock warns against ignoring Home Capital's woes
summary: BlackRock warns that Home Capital Group Inc.'s prolonged troubles could lead to a disorderly fallout, potentially hurting credit markets and the Canadian economy. The alternative mortgage lender has faced a run on deposits since allegations of misleading investors. BlackRock's head of local fixed income, Aubrey Basdeo, notes that while the issue appears to be a liquidity problem, it could morph into a credit issue. This raises concerns about the Canadian economy, particularly given the country's reliance on real estate, and the potential for a systemic issue.

site_title: Foreign funds seen heading for exit in wake of scrapped deal
summary: Malaysia's equities market may see a reversal of foreign funds after the surprise cancellation of a major real estate deal with a Malaysian-Sino consortium. The Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange closed 0.78% lower, with analysts attributing the move to a market correction and concerns about political uncertainties. The cancellation has raised questions about the reliability of government deals and may halt or reverse foreign equity inflows into Malaysia. This could lead to a period of risk-off, marked by profit-taking on concept stocks, and may also impact China's participation in Malaysia's proposed East Coast Rail Line and high-speed rail projects.

site_title: Two former executives of Brazil's Petrobras arrested
summary: Two former Petrobras executives, Marcio de Almeida Ferreira and Mauricio de Oliveira Guedes, were arrested in Brazil's "Operation Car Wash" corruption investigation. They are accused of taking 100 million reais (S$43.4 million) in bribes from construction companies linked to the scandal. The arrests follow evidence from telephone taps, bank records, and statements from cooperating executives, including a third suspect who reached a plea deal. The investigation, which started in 2016, has already uncovered a vast web of politicians and executives involved in embezzlement and bribery, with losses estimated at US$2 billion.

site_title: Investment, infrastructure, digital economy to drive Asean prospects: EY
summary: A new report by EY projects high investment interest in Asean over the next five years, with 87% of US companies expected to increase trade and investment in the region. Infrastructure spending is also expected to rise, reaching $110 billion annually by 2025. The report also notes that China's business focus in Asean is projected to reach $1 trillion in trade and $150 billion in investments by 2020. The Asean+3 Macroeconomic Research Office (Amro) also projects the region's growth to 5.2% this year and 5.1% next year, driven primarily by domestic demand.

site_title: Japan, China, South Korea pledge to resist protectionism
summary: Finance leaders of Japan, China, and South Korea agreed to resist all forms of protectionism in a trilateral meeting, taking a stronger stance against protectionist policies advocated by US President Donald Trump. The three nations emphasized the importance of free trade in driving economic growth and development. China, in particular, has positioned itself as a supporter of free trade following Trump's calls to prioritize America's interests and withdraw from multilateral trade agreements. The agreement was made in a communique issued after the meeting, with a line removed due to pressure from Washington.

site_title: Former execs dispute Yuuzoo's breach of contract claims
summary: Former Yuuzoo Corp executives Fred Lim and Thai Youn Fatt are disputing the company's claims that they left due to "breach of employment contract". They stated they resigned, but declined to elaborate on the reasons. The two former financial executives made the statement to The Business Times, contradicting Yuuzoo Corp's announcement of their departure.

site_title: Fed remains cautious over Trump Bump
summary: The US Federal Reserve remains cautious about the "Trump Bump" in the stock market, despite a 14.22% rise in the Dow Jones Industrial Average since President Trump's inauguration. Policymakers are concerned about the sustainability of the economic growth fueled by tax cuts and infrastructure spending, as well as the uncertainty surrounding President Trump's ability to advance his fiscal policies. The Fed voted not to raise interest rates, citing concerns about the pace of economic growth, and policymakers are watching the situation closely, with some warning that the expectations about the economic outlook may have been raised too high.

site_title: Air France-KLM says demand from Asia, S America recovering
summary: Air France-KLM reported a resilient start to the year with demand recovering from Asia and south America, but warned of risks from a geopolitical backdrop and fluctuating fuel prices. Unit revenues fell 0.5% in the first quarter, in line with expectations. The carrier sold more seats on long-haul routes than last year, and confirmed financial targets for 2017. Despite an operating loss of 143 million euros, the company stuck to a target for a 1.5% reduction in unit costs this year.

site_title: Big Pharma losing price leverage amid squeeze by payers
summary: Big pharmaceutical companies are facing increased pressure to pump up sales volumes and find lucrative new treatments due to the consolidation of payers and pharmacy benefit managers. The rise of a handful of powerful players has led to better negotiating power against pharmaceutical firms on price, resulting in higher rebates to insurers and pharmacy benefit companies. This shift comes after years of outcry over rising drug prices, with some drugmakers reporting slowdowns in sales due to price pressures. To maintain leverage, less-competitive disease areas could become more attractive for drugmakers, potentially including cancer or rare diseases.

site_title: US: Stocks end flat; oil shares tumble
summary: US stocks ended flat on Thursday, despite President Donald Trump's health care reform bill passing the House of Representatives. Oil producers and services companies fell as US oil prices dropped nearly 5% to $45.72 a barrel, the lowest closing price of 2017. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 added 0.1%, while the Nasdaq Composite Index also rose 0.1%. However, the passage of the health care bill had little effect on stocks due to its long road to passage in the Senate.

site_title: Singapore maps out goals for its Asean chairmanship
summary: Singapore has outlined its goals for its one-year Asean chairmanship, focusing on tangible results in growing the digital economy and exports, as well as harmonizing e-commerce trade rules. The country aims to facilitate trade and implement specific measures to boost exports. These objectives are expected to be achieved through collaborative efforts with Asean member states.

site_title: US House votes to expand North Korea sanctions
summary: The US House of Representatives voted 419-1 to expand sanctions against North Korea, including efforts to cut international financing and restrict vessels from operating in US waters. The bill, which now heads to the Senate, prohibits imports of North Korean coal, iron, and iron ore beyond UN-imposed limits and targets those involved in forced labor. The measure aims to increase pressure on the Kim regime and achieve lasting stability and peace.

images.alt_text: "Real threats demand real responses," House Foreign Affairs Committee chairman Ed Royce said.

site_title: Thrash metal veterans keep it real after 3 decades
summary: Megadeth, a thrash metal veteran band, performed a 90-minute concert at Kallang Theatre in Singapore, marking their third and most intimate gig in the city. The band, led by frontman Dave Mustaine, delivered a high-energy show with 17 songs from their 30-year career, including their 1986 debut Peace Sells... But Who's Buying and last year's Grammy-winning Dystopia. Mustaine's technical guitar skills and energetic stage presence remained unchanged, despite his 55 years. The concert was a testament to the band's commitment to keeping their music authentic and true to their roots.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: OUE H-Trust Q1 distributable income rises 19.1%
summary: OUE Hospitality Trust's distributable income rose 19.1% to S$23.5 million in Q1 2017, driven by a 6.4% increase in revenue to S$32.1 million. The stapled group's distributable income and revenue have shown significant growth from the same period in 2016.

site_title: Strategic review news lifts Sembcorp, Sembmarine stocks
summary: Sembcorp Industries' strategic review has lifted shares of Sembcorp Industries and Sembmarine, with Sembmarine surging 9.1% and Sembcorp Industries rising 5%. Analysts see the review as a potential catalyst for unlocking shareholder value, with some expecting the company to rationalize its utilities operations and reduce its stake in Sembmarine. However, others have downgraded the stocks, citing unexciting earnings and headwinds in the utilities and marine segments.

site_title: Fitbit sales fall 41%, but beat low projections amid fierce competition
summary: Fitbit Inc reported a 41% drop in sales to $298.9 million in the quarter ended March 31, beating low projections. Despite a loss of 15 cents a share, the company's shares gained 9.3% in extended trading. CEO James Park aims to transform Fitbit into a digital-health company, increasing its corporate program and partnering with UnitedHealthcare. Fitbit faces intense competition from lower-cost makers and smartwatches from Apple and Samsung, and its long-term growth depends on diversifying into new product categories and software offerings.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Genting Singapore's Q1 FY17 results are expected on May 12. Analysts predict a regain of mass market share in Q2, lifting earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortisation (Ebitda) by 14-16% to S$250 million. Hongkong Land Holdings is expected to see a potential revaluation of office assets, with a tender for a car park building site set to close on May 12. BreadTalk Group reported strong Q1 FY17 results, with a positive profit after tax and minority interests. Analysts maintain "buy" recommendations for all three companies, citing potential catalysts and undervaluation.

site_title: MOF mulls greater powers for property tax investigation
summary: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) is proposing amendments to the Property Tax Act to give the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) greater powers for property tax investigation. The proposed changes include allowing IRAS to access properties, documents, computers, and software, as well as enhance penalties for non-compliance. The amendments aim to strengthen enforcement and information gathering powers, but experts question the need for such harsh measures, citing existing provisions in the Act that allow for information gathering. The public consultation on the draft Property Tax (Amendment) Bill 2017 runs from May 4 to 19, 2017.

site_title: Prescription medicine spending in US may hit US$610b by 2021: report
summary: US prescription medicine spending is projected to reach $580 billion to $610 billion by 2021, with a 4-7% growth rate, according to a QuintilesIMS Holding report. This is lower than the previously forecasted 6-9% growth rate due to fewer new medicines approved in 2016 and increasing pricing pressure. Discounts and rebates will offset some of the expense, with spending growing 2-5% to $375 billion to $405 billion in 2021.

site_title: Tesla assures investors Model 3 is on track as cash burn continues
summary: Tesla assures investors that its highly anticipated Model 3 sedan is on track to begin production in July, despite concerns about its cash burn. The company reported a loss of $1.33 per share in its first-quarter earnings results. The Model 3's arrival is crucial to supporting Tesla's high share price, and its production timeline remains unchanged.

site_title: Seizing the 'radical centre' of politics
summary: Emmanuel Macron's presidential win in France has sparked debate over his political positioning, with some labeling him liberal, moderate, or centrist. However, sociologist Anthony Giddens argues that successful centrist movements are "radical" and have distinct ideas. Macron's centrist stance is ideologically intense and not simply a midpoint between right and left, challenging the conventional understanding of the term. This distinction highlights the complexity of Macron's political ideology and its potential to redefine the concept of centrism.

site_title: Sabana Reit manager faces Syariah constraints
summary: Sabana Reit manager faces criticism over its Syariah-compliant structure, which charges multi-level fees and relies heavily on Islamic-style banking facilities with near-term maturities. The manager's fee structure, within industry norms, has raised questions about the need for further incentives and potential asset churn. The Reit's restricted funding base and maturity profile also pose liquidity concerns. Some experts suggest that taking the manager in-house, like Croesus Retail Trust, could be a solution to these issues, but the article does not provide a clear conclusion on this matter.

site_title: Shell's profit surges as oil sector rebounds
summary: Royal Dutch Shell's net profit more than doubled in the first quarter, surpassing analyst forecasts due to rebounding oil prices and refining margins. The company's shares rose 2.6% at the market open. A 55% increase in oil prices and cost cuts boosted cash generation, enabling Shell to cover spending and dividend payouts while reducing debt following its $54 billion acquisition of BG Group last year.

site_title: Newcomers change face of Republican bastions
summary: Suburban communities in northern Atlanta, once considered Republican strongholds, are experiencing an identity shift as they become more diverse. Johns Creek, a city of 83,000, now has 24% of its population of Asian heritage, and Indian-Americans, Chinese-Americans, and others are integrating into the community. The success of a Democrat in a special election and declining Republican sentiment in the area have contributed to this change. Despite this, Republicans remain confident that conservative culture will prevail in the district, and some believe the suburbs will adapt to the changing demographics.

site_title: Championing the green cause
summary: In Singapore, various initiatives are promoting environmental sustainability. The Income Eco Run, a 21.1 km half-marathon, encouraged participants to reduce waste by not receiving medals and finisher's entitlements. The event saved 87.8kg of fabric and 150kg of metal. Urban farming is also gaining traction, with Darren Ho starting Citizen Farm, which cultivates microgreens, vegetables, and mushrooms. The farm aims to become self-sufficient and export food waste to produce nutrients. Meanwhile, architecture firm Woha's rooftop farm produces edible plants, including herbs, vegetables, and fruits, using rainwater and solar power. Additionally, Chiam Yiak Joo, a 54-year-old former IT professional, is now a volunteer farmer at Onesimus Garden, promoting chemical-free farming and teaching others how to grow their own food.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: UK's April car sales tumble 20% after record demand in March
summary: UK car sales plummeted 20% in April, the largest year-on-year drop in six years, after record demand in March driven by customers seeking to avoid a tax increase. Registrations fell to 152,076 vehicles, with diesel sales dropping 27% due to government plans to tackle air pollution. Despite forecasts of a 5% decline, the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders expects demand to stabilize as the tax changes decrease.

site_title: M1's month of contemporary dance kicks off
summary: M1's eighth edition of the M1 Contact Contemporary Dance Festival is underway, featuring 27 dance works from 15 nationalities and 7 new works. The festival aims to grow dance appreciation in the public through its "Dance at Dusk" platform, offering free performances at the Esplanade Outdoor Theatre. Festival director Kuik Swee Boon emphasizes the importance of inclusivity, seeking to showcase a wide range of voices and perspectives.

site_title: EU plans to ease derivatives rules in bid to boost economy
summary: The European Union plans to ease derivatives rules to boost the economy, saving pension funds billions of euros. The new rules, introduced in 2012, aimed to curb the sector's role in the 2007-09 financial crisis. Policymakers now seek to reduce red tape for companies and investors, except for big banks.

site_title: Adidas outpaces Nike in North America and China
summary: Adidas reported a 30% increase in quarterly net profit to 455 million euros, outpacing rival Nike in North America and China. The German sportswear firm's sales rose 19% to 5.67 billion euros, beating analyst forecasts, and its shares hit a record high. Adidas attributed the strong quarter to a shift in marketing spending and growth in e-commerce, with revenues up 53%. The company confirmed its 2017 forecast for sales growth of 11-13% and attributed a slowdown in earnings momentum in the coming quarters to a one-off gain in 2016.

site_title: UOB doubles business flows into Asean at S$27b
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has doubled its foreign direct investment (FDI) advisory unit's business flows into Asean, reaching S$27 billion in 2016. The majority of funds came from the Greater China region (60%), followed by South-east Asia (20%), Europe, Japan, and elsewhere (20%). Funds from South-east Asia tripled in 2016, while those from Europe doubled. Companies from fast-moving consumer goods, natural resources, and building sectors are expanding into the region, attracted by Asean's diversity and growth potential.

site_title: French election's international impact could be key
summary: French presidential candidate Emmanuel Macron is expected to win the election, defeating far-right nationalist Marine Le Pen. Macron's liberal centrist vision and pro-European Union stance are seen as a counterbalance to the populist trend that has swept other European countries. A Macron victory would be a significant boost to liberal politics globally, and could offer lessons to other centrist politicians seeking to win power. Macron's success highlights the potential for the centre ground to resist conservative, anti-establishment forces and underscores the need for long-term, concerted efforts to address economic and social challenges.

site_title: BT Weekend explores the future
summary: Singapore has over 1,100 centenarians, with the number increasing annually. The Business Times' Weekend magazine explores the future, featuring articles on the automotive industry, exotic honey, flying taxis, driverless cars, a robotic floorbot, and high-end sound systems. The paper also covers various lifestyle topics, including mod-Indian cuisine, volunteer engagement, zero-waste initiatives, and financial literacy for women.

site_title: Coordination crucial for infrastructure investment to work
summary: World governments must demonstrate more joined-up thinking and action to effectively utilize infrastructure spending for regeneration and growth. A global coalition of public authorities is needed to stretch taxpayers' money further in boosting beneficial investment in various infrastructure ventures. The international community, including the World Bank and IFC, must turn aspiration into reality to address the pressing need for coordination on infrastructure investment, which faces a significant market imbalance and could lead to lower returns for governments and taxpayers.

site_title: Wanted: Gazelle startups, not zombies
summary: Singapore's tech startup ecosystem has become more dynamic, but still lags behind innovation hubs like Silicon Valley and Shenzhen. A NUS Enterprise study found that young startups (under 3 years old) have increased participation in government schemes and venture capital funding, and are more innovative, with nearly 50% reporting ownership of intellectual property. However, the study also identified a lack of deep-tech, globally-oriented startups and insufficient commercialization of technologies. To compete, Singapore needs to foster "gazelles" (fast-growing, profitable startups) and weed out "zombies" (non-viable firms) and "non-viable firms" (those that generate little growth and employment).

site_title: Gold imports by India climb to highest in more than two years
summary: India's gold imports surged to 270.1 tonnes in the first quarter, the highest level since 2014, driven by jewellers restocking for weddings and improving cash flow. Domestic demand rose 15% to 123.5 tonnes, with forecasts suggesting purchases may reach 650-750 tonnes for 2017. The rupee's appreciation shielded Indians from price increases, but the upcoming goods and services tax could impact the bullion trade.

site_title: ITM programme needs to improve measurability and accountability
summary: Singapore's Industry Transformation Maps (ITMs) need improvement in measurability and accountability. The ITMs, designed to customize strategies for each industry, have been created for 23 sectors accounting for 80% of the country's GDP. However, concerns arise about the effectiveness of a top-down approach to economic restructuring. The ITMs aim to address changes in demographics, markets, and technology, which may impact industry sectors differently.

site_title: Mesmerising minimalism
summary: A lone man is shipwrecked on a remote island inhabited by crabs, repeatedly attempts to escape on a bamboo raft, but is thwarted by a mysterious force and a giant red turtle. Eventually, the castaway meets his nemesis, but instead of leaving, he starts a family with a crab. The article lacks concrete details about the family or the island's inhabitants, leaving the narrative open to interpretation.

site_title: Improved market may have played a part in scuppering of deal
summary: The Malaysian government has canceled a deal to sell a 60% stake in the Bandar Malaysia project to a consortium led by China's state-owned China Railway Engineering Corp, citing repeated delays in submitting a bank guarantee and the consortium's failure to meet payment obligations. The deal, valued at RM5.3 billion, was part of 1Malaysia Development Berhad's debt workout plan, but the government now believes it is better off handling the project itself due to improved market conditions and increased value of the project since its signing in 2015.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Hi-P turns around with S$8.4m Q1 profit despite revenue fall
summary: Hi-P International, a Singapore-based consumer electronics manufacturer, reported a net profit of S$8.4 million for the first quarter of 2017, reversing a net loss of S$12.4 million a year ago. Revenue fell 11.4% to S$244.2 million due to fewer high component content assembly products. The company attributed its improved net profit to a better product mix, operational efficiency, and cost management. Other expenses decreased by 54.8%, and net debt improved. The group's inventories decreased 10.5% as a result of improved inventory management.

site_title: UK economy rebounds with unexpected services strength
summary: The UK economy rebounded in April with a stronger-than-expected services sector, with IHS Markit's index rising to 55.8 from 55 in March. Manufacturing and construction gauges also improved, suggesting a 0.6% pace of economic growth. New business grew at the fastest pace this year, and employment rose modestly, despite concerns over Brexit-related uncertainty and inflation. Household borrowing rose £4.7 billion, and companies are passing on higher costs to customers, with prices signalling the sharpest inflation since 2008.

site_title: Apple announces US$1 billion fund to create US jobs in manufacturing
summary: Apple announces a $1 billion fund to invest in advanced manufacturing in the US, aiming to create jobs in the industry. The fund will focus on high-value-added products such as technology, aerospace, and medical equipment. CEO Timothy Cook stated that the fund can create ripple effects, leading to additional jobs in the service industry. This move comes after US President Donald Trump called for companies like Apple to bring manufacturing jobs back to the US.

site_title: Tuaspring's S$27m loss takes heavy toll on Hyflux Q1 earnings
summary: Hyflux reported a 89% plunge in Q1 earnings to S$0.8 million, largely due to a S$27 million loss from its "held for sale" Tuaspring plant. Excluding Tuaspring, the net profit would have been S$27.8 million, an 8% increase. Revenue dropped 59% to S$91.5 million due to lower construction activities. Hyflux has appointed financial advisers to evaluate a partial divestment of up to 70% of Tuaspring, which has attracted buying interest.

site_title: Public housing shouldn't be too comfy for poor
summary: US Housing Secretary Ben Carson believes that public housing should not provide too many comforts for low-income Americans, as it can create a sense of dependency. During a tour of facilities in Ohio, Carson joked about the amenities and services provided, stating that he wants to incentivize people to "help themselves." He plans to focus on persuading developers to hire local low-income residents for construction programs and has indicated that some HUD programs targeted for elimination may be rebranded but still function similarly. Carson's views on poverty alleviation are influenced by his childhood in Detroit and his own bootstraps journey.

site_title: 1983 vintage: a question of provenance
summary: A 2017 article reviews the 1983 vintage of Bordeaux wine, finding that 34-year-old bottles show signs of early decline. A tasting of top wines, including Mouton Rothschild, Lafite Rothschild, and Latour, revealed fading flavors and declining quality. The article concludes that the provenance of the wine, including its history and storage conditions, significantly impacts its quality and drinkability. It advises against purchasing 1983 Bordeaux without verifying its provenance, especially for those building a wine collection. The article also touches on the implications for buying wine today and the challenges of verifying provenance, particularly in online and auction markets.

images.alt_text: 1983 Bordeaux is reaching the end of its drinkable life - so those with 1983s still sitting in our cellars should not wait too much longer.

site_title: Kraft Heinz faces pressure to do a deal as sales stagnate
summary: Kraft Heinz Co reported a 4th consecutive quarter of declining sales, with first-quarter revenue falling to $6.36 billion, missing analyst projections. The company's earnings also fell short of estimates, despite cost-cutting efforts. Investors are concerned that Kraft Heinz lacks the talent to expand sales in a sluggish packaged-food industry, leading some to speculate that the company may need to do another deal to grow. The company's shares dropped 4.3% in extended trading after the report was released.

site_title: DBS pullback leaves STI weaker
summary: DBS cut 8.7 points off the Straits Times Index after its stock fell S$0.38 to S$20.45, trading ex-dividend. OCBC dipped two cents, while UOB ended firmer after an intraday low. Despite this, DBS's earnings estimates were raised by OCBC Investment Research, citing an improving business outlook. Analysts also expect the Fed to hike interest rates despite recent weak data, with Bank of America Merrill Lynch stating there's no need to worry about the Fed's actions.

images.alt_text: DBS on Tuesday announced the launch of DBS Electricity Marketplace to allow select households in Jurong to switch seamlessly between energy retailers.

site_title: Forgettable medical melodrama
summary: Biographical drama "BRAIN on Fire" tells the story of American journalist Susannah Cahalan's mysterious illness at 24, which left her with memory lapses, hallucinations, and violent mood swings. Despite doctors' inability to find a cause, Cahalan eventually recovers after being diagnosed with a rare autoimmune deficiency. The film, directed by Gerard Barrett, received mixed reviews, with criticism of its emotionally uninvolving and poorly executed performances, except for a few standout characters. The movie's valuable message about the importance of patience in medical diagnosis is overshadowed by its overall forgettable nature.

site_title: Factory goods orders up for fourth straight month in March
summary: US factory goods orders rose 0.2% in March, marking a fourth consecutive month of growth, and capital equipment orders also increased, pointing to a sustained recovery in the manufacturing sector. The manufacturing sector, which accounts for 12% of the US economy, is recovering due to rising oil prices reinvigorating the energy sector. The trade deficit narrowed in March, despite record imports from Mexico and a drop in total exports.

site_title: US Fed: Weak growth temporary; gradual rate hikes on the cards
summary: The US Federal Reserve held interest rates steady, but downplayed recent weak economic growth, indicating a continuation of gradual rate hikes. The Fed views the slowdown as temporary, citing a strong labor market and solid hiring. The central bank emphasized the need for moderate economic growth and signaled the move towards policy normalization, with two more rate increases likely this year, possibly at the June and September meetings.

site_title: Sheng Siong needs to shop for new stores to fuel growth
summary: Sheng Siong Group is likely to expand with new stores, driven by a rational market for commercial sites. After aggressive bidding by smaller supermarket operators in Q4 2016, prices have stabilized, making it more sustainable for smaller players to rent sites. Industry analysts expect Sheng Siong to capitalize on this trend in the second half of 2017, positioning itself for growth in a competitive market.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Dairy Farm to implement Unified POS terminals
summary: The Dairy Farm Singapore Group will install 2,000 unified Point of Sale (POS) terminals across 650 stores in 2017, partnering with NETS and UOB. The terminals will be located at Cold Storage, Market Place, Jasons, Giant, 7-Eleven, and Guardian Health and Beauty stores, marking one of the largest unified POS installations in Singapore.

site_title: Arts training for more young Singaporeans
summary: The Business Times Budding Artists Fund (BT BAF) is celebrating its 12th anniversary by opening two new arts training centres in Yishun, supported by The RICE Company Ltd. The new centres, Little Arts Academy North Campus 1 and North Campus 2, will provide facilities for dance, theatre, music, and visual arts, increasing the annual intake by 300 and reaching more families in the North and North East. The fund has already supported over 15,000 children and youth since its inception in 2005.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Programmes to take local management consultants overseas start to yield fruit
summary: The Institute of Management Consultants (Singapore) has certified 112 registered management consultants in 5 months under Spring Singapore's recognition programs. The certification enables local consultants to tap into grants to enhance small and medium enterprises' capabilities. IMCS' certification is internationally recognized, allowing consultants to join the International Council of Management Consultants Institutes (ICMCI) and expand their professional network to countries like the US, Canada, Britain, and China.

site_title: Singaporeans should believe that foreign workers bring opportunities
summary: Singapore's employment figures are expected to worsen due to a skills mismatch and restructuring in various sectors. The country's labour policies, which require employers to fulfill foreign worker quotas, may have contributed to this issue. Rising unemployment could lead to social issues, decreased labour productivity, and economic growth. To address this, the government should increase labour market flexibility by allowing more foreign workers and promoting programmes that build understanding and interdependence between Singaporeans and foreigners. Proactive efforts by employers and employees to upgrade skills will also be crucial in improving productivity and competitiveness.

site_title: Iron ore keeps sinking as port stockpiles remain at high levels
summary: Iron ore prices plummeted, sinking into a bear market, amid concerns about oversupply and demand in China, the world's top user. Port stockpiles in China remain near a record high, and steel production in the country fell in April, signaling a return to contraction. Analysts predict further declines in iron ore prices, with some miners' shares sinking. Despite this, Rio Tinto CEO Jean-Sebastien Jacques remains optimistic about the outlook for 2018, citing positive indications for the industry.

site_title: Peek into Korea's Joseon dynasty
summary: The Joseon dynasty, which ruled Korea from 1392 to 1897, had a profound impact on modern Korean culture. The 505-year dynasty shaped Korea's aesthetics, including the Hanguel script, and its legacy can be seen in period dramas and contemporary art. The Asian Civilisations Museum's latest exhibition, "Joseon Korea: Court Treasures and City Life," showcases royal patronage, court culture, and everyday life, featuring 150 artefacts from the National Museum of Korea and National Palace Museum of Korea. The exhibition highlights the dynasty's influence on Korean identity and culture.

site_title: US:Wall St edges up at open
summary: Wall Street opened slightly higher on Thursday, led by banks, after the Federal Reserve expressed confidence in the economy's strength. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.12% to 20,983.39, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite gained 0.13% and 0.11% respectively. Gains were limited by a fall in technology and energy stocks, despite a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a fresh record for the S&P 500 and Nasdaq.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index ended lower on Thursday, closing at 1,758.67 after 3.45 billion lots were traded, with 824 losers and 185 gainers.

site_title: Euro jumps on Macron's showing in TV debate
summary: The euro surged to a 6-month high against the US dollar at US$1.0950 after French centrist Emmanuel Macron's solid performance in a TV presidential debate, boosting investor confidence. The dollar's value against the euro dropped 0.4% as investors reconsidered bets on US rate hikes. The euro's gain was partly due to buying of French stocks and bonds, while the dollar remained strong against the yen. The broader dollar index traded less than 0.1% after reaching a two-week high.

images.alt_text: The euro surged towards 6-month highs around US$1.0950 on Thursday as support for the US dollar from Wednesday's Federal Reserve statement faded and investors took heart from French centrist Emmanuel Macron's performance in a TV presidential debate.

site_title: US trade deficit edges lower in March
summary: The US trade deficit decreased 0.1% in March to $43.7 billion, contrary to analyst expectations of a 1.4% increase. This decline was attributed to lower exports and rising oil import prices, which reached a near two-year record. The Commerce Department's report highlights the trade deficit's ongoing focus for the Trump administration's nationalist economic agenda.

site_title: German bourse eyes Asian markets via Spore's CLTX
summary: German bourse European Energy Exchange (EEX) expects Cleartrade Exchange (CLTX) to grow its market size to US$200 million by 2020, aiming to capture a larger share of iron ore, shipping, and fuel oil trading. CLTX, now fully owned by EEX, is part of Deutsche Boerse, Germany's largest stock exchange, as it seeks to expand globally through acquisitions.

site_title: Foreland Fabrictech Holdings to buy food processing business for S$2.3m
summary: Foreland Fabrictech Holdings has agreed to acquire Liancheng Lianxiangyuan, a Chinese food processing business, for S$2.3 million. The acquisition is expected to provide the group with strategic exposure and entry into the food processing business. Liancheng Lianxiangyuan reported net profits of 5.9 million yuan and 7.2 million yuan for FY2015 and FY2016, respectively, making it an attractive investment for Foreland Fabrictech. The purchase amount will be paid within three months after the completion of the acquisition.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng's Q1 profit surges
summary: Chip Eng Seng Corporation reported a 647.9% increase in its net profit for Q1 2017, reaching S$6.1 million, up from S$817,000 the previous year. The surge was largely due to a gain on disposal of a quoted investment security, which increased "other income" to S$7.7 million from S$2.4 million.

site_title: POSH posts US$18.38m Q1 loss
summary: POSH, an offshore support vessel owner-operator, posted a Q1 net loss of US$18.38 million, reversing from a net profit of US$4.45 million in the same period last year. Revenue declined 42% to US$34.32 million, and the company had US$11.83 million in cash and US$348.48 million in current liabilities.

site_title: HDB resale volumes, prices ease in April: SRX
summary: HDB resale prices and volumes eased in April, with a 0.3% drop in prices and a 4% decline in resale units compared to March 2017. The price index has shed 0.3% year on year and 11.4% since 2013. Experts expect HDB resale prices to fluctuate within a narrow band this year, with prices influenced by factors such as loan curbs, Build-to-Order flats, and an uncertain economic climate. Resale volumes are expected to grow around 2-5% in 2017.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Influx of young creative people makes Nashville hip again
summary: Nashville, Tennessee, has transformed into a vibrant city, attracting young creatives with its affordable real estate and thriving arts scene. Artists and entrepreneurs, like Vadis Turner and her husband Clay Ezell, have moved back to the city, revitalizing historic buildings and neighborhoods. The influx of new residents has led to an influx of independent restaurants, stores, and trendy projects, giving Nashville a fresh, hip vibe. The city's boomtown status is evident, with cranes and construction dominating the skyline, as Nashville redefines itself as a hub for creative talent.

site_title: SocGen to pay $1 billion euros to end Libyan wealth fund row
summary: Societe Generale agreed to pay nearly 1 billion euros to settle a long-running dispute with the Libyan Investment Authority, which alleged trades were secured as part of a "fraudulent and corrupt scheme." The bank avoided a costly court case, with CEO Frederic Oudea stating that "appropriate measures" would be taken against employees involved. The settlement overshadowed SocGen's 19% fall in first-quarter net income, but analysts remain cautious, noting the bank's ongoing legal woes, including talks with US authorities over dollar transfers.

site_title: E-mail attack hits Google: What to do if you clicked
summary: Google reported an email scam where malicious emails appeared to come from known contacts, prompting recipients to grant access to their Google contact lists and Drive. Google disabled the accounts responsible for the spam, updated its systems to block it, and is working to prevent similar attacks. Victims are advised to turn on multifactor authentication, shut down access, change passwords, and report suspicious emails. The incident is not attributed to a specific nation-state or organization, and the exact number of affected users is unknown.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Chip Eng Seng Corporation reported a 647.9% increase in net profit for the first quarter, driven by higher contributions from its property development and construction divisions. Lippo Mall Indonesia Retail Trust saw a 0.06% increase in distribution per unit and a 12.9% increase in net property income. PACC Offshore posted a net loss of US$18.38 million, while Nera Telecom reported a 40.8% rise in net profit. CDL Hospitality Trusts acquired a five-star hotel in the UK for S$94.7 million, marking a significant expansion into the European market.

site_title: Mediacorp fined over blackface in drama
summary: Singapore's national broadcaster, Mediacorp, was fined S$5,500 by the Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) for airing a racist content segment in its Chinese language web-only series "I Want To Be A Star". The episode featured a Chinese actor with black face make-up, causing outrage online. The regulator deemed the segment racially insensitive and a form of racial stereotyping, but praised Mediacorp for quickly removing the content and taking remedial action to prevent a recurrence.

site_title: Yuuzoo financial controller leaves; parties disagree on reason for departure
summary: Yuuzoo Corp's financial controller, Thai Youn Fatt, has left the company amid its annual audit, citing a breach of employment contract. However, Thai disputed this, stating he had resigned. This is the latest in a string of key finance executives to leave the company since its listing on the Singapore Exchange in 2014.

site_title: Boxing: Mike Tyson launches fitness franchise
summary: Mike Tyson, a 50-year-old former heavyweight boxing champion, has launched a fitness franchise called the Mike Tyson Academy. The franchise plans to open branches in the Middle East, Africa, Europe, and South America, with headquarters in Las Vegas. Tyson, known for his troubled past, aims to promote a healthy lifestyle and is excited to be working. He expressed fear of being idle and has been working on plans for the fitness centers in various countries.

site_title: Euro zone businesses race into second-quarter on six-year high
summary: Euro zone businesses experienced a six-year high in activity in the second quarter, with the Composite Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 56.8 in April. This suggests a GDP growth rate of 0.7 percent, indicating a broadly based and sustainable economic recovery. The data also showed solid demand, rising capacity pressure, and higher hiring intentions, consistent with the bloc's economic growth.

site_title: SingPost reprimanded for listing rule breach in 2014 acquisition disclosure
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) issued a public reprimand to SingPost for breaching its listing rules in a 2014 announcement regarding the purchase of UK-based freight forwarder FS Mackenzie. The breaches included a factual inaccuracy about a director's interest and an omission in disclosure due to inadequate internal controls.

site_title: OUE Hospitality Trust's distributable income up 19.1% for Q1
summary: OUE Hospitality Trust's distributable income increased 19.1% to S$23.5 million in Q1 2017, driven by higher contributions from Crowne Plaza Changi Airport and increased occupancy at the Mandarin Gallery. Revenue also rose 6.4% to S$32.1 million.

site_title: Basketball body lifts 'hijab ban' during games
summary: The International Basketball Federation (FIBA) lifted its ban on professional players wearing headgear, including religious coverings such as the Muslim hijab, after widespread criticism. The decision allows players to wear traditional dress codes, including headgear, on court. The change comes after FIBA recognized that its previous rule was incompatible with certain countries' traditional dress codes.

site_title: Creating New Value with Digital Transformation
summary: Digital transformation is revolutionizing business models, processes, and innovation, unlocking new value through technology. As social, mobile, analytics, and cloud computing converge, new technologies like robotics, machine learning, and blockchain are paving the way for a paradigm shift in business operations and customer engagement. To succeed, organizations must adopt a creative approach, developing innovative solutions to support new business models, speed, and agility in responding to changing customer needs. Digitalization is creating new value in public safety, healthcare, transportation, education, and finance, enabling organizations to meet megatrends such as aging populations and rapid urbanization.

site_title: Yokohama: A showcase of sustainable city management
summary: Yokohama, Japan, has successfully transformed itself into an eco-friendly, livable city with a strong economic base, serving as a model for sustainable city management. The city's transformation from a post-war suburban town to a thriving metropolis involved strategic infrastructure projects, such as the Minato Mirai 21 district, Kanazawa reclamation project, and subway network development. Yokohama's "7 approaches" to achieving sustainable growth have been shared with other cities, focusing on innovations to tackle global warming, natural resource depletion, and ageing population. The city has also promoted international cooperation through sister cities and partnerships, showcasing its expertise in addressing urban challenges.

site_title: Dozens of Fairfax journalists down pens in protest over job cuts
summary: More than 100 Fairfax journalists protested outside the company's offices in Sydney, Australia, starting a rare week-long strike against 125 job cuts, or a quarter of its editorial staff, amid falling print readership numbers. The cuts aim to restore the company's financial well-being. Despite the strike, Fairfax plans to continue publishing its newspapers, with other employees and contractors helping with news coverage. The journalists union has described the job cuts as unfair, given employees' contributions to the company's digital transition.

site_title: Nera Telecommunications' Q1 net up 40.8% at S$2.86m
summary: Nera Telecommunications reported a 40.8% increase in Q1 net profit to S$2.86 million, driven by a 44.3% rise in revenue to S$44.12 million. The company secured S$58.7 million in order-in-take, with its network infrastructure segment experiencing an 18% increase in S$41.1 million orders. Despite a 28.8% decline in wireless infrastructure orders, the company remains confident in demand and growth for its wireless infrastructure business, driven by mobile carrier investments and upgrades.

site_title: Singapore stocks finish mixed as banks drag STI lower
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) ended Thursday at 3,228.62, down 9.19 points, due to a decline in bank stocks. DBS, OCBC, and UOB fell 8.7 points, 2 points, and 1 point respectively. Trading volume was 2.2 billion units worth S$1.25 billion, down from Wednesday. The STI has rallied for five consecutive days ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Sushi tapas bar plates up fish a cut above
summary: Chef Aeron Choo's omakase-only menu at Kappou Japanese Sushi Tapas Bar in Singapore showcases her meticulous approach to Japanese cuisine, using affordable ingredients to create unique dishes. The restaurant, open only for dinner, offers a personalized experience with a focus on fish and seafood, including aged sawara and tenmi tuna. With a price range of S$68 to S$128, the omakase menu is a steal, offering a variety of flavors and textures. Despite a lack of ambiance, Kappou is a unique dining experience that highlights the chef's skills and dedication to her craft.

images.alt_text: Tireless and driven young chef Ms Choo has her own vision of Japanese cuisine and is intense and meticulous at her tiny eatery in Fortune Centre.
Chef Choo's freestyle approach to Japanese cuisine has won her a loyal following, and her menu includes tamago with ikura pearls (above); noodle salad; and her tapas-styled dessert.
Chef Choo's freestyle approach to Japanese cuisine has won her a loyal following, and her menu includes tamago with ikura pearls; noodle salad (above); and her tapas-styled dessert.

site_title: Ferrari Q1 beats expectations
summary: Ferrari reported a 36% rise in first-quarter core earnings to 242 million euros, beating expectations. Quarterly revenues increased 22% to 821 million euros, driven by sales of 12-cylinder models like the GTC4Lusso and LaFerrari Aperta. The company confirmed its full-year guidance, lifting shares by over 3%. This marks a strong start to the year for Ferrari, with adjusted earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortisation (EBITDA) surpassing the Thomson Reuters SmartEstimate consensus.

site_title: Mapletree prices S$700m principal amount of 3.95% perpetual securities
summary: Mapletree Investments Pte Ltd's subsidiary has priced S$700 million principal amount of 3.95% perpetual securities, the largest Singapore dollar-denominated perpetual issuance this year. The issuance received over S$1.9 billion in orders, translating to a 2.7 times subscription rate from more than 70 investors. The securities are guaranteed unconditionally and irrevocably by Mapletree, pursuant to its US$5 billion Euro Medium Term Note Programme.

site_title: Cambodia's Hun Sen hospitalised in Singapore
summary: Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen, 64, has been hospitalized in Singapore for treatment due to exhaustion. He plans to return to Cambodia on Sunday to resume work as normal. Hun Sen, who has ruled Cambodia since 1985, has faced criticism for promoting corruption and human rights abuses. The European Union has called on the government to respect the rights of five human rights workers detained without trial. Hun Sen has been briefly hospitalized in Singapore last year.

site_title: Hi-P back in the black with S$8.4m Q1 profit as revenue falls
summary: Hi-P, a Singapore-based consumer electronics manufacturer, reported a net profit of S$8.4 million for the first quarter of 2017, reversing a net loss of S$12.4 million in the same period last year. Revenue fell 11.4% to S$244.2 million due to fewer high component content assembly products. Improved product mix, operational efficiency, and cost management contributed to the increase in net profits. The company's net debt position improved, and its effective tax rate was 29.3%.

site_title: Saudi central bank chief does not see more bank mergers
summary: Saudi Arabia's central bank governor Ahmed al-Kholifey stated that he does not see more bank mergers in the pipeline, following recent talks between Alawwal Bank and Saudi British Bank. Al-Kholifey also mentioned that Credit Agricole had not requested approval to sell its stake in Banque Saudi Fransi, and that the central bank is open to foreign banks seeking to open new branches in Saudi Arabia.

site_title: Australia shares ease as material, financial stocks sag; NZ down
summary: Australian shares fell 0.5% to 5,861.7, marking a third straight decline, due to a decline in the basic materials sector and weaker financials. The sector fell 1.7% on softer metal prices and technical selling. The US Federal Reserve's policy meeting, where rates were kept unchanged, also contributed to the market decline. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.4% to 7,375.57.

site_title: South Korean carmakers see China sales plummet further amid political tension: sources
summary: South Korean carmakers Hyundai Motor and Kia Motors Corp saw their China sales plummet over 60% year-on-year in April, marking the second straight monthly drop due to political tensions. The decline, 64% for Hyundai and 68% for Kia, is attributed to a nationalist backlash over Seoul's decision to deploy a US missile defence system. China accounts for about a quarter of their total sales, and the companies have been losing market share to local Chinese brands. This is the latest in a series of setbacks for South Korean companies in China.

site_title: Update: Britain's Prince Philip, 95, to cease royal duties in autumn
summary: Prince Philip, 95, will cease royal duties in autumn, Buckingham Palace announced. The Duke of Edinburgh will attend previously scheduled engagements until August, but will no longer accept new invitations. Queen Elizabeth, who turns 92 next month, will continue to carry out a full programme of official engagements. There is no cause for concern about the welfare of the queen or Philip, according to a well-placed source. The decision follows years of Philip and the queen reducing their workload and passing on responsibilities to Prince Charles and their grandsons, Princes William and Harry.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore commits up to S$150 million to boost artificial intelligence capabilities through the AI.SG national program. HDB resale flat prices and transactions eased in April, with prices and volumes down compared to the previous month. United Overseas Bank reported drawing S$27 billion in business flows into Asean in 2016 through its advisory units. Asean aims to focus on the digital economy and trade facilitation in 2018, with Singapore as chair. Growth in China and Japan is expected to anchor Asean+3 growth, with a predicted 5.2% growth in 2017 and 5.1% in 2018.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end at record high on firm earnings, won flat
summary: South Korean stocks reached a record high on Thursday, closing at 2,241.24 points, driven by robust exports and corporate earnings. Foreign investors purchased a net 361.4 billion won worth of Kospi shares. The won was weaker after the US Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged, but downplayed recent economic weakness. The Kospi rose 1.6% for the week, marking a third straight week of gains.

site_title: New Philippine central bank chief to be named in next few days
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte is set to name a new central bank governor in the next few days, with either of his deputies, Nestor Espenilla or Diwa Guinigundo, considered well-qualified for the job. The new governor will need to protect the country's fast-growing economy from risks such as higher US interest rates and capital outflows. The current governor, Amando Tetangco, is stepping down in July, and the president has yet to announce a candidate for the six-year term.

site_title: Shell's profit surges as oil sector rebounds
summary: Royal Dutch Shell's net profit more than doubled in the first quarter, reaching US$3.75 billion, as oil prices rebounded and refining margins improved. The company's cash flow surged 13-fold to US$9.5 billion, beating analyst forecasts. Shell's shares rose 2.6% and the company maintained its plan to invest US$25 billion this year, with a focus on asset disposals to finance its US$54 billion BG Group acquisition.

site_title: China: Stocks close at 3-month lows after slower service sector activity
summary: China's stocks closed at three-month lows on Thursday, down 0.3% to 3,404.39 points, after a survey showed softer services sector activity. The Shanghai Composite Index also fell 0.3% to 3,127.37 points. The services sector cooled to its slowest in almost a year in April, raising concerns over growing economic risks. The securities regulator vowed to step up efforts to prevent and control financial risks ahead of a key Party Congress later this year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end the day lower
summary: Hong Kong's stocks fell on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index down 0.05% to 24,683.88, amid investors' return from a public holiday and anticipation of US jobs data. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined 0.25% and 0.28%, respectively. The decline follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and comes as the US market edges to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: BMW sees forecasts in reach after Q1 profit boost
summary: BMW reported a 31% year-on-year increase in net profit to 2.15 billion euros in Q1, driven by 12.4% revenue growth to 23.45 billion euros. The company attributes the boost to increased sales of new models, including electric-powered cars, which saw a doubling in sales. BMW expresses confidence in achieving its 2017 objectives.

images.alt_text: German luxury carmaker BMW on Thursday said it was "confident" of achieving its objectives for 2017, as it reported a leap in profits in the first three months.

site_title: Up to S$150m boost for Singapore's artificial intelligence push (Amended)
summary: Singapore has committed up to S$150 million to its AI.SG national programme, aiming to boost the country's capabilities in artificial intelligence over the next five years. The programme, led by the National Research Foundation, will focus on three objectives: harnessing AI to address societal challenges, investing in deep capabilities to drive innovation, and broadening the adoption of AI in industries. The initiative will bring together government agencies, research institutions, startups, and firms to develop meaningful AI projects and proofs-of-concept.

site_title: ADB chief seeks to cooperate, not compete, with China-led Obor, AIIB
summary: ADB President Takehiko Nakao expressed willingness to cooperate, rather than compete, with China's development finance and infrastructure plans under its "One Belt, One Road" initiative. He stated that the ADB and China's Asia Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) can complement each other, despite differing objectives and management ideas. The two lenders have agreed to co-finance three projects and discussed cooperation on local currencies, expertise, and environmental safeguards. Nakao warned creditors about the costs of projects in economies targeted by China's Obor initiatives, emphasizing the need for economic feasibility assessments.

site_title: CDL Hospitality Trusts buy Manchester hotel for £52.5m
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts has acquired The Lowry Hotel in Manchester, UK, for £52.9 million (S$94.7 million), with £52.5 million of the purchase price funded by debt and £0.4 million by the estimated net working capital and cash of the hotel. The acquisition increases CDLHT's gearing to 39.1% and is expected to generate a pro-forma net property income yield of 7.3% and a distribution per stapled security (DPS) accretion of 2.7%. The hotel offers 165 rooms and is located near Manchester's city centre.

images.alt_text: The trustee-manager said in a release on Thursday night that through its indirect wholly owned subsidiary, CDL HBT North Ltd, it has bought The Lowry Hotel by acquiring The Lowry Hotel Limited, which will continue to hold and operate the hotel.

site_title: Europe: Shares power ahead as Q1 earnings season gathers pace
summary: European shares rose 0.3% on Thursday, near 20-month highs, as a strong earnings season boosted the sector.
