summary: Pan-United Corporation plans to split off its ports business, Xinghua Port Holdings, to be listed in Hong Kong. The move aims to allow investors to assess the separate market values of the businesses. Up to 141.6 million new shares will be issued at S$0.43 each to raise up to S$60.9 million to pay off port-related debt. The company also announced its first quarter results, showing a 19% decline in net profit and 14% fall in revenue.

site_title: Four banks to use MyInfo authentication service for customers
summary: The Smart Nation and Digital Government Office, in collaboration with the Monetary Authority of Singapore, has begun a pilot with four banks (UOB, DBS, OCBC, and StanChart) to simplify online banking transactions using the MyInfo service. Starting May 3, customers can apply for a new bank account without submitting supporting documents, enabling greater convenience and faster transaction times. This will also benefit banks by increasing productivity and reducing compliance costs. The pilot aims to reduce paperwork and increase efficiency in online banking applications.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines to add new routes, hire more staff by year-end
summary: Malaysia Airlines plans to add 11 new routes and hire more staff by year-end amid increased demand from international customers. The airline's CEO, Peter Bellew, stated that the company is evaluating at least 26 more routes for introduction by 2018. Malaysia Airlines is seeking to recover from two tragedies in 2014 and is aiming for a return to profitability by 2018 and a stock market listing again in 2018. The airline is also looking to expand its fleet with wide-body aircraft and hire more pilots, crew, and engineers.

site_title: Saudi Airlines starts sale of US$500m medical business -sources
summary: Saudi Arabian Airlines is selling its medical services business, valued at around $500 million, as part of a drive to reduce non-core assets. The business, Saudia Medical Services, owns a major hospital in Jeddah, which is underserved in the local healthcare market. The sale process, led by Jadwa Investment, could be completed by the third quarter. This is part of Saudia's five-year strategy to make the airline profitable by 2020, following the appointment of a new CEO, Jaan Albrecht.

site_title: UK construction growth surprises, hitting 4-month high - PMI
summary: Britain's construction industry saw a four-month high in growth in April, with the Markit/CIPS UK Construction Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 53.1 from 52.2 in March. Civil engineering and house-building growth accelerated, with construction companies taking on workers at the fastest rate since May last year. The positive signs come as the UK gears up for a national election on June 8, and amid concerns about inflation and the economy's recovery.

site_title: UK's Mitie announces writedown, shares rise as revenue steady
summary: UK services firm Mitie expects to write down £40-£50 million due to a review of its accounting practices, mainly related to long-term contracts and costs. Despite this, revenue remains steady, and shares rise 5% to 222.1pence. The company is seeking to raise its borrowing limits to £1.5 billion and will announce full-year results on June 12. Mitie's trading performance is unchanged, but costs have increased by £5 million since January as part of a cost reduction program.

site_title: Sembcorp Industries' new CEO announces strategic review; Q1 profit up 11.3%
summary: Sembcorp Industries' new CEO Neil McGregor announced a strategic review of the company's business to focus on performance, sustainability, and value creation amid a challenging macro environment. The review, to be conducted over the next few months, aims to build durable and sustainable businesses. The company reported an 11.3% rise in net profit to S$119.1 million for the first quarter, driven by higher other income and lower tax expense. Revenue rose 12.9% to S$2.14 billion, driven by its utilities division.

images.alt_text: Sembcorp Industries' new CEO Neil McGregor said the firm will be undertaking a strategic review of its business, as the firm recorded an 11.3 per cent rise in net profit for the first quarter of this year compared to the year-ago period.

site_title: North Korea state media confirms arrest of US professor
summary: North Korea has confirmed the arrest of US professor Tony Kim, who was detained at Pyongyang's airport on April 22 after teaching at the elite Pyongyang University of Science and Technology. Kim, who was accused of committing "criminal acts of hostility" to overturn the country, is the third American held in the country amid growing tensions with the US. The arrest comes as Pyongyang issues increasingly belligerent rhetoric in a stand-off with the Trump administration.

site_title: SPH launches SPH Content Lab
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) has launched the SPH Content Lab, a one-stop shop for content marketing solutions. The unit, led by award-winning journalists, has developed content marketing solutions for various organizations, including Canon, Cathay Pacific, and Citibank. The SPH Content Lab will work with SPH's newsrooms, including The Straits Times, to provide content marketing services. This move aims to provide organizations with a comprehensive content marketing solution, leveraging SPH's expertise in journalism and media.

site_title: TTJ unit to acquire property and equipment for S$12m in Johor
summary: TTJ Holdings' wholly owned indirect unit has agreed to acquire land and assets in Johor, Malaysia, for RM38 million (S$12.2 million). The acquisition includes a 4.9-hectare leasehold land zoned for industrial use, two single-storey factories, a double-storey office block, and a single-storey canteen. The deal aims to reduce labour costs and will be funded by internal resources and bank borrowings.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: China tightens rules for online news providers
summary: China has issued new internet regulations increasing Communist party control over online news providers, requiring licenses for websites and apps to post about sensitive topics and ensuring "correct guidance" of public opinion. The regulations, taking effect June 1, also mandate governmental training and assessment for staff, and top editors must be approved. Failure to comply will result in license revocation and fines of up to 30,000 yuan. The move is seen as a step to tighten online policing, following a controversial cybersecurity bill and ranking China as the fifth worst country for press freedom.

site_title: UK will not pay 100b-euro EU exit bill, says Brexit minister
summary: Britain's Brexit minister David Davis stated that the UK will not pay a 100 billion-euro exit fee to leave the European Union, contrary to a Financial Times report. Davis cited analysis showing the figure was driven by France and Germany. He emphasized the need to discuss the rights and obligations of the UK's exit, rather than paying a large sum.

site_title: Hong Kong, Japan, South Korea: Markets closed for holidays
summary: Financial markets in Hong Kong, Japan, and South Korea are closed on May 3, 2017, due to public holidays. No relevant news is provided for this date.

site_title: Apple's dilemma: what to do with US$256b cash pile
summary: Apple's US$256.8 billion cash pile is sparking debate on what to do with the funds, with some experts arguing it's a sign of success but also a problem due to the US tax code's disincentives for repatriating earnings. Proposals by President Trump and lawmakers could lower tax rates for repatriated earnings, but experts say it's unlikely to encourage companies to bring funds back. Apple has resisted repatriation, with some suggesting it could diversify its business by acquiring a chipmaker or investing in content for its ecosystem. The company's cash hoard has highlighted the growing stockpiles of cash held overseas by US multinationals.

site_title: Uber in US court reckoning on possible shutdown of self-driving program
summary: Uber faces a US court hearing on Wednesday to contest a lawsuit by Alphabet's self-driving car unit Waymo, which accuses former Uber executive Anthony Levandowski of stealing technical secrets. If Uber is found to have conspired with Levandowski, it could lead to a shutdown of its self-driving car program, jeopardizing its $68 billion valuation. A judge's ruling could also impact Uber's growth strategy and valuation, with experts warning that a blanket ban on autonomous efforts could stall its progress.

site_title: Excelpoint Technology reports 61.6% rise in Q1 earnings
summary: Excelpoint Technology reported a 61.6% rise in net profit to US$1.4 million in Q1 2017, driven by a 26.5% increase in group revenue to US$260.3 million. Higher sales from Hong Kong and Singapore business units contributed to the growth. Cost of sales rose 27.4% to US$246.9 million, while sales and distribution costs remained stable.

site_title: Australia shares fall, NZ snaps 7 days of gains
summary: Australian shares fell 0.98% on Wednesday, led by financial and basic material stocks, due to softer metals prices and caution about bank earnings and monetary policy. The S&P/ASX 200 index ended at 5,892.3. Investors await the US Federal Reserve's policy meeting, where interest rates are expected to remain steady. New Zealand shares snapped a seven-day winning streak, falling 0.22% on the S&P/NZX 50 index.

site_title: Thai police struggle to locate fugitive Red Bull heir
summary: Thai police are struggling to locate Red Bull heir Worayuth Yoovidhya, who fled to Singapore on his private jet days before an arrest warrant was issued for him in connection with a 2012 fatal hit-and-run. Worayuth, 32, is wanted for reckless driving that resulted in death and faces up to 10 years in prison. Authorities are seeking to revoke his Thai passport and have contacted the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to cooperate with law enforcement. The two countries do not have an extradition treaty, complicating efforts to apprehend the fugitive.

site_title: Singapore stocks finish mixed - banks power STI but broad market weakens
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 26.7 points to 3,237.81, driven by the outperformance of three banks: DBS, UOB, and OCBC. The banks' strong first quarter results led to a 33-point gain, despite a weak broader market. Turnover fell to S$1.2 billion from Tuesday's S$1.5 billion. The STI reached fresh 21-month highs, but narrowly focused gains were seen, with 198 rises versus 255 falls.

site_title: Rising Brexit "bill" raises negotiating stakes
summary: EU negotiators have increased possible payment demands for Brexit, with a Financial Times headline suggesting an upfront payment of up to 100 billion euros (S$152.2 billion) in 2019, prompting a rejection from Britain's Brexit Secretary David Davis. The European Commission has previously estimated the bill at around 60 billion euros. EU officials are pushing for a payment before talks start next month, with leaders hoping to reach an agreement by December, but concerns are rising that talks might collapse due to the widening divide between Brussels and London.

site_title: China: Stocks extend fall on policy tightening, regulatory concerns
summary: China's main stock indexes fell on Wednesday, with the CSI300 index down 0.4% and the Shanghai Composite Index losing 0.3%. The central bank injected 506.39 billion yuan into the financial system, but made no mention of maturing medium-term lending facility loans. Authorities have tightened regulations and shifted towards tighter policy, causing investors to be cautious. This marks a shift from super-loose policy, with regulators cracking down on riskier financing forms to contain financial risks.

site_title: Buffett to face big crowd as Berkshire grows bigger
summary: Warren Buffett is set to address Berkshire Hathaway shareholders in Omaha, Nebraska, as the US adapts to the Trump presidency and faces global tensions. The annual meeting, known as "Woodstock for Capitalists," will feature five hours of Q&A sessions with Buffett and vice chairman Charlie Munger. Despite Berkshire's huge size, details about its businesses can be thin, and Buffett has expressed concerns about the impact of conglomerates. Shareholders will likely ask about Berkshire's support of Wells Fargo and 3G Capital, as well as its cash deployment and succession plans, with Buffett's eventual successor expected to be a top-flight executive.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly up in holiday-thinned trade
summary: Asian markets mostly rose on Wednesday amidst a holiday-thinned trading session, driven by Wall Street's record close. The Nasdaq posted a new high, while the Dow and S&P 500 also gained. Traders await the Federal Reserve's policy meeting and US jobs data, which may provide clues about future interest rate hikes. The euro remains at recent highs ahead of the French presidential election, and the dollar holds steady against the yen.

site_title: Gold trades near three-week low on higher risk appetite as US Fed meets
summary: Gold prices fell to a three-week low, near $1,256 per ounce, amid higher risk appetite and a stronger US dollar. Investors sought returns from riskier assets ahead of the US Federal Reserve's meeting, which is expected to hold interest rates steady but may signal a June rate hike. This could reduce demand for non-interest bearing gold and make the US dollar-denominated metal more expensive.

site_title: Australia to review millionaire migrants rule as it tightens immigration
summary: Australia will review visa rules for wealthy migrants, including the Significant Investor Visa, which requires applicants to invest A$5 million. The review aims to ensure the program meets the country's economic needs and has been influenced by the rise of nationalist, anti-immigration politics. The government emphasizes the importance of proficiency in English, and applicants will have the opportunity to provide feedback on the changes. This move comes after the government tightened rules for the visa in 2015 and replaced a temporary work visa with a tougher program.

site_title: 12 dead in tunnel blast in southwest China
summary: A tunnel blast in southwestern China killed 12 workers and injured 12 others, with over 2,000 rescue workers searching the rubble for 14 hours before giving up. The cause of the accident is under investigation, and it is believed the gas filled the tunnel, which was being bored through a coal seam. The incident raises concerns about safety regulations in China, where industrial accidents are common and the country has recorded 66,000 workplace deaths in 2015.

site_title: Fairfax Media staff strike for a week over job cuts
summary: Staff at Fairfax Media in Australia walked off the job for a week in protest of 125 job cuts, a quarter of its newsroom staff, amid the company's struggles with slumping revenues. The strike follows hundreds of staff cuts and restructuring efforts to shift focus to digital publishing. The Media Entertainment and Arts Alliance condemned the decision, stating it will damage the company's mastheads and alienate its audience. Fairfax reported a 6% rise in half-year net profit, but the job cuts are part of a broader effort to save money amid falling circulation and advertising revenue.

site_title: Volkswagen profitability surges in post-scandal savings push
summary: Volkswagen's profitability surged in the first quarter, widening to 7.8% of revenue from 6.8% a year earlier, as the company intensifies efforts to reduce costs and revive weak margins at its VW brand. The improved margin comes despite a cash outflow in the "double-digit billion-euro range" to pay for damages from the emissions-cheating scandal. The company aims to achieve a 4% return on sales by 2020 and has set aside 22.6 billion euros to cover fines, buybacks, and repairs.

images.alt_text: Volkswagen AG's profitability surged as turnaround efforts at the struggling namesake car brand gained traction, providing much-needed support to stem an unprecedented financial hit from its diesel-emissions crisis.

site_title: Hong Kong firm snaps up London skyscraper in US$1.47b deal
summary: A Hong Kong property developer, C C Land, has completed its nearly $1.5 billion purchase of London's Leadenhall Building, dubbed the "Cheesegrater" due to its wedge shape. The deal, facilitated by the pound's slump to 12% lower against the US dollar, is the largest single property purchase in the UK since 2014. The acquisition is part of C C Land's business strategy to invest in quality properties globally, generating stable and strong recurrent income.

images.alt_text: A Hong Kong property developer has confirmed the near completion of its almost US$1.5 billion purchase of London's "Cheesegrater" tower, as it takes advantage of the pound's slump to snap up addresses in the British capital.

site_title: Adidas spins marketing gold with a 70-year-old in nerdy shoes
summary: Adidas is using a 70-year-old tennis player's retro shoe, the Stan Smith, as part of its marketing campaign to appeal to fashion-conscious teens and urban hipsters, aiming to increase sales by 40 million pairs annually to reach half a billion by 2020.

images.alt_text: The shoe is the Stan Smith, a white-leather number with pale green accents introduced in 1971, the year before Stan Smith (the player, now 70) earned his second and last Grand Slam singles title.

site_title: Europe: Stocks dip at open, before Fed outcome
summary: Europe's main stock markets fell slightly at the start of trading on Wednesday, with investors awaiting the outcome of the Federal Reserve's interest-rate meeting. The FTSE 100 index slipped 0.2% to 7,236.93 points, while the DAX 30 eased 0.1% to 12,502.36. Most economists expect the Fed to keep interest rates steady, with potential hikes in June and September. This follows a weak economic indicators and a softening US inflation rate.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Nobel Design, Sinostar PEC
summary: Grand Slam RF18 Investments made a mandatory unconditional cash offer for the remaining shares of Nobel Design Holdings at S$0.51 apiece. Sinostar PEC Holdings posted a more-than-doubled net profit of 26.4 million yuan (S$5.3 million) for its first quarter.

site_title: JPMorgan to move hundreds of staff to three EU offices on Brexit
summary: JPMorgan plans to move hundreds of London-based bankers to expanded offices in Dublin, Frankfurt, and Luxembourg as the UK prepares to leave the EU's single market after Brexit. The move aims to maintain easy access to the EU's financial market. The bank's CEO, Jamie Dimon, had previously mentioned that up to 4,000 employees could be relocated. JPMorgan is not the only bank making such plans, with other global banks like Deutsche Bank, Barclays, and Goldman Sachs also preparing to relocate operations.

site_title: Indonesia's GDP growth seen edging up in Q1 on higher exports: poll
summary: Indonesia's economy is expected to have grown 5% in the first quarter of 2017, slightly faster than the fourth quarter, driven by improved exports. Exports increased by over 20% compared to the same period last year. The central bank forecasts growth will improve in the second quarter, reaching 5.2% for the full year, meeting the government's target of 5.1%. Analysts predict the economy will continue to grow, with some forecasting 5.15% for the full year.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks head to 10,000-poimt mark; TSMC, Hon Hai up despite dip in iPhone sales
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 0.2% to 9,960.55, nearing the 10,000-point milestone, driven by gains from TSMC and Hon Hai Precision Industry, despite a dip in Apple's iPhone sales. TSMC climbed 0.5% and Hon Hai added 0.5%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to NT$29.987 per US dollar. The gains were largely attributed to investor confidence in the region's electronics sector, with the electronics subindex rising 0.3%.

site_title: Bank stocks climb for second straight day
summary: Bank stocks in Singapore rose for the second consecutive day on Wednesday, with DBS Bank leading the gain, increasing 3.4% to S$20.54. UOB and OCBC Bank also saw significant gains, advancing 1.8% and 1.3% respectively. The rally comes ahead of GDP data release and amid a strong market trend, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Hugo Boss sales, profit helped by China, Britain
summary: Hugo Boss reported a 25% increase in net profit to 48 million euros, driven by a recovery in China and growth in Britain, where the weak pound boosted tourist spending. Sales rose 1% to 651 million euros, beating analyst forecasts. The results are part of a trend of luxury goods demand picking up, particularly in China, with companies like LVMH and Hermes also reporting recoveries.

images.alt_text: German fashion house Hugo Boss reported a better-than-expected increase in first-quarter sales and net profit on Wednesday, helped by a recovery in China as well as growth in Britain, where the weak pound has boosted tourist spending.

site_title: China's yuan firms, traders await Fed policy statement for rate, US dollar clues
summary: China's yuan strengthened against the US dollar on Wednesday after the People's Bank of China set a stronger midpoint rate of 6.8892 per dollar. However, trading was subdued as markets awaited the Federal Reserve's policy statement, which may influence exchange rate volatility. The Fed is expected to hold interest rates steady, but may hint at a potential rate hike in June. China's policymakers aim to keep the yuan stable to reduce risk and leverage in financial markets.

site_title: China's military pact with North Korea looks shaky
summary: China's military pact with North Korea, signed in 1961, appears shaky due to Beijing's reluctance to defend its treaty partner in a potential conflict with the US and South Korea. The pact, which has automatically renewed every 20 years, is now valid through 2021, but China's current leaders, Xi Jinping and Kim Jong-Un, have never met. Analysts question whether Beijing would intervene militarily, citing North Korea's nuclear development and US pressure to punish Pyongyang. China's commitment to the pact remains sensitive to US military movements in the region, with Beijing demanding the US suspend its missile shield deployment in South Korea.

site_title: FBI chief and Putin cost her election: Clinton
summary: Hillary Clinton blames FBI director James Comey and Russia's Vladimir Putin for her 2016 presidential defeat, stating they "scared off" voters. Clinton takes "absolute personal responsibility" for campaign blunders, but criticizes Comey's re-opening of a probe into her email server and alleged Russian interference. Clinton's comments come after the FBI's investigation was seen as a major factor in her loss to Donald Trump.

site_title: Australia shares lower for a second session; NZ down
summary: Australian shares fell 1.01% to 5,890.5, extending their decline for a second session, led by telecom, financial, and basic material stocks. The Federal Reserve is expected to hold interest rates steady at its policy meeting. Telecom stocks, including Vocus Group, plummeted as much as 30% after cutting its forecast for the 2017 financial year. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.15% to 7,411.32, with financial sector losses attributed to Australian and New Zealand Banking Group's decline.

site_title: nuTonomy, Groupe PSA tie up to trial driverless Peugeot cars in Singapore
summary: NuTonomy, a driverless-car technology startup, has partnered with Groupe PSA to trial Peugeot 3008 autonomous cars in Singapore. By September, two Peugeot 3008 vehicles will be on the road, with plans for a dozen by 2018. The collaboration will enable PSA to become a mobility provider and help nuTonomy integrate its software with different vehicle platforms for on-road testing. The partnership aims to test the Peugeot 3008's suitability for autonomous driving in urban environments.

site_title: NZ dollar gains on strong jobs, Australian dollar drifts lower
summary: The New Zealand dollar rose to a 10-month high against the US dollar after a strong jobs report reinforced a steady interest rate outlook. The Australian dollar, on the other hand, drifted lower due to falling iron ore prices. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand is expected to keep rates at a record low of 1.75% at its upcoming policy review. Dealers are pricing a 20 basis points-tightening by February, but some economists remain cautious, citing no sign of wage inflation.

site_title: SIA, CAAS work together on 'green package' flights on San Francisco-S'pore route
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and the Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) have launched a three-month initiative on non-stop San Francisco-Singapore flights, dubbed "green package" flights. The flights, which began on May 1, combine biofuels, fuel-efficient aircraft, and optimized operations to reduce fuel burn and carbon emissions. CAAS is facilitating optimized air traffic management practices. The initiative supports Singapore's Sustainable Singapore Blueprint 2015, aiming to develop a green economy. The first of 12 flights, SQ31, departed San Francisco on May 1 with 206 passengers.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.4% higher on Wednesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 12.86 points to 3,223.97 on Wednesday, opening 0.4% higher. The rally was driven by Wall Street's edge higher overnight amid corporate earnings digestion. About 65.3 million shares worth S$115.5 million were traded, with Noble Group leading the gainers. The index has now extended its 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with gainers outnumbering losers 73 to 55.

site_title: BP held back by Gulf oil-spill costs as rivals emerge from slump
summary: BP's profits surged last quarter, tripling to $1.51 billion, but investors are waiting for cash flow growth due to high costs from the Gulf of Mexico oil spill. The company's net debt climbed to its highest in a decade, and it needs oil prices to reach $55 to cover spending and dividends without borrowing. Total, Exxon, and Chevron are emerging from the oil slump, while BP plans to invest in growth, but its cash flow remains impaired until the spill liabilities are resolved.

site_title: Oceanus gets qualified opinion from auditor, adjusts FY15 financial statement
summary: Oceanus Group, an ABALONE producer, received a qualified opinion from its independent auditor, Foo Kon Tan, for its FY15 financial statement. The auditor was unable to obtain sufficient audit evidence, resulting in a 258 million yuan (S$52 million) drop in net assets and a 39 million yuan reduction in the group's loss for the year.

site_title: Made-in-China passenger jet set to take maiden test flight
summary: China is set to carry out the maiden test flight of its home-grown passenger jet, the C919, over Shanghai. The narrow-body jet, built by state-owned Comac, represents nearly a decade of effort to reduce dependence on Boeing and Airbus. With a range of up to 5,555 kilometers and seating 168 passengers, the C919 is expected to challenge the dominance of European and US aerospace giants. While analysts say it's an important milestone, selling the product will be a long journey ahead, and Comac will need to obtain Chinese airworthiness certification and secure orders from domestic airlines.

site_title: US Fed not likely to move rates amid tepid inflation
summary: The US Federal Reserve is unlikely to raise interest rates amid softening inflation, easing pressure to increase rates. Despite weak economic indicators, most economists expect the Fed to hike rates twice more this year, possibly in June and September. The Fed's preferred inflation measure, PCE, retreated and remains below the 2% target, while weak consumption and auto sales contributed to the low growth. Economists disagree on the Fed's next move, with some predicting a rate hike in June and others expecting it to be pushed back to the July meeting.

site_title: Pakistan ramps up coal power with Chinese-backed plants
summary: Pakistan is investing heavily in coal-fired power plants with Chinese backing as part of the $54 billion China Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC) project. The plants, expected to cost $15 billion, will generate 16,000 megawatts of electricity, with three-quarters coming from coal-powered plants. Environmentalists and energy experts criticize the plans, citing concerns over pollution and climate change. Despite claims of using "supercritical" emission-reducing technology, experts argue that coal power is still a dirty energy source that will harm public health and the environment.

site_title: US dollar steady with eyes on Fed for rate clues; kiwi higher
summary: The US dollar traded near a six-week high against the yen on Wednesday, awaiting the Federal Reserve's policy statement for interest rate clues. The kiwi rose due to higher dairy prices. The Fed is expected to keep interest rates unchanged, but investors will look for hints on a potential rate increase in June.

site_title: US Senate confirms Jay Clayton as new SEC chief
summary: The US Senate confirmed Jay Clayton as the new head of the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) with a vote of 61-37, following a nomination by President Donald Trump in January. Clayton, a partner at law firm Sullivan & Cromwell, will oversee Wall Street and the financial sector, with Trump aiming to loosen rules and "restore" banking supervision. Clayton's confirmation comes amid criticism of the SEC's handling of past financial crises and plans to review the effectiveness of the Dodd-Frank law.

site_title: Europe: Shares stride into May as earnings power gains
summary: European shares rose 0.75% in the first trading day of May, driven by strong corporate earnings and manufacturing data. Financials and industrial stocks led the gain, with French bluechips reaching a nearly decade-high and Germany's DAX hitting a new all-time high. Euro zone factory activity hit a six-year high in April, adding to the improving economic backdrop for European corporates. The MSCI Europe's first-quarter earnings growth is seen at 13.9%, neck-and-neck with the US.

site_title: Gulf budget deficits shrink as rulers spend less
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) reports that Gulf Arab monarchies have made "substantial" fiscal adjustments, reducing budget deficits. The cumulative budget shortfall of the six-member Gulf Cooperation Council is expected to decrease from $350 billion to $240 billion by 2021. Saudi Arabia is expected to record a 1.5% surplus, while Bahrain struggles with low oil prices, with its foreign exchange assets falling 11% in January. The IMF emphasizes the need for fiscal reforms, including value-added taxation and subsidy cuts, to address the region's hydrocarbon-dependent economies.

site_title: Shanghai: Stocks open lower
summary: Chinese stocks opened lower on Wednesday, with the Shanghai Composite Index sliding 0.17% and the Shenzhen Composite Index dipping 0.12%. The lower opening was attributed to tighter market liquidity. Hong Kong markets were closed for a holiday.

site_title: Malaysia considers more Syariah-listed shares to boost Islamic funds
summary: Malaysia aims to boost Islamic funds and wealth management by increasing the number of Syariah-listed shares on its financial index. The country is considering listing additional Islamic banking groups or the "i-shares" of selective banking groups, with PNB group chairman Abdul Wahid Omar proposing three options to advance the segment. These options include listing Islamic shares of banks with significant Islamic finance activities, forming a second listed Islamic banking group, or listing Islamic development finance institutions. The move is expected to enhance Malaysia's position as a global hub for Islamic funds and provide competitive returns for Muslim investors.

site_title: IMF says still need 'credible' debt relief for Greece
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has stated that Greece still needs "credible" debt relief before it can provide more financing. Despite a reform package agreement, Europe must provide debt relief measures to restore debt sustainability. Discussions on debt relief are underway, with the IMF seeking a compromise on how to address Greece's debt burden. The IMF is willing to agree to debt relief at the end of the agreement, contingent on Greece meeting targets, and has welcomed the agreement's growth-friendly measures.

site_title: Ivanka Trump publishes women's self-help book
summary: Ivanka Trump's self-help book, "Women Who Work: Rewriting the Rules for Success", was released on May 2, 2017, despite criticism for offering little help to working-class women. The book, which focuses on skills for success, was written before her father's presidential election and features quotes from business leaders and politicians. Critics argue that the book is out of touch with the struggles faced by many women, and Ivanka Trump's own privileged lifestyle. The book has received mixed reviews, with some praising her as a role model and others criticizing her as a woman of privilege.

site_title: Airbnb, San Francisco settle lawsuit over short-term rental law
summary: Airbnb has settled a lawsuit with San Francisco, agreeing to require all hosts in the city on its platform to register their homes. As part of the settlement, Airbnb will create a registration system and turn over host registration information to city officials. The city's ordinance, which made it illegal for Airbnb to collect fees for unregistered rentals, will be enforced, and Airbnb will deactivate listings for hosts with invalid registrations. The agreement marks a compromise by Airbnb to improve its relationship with regulators as it prepares for an initial public offering.

site_title: Brexit may have unintended consequences for UK power supply
summary: The UK's decision to leave the European Atomic Community (Euratom) after Brexit poses risks to the country's nuclear industry and power supplies. A cross-party group of lawmakers warned that a delay in leaving Euratom would hurt nuclear trade and research, and potentially affect power supplies. The government is under pressure to delay its departure to allow for alternative arrangements to be put in place, with the Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy committee calling for urgent action to prevent the continued operation of the UK nuclear industry from being at risk.

site_title: Brent crude falls to 5-month low, erases gains since Opec agreed to cuts
summary: Brent crude oil prices fell to a 5-month low, reaching $50.46 a barrel, erasing gains since Opec agreed to cut production in November. The decline was attributed to rising US and Libyan production, as well as declining compliance with the output cut agreement. US West Texas Intermediate crude also fell to its lowest close since March 21. The market's sharp technical decline came after US futures fell below last week's low, with over 50,000 contracts trading in the five minutes following the price drop.

site_title: Apple delivers higher profits, but iPhone sales slip
summary: Apple reported a 4.9% increase in quarterly profits to $11 billion, driven by 4.6% revenue growth to $52.9 billion. However, iPhone sales slipped to 50.8 million units, below forecasts. Despite this, Apple's services business saw strong momentum, and the company announced an additional $50 billion for dividends and share buybacks. The company's cash holdings reached a record $256.8 billion, raising questions about its reserve management. Apple's shares fell nearly 2% following the earnings release.

site_title: US: Wall Street edges up on heavy earnings day; Fed on tap
summary: US stocks edged higher on Tuesday as tech and industrial sectors gained ground, despite weakness in auto and energy stocks. The S&P 500 rose 0.12% and approached record highs, with profits estimated to have risen 13.9% in the first quarter. Investors await the Federal Reserve's statement on interest rates and the US employment report. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.17% to 20,949.89, while the Nasdaq Composite added 0.06% to 6,095.37.

site_title: Trump, Putin discuss first meeting, Syria during 'very good call'
summary: US President Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin discussed steps to ease the six-year-old Syrian civil war during a "very good call" on Tuesday. They agreed that the suffering in Syria has gone on for too long and that all parties must end the violence. The two leaders also spoke about safe zones in Syria to achieve lasting peace, as well as the situation in North Korea. Trump and Putin expressed interest in meeting at a G-20 summit in Germany this July, amid tensions over Russia's involvement in the 2016 US election.

site_title: Microsoft out to regain ground in schools with Surface
summary: Microsoft unveiled the Surface Laptop, a Windows 10 S-powered laptop aimed at college students, to regain ground in classrooms where Google Chromebooks have gained popularity. The laptop will start at $999 and is intended to set a performance bar for partners, who will offer lower-priced computers. This move is part of Microsoft's strategy to compete with Chromebooks in the education sector.

site_title: New Zealand Q1 unemployment falls but wage growth remains tepid
summary: New Zealand's jobless rate fell to 4.9% in the first quarter, driven by gains in the tourism and construction sectors. However, wage growth remained sluggish. Analysts had expected the unemployment rate to remain unchanged at 5.2%. The New Zealand dollar rose to US$0.6965 following the release. The country's economy continues to show signs of growth, despite tepid wage growth.

site_title: Pipeline companies push back against Trump's 'Buy American' rule
summary: US pipeline companies are pushing back against President Trump's "Buy American" rule, which would require them to use American steel and iron in their projects, citing increased costs and disrupted operations. Steel companies, on the other hand, support the policy as an opportunity to benefit from the country's surging oil and gas production. The debate has raised concerns about the president's ability to reconcile his America-first platform and the conflicting interests of the energy and steel industries. A compromise is likely, with exemptions for projects with shipper commitments or pending permits.

site_title: Israel-born Michael Solomonov wins top US chef prize
summary: Michael Solomonov, a Philadelphia chef of Israeli descent, won the top US chef prize from the James Beard Foundation. His restaurant Topolobampo in Chicago was named the best US restaurant, marking the second time a Chicago restaurant has received the award. Solomonov's win comes after his brother's death in 2003, which inspired his focus on Israeli and Jewish cooking. The awards ceremony also recognized other winners, including pastry chef Ghaya Oliveira, rising star chef Zachary Engel, and restaurants Le Coucou and Canlis.

site_title: US car sales slip significantly in April
summary: US car sales declined significantly in April, with a 4.7% drop compared to the same period last year, according to Autodata. The industry-wide sales fell 8.3% compared to March, and the fourth consecutive month of declines. Major automakers such as General Motors, Ford, and Fiat Chrysler reported declines in sales, with some exceptions like Toyota's SUV sales rising 12.9% and Volkswagen's US sales increasing 1.6%. Industry analysts attribute the decline to a slowdown in demand, despite incentives and discounting efforts.

site_title: Alibaba rival JD.com eyes major investment in Indonesia's Tokopedia

The potential deal would propel Tokopedia past $1 billion in valuation and take JD's competition into Indonesia's largest economy. This move follows Alibaba's acquisition of Lazada Group and Amazon's planned expansion into the region. The investment could further fuel e-commerce growth in Indonesia, expected to reach $65 billion by 2020.

site_title: Singapore plans to be LNG-bunker ready by 2020
summary: Singapore aims to be liquefied natural gas (LNG) bunker-ready by 2020, following a landmark ruling by the International Maritime Organisation to impose a 0.5% sulphur cap on fuel oil. Pavilion Energy successfully demonstrated LNG bunkering capabilities at Jurong Port, with the process taking two to three hours. The move aims to provide a cleaner and sustainable solution to traditional bunker fuel, with over 100 LNG-fuelled and LNG-ready ships already operating. The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore will conduct a three-year LNG bunkering pilot programme to test operational protocols and strengthen capabilities.

site_title: Stepping up to the plate
summary: Sisters Bernadette and Bonnie Wong, directors of corporate affairs and human resources, and marketing and business development respectively, have taken over the family business, Creative Eateries Group, in the competitive food and beverage industry. The group, founded by their father Anthony Wong, has 30 outlets in Singapore and 11 in Malaysia, Taiwan, and China. The sisters joined the business in 2011 and 2013, respectively, and have become key decision-makers, overseeing 320 staff. They credit their father's influence for inspiring them to join the business and have learned to work together despite inevitable disagreements. The group plans to maintain its growth in Singapore and cautiously expand overseas, focusing on research and development and promoting staff from within.

site_title: Saudi prince says economic reforms working, promises huge investments
summary: Saudi Deputy Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman announced that his economic reforms are succeeding in protecting the kingdom against low oil prices, despite prices dipping to $27 for over a year. He promised massive investments in coming years to diversify the economy beyond oil, with over 50% of the $185 billion from Saudi Aramco's share sale to be reinvested domestically. The kingdom aims to develop non-oil sectors such as mining and logistics, with a spending plan of over $500 billion in the next three years.

With the right mindset, businesses can develop new processes, products, and services, driving growth and success.

site_title: China spending boosts machinery demand

The country's economic growth of 6.9% in the first quarter and increased property investment have driven the demand. Companies must invest in digital tools, nurture a workplace culture that supports innovation, and involve their entire organisation in the innovation process to realise real revenue growth and value creation.

site_title: Three reasons why there's still value in 'quality' stocks
summary: Quality firms remain relevant for investors amid global economic uncertainty, as a modest cyclical rebound in a sluggish growth world. The authors argue that the risk-on trade is unsustainable, and quality companies can provide long-term outperformance, citing three reasons: (1) a modest cyclical rebound within a secular world of sluggish growth, (2) quality stocks have not changed fundamentals despite market rotation, and (3) diversification reduces reliance on cyclical market trends.

site_title: Blackstone's GSO snaps up J Crew's debt in restructuring gambit

site_title: China's US$11 trillion economy and markets are in a tug of war
summary: China's US$11 trillion economy is facing a tug of war between its solid economic indicators and shaky financial markets. Economists warn that if not managed well, this could result in a faster-than-intended slowdown of credit growth. The country's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers to balance short-term pain with long-term benefits.

site_title: Higher taxes inevitable for America
summary: The US faces an undertaxed society, with government spending and wants exceeding willingness to be taxed, particularly among older Americans. President Donald Trump's proposed "tax reform" may obscure or worsen this reality, with the potential to exacerbate massive peacetime deficits. The plan's fatal defect is its effect on the federal debt, projected to reach $25 trillion and 89% of GDP by 2027, threatening interest rates, national emergencies, and global financial stability. Economists warn that the gamble on future economic growth may not come true, and prudence suggests caution against betting on it.

site_title: Marco Polo Maritime sailing into rough seas
summary: Marco Polo Marine, a marine logistics firm, has suspended trading of its shares due to uncertainty over meeting lender and investor expectations. The company expressed "not confident" of meeting expectations and asked for a trading suspension. This move comes after the company faced resistance from lenders in talks over a refinancing plan. A statutory demand from creditors and rising reservation of rights letters have further worsened the situation. The suspension is seen as a result of the company's struggles with debt woes and poor cash flow in the oil and gas services sector.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Enhancing corporate transparency
summary: Parliament has passed amendments to the Companies (Amendment) Bill and Limited Liability Partnerships (Amendment) Bill, requiring corporate entities to maintain a register of beneficial owners and nominee directors. The changes aim to enhance corporate transparency and combat money laundering, terrorist financing, and tax evasion. The registers will be kept by the corporate entity, but can be inspected by authorities upon request. Companies have a 60-day transitional period to comply with the new requirement, with those incorporated/registered after March 31 having a 30-day period.

site_title: Trump's priorities left out of US spending deal
summary: A bipartisan US government spending deal was reached, funding government operations through September 30. The agreement includes President Trump's call for increased military spending but rejects his demand to fund a border wall. The bill adds $1.5 billion in funding for border security and boosts military spending by 4.5%. It also includes funding for key government operations, such as the State Department and the National Institutes of Health, and maintains funding for women's health care provider Planned Parenthood. The deal was seen as a defeat for President Trump, who threatened a government shutdown if his priorities were not met.

site_title: Infosys to hire 10,000 US workers amid visa crackdown
summary: Infosys plans to hire 10,000 US workers over the next two years, expanding local hiring and adding four hubs for research technologies like AI and machine learning. The move comes amid criticism from the Trump administration that Indian outsourcing firms are displacing American workers with overseas employees. The first location will open in Indiana in August 2017, creating 2,000 jobs by 2021. Infosys CEO Vishal Sikka stated that being local and trusted by customers is crucial in the fast-changing world.

site_title: Feeding the passion
summary: Restaurant chains Putien and Qi Ji have achieved success by focusing on authenticity and fresh, seasonal ingredients. Putien, which has over 30 outlets across Asia, prioritizes the use of local ingredients and traditional cooking methods to differentiate itself from competitors. Qi Ji, which specializes in retail and catering of local comfort food, has introduced innovative production methods, such as automated popiah-making machines, to improve efficiency and consistency. Both companies attribute their success to their commitment to quality and customer experience, and are expanding their operations to other markets, including Japan and Europe.

site_title: Investor group slams Urban Outfitters board for 'extreme insularity'
summary: An investor group, CtW Investment Group, is urging Urban Outfitters shareholders to vote against re-electing two directors due to the board's "extreme insularity" and lack of diversity. The nine-member board has only two women and an average tenure of 19 years, contributing to the company's weak performance. CtW recommends voting against directors Robert Strouse and Harry Cherken Jr., citing the need for director qualifications during a critical juncture. Urban Outfitters has responded, saying it has taken targeted steps to alter the board's composition and engaged with shareholders.

site_title: Software tycoon Ahn channels France's Macron in bid for Korean presidency
summary: South Korean software tycoon Ahn Cheol-soo, a centrist candidate, is trailing behind former party comrade Moon Jae-in in the May 9 election. Ahn is trying to channel France's Emmanuel Macron's approach, focusing on markets and technology, but is struggling to gain traction due to public demands for a crackdown on the country's elite. Ahn's party has fewer than 40 seats in the National Assembly, and he would need to form alliances to address the country's crises, including North Korea's nuclear threat and economic growth.

site_title: Will Zillow's home-buying calculator add up?
summary: Zillow launches a new portal, realestate.com, designed to help first-time homebuyers navigate the home-buying process with a budget calculator that computes mortgage payments, property taxes, and other carrying costs. The site aims to provide a utilitarian approach to make comparisons between the cost of owning and renting a home. Despite the new tool, the industry faces a bigger issue: affordability, with a shortage of homes for sale at lower price points. This shortage is particularly acute for first-time buyers, who make up 42% of all homebuyers but often underestimate closing costs and other expenses.

site_title: China private banks won't kill the offshore wealth business just yet
summary: Chinese private banks are expanding their offshore wealth-management presence, but face challenges in meeting international standards due to lower investment and higher costs. They will need to develop expertise in investment and compliance, particularly in anti-money laundering and tax regulation. Despite this, non-Chinese private banks may have an advantage in serving Asian clients, particularly those seeking to start businesses, and tapping into the Asean market. Chinese private banks will also struggle to compete with established foreign banks offering diversified investment services, potentially limiting their growth in the region.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: Indonesia has detained a Trafigura employee in connection with a US$17 billion graft case. Meanwhile, OCBC Bank announced that Helen Wong will retire as CEO, with Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, taking over as the new CEO. Singapore's Sats CEO Kerry Mok's pay rose 30.5% to S$3.1 million. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Singapore's stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Dealing with digital disruption
summary: Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) must adapt to digital disruption by understanding key regulations, data protection, and intellectual property rights. Before adopting a new business model, SMEs should survey regulatory landscapes, ensure data protection, and secure intellectual property rights. They must also be mindful of social media legal issues, such as defamation laws and industry good practices, to avoid adverse publicity or lawsuits. By addressing these issues, SMEs can realize exponential growth and stay competitive in the era of sharing economy and social media.

site_title: Tony Blair returns to politics as UK prepares for Brexit
summary: Former UK Prime Minister Tony Blair announced his return to domestic politics to fight Brexit, despite being a divisive figure. Blair stated he won't stand in the June 8 general election but wants to help shape the Brexit debate. He aims to get involved in the UK's Brexit negotiations, which are set to begin soon.

site_title: Dishing it up
summary: The SME Magazine's May/June 2017 issue highlights Singapore's thriving food and beverage industry. Top SMEs showcase innovative food products and lean operations. The Towkays section features second-generation leaders at Creative Eateries, Bernadette and Bonnie Wong. The Cutting Edge section highlights Qi Ji and Putien's balance of traditional and modern approaches. The issue also covers topics such as innovative office space, digital transformation, and corporate transparency, including updates from the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority.

site_title: The problem with 'transactional diplomacy'
summary: US President Donald Trump's approach to international affairs, dubbed "transactional diplomacy," overlooks the complexities of deep-rooted historical, religious, and psychological forces driving conflicts like the Israeli-Palestinian dispute. This approach, where policy problems are viewed as business transactions, is misleading in international relations where issues of war and peace, life and death are involved. Trump's pragmatism, focusing on cost-effectiveness, neglects the core values and sense of identity of a national community, and the president's role in making critical foreign policy decisions that can lead to wars.

site_title: Serving up new dishes
summary: Singapore's food services and food manufacturing sectors are undergoing a transformation to become more productive, efficient, and future-ready. Despite challenges such as high churn rates and labor shortages, companies are embracing technology and innovation to stay competitive. The government's Industry Transformation Maps (ITMs) program aims to support the sector's growth. Innovative solutions, such as digital ordering platforms, ready-to-eat meals, and automated vending machines, are being implemented to meet changing consumer demands. Companies like Select Group and Coffee Hive are leveraging technology to improve efficiency and customer experience, while also focusing on talent development and retention.

images.alt_text: "In the quest to provide good quality meals, food service providers have to consider not just the end product, but the process of development as well." - Vincent Tan (above), managing director of Select Group
