site_title: German project looks to home photovoltaic systems to help grid
summary: Germany's grid operator Tennet and solar panel maker Sonnen GmbH have launched a pilot project to tap home photovoltaic systems with storage batteries to help balance the country's power network. The project aims to sign up 6,000 households by May, initially pooling 24 megawatts of power capacity. Blockchain technology from IBM will facilitate tracking and recording of encrypted information. The project has the potential to make small energy producers independent of centralized power providers and reduce waste of wind power.

site_title: Tesla executives listed as officers at materials recycling firm
summary: Two top Tesla executives, JB Straubel and Andrew Stevenson, have been listed as officers at materials recycling company Redwood Materials Inc. The company, which aims to recycle, re-manufacture, and reuse materials, raised $2 million from a single investor in April. Tesla has been diversifying its business, including its focus on re-thinking the materials supply chain, and the possible ties between the companies could be key to its manufacturing efforts. The company's CEO, Elon Musk, has not commented on the matter.

images.alt_text: Two top Tesla Inc executives were listed as officers at a materials recycling company, Redwood Materials Inc, indicating possible ties between the companies.

site_title: US looking past energy independence to global dominance
summary: US Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke says the country is poised to become energy-dominant, not just independent, thanks to fracking and plans to loosen drilling regulations. Oil production is expected to increase by 17% to a record 10.24 million barrels a day by the end of next year. Zinke is pushing forward President Trump's plans to expand oil and natural gas drilling and reconsider regulations. He also signed orders to revise the five-year schedule for auctioning offshore drilling rights and reorganize the Interior Department.

site_title: Norway wealth fund has not found attractive property investments in Tokyo, Singapore: CEO
summary: Norway's $935 billion sovereign wealth fund, the world's largest, has not found suitable real estate projects in Tokyo and Singapore, according to its CEO Yngve Slyngstad. The fund has invested in European and US cities, including London, Paris, and New York, but has not found attractive properties in the two Asian capitals. This decision comes despite long-standing plans to invest in Tokyo and Singapore.

site_title: Airline executives lambasted at hearing on passenger treatment
summary: Lawmakers criticized airline executives from United Airlines and other carriers at a congressional hearing on passenger treatment, following the April 9 incident where a man was dragged off a flight. Executives, including United CEO Oscar Munoz, apologized and promised policy changes, including increased compensation for bumped passengers. The industry faces calls for new passenger protections, including clearer rules and regulations, as lawmakers consider legislation to restrict airline bumping and improve customer service.

site_title: China central bank's lower cash injections signal bid to curb credit growth
summary: China's central bank reduced cash injections by 18% in April to 506.39 billion yuan, signaling a bid to curb rapid credit growth. This follows a 50% month-on-month jump in March and a 35% drop in February. The People's Bank of China has adopted a "prudent and neutral" policy to cool debt growth while avoiding hurting economic growth. The bank lent 495.5 billion yuan via its medium term lending facility and extended 10.89 billion yuan of loans via its standing lending facility in April.

site_title: Maritime Singapore has plenty to offer
summary: Singapore has been ranked the world's top maritime capital by the Menon Report, marking the third consecutive year it has held the top spot. The city-state excelled in shipping, ports, logistics, and attractiveness, while also scoring high in maritime technology and finance. Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) chief executive Andrew Tan expressed gratitude for the recognition, stating that it will spur the nation to work harder to maintain its reputation as a global maritime hub. However, the report noted that competition among maritime centers will continue to drive growth.

site_title: Alitalia shareholders approve administration move
summary: Alitalia shareholders voted unanimously to put the airline into administration, moving closer to liquidation. The move comes after staff rejected proposed job and salary cuts as a condition for a 2-billion-euro rescue plan. Flights will continue to operate under administrators, with the Italian government providing a 500-million-euro bridging loan to keep planes flying for six months. If no buyer is found, the airline may lose 20,000 jobs and face winding-up. Despite efforts to save the airline, consumer groups threaten to sue the government if more taxpayer money is spent.

site_title: Hilton beats Q1 profit estimates
summary: Hilton Worldwide Holdings Inc reported better-than-expected first quarter earnings, with net income of US$74 million and revenue jumping 25.2% to US$2.16 billion. The company raised its full-year profit forecast to US$1.73-1.81 per share, citing higher room rates and occupancy. Average daily rates rose 0.6% to US$141.55, while occupancy climbed 1.6 percentage points to 70.9%. This exceeded analyst expectations and sets a positive tone for the company's 2017 earnings.

site_title: AIG's investors, awaiting CEO plan, uneasy ahead of results
summary: AIG's investors are uncertain about the company's future due to the prolonged search for a new CEO. Despite Chairman Douglas Steenland's assurance that the board remains committed to the turnaround effort, analysts express concerns that a new CEO may alter the strategy. The company's shares have dropped 5.7% in the year to date, and investors are awaiting the release of its first-quarter earnings on Wednesday, which are expected to show a 37% increase in quarterly profit.

site_title: Fight for younger clients weighs on IP insurers
summary: Singapore's Integrated Shield Plan (IP) insurers face a dual challenge as medical claims rise due to an ageing population. The industry is struggling to attract new, younger clients amidst a shrinking pool of healthy consumers. Industry observers warn that this trend will impact the IP industry's sustainability. The six IP providers are exploring innovative ways to ensure the industry's viability in the face of growing medical claims and an increasingly ageing population.

site_title: Microsoft launches US$999 laptop in hardware push to college kids
summary: Microsoft has launched a US$999 laptop targeting college kids, with a 13.5-inch touchscreen, Intel processors, and 14 hours of battery life. The device, which weighs 1.25 kilograms, comes in four colors and features Microsoft's new Windows 10 S operating system for faster performance and better security. The laptop is available in various configurations, including a base model with 128GB of storage and 4GB of RAM, and can be upgraded with a faster Intel Core i7 chip and up to 16GB of RAM.

site_title: Pacific Star Development appoints Kam Tin Seah as COO and head of property division
summary: Pacific Star Development Limited appointed Kam Tin Seah, 52, as chief operating officer and head of property division. Seah brings over 26 years of property experience from companies including UOL Group and Parkway Holdings. He will report to CEO Glen Chan and has also been an adjunct associate professor at the National University of Singapore's Department of Real Estate.

site_title: World's "oldest person" dies in Indonesia at 146: relatives
summary: An Indonesian man, Sodimejo, reported to be the world's oldest person at 146, died in a local hospital due to deteriorating health. Born in 1870, his age was verified by local officials using a government-issued ID card. Sodimejo's death was confirmed by his grandson, who said the elderly man refused to eat or drink before passing away. This surpasses Jeanne Calment's record of 122 years old, held by Guinness World Records. Sodimejo was buried in a local cemetery on Monday morning.

site_title: Sales of Merck's cancer drug soar, company raises forecast
summary: Merck & Co raised its full-year forecast after sales of its cancer drug Keytruda more than doubled to $584 million in the first quarter, exceeding analysts' expectations. The company's diabetes business declined 5.5% due to price pressures, but adjusted earnings are now projected to be $3.76-$3.88 per share. Keytruda's growth is seen as a major factor in Merck's revenue increase forecast to $39.1-$40.3 billion.

site_title: Allianz-backed consortium to buy Britain's Affinity Water
summary: A three-member consortium backed by Allianz has agreed to buy Affinity Water Ltd, the largest water-only supply firm in England and Wales, through two transactions valued at £687 million. The consortium, also including HICL and DIF, will acquire 90% of the company's stake from Morgan Stanley's infrastructure team and M&G Investments-owned Infracapital. The deal is the latest high-profile acquisition of British infrastructure by overseas investors, following a similar deal last month for Thames Water.

site_title: Nobel Design receives unconditional cash offer of S$0.51 per share from Grand Slam
summary: Nobel Design Holdings has received a mandatory unconditional cash offer of S$0.51 per share from Grand Slam RF18 Investments, representing premiums of 18.6% and 22.6% above six-month and 12-month volume-weighted average prices. The offer aims to allow shareholders to exit the thinly-traded counter at attractive premiums.

site_title: Sunseap valued at S$200m after latest funding round
summary: Sunseap Group, a sustainable energy provider in South-east Asia, has reached a valuation of over S$200 million following its third funding round. The Series C investment round raised S$6.7 million, led by ISOTeam Limited, to aid expansion plans in Singapore and the region. The company aims to supply 200 megawatts of clean energy to customers in Singapore and has projects in Cambodia, India, Thailand, Vietnam, Malaysia, and Australia.

site_title: Thai king takes control of five palace agencies
summary: Thai King Maha Vajiralongkorn has taken control of five palace agencies, including the Royal Household Bureau and Office of His Majesty's Principal Private Secretary, following a private vote by lawmakers. The transfer aims to consolidate the monarch's power and handle royal affairs and security. The move is part of the new king's assertive efforts to expand his influence since ascending the throne in October, following the death of his father Bhumibol Adulyadej. The secrecy surrounding the transfer is typical of the monarchy's opaque nature, with harsh defamation laws shielding critics.

site_title: Living a luxe life for less
summary: EatPlayLive, an Asian lifestyle app, aims to provide users with access to luxury experiences at discounted rates. Founded by managing director Julie Renyard, the app offers a 20-50% discount on total bills at top restaurants, spas, and other high-end establishments across Singapore, Hong Kong, Bali, and other South-east Asian countries. The app has gained traction, with 5,000 downloads and 1,000 active users, and plans to expand to new markets. Renyard attributes the app's success to its unique user-pay model and focus on providing exclusive perks and promotions to its members.

site_title: Insurer Aetna posts loss, evaluates Obamacare exposure
summary: Aetna Inc reported a quarterly net loss of $381 million, or $1.11 per share, due to costs from its failed acquisition of Humana Inc. The insurer plans to cut exposure to money-losing Obamacare coverage in 2018. Aetna faces uncertainty over premium rates, including government subsidies and the mandate for Americans to have insurance. The company will evaluate its footprint to significantly reduce individual commercial products in 2018, citing high customer medical costs and a $110 million premium deficiency reserve.

site_title: Ford, Chrysler post biggest sales declines as US slump deepens
summary: Ford Motor Co and Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV reported the largest US sales declines, with car and light truck deliveries falling 7.1% and 6.6% respectively in May. The industry is on track for a fourth consecutive month of shrinking demand, attributed to higher auto prices, which rose 2% over the past year. This increase may be a barrier for consumers, despite low borrowing costs and loose credit.

site_title: Married deal sparks offer for Nobel Design
summary: Grand Slam RF18 Investments has made a mandatory unconditional cash offer for the remaining shares in Nobel Design Holdings at S$0.51 apiece, representing premiums of 18.6 and 22.6 per cent above the six-month and 12-month volume-weighted average prices respectively.

site_title: Conserved Orchard Road property up for first price and quality tender: SLA
summary: The Singapore Land Authority (SLA) will conduct the first price and quality tender for the conserved state property at 26-36 Orchard Road, a historic street-block with unique architectural features. The tender will assess bids based on a combination of price and quality, with the site not necessarily awarded to the highest bidder. The goal is to encourage entrepreneurship and preserve the heritage buildings while providing functionality for the community. This approach aims to strike a balance between preservation and functionality, offering an expanded range of use for state properties.

site_title: Singapore manufacturing PMI posts slower expansion at 51.1
summary: Singapore's manufacturing PMI slowed down to 51.1 in April, indicating a weaker expansion compared to the previous month. The electronics sector saw a more pronounced weakness, with new orders slipping. This marks a slight decline from the 51.2 PMI reported in March.

site_title: Update: Hollywood writers and studios reach tentative deal
summary: Hollywood writers and studios reached a tentative deal, averting a potential strike that could have impacted talk shows and soap operas. The agreement includes provisions for shorter TV seasons and a 15% increase in pay TV residuals. The deal also covers health and parental leave benefits, and addresses royalties for shows sold on streaming platforms and cable TV. The 9,000-member Writers Guild of America had threatened to call a strike if no deal was reached by midnight on Monday, citing a 23% drop in earnings over the past three years.

site_title: Hong Kong, Chinese regulators set to unveil 'Bond Connect' in July: sources
summary: Hong Kong and Chinese regulators plan to unveil "Bond Connect" in July, a scheme to connect China's US$8 trillion bond market with overseas investors. The launch is expected in the autumn, coinciding with the 20th anniversary of Hong Kong's handover to China. The program, which began in 2014 with two-way trading between Hong Kong and Shanghai stock markets, has been in development. Details on the program's mechanics and timeline have been scarce, but the announcement is seen as a significant step in increasing China's access to international capital markets.

site_title: Israel shows off F-35 stealth fighters for first time
summary: Israel has showcased its new F-35 stealth fighter jets for the first time, as part of its annual Independence Day celebrations. Three of the five jets received from the US took to the skies off the Mediterranean coast, marking the country's 69th anniversary of independence. Israel aims to maintain military superiority in the Middle East, particularly against Iran, and plans to purchase a total of 50 F-35s. The jets feature advanced stealth capabilities, supersonic speed, and high-tech equipment, making Israel the first non-US country with an operational F-35 squadron.

site_title: Sinostar PEC Q1 net profit more than doubles to 26.4m yuan
summary: Sinostar PEC Holdings reported a 132% increase in Q1 net profit to 26.4 million yuan, driven by 43% revenue growth to nearly 472 million yuan, mainly due to a 62.5% growth in propylene sales. Earnings per share rose to 4.13 cents, while free cash flow increased to 533.3 million yuan. No dividends were declared for the period.

site_title: Merkel meets with Putin on rare Russia visit
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel met with Russian President Vladimir Putin in Sochi, Russia, on Tuesday, marking her first visit to Russia since 2015. The two leaders discussed Ukraine and Syria, signaling renewed dialogue despite deepening rifts. Merkel and Putin have scaled back ties since Moscow's ties with the EU plummeted over the Ukraine crisis. The meeting aimed to address bilateral relations and problematic issues, including Ukraine and Syria.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index increasing 0.33% to 24,696.13 points. The move follows a long weekend and ahead of the Federal Reserve policy meeting and US jobs data. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.35% and the Shenzhen Composite Index remained flat. The gains were seen as a sign of investor optimism despite ongoing trade uncertainty.

site_title: Dow,Dupont receive conditional approval for proposed merger
summary: China has conditionally approved the proposed merger between Dow Chemical Co and Dupont, subject to the companies' divestment of assets and research and development facilities. This approval follows EU antitrust regulators' conditional approval in March. However, US, Brazilian, Australian, and Canadian regulators are still reviewing the deal.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end the day higher
summary: Malaysian shares rose on Tuesday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index gaining 10.4 points to 1,778.47. A total of 3.88 billion lots valued at RM3.4 billion were traded, with 594 gainers outnumbering 411 losers.

site_title: Bitcoin soars above US$1,400 to all-time high
summary: Bitcoin reached an all-time high above US$1,400 on May 2, 2017, following strong demand in Japan, where the digital currency has been deemed a legal means of payment. The surge, which more than tripled its value over the past year, was attributed to the Japanese market's warming approach towards bitcoin and China's clampdown on exchanges, which forced them to charge trading fees. This move was seen as a positive step for the industry by analysts.

site_title: IPOS chief elected chair of UN committee on copyright
summary: Daren Tang, CEO of Singapore's Intellectual Property Office (IPOS), has been elected chairman of the World Intellectual Property Organisation (WIPO) Standing Committee on Copyright and Related Rights (SCCR) for a two-year term. This marks the first time a Singaporean has held the position, and Tang's appointment reflects his extensive experience in intellectual property and trade. The move is seen as a testament to IPOS' efforts to build strong international networks and shape a robust IP regime.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: DBS Group Holdings reported a record S$1.21 billion net profit for Q1 2017, a 1% increase from last year. The Singapore Land Authority (SLA) will conduct the first-ever price and quality tender for the conserved Orchard Road property. IPOS chief Daren Tang was elected chairman of the World Intellectual Property Organisation's Standing Committee on Copyright and Related Rights. Singapore Airlines is expected to turn to a net-debt position as early as 2018, marking a change from 13 years of being debt-free.

images.alt_text: DBS Group Holdings reported on Tuesday that its net profit for the first quarter ended March 31, 2017 rose to a record S$1.21 billion, up 1 per cent from a year ago.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei climbs to 6-week high on earnings optimism
summary: Japan's Nikkei share average rose to a six-week high on Tuesday, closing at 19,445.70, driven by robust earnings and gains on Wall Street. The Nikkei added 1.3% for the week, its highest close since March 21. Tokyo markets will be closed for three days from Wednesday for Golden Week. The US stock market also rose on Monday, with the Nasdaq Composite reaching a record high.

site_title: Singapore stocks finish mixed even as banks push STI to 21-month high
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) reached a 21-month high of 3,211.11, driven by a surge in bank stocks following their strong first-quarter results. UOB and DBS, the two major banks, rose 4.6% and 2.6% respectively after reporting significant increases in net earnings. The STI gained 1.1% to close at 3,211.11, with the FTSE ST Financial Index also rising 1.5%. The rally comes ahead of upcoming GDP data and amid ongoing market volatility.

site_title: Indonesia's annual inflation rate rises to 13-month high in April
summary: Indonesia's annual inflation rate surged to 4.17% in April, the highest in 13 months, exceeding expectations. This is the quickest pace since March 2016. Rising electricity tariffs drove the increase, while core inflation remained at 3.28%. The central bank targets annual inflation between 3% and 5% this year, and its next policy review is on May 17-18.

site_title: Asian junk bonds outperform investment-grade credit in Q1
summary: Asian junk bonds outperformed Asian "high-grade" bonds in Q1 2017, with total returns of 3.86% compared to 2.13%. High-yield sovereign bonds, particularly those from Mongolia and Sri Lanka, saw significant gains, with returns of 12.54% and 4.92%, respectively. The Asia Securities Industry and Financial Markets Association attributed this performance to the strong credit ratings of these countries, with effective ratings of at least BBB-.

site_title: Pledging more austerity, Greece cuts deal with lenders
summary: Greece has reached a deal with international lenders, paving the way for the disbursement of further rescue funds and potentially opening the door to debt relief. The agreement includes austerity measures such as cutting pensions and tax-free thresholds, as well as selling coal-fired plants and coal mines. Greece needs to legislate the reforms before euro zone finance ministers approve the funds at their next meeting on May 22. The deal is seen as a step forward, with financial markets welcoming it, but lenders differ on what Greece's budget can sustain, with the IMF calling for debt relief and EU lenders ruling out forgiveness.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks close at six-year high on strong exports, won firms
summary: South Korean shares closed at a six-year high on May 2, 2017, driven by strong exports and a 0.7% increase in the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi). Foreign investors purchased 131.9 billion won worth of Kospi shares, while the South Korean won rose 0.7% to 1,130.5 to the US dollar. The stock market closed due to a public holiday on Monday and will also be closed on Wednesday and Friday.

site_title: Europe: Stocks gain ground at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose 0.3% on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 index advancing to 7,223 points, Paris's CAC 40 index to 5,284.88 points, and Frankfurt's DAX 30 index to 12,478.46 points. The gains were driven by mining and healthcare stocks. Meanwhile, US stocks reached fresh records despite ongoing trade uncertainty, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq indices edging higher.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall as financials drag
summary: Australian shares fell 0.1% on Tuesday, snapping a seven-day winning streak, as financial stocks declined after banks' quarterly earnings missed expectations. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,950.4, with ANZ and other 'Big Four' banks falling between 0.2% and 3.5%. The central bank held interest rates steady at 1.5% for a ninth consecutive month, aiming to balance inflation and wages growth. Investors await National Bank of Australia's half-year results on May 4.

site_title: Home Capital former investor is mulling contagion odds
summary: A former investor of Home Capital Group Inc is reconsidering the possibility of a financial contagion spreading across Canada's strong financial system. Despite concerns over the alternative-mortgage lender's struggles, former Mawer Investment Management Ltd chief investment officer Jim Hall believes the odds of a wider crisis are "unlikely, but possible." Home Capital secured a C$2 billion credit line and is considering a sale, and Canada's banking regulator closely monitors the situation. Hall notes that Canada's financial system has fire breaks to prevent problems from spreading, with well-capitalized banks and a robust regulatory framework.

site_title: Mineral-rich area of Papua New Guinea lifts decades-old ban on new mining
summary: Papua New Guinea's autonomous Bogainville region has lifted a 40-year-old ban on new mining, allowing iron ore and copper operations. The ban was imposed due to concerns over revenue-sharing and environmental impact. Global mining giant Rio Tinto has relinquished ownership of the Panguna copper mine, which will not be included in the new mining activities. The move aims to promote economic development in the region, with the government seeking applications from genuine investors.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines reaches settlement with family over MH17
summary: Malaysia Airlines has reached a settlement with an Australian family who lost four family members on Flight MH17 in 2014. The airline announced an amicable and confidential settlement with the Maslin family, allowing them to withdraw their lawsuit. This settlement is part of a "substantial number" of next-of-kin who have reached agreements with the airline. The Dutch-led investigation concluded that a BUK missile was fired from Russia, but did not determine who pulled the trigger, leading to ongoing disputes over liability.

site_title: At least six killed in South Korea crane accident
summary: At least six Samsung workers were killed in a shipyard crane accident in Geoje, South Korea, on Monday. The incident occurred when two cranes collided, causing a 60m, 32-tonne crane section to break and crash onto a workers' rest area. Twenty-five others were injured in the chaotic scene. The accident is the latest blow to Samsung Heavy Industries, which is currently on trial for bribery. The Total project, worth $500 million, may be delayed due to the incident, and 12 crane drivers are under investigation for potential operational mistakes or safety violations.

site_title: China's capital controls to hamper yuan internationalisation: Fitch
summary: China's capital controls are expected to hinder the internationalisation of the yuan, according to Fitch Ratings. Tightening controls on capital outflows and concerns over currency depreciation have led to a decline in yuan-denominated international payments, from 2% in 2016 to 1.8% in March 2017. While gradual increases in yuan holdings by reserve managers could support China's rating profile, the yuan's long-term potential as a reserve currency remains uncertain due to investor concerns about medium-term financial stability.

site_title: North Korea says US bomber flights push peninsula to brink of nuclear war
summary: North Korea accused the US of pushing the Korean peninsula to the brink of nuclear war after two B-1B Lancer bombers flew over the area in a training drill with South Korea. The US President Donald Trump said he would be open to meeting North Korean leader Kim Jong Un in the right circumstances, despite Pyongyang's continued pursuit of nuclear tests. Tensions remain high, with North Korea conducting military parades and live-fire drills, and the US maintaining an aircraft carrier strike group in the area.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall, ANZ drags financials lower
summary: Australian shares fell 0.6% on Tuesday, snapping their longest winning streak since July 2016, due to ANZ Bank's earnings miss and anticipation of the Reserve Bank of Australia's policy decision. The financial index lost 1.4% after seven sessions of gains, with other "Big 4" banks also declining. US President Trump's comments on breaking up big banks had little effect on US stocks.

site_title: UK builder Bovis takes £2.8m hit from failed merger talks
summary: British housebuilder Bovis will take a £2.8 million hit due to failed merger talks with Galliford Try and Redrow. The company warned on profits last year after failing to meet building expectations, prompting its CEO to quit. Bovis has hired former Galliford chief Greg Fitzgerald, and shareholders will vote on his pay during the annual general meeting. The company's sales are currently in line with reduced building expectations.

site_title: Asia: Stocks climb as yen weakens, China reopens
summary: Asian stocks rose as the yen weakened for a fourth day, with South Korea leading gains. The Nasdaq Composite Index reached an all-time high in the US, and the Australian dollar extended its gains ahead of the Reserve Bank of Australia's policy decision. Copper rose, while oil traded near a one-month low. Markets are awaiting China data, the US monthly jobs report, and the French presidential election.

site_title: Australia central bank holds rates at 1.5%
summary: Australia's central bank held its cash rate at 1.5% on Tuesday, as widely expected. The Reserve Bank of Australia made the announcement following its monthly policy meeting. Economists had predicted a steady outcome, with all 71 economists in a Reuters poll expecting a steady rate. The decision reflects the bank's steady outlook for the year ahead.

site_title: Singapore shares open 14.9 points higher on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 14.89 points to 3,190.33 on Tuesday, driven by Wall Street's gains on Monday. About 90.8 million shares changed hands, averaging S$1.29 per share.

site_title: Twitter says it would love world leaders to use it like Trump
summary: Twitter's chief operating officer, Anthony Noto, stated that the company would love world leaders to use the platform like US President Donald Trump, as it would make it easier to deliver on its mission to show what's happening in the world. Noto expressed a desire for every world leader to use Twitter as their primary mechanism to communicate with their constituents, which would help the company better serve its users.

images.alt_text: Twitter Inc won't attribute a bump in activity on its platform to US President Donald Trump's prolific usage. But the president's tweets certainly put the company in the spotlight, chief operating officer Anthony Noto said.

site_title: Trump to speak with Putin on Tuesday
summary: US President Donald Trump will speak with Russian President Vladimir Putin by telephone on Tuesday, marking the third call between the two leaders since Trump took office. The call's topics are unclear. Trump previously discussed defeating the Islamic State and pledged support for Russia following a metro bombing in Saint Petersburg. The conversation comes amid scrutiny of US ties with Russia, with investigations into potential links between Trump's campaign and the Russian government.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.020 points to 1769.160 on Tuesday, with 255 gainers and 92 losers. The index saw a slight increase in volume, worth RM97.96 million, following a global stocks rally.

site_title: Soccer-Euro 2024 bidders told human rights of 'utmost importance'
summary: Uefa has stated that human rights and labour rights are of utmost importance for Euro 2024 hosting candidates Germany and Turkey. The European soccer body has introduced specific articles in the bidding requirements, based on United Nations principles on business and human rights and other UN conventions. Germany and Turkey have been given detailed explanations of the requirements and have until April 2018 to submit their bid dossiers. Uefa will choose the hosts in September 2018, with the tournament to take place in 2024. This move aims to ensure compliance with anti-corruption measures and protect human rights.

site_title: Jack Ma-backed fund, Temasek Invest in Genomics Business
summary: A fund backed by Jack Ma and Temasek Holdings invested US$75 million in WuXi NextCODE, a contract genomics organization expanding in China's precision medicine market. WuXi NextCODE offers genetic tests for rare conditions and inherited diseases. The investment round also included Amgen Ventures and 3W Partners. This investment is part of China's push into precision medicine, with WuXi NextCODE expanding its offices in Shanghai, Reykjavik, and Cambridge, Massachusetts.

site_title: Aussie lifted as RBA stands pat, NZ dollar dragged higher
summary: The Australian dollar rose to a one-month high of 84.26 against the yen due to the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) keeping interest rates unchanged at 1.5%, and a more optimistic outlook for global growth. The RBA's neutral stance and reference to low wage growth limited upside for the Aussie. The New Zealand dollar also rose 0.2% against the yen, supported by broad yen weakness, and against the US dollar, reaching a three-week high of US$0.6925.

site_title: Greece reaches preliminary deal with creditors: minister
summary: Greece has reached a preliminary deal with its creditors, paving the way for debt relief talks, according to Finance Minister Euclid Tsakalotos. The agreement, set to be approved by eurozone finance ministers on May 22, is crucial for Greece to secure debt relief measures and avoid a default. A compromise is needed to unlock a $10.6 billion loan tranche for debt repayments in July. The deal is seen as a significant step towards Greece's economic recovery.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rise as TSMC, Hon Hai jump; index on track to hit 10,000-mark
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 0.7% to 9,942.14, on track to hit the 10,000-point milestone, driven by gains in TSMC and Hon Hai Precision. TSMC jumped 2% and Hon Hai rose 1% as investors became more optimistic about the technology industry. The easing of concerns over North Korea also contributed to the rally. The electronics subindex rose 1% and the financials subindex gained 0.8%.

site_title: CCT divests One George Street for S$1.18b into limited liability partnership
summary: Capitaland Commercial Trust (CCT) sold One George Street for S$1.18 billion to a limited liability partnership, with CCT owning 50% of the joint venture. The sale price translates to S$2,650 per square foot, 16.7% above the property's valuation. CCT expects a S$79.7 million net gain from the divestment. One George Street is a 23-storey Grade A office building located near Raffles Place and Chinatown MRT stations.

site_title: Fed set to leave interest rates unchanged, may hint at June hike
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to hold interest rates steady at its meeting this week, with some policymakers hinting at a potential increase in June. Fed Chair Janet Yellen will not hold a press conference, and most policymakers have expressed confidence in their forecast of two more rate increases this year. The decision will be released on Wednesday, and economists expect the Fed to wait for more economic data before making a final decision.

site_title: Addvalue Technologies raises S$13.1m from share placement, convertible loan
summary: Addvalue Technologies has raised S$13.1 million through share placements and convertible debt to commercialize its inter-satellite data relay system services. The funds will also be used to grow in the fishery industry vessel market. This move is part of the company's efforts to expand its services in the mobile satellite communications sector.

site_title: Singapore Airlines may land unfamiliar net-debt spot as soon as 2018
summary: Singapore Airlines may land in an unfamiliar net-debt position as early as 2018, marking the first time in 13 years. The airline plans to borrow money and sell bonds to meet capital expenditure needs, aiming to improve return ratios and valuations. Analysts say this move will benefit shareholders, as a company that can borrow cheaply can have higher leverage, leading to better prospects. Singapore Air's net debt may reach approximately S$660 million by March 2018, with a five-year average return on equity below that of Cathay Pacific Airways.

site_title: Hollywood writers talks resume as strike deadline looms
summary: Hollywood writers and the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers resumed contract talks on Monday, aiming to stave off a potential strike. The 9,000-member Writers Guild of America (WGA) and the AMPTP negotiated over issues such as earnings, royalties, and health plan funding. Despite some progress, the talks remained inconclusive, with a midnight deadline looming. If no agreement is reached, the WGA may call for a strike, potentially affecting late-night talk shows and daytime soap operas. The last WGA strike lasted 100 days in 2007/8, with estimated economic losses of $2.1 billion.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.17% and the Topix index increasing 0.23%. The gains were attributed to yen weakness in quiet trading ahead of a string of holidays in Japan.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sabana Reit, First Ship Lease Trust, Noble Group
summary: Sabana Reit's unitholders voted against removing the underperforming Reit manager, keeping the trust intact. First Ship Lease Trust secured a US$20 million loan from Navios Maritime Holdings. Noble Group passed a share consolidation resolution, despite some shareholders' protest. The Singapore Stock Exchange (STI) rallied 0.4% on Thursday, driven by investor positivity despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks bounce back to 6-yr high on upbeat exports
summary: South Korea's stocks rose to a six-year high on May 2, 2017, driven by a faster-than-expected increase in April exports. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) gained 0.9% to 2,226.18 points, with optimism surrounding the economy's potential pick-up after the presidential election on May 9. This marked the highest level since April 27, 2011.

site_title: Hot stocks: Local bank stocks climb amid results
summary: Local bank stocks, including UOB, DBS, and OCBC, rose on Tuesday after two of them reported quarterly results, with UOB climbing 3.3% and beating analyst expectations with a 5.4% net profit increase. DBS and OCBC also saw significant gains, with DBS rising 2.2% and OCBC increasing 1.8%. The results followed UOB's release last week, which saw its shares rise 71 Singapore cents to S$22.51.

site_title: South Korea April inflation slows, but still near central bank target
summary: South Korea's annual inflation eased to 1.9% in April, slightly below forecast, due to falling utility and fresh food costs. Despite this, prices are still near the central bank's 2% target. The economy is expected to continue its recovery, with exports growing due to a global economic boost. The Bank of Korea is unlikely to raise interest rates in the near term, with analysts expecting the base rate to remain at 1.25% this year. The central bank's next review is scheduled for May 25.

site_title: Vard to build research expedition ship for Norway industrialist
summary: Vard Holdings has won a contract to design and build a research expedition vessel for a Norwegian industrialist. The 182-meter-long ship will monitor and survey marine life globally, surpassing Vard's previous record. The vessel is expected to enter service in 2020, marking a significant milestone for the company.

site_title: Canada minister urged to resign for inflating military record
summary: Canada's defence minister, Harjit Sajjan, faced criticism for overstating his role in a 2006 military operation in Afghanistan, known as Operation Medusa. Sajjan claimed to be the "architect" of the operation, which resulted in a dozen Canadian and 14 British soldier deaths. Opposition leaders called for Sajjan to resign or be sacked, with some labeling the claim a "whopper" of a lie. Prime Minister Justin Trudeau stood by Sajjan, stating he acknowledged the mistake and apologized, but Sajjan wishes to retract the inflated claims.

site_title: China Kangda Food's chairman and others rid 69.18% stake at HK$1.34/shr
summary: China Kangda Food Company has agreed to sell 69.18% of its shares, valued at HK$401.35 million, to China Tian Yuan Manganese for HK$1.34 per share. The sale represents a 44.63% discount to the closing price on April 21, 2017. The six shareholders selling the shares include China Kangda Food's chairman, Gao Sishi, and other executives. The deal values the company at HK$580.15 million and will maintain its listing status on both Hong Kong and Singapore stock exchanges.

site_title: Australia's red hot housing market shows first signs of slowing
summary: Australia's housing market showed signs of slowing in April, with home values increasing at their slowest pace in 16 months, rising 0.1% from March. This follows the tightening of lending restrictions amid concerns of a housing bubble. However, it's too early to call a peak, with CoreLogic's head of research Tim Lawless stating it's just one month of "soft results". Prices in Sydney remain 16% higher than last year, while other capital cities may also show similar growth.

site_title: Thaad missile defence system now operational in South Korea
summary: The Terminal High Altitude Area Defence (Thaad) missile defence system is now operational in South Korea, following a US-South Korea agreement in July 2017. The system, which has angered China, has reached initial intercept capability. The deployment was made in response to North Korea's missile tests. The Thaad battery is the first of four planned locations in South Korea.

site_title: ANZ Bank interim profit rises on restructure
summary: ANZ Bank reported a 6% rise in interim net profit to A$2.91 billion for the six months to March 31, driven by a restructuring focus on core assets and a 23% spike in cash profit to A$3.41 billion. The result was slightly below expectations, with the lender maintaining its dividend payout at 80 cents. The bank's shift away from Asia and onto core assets aims to improve profitability.

site_title: Trump priorities left out of US spending deal
summary: US President Donald Trump expressed satisfaction with a bipartisan deal to fund the government through September, despite several of his top priorities being left out, including funding for a border wall. The agreement includes increased military spending and added funding for border security operations, but rejects Trump's demand for a wall and maintains spending levels for key government operations. The bill provides $1.163 trillion in federal spending and is expected to pass the House this week with Democratic support.

site_title: GM says will be first to profit from electric cars
summary: General Motors is poised to become the first manufacturer to profit from electric vehicles, according to Mark Reuss, GM's executive vice-president for product development. The company aims to reduce the cost of electric vehicles through mass reduction and battery efficiency improvements. GM plans to introduce multiple electric models in China by 2020, including a plug-in Cadillac CT6 and Buick extended range electric vehicle. The company's electric vehicles will also serve as a platform for its autonomous vehicle efforts, potentially lowering battery costs through fleet deployment.

site_title: Fox News co-president Shine resigns as harassment scandal rumbles on
summary: Bill Shine, co-president of Fox News Channel, has resigned amid a sexual misconduct scandal at the cable network. Shine, who has been with the company over 20 years, was named in multiple lawsuits and blamed for not preventing the misconduct. His departure follows that of former CEO Roger Ailes and top-rated news host Bill O'Reilly, as well as the departure of anchor Megyn Kelly. Shine's role remains open, but it is unclear if Fox will fill it. The company has promoted several veterans, including Suzanne Scott and Jay Wallace, to key positions.

site_title: Manulife US Reit posts 1.65 US cent Q1 DPU; gross revenue below projection
summary: Manulife US Real Estate Investment Trust posted a Q1 DPU of 1.65 US cents, exceeding projections. Gross revenue was 1.3% lower than expected at US$19.8 million, while net property income rose 2.7% to US$12.8 million. DPU was 7.3% higher than forecast at US$10.4 million. No distribution was declared for the quarter, and future distributions will be made semi-annually.

images.alt_text: Office landlord Manulife US Real Estate Investment Trust's (Reit) fiscal first-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) came in at 1.65 US cents, up from a projected 1.52 US cents, it said in a Singapore Exchange filing on Tuesday morning.

site_title: Twitter, Bloomberg team up for streaming news channel
summary: Twitter is launching a 24-hour streaming news channel in partnership with Bloomberg Media, combining Twitter's digital power with Bloomberg's global editorial and newsgathering capabilities. The new channel, set to launch later this year, will feature user-generated content verified by Bloomberg editors and live video reporting from Bloomberg journalists. The move aims to reinvent the digital breaking news experience and expand Twitter's appeal beyond its core user base. Twitter shares jumped 6.4% on the news, and financial details of the new venture were not disclosed.

site_title: NTUC raises S$25m for education, training fund
summary: The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) in Singapore has raised S$25 million for its Education and Training Fund, exceeding the government's 3:1 matching and bringing the total to S$100 million, half its original target. This fund aims to help workers upgrade and acquire new skills.

site_title: Sydney Airport Holdings declines to develop city's second major airport
summary: Sydney Airport Holdings has declined to develop a proposed A$5 billion second major airport in the city's west, potentially ending its monopoly status within a decade. The decision, made due to unfavorable terms, clears the way for the Australian government to build the airport itself or offer it to other groups, such as pension funds and infrastructure funds. The new airport aims to boost inbound air passenger numbers to Sydney by about a quarter, or 10 million people per year, by 2026.

images.alt_text: Sydney Airport Holdings on Tuesday said it would not take up its rights to develop a A$5 billion (S$5.26 billion) second major airport in the city's west.

site_title: UK needs more small housebuilders to fix 'broken' market: report
summary: A UK parliamentary committee warns that Britain's housing market is "broken" due to the dominance of large housebuilders, with over half of new homes built by the eight largest firms. The committee recommends supporting smaller builders to increase construction rates and making land available in smaller portions to allow them to secure space. The report states that around 190,000 net additional homes were built in 2015-16, but charities believe this figure is too low to meet demand. The committee aims to end the reliance on commercial providers and encourage more competition in the market.

site_title: Sony shares hit 22-month high as analysts predict record profit
summary: Sony shares reached a 22-month high after the company forecasted a record profit of 500 billion yen for the fiscal year through March 2018. Analysts from Goldman Sachs and Jefferies predict Sony could surpass its previous record profit of 525.7 billion yen in 1998. The company's gaming division is expected to drive growth, with operating profit projected to reach 170 billion yen. Sony's chip division is also expected to see strong growth, reversing a loss, thanks to the increasing adoption of multiple image sensors in phones.

site_title: Oil slips 1% as rising output faces weak demand worries
summary: Oil prices dropped 1% on Monday as rising crude output in Libya and the US countered OPEC-led production cuts, while weak demand expectations weighed on the market. Global benchmark Brent crude fell 53 cents to $51.52 a barrel, and US crude dropped 49 cents to $48.84 a barrel. Slower-than-expected growth in manufacturing in China and weaker US manufacturing sentiment also contributed to the decline.

site_title: US dollar hits 1-month high vs yen as US yields rise on Mnuchin comments
summary: The US dollar reached a one-month high against the yen, trading at 111.800 yen, following Treasury yields' surge after US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin commented on ultra-long-term bond issuance. The dollar's gain was boosted by long-term Treasury yields rising above 2.3% and despite downbeat US data, including slowed factory activity and unchanged consumer spending. The euro held firm against the US dollar, while the Australian dollar rose due to a bounce in iron ore prices.

images.alt_text: The US dollar hit a one-month high against the yen on Tuesday, lifted by Treasury yields which surged after US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin commented on the possibility of ultra long-term bond issuance.

site_title: Bombardier rejects Boeing trade complaint
summary: Bombardier Inc rejected Boeing Co's claim that it sold jets below cost to gain market share in the US, amid increasing trade tensions. Boeing alleged that Bombardier sold a CSeries jet to Delta Air Lines for $19.6 million, significantly below its $33 million production cost. Bombardier spokesman described the claim as "absurd." The US Commerce Department could investigate, but the process typically takes a year, and Bombardier has rejected Boeing's accusations, citing the use of US parts and thousands of US jobs generated by the CSeries.

site_title: Paring Fed's big bond holdings may be messier than Yellen hopes
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen aims to shrink the central bank's $4.5 trillion balance sheet in an "orderly and predictable way." However, the economic impact, pace, and ultimate end point are uncertain and influenced by external factors. The Fed's balance-sheet strategy may lead to tumultuous financial markets and the economy. Policymakers will discuss the plan at the FOMC meeting, and the Treasury Department's response to the Fed's reduction of its US$2.5 trillion portfolio of US government securities is uncertain, potentially affecting interest rates and the housing market.

site_title: US issues travel alert for Europe, citing threat of terrorist attacks
summary: The US State Department issued a travel alert for Europe, citing a continued threat of terrorist attacks. The alert, which expires on September 1, was prompted by recent incidents in France, Russia, Sweden, and the UK, and notes that Islamic State and al Qaeda have the ability to plan and execute attacks. The alert was not triggered by a specific threat, but rather a recognition of the ongoing risk of attacks ahead of the summer holidays.

site_title: China's appetite for fish pushes world's supplies to the brink
summary: China's overfishing has led to depleted global fish supplies, with Chinese firms exploiting waters elsewhere. Fishermen in Senegal and other countries report nearly empty nets, as China's appetite for seafood pushes the world's resources to the brink. This is partly due to government-subsidized fishing firms that prioritize profit over sustainability. The depletion of global fish stocks has severe economic and environmental consequences, highlighting the need for more sustainable fishing practices.

site_title: DBS Q1 net profit up 1% from a year ago
summary: DBS Group Holdings reported a record net profit of S$1.21 billion for the first quarter of 2017, a 1% increase from the previous year. CEO Piyush Gupta attributed the growth to sustained business momentum and productivity gains, which offset lower net interest margins. Net interest income remained unchanged, while net fee income rose 16% due to increased wealth management fees. Total income rose 1% to S$2.89 billion, with allowance coverage of non-performing assets at 103%.

site_title: Brexit puts tiny German village at centre of euroverse
summary: The European Union's withdrawal from the UK, known as Brexit, has drawn attention to the small German village of Gadheim, which is at the centre of the EU's relocation efforts. The village, located in Bavaria's wine country, has been selected as a potential site for a new EU headquarters due to its remote location and minimal impact on the environment. The move aims to minimize the EU's carbon footprint and reduce its reliance on traditional office spaces. The EU is expected to make a final decision on the location in the coming months.

site_title: Consumer spending stalls in March for second month
summary: US consumer spending stalled in March for the second month, with purchases remaining little changed from their prior months. Analysts expect spending to bounce back due to rising income growth and a steady job market. Inflation slowed to below the Federal Reserve's target, and disposable income increased 0.5% in March after adjusting for inflation. The saving rate increased to 5.9% from 5.7% in February, and the personal spending report showed the price index tied to consumer purchases fell 0.2% in March.

site_title: UK can no longer rely on US leadership over Middle East: lawmakers
summary: Britain can no longer rely on US leadership on Middle East policy, according to a committee of lawmakers. The report calls for closer collaboration with Europe to maintain the Iran nuclear deal and other policies. The US has launched a review of lifting sanctions on Iran, which Trump called "the worst deal ever negotiated." The UK must adapt to a changing global landscape and work with Europe to ensure its interests are protected.

site_title: Fox, Blackstone seen teaming up to make competing bid for Tribune Media
summary: TWENTY-FIRST Century Fox Inc is teaming up with Blackstone Group LP to make an all-cash bid to acquire Tribune Media Co, rivaling Sinclair Broadcast Group Inc's planned bid. The joint venture would be funded by Blackstone and would include Fox's TV stations. The deal is in talks ahead of a deadline this week. A combined Tribune and Sinclair would give Sinclair a stronger negotiating hand with Fox over cable provider fees. Fox must consent to transfer of Tribune's affiliate agreements to a new owner.

site_title: Australia home prices stall in April
summary: Australia's home prices stalled in April, with a 0.1% month-on-month rise, the weakest since December 2015. This slowdown follows dramatic gains in Sydney and Melbourne in 2016 and early 2017. Annual growth slowed to 11.2%, from 12.9%, as regulators' efforts to cool the market appear to be working. If the trend continues, it could vindicate recent measures to curb speculation and protect consumers, banks, and the economy.

site_title: Uber marks four years in S'pore with 1m active riders
summary: Uber Singapore has celebrated its fourth anniversary with over 1 million active riders, marking 20% of the country's population. The ride-hailing service, which began operations in 2013, has grown from three employees to over 300 and has reduced average wait times to 3.4 minutes. Uber's success in Singapore is attributed to its smart innovation, government support, and collaboration with local businesses, including Netflix and Lazada. The company has not yet announced plans for flying taxis in Singapore, but expects to expand its services in South-east Asia.

site_title: US isolationism paving way for China expansion
summary: US President Donald Trump's withdrawal from international agreements, such as the Trans-Pacific Partnership, has created a power vacuum allowing China to expand its global influence in trade, climate change, and finance. China's overseas investments rose to $170.1 billion in 2016, surpassing the US in infrastructure projects and financing. China's ability to offer cheap loans and financing for infrastructure projects has made it a dominant player in global development, surpassing multilateral lenders like the Asian Development Bank. Trump's isolationism has given China a bigger role in setting global rules, which will further increase China's global influence.

site_title: Ridesharing faces more regulations as popularity increases
summary: Ridesharing services are expanding globally, with Asian countries strengthening regulations to address issues such as traffic congestion and safety concerns. In China, the government has introduced new laws to legalize ridesharing, while requiring drivers to pass a test and have a clean record. South-east Asian countries, including Indonesia and Thailand, have also implemented regulations to control the growth of ridesharing services. Despite concerns about competition with traditional taxi companies, many argue that ridesharing can improve safety and reliability, and provide more convenient services.

site_title: US$1 trillion bipartisan funding deal struck, US govt shutdown averted
summary: US negotiators reached a bipartisan deal on $1 trillion in federal funding, averting a government shutdown. The agreement includes $700 billion in spending and $300 billion in new revenue, meeting President Trump's military build-up goals. The full House and Senate must still approve the pact, which would be the first major legislation since Trump's presidency. The deal is seen as a significant step forward in Congress's efforts to address the country's budget issues.

site_title: Denmark, Finland woo Nordea as it plans to move HQ from Sweden
summary: Denmark and Finland are vying to attract Nordea Bank AB's headquarters from Sweden, citing the need for a more stable regulatory environment. Nordea's CEO, Casper von Koskull, has stated that the bank is likely to move unless Sweden relaxes its plans to increase banking fees. Denmark's Business Minister Brian Mikkelsen and Finland's Finance Minister Petteri Orpo are making efforts to entice Nordea to their countries, with Finland's offer potentially benefiting from being part of the eurozone's single supervisory mechanism. The decision is expected to be made by summer, with a potential impact on the Nordic region's financial landscape.

site_title: Facebook targets coordinated campaigns spreading fake news
summary: Facebook is taking steps to combat coordinated campaigns spreading fake news, following malicious tactics used during the US and French elections. The company is expanding its security focus to include "information operations" and is working to detect and remove coordinated accounts. These accounts often use real identities, create fake groups, and spread false information to manipulate public opinion. Facebook has improved its detection tools, taking down over 30,000 accounts in France last month. The company aims to protect users from being manipulated and deceive people through these coordinated campaigns.

site_title: South Korean exports surge for 6th straight month
summary: South Korea's exports surged 24.2% in April, marking the sixth consecutive month of growth, driven by robust demand for high-tech memory chips and a rebound in shipments to the US. The trade surplus with the US declined to $1.68 billion, easing concerns of protectionist measures. Economists predict the trend will continue, potentially easing currency manipulation concerns and reducing the trade surplus with the US below $20 billion this year.

site_title: Vacant apartments held for ransom in Spain
summary: In Barcelona, Spain, vacant apartments are being held for ransom by organized gangs that break into empty homes, change the locks, and sell the keys to squatters who demand money from the owners to leave. The gangs, who target properties left vacant after the 2008 property bubble collapse, charge owners around 1,000 euros to retrieve their property. Authorities are investigating these cases, and homeowners are being advised to install advanced security systems. The problem has led to a surge in demand for security solutions, with over 1,500 steel doors installed monthly across Spain.

site_title: Swee Keat named chairman of Future Economy Council
summary: Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat has been named chairman of the Future Economy Council, replacing Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam. The council aims to boost skills and innovation in Singapore, with a focus on tackling issues such as skills and productivity, and innovation and internationalization. Heng will work with other ministers to implement the council's recommendations, including industry transformation maps. The council's first meeting is expected soon to roll out the proposals.
